column2: OSLO, Norway, May 6 -- The problems of the world seem far away from Oslo, one of the most peaceful of settings for a conference of military allies.

WHAT would you estimate are the chances for a new, difficult, thoughtful and profound string quartet to capture the esteem of the critics and a large public, two major awards, a pack of performances by several different quartets, publication and a topnotch recording, all within hardly more than a year?

"I FELT as if I were lifted up by my armpits, and said to my dear companion, Now we mount, etc. At the same time I heard a noise from the top of the machine, as if it were going to burst; and I looked, but did not see anything.
RABAT, Morocco, May 6 -- West Germany signed an agreement here today establishing a wide program of economic and technical assistance to Morocco.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 -- Cornell rallied to defeat the Pennsylvania track team, 73 -- 67, today at Franklin Field. The Big Red mile-relay team won the final event by a wide margin and clinched the victory.
ST. LOUIS, May 6 (AP) -- The Cardinals scored four times in the sixth inning today and trounced the Chicago Cubs, 6 -- 1, behind the five-hit pitching of Ray Sadecki.

THE prediction, "the theatre is dying," has been afloat in the air, twelve months of the year, ever since the days of Sophocles. Yet the spring theatre columns are crammed with announcements of what seems like 800 projected offerings for the fall.

New York University, taking advantage of twelve errors by City College, won 15 -- 1, yesterday in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game at Macombs Dam Park, the Bronx. the Bronx. None of the game's runs was earned.

CALGARY, Alta, May 2 -- Nathan E. Tanner, a multimillionaire and a former provincial Minister of Mines and Minerals, has resigned all his company directorships to enter the full-time service of the Church of Jesus Christ of the Latter Day Saints (Mormon).

A SICILIAN invasion is on again -- only this time it is a group of film units that are taking posession of key island sites before the tourists follow suit. No fewer than three major productions are at work on the colorful Italian island, and several more are due in the near future.
The public international market for debt capital has two faces.
An artist's conception of what would be the nation's largest bulk ore carriers was made public last week by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

Retail sales in this area last week fell below the level of the year-ago period. Department stores placed the decline at 7 to 8 per cent. Merchants attributed the poor showing to the fact that Mother's Day falls a week later this year than last.
PITTSBURGH, May 6 -- Joe Gibbon beat Los Angeles for the second time this season as the Pittsburgh Pirates scored a 9-5 victory today over the Dodgers.

The brown thrasher is sometimes called a northern mockingbird, but some of us, especially on a song-filled May morning, wonder if the names shouldn't be turned the other way, if the mockingbird shouldn't be called a southern thrasher. That may be heresy in Dixie, but we don't see that the thrasher should take second place to anyone.
LOUISVILLE, May 6 -- They were thick and elaborately braided, like Wagnerian sopranos, but their legs were long and thin, like Suzy Parker's.
Sonya Monosoff, violinist, and Louise Rood, violist, played music composed for their instruments in combination in a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon.
A LEAKY faucet or valve is annoying; it adds dollars to the home owner's annual water bill. If the leak occurs in a hot water line, fuel is also being wasted.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Republican-Southern Democratic coalition in the House is still alive, according to some hardheaded Administration Democrats.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Alan Shepard's heavenly lob was not only the happiest homecoming since the prodigal son, but it points up the difference between our scientists and our statesmen.
ON our last vacation, my husband made a declaration as we were setting out.

EARLY readers who are still not too easy about all those new words they see ought to find relaxation and reassurance with Olaf. They will know just how that ebullient small boy came to mail a letter in a street basket because the sign said Put Litter Here.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, May 6 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan, received today a report drawn up by the commission that has been drafting a constitution for Pakistan.
At the age of 6, Deborah Cavaliere already has the habit of winning beauty contests.
HASTINGS ON HUDSON, N.Y. May 6 -- Two Westchester social agencies will be the beneficiaries of a music program that will be given here May 20 at Lovat, the home of lIr. and Mrs. Robert S. Carlson.

GROVER CITY, Wakefield County, Ky., resembles Peyton Place in that most of its inhabitants (and its chronicler) are obsessed by sex and motivated by little else. The 48-hour action of Carl Burton's novel includes a rape-murder, a couple of attempted rapes and a Lesbian episode; and the flashbacks manage to cover in detail almost anything sexual the main action omits.
WHITE PLAINS, May 6 -- The hottest contest for a county office in Westchester since 1957 is taking shape here.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., May 6 -- The nation's space agency plans to send a second astronaut on a 300-mile rocket flight, perhaps in six weeks. This would be part of its step-by-step build-up to a manned flight into orbit around the earth.
EVERY year in the spring thousands of college students decide they want to break into the theatre. But how?

General Taylor once discussed the "military mind" and made it sound like a virtue. Expressing gratification that soldiers at least were conceded to have minds, he added, "Personally, I have never been aroused by the charge of possessing a professional mind.

EXPERIENCED writers for young people, this husband-and-wife team offers a clear, interesting, well-organized and quite thorough account of archaeology in the two American continents. They blend the history of the science itself and some of the major discoveries and explorations with a little of what can be told about the many vanished peoples themselves.

IN that special world populated by nerveless men and hurtling race cars, Stirling Moss is accorded by his peers a country all his own. Though only 30 years old, Moss has been driving race cars for fourteen years, longer than any of the others. A few of the men he started with just after the war have retired.
A full portrait of the seven ages of man is being drawn with the help of the National Institutes of Health.

PENN YAN, N.Y. -- A century ago, on the eighteenth day of May, brave young men of this town went off to war. They were the Keuka Rifles, and there were seventyeight of them. They paraded, their arms were inspected, they attended farewell ceremonies at the Court House and then they marched to the depot to take the train to glory.

I am oppressed by the similarity between the trend of our international policy today and that of the Holy Alliances under Metternich after the fall of Napoleon in 1815. Frightened by the violence of the French Revolution, the victors over Napoleon united to suppress revolution wherever it raised its head, and to suppress liberal ideas as containing the seeds of basic changes in the still feudal structure of European society.
VIENNA, May 6 (UPI) -- Bulgaria has "vigorously protested" the alleged beating of two Bulgarian diplomats on a Washington street, the Bulgarian press agency BHT said today.
CHICAGO, May 6 -- Two psychologists have given books an edge over machines in teaching.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 6 -- Events of the last week in South Africa have been a source of increasing gloom among many persons here.
The distress flags are flying for boatmen who lack moorings for pleasure craft along the shores of the Hudson River and Long Island Sound north of New York City.

Re "$2,700 a Year or $70 a Year" (April 16), by B.K. Nehru, Indian Commissioner General for Economic Affairs, I agree that the developed nations should, move ahead as fast as they can, and they should also increase their foreign aid to the lesser-developed nations.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 6 -- With considerable fanfare, the United States took the first small step this week toward manned exporation of space.
ATHENS, Ga., May 6 -Robert F. Kennedy came into the South today to deliver a resolute speech on civil rights.
METUCHEN, N.J. -- Readers' objections to my article were mainly that:

A large number of Frenchmen are convinced that agents of the United States Central Intelligence Agency played a part in encouraging the recent mutiny by French generals and professional troop units in Algeria.

Expansion of commercial plants in the Chicago area announced during March included forty-nine projects with a total value placed at $21,741,000, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. February showed a total of $16,403,000 for thirty-nine projects and January $14,950,000 for sixty-four new plants.

WITH this short, murmurous first novel, Fernando Arrabal, a Spaniard still in his twenties, living in Paris and writing in French, commits himself to that group of experimental writers in France of whose existence as a school readers became aware five years or so ago. although at least one, Nathalie Sarraute was first published before the last war.

A cocktail party will be held Tuesday at the home of Mrs. Floyd B. Odlum (Jacqueline Cochran) in River House. Proceeds will go to the scholarship fund of the New York Chapter of Theta Sigma Phi, national sorority for women in journalism.
Another coveted lump of engraved hardware fell into strong Yale hands yesterday when its crew scored a surprise victory in a triangular regatta on the Harlem River.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) -- President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia was confined to bed today because of fatigue, chronic bronchitis and laryngitis, forcing him to cancel a trip to Tennessee and Texas.

Now that hearings have been held by committees of both House and Senate, there is no reason for further delay by Congress in passing the bills to establish new national seashore parks at Cape Cod, Padre Island in Texas and Point Reyes in California.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. -- The warmest winter in years has brought an early spring to Colorado's supernal uplands and the whole region teems with unseasonable daffodils, anemones, aphid moths and vacationing lowlanders.

"THE JUDGMENT" opens with a psychopathic hitchhiker molesting an alcoholic schizophrenic, and then murdering an insane old hermit who keeps a mouldering general store. The hitch-hiker is Lucifer Freeman, a young diabolist perennially on the lam.
ATHENS, Ga., May 6 -- Following is the text of Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy's address at Law Day exercises today at the University of Georgia Law School:

ROME -- The long Roman lunch hour, when shops, museums and galleries are closed, often robs precious hours from the tourist's vacuum-tight schedule. Yet, the three-hour period from 1 to 4 o'clock need not be written off as wasted time.

THIS blazing book is the story of the life and death of two ships of war -- the first capital ships ever to be sunk in war by airpower alone. There can be no question but that British writer Bernard Ash cares passionately about the sequence of events -- tragic, dramatic, evitable perhaps in part -- which brought Repulse and Prince of Wales to their deep-fathomed graves off the Malayan coast on Dec. 10, 1941.

A skipper preparing his yacht for the annual rite of going into commission can't avoid certain small sacrifices -- like lost week-ends. But fitting-out time must not be allowed to become sheer drudgery. There must be some fun, too.
MOSCOW, May 6 -- The Soviet Union decreed today that the death penalty may be applied to large-scale embezzlers of state property and to counterfeiters.

The Cruising Club of America measurement rule under which many distance yacht races are conducted has undergone a minor change that will be effective this year and a more drastic revision effective next year.
LOUISVILLE, May 6 -- Carry Back contributed a most thrilling performance in winning the eighty-seventh running of the Kentucky Derby today.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 4 -- The European trade split has begun to pinch.

Henry Steele Commager's suggestion that the intercollegiate athletic problem be solved by giving the game back to the students is most fitting although it is probably too bitter a pill for those concerned to swallow ("Give the Games Back to the Students," April 16.).

ATHENS, May 3 -- The bells of a hundred churches rang and women waved scarves from the quayside as the island of Kalymnos gave its traditional farewell last Sunday to the sponge-fishing fleet, which sailed on its annual expedition to the Barbary coast.

AILEEN FISHER'S newest book, like her "All on a Mountain Day," is the story of a plant and animal community on the eastern side of the Rocky Mountains and especially of two animals within this community -- a female beaver and a male pine squirrel.

There was a woman who lived in Poland and died there some years ago, and of her life and death only a few things are known. It is known that she was Jewish. This is known because testimony has been given at the trial of Adolf Eichmann in Jerusalem that she was murdered near the grave's edge in one of the Germans' massacres of Jews.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., May 6 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota said tonight that the United States should sponsor an "international space year" as a first move toward a treaty for the demilitarization of outer space.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- Out-of-state motorists driving through Florida on their spring and summer vacations this year will find highway construction activity buzzing on all sides, and returning visitors will discover many new stretches of road to make their highway travel speedier and more enjoyable.

MORE than 2,000 members of the National Association of Broadcasters will gather in Washington this week for the industry's "new frontier" convention. This year the assembly of electronic elite has been infused with new blood -- LeRoy Collins, president of the N.A.B., and Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

The Union Oil Company of California and associates may have brought in what could be a most important oil well in Australia. Important showings of oil and gas have been encountered in several producing zones to a depth of 12,000 feet.
GARRISON, N.Y., May 6 -Boscobel, the mansion with many lives, will be opened at 3 P.M., May 21. Governor Rockefeller will speak at the ceremonies.
The local premiere of the film, "The Young Savages," will be held as a benefit for the New York City Mission Society. The event will take place the evening of May 23 at the Murray Hill Theatre.
If spring comes, can door-to-door salesmen be far behind?
MEXICO CITY, May 5 -- Mexico appears to be making a fresh appraisal of its position in the dispute between the United States and Cuba.
The problem of neighboring cities and competing airports was highlighted last week by two simultaneous developments.

Unless the nation's schools begin to make drastic changes in their entire approach to education -- from curriculum to the use of teachers' and students' time -- they simply will not be ready for the demands made on them for the future.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Joseph L. Weiner is not a man who looks for easy assignments.

GENERAL BILLYCOCK had a terrible temper. When the black and rusty-red pigs with the long curly tails came -- and stayed -- snouting and rooting in his Tennessee fields, General Billycock actually became sick with rage.

High school seniors in hundreds of thousands of families are again waiting for the mailman to bring that crucial letter from the colleges "of their choice." For some students, who had high hopes based on outstanding performance, rejections may be more than disappointing; they often appear incomprehensible.

VENICE, Italy, May 6 -Queen Elizabeth II of Britain paid her first call today on this city, known as the Queen of the Adriatic. She came as a "tourist" -- and, incidentally, as a week-end bonus for thousands of tourists from other lands.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, May 6 -- The time has come for Malays to have family names, Malaya's Prime Minister, Tungku Abdul Rahman Putra bin Abdul Hamid Halimshah, said today.

MONTICELLO, N.Y. -- A trade exposition sponsored by the Sullivan County Hotel Association commences next Tuesday at the Monticello Raceway. The three-day show will be a final invitation to resort proprietors toward sprucing up for the busy fair-weather season that is expected, as usual, to go into high gear with the Decoration Day week-end.
POTEAU, Okla., May 6 (AP) -- A bright sun shone today on scenes of devastation and death in two Oklahoma communities struck last night by a brief tornado that spun out of a black sky.

"Biological clocks" is a term used by biologists to describe internal, autonomous timing mechanisms, believed to be possessed by most living things, that permit plants and animals of all shapes and sizes to behave as though they could tell time.

Camping can be fun, in spite of the unhappy views of recent correspondents from New Jersey. People who have really enjoyed camping usually make better preparations than these discouraged souls seem to have done.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 6 -- New York State's boat-safety courses for youngsters are being enthusiastically supported on Long Island. It's all voluntary, too. Ironically, the island's vast network of waterways was excluded from the provisions of the recently adopted State Navigation Law, which requires instruction for young boatmen.
BAYVILLE, L.I., May 6 -- Fordham University scored a sweep of the freshman and varsity races in the third annual North Shore intercollegiate rowing regatta today.
LOUISVILLE, May 6 (UPI) -- Johnny Sellers sponged his face in the jockeys' room at Churchill Downs today and allowed, "Carry Back and I get along pretty well together."
MINEOLA, L.I., May 6 -- A record number of boats is expected on Nassau County's waterways this season.

ATLANTIC CITY -- What is generically called "the Jersey Coast" is a strip of sand 125 miles long, extending 100 yards, and sometimes more, inland from the Atlantic breakers; and a medley of boardwalks, amusement places, games of chance, hotels, motels, bathing beaches, surf-fishing beaches, family cottages and occasional lonely stretches still reserved for the seagulls.

Eichmann's counsel seems to have made an impression on many people with his claim that a fair trial requires the Israeli Government to grant complete immunity to prospective witnesses for the defense. He has named as witnesses for whom immunity is sought, high-ranking SS officials, who themselves were convicted of war crimes and crimes against humanity, and former Nazi Government officials, also heavily involved.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 6 -- One of President Moise Tshombe's troubles this week was that he had no friends -- or almost none.

EAST BERLIN -- In the world of modern international tourism, East Germany is a relative newcomer. But the country has now launched a program to obtain its share of the international tourist trade, and this year for the first time, conducted bus tours are being offered to foreign visitors by DER, the state-run travel agency whose initials stand for Deutsches Reisebuero.

ETHIOPIA on April 15 issued an 80 cents stamp in blue, delineating its modern-design Africa Hall, which was dedicated by Emperor Haile Selassie last Feb. 9. An oval portrait of the Emperor appears in the upper right corner.

Retail trade in the Kansas City area showed a modest gain from a year ago in the first week of May. Widespread rains late in the period cut down the size of the increases, however. Department stores liberally promoted durable goods and this was reflected in the improved movement of major household appliances.

THE Venice Biennale of contemporary music, this year the first rather than one of the last of the European summer festivals, opened with a large bang, caused by the music of, and the public reaction to, Luigi Nono's stage work "Intoleranza 1960."
OTTAWA, May 6 -- A bill to give the Minister of Revenue arbitrary powers to increase certain tariffs on goods has been been blocked in the Senate.
DETROIT, May 6 (AP) -- A new health insurance program that features the doctor team approach has been started here with the support and blessing of the United Auto Workers Union.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6 -- Harvard, led by Mark Mullin, swept the first three places in the mile run today and easily defeated Dartmouth and Brown in a triangular track meet. Mullin won in 4 minutes 11.1 seconds.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 6 -- A 22-year-old amateur, Roger Ginsberg of New York, furnished the surprise in the William D. Richardson Memorial golf tourney today by gaining the semi-finals at the Seawane Club course.
The International Maritime Workers Union, a joint undertaking of the National Maritime Union and the Seafarers International Union, was formally dissolved last week.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) -- A Democratic Congressman accused the Air Force today of setting aside a fleet of 719 planes for high ranking officers and civilians. He said it was a "total and unnecessary waste."

ICELAND, with its small but diverse variety of bird species has attracted the attention of several prominent ornithologists during the past decade or so. For example, in the early Nineteen Fifties the English authors, Peter Scott and James Fisher, went there in search of the breeding grounds of the pink-footed goose and wrote a popular and informative book, "A Thousand Geese," about their expedition.

National Music Week, which begins today, was heralded locally with the annual concert in Town Hall yesterday afternoon in which students from the High School of Performing Arts are soloists with the National Music Week Symphony Orchestra.
Re "Promoting Pride in Achievement" (April 9) by Dorothy Barclay.

PATTERN as the predominant element in the decorating scheme -- a technique beloved by the Victorians -- is once again in current favor. As seen in the Long Island country home shown on these pages, it can produce a sophisticated, yet informal effect if judiciously played against a color range of white plus a few clear shades.

AMONG the truly creative figures in the art of the dance of our time, place high the name of Igor Moiseyev. Not since the golden days when the modern revolution swept through the field and restored an art in decay to human experience has anything so vital occurred as Moiseyev's return to fundamentals.

MIAMI, May 6 (UPI) -- A Cuban naval craft sank today after striking an unidentified object off western Cuba, monitored radio broadcasts said. All Cuban ships and planes in the zone were ordered "to sweep the seas clean of any ships."

NEW DELHI, May 6 -- Most of his aides had gone home long before Prime Minister Jawaharial Nehru left his office in Indian Foreign Ministry one evening this week. He walked slowly toward the small car in which he is usually driven about the capital.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 7 -- Strong southerly winds that whipped up whitecaps on the Severn River forced the cancellation of today's seventh annual Goes Trophy race among the varsity crews of Navy, Cornell and Syracuse.

LOS ANGELES, May 6 -- The Yankees tonight found themselves still baffled by the mystifying contours of Wrigley Field. Although they had been given to understand that this ancient park was a veritable paradise for long-ball sluggers, Ralph Houk's Bombers again could do no more than hit one home run.

JUNEAU, Alaska -- Airplanes and summer cruise ships long have provided the islands of southeast Alaska's scenic Inland Passage with their major supply of tourists. Now, however, the Alaskan Legislature has approved plans for a state-operated ferry line, which can attract hundreds of motorists to the Inland Passage by offering them an alternate route to the Alaska Highway.
A proposed change in handling passenger manifests is arousing considerable opposition among many steamship companies here.
ALGERIA, May 6 -- Andre Zeller, one of the fugitive former generals of the attempted mutiny in Algeria April 22, gave himself up today after ten days in hiding in Algiers.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -The United States Government has established a special "crisis center" in the State Department. Officials said the new group was designed to help the Secretary of State and the President get information and recommendations quickly in the face of fast-breaking world developments.
TRENTON, May 6 -- Voters in Jersey City, Camden and nineteen other municipalities will elect local officials Tuesday.
KANSAS CITY, May 6 (UPI) -- Steve Barber allowed the Athletics only five hits today in pitching the Baltimore Orioles to a 6-0 victory.

Marine insurance is a changing thing, said Drake H. Sparkman while discussing protection against the hazards to which pleasure boats are subject. He is the president of Sparkman Stephens, Inc., of New York, whose business includes such insurance.

"I HATE being a griper, especially about a pediatrician," a young mother told us recently. "I know these fellows are busy and harassed. But they should be easier to talk to. I don't know what it is about Jill's doctor.

NATHANIEL HICKS, the intelligent and successful editor in James Gould Cozzens' "Guard of Honor," observed that with most writers "what they wrote had to be, or had to be made to appear to be, exactly what they wanted to do at the moment," and that there were a "few who could and would write [well] anything" required of them.

The Mercury capsule in which Navy Commander Alan Shepard made the successful sub-orbital flight through the threshold of space was equipped with a unique periscope system that enabled the astronaut to view the earth below him, and to use what he saw to make measurements of his altitude, direction, and position in space.

NEW DELHI, India, May 5 -- The International Control Commission received instructions today to go to Laos as soon as possible. Its chairman, Samarendranath Sen of India, said part of the staff would probably leave by air tomorrow.

EVERY spring the Allison Gallery holds a show of paintings and prints by George Bellows, reminding us gratefully of his technical brilliance and of his poetic, rather than adventurous, talent. As in the past, the present exhibition covers the short yet prolific span (1906-24) of his productive years, beginning with precocious student work under Robert Henri and ending with his throbbingly romantic Woodstock landscapes.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y. -- Things are looking up here in Ulster County. Sam's Point, the highest elevation in the Shawangunk Range and one of the best vantage points in the state, is being spruced up in the hope that it will attract more tourists than in the past.
A campaign against unnecessary automobile - horn blowing was ordered yesterday by Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy.

MONTREAL, May 6 -- Canada's 111,000 nonoperating railway workers have won their wage demands, averting a nation-wide strike that would have tied up the Canadian National Railways and Canadian Pacific Railway on May 16.

IN the tomato the home gardener has a colorful, appetizing and nutritious fruit. The novelty varieties, available in a range of colors and sizes, will add an air of festivity to the salad bowl. Some of the smaller tomatoes are delicious barbecued.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) May 6 -- The trial of Adolf Eichmann has been a good thing for Israel, Moshe Sharett, former Premier and Foreign Minister, said tonight.

MIAMI BEACH -- This glittering Gold Coast resort may not have been the originator of the modified American plan, but it is easily its greatest exponent. The plan is the one under which a hotel guest, by paying an extra $3.50 or $4 a day, is entitled to two meals (breakfast or brunch and dinner).

A new method of long-distance radio communication that would use an orbiting belt of tiny pieces of wire high above the earth's surface to bounce radio signals from point to point will be tested soon.
The chief negotiator of the Liberal party has been conferring with Governor Rockefeller, Mayor Wagner and Senator Jacob J. Javits to plan the party's role in the forthcoming Mayoral election.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The State Department finally made public today its papers on the 1945 Potsdam conference. The two-volume 2,733-page compilation contained few surprises.
AMITYVILLE, L.I., May 6 -The search continued today for a 41-year-old pilot who took off from Zahn's Airport here last night and failed to return.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., May 6 -- Nearly 6,000 Regular Army officers and men have arrived at near-by Camp Drum to take part in Operation Mohawk Arrow, which begins tomorrow and will continue for a week.

DELRAY BEACH, Fla., May 6 -- Edward C. Potter of Delray Beach, formerly of New York, received the Marlboro Award today from Edward A. Turville of St. Petersburg, Fla., the first vice president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.
The demand for executives is on the rise and so are the costs of winnowing the applicants and finding the right men for the big jobs.

LIMA, Peru -- Callejon is the Spanish word for alley. One day's drive to the north of this coastal capital, in the Callejon de Huaylas, the word takes on spectacular connotations. There, in the "alley" between the Black and the White Cordilleras mountain ranges, flows the angry, powerful Santa River, which eventually empties into the Pacific after roaring through one of the steepest and narrowest gorges in the world.
Barnard College has announced a new field work program for students majoring in sociology, economics, government and psychology.

MONTREAL -- This city is looking forward to a gayer after-dark atmosphere. Recently approved legislation has liberalized the liquor dispensing laws and extended the hours during which night clubs may stay open.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 6 -- Fifteen Suffolk County libraries have asked the state Education Department to approve the creation of a county cooperative library system.

The drama-laden race into space began Oct. 4, 1957, with a Russian victory: Sputnik I. During the next three years Russia maintained the lead, shooting up huge payloads, hitting the moon, photographing its far side, blazing a path to Venus.

I HAD hoped that Mr. Longman really was going to attack those "Zeitgeist theories" in which, he says, "the producers of art with built-in non-art value have a lifetime investment." Instead, he revealed himself as just another Zeitgeister, objecting only to those who have not, according to him, correctly read the spirit of the times.

THIS is a challenging, provocative, controversial book about a series of campaigns in the Western Desert and the British generals who fought them. The image builders have been busy since the end of World War II.

Savings in New York State's 233 savings and loan associations rose $59,210,946 in March to $4,422,260,504, the Savings Association League of New York State reported last week. The increase was 12.7 per cent greater than the $6,679,161 in March, 1960.
MOSCOW, May 6 -- Premier Khrushchev congratulated President Kennedy today on the first American space flight and said it had "possibilities for the study of nature on behalf of progress."

LONDON, May 6 -- Recent experiments at the British radio astronomy station at Jodrell Bank in Cheshire have shown that all planets are one foot a mile farther from the earth than previously calculated.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 6 (AP) -- Project Mercury officials reported today that a faulty inverter on Comdr, Alan B. Shepard's Redstone booster rocket was discovered during a routine countt-down check and was replaced.

HEALDVILLE, Vt. -- The visitor to a Vermont country store often is treated to a piece of old-fashioned Montpelier cracker, topped by a generous portion of tangy Vermont cheese. Sometimes the visitor concludes that the store is entirely responsible for the superior taste.
VILLANOVA, Pa., May 6 (AP) -- Frank Budd of Villanova University tied the world record for the 100-yard dash today with a time of 9.3 seconds.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) -- The "Spanish swindle," complete with a beautiful daughter and $500,000 hidden in a trunk, is being perpetrated with increasing frequency, Postmaster General J. Edward Day warned today.

DESPITE some curtailment of schedules here and there, there will be train service during the coming vacation months from New York to most of the leading resort areas in the country. Notable exceptions are northern New England and the Catskills.

LONDON, May 6 -- The United States faces a critical situation in Western Europe. The harsh reality is that this essential bulwark of democracy, organized in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, is in a dangerous state of disarray.
One of the stranger developments of the present annual meeting season is the proxy fight that isn't a proxy fight.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla. -- Very slowly but surely, one of America's most colorful Indian tribes, the Seminoles, is turning to the white man's ways. Visitors to Florida may still spot an occasional Indian adhering to the age-old tribal customs, but the primitive way of life is disappearing as the motor car and the television set make greater inroads on the reservations.
Cash flowing in and cash flowing out made headlines the same day in two far-removed parts of the world last week.

The Liberal party, whose total official membership amounts to only 2.1 per cent of New York City's registered voters, is finding itself these days the center of a major political storm as the preliminaries for this year's municipal elections get underway.
Ocean-going ship traffic here last month declined in comparison with March and with that of April last year, the Maritime Association of the Port of New York reported last week.

THE temptation, in surveying the turmoil, is to say something pompously optimistic about the Republican party. Look at the excitement, at the spirited dialogue in progress about the party's future, at the robust and healthy struggle for power that is already begun.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 6 -- Secondary students who have been demanding an immediate rupture of Costa Rica's relations with Cuba decided today to end the strike they have carried out since Wednesday.

IN anticipation of the eventual arrival of the summer travel season, this section published on March 12 an article by Joseph F. Hannan, who reported on a motor-camping trip his family had taken last summer. His article was an attempt to warn other first-time campers who might be struck by the series of natural, automotive and financial catastrophes that pursued his family on their holiday trip.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 6 -- Gov. Otto Kerner has resolved to hold back until late in June an appropriation bill for state purchase and restoration of the historic Sangamon County Courthouse.

Two women leader spoke up yesterday against the death penalty for two youths from Puerto Rico now in the death house at Sing Sing. Their conviction for first-degree murder, carrying a mandatory sentence, is under review in the Court of Appeals.

Union pressmen on the major daily newspapers in the metropolitan area ratified a new two-year contract yesterday with the Publishers Association of New York City. The vote was 86 to 65.
