The business tide has turned, Charles H. Kellstadt, chairman of Sears, Roebuck Co., big retail and mail-order chain, told shareowners at the annual meeting here yesterday.
TRENTON, May 8 -- Voters in twenty-one New Jersey municipalities will elect local officials tomorrow.

RICHMOND, Va., May 8 (UPI) -- A Federal judge suggested today that the Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals be given the "opportunity" to decide whether the closure of Prince Edward County public schools to avoid integration had violated the Virginia Constitution.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 8 -- Authorities on the Soviet Union suggested today that it was probable total production had doubled in that country in the last decade.

Control of the Bogue Electric Manufacturing Company, Paterson, N.J., maker of ground support equipment for aircraft and of industrial electronic devices, has been acquired by an investment group headed by S.R. Williston Beane, member of the New York Stock Exchange.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 8 -- A seal of approval has been withheld from "Town Without Pity" by the movie industry's self-censoring organization unless changes are made in the film.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- A report from the National Science Foundation today said that the quality of Communist China's scientists and other professionals was low but still suitable for the country's condition and aims.

LONDON, May 8 -- The man who prefers to call himself Anthony Wedgwood Benn lost three rounds today in his battle to retain a seat in the House of Commons and to renounce his inherited title, Viscount Stansgate.
MINEOLA, L.I., May 8 -- Salary increases averaging more than $600 a year for Nassau County employes were proposed today by Joseph F. Carlino, the new county Republican leader.
GENEVA, May 8 -- Each side at the negotiations for a ban on nuclear testing appeared today to have settled down to waiting for the other to make a move.

MENTION Mother's Day and some people react violently. Like Valentine's Day, this commemorative occasion seems to evoke every emotion from nostalgia to ire. This column takes no sides on the question of whether it is pure commerce or sheer sentiment, except to point out that a few of the items des cribed below can qualify as gifts for a mother.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Treasury bill rates moved in opposite directions on today's sale of new issues. The ninety-one-day rate dropped while the 182-day rate rose slightly.
Have the ultra-exclusive East Side night club, El Morocco, and the proletarian Broadway dance hall, the Palladium, anything in common? Indeed they do -- La Pachanga.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Comdr. Alan Shepard had a triumph in Washington today because he revived the faith of a sad and disillusioned city.

Andrew and Virginia Stone, the husband-and-wife independ ent production team, will film "The Password Is Courage" in Europe this fall for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer release. The suspense comedy, based on a book and True magazine article by John Castle, deals with a British prisoner of war and his activities in outwitting the Nazis.
Following, in unofficial translation, is the text of an address yesterday in Paris by President de Gaulle, as made public here:

In the nearly forty years John Cashmore was in public life enormous changes have taken place in Brooklyn. As Borough President for the past twenty years he was responsible for a great many of them. Some of these will serve as monuments for many years to his tremendous interest and pride in the borough where he was born and where he lived all his life.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 8 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has congratulated the United States on the successful flight of a manned space rocket. He expressed the hope that the scientific knowledge acquired "may be used only for peaceful purposes."
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- After thirty-seven years in the House of Representatives, nearly half of them as Republican leader, Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts has chosen a new taks for himself.
Perry Como, noted for his relaxed approach to television will be replaced by filmed tension during his summer recess.

The choice of Dr. James R. Killian Jr. of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to head a permanent Presidential board that will monitor the Government's foreign intelligence activities insures that Mr. Kennedy will have the highest quality advice and assistance he needs in this field. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor had previously been appointed to head a group making a special study of the Central Intelligence Agency.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has urged Congress to reject pending proposals to suspend that agency's authority to approve consolidations, unifications or acquisitions of railroads until Dec. 31, 1962.
OLEAN, N.Y., May 8 (AP) A second member of the St. Bonaventure basketball team, Fred Crawford, has tuberculosis, his physician said today.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 8 -- John L. Lewis denied in court today that the United Mine Workers had ever tried to force coal operators out of business.

CINCINNATI, May 8 (AP) -- The American Red Cross has done a great deal to show the spiritual side of America to the world, Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, the Philippines Ambassador to the United States, said tonight.

THE new National League baseball team in our village received a name yesterday. It will be known as the New York Mets. Attending the cristening party was a rather odd assortment of godfathers. Among them were Rogers Hornsby, Babe Herman and Johnny Murphy. Because they will serve as scouts for the baseball baby, they talked enthusiastically about the trinkets they expect to bring as presents.

IN recent years Haydn has been regaining status as an operatic composer. Last night the enterprising troupe known as Actors' Opera contributed to Haydn's re-establishment in this branch of the repertory.
Mrs. Vivienne Nearing, a 34-year-old lawyer, pleaded guilty yesterday to perjury, a charge that sprang from her appearance on a rigged television quiz program, "Twenty-One."

Vince Martinez of Paterson took a split decision over Miguel Aguero, a newcomer from the Argentine, in the main ten-round middleweight bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night. To this observer, the decision seemed undeserved.
New York's new National League baseball team, commonly called the Mets, henceforth will be officially called the Mets. That was the nickname announced yesterday by the owners of the franchise.

A FIVE-SPOT was the entry that made a slam possible on today's deal, played in the Long Island Championships at Long Beach Sunday; but first there were certain problems in the interpretation of the bidding and the choice of an opening lead.

Management of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., won a victory yesterday at an annual stockholders' meeting that was a cross between a Donnybrook and a dress re hearsal for a courtroom trial. Management faces a real trial tomorrow. In State Supreme Court, dissident stockholders, headed by the Dal-Tran Service Company, will try to unseat it.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 8 (UPI) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy and two members of the White House Fine Arts Commission staff, toured the Winterthru Museum today to get background for her program of authenticating White House furnishings.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 (UPI) -- Joe Louis, the former heavyweight boxing champion, land George Katz figured prominently tonight among those seeking the job of managing Charles (Sonny) Liston. Liston is a leading contender for Floyd Patterson's heavyweight title.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 8 -- The Long Island Professional Golfers Association amateur-pro tournament at the Huntington Crescent Club today ended in a six-way tie for first place at 66. This necessitated a matching of cards for the three prizes.

The Esso Standard division of the Humble Oil and Refining Company announced yesterday an upward adjustment in gasoline prices throughout most of New York State. The advances range from one-tenth of a cent to 3.2 cents a gallon, and is effective today.

The sponsorship of two boys' bowling teams by the Bronx County Civic Association was a complete success this season. Plans call for an expansion of the program for next season, with backing from local merchants and other interested adults in much the same manner that Little League baseball teams are supported.

Mayor Wagner made known yesterday that he would seek from the Board of Eestimate Friday a special $2,000,000 appropriation to repair the thousands of potholes and other pavement breaks caused by the severe winter.
The Park Department expects reports today on the analysis of water in Van Cortlandt Park Lake in the Bronx, where the fish have been dying since Sunday.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 8 (AP) -- A Negro employe of the Congress on Racial Equality refused to leave a barber shop in a bus station today and was arrested for trespass.

TRENTON, May 8 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner withdrew his nomination of William Phillmore Wood as a State Superior Court judge today. However, in a compromise, he named Mr. Wood a judge on the Union County Court.
A smoky fire at the Manhattan approach to an East River subway tunnel disrupted service on the IRT Flushing line for five hours yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The National Association of Broadcasters is a study of puzzlement tonight: it does not know quite what to make of its new president, LeRoy Collins, former Governor of Florida.

JEAN ANOUILH'S "Becket" took to the road not so long ago, shortly before it was named a Tony award winner as the most distinguished play of the season. It returned last night to the Hudson Theatre to preen a bit and also, undoubtedly, in the hope of making capital at the box office.
Prices of United States Government securities and corporate bonds of gilt-edge rank declined slightly yesterday as the bond market carried over into the new week the relaxed mood of last Friday.

Record April bank clearings of $113,269,455,000 in the twenty-six leadings cities was reported yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Volume for April was 2.4 per cent higher than the $110,629,030,000 of April, 1960, but 13.8 per cent below the record $131,394,549,000 set in March.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 8 -- Most of Denmark's 200,000 farmers stopped deliveries today of beef, veal, pork, eggs and milk and other dairy products.
Columbia's baseball team scored three runs in the eighth inning and defeated Army, 4 -- 3, at Baker Field yesterday. The victory was the Lions' fifth in seven Eastern Intercollegiate League games.
OSLO, Norway, May 8 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the Communist threat to South Vietnam was potentially more serious than the deteriorating situation in Laos.
OSLO, Norway, May 8 -- The United States said today that it was prepared to resist any Soviet encroachment on the Western position in Berlin.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- LeRoy Collins, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, spoke at the organization's convention here today and outlined his views on "Where We Go from Here Together." When his speech ended, there was a question as to whether togetherness actually prevailed among the more than 2,000 broadcasters who had listened with keen interest to their new leader.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The nation's capital gave Comdr. Alan B. Shepard today the respectful welcome due a brave man who symbolized a proud national achievement.

Dr. Leo Mayer, chairman-elect of the Physicians Forum, Inc., an association of physicians, announced yesterday he would again head an independent slate in the May 22 election of the Medical Society of the County of New York. He will seek the office of chairman-elect.
Wider use of what the Government maintains is a faster system of steamship passenger documentation was forecast here yesterday by a top official of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
Dwight D. Eisenhower intends to make his voice heard on public issues as long as he has the strength and opportunity to do so, he says in a magazine article.

OMAHA, Neb., May 8 (AP) -- Fairmont Foods Company of Omaha will acquire 100 per cent control of Kas Foods, Inc., Kas Potato Chips, Inc., and Kas Potato Chip Company of Missouri through an exchange of common stock, E.D. Edquist, Fairmont president, announced today.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 8 -- When Sarah Lawrence College opened in 1928, its plans called for an experimental curriculum in the liberal arts that would stimulate and develop the particular talents and interests of the individual student.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 8 (UPI) -- A Federal grand jury indicted today a Canastota concern and three of its officers on sixty-four counts of fraud against the Government.

J. Truman Bidwell has been elected chairman of the Board of Governors of the New York Stock Exchange, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Bidwell, a member of the exchange since 1941, acts as an independent floor broker specializing in institutional business.

MONROVIA, Liberia, May 8 (AP) -- A conference of leaders of nineteen African independent nations opened today. The talks are aimed at seeking peace and understanding among the continent's restless millions.
PARIS, May 8 -- President de Gaulle offered the Moslem rebels' Provisional Government tonight a full political discussion of the future of an independent Algeria.
Teen-agers in the Girls Club of New York will put on "Happy Faces" for their benefactors May 17, when the youngsters stage their annual spring revue at their clubhouse, 312 East Thirtieth Street.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 8 -- At 81 years of age, Dr. Harry Willis Miller can look back on a half century of service as a medical missionary in the Far East.

Cardinal Spellman approved yesterday proposed legislation that would allow parochial and private schools to accept Federal funds for the construction of facilities to teach science, mathematics and foreign languages.
Special teams from the Board of Education yesterday began an intensive inspection of nine new schools to see if the building contracts had been fulfilled.

Giulio Rinaldi, the ring hero of Rome who will bid for Archie Moore's world light heavyweight championship here on June 10, arrived here yesterday morning aboard the Leonardo Da Vinci, the Italian Line flag ship.
TRENTON, May 8 -- The State Senate approved unanimously today a bill that would add a new Fifteenth Congressional District in New Jersey.

THE American men's wear industry has surrendered to the British again. By autumn, any man who gives two thoughts to his fashion rating will strive for an effect that might be defined as a composite of Rex Harrison, Prince Philip and Prime Minister Macmillan.
"YES, the world's a ship on its passage out, and not a voyage complete; and the pulpit is its prow," exclaimed Ishmael, the foremast pariah of "Moby Dick," in 1851.
A dispute between state and city agencies has arisen over jurisdiction in housing discrimination cases here.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 8 -- Probation services for Suffolk County's lower courts and the construction of four new police precinct buildings were approved today by the Board of Supervisors.

EVERY year in early spring a loud, discordant, clashing noise may be heard steadily in the woods, sometimes low, sometimes reaching hideous crescendos. It is the fly fisherman grinding his teeth in hopeless rage because he cannot catch trout with flies before trout start taking flies.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) -- Representative Adam Slayton Powell Jr., acting almost before the ink was dry on the new Minimum Wage Law, proposed today extending its benefits to 545,000 additional workers.

I think a great deal of our foreign aid cannot be justified, especially aid to the satellite countries. But I am amazed that it is being suggested that instead of annual contributions we should make long-term loans, even loans for fifty years, and some without interest.

Although banks have been broadening their advertising and promotion activities each year -- taking down the bars and extending a friendly hand, as it were -- bankers are keenly aware that much remains to be done.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., May 8 -- The Sleepy Hollow team of Fred Gronauer and Ben Halsey posted a net best-ball card of 32, 34 -- 66, five under par, today. It won the opening pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association season by two strokes at Briar Hall.
The Blue Hill Troupe will hold a spring dance at the Sheraton-East on Thursday for the benefit of Grosvenor Neighborhood House, Inc.
The Louisiana State Bond and Building Commission is planning the sale of $14,000,000 of public building revenue bonds on June 1. The obligations will come due serially from 1962 to 1986.
Fog forced a five-hour shutdown at New York International Airport yesterday morning and delayed ferry service and the arrival of two passenger ships.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 8 -- President Kennedy wished Harry S. Truman a happy seventy-seventh birthday today and told the former President that he didn't understand how he "can look so well after seven years in this job."
Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said yesterday that the United States needed stronger Government-business coordination to mobilize the nation's resources in the "cold war."

A large hole was poked through the 4-foot, 8-inch thick wall of the second basement of the Chase Manhattan Bank's new headquarters recently, but those responsible were members of the bank's trust department, and the "loot" -- $32,000,000,000 of securities -- was to be moved in, not out.

Savings in United States credit unions increased 11.5 per cent in 1960 to $4,944,593,818, the Credit Union National Association reported yesterday. Loans outstanding rose 16.8 per cent to $4,329,557,990; reserves increased 15.1 per cent to $267,340,766, and assets rose 11.6 per cent to $5,606,189,063.

Your April 27 editorial exhortation urging "clearer signs on buses, including the back and sides" of Manhattan's many motor coaches, merits the attention of both public and private operators. Unfortunately, the trend is in the direction of less clarity rather than more.

The city will appeal the part of a decision by Supreme Court Justice Irving Saypol that would permit the City Council to go ahead with its own approach to Charter revision, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.
I know of no subject about which there is more misconception than the arrangement between the United States and the Republic of Mexico to bring Mexican national farm workers into this country.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 8 -- The International Control Commission for Laos arrived today to take up the task of supervising and controlling the cease-fire that went into effect last Wednesday.

LOUISVILLE, May 8 -- Many a horse-player left this town last night with a suitcase of dirty laundry, a pocketful of losing tickets and a hangover. The Derby week-end had been long and loud. But today, after the fans had departed by the thousands, everything was quiet.

Net income of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing (3-M) Company and subsidiaries for the first quarter was $16,489,082, against $16,217,911 for the initial quarter last year. Sales and other operating revenue of the diversified concern rose to $139,680,358 from $128,669,218.

A SHARP change of pace for Sophia Loren from the generally slick and frivolous roles she has played during the last several years in American movies is most conspicuous and praiseworthy in her return to Italian films in "Two Women" ("La Ciociara"), which came to the Sutton yesterday.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), May 8 -- An urgent motion was presented to the Knesset (Parliament) tonight for debate of the government decision to grant immunity to two former members of the Nazi S.S. (Elite guard) if they wished to testify at the trial of Adolf Eichmann.
OSLO, Norway, May 8 -- More than 10,000 Norwegians cheered the North Atlantic Treaty Organization here tonight and angrily shouted down some Communist-led youths who tried to interrupt.

PEORIA, Ill., May 8 (AP) -- One of a group of electrical company executives fined and jailed for price fixing has been named president of the Letourneau-Westinghouse Company, builder of earth-moving machinery.
Four composers of film, theatre and television music presented some of their concert music last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
What a significant editorial regarding architecture and the arts was published on May 1! Most meaningful was your statement. "The problem actually goes far beyond that of a single building."

TOKYO, May 8 -- The United States' new Ambassador to Japan, responding apparently to growing sentiment here for improved trade relations with Peiping, condemned Communist China today as an "upsetting influence" on the peace of the world.

DETROIT, May 8 (AP) -- Sol A. Dann, a Detroit lawyer and a stockholder of the Chrysler Corporation, was told today by United States District Judge Theodore Levin to file a new complaint on his charges that Chrysler had violated Federal regulations in its proxy statements.
LUANDA, Angola, May 8 -- African terrorists renewed attacks today on some key points in northern Angola.
MIAMI, May 8 -- Maj. Ernesto Guevara, Minister of Industry, told Cubans tonight that their victory over the rebels who invaded April 17 had been a great defeat for imperialism.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 8 -- The nation's coat and suit industry will be sorely tried by the revolution in distribution now developing in the economy, Max E. Weinstock, chairman of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board, asserted here today.

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- The fourth successive setback in near soybean futures ran to 8 1/2 cents a bushel today and still showed no sign of having reached the end of the slide. At today's close, losses amounted to almost 30 cents a bushel since last week's high.

A 30,000-word novella by Malcolm Lowry, possibly the last work by the blazing and troubled novelist who died in England in 1957, is secreted away in the new issue of "New World writing 18".* Called "The Forest Path to the Spring," it grew out of one of the most primitive human activities: fetching drinking water. The subject has en gaged literary giants preoccupied with social reform from Ibsen to Silone.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 8 (AP) -- Jeep-driving "Dr. Mary" of Tompkins County was named today by the State Medical Society as the outstanding general practitioner of 1961.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 8 (AP) -- The election of seven young scientists and scholars as junior fellows of Harvard University's Society of Fellows was announced today by Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, university president.

Oppenheimer Co., stock brokerage concern and sponsor of the Oppenheimer Fund, has leased three floors in the twenty-four-story building nearing completion at 66 Beaver Street, at the corner of Hanover Square.
Tom Jones and Harvey Schmidt, who won a lot of respect for their off-Broadway musical, "The Fantasticks," are working on their first Broadway venture -- also a musical.

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- Thunderstorms dumped more rain on the Mississippi, Missouri and Ohio River basins today as the fourth straight day of turbulent weather pushed the storm damage and death toll still higher.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Budget Director David E. Bell indicated to Congress today that the Federal books were likely to be more out of balance next year than had been officially estimated.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- President Kennedy warned today that a determined and powerful Communist system would subject the rest of the world to many tests of nerve in the coming years in Berlin, Asia, the Middle East and the Western Hemisphere.

The Immigration and Naturalization Service has moved to bar Richard Gibson, acting national executive secretary of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee, from leaving the country. The Fair Play group favors the regime of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.

An 18-year-old Bronx youth was held in $16,000 bail yesterday on five charges arising from an automobile accident early Sunday in which a young bride-to-be was killed and her escort seriously injured.
THOSE who were fortunate enough to watch television's coverage of Comdr. Alan B. Shepard Jr.'s day of triumph in Washington yesterday saw the medium being put to use in brilliant style.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 8 -- Dr. Paul Langdon Ward, a 50-year-old history professor, was installed today as the fifth president of Sarah Lawrence College.
Four persons in City Hall Plaza who refused to take cover during the Civil Defense drill on April 28 were sentenced to thirty-day jail terms yesterday in Manhattan Arrest Court.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Comdr. Alan B. Shepard Jr., decorated by the President and cheered by the public as a national hero, calmly described today his flight into space as a "smooth" experience with no "bad moments at all."
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- President Kennedy's proposal to include consumer representatives on newly established National Farmer Advisory Committees drew opposition today.
PHOENIX, Ariz., May 8 (AP) -- A $5,760,000 damage suit against the General Electric Company and six other electrical manufacturers was filed in Federal District Court today by the Salt River Project.

The major issues confronting American Jews are discussed by Philip M. Klutznick in "No Easy Answers," which Farrar, Straus Cudahy will publish on June 19. The author is a past president of B'nai B'rith and is now a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations.
The World's Fair Corporation said yesterday that a spurt of financial support by industry and business had solved all its immediate money problems.

The partly blind former fiancee of Burton N. Pugach, a disbarred lawyer, testified yesterday in Bronx County Court that Pugach had told her he would have her "blinded by acid" if she refused to marry him.

Blood will be given today to the Red Cross at the Bank of New York, 52 William Street; the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., 4 Irving Place, and the New York Telephone Company, 10 Spring Street, White Plains.
The stock market reverted yesterday to the type of performance that was common during the early part of this year. The word for it is "churning."

The Electric Bond and Share Company reported yesterday that net assets were $186,128,360, equal to $35.45 a share, on March 31. In line with the company's compliance by divestiture with the Investment Company Act, the directorate placed values on holdings for which there were no quotations available.
The three Aqueduct stewards absolved Clyde Troutt, the trainer of Chief of Chiefs, yesterday of negligence in a stimulation case.

Eighteen lawyers here, headed by Theodore W. Kheel as chairman, formed an advisory committee yesterday to assist the defense counsel in the libel suits brought by Alabama officials against Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., four other Negro religious leaders and The New York Times.
Allegheny Power System, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday again in net income for the twelve months ended on March 31.

When Moise Tshombe, leader of Katanga, traveled to Coquilhatville last month to confer with Leopoldville officials on the Congo's future status, he came as the leader of the richest, most independent province in the divided African state. Now, in one of those fantastic developments that we have to expect in the Congo, he stands under arrest and accused of high treason.
The British Overseas Airways Corporation reported yesterday that traffic and revenue from traffic let records in the fiscal year that ended March 31.
Eddie Donovan, who built St. Bonaventure into a national basketball power, has been named head coach of the professional New York Knickerbockers.
Wall Street's latest "guess who" puzzle was solved yesterday with the announcement that an offer to buy 470,000 shares of General Outdoor Advertising Company came from Gamble-Skogmo, Inc.
The improved position of the dollar in world financial markets is one of the notable features of the present period as compared with the last months of the Eisenhower Administration.

Fifteen schools in the Clinton-Chelsea area on the West Side sent representatives to City Hall yesterday to see where the City Fathers meet and to report on how they helped the city in their own neighborhoods.

HAMBURG, Germany, May 8 (AP) -- Three Hamburg judges began today to sift through a three-year collection of evidence in the proceedings of Mrs. Anna Anderson to win legal recognition as Grand Duchess Anastasia, youngest daughter of Nicholas II, the last Czar of Russia.

Events today: Federation Choral of New York, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30 P.M.; Markle Memorial Glee Club, Salvation Army Centennial Memorial Temple, 120 West Fourteenth Street, 8; Central Presbyterian Church Choir, Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Sixty-fourth Street, 8; Concert of Electronic Music, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The United States proposed to the Organization of American States today a detailed agenda for a ministerial-level conference designed to set in motion far-ranging economic and social development in Latin America.

ROME, May 8 -- President Kennedy gave full support today to legislation seeking to liberalize United States immigration policy for Italy. He did so in a letter to a symposium of the American Committee on Italian Migration.
MIAMI, May 8 -- The Havana radio announced today the seizure of all private clubs in Santiago de Cuba as part of the Castro regime's general nationalization campaign.

Many persons entertained at a gala champagne supper dance at the St. Regis Roof last night. The dance, originally scheduled for the new Versailles Suite of the hotel, followed a theatre party to "Carnival!" at the Imperial Theatre.
New Yorkers are just beginning to waken to their city's cultural, esthetic and historic values, James Felt said yesterday.
Real estate tax collection in Albany County was criticized yesterday by the State Investigation Commission as ineffective and costing of considerable loss of revenue to the county.
EAST MEADOW, L.I., May 8 -- Six youths who earned high school equivalency diplomas in a school taught by a former inmate at the Nassau County Jail were graduated here today.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court denied today a hearing to WHDH, Inc., the Boston Herald-Traveler station, which is battling to continue broadcasting on TV Channel 5.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- The Supreme Court struck down today another Louisiana effort to bloc desegregation of schools in New Orleans.
DETROIT, May 8 (AP) -- Auto production figures so far bear out at least one prophecy made before the 1961 model run started last fall.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 8 -- United Nations officials said today that Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold had asked for "fair treatment" for Moise Tshomhe.
A 49-year-old Hempstead business man pleaded guilty yesterday to a charge of conspiring to smuggle Chinese aliens into the United States.

E.E. Dale Shaffer, the president of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations, disclosed yesterday on the eve of his departure for Europe that he hoped to form a world-wide organization to conduct an international triple-crown series.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 8 -- Congolese leaders were reported today to be moving toward a plan that would change the political structure of the Congo before the end of the summer.
The entrance to Brooklyn Borough Hall was draped in black and purple bunting yesterday in respect to the memory of Borough President John Cashmore, who died of a heart attack Sunday night.

TUNISIA'S First Lady is taking English lessons from her grandsons during her stay here and, if all goes well, Madame Habib Bourguiba will have new words with which to greet New Yorkers when she arrives tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Senate confirmed President Kennedy's appointment of Julius C. Holmes as Ambassador to Iran today by a vote of 63 to 17.
Two new steps in the expansion of one of the world's youngest but increasingly important steamship lines, the Zim Israel Navigation Co. Ltd., were reported last week.
LONDON, May 8 -- The Rolls-Royce Company has told the Government it may have to abandon production of its world-famous car if a proposal in the 1961-62 budget becomes law.

Comdr. Alan B. Shepard was due to go back to work today after a brief break in his regular schedule. Between last Friday morning at 10:34 daylight-saving time, and yesterday when he called on the President and was the guest of honor at a reception on Capitol Hill, he covered a good deal of sea and land.

The American Jewish Committee sharply criticized yesterday assertions that the World Zionist Organization or any other group had the right to speak for the Jews of the United States on their relationship to Israel.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A series of civil rights bills designed to carry out 1960 Democratic platform pledges was introduced in Congress today, but no message from President Kennedy accompanied it.
Sharp price declines in wool and cocoa futures dominated generally quiet dealings on New York exchanges yesterday. Most other commodities showed an easier to mixed tone.
Cardinal Spellman will undergo surgery today for a detached retina of the right eye.

BONN, Germany, May 8 -- Western Europe's continuing economic boom has led the Common Market Executive in Brussels to recommend another acceleration in the dismantling of trade barriers among the group's six member countries.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 8 -- Six hundred Asians and Africans demonstrated today at Residensia, a small town thirty miles south of here, in protest against the of Group Areas Act. The act sets aside the areas in which whites, Asians and Africans must live.

Although forces were precisely even, with two rooks and one knight on each side in the twentieth game of the world chess championship match in Moscow yesterday, the edge appeared to rest with Mikhail Tal, the champion.
CAIRO, May 8 -- President Sekou Toure of Guinea received a personal welcome from President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic today on his arrival for a one-week state visit.

PARIS, May 8 -- When riots erupt at soccer matches (as they do regularly in Italy, for example), it is often quit funny -- unless you happen to be the unfortunate referee or players trapped by the mob. Bu now a riot has occurred that is not funny at all.
CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court granted a hearing today to the Rev. Theodore R. Gibson, who refused to produce records of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People for a Florida investigating committee.
FLINT, Mich., May 8 (AP) -- Senator Barry Goldwater said tonight that if America was to remain the shield for the free world it would have to choose between big business and big government.
LONDON, May 8 -- Indignation over the case of George Blake, the Foreign Office official who confessed to spying for the Soviet Union, mounted in Britain today.

Hornblower Weeks and associates are offering to the public today common stock of the Welsh Scientific Company valued at more than $15,000,000. The offering consists of 545,000 shares priced at $28 a share.
NEWARK, May 8 -- A 1960 election by mail of officers of the Independent Petroleum Workers Union of Bayway was voided today by Chief Federal Judge William F. Smith.

MOSCOW, May 8 (AP) -- A 26-year-old Soviet physician, marooned by a blizzard at the Novo-Lazarev research station in the Antarctic, removed his own appendix in surgery lasting almost two hours, Tass said today.
CHICAGO, May 8 -- The president of the American Psychiatric Association challenged today the general medical knowledge of many psychiatrists.
LONDON, May 8 -- Most industrial sections of the stock market here were busy and buoyant today.
Prices of cotton futures moved 1 point off to 11 up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) -- President Kennedy signed legislation today channeling Federal relief funds to the jobless for the first time since the depression of the Nineteen-Thirties.

Winners of the annual Vernon Rice Memorial Awards for "outstanding achievement" in the off-Broadway theatre were announced at yesterday's luncheon meeting of the Drama Desk at the Playbill Restaurant, Eighth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street.

The city's Marine and Aviation Commissioner said yesterday he would oppose any renewal on the original terms of a pier lease between the city and the Hudson River Day Line, an excursion boat company owned by George Sanders, a friend of Mayor Wagner.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- Following is a transcript of remarks by President Kennedy an Comdr. Alan B. Shepard Jr., at the White House today:
ATLANTA, May 9 (AP) -- Gov. Ernest Vandiver said today that he had obtained a pre-election pledge from President Kennedy that he would never send troops to Georgia to enforce school desegregation.

A correspondence course doctorate in psychology from the College of Divine Metaphysics, Indianapolis, is not quite enough for treating patients with emotional problems, according to the State Department of Education.
The board of directors of the Maine Public Service Company voted yesterday to split the common shares. The split would be in the ratio of thirteen new shares in exchange for each ten outstanding.
YONKERS, May 9 -- Hughie Bell was involved in two accidents at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9 -- The Board of Overseers of Harvard University approved the abandonment of Latin as the language for diplomas today.
Two biologists from an atomic laboratory presented a new mathematical theory of death here yesterday. This is it:

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- When President Kennedy invited the newspaper editors and publishers to the White House today his concern was precisely the same as George Washington's complaint against the press 184 years ago this month.

In his letter to The Times (April 29), Dr. Harry Gideonse cites testimony before the Senate Internal Security Committee as proof that members of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee have acted as paid agents for the Cuban Government.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- A revised version of the Administration's school-aid bill was cleared by a House Education and Labor subcommittee today on a party-line vote of 4 to 3.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 9 -- The Government announced tonight that it had smashed a plot against Gen. Cemal Gursel's regime by supporters of deposed Premier Adnan Menderes. About eighty persons were reported to have been arrested.
BOSTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Massachusetts House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill granting the New Haven Railroad a 60 per cent property tax cut for the next three years.
Eastern Air Lines said yesterday it had been encouraged by the public's initial response to its airline shuttle services to Washington and Boston, which began April 30.
Work will begin this fall on the third large new hotel in the West Fifties near Broadway the twenty-one-story Country Squire Motor Inn.
Jack Brabham of Australia, the world road-racing champion, is a busy man.
Stocks went around and around yesterday in a churning action. It was the second straight session in which trading was heavy and prices ended about where they began.

Announcement was made yesterday of the formation of Itinerama, a French corporation that plans to exhibit Cinerama films abroad in a complete touring unit that includes a 3,000-seat, inflatable balloon-enclosed theatre. Starting in mid-July, one of three scheduled Itinerama units will tour France and French-speaking countries.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The United States delegation to the Geneva conference on Laos began leaving today, but the State Department reiterated that this country's participation depended on verification of a cease-fire.
The Karlsruhe Soccer Club will represent Germany in the International Soccer League when that circuit begins its second campaign next Wednesday night at the Polo Grounds.
More insiders but fewer bandits and burglars are stealing from banks, according to figures published yesterday by the American Bankers Association.

Sales of the General Dynamics Corporation in the first three months of this year exceeded those of the 1960 period, hut profits declined, the company reported yesterday. Net income was $4,194,076, or 42 cents a share, compared with $6,164,175, or 62 cents a share, last year. Net sales rose to $507,524,954 from $473,368,568.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Wednesday, May 10 -- A former Argentine Ambassador to Israel, Dr. Gregorio Topolevsky, said that he had no knowledge from official sources about the whereabouts of Martin Bormann, Hitler's deputy.

The New York Blue Cross is "in a much healthier situation than we've been in recent years," its president said yesterday. He added he was hopeful that the present rate structure would be "satisfactory and sufficient through 1962."

James Monroe High School of the Bronx set a meet record of 1:29.5 in winning the 880-yard open relay at the Mount St. Michael invitation track and field meet at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday. The two-day meet will conclude this afternoon with two running events and the field events.
Those who seek to make commercial gain by using the name of any one member or all members of the United States' astronaut team are in for a disappointment.

A.M. SOBEL, national tournament director of the American Contract Bridge League, brought today's deal home from Buenos Aires, where he saw Italy win the world championship and the United States (officially "North America") finish second.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The White House disassociated itself today from civil rights legislation introduced by two Democrats yesterday in Congress. Asked about the proposals, Pierre Salinger, President Kennedy's press secretary, said that "the President has made it clear that he does not think it is necessary at this time to enact civil rights legislation."
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The following are excerts from the speech of Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, before the National Association of Broadcasters today:
Varig Airlines of Brazil has purchased 50 per cent of the voting stock of Aerovias Brasilia, the international division of Real Airlines, Ruben M. Berta, president of Varig, said here yesterday.
A brief but savage windstorm caused heavy damage in upstate Sullivan County last night as much of the East was being swept by squalls bearing lightning, heavy rain and hail.
PHILADELPHIA, May 9 -- Diligence has become more apparent than ever among the Dodgers since their exodus from Brooklyn left that town without a ball club.
It took Harry P. Cole thirty-two years to close the deal, but his persistence finally paid off this spring in a $50,000 sale.
FORT DIX, N.J., May 9 (UPI) -- Three American boxers won bouts tonight in the fourteen annual international military boxing championships.

I read with great interest your editorial of May 4 concerning President Kennedy's program for assistance to the textile industry. I believe that your justified fear of across-the-board quota restrictions, in terms of our international relations and our domestic economic situation, points to the need for a broader and more thoughtful Administration approach to the problem of concentrated import competition.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Administration is planning a 25 per cent increase in the space budget.
CHICAGO, May 9 (AP) -- Jim Landis' hitting and Herb Score's pitching helped the Chicago White Sox snap a seven-game losing streak by defeating the Cleveland Indians, 4-2, tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) -- Brooklyn's District Attorney urged Congress today not to impose new Federal restrictions on police wiretapping on the ground that they would hamper the fight against organized crime.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- An appropriation of $600,000,000 to start a long-range economic aid program for Latin America was approved by the Senate today in a voice vote.

CAIRO, May 9 -- President Sekou Toure of Guinea, who is on a state visit here, is receiving Cairo's best wishes for the future of the Federation of Guinea, Ghana and Mali, but his suggestion that the door is open to the United Arab Republic and other African states to Join the union has met with a cooler, if polite, response.
President de Gaulle, had he been a less serious man, could have begun his press conference on Monday with the observation: "As I was saying before I was interrupted * * *."
" Rhapsody in Blue" will not be heard on an all-Gershwin night at Lewisohn Stadium for the first time in twenty-nine years.
The Greenwich Village coffee-house and cabaret license conflict moved into the precincts of City Hall yesterday.

LONDON, May 9 (UPI) -- Wolf Mankowitz, playwright and producer, led six attractive dancing girls carrying a small coffin into the office of The Daily Express today. The coffin was addressed to Bernard Levin, the paper's drama critic.

Jose Greco brought his company of Spanish dancers and musicians into the Royale Theatre last night for a three-week season, his first on Broadway in four years. It was far from being one of his most distinguished evenings.

" The Nose of Jerry Pepper," starring Milton Berle, is off. Roger L. Stevens, co-producer with Julie Styne, said yesterday that a Broadway house with a large seating capacity was not available next season for Arnold Schulman's spectacular drama.

DETROIT, May 9 (AP) -- A proxy fight for control of Evans Products Company was opened yesterday in a Circuit Court suit brought against the company and its directors. The suit was filed by Kenneth J. Logan, a lawyer, on behalf of four stockholders who, he said, hold a total of 35,000 common shares.
Bruce Campbell's Conestoga heads a field of ten horses entered in today's $29,200 Idlewild Handicap, the first turf stakes of the season at Aqueduct.
The National Association of Women Artists is sponsoring a benefit for the Eleanor Roosevelt Cancer Foundation at the National Academy Galleries, 1083 Fifth Avenue, next Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) -- Senator Robert S. Kerr disclosed some details today of a backstage White House struggle over the wisdom of last Friday's man-in-space shot.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The program for joint development of nuclear power by the Government and private industry received another setback today.

Mrs. Bruce McGhie, the Tri-County champion, led Apawamis to a 12-3 victory over Fenway as the third round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches were completed yesterday.
Cincinnati, Ohio, borrowed $21,500,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance hospital, construction, water supply expansion, urban redevelopment projects and other public improvements.

The Pure Oil Company reported yesterday a net income of $6,828,000, or 69 cents a common share for the first quarter. This compared with a revised net income of $6,702,000 and 68 cents in the like period of 1960. The 1960 figures were adjusted to include the earnings of the Woodley Petroleum Company, acquired on April 1, 1960.

ATLANTA, May 9 (AP) -- A Central of Georgia Railway representative and two paper company executives have expressed opposition to a proposed merger of the Atlantic Coast Line and Seabord Air Line Railroads.
The New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women yesterday elected Mrs. Norman Tishman to a two-year term as president.

The twenty-story apartment building at 345 East Fifty-sixth Street in the Sutton Place area has been bought for investment by the Marlboro Realty Associates. Melvin Senville and associates, the sellers, leased back the property and will continue to operate it.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn, May 9 (UPI) -- Jim Gentile hit grandslam home runs in two successive innings today and led the Baltimore Orioles to a 13-5 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

The scholarship fund of the Grace Church School at Fourth Avenue and Tenth Street will be the beneficiary of the sixth annual May Fair, to be held in its classrooms and playground on Friday and Saturday.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) Representative Edgar W. Hiestand, California Republican, asked Congress today to investigate whether Communists were behind some commitments to mental hospitals.
The Maritime Administration announced yesterday that it had permitted Victory Carriers, Inc., to cancel a contract under which the concern was to have built a 106,500-deadweight-ton tanker.

IN the wondrous upsidedown land of Australia the Fourth of July arrives in midwinter and Christmas is a summer holiday. The Aussies refer to thoroughbred horses as gallopers and get themselves into such a semantic tangle that pacers are known as trotters while trotters are called square-gaiters.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fell 1 to 6 points yesterday, except new October contract which was nominally 19 points up. A point is 5 cents a bale.
HARRISON, Ark., May 9 -- This pleasant little town in the Ozarks is digging itself out of the mud and debris left behind by one of the worst natural disasters ever to strike northwestern Arkansas.
The Liberal party's leadership is showing at least outward signs of objectivity toward the 1961 municipal election.

Having rebuffed American efforts to ease international tensions through "quiet diplomacy" and earnest negotiations, Premier Khrushchev is now staging what President Kennedy calls a test of nerves all over the world, with a showdown in the offing this year.

MILWAUKEE, May 9 (AP) -- The Braves broke a tie with a disputed run in the seventh inning and defeated the Chicago Cubs, 8 -- 5, tonight. Bob Buhl survived a pair of home runs by Ernie Banks in gaining his first victory of the season.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 9 -- Documents submitted today at the trial of Adolf Eichmann purported to show that he had given orders that sent 4,000 Jewish children from France to the gas chambers of Auschwitz, Poland.
CINCINNATI, May 9 (AP) -- The American National Red Cross moved today to develop successful participation in local Red Cross activities by labor unions and their members.
Cardinal Spellman underwent surgery yesterday to correct a detached retina in his right eye.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee joined its House counterpart today in unanimously asking more long-range strategic bombers than Presidents Eisenhower or Kennedy believed necessary.
Mayor Wagner stepped up his attack yesterday on Governor Rockefeller's legislative program.
Silt from heavy showers Saturday and Sunday morning was blamed yesterday for the deaths of thousands of fish in Van Cortlandt Park Lake in the Bronx.

KANSAS CITY, May 9 -- A number of old Yankee hands, perhaps feeling a trifle miffed that the Bombers had overlooked them in the recent deal for Bob Cerv, got even with their former team-mates tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Mr. McKnight explained today that the news executives had sought the meeting with Mr. Kennedy for clarification of his New York speech, and had "got quite a bit."

CONNECTICUT River shad, often reasonably called the poor man's salmon, are coming slow but they are on their way. In spite of high water, fish are being taken at Enfield Dam and elsewhere in moderate numbers.

Prices of prime fixed-income investments held firm in a trading session of moderate activity yesterday, except among the securities of the United States Government, where bids backed away before a preponderance of offerings.

LUBBOCK, Tex., May 9 (AP) -- James T. Ralph, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, told the American Cotton Congress last night the Kennedy Administration "believes in private enterprise" and is trying to save the American way of life."

DETROIT, May 9 (AP) -Gene Woodling produced half of Washington's eight hits tonight, leading the Senators to a 5-4 triumph over Detroit after the Tigers had captured the opener of the twilight-night bill, 7 -- 2, behind Don Mossi's four-hit pitching.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 9 -- Two Nassau Community College instructors charged today that they had been barred from reappointment because of their "conservative political beliefs and activities." This was denied by Lieut. Gen. B.M. Bryan, president of the college.

RICHMOND, Va., May 9 -- The Federal Government's intervention in Little Rock and New Orleans was cited today as precedents for its effort to become a co-plaintiff in the Prince Edward County school case.
Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy was asked yesterday to clear the way for Henry Miller's "Tropic of Cancer," a book that has been banned here as obscene, to be imported into the United States.

ONCE upon a time, in Seattle, Wash., there lived a little girl named Rose Louise Hovick. She dreamed of a career in show business. With her mother and sister she traveled from town to town, slept in tents and rode in a beat-up car.

Peoples Gas, Light and Coke Company awarded an issue of $30,000,000 of twenty-five-year first and refunding mortgage bonds yesterday to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. and associates on a bid of 99.6399 for the securities as 4 5/8 per cent obligations.
PITTSBURGH, May 9 (UPI) -- Roberto Clemente drove in four runs tonight to pace the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 9-6 victory that snapped the leagueleading San Francisco Giants' four-game winning streak.
Within the next decade, housewives will watch their children at play, answer the front door or watch a television show, all in color, by means of a new home communications system.

PARIS, May 9 -- One of the morel important and less publicized problems facing allied leaders in their Oslo conference is that of Russia's brilliant petroleum "offensive" aimed at capturing an ever-increasing share of West European markets.
The police reported yesterday that 1,125 persons were hurt in city traffic accidents last week, seventy-eight fewer than in the like 1960 week.
ST. LOUIS, May 9 (UPI) -- Clark Hungerford, president of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway, said today that he expected an improvement in the road's business sometime in the last half of this year.

OPENING today, and continuing through June, a notable, anonymously owned collection of French and American Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings, prints and sculpture will be shown at the Knoedler Galleries.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Intensive treatment of the mentally ill by general hospitals was proclaimed successful here today in a report by St. Luke's Hospital of New York. It said that 87 per cent of its patients were returned home within three weeks.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 9 -- A typhoon and tidal waves devastated the 12,000-square-mile area of populous East Pakistan Province today.
Work on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's memoirs is progressing well, a source at Doubleday Co., his publishers, said yesterday.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., May 9 (AP) -- Dr. George S. Benson, head of the National Education Program, has challenged Norman Thomas on the issue of censoring information about communism for the armed forces.

The successful space flight by Comdr. Alan B. Shepard Jr. last Friday will be the subject of a book that Martin Caidin will be working on and that Pyramid Books hopes to issue in a paperback edition on! May 19. To be called "Man Into Space," it will give a second-by-second account of the flight and the personal story of Commander Shepard.
Vice President Johnson faces a difficult task on his mission to Southeast Asia.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 9 (UPI) -- A Blue Scout rocket carrying 390 pounds of instruments on a data-gathering mission in space veered out of control today and was destroyed sixty seconds after it was launched.

PARIS, May 9 (AP) -- Young fashion designer Yves St. Laurent today brought a 600,000 franc ($120,000) suit against the Christian Dior fashion house for declining to take him back after his army discharge.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The House passed today and sent to the Senate a bill to authorize financial aid for the Menominee Indians of Wisconsin, who have been free of Federal supervision since April 30.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The speech by Newton N. Minow, the new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, marks a historic change in the fundamental concept of the regulation of broadcasting.
A suit to prohibit the proposed Huntington Hartford cafe in Central Park was dismissed yesterday by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.
MONROVIA, Liberia, May 9 (UPI) -- Leaders from nineteen independent African nations met today for a round-table discussion on the future of their continent.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 9 (AP) -- Hudson County Superior Court Judge Donald G. Collester refused today to lift a temporary restraint forbidding proceedings on a proposed merger of the Pyramid Electric Company and the General Instrument Corporation, maker of electronic components and equipment.

Events today: Jack Ossewaarde, organist, St. Bartholomew's Church, 12:10 P.M.; John Upham, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Broadway and Fulton Street, 12:30; Instrumental and Choral Concert, presented as part of the Festival of the Arts in Education of Teachers College, Columbia University, Horace Mann Auditorium, 5; Chamber music concert, Queens College Theatre, 1; "Y" Chamber Orchestra, Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Asociation of Washington Heights and Inwood, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Newton N. Minow, the new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, presented a scorching indictment of contemporary television at the National Association of Broadcasters convention today.
The Cuban Revolutionary Council, which sponsored the unsuccessful April 17 landing against the regime of Premier Fidel Castro, announced last night that it was "preparing new plans" to win its fight.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Joseph C. Swidler, who is President Kennedy's choice to be chairman of the Federal Power Commission, urged both public and private power interests today to moderate their traditional fight to produce the nation' electricity.

MONTREAL, May 9 (AP) -- Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion of Montreal, the scoring champion, beat Johnny Bower and Gordie Howe in a close vote to win the Hart Trophy as the National Hockey League' most valuable player for the 1960-61 season.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 9 -- The Israeli Government has been divided by the assurance of immunity it gave two former Nazis sought as witnesses for the trial of Adolf Eichmann.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 9 (AP) -- Rebel authorities snubbed members of the International Control Commission for Laos in their first contact at a Laotian truce meeting today, an Army spokesman said.
Ben Hibbs, editor in chief of The Saturday Evening Post since 1942, will resign at the end of this year. He will be succeeded by Robert Fuoss, now executive editor.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 -- James M. Symes, chairman of the Pennsylvania Railroad, the nation's largest, today charged the New York Central Railroad, the second largest, with attempting to throw a "roadblock" in the path of railroad mergers in the East.

The five-year perjury sentence imposed in 1951 on James Moran, former city official, has reduced yesterday by Federal Judge Charles M. Metzner six months, to be followed by two-year period of probation. Moran, who was first deputy Fire Commissioner when William O'Dwyer was Mayor, will be 60 years old in June.
The Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts will make its debut as a patron of the arts on television on Sunday.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The National Aeronautic Association today claimed two world records for Comdr. Alan B. Shepard Jr.

The Cuban tragedy has raised a domestic question that is likely to come up again and again until it is solved. The cause may be something that is happening in Laos, in Central Africa or in Latin America, but the question remains the same: is a democratic government in an open society such as ours ever justified in deceiving its own people?

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Vice President Johnson left today on a mission to reassure nations in Asia of United States support against Communist aggression. The Vice President carried personal letters from President Kennedy to heads of government in that region who are deeply concerned over the possible loss of Laos to communism and what this might portend for the rest of Southeast Asia.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Leading editors, publishers and press association executives told President Kennedy today they saw no need now for machinery to assist the press in guarding vital security information.
ALGIERS, May 9 (AP) -- Three nationalist demonstrators were slain and about ten wounded by French riot forces in a small town in eastern Algeria today.

Botany Industries, Inc., will distribute to its stockholders as a dividend the company's 49 per cent interest in Premier Industries, Inc., the annual meeting was told here yesterday by A.M. Sonnabend, chairman of Botany.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., May 9 -- For the first time in the more than a century since its founding, exclusive Llewellyn Park will open its gates next Tuesday to a continuing flow of visitors. The guests will be sight-seers heading to the former home of Thomas A. Edison.

Two major companies disclosed yesterday that they had made discoveries in the chemical field. A chemical said to be able, among its many applications, to make cutting tools almost as hard as diamonds or to make synthetic fibers stain resistant was announced by E.I duPont de Nemours Co., Inc.

In Wall Street language, investors were "reaching" hard for new issues yesterday in a kind of frenzy that some brokers described as "crazy." The issue that captured the liveliest public fancy consisted of 545,000 shares of Welch Scientific Company, of Skokie, Ill.
PARIS, May 9 -- Many of France's transport workers went on a twenty-four-hour strike today for higher wages and shorter working hours.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board asked cities today to take air service complaints to airlines before appealing to the Government.

The Right Rev. Horace W.B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, gravely warned churchgoers yesterday against "subversive" activities of the John Birch Society and other groups with "equally dangerous" programs.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 9 -- President Francois Duvalier was elected unopposed to a new term by 1,320,748 votes, according to newspaper reports of the results of the April 30 election of an unicameral legislature.
DETROIT, May 9 -- Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon called today for a firmer and tougher United States policy toward the Soviet Union.
OSLO, Norway, May 9 -- The United States pledged today to commit Polaris nuclear missile submarines to forces assigned to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 9 -- John E. Horne, Small Business Administrator, told manufacturers of women's coats here today that his agency would seek to liberalize its lending policies to speed economic recovery.

DETROIT, May 9 (AP) -- Two of Detroit's largest commercial banks announced today increases in the interest paid on individual savings accounts to 3 per cent from 2 per cent. The move signaled an aggressive effort to capture a larger share of the city's individual savings account customers.

The Ambrose Monell Foundation announced yesterday that Jesse Charles Johnson, director of the division of raw materials of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, had been awarded the Ambrose Monell Medal for distinguished achievement in mineral technology.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 9 (AP) -- Jim Gentile took his record-breaking home-run performance today as if it were an every day occurrence.
Michael H. Prendergast maintained complete silence yesterday on how he fared in negotiations with White House aides to have Federal patronage for New York State channeled through him.
BRADFORD, England, May 9 (Reuters) -- The Australian cricketers, hindered by bad weather at the start of their tour, today drew their match with Yorkshire.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The State Department announced today that more than 300 United States citizens in Cuba were having difficulties obtaining exit permits necessary to return to the United States.
DETROIT, May 9 -- Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon was sharply critical today of President Kennedy's recent appeal to the press for self-restraint.

Mikhail Tal of Latvia, the champion, and Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia devoted six more hours to the twentieth game of their world title chess match, yesterday in Moscow, according to Tass, the official Soviet news agency.
American dentistry hurts less than the Soviet variety, a visiting Soviet dentist reported yesterday.
NASSAU, Bahamas, May 9 (AP) -- Two young American drifters were hanged today for the slaying of a charter-boat captain who had tried to aid them when they were shipwrecked.

PELHAM, N.Y., May 9 -- Princeton regained the inter-collegiate championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association today. Lynn Adelman captured individual honors and led the Tigers to a thirteen-stroke victory at the Pelham Country Club.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- A strong movement against continuation of the 10 per cent tax on public transportation is developing in Congress. Opponents of the levy appeared moderately confident today of at least winning a 50 per cent reduction.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 9 -- The Congolese Interior Ministry issued an act of internment tonight against Moise Tshombe on ten charges involving treason.

ROOSEVELT, N.J., May 9 -- This community of 200 families, established twenty-five years ago by the New Deal as a rural utopia for garment workers, will begin this month to construct a memorial amphitheatre to Franklin D. Roosevelt.
NEW DELHI, India, May 9 -- Parliament completed passage today of a bill to ban the age-old Hindu practice of giving and accepting dowries.
MILWAUKEE, May 9 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves obtained Frank Thomas from the Chicago Cubs today in exchange for Mel Roach, a 1953 bonus player.

No matter how able the politically chosen official leadership of New York City is, or may be in the future, it cannot succeed without a sound foundation of professional, technical and managerial manpower. The city has 30,000 such positions budgeted, of which 20 per cent are unfilled.

The candidate of the Democratic organization of Hudson County won a comfortable plurality in the mayoral election in Jersey City yesterday. However, he failed to gain a majority, and a run-off election was made necessary.
CHICAGO, May 9 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The beginnings of a campaign to draft Senator Jacob K. Javits as the Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor were discernible yesterday.
Frank S. Hogan was endorsed for re-election as District Attorney of New York County last night by the annual membership meeting of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

WHEN the curtain went up last night at the McMillin Theatre, the stage was bare save for six acoustic suspension loudspeakers. The audience looked at the speakers. The speakers looked back at the audience.

KANSAS CITY, May 9 -- And so you think it's great to be a Yankee. If you have the ability to fire a ball like a bullet, belt it into outer space or fetch it out of the clouds like a hawk on the wing, you may be right.

LONDON, May 19 -- Prime Minister Macmillan will meet tomorrow with representatives of the Opposition to discuss the spy case of George Blake and the questions it has raised about the British security system.
PHILADELPHIA, May 9 -- The shareholders of the Philadelphia National Bank and the Girard Trust Corn Exchange Bank overwhelmingly approved the proposed merger of the two institutions today.
A Johnson Johnson executive defended the pharmaceutical industry yesterday as "dedicated" to mankind.
A 19-year-old New York University student was sentenced to sixty days in the workhouse yesterday for failing to obey take-cover orders during a national Civil Defense drill on April 28.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Senator J.W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, attacked the State Department today for what he called an "idiotic policy" of shifting ambassadors constantly.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 9 (AP) -- Alvin Jackson, a left handed pitcher, protected the Columbus Jets' first-place lead in the International League tonight, downing Jersey City, 5-1, on six hits after the Jerseys had taken the seven-inning opener, 6 -- 3.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- President Kennedy nibbled a fall-out biscuit today and promised to have a new and strengthened Civil Defense program ready in a month.

OSLO, Norway, May 9 -- The United States, Britain and France are urgently reviewing their plans to counter new Soviet military, political and economic pressures on West Berlin, authoritative sources declared tonight.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., May 9 -- One hundred and twenty-five business executives, doctors, teachers, clergymen and editors in the northeastern states were told here today that this country was lagging so far behind the Soviet Union in the propaganda war that the Communist flag probably would be flying over Washington before 1973.

In an unusual appearance before an informal session of the City Council yesterday, James Felt pleaded for an "open mind" by the lawmakers in their approach to the City Planning Commission's newest urban renewal plans.

Seventy professors and writers, including forty-one faculty members of Harvard University, have endorsed a resolution urging the United States to "give no further support for the invasion of Cuba by exile groups."

FORT JAY, Governor's Island, may be toured by children and their families on Saturday between noon and 4 P.M. as part of Armed Forces Week celebration. The army installation may be reached by a free ferry boat ride from the Battery.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Textile Workers Union today accused the National Labor Relations Board of favoring employers and said it had helped create an anti-union climate in the nation.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., met with a group of artists here yesterday and assured them that the city wanted its artists to stay.
LAUREL, Md., May 9 -- Rain-checks, a rarity at New York harness tracks, will be honored at Laurel Raceway tomorrow, night, when the Reading Futurity for 2-year pacers will be staged.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- President Kennedy proposed reorganization of the Federal Trade Commission today to provide greater flexibility in the handling of its business.

Despite political tensions, thousands of young men and women abroad are seeking pen friends in the United States. They write from such diverse places as India and England, Brazil and Japan, Korea and Nigeria, and other parts of the free world.

BUFFALO, May 9 -- The Mayor of Buffalo protested today that a 1960 report by the State Investigation Commission describing the Buffalo Police Department as inefficient, undisciplined and politically dominated was short of the "whole truth."

The six-story apartment house at 1100 Grand Concourse, long one of the most prominent residential addresses in the Bronx, has been sold by Tompkins Estates, Inc., to an investing client of Jesse Friedman, lawyer.

More than a score of internationally known persons have agreed to be honorary patrons for the "Steuben Crystal in Private Collections" exhibition that will be held Monday evening at Steuben Glass, 715 Fifth Avenue.

HOW useful it would be to know the secret of remaining as cool as a cucumber on a hot summer day. The phrase is no idle sentiment for the temperature inside an unrefrigerated field cucmber is at least 20 degrees lower than the air surrounding it in warm weather.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 9 (AP) -- Defendants in a pending Federal Court action involving charges of fraud in solicitation of proxies by anti-management stockholders in the United Industrial Corporation asked today for a change of venue to southern California.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- For nearly twenty years Dr. Edward Cristy Welsh has belonged to the legion of public servants who from behind the scenes influence and direct public decisions but never receive public recognition.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 9 (AP) -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran dissolved Parliament today and gave Premier Ali Amini temporary power to rule without legislative obstruction.

LONDON, May 9 -- Prime Minister Macmillan said today that any association by Britain with the Common Market would depend on satisfactory arrangements to protect the interests of British agriculture, the Commonwealth and other members of the European Free Trade Association.

Wool futures broke sharply yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The December, March and new May grease wool positions dropped the daily limit of 10 cents a pound from Monday's close. The last time wool registered a limit decline was in October, 1951.
Three major symphony orchestras and two important centers of theatre, opera and ballet were named yesterday to participate in a state-aided program to stmulate cultural actvty throughout New York.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 9 (AP) -- France is not liable for the United States' worst industrial disaster, the Fifth Circuit United States Court of Appeals has ruled. The finding came fourteen years after the series of explosions at Texas City, Tex., that killed 570 persons.
Action to tighten and extend the ban on discrimination in private housing was unanimously approved yesterday by the City Council.

LONDON, May 9 -- Profit taking increased in the stock market here today, but demand was still substantial. In the heavy two-way trading price movements in many industrial shares groups were irregular.

Paperboard output soared to a six-month high of 325,861 tons in the week ended last Saturday from 319,809 tons the week before, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. The latest production figure was the highest since the week ended Oct. 22, 1960, when 327,941 tons were produced.

CHICAGO, May 9 (AP) -- A fairly steady demand slowed but failed today to halt the decline in soybean prices on the Board of Trade. All finished lower, but losses were relatively small after active dealings in which the old crop months showed a tendency to rally.
Architects and city planners who adopted the "simple but inhuman method" of the bulldozer-approach in slum clearance now realize they were mistaken, an architect said yesterday.

BERLIN, May 9 -- The departure of the Soviet commander from East Berlin gave rise to speculation today that the move might be a first step by the Soviet Union in turning over control of East Berlin to East Germany.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller of New York has rejected reapportionment as a topic for discussion at a dinner he plans to give for New York members of Congress here May 24.
About a year ago two scientists in Memphis caught malaria.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -Two members of Congress who also belong to the John Birch Society urged the House Rules Committee today to approve a full-scale investigation of the policies, principles and activities of that controversial organization.

The police rounded up eight members of a Brooklyn teenaged gang yesterday in the knife-slaying of a 14-year-old Queens boy. They said the boy apparently had been the victim of mistaken identity.

Earnings of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., Inc., were $18,660,000, or 63 cents a share in the first quarter of this year. That compared with $24,932,000, or 85 cents a share, a year earlier, the company announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 10 -- The major problem for a producer, so far as Philip Barry Jr. is concerned, is how to maintain the original enthusiasm that drives a man to want to make a movie out of a novel, play, short story or a television script.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Two union attorneys accused the National Labor Relations Board today of anti-labor bias in its decisions.

MILAN, Italy, May 10 (AP) -- Diulio Loi of Italy retained his world junior welterweight championship tonight with a fifteen-round decision over the former champion, Carlos Ortiz, a Puerto Rican-born New Yorker.
A jury in Bronx County Court yesterday acquitted Charles B. Kiernan of charges that he had accepted bribes while a cashier in the Bronx Motor Vehicle Bureau.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 -A budding, belated "get-mad" movement among the fading Phillies fizzled abruptly tonight. Johnny Podres frustrated the National League tail-enders with five-hit pitching and registered a 6-0 triumph for the Dodgers.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 10 -- Lieut. Gen. B.M. Bryan, president of the Nassau Community College, was defended today in the controversy over the dismissal of two instructors at the school.

Two robbers shot and killed a guard in a payroll hold-up yesterday at the Globe Lighting Company, Maspeth, Queens. The gunmen escaped with about $2,000 of a $15,000 payroll.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The mounting criticisms abroad and at home of the part played by the United States Government in the invasion of Cuba by foes of its para-Communist regime have initiated what could become an adversary proceeding from which this regime and its aims would be the principal beneficiaries.

Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman voiced severe criticism yesterday of a New Rochelle Board of Education plan to desegrate one of its elementary schools. He described the plan as "more or less of a palliative" to the court.

Andrew Jackson High School won the team title in the ninth annual Mount St. Michael invitation track and field meet, which was concluded at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday. The Queens school scored 20 points.

The specialty of the German Shepherd Dog Club of Long Island, held last Saturday at Franklin Square, L.I., differed from all similar one-breed shows in the country in the way the dogs were evaluated. Bruce S. Campbell's bay 4-year-old Conestoga, the even-money favorite, won Aqueduct's first turf race of the season yesterday, taking the $28,950 Idlewild Handicap by one length. A crowd of 27,045 saw the event.

Bergen County, N.J., announced yesterday plans to borrow $5,460,000 to finance public improvements. Bids will be received on May 24 on $4,882,000 of general improvement obligations and $578,000 of parks obligations.

Top management of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., which today will face a legal action seeking to curb or oust it, is preparing to press for a 5-cent fare increase on its buses.

Laurence Harvey has been signed to co-star with Leslie Caron in Warner Brothers' "The L-Shaped Room," to be produced by James Woolf and directed by Jack Clayton. The drama is based on Lynne Reid Banks' novel.
