A dinner dance was given aboard the S.S. Brasil at Pier 32 last night for the benefit of the Child Adoption Service of the State Charities Aid Association.
Senator Robert S. Kerr urged health insurance company executives here yesterday to continue their opposition to the Kennedy Administration's Social Security approach to medical care of the elderly.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 10 -- Hofstra broke a seven-game losing streak today by beating Brooklyn College, 6 -- 2, in a Metropolitan Conference game.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -The United States is now prepared to consider financial aid to foreign Government-owned oil companies, including state monopolies, to help supply equipment.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 10 -Top officials of the International Control Commission went today to the Laotian rebel capital of Xiengkhouang to verify that a cease-fire exists.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 10 (AP) -- Nearly 400 high school students opened the twelfth annual National Science Fair-International today.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., May 10 (UPI) -- The Republican national chairman, Senator Thruston B. Morton, said tonight that under the Kennedy Administration there had been a "softening of the firm Republican foreign policy that established peace and maintained it" for eight years.
Rudy Vallee is returning to Broadway.
NEW ORLEANS, May 10 (UPI) -- Fire burned out of control today aboard an explosives-laden ship used by a Houston company to hunt for oil on the bottom of the Gulf of Mexico.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Key Senate Democrats agreed today on a more costly formula than President Kennedy had proposed for allocating grants states under the Administration's school-aid bill.
The State Attorney General has sued to prevent private operators from naming a business on Palisades Interstate Parkway, ten miles from Bear Mountain, the "Bear Mountain Motel and Recreation Center."

FORT DIX, N.J., May 10 (UPI) -- Five boxers from the United States, two from Italy and one from the United Arab Republic scored victories tonight in the second round of the fourteenth annual international military championships.
" Face the Nation" will not return to Columbia Broadcasting television next season.

The president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation warned stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting in San Francisco that United States companies would lose out eventually in foreign markets if they were "required to compete under rules and burdens more restrictive than those applicable to our foreign competitors."
City officials were warned yesterday that they must abolish the 5 per cent ticket tax for legitimate theatres if they wanted the theatre to continue to exist here.

The New York Central Railroad yesterday sold $4,155,000 of equipment trust certificates to a group led by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., on a bid of 98.1799 for certificates with 4 7/8 per cent interest coupons. Salomon Brothers Hutzler and associates bid 98.0607 for a 5 per cent coupon.
OSLO, Norway, May 10 (AP) -- Following the text of a communique issued today at the end of the meeting here of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's Council of Ministers:

WASHINGTON, May 10 -One of the liveliest controversies in television's hectic history erupted today in the wake of Tuesday's speech by Newton N. Minow, new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, describing most video programing as "a vast wasteland."

Electric power production dipped in the week ended last Saturday to 14,206,000,000 kilowatt hours from 14,254,000,000 the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. A year ago the figure was 13,495,000,000.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Two Federal agencies concerned with aviation have split on President Kennedy's recommendation to continue the present 10 per cent tax on passenger fares.

Webb Knapp, Inc., annouced yesterday that it had agreed to sell the blockfront on the east of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) between Fifty-third and Fiftyfourth Streets. The sale price is $3,200,000.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Defense Department announced today it had selected the Sperry Rand Corporation of Great Neck, L.I., as the prime contractor for a $60,000,000 mobile missile tracking project.
As ranking minority member of the House Committee on Education and Labor I am deeply interested in the entire question of Federal aid to education.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the oil industry agreed generally today that the oil import program in operation the last two years be continued with some revisions. But there was considerable disagreement on what changes and revisions should be made.

A Veterans of Foreign Wars post in Teaneck, N.J., wrote to Mayor Wagner yesterday questioning the propriety of his "recent order to lower the flag of the United States of America to half-mast on the passing of a very honored city official."
DENVER, May 10 -- Progress toward including Negroes in activities of the Young Women's Christian Association is very uneven, Mrs. Henry A. Ingraham of Brooklyn, said here today.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 10 -- Charles Robberts Swart, former Minister of Justice and Governor General until his resignation April 30, was elected today first President of the South African Republic, which comes into being May 31.

A seasonal decline of 2,585,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks last week was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Total supplies were 216,732,000 barrels on Friday, compared with 219,317,000 a week earlier and 218,772,000 a year ago.
Senator Jacob K. Javits asked Governor Rockefeller and state and city Republican leaders last night to remove his name from consideration as a possible Republican candidate for Mayor this year.
The advertising agencies yesterday left the networks and the public holding the bag as far as responsibility for poor television programing was concerned.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 10 -- A Buddhist monk, Talduwe Somarama Thero, was found guilty today of the murder of S.W.R.D. Bandaranaike, Prime Minister of Ceylon, in September, 1959.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 10 (UPI) -- Minnesota scored nine runs in the second inning today and went on to defeat the Baltimore Orioles, 10 -- 6.
CLEVELAND, May 10 (AP) -- Federal Judge Paul C. Weick today ordered four men convicted of conspiring to violate the Taft-Hartley Act to begin their eighteen-month prison sentences May 22.
A scientist cast dought yesterday on the validity of blood pressure measurements taken in the arm.

LONDON, May 10 -- A small pen and ink drawing of a young woman by Hugo van der Goes, who lived from 1440 to 1482, was sold at auction today for 30,000 ($84,000), one of the highest prices ever paid for such a work.
CHICAGO, May 10 -- An explanation of why some married couples cannot live with each other or without each other was offered here today.

CINCINNATI, May 10 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther told the closing luncheon meeting of the national convention of that organization here today that the Communist countries were seeking to involve the world Red Cross movement in political issues.
Nine pacifists arrested April 28 for refusing to obey orders to take shelter during a Civil Defense drill at City Hall Plaza pleaded guilty yesterday in Upper Manhattan Arrest Court.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -The American Telephone and Telegraph Company disclosed that it had requested Government assistance last December in launching an experimental communications satellite but had not yet received a definite reply.
Michael H. Prendergast reported yesterday that he was "well satisfied" with the results of his meeting in Washington on Monday with two of President Kennedy's assistants.

CINCINNATI, May 10 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds went on a ten-hit rampage tonight, including Vada Pinson's homer, to defeat the St. Louis Cardinals, 3 -- 2, and stretch their winning streak to nine games -- the longest in the National League this year.
The city apparently reversed itself yesterday when it indicated it would prosecute Jacob Brownstein, convicted slum operator.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 10 -- A Buddhist monk, Talduwe Somarama Thero, was found guilty today of the murder of S.W.R.D. Bandaranaike, Prime Minister of Ceylon, in September, 1959.

Production of lumber in the week ended last Saturday totaled 233,790,000 board feet, compared with 237,832,000 in the prior week, according to reports from regional associations. A year ago the figure was 252,406,000 board feet.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The United States said today it had uncovered an international ring that tried to obtain millions of dollars worth of Western-made goods for illegal shipment to Communist China and other Communist countries.
A city magistrate had second thoughts yesterday and freed a college girl he had sent to jail for thirty days for refusing to take cover in an air-raid drill.
President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia expressed the hope yesterday that his country and the United States would work toward ever-increasing friendly relations "in the world which is developing."
Railroad merger proposals received stanch stockholder support yesterday in both Roanoke, Va., and St. Paul, Minn.
MIAMI, May 11 -- Cuba is continuing to prepare against invasion, which the Castro Government says may come any time.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., May 11 -- It pays to know your own golf course. Mrs. William Tracy proved it today when she won low gross honors in a weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) -- Chairman John L. McClellan of the Senate Investigations Committee called labor practices at missile bases "damnable" today. He said Congress should pass a law outlawing strikes and deliberate work stoppages on vital Government contracts.

MONTE CARLO, May 11 -- Jimmy Clark, driving a sleek new 1.5-liter Lotus entered by the factory, posted the fastest lap today as trials opened for the Grand Prix de Monaco auto race -- then spun into a barricade and demolished the car.

PARIS, May 11 -- The French Communist party claimed today a major share of the credit for the defeat of last month's generals' mutiny in Algeria. It also took credit for the coming peace talks between France and the Algerian nationalist rebels.
Prime fixed-income investments of all kinds were in good demand yesterday, with many issues of Treasury and corporate securities going to new high prices for the year.

The sale of tickets for the theatre party at the May 25 performance of "Carnival!" at the Imperial Theatre is continuing. The committee arranging the evening as a benefit for the Ethel Walker School has announced the names of persons who already have purchased tickets.

THE fashion industry employs close to a million people. It is made up of many related fields and offers positions in design, illustration, merchandising, manufacturing and management. To keep New York City's largest industry going requires a constant flow of well-trained young men and women.
A City Hall experiment of "taking the city government closer to the people" will be extended this year.

LONDON, May 11 -- The Government announced today that it was considering an application by the Steel Company of Wales to import United States coking coal, which is about $4.20 a ton cheaper than the same grade of coal mined on its doorstep.
YONKERS, May 11 -- Steering clear of trouble early, Australia's Apmat easily won the $62,800 Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
Three hundred donors, performing artists and other guests will watch concrete being poured on the roof of Philharmonic Hall in the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts this afternoon.
Reports from the Soviet Union yesterday gave a new figure for the astronomical unit, but the most recent American calculations find this substantially too low.

The Wiltwyck School for Boys will benefit from an art exhibition to be held at Mr. and Mrs. Herman Brickman's estate in Kings Point, L.I., Monday evening. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will be guest of honor.
Price increases in spot sugar raised both domestic and world futures yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.
PALM BEACH, Fla., May 11 -- President Kennedy began a brief Florida holiday today by playing twelve holes of golf on a balmy sunny afternoon.
Judges faced with the prospect of having their private cars tagged for illegal parking have succeeded in getting parking areas outside court buildings earmarked for their use.
DEPENDING on one's view of her, Margaret Sanger is a great humanitarian or a contemptible rebel.
Many private colleges in New York State have accepted about all the freshmen they can for next fall, a report showed yesterday. However, space is still available in some of the larger institutions.
Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy yesterday ordered Pan American World Airways, Inc., to divest itself of its 50 per cent interest in the capital stock of Pan American-Grace Airways, Inc. (Panagra).
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Doubts about the practicality and reliability of intercontinental ballistic missiles were raised today in a report to the House by its Armed Services Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee said today that the Organization of American States should take strong action against Cuba because Premier Fidel Castro's regime was a "clear and present danger" to the Western Hemisphere.

LONDON, May 11 -- A wide investigation of Britain's security system was ordered today by Prime Minister Macmillan. He announced in the House of Commons that, be cause of the public anxiety aroused by the case of George Blake, a Foreign Service employe convicted last week of spying for the Soviet Union, a top-level investigating committee would be appointed as soon as possible.

FORT WORTH, May 11 (AP) -- The British Open champion, Kel Nagle, shot a hole in one and posted a five-under-par 65 today in taking the first-round lead in the $40,000 Colonial national invitation golf tournament.
Albert C. Simmonds Jr., president of the New York State Bankers Association, warned bankers yesterday against allowing competition for time deposits to undermine profits and customer service.
The air transport industry has neglected the cargo business and concentrated instead on the "more glamorous" passenger traffic, E.R. Quesada said here yesterday.
Senator Javits' rejection of Republican appeals to draft him as a candidate for Mayor has every appearance of being final and irrevocable.
OLEAN, N.Y., May 11 (UPI) -- Pierre Salinger said today that the Government would soon establish a foreign newspaper center in New York to facilitate the free flow of information.
NEWARK, May 11 -- The former president of the Manufacturers Bank of Edgewater, N.J., and two other men were found guilty in Federal Court today of a $150,000 swindle that closed the bank in 1958.
In the finals of the fourth annual American Opera Auditions, held yesterday afternoon in Judson Hall, six young American singers were chosen to make operatic debuts in Italy late next summer.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Senate voted, 43 to 36, today to grant President Kennedy wide authority to aid Eastern European satellites of the Soviet Union whenever he thought it would help wean them away from Moscow.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The builder of an ill-fated Atlantic radar tower said today the Navy had decided to put up the structure despite prior damage. But, he said, the decision seemed in the national interest at the time.

John P. Sisk, Associate Professor in Gonzaga University's English Department, is the winner of the Carl Foreman Award of $2,500 for his novella, "A Trial of Strength." The announcement was made yesterday by Harcourt, Brace World in behalf of itself, Collins Publishers of Great Britain and Highroad Productions, Inc., in association with Columbia Pictures.

DUTCH NECK, N.J., May 11 -- The attorney of a father and mother who refuse to send their three musically gifted children to public school threatened today to contest the constitutionality of New Jersey's compulsory education law.
CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) -Prices in the grain futures market were steady to firm most of the time today, but soybeans eased on late selling and fell behind on most contracts.
IT took Terence Harold Robsjohn-Gibbings only six months to span twenty-five centuries of furniture design.

FOR 99 cents each, several hundred young people heard a Mozart concert in Carnegie Hall last night that was well worth hearing. Robert Mandell had brought his Ars Nova Orchestra and the glee clubs of Fordham University and the College of New Rochelle to perform a program that encompassed the Serenade in D (K. 239), the Symphony No. 29 and the Requiem.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) -- Gen. Curtis E. Lemay, an architect of modern strategic air power, was reported tonight to be President Kennedy's choice for Chief of Staff of the Air Force.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Two Army civilian scientists and the widow of a third received cash awards and President Kennedy's congratulations today for work in developing nuclear warheads for the Davy Crockett, an infantry weapon.

Major financing plans were announced yesterday by Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and by P. Lorillard Company, the maker of Kent, Newport and Old Gold cigarettes. Vic Tanny Enterprises, Inc., the health center operator, also announced financing plans.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 11 -- The Actor's Workshop, San Francisco's permanent professional theatre, changes its bill every night with the aplomb of the great European repertory ensembles.
LONDON, May 11 -- Stock market prices advanced on a broad front here today in an active session.
Welfare Commissioner James R. Dumpson yesterday disputed Governor Rockefeller's charges that New York City was not yet ready to participate in the state's program of medical care for the elderly.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve rose $3,000,000 to $64,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $47,000,000 to $512,000,000.
In January, 1945, Russian troops stormed the Nazi death camp at Auschwitz, Poland. A Soviet camera man focused on a knot of dazed, half-starved children staring at their liberators.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 11 (UPI) -- Gov. Ernest F. Hollings commuted the death sentence of a 20-year-old Negro today, less than twenty-four hours before he was scheduled to die for the rape of a white woman.
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., May 11 -- Daniel Buckley, president of the Crusade for America, denied today that he had accused the president of the Nassau Community College of being "soft" on communism.

On returning from their first long road trip of the season, the Yankees rested yesterday. They perhaps fretted a bit about the gap between them and the Detroit Tigers generally and Frank Lary in particular.
FORT DIX, N.J., May 11 (AP) -- Four United States boxers gained the finals of the international military championships tonight.
Earnings of Aluminium, Ltd., fell to $7,397,000, or 24 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1961 from $8,804,000 and 29 cents a year earlier, the big Canadian aluminum producer announced yesterday.
A Bishop of the Church of South India warned Western churchmen here yesterday that "ecclesiastical colonialism must come to an end."

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Following are the texts of a letter President Kennedy sent to Speaker Sam Rayburn today on his proposals to combat juvenile delinquency and a letter from Secretary Abraham A. Ribicoff, which the President enclosed:

The urgent necessity that Congress approve pending legislation for direct Federal aid to the public schools was reiterated in these columns yesterday. There is no domestic question of greater importance; and a bill along the general lines of the one approved yesterday by a 12-to-2 vote of the Senate Labor Committee ought (with some changes) be enacted into law.
"An Evening With S.J. Perelman" temporarily identifies the entertainment the humorist is writing for the stage, from which he has been absent for a long time.

IF Michael Campbell's first novel, "Peter Perry," was half as good as his second novel, "Across the Water,"* then it must have been twice as good as most first novels. It wasn't noticed in this space. More's the pity! Such lamentable oversights can be expected when fallible mortals prone to error are trying to cope with too many books.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 11 -Vice President Johnson assured the people of South Vietnam today of United States assistance against the Communist threat and in dealing with "problems of economic and social progress."
BOOKS describing the finer points of rubber bridge are appearing with increasing frequency.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- "Under no circumstances does Secretary Robert S. McNamara feel that the American public should be misled about a military program," a Defense Department spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Spokesmen for independent oil producers and for major oil companies were far apart today on their suggestions to the Department of the Interior as to how the oil import program should be revised.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A $2,550,000,000 school-aid bill, sweetened to attract Southern Democratic votes, emerged today from the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) -- Two Senators introduced a sports bill today that would extend professional baseball's exemption under the antitrust laws to professional football and other major sports.
Three new films will open here today.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 11 (AP) -- The National Gypsum Company today reported net earnings of $2,744,442, equal to 42 cents a share, for the first quarter of 1961.

I agree with your editorial recommendation (April 26) of more diligent Congressional surveillance of the Central Intelligence Agency and join your protest against the agency's increasing tendency "to make policy decisions." Yet it is not entirely accurate to say that C.I.A. is "virtually a law unto itself, subject only to Presidential direction."
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 11 -- "It is very cold tonight. I advise you to dress your children warmly."
The drift toward neutralism in Thailand reported by our correspondent in Bangkok was to be expected.

Management of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., struck back hard yesterday at a dissident stockholder seeking to curb or displace it. The company landed its first solid blow after more than a week of attack in and out of court by the Dal-Tran Service Company.

Michael H. Prendergast, the Democratic state chairman, said last night there was room "for all degrees of opinion" in the party, but he again denounced "self-proclaimed liberals who recklessly condemn the will of the overwhelming majority."

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- President Kennedy flew to Florida this afternoon and left behind a most interesting paradox. This is that in the midst of one of the worst Presidential blunders in recent history, over Cuba, he stands higher in the esteem of his colleagues in Washington than ever before.

CENSORSHIP of motion pictures was the topic of a provocative telecast last night over the Columbia Broadcasting System. The one-hour filmed program, shown in the "C.B.S. Reports" series, was designed to study the influences that determine what is permitted to be shown or banned from theatre screens.
Newton N. Minow, who earlier this week described most television programing as a 'vast wasteland," will have a chance on Sunday to unburden himself directly to the viewers -- on television.

Mayor Wagner's Charter Revision Commission held its first public hearing yesterday. Some speakers warned against hasty Charter revision, but others called for the submission of a new Charter at this November's election.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The first "significant" upturn in employment since the start of the recession came last month, the Labor Department reported today.

THE editor of the official baseball guide was distraught. He had observed a trend in managerial strategy the previous season and it alarmed him because it was warping fundamental principles of the sport. So he wrote a bitter editorial condemning the practice. One lengthy sentence outlined his charge.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 11 (AP) -- A Government military team flew deep behind rebel lines today for talks with neutralists and the Pathet Lao pro-Communists. But the mission again failed to find agreement on where to hold ceasefire and political negotiations.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The president of the Allen-Bradley Company said today that he and his company had pleaded guilty to charges of price-fixing only because "we were left with no other alternative."

FOR most of us, "The Grand Duke" or "The Statutory Duel," which the American Savoyards presented last night at the Greenwich Mews Theatre, is a brand-new piece. The fourteenth and final of the operettas written by Gilbert and Sullivan.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The Army has decided to buy coal in Europe only from concerns that get their coal supplies from the United States.
LISBON, Portugal, May 11 -- Portuguese authorities in Angola recently captured seventy-one Ghanaian nationals fighting alongside rebel bands in the strife-torn West African province.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The House of Representatives extended the Mexican labor-import program for two years today. It rejected all amendments aimed at protecting the wages and jobs of American farm laborers.
DETROIT, May 11 (AP) -Billy Klaus smashed a grand-slam home run that sparked the Washington Senators to a 9-4 victory over the first-place Detroit Tigers today.
CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) -- Vast floods rolled down Midwestern valleys today, routing more lowland dwellers in Illinois, Missouri, Arkansas, Oklahoma, Indiana and Kansas.

TOKYO, May 11 -- The question whether the United States will relinquish a military base in the Tokyo environs for use in the 1964 Olympic Games threatened today to cause a new controversy between Japan and the United States.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 11 -- Tom O'Leary made three hits in four at bats and figured in all his team's scoring as the Manhattan baseball team defeated Princeton, 3 -- 1, on Stadium Field today.
IOWA CITY, May 11 -- Among the topics not mentioned during the last two days: Russia, Cuba, President Kennedy, beatniks, the recession, the race into space.

At the initiative of the United States, the North Atlantic Council has resolved in principle to raise the stature and expand the scope of the North Atlantic alliance by converting it from an organization dedicated primarily to the defense of Europe into a global united front to meet the growing challenge of Communist imperialism everywhere.
Union electricians are going to school at night in an unusual project combining training in union leadership with the development of a stronger sense of community responsibility.
WASHINGTON, May -Railroad freight loadings last week dropped from the 1960 level and dipped slightly from those of the preceding week of this year.
NAIROBI, Kenya, May 11 Thousands of Africans gathered outside Kenya's Parliament Building here today at the formal opening of the new Legislative Council.

Knowing motorists who have been zigzagging across the upper East Side to catch green lights are a frustrated group this week. They are victims of a Traffic Department test aimed at saving time for the driver who follows the straight path.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission reported today 3 per cent fewer fatalities in 1960 than in the previous year in accidents involving motor carriers reporting to the agency.
The railroad industry is on the defensive for the first time in many years, Braxton B. Carr declared yesterday.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz was projected into the front ranks of possible Republican candidates for Mayor yesterday after Senator Jacob K. Javits had removed him self from consideration. A privately financed poll by an independent opinion-sampling concern was reported as crediting Mr. Lefkowitz with the power to make a "horse race" of a contest with Mayor Wagner.

Shares in Grosset Dunlap, Inc., the publishing concern, were offered to the public for the first time yesterday. The 436,086 shares, priced at $29, found a ready market and the offering was soon oversubscribed, according to Blyth Co., Inc., and associates, the underwriters.
New York University's nine gave Bill McCarthy the handsomest going-away present a retiring baseball coach could wish yesterday.

Lay and spiritual leaders of the two largest Orthodox Jewish bodies criticized Arnold J. Toynbee, the British historian, yesterday for saying recently that intermarriage would break down "the traditional caste-barrier between Jews and non-Jews."

WILLIAM SCHUMAN was the composer set in the final Composers' Showcase of the season last night at the Museum of Modern Art. He was represented by two works given in a form other than that in which they were first conceived.

TRENTON, May 11 -- The door to a state sales or personal income tax was opened wide today as the Democratic party dropped its pledge against the levies. The Republicans dropped the pledge two years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 -- A Federal Judge refused today to release the records of five grand juries that indicted twenty-nine corporations and forty-four persons for price-fixing in the electrical antitrust prosecution.

While most children are itching for their summer vacations, the fashion world has already planned their back-to-school clothes. The Fashion Group presented yesterday the story of "growing fashions," which range from designs for toddlers up to and including the young junior (high school student), at a luncheon showing held at the Astor Hotel.
The official family at Aqueduct was shaken yesterday by the season's third case involving a winning horse showing traces of a drug forbidden under New York racing rules.

Walter H. Breuer, vice president of European operations for Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., was killed in an automobile accident April 26 in Germany, according to information received here yesterday. He was 61 years old.
WARSAW, May 9 -- Church and state in Poland are girding for a test of wills over traditional Roman Catholic processions in the first week of June.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- In his recent series of speeches Richard M. Nixon directly hit three highly visible targets of Administration vulnerability. But members of his own party in Congress have weakened the impact of his hits on two of these targets.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today President Kennedy's nomination of Walworth Barbour of Massachusetts, a veteran Foreign Service career officer, to be Ambassador to Israel.

The population explosion is as dangerous to world peace as an atomic explosion, the Indian Ambassador to the United States said here last night. He spoke at a dinner opening a conference on the "World Population Crisis" at which Margaret Sanger was honored for her pioneering work in birth control.

Plans are nearing completion for the Salute to Summer cocktail tea dance, to be held Monday in the Pierre's ballroom for the benefit of the Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Mrs. Joseph W. Donner and Mrs. Wallace S. Jordan are co-chairmen for the event.
E.R. Braithwaite and Louis Lomax were named joint winners yesterday of the $2,000 annual Anisfield-Wolf Award for books dealing "most creditably with social and group relations."

STRIPED bass are now all over both shores of Long Island, in the surf and in the inlets, taking bait as if starved. Most of them are small and maybe no more than a third or a half are keepers. But they are providing action not seen around here for years until last fall.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- President Kennedy urged Congress today to initiate a "total attack" on the growing menace of juvenile delinquency.
By a 3-to-2 vote a board of arbitration has upheld the discharge on April 26 of Samuel Resnick, a printer at The New York Times and chairman of The Times chapel of New York Typographical Union 6.
Leases of space in Manhattan buildings reported yesterday reflected expansion plans of several concerns.
President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia cautioned the United States last night against endorsing pan-African propaganda.

Radio and television sets caught the ears and eyes of more consumers in March than in February. Even so, however, the purchases for the first quarter ran somewhat below those for the 1960 period, according to the Electronic Industries Association.

NEW HAVEN, May 11 -- Yale University Library announced today that it was establishing a sound recordings program for the collection, preservation, study and republication of important recorded music and documents.
City school officials made surprise inspections yesterday of three antiquated public school buildings. They concluded that, ideally, these and similar buildings should be replaced.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The chairman of the Export-Import Bank denied today that a loan granted the Argentine Government's oil corporation and his ownership of stock in a drilling company associated with it had constituted a conflict of interest.
The ticklish issue of relations between the merged labor federation and the expelled International Brotherhood of Teamsters is causing new tension among the federation's feuding maritime unions.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 11 (AP) -- Premier Ali Amini announced today a fifteen-point program to fight corruption and save Iran from chaos.

AN indisputable masterpiece by the great French classical painter Claude Lorrain (1600-82) has been recently acquired by the Frick Collection and goes on view there today. This is "The Sermon on the Mount," a majestic landscape of deep and sparkling luminous vistas, in the center of which rises Mount Tabor from the summit of which Jesus is seen addressing the multitudes.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Senator Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania accused the Kennedy Administration today of trying to "suppress, manage and regulate" the flow of news that should be going to the American public.

BUFFALO, May 11 -- -John M. Bailey, the Democratic national chairman, hinted today that the Kennedy Administration was preparing to compromise on its differences with the state chairman, Michael H. Prendergast.

Boating is a sport that encourages novelties. Every now and then skippers wander off the beaten path (waterway, that is) and have their fun with a craft that is not conventional along cruiser lines with a battleship cut-water prow and a vertical stern transom.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These rates do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton exchange closed 9 points off to 4 points up yesterday. Only one contract rose. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 11 -- A commission set up to investigate the death of Patrice Lumumba, former Premier of the Congo, held its first session here today behind closed doors.
GENEVA, May 11 -- The meaning of neutrality, a rather straightforward business for the man in the street but an involved affair for diplomats, is what the conference on Laos is all about.
Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, has been questioned by state investigators who are looking into possible irregularities in the city's school construction program.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The nation's election-financing laws were attacked as outmoded, unrealistic and unfair today by three Senators. They testified on the first day of hearings on proposed spending reforms.

MANCHESTER, England, May 11 (Reuters) -- With centuries from Neil Harvey and Peter Burge, Australian cricketers today amassed 402 runs for eight wickets declared and a first-innings lead of 92 runs. However, Lancashire reduced its deficit with 42 for the loss of one second innings wicket by the close of play.
ATLANTA, May 11 -- Georgia Tech announced today it had accepted three Atlanta high school students from among thirteen Negro applicants for admission next fall.

KITCHAWAN, N.Y., May 11 -- The International Business Machines Corporation reported today that it would experiment to determine whether its corporate headquarters should be moved from Manhattan to a suburb.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- A Justice Department official urged Congress today to legalize telephone wiretapping by Federal and state police agencies and to permit the use of wiretap evidence in criminal trials.
A $1,000,000 grant to four colleges comprising the Atlanta, Ga., University Center was announced yesterday as a memorial to John D. Rockefeller Jr. on the first anniversary of his death.

Helen Hayes has extended her stay with the Theatre Guild American Repertory Company to cover a three-month tour of Latin America. Sixteen cities in ten countries will be visited, probably starting Aug. 13 in Caracas, Venezuela.
CHICAGO, May 11 -- Psychiatrists, who often find it easier to decide who is mentally ill than who is well, were presented today with a study of the normal man.
The stock market failed yesterday to break loose from its indecisiveness. After much churning, prices on the New York Stock Exchange ended down a bit on average.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 11 -- Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that he and his former Presidential aides would make a continuing review of the Kennedy Administration's domestic and foreign policies.

One could scarcely agree more with The Times' editorial on urban renewal of May 3 in so far as it recommends (to citizens with homes to protect) that there be less striking of attitudes and more attention to facts.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended last Saturday, were 10 per cent below the level of a year earlier.

STANGER, South Africa, May 11 -- Albert Luthuli, African nationalist leader, expressed fear today that the anti-Government demonstrations scheduled to take place later this month might lead to bloodshed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 11 -- Karl Malden is prepared to take one of the biggest gambles of his acting career. He is willing to abandon Hollywood for the theatre for at least two years if the repertory group planned for the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts will have him.

PERHAPS it is the recent weather, perhaps it is merely psychological, but this week's few adverse price changes seem to have taken all atmosphere of spring out of local food markets. Nevertheless the telltale signs are still there -- an abundance of lamb, good supplies of asparagus and low-price vegetables such as scallions and radishes.
ALBANY, May 11 -- Theodore F. Bowes, former United States Attorney for the Northern District of New York, was appointed to the Public Service Commission today by Governor Rockefeller.
The United Hospital Fund of New York yesterday named Donald M. Elliman president, to succeed Percy J. Ebbott, who was named chairman of the board.
CHICAGO, May (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Republican Congressmen and a spokesman for organized labor argued today whether the issue of taxes on dividends had been twisted into a misleading "rich guys against poor guys" debate.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Republican Congressional leaders termed the Geneva negotiations for a treaty to ban nuclear testing "a monumental stall" and urged President Kennedy today to set a time limit on the United States' participation in them.
Nassau County, L.I., is planning to borrow about $20,000,000 in the public bond market to finance public improvements. The bond sale is to be held early in June.

THE tiniest toddlers are likely to be the most chic creatures on the beach this summer. Designers have gone all out to create deceivingly practical yet gay, stylish beachwear suited to active children. A boon to mothers is the plethora of costumes that come in "one size for all," as well as fabrics such as baby-soft terry cloth and stretch knits that require no ironing.
As a member of the Committee to Save the West Village, I must take exception to your editorial of May 3 "Housing Study and Action."

GENEVA, May 11 -- The fourteen-nation conference on Laos is scheduled to open here tomorrow. However, the United States refused tonight to commit itself to participate pending verification of a cease-fire between the Government forces and the Communist-led rebels in the Indochinese kingdom.
BOSTON, May 11 (AP) -Carl Braun today said he has received "a very satisfactory offer" A to join the world champion Boston Celtics and would consider returning to professional basketball as a player.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., May 11 -- Allison Choate of Apawamis won the women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association tournament at Scarsdale Golf Club today she had a 39, 42 -- 81, seven over par. Mrs. James R. Hand of Sleepy Hollow finished with 42, 40 -- 82 for the second gross prize.
Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City dropped $71,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
The Crowell-Collier Publishing Company plans to expand its activities in the educational field through the acquisition of the La Salle Extension University.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) -- Representative Oren Harris, Chairman of the House Commerce Committee, today said he had reservations about President Kennedy's plan to reorganize the Federal Communications Commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ROME, May 11 -- Pope John XXIII added an Italian woman to the catalogue of saints in a ceremony today in St. Peter's Basilica. The saint is Bertilla Boscardin, who was born in Brendola, near Vicenza, in 1888.

PARIS, May 11 (Reuters) -An official report about a mysterious nosedive today heightened speculation here that the crash of a French airliner in the Sahara Wednesday was caused by sabotage or collision in the air.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, warned shipowners and operators today that his union "will not tolerate" a repetition of the "bad faith" he said they demonstrated in 1958 when the current three-year contract was negotiated.

PARAMUS, N.J., Friday, May 12 -- Tom Harnisch, a young Detroit bowler who has yet to win his first major tournament, took the lead early this morning in the $75,000 Professionally Bowlers Association invitation tournament at Paramus Bowling.

The Estate Securities Company, realty operators, have bought the twelve-story loft building at 10 East Thirty-third Street from James Arnold and have resold it to the Sales Realty Corporation. Pearce, Mayer Greer were the brokers in both deals.
MUSIC by two composers with similar backgrounds, William Mayer and William Sydeman, was played in Carnegie Recital Hall last night before an audience that nearly filled the auditorium.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Friday, May 12 -- Vice President Johnson told South Vietnam's National Assembly today the United States was ready immediately to help South Vietnam increase its 150,000-man regular military forces by a substantial number.

Mrs. Ida Exle, a 75-year-old widow from Budapest, was reunited yesterday with her foster son, a nephew, after a twenty-year separation. It took a special act of Congress that provided, for immigration purposes, that Mrs. Exle "shall be held and considered to be the natural mother" of her nephew.
BOSTON, May 11. -- Formal consolidation of the American Unitarian Association and the Universalist Church of America was achieved today.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 11 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles turned clutch hitting and five Minnesota errors into an 8-7 victory today.

In the wake of the furore caused by the criticism of television programing by Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, a review of television sponsorships for the coming season finds the advertisers in a vulnerable position.
DENVER, May 11 (AP) -- The Young Women's Christian Association at its national convention today urged greater efforts toward complete racial integration of its facilities and activities.

AT this season eggs are low in cost (and likely to remain so until the outside temperatures soar) and many a new wife is about to enter her new kitchen. So now seems a good time to review some of the basic methods of egg cookery.
The Government announced yesterday a revised war-risk insurance program for merchant shipping.

Events today: Ilana Vered, pianist, and Laurel Miller, mezzo-soprano, Town Hall, 5:15 P.M.; New Chamber Music, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; Sounds and Movements, a program of progressive jazz and modern dance, Hunter College Assembly Hall 8:30; Mannes Chorus, with soloists and instrumentalists, Mannes College of Music, 8:30; "La Forza del Destino," presented by Opera Workshop, Public School 75, West End Avenue and Ninety- fifth Street, 8.

The most important collective bargaining of 1961 will be the negotiations this summer between the Big Three auto manufacturers and Walter P. Reuther's United Automobile Workers. The union has recently completed its preparations for these crucial talks by giving its leaders what amounts to a blank check to press for a broad list of contract changes involving more money and more job security.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. May 11 -- In Afghanistan cotton is second only to karakul pelts as a source of foreign exchange. Within the last decade the crop has assumed great significance, as the country forged ahead with the development of a promising export trade in the staple.

GROTON, Conn., May 11 (AP) -- Pierre Sevigny, associate defense minister of Canada, said today that "the need for a naval force capable of insuring the freedom of the seas is greater than it has ever been before."
Pacific Gas and Electric Company reported yesterday sizable gains in operating revenues and net income for twelve months ended on March 31.

Three men and a woman were arrested yesterday in the investigation of the killing of a private detective during a payroll robbery in Queens last Wednesday. The woman was identified as an employe of the Globe Lighting Products Company in Maspeth, where the robbery took place.

Manhattan Borough President Edward R. Dudley ordered a speed-up in street repairs yesterday. He summoned the entire inspection force to his office and warned that he would "no longer tolerate" any "loafing on the job."

The Northside Center for Child Development, a psychiatric clinic for emotionally disturbed children in Harlem, will receive the proceeds of a public auction the evening of May 23 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries.
The Federal Maritime Board rejected yesterday an application of file American-Hawaiian Steamship Company for Government aid in building three huge new ships for the inter-coastal trade.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that folk singing, with instrumental accompaniment, would be permitted tomorrow afternoon in Washington Square "on a controlled basis."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 12 -- The Soviet Union intimated today that it might bring the question of racial discrimination in South Africa before the Security Council.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 12 (UPI) -- Tony Bettenhausen's car burst into flames after tearing through the 8-foot-high wire fence. Track officials said he was killed instantly.

YONKERS, May 12 -- Su Mac Lad, who swept the three-race international trot series, is the early 7-5 favorite for the $15,000 Monitor Trot Handicap at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night. Su Mac Lad will start from the No. 8 post position.
Sir Julian Huxley charged yesterday that the Roman Catholic Church had exerted pressure on the World Health Organization to kill any policy discussion of the world's population.

The African Research Foundation will be the beneficiary of a jazz concert to be given next Friday at Carnegie Hall. It will feature Miles Davis and an orchestra conducted by Gil Evans. Tickets may be obtained from the box office or from the foundation at 333 East Forty-sixth Street.
PARIS, May 12 -- The world's leading trading nations decided today to wind up seven-month-old technical tariff negotiations and proceed to the long-awaited bargaining on general tariff reductions.
LONDON, May 12 -- A leading British industrialist asserted today that Americans were determined to prevent Britain from making any commercial use of outer space.
What lessons have we learned from the failure of American intelligence and diplomacy in Cuba and Laos?
A FRONTAL attack on the Cub Scouts was made last week-end by a child-development specialist who called the organization not merely unnecessary but "harmful."
PALM BEACH, Fla., May 12 -- President Kennedy played twelve holes of golf today under a hot Florida sun that sent the temperature up to 88 degrees.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 12 (AP) -- James Howard Bishop, 68 years old, an instructor at Culver Military Academy in Culver, Ind., died in an auto accident today about thirty miles north of Grand Rapids.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A large chemical company received a patent this week for a baseball bat. The inventor holds a Ph. D. in physical chemistry from Yale and is president of the Connecticut Patent Law Association.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The National Association of Securities Dealers announced today that it had expelled eleven of its members for alleged violations of the group's rules of fair practice.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 12 -- Members of the United States Congress visited the United Nations today and were told that the world organization should be one of the pillars of United States foreign policy.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 12 (AP) -- Tony Bettenhausen, one of the leading drivers in American auto racing, was killed today in a car he was testing for a friend. He was 44 years old.
LOS ANGELES, May 12 (AP) -- Sandy Koufax of the Los Angeles Dodgers turned back the Chicago Cubs tonight, 4 -- 2. He struck out eleven and allowed only four hits before 17,122 fans.
FORT WORTH, May 12 (AP) Mike Souchak played cautiously in wind today, carding a par 7C and taking the lead at the 36-hole mark of the $40,000 Colonial national invitation golf tournament.

The New York Mercantile Exchange echoed yesterday with some of the most excited trading in its twenty-year history. The highlight of the session was the liquidation of the largest open commitment for any potato contract on its day of expiration.
CHICAGO, May 12 -- "Quite a place!"

CLEVELAND, May 12 (AP) -- Jim Gentile drove in two runs with his tenth homer and Brooks Robinson got three singles in four times at bat in leading the Baltimore Orioles to a 4-2 victory over the Indians tonight.

GENEVA, May 12 -- The opening of the international meeting on the future of Laos was postponed today because of an effort by the Soviet Union to win equal status at the conference table for the Communist-led Pathet Lao rebels.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- About forty wives of truck drivers picketed the White House today, protesting what they called selective rate-cutting by the railroads.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets were 0.2 per cent lower during the week ended last Tuesday, declining to 119.1 per cent of their 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies equaled their longest losing streak since 1956 tonight when they dropped their tenth straight game, 5-1, to the St. Louis Cardinals.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 12 -- The Thai Minister of the Interior was quoted today as having said Thailand had no intention of withdrawing from the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization and aligning herself with the neutrals.

The United States, which rejected a Soviet bid yesterday to seat pro-Communist Pathet Lao representatives at the Geneva conference table, was faced with a similar problem at a foreign ministers' conference in Geneva in May, 1959.
The steel picture continues to brighten in most districts around the country. Several companies reported yesterday that orders were improving and workers were being recalled.

LONDON, May 12 -- Increased profit taking caused some industrial share groups to turn irregular in the stock market here today, but gains still predominated, lifting The Financial Times index to a record high.

AN overcall is usually made to interfere with the opponents' bidding, to guide partner's opening lead or to find a sacrifice contract. Seldom does an overcall result in a game contract, for the simple reason that the opponent's opening bid will usually include enough high-card strength to stop a game.

Once again, stocks failed yesterday to set a clear-cut pattern. After much milling around, prices ended with a slight gain on average on the New York Stock Exchange. The market thus closed out the week on the same indecisive note that had prevailed for five days.

MOSCOW, May 12 -- Premier Khrushchev insisted today that communism would gain control of the world one day -- and without using bayonets or rockets. The Soviet people, he declared, are "the freest" people in the world.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- From the Right and Left, from the campus and from within Government itself President Kennedy's tax legislation was criticized today.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Industrial production showed a strong pick-up in April, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Air Force announced plans today for a special course of instruction to train space pilots.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 12 (AP) -- Pedro Ramos, the pitcher, abandoned his switch-hitting tactics today and drove in three runs in the Minnesota Twins' 5-4 triumph over the Los Angeles Angels.
The Broadway Presbyterian Church has called the Rev. Dr. Stuart Hamilton Merriam to be its pastor. He will preach his first sermon as pastor there tomorrow.

BUCKINGHAM, Va., May 12 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, today blamed the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People for the school situation in Prince Edward County.

A one-day strike of drivers for the United Parcel Service stopped deliveries of parcels on hundreds of trucks at thirty-five sorting stations yesterday. The walkout was settled last night and deliveries will be resumed today.

Mrs. Auguste Redman, a widely known tenement owner who has just completed a three-month jail sentence for housing violaions, appeared in Housing Court again yesterday to answer charges contained in twenty-four warrants.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 12 -- Vice President Johnson promised today that the United States would cooperate "shoulder to shoulder" with South Vietnam to erase social ills and raise living standards in this embattled country.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 12 -- An advance guard of the Rightwing Government's delegation to the Geneva conference left here today. Gen. Phoumi Nosavan, defense chief in Prince Boun Oum's Cabinet, is expected to depart tomorrow.
The first joint collective bargaining session between West and East Coast steamship companies and a maritime union began here yesterday.

Broadstreet's, Inc., a chain of men's clothing stores, has leased a floor at 44 West Eighteenth Street through Charles Klatskin of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., broker. Adams Co., Real Estate, Inc., is the agent for the building.
A major step toward Protestant unity in this country is expected to be taken on May 22 in Buffalo at the General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.

PITTSBURGH, May 12 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates ended the Cincinnati Reds' winning streak at nine games with an 8-5 triumph tonight. Rocky Nelson and Dick Stuart, a pinch-hitter, led the way with three-run homers.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The International Development Association made its first loan today -- $9,000,000 to Honduras for highway development.
ONE of the few evidences of brightness on these dank days when Manhattan seems to be anchored at the bottom of a tank in an aquarium are occasional works of art lighting up galleries like good deeds.
CHICAGO, May 12 (UPI) -- Thousands of persons fought a weary battle against flooding rivers in the Midwest today.
Oklahoma sold yesterday $2,000,000 of industrial finance bonds secured by general taxation. The obligations will come due Jan. 1, 1991.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 12 -- Americans love The Hague. They are always telling Dutch friends how charming they find the city's eighteenth-century facade. The Dutch respond warmly because there is a community attachment to this distinctive appearance and atmosphere.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) -- Researchers say "women may be better space drivers than men." Their opinion is based on a year of simulated space flights at the Martin Company's installation in Baltimore.

Daniel Perlsweig, the trainer of Thomas Lutz's Concert Tour, was suspended for sixty days and was denied admission to New York thoroughbred tracks for that period by the stewards at Aqueduct yesterday. The penalties will run from today through Tuesday, July 11.
The President's proposal to limit the tax advantage now enjoyed by American firms that have foreign subsidiaries stems logically from the new economic circumstances of the Nineteen Sixties.
The Presidential commission studying the issues behind the February strike of airline flight engineers concluded four days of intensive mediation with the parties involved yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union, joined two maritime union leaders today in a new move toward labor unity in the transportation field. After a two-hour meeting Mr. Hoffa, Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, and Capt. William V. Bradley, head of the International Longshoremen's Association, announced agreement to enter into a formal mutual assistance pact.

" THE country was rich, the weather fine, the forts abandoned. The column, seven miles long, clanked its way forward under a pall of fine dust -- the Mounted Infantry in front, followed by a caterpillar of bobbing turbans or topees or forage-caps, the advance-guard of Sikhs or Fusiliers, Pathans or Gurkhas: behind them the main body, a long stretch of it taken up by the fine upstanding mules of the mountain batteries.
The broadened demand for United States Government securities that became visible in mid-week was more emphatic yesterday as the market trading week came to a close.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 12 -- Adolf Eichmann was depicted by the prosecution today as having moved to block the last avenue of escape for European Jews in 1941.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 (AP) -- Warren Spahn, aided by three home runs, pitched the Milwaukee Braves to a 5-4 victory over the San Francisco Giants tonight.
An investigation into the recent slaying of a Manhattan restaurant owner led yesterday to the arrest of five men on charges of attempted extortion.

The fees paid from 1958 through 1960 by Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., to the law firm in which one of its directors is a partner exceeded the transit company's earnings by $111,460, it was reported yesterday in State Supreme Court.
HAVANA, May 12 -- The expulsion of foreign Roman Catholic priests from Cuba by the Government was given warm support last night in a broadcast by the Rev. Guillermo Sardinas, a Cuban Catholic priest.
WASHINGTON. May 12 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautic Board refused today to reconsider its approval of the merger of United Air Lines and Capital Airlines.

The tentative credit package assembled in Washington by the so-called Aid-to-India Club has fallen considerably short of estimated needs for the first two years of India's third five-year plan, which began April 1. Unless some members increase their pledges and alter their terms, India will have to readjust her development schedule.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) -- Administration spokesmen urged the Senate today to extend the Defense Education Act. However, they remained silent on the controversial question of additional aid for private schools.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 12 -- Rain slowed the opening of this city's second annual art show today but did not dampen the spirits of 125 artists, some from California.
A group of sixth-grade scholars in upper Manhattan have brought history up to date. The youngsters, pupils at Public School 152, have just published a revised history of their Dyckman Valley area.
Seventeen countries have indicated their intention of participating in the First International Television Assembly. It will be held here in November.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A Pentagon spokesman said today that the Administration had introduced new classification criteria to prevent public disclosure of the nation's intelligence-gathering techniques.

NGO DINH DIEM, President of South Vietnam, has been described by an American diplomat as a "sound and tenacious leader" and by some of his country's principal politicians as a dictator who has denied his people their liberty.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points down to 6 points up yesterday.

The Board of Estimate handed Mayor Wagner a rebuff on Charter revision last night. By a vote of 14 to 8 it approved a bill drafted and enacted by the City Council setting up the Council's own Charter revision plan.

PARAMUS, N.J., Saturday, May 13 -- Bob Chase, a young bowler from Prairie Village, Kan., was the medalist in the $75,000 Professional Bowlers Association tournament, which ended its qualifying round early this morning at Paramus Bowling.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 12 -- Congolese leaders made public today a project for a "United States of the Congo" with a strong central Government.
The city's Purchase Commissioner plans to report all identical bids received by him to the Federal Trade Commission, the United States Attorney here and the Corporation Counsel.
Union pressmen on the major daily newspapers in the metropolitan area voted last night to accept a new two-year contract with the Publishers Association of New York City. The vote was 474 to 312.

Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia today regained the world chess championship by defeating Mikhail Tal of Latvia in the twenty-first game of the scheduled twenty-four game match, according to Tass, the official Soviet news agency.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The chairman of the Senate Elections subcommittee foresaw some chance today for legislation granting small tax credits to contributors to political campaigns. Such legislation, he said, stands a better chance than proposals for direct Federal fund aid to political parties or candidates.
MONROVIA, Liberia, May 12 (AP) -- Leaders of twenty African nations regarded as pro-Western or uncommitted reaffirmed tonight their faith in the United Nations.

Assuming that initial snags are cleared away, the Geneva Conference on Laos will convene with only one thing definitely assured: a complicated and arduous meeting. It is impossible to say whether the conference will produce anything more than that.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Bill Monbouquette struck out seventeen batters, one short of the modern major league record, as he pitched the Boston Red Sox to a 2-1 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.

The Board of Estimate voted 18 to 4 yesterday to let a nonprofit cooperative corporation purchase and operate the $26,669,000 Luna Park Houses in Brooklyn. The 1,576-apartment project has been finished by the New York City Housing Authority.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub matches were interrupted by rain yesterday. Only two series were played in Long Island and three in Westchester. Four of five were completed in New Jersey.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 12 -- President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia, who only a few years ago walked among the disgruntled and little-known lobbyists here, returned today in a flush of ceremonial pomp.
An active period is forecast next week for the new capital market, with $222,455,000 of fixed-interest securities slated for marketing.
The Armed Forces put their best faces forward -- five faces, to be precise -- in the opening event of Armed Forces Week.

Latin America has seen many rigged elections in its history but none more outrageous than the proceedings of May 7 in Haiti. President Francois Duvalier chose fifty-eight deputies for his National Assembly and forced a certain number of Haitians to go to the polls and vote for them. At the same time he slipped in his own name for "re-election" as President, although his term of office does not end until May 15, 1963.
People who thought they saw the cherubic face of Walter Slezak under a white riveter's helmet on West Sixty-sixth Street yesterday afternoon were right.

" The History of the United States Flag," by Milo M. Quaife, Melvin J. Weig and Roy E. Appleman, will be published by Harper on June 14 in honor of Flag Day. The book describes and illustrates the flags adopted by the American Colonies during the Revolution, the earliest regimental colors, naval pennants, mercantile flags and the Stars and Stripes in its many changes throughout the years.
E.J. Korvette, Inc., is in a position to increase its holdings in Alexander's Department Stores, Inc., it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy announced today an income tax evasion indictment against Metro M. Holovachka, former prosecuting attorney for Lake County, Ind., who was a balky witness before the Senate rackets committee two years ago.
Whether in unresolved doubt or by devious design, Mayor Wagner has created a real question mark as to whether he will seek a third term at City Hall.

Washington, like New York, will have its free Shakespeare in the park this summer. The founder and organizer of the venture is Ellie Chamberlain, who once worked with Joseph Papp's Shakespeare Festival in Central Park.
There was a modern music marathon late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, with fourteen new compositions in a two-and-a-quarter-hour stretch without intermission.
Two teen-aged boys were captured in Central Park yesterday after they had snatched a nurse's pocketbook containing her life's savings of $6,000.

AUGSBURG, Germany, May 12 (UPI) -- A reporter for an American - owned newspaper that accused a United States general of indoctrinating his troops with John Birch Society literature has been ordered to face a slander charge filed by the general.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 12 (UPI) -- A giant brush fire, fanned by forty-mile-an-hour winds, burned to within 100 yards of the Griffith Park Observatory tonight, destroyed an undetermined number of houses in the Hollywood hills and forced hundreds of people to flee their homes.
HAVANA, May 12 (Reuters) -- Communist China has responded to an appeal by Premier Fidel Castro for support against possible "United States aggression."

For one of the few times in the history of organized securities trading volume on the American Stock Exchange yesterday topped that on the New York Stock Exchange. On the American Board, 5,430,000 shares changed hands, second only to the record turnover of 7,096,300 shares on the New York Curb Exchange, its predecessor, on Oct. 29, 1929.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) -- President Kennedy said today that the times called for action, change and liberalism to regain the historic social momentum of the American Revolution.
MEXICO CITY, May 12 (AP) -- Two Cuban diplomats -- man and wife defected yesterday and predicted the struggle against the regime of Premier Fidel Castro would "continue and succeed."
Members of the staff of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union voted yesterday whether to have a union of their own.
CHICAGO, May 12 -- An almost complete reversal in public opinion toward mental illness has occurred during the last decade, according to a Baltimore study that was reported here today.

The industrial property at 585 Gerard Avenue and 570 River Road, facing the Major Deegan Boulevard at 150th Street, the Bronx, has been leased by Charles S. McVeigh and the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company, as trustees, to a client of Joseph Fischer.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 12 (AP) -- The Air Force fired an Atlas missile 5,000 miles tonight and demonstrated that it apparently had solved problems that had plagued the new, more powerful version of the intercontinental range weapon.
Your editorial of April 28 on General Salan and Spain does honor to the unrelenting opposition you display toward my country.

All of last night's thunder did not come from the sky. Some of it emanated from the Yankee Stadium, where Frank Lary blasted a long home run in the ninth inning for the Detroit Tigers and gained a 4-3 triumph over the Yankees.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 12 (AP) -- Economists predicted privately today that the nation's annual production would rise to a record rate of more than $525,000,000,000 by the end of the year.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 12 (AP) -- Standard Oil Company (Indiana) through its Australian subsidiary, Amoco, Australia, Pty., Ltd., said yesterday it was seeking a Sydney harbor-side site for an oil terminal and forty city sites for gasoline service stations.
CHICAGO, May 12 (UPI) -- Early Wynn pitched a four-hitter tonight for his 287th major-league victory as the Chicago White Sox won, 2 -- 1, from the Kansas City Athletics.
More than 200 parents whose children attend Public School 129 in the College Point section of Queens are opposing plans by school authorities to split up the elementary school next fall.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 12 (AP) -- Basil (The Owl) Banghart, racketeer, mail robber and kidnapper in the prohibition era, was granted parole from Stateville Penitentiary today.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) -- American Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to stay its decision in the controversial Southern transcontinental service case.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 12 -- James F. Tingley of the Nassau Country Club won the qualifying medal in the Walter J. Travis Memorial golf tournament with a 76 today. In doing so, he followed the suggestion of a club-mate, Bob Kirsky.

FORT DIX, N.J., May 12 (UPI) -- Boxers from the United States, Italy and the United Arab Republic scored victories in the final rounds of the fourteenth annual international boxing championships tonight. Americans won five, Italy three and the U.A.R. two.
OTTAWA, May 12 -- Canada moved today to aid her ailing shipbuilding industry and reduce competition for Canadian vessels operating in domestic trade in the Great Lakes.
A succession of gray, sodden days prompted the Weather Bureau yesterday to stand by its gray, sodden forecast for the rest of May.
The nuclear weapons conference held this month in Oslo was discussed here last night by Dr. Linus Pauling.

Your editorial of April 26 "Paying for the Highways" displays a commendable interest in good roads. It also displays, in my judgment, a distressing lack of understanding of how the national highway program is actually financed.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 -- If this country's offbeat tastes are spawned in such uninhibited spots as the bistros of this city's North Beach district, look out for a wave of Bohemianism combining the chi chi of Paris and the breeziness of San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) -- Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. said today it was time Congress clarified thirty-one disputed words about wiretapping that judges, prosecutors and civil rights advocates have haggled over for twenty-seven years.

PARIS, May 12 -- Events have once again forced us to reconsider all the implications, in terms of ultimate survival, of what we so proudly call our open society. WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, declared in Congressional testimony released today that the United States was "militarily the most powerful nation in the world."

THE budgeter with a gift to give might take a look at the Elder Craftsmen Shop, 850 Lexington Avenue, at Sixty-fourth Street. Here, a gay pair of colorful chintz pot holders, folded to form "butterflies," can be purchased for $2. A sweet-smelling jar of potpourri for the dressing table or to scent a lingerie drawer comes embellished with velvet ribbon and an artificial posy for $1.50.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 12 -- The General Assembly has completed legislative action on a nonresident tax bill as part of an agreement with New York State. Under it Connecticut will turn over to New York employment and salary information on New Yorkers who work in this state.

A COMELY Englishwoman, visiting America for the first time, has been sending postcards to the folks back home inscribed with the message, "With love from Joyce, the only woman in New York without a mink stole."

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman ordered the old wheat-control program into effect today for the grain crop of 1962. He expressed hope, however, that Congress would authorize a more effective program in time to make a change.

MANILA, May 13 -- South Vietnam and the United States have agreed on an eight-point program for increased American military and economic assistance.
