WASHINGTON, May 14 -- An effort may be made in the House tomorrow to push through a bill setting up sweeping controls over "foreign political propaganda" mailed to this country from abroad.

The explosive rate of growth of the world's population was described last week by Marriner Eccles, former chairman of the board of the Federal Reserve System, as the "most vitally important problem facing the world today," which may well prove to be "more explosive than the atomic or hydrogen bomb." Other distinguished participants at an international symposium on the world population crisis agreed with him.
The United States will shortly make its first attempt to hit the moon. The target is the Ocean of Storms on the edge of the moon.
Liberal elements in the South are beginning to feel a real difference in support from the Executive Branch of the Government, a Unitarian minister from Georgia said here yesterday.
The Yankees needed 6 hours 42 minutes to make it, but in the end, which came at 8:42 o'clock last night, they had gained their objective.

When President Kennedy called his five-year program of Federal action against juvenile delinquency a "total attack" he made it sound like a far larger operation than could be mounted with the $10 million proposed to Congress for the first year's expenses.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 14 -- The United States Ambassador, Robert Newbegin, was called to Washington today for consultations.
The "safe to pass" wave of the arm traditionally given by drivers of slow-moving over-the-road trucks may soon become a thing of the past.
The annual awards of the New York Press Photographers Association, Inc., were made Saturday night at the Astor Hotel.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- With the recession now officially ended, the attention of economists turns to whether the recovery will be gradual or brisk.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 14 -- Peter Jurow of Adelphi won the singles title and Hofstra the team title in the first Athletic Association of Long Island Colleges tennis championships today at the Hofstra College courts.

BAYPORT, L.I., May 14 -- Susan Jolly of Garden City, L.I., rode Peppermint, owned by the Thomas School of Horsemanship, in the open jumper and horsemanship championships today at the third annual Equitation Lodge horse show.
CHICAGO, May 14 (AP) -The backlash of a wintry storm that smothered parts of Wyoming and Colorado with heavy snows and wind-whipped drifts hit the Midwest today with punishing thunderstorms.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 14 -- The measure of the Actor's Workshop as a repertory company is the skill with which it has presented such disparate and difficult pieces as "King Lear," "A Touch of the Poet" and "The Birthday Party" on successive evenings.

PERFUME is as much a part of the French personality as the French accent. From the time a girl is a baby, light cologne is used in her daily regime, according to Mlle. Denise Minet. And at the age of 10, she graduates to real perfume -- long before she even thinks about make-up.

CHICAGO, May 14 (UPI) -- Joe Nuxhall, a former National Leaguer scored his first American League victory today as the Kansas City Athletics defeated the Chicago White Sox, 5 -- 3, in the second game of a double-header.
Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell's resignation as minister of the Fifh Avenue Presbyterian Church was accepted yesterday and he was made minister emeritus.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 14 -- The movie career of the works of Marcel Proust is becoming as complex as his sentence structure.
IN spite of what some people think, it really is not easy to write music today.
NAMONE, Laos, May 14 -- Government and rebel negotiators began discussions today on the knotty questions involved in achieving a military and political settlement of the Laotian civil war.

Four hundred and forty acres of land in Palm Springs, Calif., have been leased for seventy years from eighteen families of the Agua Caliente Band of Mission Indians. A residential and recreational community representing an investment of $50,000,000 will be constructed on the tract, according to the lessees, the First National Realty and Construction Corporation of New York.

GOLDENS BRIDGE, N. Y., May 14 -- Tom's Delight, a 6-year-old black and white English setter owned and handled by Tom Mazzaccaro of Rutherford, N. J., won the Amateur Gun Dog Stake that ended the annual Southern New York Field Trial Club competition today.

It is encouraging that The Times, in its May 4 editorial "Textile Quotas Are Unsound," recognizes at least one, if not the most glaring, injustice imposed upon the textile industry in its fight for survival in a world exploding in advanced technological gains -- namely, the two-price cotton system.

A former Roman Catholic missionary in China said yesterday that the Chinese Communists' brainwashing of missionaries had led to "repeated confessions of their 'crimes against the Chinese Red republic.'"
Unnecessary exposure of patients and operating personnel to radiation has been disclosed by a two-year survey of medical and dental X-ray equipment.

A potent new entertainment personality, Oscar Brown Jr., made his first concert appearance in New York Saturday night at Carnegie Hall as part of a program called "Blues at Carnegie Hall." The concert also included four blues singers -- Jimmy Witherspoon, Muddy Waters, Big Maybelle and Jimmy Reed.

Harry Horwitz, realty investor, has sold the northwest corner of Third Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, which is now occupied by a parking lot. The property, 102 feet on the avenue and ninety feet on the street, has been acquired by the S.S. Silberblatt Construction Company for improvement with an office building.
GRUENBERG, Poland, May 15 -- The fields of rye here already stand high enough to hide the toddlers herding the cows hope for milking.

Washington Square yesterday afternoon saw the peaceful coexistence of scores of folk singers and hundreds of their fans, swarms of playing children, thousands of Sunday strollers, chess players, sun worshipers and fifty-five policemen.

GENEVA, May 14 -- The Swiss stock markets took off again last Monday from the new highs reached the week before, then fell the next two days. The market was closed Thursday because of a religious holiday and closed Friday as well.

It is a fine thing for the city to acquire, as it is about to do, ten new parks and major park additions in four boroughs. But what is the logic of pouring millions of dollars into such a venture while at the same time hacking away at existing parks by gobbling up large amounts of their acreage for rights-of-way for roads?

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 14 (UPI) -- Bob Allison's sacrifice fly in the eighth inning scored Harmon Killebrew with the winning run as Minnesota beat Los Angeles, 4 -- 3, today for a sweep of the three-game series.
Another new, large oil tanker, the fourth in recent months, has been sold to the Soviet Union.
Al Filardi, a substitute at the beginning of the 1960-61 season, will be the captain of New York University's basketball team next winter.
International airlines meeting in Montreal are near an agreement on trans-Atlantic air cargo rates, according to a source close to the conference.

We Westerners, who live in a semi-colonial condition, were resigned to having our affairs run by the Washington-New York power elite so long as it was reasonably competent. However, the Cuban debacle has made us wonder if our fates are not in the hands of an incompetent elite within the elite.
Murray P. and Ralph B. Lennard have contracted to buy the three-story garden apartment buildings at 221 Middle Neck Road, Great Neck, L.I. They plan to syndicate the property.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 14 (AP) -- A Milwaukee pitcher, Ron Piche, walked a pinch-batter, Matty Alou, with the bases filled in the ninth inning today, enabling the San Francisco Giants to score an 8-7 victory over the Braves.

L. Judson Morhouse, Republican state chairman, charged yesterday that "scuttling of worthwhile Charter revision is the price Mayor Wagner will pay for re-election support by the Democratic machine bosses."
NOT often does a church choir have the temerity to invade a concert hall. On Saturday night in Judson Hall, one did, and proved an interesting thesis in the process.
Representative Hale Boggs, Democrat of Louisiana, is a strong advocate of the idea of building the Western Alliance through the exchange of business contacts and he said so in a speech last week.
MIAMI, May 14 -- The plight of Cuban refugees has become far more serious both for the exiles and for relief workers as a result of the failure of the April 17 rebel landing in Cuba.

THIS is the season for a shift in sugar bowls, with the advent of iced beverages such as tea and coffee; lump sugar in many dining places gives way to the loose varieties in shakers open sugar bowls or packets. The reason is obvious: Lump sugar melts readily in hot drinks, the loose sugar more readily in cold liquids.
PALM BEACH, Fla., May 14 (AP) -- President Kennedy heard a special tribute to his mother at mass today, and sent to anti-Castro Cuban mothers "a message of hope" that freedom will come.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 14 (AP) -- With a few stitches on a treadle machine, Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson symbolically sewed uniforms today for the Chinese Nationalist armed forces. So did Mrs. Stephen E. Smith, President Kennedy's sister.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $81,026,194,959. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:

Atomic Physics and Science Fund, Inc., announced over the week-end that it was offering its shares in the metropolitan District of Columbia area through Central Charge Service, Inc. The latter group's approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission as a broker-dealer became effective last Friday.

Not since the Nineteen Thirties, when such places as the Cotton Club, Small's Paradise and The Nest flourished in Harlem, have so many customers from downtown Manhattan been traveling to an uptown cabaret.

Your editorial of May 1 on "Automation Unemployment" should hearten readers who still believe that chronic or structural joblessness has subtle and unexpected, as well as proximate and obvious, sources; and that, accordingly, wide-ranging economic policies have to be devised and adopted by private groups as well as public bodies to support whatever direct legislative actions may be taken.

HERMOSILLO, Mexico, May 14 -- One demonstrator was reported killed by gunfire today as the police broke up a political rally of about 4,000 persons here. Seven demonstrators were wounded by the gunfire and at least eight others were hospitalized for treatment of tear gas used by the police.
MOSCOW, May 14 (Reuters) -- A woman has been sentenced to five years in a labor colony for "categorically refusing to work," the Soviet trade union newspaper Trud reported today.

Three works of art will be given away at the second annual Collector's Choice Cocktail Party on June 6 at the St. Regis Roof. Proceeds of the event will go to the Hudson Guild Neighborhood House at 436 West Twenty-seventh Street.
A BEHIND-THE-SCENES look at the headquarters of the United Nations was provided in an informative telecast on "International Zone" on Channel 4 yesterday.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 14 (AP) -- Skin divers have located wreckage of two ships, one atop the other, which they believe clears up the mystery of the bark Adonis and the freighter Rusland.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Monday, May 15 -- Vice President Johnson has given him a pledge of continued, unqualified United States support for the free Republic of China. President Chiang Kai-shek said today.

POUND, Va., May 14 (AP) -- Francis Gary Powers, the pilot of the U-2 plane downed over the Soviet Union, has denied categorically reports that he planned to remain in the Soviet Union when he was released from a Soviet prison.
PITTSBURGH, May 14 -- Demand for most steel products improved last week. Practically all steel companies reported gains.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 14 -- The police here have been gathering evidence for Austrians handling the case of Franz Murer of Steier.

Tom Ewell has his eye on "The Mirror Under the Eagle" for his next stage appearance. The star and Martin Manulis, film producer, are on the verge of buying Philip C. Lewis' cavalcade of the American stage.

IT'S still much too early to hang a team-of-destiny label on the Detroit Tigers. But they have provided the major surprise of the new season by sprinting into the league lead behind impressive pitching, the sparkling play of rookie infielders and the solid strength of an outfield that may be the best in the big leagues.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The Washington Senators got superb pitching from Joe McClain and Bennie Daniels and swept a double-header from the Boston Red Sox today, 3-0 and 2-1.
GENEVA, May 14 -- What was to have been a fourteen-nation conference on Laos has started to develop into a sixteen-ring propaganda circus.
An orphan of the sea, deserted and uncared for for several months, appears to have found a set of foster parents.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (AP) -- Run-scoring singles by Clay Dalrymple and Lee Walls resulted in a two-run eighth inning for the Philadelphia Phillies and a 6-4 victory today over the St. Louis Cardinals.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Kennedy has named two well-known capital figures to the board of private citizens he re-established early this month to make a continuing study of the Government's intelligence activities.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 14 -- Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Abraham A. Ribicoff said here today that the nation was "just drifting" in the welfare field and that he and social work leaders would seek a new approach to it.
LONDON, May 14 -- Industrial share prices surged upward in the stock market again last week.
Three thousand persons honored the entertainment industry's stagehands last night during a Diamond Jubilee dinner of the Theatrical Stage Employes Union at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Norwegian and American flags flew side-by-side in bright sunshine yesterday in Brooklyn as 7,000-Norwegian-Americans paraded on Eighth Avenue in the Bay Ridge section.

LANCASTER, Pa., May 14 -A 14-month-old red chow, Pandee's Red Sing, owned by Imogene P. Earle of Laurel, Md., completed her championship today, then went on to win best in show over 650 dogs in the sixteenth annual Lancaster Kennel Club fixture.

Bobby Riggs, the 1960 winner, was upset yesterday by Paul Cranis in the final of the national paddle tennis tournament at Carl Schurz Park. Cranis triumphed, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 8, 6 -- 4, in the two-hour match.
THIS deal comes from Texas Bridge, a bi-monthly magazine published in Houston, which is among the more elaborate of the seventy-odd bridge periodicals published in the United States.

ANNISTON, Ala., May 15 -- A group of white persons ambushed today two buses carrying Negroes and whites who are seeking to knock down bus station racial barriers. A lit tle later, sixty miles to the west, one of the buses ran into another angry crowd of white men at a Birmingham bus station.
BALTIMORE, May 14 (AP) -- The outlook for Saturday's $150,000 added Preakness was brightened today by good medical reports on ailing Crozier and Globemaster.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., May 14 -- Walter Crump's Banana Split, a Tigercat from the Noroton (Conn.) fleet, captured the Division One honors in the third annual two-day multihull regatta sponsored by the Sea Cliff Yacht Club.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 14 -- Gen. of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower is finding out the hard way that private life in retirement is not all he thought it would be -- not yet, anyway.

CANNES, France, May 14 -An independently made American feature, "The Connection," has become the surprise hit of the Cannes Film Festival, where it had its world premiere at a noncompetitive showing this morning.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 14 -- Skip Wallace of Syracuse the medalist, advanced to the semi-finals today in the thirty fourth annual tournament of the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association.

WE are apt to forget what an incredibly direct and sensuous act painting is -- a touching, a caressing, a movement of something eloquent and wordless through the fingers. This reflection is provoked by two current exhibitions -- Kumi Sugai at the Kootz Gallery, 655 Madison Avenue, and Guillermo Heiter at the Angeleski Gallery, 1044 Madison Avenue.
Sunshine, the warmest day of the year and the end of a rain-drenched week drew New Yorkers out of their homes yesterday for Mother's Day and a long-awaited look at approaching summer.
ATLANTA, May 14 -- The words of "America the Beautiful" rang out from the old brick church and were drowned in the roar of the Diesel rigs rolling on U.S. 1.

The so-called "tax-free exchange funds" continue to attract investors' attention. These are the funds that allow an investor to exchange -- tax-free at the moment of exchange -- his own shares in individual issues for shares in a new mutual fund that is set up to amass its portfolio by that means.

While a wailing baby in church is enough competition for most clergymen, there is a rector in Greenwich Village whose Sunday sermons compete with the rumble of buses, squeaks of perambulators, grinding of roller skates and, occasionally, the bongos of beatniks.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- An Air Force general says that the Soviet Union may soon be able to control space and prevent manned or unmanned United States vehicles from using it.

GENEVA, May 14 -- Prior to his inauguration it was President Kennedy's evident intention that neither he nor his Secretary of State should travel from Washington more than a minimal amount of time. Yet the President himself will visit both Ottawa and Paris this May and Mr. Rusk, in less than four months of office, has flown to Bangkok, Ankara, Oslo and Geneva.
About 500 persons attended the second annual solemn field mass for the armed forces here yesterday in Nolan Park on Governors Island.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, May 14 -- The Alaska Festival of Music, which each year draws many outstanding musicians from throughout the United States, has won a one-year reprieve after being faced with possible extermination through union action.
The American Association for Jewish Education, said yesterday it opposed any Federal aid to private and parochial schools.

The forces that formed America constitute the subject of a new book by William Appleman Williams called "The Contours of American History." He redefines the meanings of "laissez-faire" and "mercantilism" in terms of the American experience, showing how the social interpretation of these phases has accounted for various attitudes.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector) May 14 -- West Germany has informed Israel it will assist in the trial of Adolf Eichmann.

A group of Protestant Episcopal clergymen assailed the church-owned University of the South yesterday for planning to award an honorary doctorate to a segregationist newspaper editor in South Carolina.

READINGTON, N.J., May 14 -- A 21-year-old French girl who has taken off in an airplane twice in her life but has never landed in one, parachuted here today and pronounced her 2,500-foot drop "a great time."
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman predicted yesterday that under certain circumstances Mayor Wagner would have the support of most anti-De Sapio Democrats if he sought re-election this year.
CHICAGO, May 14 -- A plane flying at 23,000 feet near Montpelier, Ind., tomorrow will be the vehicle for an educational experiment that promoters hope will help solve the teacher shortage.
Carl Braun, released as the coach of the New York Knickerbockers just a week ago, last night signed to play with the champion Boston Celtics of the National Basketball Association.
CLEVELAND, May 14 (AP) -- The Indians cooled off the Baltimore Orioles today by sweeping a double-header. They won the first game in fifteen innings, 1 -- 0, and took the second game, 6 -- 4.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- A bill to provide $2,550,000,000 for Federal aid to education goes to the Senate floor on Tuesday. The ensuing battle is expected to spill over into next week.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) -- The head of the Federal Communications Commission said today that hundreds of viewers, including President Kennedy, had supported his demand for better television programs.
PARIS, Monday, May 15 -- A bomb exploded early today in an apartment building in a fashionable section of Paris near the Bois de Boulogne.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) -- Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon, said today the "Russian MIG's" that the Castro regime supposedly used to help thwart the April 17 rebel landing in Cuba actually were United States planes that had been sent to the old Batista regime.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 14 -- Post-war expansion of crude steel production has been paralleled by a steep rise in consumption, the 1960 Statistical Year Book of the United Nations indicates. The twelfth edition, covering many phases of national reports through 1959, shows that output for that year was higher by 31,000,000 metric tons than in 1958, with a total of 305,000,000 tons.

MERCURY, Nev., May 14 -- An experimental nuclear engine for a new sort of weapon -- a wandering supersonic "suspense'' missile -- underwent its first power test at the Atomic Energy Commission's desert proving ground here today.
PARIS, May 14 -- For the United States, increasingly agitated over the problem of tariffs and competitive imports, there may be a lesson to be learned in Western Europe.

A question that recurs frequently in discussions among people interested in New York City politics is: Holy much more time will Mayor Wagner be given to make up his mind whether he wants to run for a third term? Many Democratic officials and leaders, both regular and anti-organization, are rapidly becoming convinced they need a prompt answer.
FALL RIVER, Mass., May 14 -- The New York Americans defeated Fall River, 4 -- 0, today in an exhibition soccer match at Fall River Stadium.
Some major segments of the television industry have suddenly developed an active or let's-get-going-now interest in news programs designed especially for children.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -The Peace Corps said today that candidates for overseas projects should report to one of 330 centers for entrance tests May 27 or June 5.
A team of psychiatric workers will patrol the streets of high delinquency areas in the city this summer in an effort to ferret out seriously disturbed members of youth gangs.

On and off the screen Gary Cooper played the same part. The observer who called him the "indestructible, incorruptible Galahad of moviedom" was not too far wrong. Whether he was doing Sergeant York or the sheriff in "High Noon" he had to be strong, brave and reticent. The word "Yup" was almost the only one he needed in his professional life.

THE slight, smiling man who led Vice President Johnson through the dancing dragons and zig-zagging lions in Taiwan yesterday is a Nationalist Chinese leader who prefers "mister" above any in his array of mighty titles.

A processing system estimated to enable a plant to double its output of beet sugar has just been put into operation in Brawley, Calif., by the Holly Sugar Corporation. The company said installation of the system cost half the price of a new factory.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 14 -- Jack Turner of Seattle, driving a Bardahl Special, was the fastest of five drivers who qualified today for the 500-mile automobile race to be run here on May 30.

BONN, Germany, May 14 -- Defense Minister Franz Josef Strauss has acknowledged West Germany's uneasiness over the new emphasis on conventional weapons in the strategic military planning of the Western Allies.
Mayor Wagner brightened a breakfast of sanitation men yesterday by telling them he was cutting their work week from forty to thirty-seven and a half hours.

The new minister of Broadway Presbyterian Church, the Rev. Dr. Stuart Hamilton Merriam, told his congregation yesterday that he hoped to make his preaching "interesting at all costs," instructive and inspiring.

Union laundry workers appealed yesterday for state action to "fill the gap" left by the exclusion of laundries from the broadened minimum wage coverage recently approved by President Kennedy and Congress.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 14 -- Jordan has found the rapid pace of development resulting from modernization of the port of Aqaba on the Red Sea so profitable that the American expert who designed and supervised the work has recommended a further five-year period of expansion.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 14 -- Iran's new reform Government was reliably reported today to have called former Premier Manouchehr Eghbal for questioning on his role in last summer's parliamentary election.

MONTE CARLO, May 14 -- Stirling Moss of Britain, driving a year-old 1.5-liter Lotus Climax, held off the Ferrari hordes for nearly three hours today and won the 196-mile Grand Prix de Monaco auto race. He triumphed by 3.6 seconds -- only a few hundred feet.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 14 -- The fifty-second national amateur trapshooting championships came to a close today at the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island traps with the crowning of William G. Rheaume of Worcester, Mass., as the handicap champion and Lou Hidu of Fairfield, Conn., as the over-all titleholder.

WILLIMANTIC, Conn., May 14 -- Ch. Pixietown Serenade of Hadleigh, owned by Mrs. R.H. Bellick of Hanson, Mass., and Lady Conyers of Bermuda, won best-in-show honors today at the Windham County Kennel Club's fixture. Mrs. Hayes Blake Hoyt of Darien, Conn., was the judge.
Your editorial of May 4 termed the sale of six million tons of Canadian wheat to Communist China "a normal commercial transaction."
Henry Hope Reed, historian of architecture who knows New York better than most people know their own back yards, took a group on a tour of Central Park yesterday.
The Federal Government's advance plan for operating ports in national emergencies is moving too slowly, planning officials said yesterday.
The sixty-fourth annual dinner of the Citizens Union of the City of New York will be held on next Monday at the Park Lane.

The Bendix Corporation had consolidated net income for the quarter ended on March 31 of $4,867,081, equal to 90 cents a share on 5,379,529 shares outstanding. This compared with a profit of $5,923,110, or $1.10 a share, on 5,366,624 shares outstanding, for the first three months of 1960.

The mutual aid pact signed by James R. Hoffa of the Teamsters Union, Joseph Curran of the National Maritime Union and Capt. William V. Bradley of the International Longshoremen's Association is a clear and present danger to the national welfare.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 14 -- "It was different this Sunday," said Billy Edwards today as he left the Garden City Golf Club with a silver trophy tucked under his arm.

The Karlsruhe soccer club of West Germany, which makes its International Soccer League debut Wednesday, bowed to the German-American Soccer League All-Stars, 2 -- 1, yesterday at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
Trading in the over-the-counter market slowed last week from its hectic pace of recent weeks. The result was a minor change in prices.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- Americans for Democratic Action urged today a start toward recognition of Red China. It also described as inadequate the Kennedy Administration's plans on employment and economic growth.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 14 -- Teodoro Moscoso, newly appointed United States Ambassador to Venezuela, arrived here today. Although extremist groups had been threatening to attack him, no incident marked the diplomat's arrival.
PALM BEACH, Fla., May 14 -- President Kennedy is considering a conference with Premier Khrushchev in early June in a mid-European city.

The formation of the American Motion Picture Export Company (Africa) under the chairmanship of Eric Johnston, was announced yesterday. The company, organized here last Thursday, will distribute the films of most American major producing companies in West Africa.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -The United States has offered and Bolivia has accepted nearly $10,000,000 in immediate economic and relief aid.

The Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company of Chicago and subsidiaries reported over the week-end gains in operating revenues and net income for the twelve and three months ended March 31. The gain in net earnings was traced primarily to the addition of some 42,000 new space heating installations.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Col. John Abbes Garcia, chief of the military intelligence service of the Dominican Republic, was reported today to have visited Moscow late last year on an apparently unsuccessful secret mission designed to win Soviet support for Generalissimo Leonidas Trujillo Molina.

" THIS is a study of the relationship between the Soviet Union and the major Western countries from the inception of the Soviet regime in 1917 to the end of World War II." That is the first sentence of "Russia and the West Under Lenin and Stalin," * by George F. Kennan. It describes his book with simple and precise clarity just as the book describes its intricate and much misunderstood subject.
Services to New York children involved in domestic, vocational or medical difficulties were improved and expanded in 1960, the Children's Aid Society said in its 108th annual report yesterday.
BUEOS AIRES, May 14 -- Two aspects of United States aid plans for Latin America have come under sharp criticism here.
CAIRO, May 14 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser said last night that the United Arab Republic could best help the African states by keeping them out of the "cold war."

Printers on ten metropolitan daily newspapers asked the executive council of the International Typographical Union yesterday to authorize the termination of their contract with the Publishers Association of New York City.
ROME, May 14 -- Pope John XXIII called today for international cooperation in a well-planned and boldly executed world-wide attack on hunger and poverty.
In a major change of highway policy, the state Department of Public Works will begin painting solid white traffic lines along the outer edges of primary roads this summer.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 15 -- A recommendation that New Jersey be apportioned into six districts in which banking operations of the unit, branch and holding-company types would be permitted simultaneously has been made by the Peoples Trust Company of Bergen County.
Two large United States commercial finance and factoring companies announced plans yesterday to enter the Canadian market through joint ventures with Canadian concerns.
The Justice Department was invited yesterday by Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman to help him formulate a final plan to desegregate the predominantly Negro Lincoln School in New Rochelle.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 15 -- Thirty-eight Princeton University faculty members have expressed concern over the Administration's Cuban policy in a letter to President Kennedy.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Supreme Court left standing today a Vermont decision holding unconstitutional the use of public funds for parochial school tuition.

THE contents of a woman's handbag are part of standard joke repertoires. But, all kidding aside, the choice of what she can put into her pocketbook has become truly impressive. The range of purse-size articles has particular significance for the traveler who wants to be able to freshen up and cope with good-grooming emergencies anywhere in the world, from a desert to a drafty airport at dawn.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, May 16 -- The United States Embassy issued a statement today expressing strong support for the "freely elected and constitutionally established Government" of Premier John M. Chang.
TRENTON, May 15 -- The State Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a bill that designates Middlesex County as New Jersey's Fifteenth and newest Congressional District.
The Bronx Zoo and Coney Island Aquarium will probably reopen this week, according to spokesmen for the New York Zoological Society and the union that has been on strike for forty-five days.
BOSTON, May 15 -- Tax relief for the New Haven Railroad was signed into law by Gov. John A. Volpe of Massachusetts at 10:30 o'clock tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Rural electric cooperatives are making a strong bid for a major role in the Kennedy Administration's program of rehabilitation for depressed areas.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 15 -- Stuart (Skip) Wallace, a Syracuse senior and the father of three children, captured the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association championship today by defeating Ron Dermitt of Pittsburgh on the nineteenth hole at the Yale golf course.

Doug Harvey, the winner of the National Hockey League's James Norris Memorial Trophy as the outstanding defenseman, will remain with the Montreal Canadiens. He turned down an offer to become player-coach of the New York Rangers.

A WIDOW raised her son and daughter to avenge her husband who had been killed by a deputy sheriff. To instill adequate hatred in the young people, she periodically lashed their backs with a blacksnake whip.
NOT that Elmer Davis was not appreciated when he was alive. His friends found him stimulating and entertaining, and stood in awe of his mind.
LEOPOLDVILLE the Congo, May 15 -- The United Nations has withdrawn most of its troops from South Kasai and stopped all its civilian and famine-relief operations there.

The Ansor Corporation, general agent in the United States for several large foreign concerns, has leased 9,000 square feet of office space in the new International Telephone and Telegraph Building at 320 Park Avenue.

PARIS, May 15 -- The opening of peace negotiations Saturday between France and Algerian Moslem rebels at Evian-les-Bains is expected to bring the partial liberation of a rebel leader imprisoned since October, 1956.

I have read with great interest your editorial of May 5 "A 20-Cent Fare?" Although a fare increase would work personal hardship on me and my wife as regular Manhattan bus riders, I for one definitely endorse your conclusion -- namely, that the appeal of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company merits full and sympathetic consideration.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 (AP) -- Bill Nieder, the Olympic shot-put champion, was knocked out in the first round of his professional boxing debut tonight. Jim Wiley, 198 pounds, a Philadelphia fighter with an 11-9-6 record knocked out Nieder 216, from Los Angeles, in 2:10 of the first round.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Fellow union officials charged a headquarters group in the Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union today with widespread padding of expense accounts to cover up an earlier alleged fraud.
About 300 New Haven Railroad commuters left a disabled train at 129th Street yesterday morning and walked four blocks along a catwalk high above Park Avenue to the 125th Street station.
The long predicted proxy fight of the Dal-Tran Service Company for control of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., or representation on its board of directors has begun.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI) -- The Senate heard a round of tributes today to Gary Cooper.
BONN, Germany, May 15 -- The last commander of the S.A., a Nazi paramilitary organization, is now Deputy Mayor of a town in West Germany.
The president of Mount Holyoke College took exception yesterday to predictions that independent colleges for women might not survive.
HACKENSACK, N.J., May 15 -- Armed guards will take $275,000 to Bergen County Court this week as evidence in a lottery trial.

I welcome the opportunity to express appreciation and support of the recommendations made in the lead editorial in the May 5 issue of The Times, outlining a policy for Laos and advising that every effort "should be made to enlist Asian participation in coping with the problem of Laos and strengthening Southeast Asia * * *."
WASHINGTON, Tuesday, May 16 -- Responsible Government officials said this morning that the military coup in South Korea was not supported by the United States.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 15 -- A project for a movie that was so controversial it was abandoned last year has been revived.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 15 (UPI) -- The General Electric Company said today it had test-fired a new rocket engine that might save time and money in narrowing the gap between American and Soviet propulsion systems.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday he would veto the City Council's Charter revision bill. Last Friday the Board of Estimate rebuffed the Mayor by approving the Council bill by a vote of 14 to 8. The bill calls for a nine-member revision commission, of which Mr. Wagner would name only three members.

May I call your attention to the recent article in your newspaper by Harrison E. Salisbury in which the writer felt that the United States was ill prepared to serve the foreign tourists who will soon be arriving as visitors to our country.
The heavy cruiser Newport News and two other Navy vessels will arrive here on Thursday and Friday from Norfolk, Va., to take part in Armed Forces Week observances.
EVERY player should be alert to chances for a choice-compelling play.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 15 -- Any apprehensions on Taiwan that the United States was weakening its support of the Nationalist regime as representing the Government of China have been dispelled by a joint communique issued today in the names of President Chiang Kaishek and Vice President Johnson.
BALTIMORE, May 15 (AP) -- The league-leading Detroit Tigers made fifteen hits and scored their runs in clusters tonight as they defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 10 -- 5.
The Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria was transformed into an Edwardian Winter Garden last night for the May Festival Ball, a benefit for Just One Break, Inc. (JOB).

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 15 -- The ninth assembly of the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America ended today after a call by the delegates for measures to improve what they termed an alarming economic and social situation in the hemisphere.
The $2.5 billion Federal aid-to-education bill, which goes to the Senate floor today, is essentially in line with President Kennedy's proposals.
LAWRENCE J. BURNSTEIN is one entrepreneur of the antiques world who is doing his best to combat the spiraling prices on authentic period furnishings.

GENEVA, May 15 -- The Soviet Union threatened today to resume nuclear testing should France fail to desist from further atomic tests. It accused the United States and Britain of having ignored its warning against such French testing.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Lieut. Gen. Do Young Chang, who was born in Korea forty-two years ago, is a "much decorated" hero of the Korean war, a spokesman for the South Korean Embassy said today. His decorations include "several from the United States," the spokesman said.
Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia was crowned with a laurel wreath and officially declared the world chess champion yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Secretary of Interior Stewart L. Udall today suggested a 1-cent tax on soft drinks or cigarettes as a possible way of financing a massive, national outdoor recreation program.
Representatives of more than a dozen civic and religious groups in the Greenwich Village area urged Mayor Wagner last night to hear their objections to Sunday folk singing in Washington Square Park.

The comment around Aqueduct race track yesterday was "Old Fitz certainly has his horses in shape." This admiring appraisal was ventured with special emphasis after the feature race, a one-mile test for fillies and mares.

Secretary of State Rusk has gained a point but no real advantage at the Geneva Conference on Laos by resisting the Soviet demand that Communist Pathet Lao emissaries be seated with status equal to those of both the Vientiane Government and the rebel neutralist regime.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The Supreme Court reversed today the contempt convictions of two persons, but upheld in part the convictions of three who had refused to answer some questions by the Ohio un-American Activities Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI) -- Adolf A. Berle Jr., the Administration's special expert on Latin America, went behind closed doors with a Senate subcommittee today to explain his role in the recent ill-fated rebel landing in Cuba.
Evansville, Indiana, is a city that has come to grips with the problems of mass automation -- and won.

WHERE Rome left off, Revlon has commenced. Already renowned throughout the world for his extensive line of cosmetics, Charles Revson, president of Revlon, has built himself a Pompeiian palace dedicated to the pampering of a woman from head to toe.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Senate disregarded the advice of two Presidents and voted today to authorize $525,000,000 for more long-range bombers for the Strategic Air Command.

CHICAGO, May 15 (UPI) -- Camito Paseual shut out theJ Chicago White Sox on four hitsI tonight and led the MinnesotaI Twins to a 5-0 victory. TheJ triumph gave the Twins their longest winning streak of the season, four games.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 15 -- A Pennsylvania judge charged today that Adolf Eichmann, in the final weeks of World War II, wanted to shoot all captured Allied airmen of Jewish ancestry.
PARIS, May 15 -- New orders for steel in the six nations of the European Common Market have started to slide lower.
A master plan to integrate the city's public schools was asked yesterday at a meeting of the coordinating committee of the Public Education Association.

Stockholders of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., called again and again at yesterday's annual meeting for the identical rights that shareholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company have long enjoyed.

" Standard" issues -- the steels, motors, chemicals, oils, rubbers, papers and nonferrous metals -- moved forward strongly in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. Aircrafts, electronics and drugs were irregular.
LOS ANGELES, May 15 (AP) -- Lew Burdette won at the Coliseum for the eighth straight time tonight as the Milwaukee Braves defeated the Dodgers. 7 -- 5.
The North Brooklyn Heights Community Group demanded yesterday that the city discard plans for two apartment projects on the Cadman Plaza slum clearance site.

Before his departure from Washington, authoritative sources there indicated that the purpose of Vice President Johnson's Far East swing was not only to reassure the Asian countries allied to the United States of our continued support in their struggle against Communist aggression, but also to explore what their Governments could do to strengthen themselves politically for this struggle.
WARSAW, May 15 -- Josef Cyrankiewicz, Poland's Premier, was named again today to form a new Government.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The Maritime Administration today opposed retroactive features of a bill that would give ship owners more flexibility in trading-in their obsolete vessels.
DETROIT, May 15 -- General Motors Corporation reported today that its dealers had sold more new cars in the first ten days of May than in any first ten days of May since 1956.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The House Appropriations Committee approved today $48,154,919 more than had been requested by the Administration for the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

" Child of Our Time," the novel by Michel del Castillo dealing with a young Spanish boy's search for love during World War II and the post-war period, has been acquired for independent filming by Stephen W. Sharmat and Fred Hift.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, May 15 -- President Kennedy's program for combating juvenile delinquency failed today to win the approval of Western Governors.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Embezzlers were told by the Supreme Court today that they must report their ill-gotten gains on their income tax returns.

YONKERS, May 15 -- Mr. Budlong will start from the rail, the best place to be in any harness race, in Thursday night's $50,000 National Championship Pace at Yonkers Raceway. Saul Finkelstein's 5-year-old brown gelding drew the No. 1 post in the draw for positions today.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- United States military leaders believe that they know the locations of thirty-seven Soviet missile-launching pads, including one less than 500 miles from Alaska.
The usage of "twofers" -- the system that makes available two tickets for the price of one -- will be drastically curtailed starting next season at all of the Shubert-controlled playhouses.
Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, elected Walter W. Weismann its president last night.

Shopping center owners who believe that there is a pall on the mall as far as business returns are concerned may be encouraged by reports of some metropolitan area business men who have found that mall concessions bring added income.
Peter C. Tripp, a former disk jockey for Radio Station WMGM, was found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions Court of accepting payola to play records on the air.

Alexander L. Guterma, serving a five-year sentence for failure to file reports concerning a company now in trusteeship, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court to eight other counts. They involve conspiracy and fraud charges stemming from stock sales.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The Supreme Court denied today a hearing to Ernest Mark High, New York publisher of a labor publication called "The Spotlight," who had been sentenced to five months in jail for contempt of Congress.

OTTAWA, May 15 -- This capital, normally blase toward celebrities, is expected to turn out in the greatest numbers since the 1959 royal visit of Queen Elizabeth II when President and Mrs. Kennedy arrive tomorrow for a two-day state visit.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 15 -- An end of poverty and a middleclass life for all in a harmonious society were suggested as possibilities today by Dr. Kenneth Boulding, a professor of economics at the University of Michigan.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 15 -- Premier Ali Amini said today, that all actions related to his drive to eliminate corruption in public office would be legal.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday his decision on whether to run for a third term would "rest upon strictly personal reasons."
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Kennedy backed the controversial proposal of Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard University, to anglicize the Harvard diploma.

The rise of the Soviet Union from the devastation of World War II to her present position as one of the world's great powers is the subject of "The Red Phoenix." The author is Harry Schwartz, a member of this newspaper's editorial staff and a specialist in Soviet affairs.

Despite the Kennedy Administration's earnest effort to achieve a treaty banning further nuclear weapons tests as a step toward disarmament, the Soviets continue to raise one roadblock after another on the way to that goal. The latest is their threat to walk out of the Geneva test-ban conference and resume testing unless the United States and Britain stop France from making further tests of its own.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, May 15 -- The special sessions of Southern Rhodesian Constitutional talks opened in Salisbury today and the African delegates representing the powerful National Democratic party walked out within half an hour.
Dr. Harry N. Rivlin was appointed acting president of City College last night.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
The American Stock Exchange was known as the New York Curb Exchange until 1953. It is the second largest organized securities market in the country.
TRENTON, May 15 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner failed again today to get legislative approval for a tax program to raise $39,000,000 in new revenue needed to balance the 1961-1962 state budget.

MONTAUK POINT, L.I., May 15 -- A bunch of the boats were whooping it up in the fog around Block Island today, waiting for the pollock to come up from the bottom and start feeding in the tide rips. While they were hanging around Southwest Ledge they caught, tiresome quantities of cod, pollock and snowshoe flounders from the bottom.

Copper futures opened steady yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York, reflecting firm prices in London. Commission house and dealer buying and short covering rallied prices to the highs of the day. Speculator profit taking and dealer selling supplied the contracts.

PARIS, May 15 -- A shake-up has just been completed in the leadership of the French Communist party, resulting in the exclusion from the Central Committee of five of its most prominent members and one alternate member.

The city has finally decided to do something more than simply plead with operators of trucks, buses and automobiles to correct conditions in their vehicles causing undue smoke. Police Commissioner Murphy has ordered that summonses be given to offenders. Now there is hope that the law will be enforced.
BOSTON, May 15 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Indians backed Jim (Mudcat) Grant's three-hitter with their highest hit total in nearly four years while walloping the Boston Red Sox, 13 -- 2, today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 15 -- A plea from Moise Tshombe has led Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold to send a cautious message to the Katanga leader's captors expressing interest in his fate.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 15 -- Dwight D. Eisenhower, who was graduated here with a "clean sleeve" in 1915, returned today to receive the highest honors of both the cadet corps and the graduates.

Maybe it's spring, maybe it's the recession, but a banker has resorted to rhyme. "'April showers bring May flowers,'" Robert M. Young of the staff of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, writes in the bank's latest monthly review.
The first American edition of Henry Miller's controversial book "Tropic of Cancer" will be published on June 24, Grove Press announced yesterday.

LONDON, May 15 -- Prime Minister Macmillan announced today the appointment of Lord Radcliffe, a Lord of Appeal with wide experience in directing Government inquiries, as chairman of a committee to investigate Britain's security system.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 15 (UPI) -- The Lawn Tennis Association of Australia decided tonight that the official Australian touring team would not play in the United States singles championships. The tournament will be played Sept. 1 through 10 at Forest Hills, Queens.
Public offering of $102,000,000 of public utility and industrial debentures and first mortgage bonds is being made today. These offerings include:
The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies reported yesterday a net income of 42,060,000 ($117,768,000) for the first quarter of 1961. That compared with 41,781,000 ($116,986,800) in the 1960 period.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- A spokesman for sales companies asked Congress today not to put a ceiling on income deductions for hotel rooms and meals.
The army coup in South Korea occurred thirteen months after the forced resignation of the Government of Dr. Syngman Rhee.

The Gulf Oil Corporation and its agency, Young Rubicam, Inc., have included a clause in their latest television contract with the National Broadcasting Company giving Gulf the right to cancel any station using triple advertising spots either before or after the sponsored program.
President Kennedy says he has been calling on Americans for specific sacrifices but finding his requests "strongly resisted by some unwilling to pay the price of national greatness."

GREENWICH, Conn., May 15 -- A steam shovel will unceremoniously bite into a clump of earth in the Havermayer Park section of town this week to mark the start of construction of a new public school that will revolutionize the educational program here.
KANSAS CITY, May 15 (AP) -- Joe Gordon, the manager of the Athletics, directed his team from the press box tonight as Kansas City beat the Los Angeles Angels, 5 -- 3.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would make an extensive investigation of the American Stock Exchange.

CHICAGO, May 15 (AP) -- Despite the absence of any significant bullish influences, the grain futures market worked into a generally firm to strong range today on the Board of Trade. Soybeans were the only laggards.

TOKYO, May 15 (AP) -- The International Cotton Advisory Committee reported today that the United States recession plunged mill cotton consumption to "near the lowest level for the entire post-war period" in the 1960-61 season.

Of the many explanations offered for the collapse of the recent Algerian coup against the Fifth Republic perhaps the most quixotic is that suggesting that French pilots refused to help launch a paratroop invasion of the capital out of their love for Paris.

Helene Curtis Industries, Inc., is planning to acquire the Pyramid Rubber Company, privately-owned manufacturer of the Evenflo line of baby-feeding equipment, nursers, bottles, nipples, sealing kits and related accessories.

The $75,000 Professional Bowlers Association invitation tournament, won by Roy Lown of El Paso last week, was a complete success as a spectator attraction. Rarely has bowling been a competition to keep the interest of fans for very long.

WHEN it comes to vacation clothes, Abraham Straus is concentrating on cruising this season. Until May 27, the third floor at the store will be devoted to clothes that fill the needs of the cruise-bound vacationer, from dance dresses to bathing suits.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 15 -- A bi-racial group, forced to abandon an anti-segregation bus ride through the South for lack of a driver, flew to New Orleans tonight after an earlier flight was canceled because of a bomb threat.

AKRON, Ohio, May 15 (AP) -- Edward O. Lamb, Toledo lawyer and business man, gained a fifth director on Selberling Rubber Company's fifteen-member board today at an annual meeting attended by some seventy stockholders.
BOSTON, May 15 -- Bernard Goldfine pleaded guilty today to charges of evading $791,745 in corporate and personal income taxes.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- A 15-year-old high school girl from Eaton's Neck, L.I., today was named the winner of the annual nation-wide competition for design of a Maritime Day poster to be displayed on all mail trucks.
Most New Yorkers -- and especially the straphanging kind -- see nothing esthetic in the subway rush hour.
Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg pleaded yesterday for more voluntary assumption of responsibility for advancing the national welfare by labor, management and citizens generally.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Treasury bill rates moved up slightly on today's sale of the regular weekly issues. The change from the rates on last Monday's sales was the smallest in three months.
Ten one-of-a-kind books valued at close to $325,000 are being shown here.

There is a legend that the first specialist in stocks was a member of the New York Stock Exchange who broke his leg at some time during the Eighteen Seventies. According to the story, he took a sedentary position near the location on the floor where Western Union stock was traded and handled orders in that issue for other members of the Exchange.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 15 -- Emil R. Capita's forty-five-foot Hi-Q II won the Winged Foot Trophy early today by placing first in the New York Athletic Club's fifty-second annual overnight race. The elapsed time was the slowest on record for the race.
MELBOURNE, Australia, May 15 -- Bribane's Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals is investigating its strangest case -- a complaint that birds are being cruel to a man.
" There was plenty of advance warning that trouble might develop in the situation at the bus station," said the club in a unanimous resolution.

HERMOSILLO, Mexico, May 15 -- Order was restored to this capital of the state of Sonora today after several hours of violent demonstrations yesterday. At least thirty-eight demonstrators and policemen were treated for gunshot wounds or injuries.
METUCHEN, N.J., May 15 -- Three teams tied for the qualifying medal and won their first-round matches today in the New Jersey pro-pro championship at the Metuchen Golf Club.

Mr. Kennedy is today making his first trip outside of the United States as President. It is natural that the country he goes to is Canada. It is also practical; and Canadians will appreciate it if we consider it as such, and if we do not indulge in the customary sentimentalities.
Pakistan and Thailand have brought to thirty-seven the number of foreign Governments committed to exhibit at the New York World's Fair.
A dredgeboat churned up mud and a $640,000 lawsuit when it deepened the basin alongside a Brooklyn dock four years ago.

LISBON, Portugal, May 15 -- The Government has arrested three opponents of the thirty-two-year-old regime of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar. They are charged with having held an illegal news conference to publicize demands for nationwide democratic reforms.
The prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined by 3 to 9 points yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
LONDON, May 15 -- Heavy selling was again absorbed in the stock market here today and most industrial share groups finished with more small rises than falls.
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub team matches that were rained out last Friday were completed yesterday.
GENEVA, May 15 -- The United States agreed tonight to a Soviet-British compromise that will permit the conference on Laos to begin tomorrow.
ATLANTA, May 14 -- "Sometimes I get the idea that some people don't want our democracy to succeed if it means making concessions in the field of race relations."

HISTORIANS repeat themselves; storytellers repeat one another. When they do it in concert, we have what is known as a trend. The trend may take the form of a rash of novels about the gray-flannel-suit brigade, or tales of nuclear holocausts, or beatniks beating their way across America.
Five young New Yorkers chose to spend twenty-five days in jail yesterday for refusing to take shelter during the Civil Defense air raid exercise on April 28.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 15 -- Stockholders of Sterchi Bros. Stores, Inc., at their annual meeting here today elected John W. Sterchi, grandson of founder J.G. Sterchi, as a director. Sterchi's has forty-six furniture stores in the South.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday. May 16 -- The South Korean armed forces revolted today, crushed resistance in Seoul in heavy street fighting and set up an anti-Communist military government that declared its close friendship for the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Kennedy returned from Florida today and found the capital divided over the desirability of a Kennedy-Khrushchev meeting at this time.

Dr. Robert C. Weaver, Administrator of the Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency, committed the Kennedy Administration yesterday to conservation and rehabilitation as the primary techniques of urban renewal.

DETROIT, May 15 -- Sol A. Dann, Detroit lawyer, filed an amended complaint today in a suit against the Chrysler Corporation in which he is seeking to est aside all actions taken at the April 18 stockholders meeting. Among the actions that he asked to be nullified was the election of the directors.
Shipowners in Hong Kong and in Greece who have long provided the backbone of the second-hand ship market, have now entered the new building field, according to Harley, Mullion Company, Ltd.
Columbia and Fordham, baseball rivals since 1884, seemed in no hurry to end matters at Baker Field yesterday as they met for the sixty-seventh time.

FIFTEEN years ago, Justice Michael A. Musmanno of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, who testified yesterday for the prosecution in the Adolf Eichmann trial, proposed that a world court be set up to try "international criminals" responsible for "crimes against humanity."

Steel production continued to rise last week, with mills operating at about 68 per cent of capacity as compared with 66 per cent two weeks ago and 64 per cent three weeks ago. According to figures released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute, industry output climbed to 1,988,000 tons from 1,943,000 two weeks before and 1,858,000 three weeks earlier.

The American Electric Power Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday declines in net income for April and the four months ended on April 30. Earnings for the latest twelve months, however, exceeded those of the year before by 2.6 per cent.

Terms have been proposed by the Dramatists Guild to help prevent a crisis in putting on shows, a situation that has alarmed producers. Members of the guild will vote on the proposals at 2:30 P.M. on May 24 in the Sherry-Netherland Hotel.
MONTREAL, May 15 (Canadian Press) -- Airlines flying trans-Atlantic routes reached agreement today on what the International Air Transport Association called "substantial reductions" in cargo rates.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 15 (AP) -- Following is the text of a letter, released here, from President Kennedy to Alicia Patterson, editor and publisher of the newspaper, Newsday, who asked him to specify the sacrifices he was asking of Americans:
BONN, Germany, May 15 -- Anna Anderson's forty-year struggle for recognition as the youngest daughter of the last Czar, Nicholas II of Russia, suffered a major setback to' day.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 15 (UPI) -- Orlando Cepeda drove in five runs today with two home runs and a double and Felipe Alou crashed a grand-slam homer as the league-leading San Francisco Giants scored a 14-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
DETROIT, May 15 (AP) -- Registrations of new cars -- an official indicator of sales -- dropped 16.6 per cent in the first quarter of 1961 from the 1960 level, it was reported today.

SOME New Jersey children who are studying first-year Spanish in school are now among La Fonda del Sol's most enthusiastic patrons. "They come in groups, thirty or forty kids at a time," a spokesman for the Latin American restaurant in the Time-Life building said last week.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Kennedy has several important personal and policy reasons for thinking about a meeting with Premier Khrushchev in Vienna next month.
The State Supreme Court refused for a second time yesterday to reduce the $65,000 bail in which Aaron Wagman is being held on charges of bribing college basketball players.

Yesterday was a day of heavy churning in the money market as $7,750,000,000 of maturing Treasury debt was paid off and as the deadline passed for payment of subscription money for the new Treasury issues supplanting those redeemed.
The American Jewish Congress honored Senator Hubert H. Humphrey last night with its Stephen Wise Award.

MONTE CARLO, May 15 -- The United States Grand Prix, a rousing financial flop at Sebring, Fla., in 1959 and at Riverside, Calif., in 1960, probably will be run at Miami this year, Alex Ulmann, the promoter of the race, indicated today.

The price of copper, which was raised by 1 cent a pound only two weeks ago, appears headed for another general 1- cent increase. However, the price of another key nonferrous metal, zinc, is headed downward.
The Chicago, Ill., Board of Education borrowed $40,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance school construction. The deal cost the city an interest charge of 3.28064 per cent.

The Capital Cities Broadcasting Corporation has purchased Radio Station WPAT-AM and FM, Inc., Paterson, N.J., for cash exceeding $5,000,000. The sale was announced jointly yesterday by Frank M. Smith, president of Capital Cities Broadcasting, and Dickens J. Wright, president of WPAT.
Blood will be given to the Red Cross today at Macy's Herald Square store.

In a period when most of the crusading vigor appears to have drained out of organized labor's high command, there is at least one union leader who remains as full of zest as a mountain stream. We refer to Harry A. Van Arsdale Jr., the enterprising head of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers and of the million-member N.Y.C. Central Labor Council.
Cecil Shorts of Cleveland scored a majority decision over Isaac Logart, the Cuban star, in the ten-round feature bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night.
The Institute for Crippled and Disabled began a five-day administrative training course yesterday for rehabilitation specialists.

Dr. Robert C. Weaver, Administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, declared last night that there was "the same sense of urgency" now in Washington as in the early days of the New Deal when he first entered Government service.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 15 -- The United States took possession of its newest embassy today -- the only one within its own territory.

The winners and losers in the nation's most anxiously awaited academic sweepstakes knew their fate by yesterday morning when the mailman delivered the last of this year's Ivy League college acceptance or rejection notices.

An agreement for the sale of the assets of the Honolulu Oil Corporation to the Pan American Petroleum Corporation and the Tidewater Oil Company for about $380,000,000 was concluded yesterday, the companies announced Pan American is a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana).
Joseph F. Carlino, Speaker of the State Assembly, charged last evening that City Hall, rather than the Legislature, had been "soft on slumlords."
The six-month narcotics-conspiracy trial of nineteen men, which was beset by illnesses, stormy court sessions and picketing, ended yesterday in a mistrial.

A deal is pending for Steve Allen to return to television next fall as the star of a weekly program over the American Broadcasting Company network. It would be presented on Wednesdays from 7:30 to 8:30 P.M.

The United States also took a strong position during the last Korean crisis -- thirteen months ago. At that time it directed its criticism against the incumbent government, that of former President Syngman Rhee.

THE most spectacular gambling in horse racing does not take place at the mutuel windows. It takes place on the breeding farms. Yearlings that sell for as high as $80,000 fail to win enough to pay their feed bill but a colt like Carry Back, out of a $300 mare, already has won $612,868 and takes dead aim at the Preakness jackpot of $150,000 added at Pimlico on Saturday.

The "cold war" between advocates of welfare fund-raising through the federated approach and advocates of separate campaigns is not likely to bring victory to either side, a philanthropic foundation head said yesterday.
Four affiliates of the Pride of Judea Children's Services, Dumont Avenue and Elton Street, Brooklyn, have arranged benefit events for this month and next.
A tea will be given at Gracie Mansion on Thursday to form a ladies committee for the Dimitri Mitropoulos Memorial Project of the Musicians Aid Society.
A number of four-year colleges in the state could have admitted more qualified transfer students from junior colleges last fall, the State Education Department reported yesterday.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 15 -- Six outstanding contemporary houses here will be open to the public from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Sunday as part of a fund-raising drive on behalf of the New Canaan Community Nursery School.
FAIR LAWN, N.J., May 16 -- A 55-year-old widower killed his 14-year-old son this morning because he feared the boy's face might become disfigured as his was.

The Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation announced yesterday that it had completed the acquisition of Curtis Laboratories, Inc., and Circle Weld Manufacturing Company, both of Los Angeles. Curtis Laboratories designs, develops and manufactures specialized optical and photographic equipment. Circle Weld produces precision metal bellows equipment.

Stocks on the New York Stock Exchange made a moderate but fairly general advance yesterday. In the course of it, The New York Times combined and industrial averages made highs since the first half of 1960 and the Dow, Jones Co. industrial average established historic intra-day and closing highs.

MONTAUK POINT, L.I., May 16 -- Pollock didn't come up into the rip today, so far as anybody knows. But the question whether owls can see in the daytime got pretty well thrashed out, which is good progress for people catching flounder.

FROM the standpoint of performance, setting and staging, the Olympic Games in Rome last summer were unquestionably the finest of these international athletic carnivals. Most of the drama, pageantry, grandeur and excitement of the sports festival has been imprisoned in film as a legacy for future historians in a breath-takingly beautiful color documentary, "La Grande Olimpiade" or "The Great Olympics."

Consul General Luis R. Mercado of the Dominican Republic announced yesterday that he had been instructed by his Government to state that "there exists no understanding or deals of any kind whatsoever between the Dominican Republic and the Castro Communist regime in Cuba."
Large gains in heavy-volume air-cargo shipments were predicted yesterday by several major airlines as a result of a new trans-Atlantic rate agreement concluded in Montreal Monday.
BALTIMORE, May 16 (AP) -- Ben Weiner's Orleans Doge was listed today as a probable starter for Saturday's Preakness Stakes at Pimlico.

Stanley R. Broff, New York builder, has been elected president of Tenney-Broff Corporation. It was recently formed as a construction and real estate development subsidiary of Tenney Corporation, the national real estate investment concern.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 16 -- A German pastor testified today that Adolf Eichmann harbored a demonic hatred of Jews and was quite impervious to pleas for clemency.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., May 16 -- Victor J. Shankey, Supervisor of the Town of Haverstraw, protested today to Governor Rockefeller over the state's assessments on state-owned land that now totals 65 per cent of the 14,399-acre township.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- Republicans called today for an investigation of why Congressional hearings on the Massachusetts highway program were postponed last year.
Tail-gating, or following the automobile ahead too closely, is the greatest cause of vehicular fatalities here, the Police Department's annual statistical report said yesterday.

George Kirby, a gifted, 35-year-old comedian whose personal tragedy put a five-year gap in his career, made a publicly unannounced appearance at Basin Street East in the early morning hours yesterday. The show's star, Sarah Vaughan, cut short her own turn after two or three songs and, with a brief word of introduction, presented Mr. Kirby.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- All President Kennedy's news these days is not bad. His legislative program is doing better than had been expected. His domestic program is making more progress than his foreign program. The coalition of Southern Democrats and conservative Republicans that was supposed to dominate the Congress has been powerful but not decisive.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Administration is planning to give the Air Force responsibility for the development of a new family of "super-booster" launching rockets using solid fuels.

Five outstanding race drivers from the Southwest have been invited to compete in the national Sports Car Club of America contests at the Bridgehampton, L.I., course on Saturday and Sunday, May 27 and 28.

A plot of land at the northeast corner of 149th Street and Concord Avenue in the Bronx has been sold for cash by Robert Hall Clothes, Inc., to Trio Investors. It will be improved with a two-story factory building.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, May 17 -- Lieut. Gen. Chang Do Young's military junta, which is opposed by United States officials here, said today it had full control of the South Korean Government and of the country.
The Board of Education is seeking to obtain city approval for a move that would give teachers an extra $2,280,000-a-year pay increase starting in the 1962-63 fiscal year.

GENEVA, May 16 -- The home town of John Calvin, who believed in predestination, has not been a lucky one for American diplomacy. Here, in recent years, we have been crossed and doublecrossed on Germany. Here we reluctantly sat down with, among others, the Chinese Communists and took part in Vietnam's amputation.
The International Business Machines Corporation got a new president yesterday. He is Albert L. Williams, who joined the company as a student sales representative twenty-five years ago.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- Senate investigators were told today that testimony they received last week linking a high executive of the General Electric Company to price-fixing activities was erroneous.
The Federal Maritime Board yesterday began an investigation of complaints by the American Society of Travel Agents against the Trans-Atlantic Passenger Steamship Conference.

NO longer can the 28,000,000 fishing enthusiasts in the United States be called fishermen. For, according to the Sport Fishing Institute's 1960 statistics, 25 per cent are fisherwomen. And this year 30 per cent of those wading, baiting and casting in fresh as well as salt water are expected to be women.

W. Gunther Plaut's accusation against German indemnification courts and administrative agencies (May 3) of "immoral interpretation of the law" because they do not award civil service pensions to persons who passed state examinations but did not enter the civil service due to Nazi persecution needs a correction.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- President Kennedy and Dr. Walter R. Hallstein, president of Europe's Common Market, conferred today on the problems created by that six-nation trade bloc. They paid particular attention to the market's effect on United States agriculture and African and Latin-American economies.
SEOUL, Wednesday, May 17 -- A United States spokesman said last night that relatively few troops had been involved in the uprising and the rebels appeared to have little popular support.

Sixteen disabled persons were honored last night by the Federation of the Handicapped for their social and vocational adjustment.

A working agreement to reform youthful offenders has been set up by Manhattan courts and the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

News for young people will become a regular weekday feature of the American Broadcasting Company Television network in the fall.

Hard on the heels of the New York Philharmonic's first visits to the Orient and to Alaska, the orchestra has undertaken its first full week of children's concerts.

The scholarship fund of the Educational Institute for Learning and Research will benefit from the May Festival of Art at the Graham Gallery, 1014 Madison Avenue. The exhibition of modern art will open May 23 and be on display daily through June 24.

The International Longshoremen's Association canceled yesterday its pledge to enter a mutual-aid pact with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the National Maritime Union.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- A call on the United States to beat the Soviet Union in the development of giant electrical power was sounded today at a meeting honoring the late Senator George W. Norris. Mr. Norris has been described as the father of the Tennessee Valley Authority.
PHILADELPHIA, May 16 -- Dr. Ivor Griffith, president of the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and Science since 1940, died today at his home in the Germantown section here. He was 70 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The House tentatively approved the Administration's tourism program on a voice vote today.
GENEVA, May 16 -- The United States has drafted a new plan for Laos to safeguard her neutrality as a unified country.
At the annual luncheon of the Order of Lafayette, to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Friday, General of the Army Douglas MacArthur will receive the organization's first freedom award.

CLEVELAND, May 16 (AP) -- Shareholders of the New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad approved today a merger with the Norfolk and Western Railway Company -- a step toward creation of a new rail system that would extend from Norfolk, Va., to Omaha, Neb.
YONKERS, May 16 -- "killing" was made tonight when Ted Lybrook, an 11-year-old pacer, won-the fourth race at Yonkers Raceway, following a last-flash dropdown of 5 points.

PUTTING a man into space has been a hazardous adventure. It is less well known that artists have also, for some time, been trying to put a man into a space where his survival is doubtful -- a space filled by the cosmic energies of abstract expressionism.
Two humorous novels set in Britain's African colonies will be published next month.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UPI) -- Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, wants television and radio stations to start paying for their licenses. He also wants all radio "hams" to pay for their permits and help to finance the F.C.C.'s licensing activities.
A bumper crop of mosquitoes is expected this summer as a result of the wet spring.

The touchy matter of selling to Cuba was in the news yesterday. There was word from Canada that the Columbia Cellulose Company, a subsidiary of a United States company, was participating in a $1,000,000 order of pulp for Cuba.
Cotton futures declined 6 to 13 points (30 to 65 cents a bale) yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

TRENTON, May 16, (AP) -- A bill aimed at giving the bi-state Waterfront Commission added powers was discussed in the Senate Republican caucus yesterday but fell one short of the required number of votes.

The cruiser U.S.S. Newport News may be boarded this week-end from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. at Pier 84, at the foot of Forty-second Street. Other vessels at near-by piers that may be examined by the public as part of Armed Forces Week celebration include the destroyer U.S.S. Joseph P. Kennedy and the submarine U.S.S. Reindeer. Admission is free.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 16 (AP) -- One of the largest assemblies of movie stars in years met today to pay final tribute to Gary Cocper.

Short covering and general buying firmed copper futures prices early yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The market eased later in the session, but then rallied on renewed buying to close at new highs for the lives of the contracts.

WASHINGTON', May 16 (UPI) -- The South Korean Army currently has eighteen divisions and, with supporting services, totals about 600,000 men. Each South Korean division includes 14,000 men.

Events today: Gerre Hancock, organist, St. Bartholomew's Church, 12:10 P.M.; John Upham, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Broadway and Fulton Street, 12:30; Four Ages of Recorder Music, Barbizon-Plaza Theatre, 106 Central Park South, 8:30; Musica Hebraica Concerta, Hebrew Union College, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street, 8:15.

American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc., is preparing for the time when live television programs transmitted by space satellites across continents will become a reality, Leonard H. Goldenson, president, disclosed at the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday.

THE woman who has only the vaguest notions of what she wants in a summer shoe can have a field day making up her mind at Macy's. The entire sixth floor in the Seventh Avenue building is devoted to women's shoes, shoes and more shoes.

A new $225,000 automation system here has begun speeding parcels toward their destinations. It lies deep in the multi-level, nether region of conveyor belts, chutes, lifts and rumbling carts that lies between the floor of the Main Post Office and the subterranean Pennsylvania Railroad tracks.
