The appointment of Dr. M. Forest Ashbrook as the first director of The Interchurch Center, 475 Riverside Drive, was announced yesterday.

DETROIT, May 16 -- Sales at retail of new cars in the first ten days of May followed the upward trend established earlier this spring but continued below daily rates for the 1959 and 1960 periods. Purchases of new cars built in the United States totaled 165,130 units for the nine selling days in the May 1-10 period, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.
LONDON, May 16 -- Britain's trade deficit, the excess of her imports over exports and re-exports, was considerably smaller last month than in March.

The military coup in South Korea appears to belong in the category of military uprisings that have occurred in a number of Asian countries in recent years. WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Senate Democratic leaders agreed today to seek the passage of separate bills authorizing Federal aid to public and private schools.

It is good news that the International Longshoremen's Association has torpedoed the mutual aid pact its president, Capt. William V. Bradley, had committed himself to sign with James R. Hoffa's Teamsters Union. We hope the third partner in this ill-conceived alliance, Joseph Curran's National Maritime Union, will follow suit. The proposed pact was an affront both to the public welfare and to trade union morality.

A stricter screening of foreign physicians seeking interneships and residencies in American hospitals is producing a sharp increase in the number of qualified candidates taking the screening tests before coming to this country.
JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), May 17 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion talked bluntly in the Knesset (Parliament) today about Jews in the United States who call themselves Zionists.

STORE buyers and the fashion press sat expectantly on the edge of their chairs at the beginning of the showing of fall fashions yesterday in Dior-New York's pearl gray and white salon. But before the show came to an end, everyone was far more relaxed.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) -- A Government auditor told House investigators today that the United States had spent $13,000,000 on a drought relief program for Peru but that only 5 per cent of the food had been given free to needy victims.

THE Barclay Bridge Club, recently established in a new shopping center in Jackson Heights, Queens, is devoted chiefly to duplicate bridge. The deal shown comes from a duplicate game played there last Sunday for the benefit of the National Association for National Health.
Don Budge and Ellsworth Vines, two of the outstanding names in American tennis, introduced Paradise Tennis to a selected gathering of enthusiasts yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 17 -- Foreign Minister Afonso Arinos de Melo Franco said at a Congressional hearing today that Brazil was opposed to international communism and to the introduction of the Communist system in Latin America.
St. John's gained sole possession of first place in the Metropolitan Baseball Conference yesterday by scoring a 5-3 decision over Wagner at Grymes Hill on Staten Island.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, May 18 -- South Korea's military junta emerged triumphant today as Premier John M. Chang came out of hiding. The Premier announced his resignation and that of his nine-month-old Cabinet.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The United States and the International Monetary Fund announced today a major program of financial assistance to rescue Brazil from a balance-of-payments crisis.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Peter H. Olson resigned today as secretary-treasurer of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union and was ordered to face a union trial tomorrow on corruption charges.

International air fares must be reduced 20 per cent by next year at the latest to give the airlines a 15 per cent increase in passengers and develop the long-awaited mass market, a top executive of Air-India said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges scored an initial success today in his effort to find a modern code of ethics for business.

NOTHING spoils a moth's summer like the news that the woman of the house is planing to send her furs to a department store for safe keeping. Regardless of where the fur was bought originally, most stores offer storage facilities and will, in most cases, pick up and deliver on request.
ALBANY, May 17 -- Thomas B. Gilchrist Jr., a lawyer with wide experience as an investigator, was assigned by Governor Rockefeller today to clean up bingo.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The head of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that its management assumed liability for the price-fixing conspiracy because it could not meet its responsibility "by making scapegoats of a few."
NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 17 -- The Women s Auxiliary of the Phelps Memorial Hospital is planning an old-time country fair based on a circus theme for June 3 from noon to midnight.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- William L. Batt Jr. was confirmed by the Senate today as administrator of the program to help distressed areas.
PITTSBURGH, May 17 (AP) -- Smoky Burgess walloped a double and a single tonight, driving in three of Pittsburgh's four runs as the Pirates downed the St. Louis Cardinals, 4 -- 3, at Forbes Field.

The little French girl who on Nov. 5, 1918, welcomed liberating American troops with a bag of caramels at Stonne, in the Ardennes, is much luckier than she may think. That is even allowing for her good fortune in coming here on Sunday as the guest of the former doughboys.
PARIS, May 17 (AP) -- Ron Holmberg of Brooklyn gained the third round of the French tennis tournament today by eliminating Pierre Jauffret of France, 6 -- 3, 10 -- 8, 6 -- 4.
The Health Department's 1961 anti-polio campaign will start Saturday when two mobile clinics and door-to-door vaccination teams offer free protection to residents of the upper West Side.
A new president and new chairman were elected yesterday by the directors of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company. The directors also announced seven other executive changes.
" AMERICAN PAINTING, 1865-1905," the new exhibition at the Whitney Museum, admirably surveys the forty years of our native art from the Civil War to the dawn of the twentieth century.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- A scientific debate between the United States and Britain appeared imminent today on the question: how thick is the ice on the road to the South Pole?

A posthumous edition of the memoirs of Michel Fokine (1880-1942), the famous choreographer, will be issued by Little Brown on June 8. "Fokine: memoirs have been translated tells of his efforts to become a ballet master and of the many noted persons he knew, among them Nijinsky, Pavlova, Ravel, Stravinsky and Benois.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Two conclusions reached by this department after an examination of the origins of the currently hostile United States-Castro relations, and published here under date of May 10, have evoked an unusual number of remarkably uniform dissents from readers.
MINEOLA, L.I., May 17 -- The Nassau County Democratic executive committee designated, seven candidates tonight to run for county and town offices in the November elections.

WITH the approach of June let it be said that cake decorating is one of the easiest and most rewarding branches of the culinary arts. And, given a little practice, anyone can wield a pastry tube with estimable success.
MOSCOW, May 17 -- Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, reported today that Soviet commercial airliners were carrying supplies to forces supporting Prince Souvanna Phouma, former Premier of Laos.
Eighteen New York Central and New Haven Railroad trains were delayed from four to twenty-five minutes in the evening rush hour yesterday.

DARIEN, Conn., May 17 -- On April 21 the home of Charles O'Neill, opera and concert singer, was nearly destroyed by fire. Almost all the belongings of himself, his wife and their six children were gone.

It is the eleventh hour and the American ship of state is dangerously close upon the rocks in Taiwan. The peril might be avoided if our President were upon the captain's deck and the vessel were labeled "Honorable American Interest."

A 50-year-old United Parcel Service driver was shot and fatally wounded yesterday following a struggle with one of two men he found trying to steal packages from his truck at Fifty-third Street and Second Avenue.

DETROIT, May 17 (UPI) -- Nicholas Kelley Jr., a son of a partner in the New York law firm that has long represented Chrysler Corporation, has resigned as a Chrysler vice president, the auto company confirmed today.
CHICAGO, May 17 -- R. Sargent Shriver, director of the Peace Corps, said today that when the new agency was on a permanent footing it would require an annual budget of $25,000,000 to $40,000,000.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- The executive secretary of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee withdrew $19,000 of the organization's funds just before he left for Cuba early this year, Senate investigators have been told.
TUNIS, May 17 -- An eight-man delegation was named by the Algerian Provisional Government here today to conduct peace negotiations with France.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 17 (AP) -- The Government has refused to grant permission to a United Nations investigating committee to enter South-West Africa.

THE huge, rambling kitchen featured in model homes and envisoned as the ideal bailiwick for American women has not proved in all cases to be a labor-saving dream. For many a woman who does most of her own cooking, the small, compact kitchen is far more efficient.

If the First National City Bank of New York is permitted to acquire the National Bank of Westchester, White Plains, it intends to intensify its competition for home mortgages throughout the New York metropolitan area.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Thursday, May 18 -- The United States has agreed to increase military assistance to Thailand in the face of intensified Communist pressure from the direction of Laos.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Pentagon was under Democratic attack in the House and Senate today. The attacks exemplified the recent difficulties besetting Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Two members of a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee today questioned whether the Federal Government should pay for added police expenses of last fall's United Nations meeting, attended by Soviet Premier Khrushchev and other world figures.
The Animal Research Center was dedicated yesterday by Cornelia Otis Skinner, the actress.

THE man appointed to investigate bingo in New York State played the game only once. That was at the officers' mess at Camp Rucker, Ala., in World War II. He didn't win, but he says he has no reason to assume the game wasn't on the level.

In reporting to the United Nations recently on the dangers facing the world as a result of the vast and continuing increase in population, Eugene R. Black, head of the World Bank, has given some perspective to a problem that most of us face only in subjective terms, and then with varying degrees of annoyance.

The United States Supreme Court has been asked to reconsider its decision not to rule on a Pennsylvania Supreme Court finding that it has no jurisdiction in a labor dispute between American maritime unions and American owners of foreign-flag ships.
CHICAGO, May 17 (AP) -- A late surge of buying today raised the grain futures market and left most contracts with substantial gains at the close of the Board of Trade.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 17 (UPI) -- Mounting racial tensions in Alabama; quiet, orderly integration of lunch counters in Jacksonville, Fla., and a new drive to end segregation in Atlanta city parks and courts today marked the seventh anniversary of the historic United States Supreme Court decision that public school segregation is unconstitutional.
During their desperate pursuit of the Washington Senators at the Stadium yesterday, the Yankees employed every regular and reserve plus four pitchers -- all in vain.
LOS ANGELES, May 17 -- Marine engineers indicated today that they would oppose automation at sea in their negotiating sessions next month.

Ron Petro pitched a one-hit shutout and faced only twentyeight batters as Manhattan College scored a 7-0 decision :over City College in a Metropolitan Conference game at Ohio Field in the Bronx yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Theodore Kuss, a key designer of the offshore radar tower that collapsed, carrying twenty-eight men to their deaths, last Jan. 15 said today he was surprised it had stood up so long.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -- City Treasurer George Di-Lauro was suspended today for accepting a Christmas gift of whisky wrapped in two $100 bills from a contractor whose work on the city-owned Frankford Elevated Line is now under investigation.
PARIS, Thursday, May 18 (UPI) -- A Nation-wide transport workers strike began early today, tying up train and subway service. The unions seek to force President de Gaulle to permit wage increases.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., May 17 -- The F.W. Woolworth Company, which not so many years ago specialized in merchandise priced at not more than a dime, is planning to set up a chain of discount department stores.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Racial complications in a new form arose today and clouded prospects for Congressional approval of the Administration's $2,550,000,000 school-aid bill.

PENRHYNDEUDRAETH, Wales, May 17 -- The third Earl Russell, or Bertrand Russell, as he prefers to be called, will celebrate his eighty-ninth birthday tomorrow, still convinced that a world of free and happy people is possible.
New York's newest landmark, the sixth tallest building in the world, was opened yesterday at 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza, in the center of the billion-dollar redevelopment under way in lower Manhattan.

The American Broadcasting Company and the National Broadcasting Company both have scheduled new hour-long television drama shows about young physicians for next season. Those who look to A.B.C. will have the services of Dr. Casey, while those who prefer N.B.C. can depend upon Dr. Kildare.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 17 -- President Fouad Chehab asked Premier Saeb Salaam to form a new Government today.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee unanimously approved today a $1,000,000,000 increase in the Federal Housing Administration's authority to insure home loans.

Senol Birol, a 23-year-old internationalist with a sure shot, was the hero for the Besiktas team of Turkey last night at the Polo Grounds. The sharpshooting center forward got all three of his team's goals as Besiktas beat Karlsruhe of West Germany, 3 -- 1, in the opening game of the International Soccer League's second season.

Volume was light and trading was featureless yesterday on almost all New York commodity exchanges. Prices moved in narrow ranges and closed irregularly lower. Copper, cocoa, potatoes, the world sugar contract and coffee declined; cottonseed oil, domestic sugar futures and zinc rose, and price movements for wool and rubber were mixed.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy asked Congress today to help the Justice Department go after hoodlums and racketeers who "have become so rich and so powerful that they have outgrown local authorities.''

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 17 (AP) -- A bi-racial group of college students from Tennessee, trying to crack bus station segregation, went to jail today after a tense four hours at the Greyhound terminal here.
Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools, was criticized yesterday for going on a six-week trip abroad at a time when the city schools were confronted with a number of unresolved problems.

HAVANA, May 17 -- Premier Fidel Castro declared sarcastically tonight that he was willing to trade the captured members of the April 17 invasion to the United States for 500 bulldozers and tractors with caterpillar treads.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 (AP) -- A coroner's autopsy showed today that Harry Campbell, a promising lightweight boxer, had died of a massive brain damage -- much more severe than could be expected to result from one professional fight.
A 622-foot Navy troopship -- the first to be reactivated since the Korean War -- was moved into a Red Hook, Brooklyn, pier yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, May 17 -- The number of housing units in the state that must be sold or rented to anyone regardless of race, color or creed will increase 800 per cent on Sept. 1, the State Commission Against Discrimination said today.

A directorial switch has been made in "Kwamina," in which Sally Ann Howes and Johnny Sekka are to be starred. Robert Lewis is the new director of the musical by Richard Adler (music and lyrics) and Robert Alan Aurthur (book).
Mayor Wagner started a wave of political speculation yesterday by canceling a speech scheduled for Wichita, Kan., so that he could attend the Brooklyn Democratic fund-raising dinner tonight.

Directors of the Sinclair Oil Corporation at their organization meeting in Houston, Tex., yesterday, following that of the stockholders, designated Edward L. Steiniger, president, as the chief executive officer of the company, effective on June 1.

A little group made a pilgrimage yesterday to Greenwood Cemetery and the grave of George Catlin, America's first great painter of American Indians. There they dedicated the first tombstone it has ever had.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 17 (UPI) -- The San Juan Marlins of the International League announced tonight that they were transferring to Charleston, W.Va., for the remainder of the season "because we don't wish to be responsible for the insolvency of the league or other clubs."

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) -- United Press International's request for a nationwide mobile radio frequency for use in news gathering operations in behalf of newspapers and broadcasters was rejected today by the Federal Communications Commission.
The Curtiss-Wright Corporation has taken three steps in its program to broaden its electronic and nuclear development and production, the company has announced.

The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham, the Southern Baptist evangelist, said here yesterday that the Southerners who had attacked the integrationist "Freedom Riders" should be prosecuted "to the full extent of the law."
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, United States Ambassador to the United Nations, said tonight that the Soviet Union had "declared war" against the world organization.
Construction has begun on a twenty-one-story air-conditioned office building opposite the United States Customs House on the east blockfront of Whitehall Street, between Stone and Bridge Streets.
The third annual May Ball, a dinner dance for the benefit of the Jacob Riis Neighborhood Settlement, was held last night in the Plaza.
GREENWICH, Conn., May 17 -- This town agreed today to a public debate on whether a shooting club should be permitted to establish a practice range on municipal property.
The most comprehensive program of automation job safeguards yet developed by any major union will be sought this summer by the United Packinghouse Workers of America.
LONDON, May 17 -- Small losses outnumbered gains in the stock market here today and turnover shrank.
GENEVA, May 17 -- The United States and the Soviet Union clashed tonight over Soviet proposals for a double-barreled veto over the authority of a control commission to maintain a neutral Laos.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 17 -- A Federal court jury began deliberations today in a $300,000 antitrust case against the United Mine Workers and the union's welfare fund.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy staged the opening round today in the developing political fight over whether to build an atomic power plant that would be the world's largest.

The Cuban Revolutionary Council called on the United States and Latin America yesterday to "take effective action" under inter-American pacts to support the council's efforts to overthrow Premier Fidel Castro.

The Pennsylvania State Public School Building Authority borrowed $24,580,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance building projects for twenty local school areas, to refund notes, and to provide funds for the completion of projects under construction.
RALEIGH, N.C., May 17 (AP) -- A North Carolina State College basketball player implicated in a point-fixing scandal was advised today not to accompany officers to New York.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Consumer groups, labor representatives, Senator Maurine B. Neuberger and several housewives came to the defense of the old-fashioned American ham today. They like it straight, without any water.

R.R. Donnelley Sons Company, a major commercial printer also known as the Lakeside Press, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed secondary offering of 270,000 common' shares to the public.
LONDON, May 17 -- The prospect of a meeting between President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev has been widely welcomed here.

BUFFALO, May 17 -- Paul D. McKelvey was elected today moderator of the 3,000,000-member United Presbyterian Church. - The 3-year-old Los Angeles business man succeeds the Rev. Dr. Herman L. Turner of Atlanta.

ANACONDA, Mont., May 17 (AP) -- An estimated 400 to 500 stockholders met here today to hear Clyde E. Weed, chairman of the Anaconda Company spell out an optimistic forecast for company operations this year.
The Transit Authority has reported to Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy that for years leading manufacturers have been submitting identical bids on subway car wheels and cable.

A FEW decades ago people laughed at cultists who announced that the world was about to end and that immediate repentance was in order. Nowadays the idea is a main stock in trade for -- among many others -- our novelists.
SEARCY, Ark., May 12 -- This small town in central Arkansas is perhaps the most prolific center of aggressive anti-Communist propaganda in the United States.

ONE afternoon recently, a Long Island housewife whose home was in the midst of being remodeled was asked by her contractor to sign the completion certificate. He said that his bank was withholding funds until he could produce this signed document.
CINCINNATI, May 17 (AP) -- Warren C. Giles, the National League president, barred his umpires today from appearing on radio programs of a controversial nature.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., May 17 (UPI) -- The executive committee of the Professional Golfers Association withdrew its 1962 national championship from Los Angeles for racial reasons today and recommended that the P.G.A. eliminate racial restrictions on membership.
BOSTON, May 17 (AP) -- Bobby Locke and Barry Latman of the Cleveland Indians combined for a six-hit, 1-0 shutout of the Boston Red Sox today, beating Billy Monbouquette.

United States Government securities broke sharply in price yesterday as the market adjusted itself to the likelihood of a new advance refunding of Treasury debt.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 17 -- The Long Island Kennel Club will hold its fifty-ninth annual Dog Show and Obedience Trial on Sunday on the Horse Show Grounds of the Piping Rock Club. The event will be a benefit for the Community Hospital at Glen Cove.
Marketing experts frequently can learn more from random remarks by housewives than they can from careful statistical profiles of sales.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 17 (AP) -- The New York State Attorney General today endorsed the New York Central Railroad's request that the Interstate Commerce Commission make one case out of five pending proposals for mergers of eastern railroads.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 17 -- New Jersey bankers remain strongly opposed to any change in the state's branch banking laws, a membership poll of the New Jersey Bankers Association is expected to show.

American Telephone and Telegraph Company made good yesterday on its promise to some 1,918,000 stockholders. It raised the quarterly dividend to 90 cents a share from the 82 1/2 cents it had paid previously.
THE rapture and jubilation that George Gershwin poured into "Porgy and Bess" were at full tide at the City Center last night.

Goldman, Sachs Co. and associates offered to the public yesterday $20,000,000 of 5 per cent twenty-year sinking fund debentures of the Federal Paper Board Company, Inc. The debentures were priced at 99 to yield 5.08 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- The Tariff Commission recommended today that President Kennedy increase the tariff on glass imports to protect the domestic industry from what it called "serious injury."

AS is usually the case with a day game after a night game, the ballplayers were in no hurry to check in for work at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. They drifted into the clubhouse in desultory fashion but none escaped the eagle eye of Pete Private, the clubhouse attendant. He collared each new arrival.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- A New York City theatrical ticket broker testified today that he had falsified some evidence that figures in a Senate investigation of graft by Federal employes.
Prizes were awarded yesterday at the eleventh annual exhibition of the interhospital photograph contest conducted by the Volunteer Service Photographers.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The House passed by a vote of 305 to 104 today its bill designed to attract more visitors to the United States. The measure seeks to promote better understanding of the country and its international objectives and to improve the flow of dollars into the country.
Irving Byron Associates have purchased the six-story building with forty-three apartments at 631 East 168th Street, corner of Boston Road, the Bronx, from 631 East 168th Street Realties, Inc.

McClellan and an "anti-labor drive of unparalleled intensity."
The Singer Manufacturing Company registered a 16 per cent increase in earnings in the first quarter of 1961 on a sales gain of 12 per cent, Donald P. Kircher, president, reported yesterday.
ALGIERS, May 17 (AP) -- One person was killed and at least ten were injured tonight in a new series of terrorist attacks by both Algerian and European activists.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 17 (AP) -- An American-piloted helicopter, missing since Monday, was spotted seemingly undamaged in a rice field in Communist rebel territory forty miles north of here today. It had been camouflaged.

PALERMO, Sicily, May 17 -- Silvio Milazzo, leader of the Christian Social Union, was today elected President of the semi-autonomous region of Sicily, defeating the candidate of the Christian Democratic party, Natale di Napoli.
A book sold in 1942 by a persuasive bookseller for $5,000 was purchased back by him for $44,000 at a two-day auction sale that ended yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds made only three hits off John Buzhardt tonight but they combined two of them with a walk and a sacrifice fly in the third inning for two runs and a 2-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 17 -- President Quadros ordered today the burning of huge Government stocks or commercially valueless coffee.

OTTAWA, May 17 -- President Kennedy urged Canada today to become a partner with the United States in Western Hemisphere affairs. In a speech to Parliament he de clared his belief that "all the free members of the Organization of American States would be heartened and strengthened by any increase in your hemispheric role."
SALT LAKE CITY, May 17 -- Western Governors voted today to go at least part way with President Kennedy's program for mobilizing the country in a broad offensive against juvenile delinquency.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 17 -- Students in five French classes at the Glen Cove High School have raised almost $1,000 to help five of their number continue the study of French here and abroad this summer.

A garment workers' union was accused yesterday by an official of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People of having denied membership to a Negro, ultimately causing his dismissal.

JERUSALEM (Israel Sector), May 17 -- A barrage of documentary evidence was produced today to counter Adolf Eichmann's contention that he had no power of decision over the life or death of European Jews.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 17 -- The Southern Pacific Company said yesterday the terms of its offer to acquire control of the Western Pacific Railroad were not necessarily final. Donald P. Russell, chairman and president of the Southern Pacific, explained at the annual meeting here that the offer to exchange one share of common for one share of Western Pacific common was subject to Government review.

The Senate's Democratic leadership, in moving for action on the $2.5 billion bill to aid public elementary and secondary schools, has acted wisely in turning down suggestions that the measure be linked to the National Defense Education Act. The managers of President Kennedy's education proposals have thus avoided dangerous pitfalls.

Edmond Hall, a veteran jazz clarinetist from New Orleans left Louis Armstrong's globe-girdling troupe three years ago because, as he told Mr. Armstrong, he "couldn't stand playing Dixieland all the time." Now he is ensconced with his own quintet at Eddie Condon's, 330 East Fifty-sixth Street, where he spends most of the evening playing Dixieland.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended on May 10:
WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) -- A Federal court jury convicted Claude A. Taylor today on fifty-two counts of fraud occurring while he was superintendent of the House of Representatives Folding Room.

NAMONE, Laos, May 17 -- After four days of bickering, rebel and Government negotiators agreed today to discuss the establishment of a coalition government for Laos and a joint military committee to help supervise the ceasefire.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 17 -- Delinquent borrowers from the Englewood Public Library who have ignored all requests to return books they borrowed in 1960 will be listed in a notice to be published as an advertisement in the local newspaper tomorrow.

The State Investigation Commission charged yesterday that false financial and work records of the Broadway Maintenance Corporation were used to conceal excessive profits and failure to perform properly on city contracts.

Peter Joyce of Browning School defeated Perry Hudson of Friends Academy, 6 -- 8, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 0, in a second-round singles match, the only one played yesterday in the twenty-ninth annual Eastern Private Schools tennis championships at the Hi-Way Courts, Brooklyn.

The average New Yorker, and his name is legion, knows and cares far too little about his city government. He should know more after watching the two-hour television program on Sunday evening, June 4, announced by Mayor Wagner to explain "the complex operation of New York City government."
MINNEAPOLIS, May 17 -- The public's picture of mothers who receive aid-to-dependent-children funds is out of focus, the National Conference on Social Welfare was told today.
Business was bad this year at the Italian Gardens "wishing pool" in front of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 17 -- The latest development in closing the gap between the movie and television industries is the adaptation of old movies into video series.
Leonard F. McCollum, president and a director of the Continental Oil Company, sold 15,000 shares of the company's common stock last month, reducing his investment to 85,960 shares.

Francis J. Kleban, a builder, said yesterday that he had broached the idea of a residential community on Welfare Island to city officials two years ago -- long before a syndicate headed by Frederick W. Richmond developed the plan it made public on Tuesday.
Twelve alleged members of an international narcotics ring were arrested yesterday and held in bail totaling $925,000.
In a survey of 610 Brooklyn women, designed to uncover hidden cases of cancer, only 207 proved to be free of disease in the pelvic area.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- John B. Oakes, editorial page editor of The New York Times, agreed today to serve another year as a member of the Advisory Board on National Parks.
The United States Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that a taxpayer could not deduct as a loss any income he had earned but never collected because it had been embezzled.

I was delighted to find an article in the April 30 Times on language training at the Foreign Service Institute and to read that "no one denies that foreign language skills are vital in the conduct of foreign affairs." But I was astonished and then dismayed that one of the fifty-three languages taught there, Tamil, was described as "a minority language spoken in Ceylon."
NEW BRITAN, Conn., May 17 (AP) -- The J.B. Williams Company of New York has won control of Landers, Frary Clark of New Britain in a stock deal exceeding $9,000,000, it was announced yesterday.
An experiment in family camping will be conducted this summer by the Young Woman's Christian Association of Brooklyn.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 17 (AP) -- Joe Bellino, star Navy halfback, today became the first middle in forty-two years to win the academy's two top athletic awards.

Power production rose in the week ended last Saturday to 14,278,000,000 kilowatt hours from 14,206,000,000 the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the comparable 1960 period the figure was 13,710,000,000 kilowatt hours.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Military Appeals, a civilian body, accused the Army today of trying to destroy the legal rights of servicemen by proposing major changes in the Code of Military Justice of 1951.

WASHINGTON, ay 17 (UPI) -- George Meany said today that the late liberal senator George W. Norris would have been "ashamed" of the nation's progress on public power projects and other welfare legislation.
ONE of the unromantic facts to be faced by June brides is that 80 per cent of them will have to handle the family finances.
New legislation to prevent harassment of tenants being evicted to make way for major reconstruction was proposed by Mayor Wagner yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) -- The House of Representatives declared Cuba to be a "clear and present danger" to this hemisphere today and urged the Organization of American States to take collective action against Premier Castro.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 16 -- Harsh police measures, including beatings and the wholesale arrest of students, have marred the celebration here of the 150th anniversary of Paraguay's independence.
Columbia's varsity lightweights scored a convincing victory over the New York Athletic Club on the Harlem River yesterday.

Hundreds of Negroes and whites joined Congress of Racial Equality demonstrators here yesterday in picketing the terminals of the Greyhound and Trailways bus lines in protest against segregated bus stations in the South.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 17 -- Dick Edmunds led the Princeton track team to an 87 1/3-53 2/3 victory over Penn in Palmer Stadium today.

I want to go on record as being opposed to the projected addition to Pelham Bay Park. The northeast Bronx does not need additional park area. The existing Pelham Bay Park is not completely utilized. There are large tracts of land currently owned by the city that are undeveloped, such as Ferry Point and Soundview.

ANACONDA, Mont., May 17 (UPI) -- Mr. Weed noted that contracts covering most of Anaconda's major producing properties were not scheduled to come up for renegotiation until next year and that therefor he did not expect work stoppages this year to have as heavy an impact on operations as they did in 1960.

LINDEN, N.J., May 17 -- The settlement of a strike that has made 2,600 production workers idle at the General Motors Corporation assembly plant here since May 1 was announced today by Local 595, United Auto Workers.
A recent ruling that schools in New York State should, upon request, show parents psychiatric reports on their children is opposed by the Medical Society of the County of New York.

Members of Local 6 of the International Typographical Union voted last night in the biennial election of officers. In early returns, Bertram A. Powers, vice president, led by better than 2-to-1 for the presidency. Final returns were expected by noon today.

National Sales Executives-International yesterday chose Peter E. Schruth, vice president and advertising director of the Saturday Evening Post, as its "Sales Executive of the Year." The award was made at the organization's twenty-sixth annual convention in San Francisco.
BALTIMORE, May 17 (AP) -- Phil Regan pitched Detroit to a 9-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight as the Tigers swept the three-game series.

The Harry Weinberg interests were charged yesterday with using their suit against Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., as a propaganda weapon in a simultaneous proxy fight to curb or oust management. Fifth Avenue Coach made this accusation in State Supreme Court.

WHAT could be less uplifting -- or entertaining -- than a drearily handled little drama with a cynical plot and a no-good hero? All this, and Frankie Vaughan (a popular "vocalist" from Britain), too, turned up yesterday on the circuits in "The Right Approach," a feeble Twentieth Century-Fox package also including Martha Hyer, Juliet Prowse and Gary Crosby.
G. Mennen Williams last night urged a speed-up in the "unfinished business of a full first-class citizenship for all Americans."

It is far too early to foresee success for conferences at Geneva and in Laos aimed at settling the Laotian civil war and neutralizing the kingdom, but what has happened so far is moderately encouraging.

YONKERS, May 17 -- Apmat, the pride of Australia and the 2-1 favorite to win tomorrow night's $50,000 National Championship Pace at Yonkers Raceway, may be sold outright or leased to American owners at any moment.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants scored two runs in the ninth inning today and beat the Chicago Cubs, 4 to 3. The winning run scored when Don Elston, a relief pitcher, walked Jim Marshall with the bases filled and one out.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- In a move to speed highway construction, President Kennedy ordered today the release of $818,000,000 in Federal funds that normally would not have become available until July 1.

Warnings against over-speculation and promises of new Washington investigations of the stock market had sharply recognizable effects in yesterday's trading. There was a strong move to switch out of glamour stocks and into the issues that make up the principal market averages.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Agriculture Department and the State Department are contending for control of the Administration's new Food-for-Peace program.
OTTAWA, May 17 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy has won the hearts of usually blase Ottawans.

Effective June 1, New York State motorists planning to tour outside this country and Canada need not surrender their New York license plates and registration even though they temporarily terminate automobile insurance required by this state.
GUILDFORD, England, May 17 -- High on Stag Hill, overlooking Guildford and the rolling green Downs of Surrey, the newest cathedral in the Anglican Communion was consecrated today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- The National Association of Manufacturers found nothing right with President Kennedy's tax program today. It said no action on taxes would be better than "a wrong and dangerous kind."

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- An Iowa lawyer who was involved indirectly in a bitter election controversy ten years ago won bipartican praise today from a Senate committee that approved his appointment to an Administration post.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- James M. Landis, President Kennedy's special assistant on the regulatory agencies, was honored tonight by the Federal Trial Examiners Conference.
Montreal, Canada, announced yesterday that it had borrowed $25,000,000 on long-term bonds payable in United States money.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Officials in Washington were hopeful today that political authority in South Korea would quickly be returned to civilian hands.
NEW DELHI, India, May 18 -- Vice President Johnson declared today that the United States fully supported India's quest for economic security and shared her goal of peace.

LOS ANGELES, May 18 -- The 11,000-member Marine Engineers Union voted a policy of "no contract, no work" today. It threatened to tie up 90 per cent of United States-flag shipping unless contract terms were worked out by June 15.
SEVENTH AVENUE was like a three-ring circus yesterday as six important American designers unveiled their fall collections before a harassed multitude of buyers and reporters.
Three bankers were charged yesterday with embezzling $1,562,000 of an Oklahoma bank's funds and using part of the money to buy controlling interest in the bank.

ST. LOUIS, May 18 -- Dr. Arthur Holly Compton, Nobel Prize-winning physicist and former Chancellor of Washington University here, will serve at three widely separated institutions in the coming academic year.
With Tommy Walsh keeping him in front almost all the way, Mrs. Lawrence Knapp Jr.'s Little Gil took the $14,300 Aqueduct Spring Steeplechase yesterday.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., May 18 (UPI) -- Art Wall Jr. and Buster Cupit, a part time tournament player, shot seven-under-par 65's today to take the first-round lead in the $20,000 Hot Springs open golf tournament.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 18 -- More than 600 Africans have been arrested in the Johannesburg area in the last twenty-four hours.

Miss Elsie Y. Trask will be among those giving dinner parties this evening before the third annual Yorkville Ball at the Sheraton-East. She is chairman of the event, proceeds of which will go to the Yorkville Youth Council.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Publishers Association today opposed postal rate increases sought by the Administration.

TWENTY-SIX European master paintings belonging to the late Electra Havemeyer Webb, an early collector of American folk art, go on view today in a memorial exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum. These pictures -- with a few exceptions of the French Impressionist school -- will remain on view here until next year when they are to be permanently installed at the remarkable Shelburne Museum in Vermont, founded by Mrs. Webb in 1952.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 18 (AP) -- Manager Alvin Dark believes that the latest great catch by the San Francisco Giants center fielder, Willie Mays, was more difficult than his famed world series grab of 1954.
GENEVA, May 18 -- Canada demanded tonight that the Soviet Union agree to strengthen the powers of the International Control Commission to quell outbreaks of fighting in Laos.
Bertram A. Powers was elected to a two-year term as president yesterday by Local 6 of the International Typographical Union. He defeated William J. Horan by 5,089 to 3,511.

PREMIER KHRUSHCHEV told correspondents at a Finnish reception in Moscow in 1957 that Americans had stolen a Sputnik rocket. "We know it fell on the United States," he said, "but they do not want to give it back to us."

The proposal of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York to acquire six upstate banks through a new holding company must be judged in terms of its effect on the market areas in which the banks operate, G. Russell Clark, State Superintendent of Banks, said yesterday
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended last Saturday were 17 per cent above the level of a year earlier.
Mount St. Michael High swept into a commanding lead as the forty-sixth annual Athletic Association of Private Schools track and field championships opened yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Two airlines -- Northwest and Delta -- sued today in an attempt to prevent the merger of United and Capital Airlines.

Mayor Wagner yesterday accepted an offer by Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons to help improve patient care at Harlem Hospital and to widen educational opportunities for its medical staff.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, May 19 -- Lieut. Gen. Chang Do Young, chief of the four-day-old military junta, pledged his triumphant revolution anew to anti-communism today. He made an evident bid to win quick support from the United States and other Western countries.
President Kennedy's chief economic adviser said yesterday that the nation should increase its investment in human as well as physical resources to attain a higher rate of economic growth.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 18 -- Applause laced with disappointment was touched off here by the three-night, three-play stand of the Theatre Guild's American Repertory Company.

The city's Hospital Commissioner, Dr. Ray E. Trussell, declared yesterday that if there were to be any redevelopment of Welfare Island for housing purposes some provision must be made to replace the hospitals that would be razed.

Barring forbidding complications, President Kennedy now plans to meet Premier Khrushchev for informal bilateral talks in Vienna early next month in an effort to stem further deterioration of the world situation, to make a personal appraisal of the Soviet ruler's intentions and to warn him that the United States and the West are determined to defend the frontier of freedom.

The Appellate Division upheld yesterday all of the state law under which Mayor Wagner has set up a Charter Revision Commission. The court, acting with unusual speed, took only a five-minute recess after hearing oral arguments before handing down its ruling.
MOSCOW, May 18 -- Four Soviet generals and a colonel have been killed in an air crash, the Soviet Government announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- The Navy announced today a world speed record for helicopters -- 192.9 miles an hour.
The State Investigation Commission said yesterday the city was being overcharged $2,000,000 a year in its lighting, air-raid siren and parking-meter contracts.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 18 -- A rocket expert said tonight that the United States could score a major victory in the space race with a Manhattan Project effort in the field of communications satellites.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 18 (UPI) -- Four United States service men were reported being held by the Turkish police today after a scuffle in which one Turkish soldier accidentally shot another dead.

Your May 15 editorial on "The Population Explosion" will be applauded by thoughtful men and women throughout the world. For much too long has this situation, which will have a decisive impact on the future of developed as well as under-developed nations, been obscured by fear and a reluctance to face inescapable facts.

BONN, Germany, May 17 -- The Hamburg daily Die Welt published today the first letter in any prominent West German newspaper on the Eichmann trial. It was an anguished confession of "wild and outrageous shame" by a former German Air Force sergeant, Horst Poeschmann.
For many Wall Streeters May 29, as well as May 30, Memorial Day, will be a holiday.
BALTIMORE, May 18 (AP) -- Nashua Blue today was made a surprise likely starter in the eighty-fifth Preakness. He joined Carry Back and seven other colts for Maryland's 3-year-old classic at Pimlico.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Radio Corporation of America has been selected to build the Government's first experimental communications satellite capable of relaying telephone calls and television programs across the Atlantic.
The National Conference of Christians and Jews began a drive yesterday to eliminate references in Protestant and Roman Catholic texts and educational materials that might be considered anti-Semitic.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The necessity of meeting the lowest price in the market place at any given time, not collusion among competitors, is what causes identical prices and bidding in the electrical equipment industry, Senators were told today.
An enlarged program of claiming races will be introduced Monday night at Roosevelt Raceway when the twenty-second season of harness racing gets under way at the Westbury (L.I.) track.
James J. Moran, former city official, lost a plea yesterday for a suspension of a two-year prison sentence for income tax evasion.

The American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., confirmed yesterday the widely held view that it was gradually shifting from a utility holding company to one investing in "diversified industrial enterprises."
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Administration is hesitating about launching the first satellite carrying an atomic battery for fear of offending Cuba and other Latin-American countries.

After four days of rising prices, three of them spectacular, the stock market sold off yesterday. Before it did so, however, both The New York Times combined and industrial averages had made new highs since January, 1960.

The 300th anniversary of the first permanent settlement on Staten Island was celebrated yesterday in ceremonies aboard the Holland-America Line's flagstaff Rotterdam at the Fifth Street Pier in Hoboken.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- The Commerce Department reported today that the nation's production rate, had averaged $499,800,000,000 in the trough of the recession, the first quarter of 1961.
The Liggett Myers Tobacco Company yesterday took all of its business away from McCann-Erickson, Inc., and gave the billings to the J. Walter Thompson Company.
Paul O'Dwyer announced his candidacy for Controller yesterday in the Democratic primary on Sept. 7.
OTTAWA, May 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of a joint communiqu issued today by President Kennedy and Prime Minister John Diefenbaker at the end of the President's visit to Canada:
GENEVA, May 18 -- The Soviet Union pressed again today for a halt in France's nuclear tests.
What does a Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright do with the $500 that accompanies the award?

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York rose $28,000.000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a rise of $69,000,000 in the 1960 week.

LONDON, May 18 -- "The Sound of Music" won warm applause at its premiere at the Palace Theatre here tonight. But the newspaper critics were not impressed with Rodgers' and Hammerstein's last joint effort.
Four Harvard University professors accepted last night a challenge to debate the "entire issue of United States-Cuban relations" with members of the anti-Castro Cuban Revolutionary Council.

A move to speed the reduction of tariffs within the European Common Market was announced here yesterday by Dr. Walter Hallstein, president of the six-nation group's administrative commission. He announced that the commission in Brussels had requested the market's Council of Ministers to cut tariffs among their countries by 20 per cent next Jan. 1, instead of 10 per cent, as scheduled.
An expanded program to improve the medical care and treatment of victims of all types of birth defects was announced here yesterday by the National Foundation.
Yankee loyalists accustomed to watching their team crush second-division rivals with ease are beginning to wonder what's wrong with the American League champions.
CHICAGO, May 18 (AP) -- A nation-wide conference of Negro organizations win be held in Chicago at Oct. 27 to mobilize public opinion behind the Kennedy Administration's policy toward Africa.
Oliver A. Unger announced his resignation yesterday as chairman of the board, president and a director of National Telefilm Associates, Inc., which owns station WNTA-TV (Channel 13).

GENEVA, May 18 -- Belkacem Krim, tough, softspoken little Algerian guerrilla fighter three times condemned to death by the French authorities, brought a delegation of thirty-two negotiators, technicians and assistants here today from Tunis for peace talks with the French Government.

WHAT a joy fruit and vegetable stands are gradually becoming. First-of-the-season cherries and peaches are visible and, if they are not of highest quality or lowest cost, they still are a welcome addition to what is available.
Shabuoth, the Jewish commemoration of the giving of the Ten Commandments will begin tomorrow at sundown.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Senate has just demonstrated its versatility as well as its love of culture by turning two successive days from grappling with acute world and domestic problems to discover and ascend a hitherto undiscovered peak of etymology. The leader of this expedition onto a height never before attained by any English lexicographer, his fair hair flying above his classic but determined features, was Albert Gore, Democrat, the junior Senator from Tennessee.
LONDON, May 18 -- A Government motion seeking support for Britain's efforts to strengthen Western unity and improve East-West relations was approved in the House of Commons today without a vote.
A record outlay for school construction and plant improvement over the next six years was urged yesterday by the Board of Education's committee on buildings and sites.

The Texas Railroad Commission yesterday ordered the regulated oil wells in the state to continue producing on an eight-day pattern for June, unchanged from May. This works out to an average permissible output of 2,702,699 barrels a day, or an increase of 48,013 since June has one fewer day.

IT'S never too late in the season for an ingratiating musical like "Donnybrook!" Although it does not swing an entertainment haymaker, the new show that opened at the 46th Street Theatre last night moves with grace and style and jabs its way smoothly under your guard.

The New Jersey Legislature is encouraging the underworld by its delay in passing a bill to close loopholes in the regulatory powers of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor. Governor Rockefeller already has signed the companion bill enacted by the New York Legislature, and action in Trenton is essential.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 18 -- A crowd of 80,000 National Front supporters cheered demands today for immediate elections in defiance of the plans of the reform regime of Premier Ali Amini.

Yee Hong Yin gives his age as "66 up," though informed speculation puts it at "at least 75." He dwells in a room on the Bowery at the Salvation Army's Memorial Hotel for Men. He spends eight hours nearly every day in a settlement house, painting in the style called primitive.
Evidence is mounting that a new operation can prevent heart attacks in selected individuals.

The police raided the Brooklyn headquarters of Anthony Anastasia's International Long-shoremen's Association yesterday and arrested five men on charges of participating in a $500,000-a-year numbers and bookmaking racket.
PARIS, May 18 -- Is the pound sterling seriously, and perhaps permanently, sick?

Wetlands are a boggy or swampy area, whose water may be fresh, salt or brackish. They are the breeding ground for the migratory ducks and geese which at this season rocket out of the sky to land with a bright splash in park pond or rural woodland pool to court, feed, gabble and lift the spirits of the beholder.

YONKERS, May 18 -- False Step of New Zealand, in front before the first turn had been completed, remained on top thereafter without too much trouble tonight and captured the $50,000 National Championship Pace at Yonkers Raceway before a crowd of 30,711.
The Women's City Club of New York announced yesterday the election of Mrs. Helen Crosby West to a two-year term as president.
Joseph T. Sharkey praised the Wagner administration last night as one marked by "progress."

Shares in Howard Johnson Company, the restaurant chain, were offered for the first time to the public yesterday by Blyth Co., Inc. and F.S. Moseley Co at $38 a share. In all, 660,000 common shares of $1 par were offered.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points up on a bid on old October to 4 to 11 points off on other contracts yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 18 -- Spain presented a detailed report of her overseas provinces to the United Nations for the first time today.
The first public hearing of the Mayor's Charter Revision Commission elicited strong opinions for and against submission to referendum of a new Charter in November.

"BECAUSE he writes fiction in order to reflect or illuminate life, his materials obviously must come out of life." When he wrote this sentence for an article in The Saturday Review, Wallace Stegner was discussing the function of a novelist who aspires to be a serious literary artist.
ALBANY, May 18 -- The Long Island Rail Road's campaign to free its commuter fare regulation from direct state supervision received another setback today.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 17 -- Opponents of the Paraguayan Government protested today that the regime had used policemen and armed civilian thugs to break up a peaceful student demonstration Monday.
LONDON, May 18 -- A dull tendency prevaded the whole stock market here today as profit-taking ahead of the long Whitsun holiday affected nearly all the industrial leaders.

PARIS, May 18 -- Life became complicated for millions of Frenchmen today when about 500,000 of their fellow-citizens stopped the nation's trains, the Paris subway and buses and gas and electricity supplies.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 18 (UPI) -- Willie Shoemaker scored three victories today at Hollywood Park and lifted his lifetime total to 3,999.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 18 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold reported today that the danger of civil war had been "substantially" reduced in the Congo.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Congress was asked today to exempt live dramatic or musical performances from the 10 per cent Federal tax on theatre ticket charges.

Events today: Hanoch Greenfeld, pianist, Town Hall, 5:30; Gil Evans and his orchestra and Miles Davis and his quintet, Carnegie Hall, 8:40; Albert Vecins, tenor, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Denise Morand, 'cellist, and Rose Marie De Leyritz, pianist, Galerie des Arts 215 East Eighty-second Street, 8; Christine Chvartazky, pianist, New York College of Music, 8:30.

A City College "faculty" team, beefed up by a majority of undergraduates, defeated the senior class, 7 to 5, yesterday, in the traditional softball game. Victory could properly be credited to the umpire, the school's retiring president, Buell G. Gallagher.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Senator Stuart Symington, Missouri Democrat, won a fight today against Defense Department censoring of some testimony by one of its witnesses.
Foes of folk singing in Washington Square warned City Hall yesterday they would call out Greenwich Village residents for a mass rally unless the ban on Sunday minstrelsy was reimposed.

The pace of price decline in United States Government securities was arrested yesterday by buying of a largely professional kind. The demand was not large enough to prevent most of the Treasury list from showing losses on the day.
CORNING, N.Y., May 18 -- One hundred leaders of education, the arts, business and labor were told here tonight that communism is "a passing phase in history."

UNDULY sensitive distaff theatregoers are hereby warned to stay clear of the Greenwich Mews Theatre on West Thirteenth Street where "Princess Ida," the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta that deliciously gibes at women's rights, opened last night.

THE city of Birmingham was the subject of last night's installment of "C.B.S. Reports" over Channel 2. Taking the form of a half-hour of interviews with white citizens followed by a haft-hour of interviews with Negro citizens, it was a program that encompassed a wide range of opinions on the racial difficulties and violence that have beset the Alabama community.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- President Kennedy's program to reorganize the Federal Communications Commission appeared tonight to be in danger of being killed by a Congressional veto. Powerful Democrats at the Capital are supporting a drive to disapprove the proposal.

LONDON, May 18 -- The Government's decision to establish four new universities was announced tonight by Sewyn Lloyd, the Chancellor of the Exchequer. Three will be at Canterbury, Colchester and Coventry and the fourth at a place still to be decided.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The new deputy director of civil defense predicted today that President Kennedy would make "some firm decisions" soon on programs to save the population against a nuclear attack.
Besides bad weather, wind squalls and high seas, the pleasure-boat skipper and his family on their cruiser, sail boat or runabout face another ugly enemy when they go to sea. The enemy is driftwood.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 18 -- Early this month Robert Mulligan stopped over in New York for one day on his way from Hollywood to South America in connection with a movie "The Spiral Road," which he is directing.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- President Kennedy returned from Canada today and plunged immediately into preparations for a conference with President de Gaulle at the end of the month.
DETROIT, May 18 -- John Dykstra, president of the Ford Motor Company, gave an optimistic report today on sales prospects for Ford and the automobile industry generally.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 18 -- The United States Children's Bureau, which has traditionally sought to protect parental rights and responsibilities toward children, will soon take what many child-welfare workers believe to be a next important step.
AMERICAN women have long coveted Danish home furnishings and toys. Now, a group of fashion manufacturers hopes to make them demand the made-in-Denmark label in their clothes.

The proposed mutual aid pact between James R. Hoffa's International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Joseph Curran's National Maritime Union has been put to the membership of the maritime union for approval.
TRENTON, May 18 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today the Port of New York Authority was considering jet passenger service at Newark Airport.

Production of lumber totaled 244,655,000 board feet in the week ended last Saturday, compared with 233,790,000 the week before, according to reports from regional associations. A year ago the figure was 255,848,000 board feet.
To bring the nation's best scientific brains to bear upon the problems of space research, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has established a special institute here.
Recent votes in Congress indicate that the United States Government will soon begin to make a modest, but welcome and useful, contribution toward attracting more foreign tourists to this country.
CHICAGO, May 18 (UPI) -- The United States Government today reinforced its ranks in its battle against organized crime with formation of a special prosecution unit.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Association of American Railroads reported today that car-loadings totaled 551,405 cars last week. That was 1.4 per cent more than in the preceding week but 13.8 per cent less than in the 1960 week.

It is said that John D. Rockefeller Sr., who lived a very long life, subsisted mainly on crackers and milk during his later years. Now one of his grandsons, Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, is recommending a similar diet for New York State employes, also for purposes of longevity.
A settlement of the strike that has closed the Bronx Zoo and Coney Island Aquarium to the public for forty-six days was announced last night by Mayor Wagner.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 18 -- The Congolese leaders who support President Joseph Kasavubu are laying out a pattern for nineteen states of a projected United States of the Congo.

The communique issued after President Kennedy's visit to Ottawa was new in its emphasis on hemispheric affairs. In fact, so far as is known, this was the most important feature of Mr. Kennedy's trip to Canada.
Commodities were mixed in generally quiet trading on New York exchanges yesterday. Sugar, which advanced, and cocoa, which declined, were the only commodities actively traded.
The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange stood at 3,525,326 shares on Monday, 197,779 shares below the mid-April figure of 3,723,105.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- President Kennedy got a bigger housing and urban renewal bill from the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today than he had requested.

Ralph Branca, the former Dodger pitcher, is weighing an offer to become head baseball coach at New York University next year. Bill McCarthy is retiring at the end of this season after forty years in the post.
The Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, Inc., achieved the highest sales and earnings in its history in the fifty-two weeks ended on Feb. 25.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI) -- House investigators today pictured a former United States Ambassador as an apparent "victim of deceit" by aides who kept him unaware of a $13,000,000 foreign aid scandal in Peru.
CHICAGO, May 18 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
MANHASSET, L.I., May 18 -- Apawamis retained the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub title today.
The Boys Club of New York will benefit from the fourteenth annual race meeting of the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association at the Blind Brook Club Course in Purchase, N.Y., on May 27.
A group of West Side mothers protesting "dangerous" equipment in New York City playgrounds will march with their children down Broadway this afternoon from Eighty-sixth to Seventy-second Street.
Three gunmen were captured yesterday and accused of the killing of a United Parcel Service driver on Wednesday.

The four-story store and apartment building at 678 Ninth Avenue, southeast corner of Forty-seventh Street, has been sold by Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Graziano to clients of Walter Scott Co. It occupies a lot 25 by 85 feet. The property, assessed valuation $55,000, was sold for cash. J.P. and L.A. Kissling were the brokers.

The "Big Seven" women's colleges mailed an undisclosed number of acceptance letters yesterday to high school seniors who had applied for the 2,600 places in their freshman classes. In the same mail were an undisclosed number of rejection notices.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- James G. Cross, suspended on charges of corruption as president of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union, resigned today both as an officer and union member.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI) -- The House passed by voice vote today a bill that would give Government officials $12 to $16 a day the allowance than the Kennedy Administration had recommended.
The city and the Perma Paving Corporation were held responsible yesterday by Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy for the shoaling of a large part of the Bronx River channel from 1952 to 1956.

Your editorial of May 10 headed "The Right Not to Be Lied To" is badly needed now. Its clear thinking has done us a great service. This is sound leadership in the public opinion field and should be more daringly exercised by the press across the country.
A record price was paid here yesterday for an envelope bearing United States stamps.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- President Kennedy is planning to send Adlai E. Stevenson on a goodwill tour of Latin America next month.

Union Oil Company of California filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday covering a proposed sale of $120,000,000 of fixed interest securities in two series. Half the amount would be in debentures due on June 1, 1986, and the remaining $60,000,000 in convertible subordinated debentures due on June 1, 1991.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 18 (AP) -- Sam Snead carded a five-under-par 65 today and took a two-stroke lead in the first round of the Sam Snead Golf Festival.

GENEVA, May 18 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk made a brief flying trip to the Swiss capital of Bern today in a gesture aimed at smoothing problems of diplomatic representation between Switzerland and the United States.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., May 18 (AP) -- This Hudson Valley city and the State of New York clashed today over the public interrogation of welfare aid recipients.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 18 (AP) -- Ten college students trying to break down racial segregation in bus stations remained in jail here today. The police said they would stay there until they have made definite arrangements to get out of the city.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- A Southern drive to guarantee Federal aid funds for segregated schools lost headway today in the face of mounting Republican and liberal Democratic opposition.

The turban is one of the sleekest, chicest hats for almost any occasion. The simplified ones -- some with a do-it-yourself quality -- are both pretty and practical for the beach and for travel, and some are smart enough to go on into the evening.

A new wall paint the consistency of blancmange should prove a boon to week-end decorators. According to the manufacturer it has qualities only the amateur can fully appreciate.
Business leaders, representing a cross section of American industry, looked upon the economic outlook yesterday and pronounced it good and getting better.
The city budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1 became official yesterday at a record of $2,541,905,636. The City Council approved it without change, as adopted by the Board of Estimate.
The wholesale commodity price index inched ahead to 86.8 on Wednesday from 86.7 Tuesday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 86.1 on May 11, 1960.

Bronson Van Wyck of Pingry School and Peter Lebhar of Trinity School, the top seeded players, advanced to the semi-finals yesterday in the twenty-fourth Eastern School private schools tennis tournament in Brooklyn.

The Sachar Development Corporation, Louis Sachar president, has bought the land bounded by Beach Eleventh and Twelfth Streets, Seagirt Boulevard and Heyson Road in Rock, away, Queens. The tract was acquired from David S. Cohen and will be improved with an apartment building. Archie Levine was the broker.

Irena Penzik, daughter of a once prominent Polish Socialist leader and a niece of the present Polish Ambassador to India, has written a report on "the cynicism and brutality" of communism's "new class" after attaining power.

Alf Sherwood, the soccer internationalist from Wales, was standing alongside a goalpost when the angle shot was made for a goal. His actions were instinctive. He would try to deflect the ball with his head.
PARIS, May 18 (AP) -- Ron Holmberg of Brooklyn advanced to the fourth round of the French tennis tournament today, along with Nicola Pietrangeli of Italy and Rod Laver of Australia.

CANNES, France, May 18 -- Luis Bunuel's Spanish-made film "Viridiana" and Henri Colpi's French entry, "Une Aussi Longue Absence" ("Winter Will Bring Him Back") tonight shared top honors at the Cannes Film Festival in jointly winning the Gold Palm Grand Prix at this Riviera event.
