JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 18 -- Adolf Eichmann told an International Red Cross official a month before the end of World War II that he disapproved of some of the measures of comparative leniency that Heinrich Himmler intended to introduce toward Jews.

LOS ANGELES, May 18 (UP) Chicago handed the Los Angeles Angels their seventh straight defeat tonight, 6 -- 4. The White Sox got their winning margin during a crazy seventh inning when a relief pitcher, Ryne Duren, struck out four men and gave up two unearned runs.
Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Zionist Organization, took sharp issue yesterday with Premier David Ben-Gurion on the role of Zionism.

MOST players can play better bridge if they take time to think, but one cannot profit by thinking on every play. Occasionally a hesitation can reveal one's holding to an opponent and save him a guess.
The New York County Lawyers Association has bought the land and buildings at 6, 8 and 10 Barclay Street, adjoining its headquarters at 14 Vesey Street, to expand its facilities.

OTTAWA, May 18 -- A joint communiqu issued just before the departure of President and Mrs. Kennedy today contained little evidence that he had attained any of the policy objectives he outlined yesterday in his address to Parliament.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- An exercise designed to test the ability of the Western powers to "command and control" nuclear-armed missiles and bombers in the event of a Soviet attack will be held next week at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's headquarters in Paris.
CHICAGO, May 18 -- Allstate Enterprises, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck Co., started a national mail-order motor club today. The annual fee is $12.50 a year.
The Pet Milk Company plans to expand its food business through the proposed acquisition of C.H. Musselman Company, a maker of fruit products with assets of $14,000,000.

BOSTON, May 18 (UPI) -- Don Buddin drove in Pete Runnels with a double in the fifth inning and Gene Conley pitched a four-hitter as the Boston Red Sox blanked the league-leading Detroit Tigers, 1 -- 0, tonight.

AS usual, the editor of Venture does not know whether there will ever be another number. After thirteen issues over the period of a decade, his 112-page magazine of fiction and poetry still lives from hand to mouth.
The military junta that took over Seoul Monday night now seems to be in general control throughout South Korea, and its status has been further strengthened by the resignation of Premier John Chang.
The Board of Health amended the Health Code yesterday to ban old and defective gas refrigerators. These have been found responsible for many cases of carbon monoxide poisoning in the home.

NIGHTLY at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre Mary Martin portrays Baroness Maria von Trapp in "The Sound of Music." The book for the musical is based on the adventures of the world-famous Trapp Family Singers. Every day -- and well into the evening -- the real Baroness is busily engaged in the duties of innkeeper at the Alpine-style Trapp family lodge in Stowe, Vt.
TEMPLE CITY, Calif., May 18 (AP) -- The Little League batter turned in toward a slow curve, and it hit him in the chest.

Henry Lewis, young Los Angeles conductor, will make his New York debut on Aug. 21, leading the third of the four concerts in the free series held in Washington Square Park known as Chamber Music Outdoors.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 18 -- Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells won the gross prize in a Women's New Jersey Golf Association tournament today by matching par 37, 37 -- 74 over the Upper Montclair Country Club course.
"Officer, officer," a little, gray-haired woman called to a patrolman in Central Park on Wednesday evening, "I think that man is following me."

EVERYTHING looks pretty good for the downtrodden trout fisherman in lower New York State this week-end, especially in the near-by Westchester-Putnam area. Of course, if it rains heavily again, all bets are off.

CHICAGO, May 18 (AP) -- Another late rally, the second in two days, added small gains to all soybean futures today on the Board of Trade but the grains were mostly easier in generally draggy dealings.

Events today: New York Saxophone Quartet, Town Hall, 5:30 P.M.; Jewish People's Philharmonic Chorus, Town Hall, 8:30; Oranim Zabar, Israeli folk song group, Barbizon Plaza Theatre, 8:30: "Ernani," presented by Opera Workshop, Public School 75, West End Avenue and Ninety-sixth Street, 8; Handel's "Saul," presented by the Baroque Festival Chorus, Robert Hickok, conductor, Brooklyn College, 7:30.
LOS ANGELES, May 19 (AP) -- Steve Bilko and Gene Leek hit homers tonight as the Los Angeles Angels ended a seven-game losing streak by defeating the Chicago White Sox, 4 -- 3.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices remained unchanged at 119.1 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday's the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., May 19 -- Governor Rockefeller's past political difficulties with tax increases and fall-out shelters will help him win re-election next year, the Republican State Chairman predicted tonight.
The National Broadcasting Company has scheduled three special half-hour telecasts covering President Kennedy's journey to Europe next month.
Four members of the Interstate Commerce Commission toured New York harbor areas yesterday for first-hand information on domestic shipping operations.
The first Kennedy-Khrushchev meeting, scheduled for Vienna next month, will be the fourth diplomatic encounter between a United States President and the present Soviet leader.
CHICAGO, May 19 (AP) -- Ernie Banks' infield pop fly that dropped safely for a double drove in the only run today as the Chicago Cubs defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 1 -- 0.
DESIGNER Bonnie Cashin, dressed and hatted to go out, stood in the middle of her apartment one morning this week impulsively wrapping herself in a long pink and orange pocoma (a length of Thai silk).
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- A dozen leaders of construction unions gave George Meany today a rebuttal to charges of bad faith made earlier by Walter P. Reuther and the industrial unions.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farmers had stored 545,054,000 bushels of 1960-crop corn under price supports through April.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 19 -- Circuit Judge Walter B. Jones issued an injunction today forbidding "freedom riders" from testing bus segregation in Alabama.

MIAMI, May 19 (UPI) -- Among the several hundred Americans still in Cuba, nineteen are still in prison from the post-invasion roundup, including Henry McEvoy of New York, dean of the American colony of Havana and a resident there for forty-eight years; Hal Feldman of Youngstown, Ohio; Jim O'Mailia of Buffalo, N.Y., a Villa Nueva professor, and Drexel Gibson of Connecticut, manager of the Havana Berlitz School of languages.

Just how much muscle the present economic recovery will display now is a matter of argument among the economists. Yesterday Dr. Paul W. McCracken, former member of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Eisenhower and now a professor at the University of Michigan, asserted he could find no evidence to indicate "an anemic, sluggish recovery."
The Jewish Book Council of the National Jewish Welfare Board has made four awards for "1960's best Jewish books in the fiction, poetry and juvenile fields."

MOSCOW, May 19 -- Premier Khrushchev attended the opening today of the huge British trade fair in Moscow's Sokolniki Park and told its organizers that he thought the Soviet Union "will buy all that Great Britain would like to sell us and all that we need."

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI) -- Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara disclosed tonight that he had prepared a directive to members of his department to stop issuing anonymous statements to the press. He said he planned to tell them to stand personally responsible for anything they might say on defense matters.
Showing a gain for the fifth day out of the last six, stocks on the New York Stock Exchange made 1961 highs yesterday in a sweeping advance that embraced almost every major group.

YONKERS, May 19 -- J.R. Rick's Royal Rick made a tremendous comeback surge from the last turn to score a half-length victory over Stephan Smith in the Grand Adirondack Pace tonight before 31,987 fans at Yonkers Raceway.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., May 19 -- New York State was called the "cradle of recreation" today by Laurence S. Rockefeller, chairman of the National Recreation Resources Review Commission.

The present high rate of activity in the new capital market is expected to continue next week with more than $287,000,000 of fixed-interest securities slated for sale. Of these, $162,685,000 is to be sold at competitive sealed bidding and $124,900,000 is to be offered the public through financing agents named by the company.

Mrs. Isabel Dodge Sloane's Bowl of Flowers will make her 1961 stakes debut at Aqueduct today in the $60.250 Acorn Stakes at one mile and probably will be the favorite at 3 -- 5 against eleven other fillies.

Net income of the Kern County Land Company for the first quarter this year increased to $4,057,000, or 94 cents a share, on revenues of $21,141,000, the report disclosed yesterday. In the corresponding 1960 period $3,535,000, or 82 cents a share, was cleared on revenues of $21,762,000.
The Health Insurance Plan of New York has applied for rate increases averaging 23.4 per cent, the State Insurance Department said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Hoagy Carmichael, the composer, was awarded a patent this week for a special package that holds short cigarettes. He believes that packs of "shorties" will appeal to smokers who like to stop after a few puffs.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 19 -- The dilemma of the street gang worker -- to whom he owes his first allegiance, law enforcement or the youngster he is trying to rehabilitate -- was pondered here today by youth workers.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board, citing such threats as "You'll find your head in your lap yet," today ordered Teamsters Union Local 777 to quit representing drivers of two Chicago taxi companies.

On the Asian tour in which he is engaged, Vice President Johnson has conducted himself with a flamboyance that must, at times, have been bewildering to the people and leaders he has visited.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The W.K. Kellogg Foundation has offered to pay $3,750,000 of the estimated $4,500,000 cost of a new building for the Pan American Health Organization here.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The flag-flying business is booming so greatly at the Capitol that officials are pulling strings to get more help. The House Appropriations Committee voted today to give it to them, approving a $146,000,000 budget for Congressional expenses.

Some of the thinking behind the belief that the economy is going was disclosed to several hundred business men attending the annual meeting of the National Industrial Conference Board at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

MIAMI, May 19 -- Fidel Castro's Cuba today is a beautiful tropical island filled with fear and hate.

One way to exert influence and gain pleasure at the same time is to read a good book to a child. There is pleasure for the adult, for example, in the child's response to the characters and ideas in the book and to the whole listening experience, which is many experiences in one.

Some of the most provocative jazz recordings made during the last four years have been the product of arrangements for a large orchestra written and conducted by Gil Evans and featuring the solo trumpet of Miles Davis. CHICAGO, May 19 -- The Administration was accused today of failure to understand the significance of making business decisions. The charge came from Erwin D. Canham, editor of The Christian Science Monitor.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur said yesterday that the chances of another world war were remote, but that one could be precipitated without intent "by a kind of spontaneous combustion". If it does come, he said the nation with the strongest nerves will win.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 19 -- The number of states proposed for the new United States of the Congo was raised today to twenty. The capital district of Leopoldville presumably would be an additional state, or the twenty-first.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Representative B.F. Sisk, Democrat of California, announced today that the Spreckels Sugar Company would build a $16,000,000 sugar beet processing plant at Mendota, Calif.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 10 points (50 cents a bale) up yesterday. Near July showed the best gain.

The third public offering of bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) in the Netherlands is slated for May 29. BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 19 (UPI) -- Dan Dobbek's two home runs, including the first grand slam of his major league career, led the Minnesota Twins to an 11-1 victory over the Kansas City Athletics tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI) -- A Quaker group urged the Government today to "explore" the possibility of using United States food surpluses to feed hungry people in Communist China.

Jerome Robbins and his "Ballets U.S.A." company invited the Moiseyev Dance Company of Moscow to the Fifty-fourth Street heatre at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon for an informal showing of some of Mr. Robbin's dances.

CLEVELAND, May 19 -- Ralph Houk's dream that excellent pitching would put the Yanks on top as soon as they started hitting proved a delusion tonight.

Federal aid to education appears to have weathered the unexpected and possibly fatal threat of Southern-sponsored provisions to prohibit the withholding of government funds from segregated schools. Playing for the second time this season in Town Hall, Hanoch Greenfeld brought his piano recital to a close late yesterday afternoon with a refreshingly lyrical performance of Mussorgsky's "Pictures at an Exhibition."

Under its new, young and dynamic President Janio Quadros, Brazil is showing a disconcerting independence in international affairs. A lawyer was suspended from practice yesterday because, the Appellate Division said, he failed to distribute $200,000 to twenty-eight children of servicemen killed in a 1957 air crash.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Managers of the Administration's school-aid bill maintained firm control in the Senate today as attempts to modify the $2,550,000,000 measure were soundly beaten.

LONDON, May 19 -- Share prices continued to give ground in the stock market here today. Among industrials, only paper and textile shares scored a majority of rises. Other groups had a predominance of falls, which seldom exceeded a shilling (14 cents).
EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 19 -- For the last week the members of the Teens for Safe Driving Club of the East Orange High School have been trying to educate the public.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 19 -- A ban on meetings in South Africa except church services and theatre or especially authorized gatherings, was announced today. The ban will continue to June 26.

Encouraging progress is being made by the Kennedy Administration in its drive to strike down barriers to the employment of Negroes on Government contract operations. Discrimination in the jobs involved can be curbed without any further action by Congress.

CINCINNATI, May 19 (AP) -- Sparked by Jim O'Toole's five-hit pitching, the Cincinnati Reds rallied tonight to beat the Milwaukee Braves, 3 -- 2.

FOR six weeks and ten sessions, in an unprecedented, intensive series of public discussions, architects have been examining with serious, soul-searching ardor the burning questions of our time: "Where are we?" and "Where do we go from here?" AUCKLAND, New Zealand, May 13 -- The desire for independence that has swept over Asia and Africa is being manifested in the South Sea islands. BLOOMINGTON, Ind., May 20 (AP) -- Jack Nicklaus, with a one-under-par 283, led Ohio State to its fifth Big Ten golf championship today. He finished fourteen strokes ahead of the runner-up, Rolf Deming of Minnesota, below par.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) -- The State Department, fearing a summer spurt in racial slights against African diplomats, is considering a plan to establish a ten-acre seashore playground where such officials can enjoy a discrimination-free week-end.

CUTTYHUNK, Mass. -- This island, the last one in the Elizabeth Island chain that stretches out into the Atlantic from the southwest corner of Cape Cod, was discovered in 1602 by Bartholomew Gosnold, the English explorer. The island has prospered over the last 359 years and its population now ranges from about twenty-five in the winter to approximately 200 in the summer.

SUPREME headquarters for "The Longest Day," a potential motion picture about D-Day, 1944, has been buzzing for weeks here in a snug bunker on the fashionable Rue du Bac formerly occupied by the Baron and Baroness de Pantz.
A police narcotics squad, lying in wait in a Harlem apartment, arrested thirty-two suspected marijuana dealers yesterday.

ROME, May 20 -- The Italian Cabinet decided to intensify its effort to bring about a revival of southern Italy, a decreased and largely agricultural area. Special attention will be paid to the Region of Calabria.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 20 (AP) -- A representative of Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy's office was injured in today's outbreak of rioting. ing.

OCHOPEE, Fla. -- A small shed once used for storing farm tools has become something of a tourist attraction in this Tamiami Trail hamlet in the Everglades. It serves the community as a post office and, as such, is believed to be the second smallest one in the entire country, the title to smallest being claimed by the post office in Wheeler Springs, Calif.

Early orders on back-to-School lines and continued demand for sportswear and better dresses were reported last week by resident buying offices.

The valley of the Potomac River is still largely unspoiled. A rarity among rivers, the Potomac has not been used heavily by industry; it traverses the fringe of the excessively urban, highly commercialized Eastern seaboard.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 21 -- Pakistani Air Force planes strafed Afghan forces in the Khyber Pass frontier region today, the Pakistani Government reported.

FALLS in bathtub or shower and foot injuries resulting from persons going around the house barefoot or in stocking feet are the two most common accidents in New York City homes, according to the Greater New York Safety Council.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 21 -- Another excellent day for sailing brought another large fleet to the starting line for the Yacht Racing Association's regatta on Western Long Island Sound today. It is 150 miles and several worlds from the campus of Smith College in Northampton, Mass., to the dance floor of the Copacabana in New York, but Barbara Dodd is making the trip quite regularly.

Ralph Houk made his first major shake-up of the Yankees at the Stadium last night. He benched Bill Skowron, who had accounted for exactly three singles in his last twenty-three times at bat and put Elston Howard, a catcher by trade, in the Moose's place at first base.
TO a world painfully aware of the anguish of racial tension a play like "Mandingo" can only seem like a crude, sensationalized effort to capitalize on a newsworthy theme.
The establishment of a peace agency headed by a scientist with Cabinet rank was proposed yesterday by an anthropologist who was arrested in 1958 for sailing into the forbidden Eniwetok area.
RALEIGH, N.C., May 22 (AP) -- North Carolina State canceled basketball games with six 1961-62 rivals as part of its athletic de-emphasis today.
Your comments in your May 15 editorial about taking park lands for the rights-of-way for highways were certainly in order. But the statement that only 400 acres were lost is certainly in error.

Don Stickey, a 20-year-old student at Ohio State, and Buddy C. Sullivan of Yuba City, Calif., set the early pace yesterday with scores of 67, 67 -- 134 as more than 2,000 players in fifty-three cities competed in trials for the United States Open golf championship.

MILWAUKEE, May 22 (UPI) -- Dick Groat's home run in the eighth inning, his first of the season, gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 2-1 victory over the Braves tonight. Harvey Haddix gained his third triumph without a loss.

All copper futures positions climbed to new highs for the life of the contracts yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Final quotations rose 34 to 47 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). The volume was 419 lots of 50,000 pounds each, the second largest this year.

PARIS, May 22 (AP) -- The last United States hope in the men's singles of the French tennis tournament was dashed today when Rod Laver of Australia defeated Ron Holmberg of Brooklyn, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 0, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3.
Four stars will perform the title role in "Calamity Jane" at various theatres on the summer circuit.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 22 -- More than 5,000 reserve troops reported for active duty in South Africa today.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The White House confirmed tonight that President Kennedy would confer with Premier Ben-Gurion in New York next Tuesday afternoon.

BUENOS AIRES, May 22 -Dr. Alfredo L. Palacios, the lone but fiery Socialist in the Argentine Senate, has been conducting a one-man campaign to lift the nation's state of siege and repeal a severe anti-terrorist law.

Kandy Koffee Shops, Inc., a company that operates restaurants, has taken a fifteen-year lease on the store, basement and second floor of the building at 28 Platt Street, between William and Gold Streets, for aggregate rentals of more than $250,000.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that Eli Lilly Co. of Indianapolis must register under New Jersey corporation laws before suing for enforcement of "fair trade" prices in New Jersey.

Leading Wall Street brokerage houses are advising their customers to "stay with du Pont and General Motors" despite the Supreme Court ruling yesterday that the giant chemical company must give up its holdings in the nation's largest corporation.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 22 -- Pakistan is expected to send a delegation of high officials to the Soviet Union soon to seek aid for a ten-year program to free 29,000,000 acres of salinity and waterlogging.

The short novel today is considered "an awkward literary stepchild" and is neglected by most contemporary writers. The form is generally too long for magazines, too short for book publication. Three stories in this genre have been brought together to form "Three," which Random House will publish July 18.
DUNOON, Scotland, May 22 (AP) -- Fifty tough Scottish constables threw themselves at scores of pacifists trying to immobilize the United States Polaris submarine base at Holy Loch today.

The American Broadcasting Company plans to initiate next month a half-hour Sunday night television news program in the time period now filled by "Winston Churchill -- The Valiant Years." The Churchill series is scheduled to end June 18.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI) -- Ambassador M.C. Chagla of India urged President Kennedy today to arrange a meeting with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru in India in the near future.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -Robert Moses challenged the Administration and Congress today to attain a new dimension in imagination in designing a United States pavilion for the 1964-65 World's Fair in New York City.

Stan Marchut has sufficiently overcome what he called "my bad habit of overturning the ball" to move into the ranks of the best bowlers in the East. In fact, he was selected as the New York area's bowler of the year yesterday by the Metropolitan Bowling Writers Association.

ZANDVOORT, Netherlands, May 22 -- Count Wolfgang von Trips of West Germany, driving a 1.5-liter factory-entered Ferrari, won the Dutch Grand Prix today. It was one of the most astonishing races in many years.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), May 22 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion is expected to ask President Kennedy next week to propose to Premier Khrushchev that the big powers issue a declaration recognizing the existing borders in the Middle East.

RYE, N.Y., May 22 -- Jim Marotta, a Maplemoor pro, and Herb Hendlin of the host club combined their cards for a winning best-ball score of 33, 32 -- 65 today in the Westchester Professional Golfers Association pro-amateur tournament at the Ryewood Country Club.
RALEIGH, N.C., May 22 (UPI) -- University officials imposed a sweeping de-emphasis of basketball at North Carolina and North Carolina State today to "protect the good name" of the institutions."

The new military Government has begun its rule in South Korea with a sweeping crackdown on groups, activities and individuals it considers objectionable. Strikes have been prohibited and political parties and social organizations banned. Thousands of persons, including racketeers, politicians, teachers, students and journalists, have been arrested.
The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman was honored here yesterday as he approaches retirement after forty-four years as pastor of Christ Church, Methodist, and more than thirty as a radio preacher.

EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, May 22 -- French and Algerian peace negotiators will begin tomorrow a cautious approach to some of the potentially explosive central issues that await solution after nearly seven years of warfare in Algeria.

The Wagner Administration moved yesterday to cut away much of the administrative red tape encountered by motion-picture and television companies seeking to film scenes in city streets, parks and other locations.
LONDON, May 22 (AP) -By acting swiftly against racial violence in Alabama, President Kennedy has done the best thing possible for the reputation of the United States, The Daily Herald said today.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 22 -- The swich from Westchester to Nassau brought harness racing to a different county tonight as Roosevelt Raceway opened its first meeting of the season.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- If Gov. John Patterson of Alabama were actually to carry out his threat to arrest any Federal marshal violating state law, Supreme Court precedents suggest that the arrest would not stick.

Dedications and formal openings of new buildings are nothing unusual in this vast metropolitan complex of so many of mankind's interests and activities. After a brief day or two in the news and a residuary record in the annals of local history, the speeches and the ceremonies are soon forgotten and the crowd moves on, quickly learning to take for granted whatever may have been added for its use or comfort.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 22 -Castle Cooke, Inc., Hawaii's biggest company, with stated assets of more than $117,000,000, announced today the formation of a new subsidiary.

TEX CLEVENGER went hungry on May 8, 1961. He didn't intend to. Being a rather deft operative in the knife-and-fork league, he dropped into his favorite Los Angeles restaurant in midafternoon that day and ordered his favorite meal, liver and onions. His team, the Angels, was playing the Boston Red Sox at Wrigley Field that night and the big pitcher wanted to stow away the vittles in leisurely fashion before reporting for work.

It was on May 23, 1911, that the great Central Building combining the forces of the Astor Library, the Lenox Library and the Tilden Trust, and built by the city at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street for service to the educational, cultural and informational research needs of the community, was dedicated by President William Howard Taft as "a work of national importance."
GENEVA, May 22 -- Poland's Foreign Minister maintained today that abrogation of the sections of the Southeast Asia defense treaty that protect Laos was essential to establishment of a neutral Laos.

ST. LOUIS, May 22 (AP) -The annual pastors' Conference of the Southern Baptist Convention was told tonight that Roman Catholic "propagandists are trying to blot out" the nation's traditional separation of church and state.
A study of how to design physics buildings that make for good teaching and research was published yesterday by the American Association of Physics Teachers and the American Institute of Physics.
ST. LOUIS, May 22 (AP) -The San Francisco Giants snapped a three-game losing streak by defeating the Cardinals, 3 -- 1, tonight.
KANSAS CITY, May 22 (UPI) -- The Detroit Tigers routed Norm Bass in a six-run fifth inning tonight and defeated the Athletics, 10-2.
DETROIT, May 22 (AP) -- Trade sources believe auto production will remain relatively stable for the next six weeks with virtually no full-week shutdowns in sight for any assembly plant.

The Women's Auxiliary of the Tuxedo Memorial Hospital is sponsoring "A Night in Old Tuxedo Park," to be held Saturday in a marquee erected at the old race track in Tuxedo Park. N.Y. Proceeds from the second annual dance recapturing the spirit of the Gay Nineties will be used to re-equip and expand the laboratory facilities of the voluntary nonprofit hospital.
CARDIFF, Wales, May 22 (Reuters) -- The Australian cricketers today moved into a good position to score the fourth successive victory of their tour.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -Gen. Curtis E. LeMay was nominated by President Kennedy today for a two-year term as Air Force Chief of Staff.
The New York Employing Printers Association has elected Samuel F. Chernoble as chairman of its board of directors for a year. He is president of Comet Press, Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI) -- Representative Francis E. Walter said today that a new effort was under way to "smear, discredit and bring about the abolition" of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, which he heads.
Sadly, but with resignation, the varsity track and field set yesterday conceded the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America team title to Villanova.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Three soldiers who allegedly helped the Communist side when they were captured during the Korean War are entitled to prisoner-of-war pay, the Supreme Court decided unanimously today.
Wall Street went through a spell of dizziness yesterday when the Supreme Court ordered E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. to divest itself of its 23 per cent interest in General Motors Corporation.

In a determined effort to pass a straightforward bill to aid tile public elementary and secondary schools, the Senate's Democratic leadership yesterday opposed segregation or anti-segregation amendments of any kind.
Diplomatic sources reported yesterday that Frol R. Kozlov, Premier Khrushchev's apparent choice as his successor, suffered a mild heart attack late last month and is now convalescing.

Savings in the nation's savings and loan associations rose $475,000,000 in April to $64,450,000,000. This gain was 28 per cent greater than that in April, 1960. In New York State, however, the April gain, for the first time in fourteen months, was less than in the same month of 1960.

Tudor Way, the Argentine-bred owned by El Tordillo Ranch, found things exactly to his liking at Aqueduct yesterday. In contrast to his previous showing there, when he finished eleventh in the Grey Lag Handicap, the imported 5-year-old horse thrilled the 30,234 customers with a record-equaling performance.
The nation's shipping industry was warned here yesterday that it must get more mileage out of the Federal ship subsidies or otherwise it would price itself out of the subsidy market.

The General Public Utilities Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in domestic revenues of 3.8 per cent for the twelve months ended on March 31 and 2.4 per cent for the latest quarter. Net income, including dollar receipts from the Manila Electric Company, rose by 2.8 per cent for the twelve months, but dropped 9.9 per cent for the quarter.

Conductors have been punching in the presence of the passenjare for more than 100 years, but only passengers weary of reading the stock quotations or looking at Westchester may have noticed that the holes punched in their tickets have distinctive designs.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 22 (UPI) -- Following is the text of a statement by Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., following the Supreme Court's ruling that the company must get rid of 63,000 shares of General Motors Corporation stock:

Record dollar sales, physical volume and profits were registered in the fiscal year ended on March 31 by the General Foods Corporation, Charles G. Mortimer, chairman, disclosed yesterday in the annual report.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 22 -- The acquisition of 4,588 acres of river-basin wetlands for conservation and recreation purposes was approved today by the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -The Senate rejected today an anti-segregation amendment to the Kennedy Administration's $2,550,000,000 bill to aid education.
LOS ANGELES, May 22 (AP) -- A squeeze bunt by the pitcher, Eli Grba. broug'ht in what tin'ned out to be the deciding run tonight as tile An-i aels defeated the WashingtonI Senators. 6 -- 4.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., May 22 -- The City Council voted unanimously today to petition Orange County to take over its welfare program.
CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WESTBORO, Mass., May 22 -- Steady progress in the reclamation and improvement of trout water has encouraged Massachusetts to take a crack at poisoning the trash fish out of a second river and re-establishing a native-trout population.
John Hay Whitney, publisher of The New York Herald Tribune, said yesterday that newspapers had been "doubly right in resisting Government attempts of various sorts to tell the people less."
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 22 -- President Janio Quadros became more deeply involved today in an angry controversy with Vice President Joao Goulart and the Opposition majority in Congress.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., May 22 -- Milton Shapiro and Dick DeMane of Engineers Country Club, the last team to post its score, won a Long Island Professional Golfers Association pro-amateur tournament today at Great River.
TRENTON, May 22 -- The Legislature approved a bill tonight that would impose a New Jersey income tax on all commuters between New York and New Jersey.
Blood will be given to the Red Cross today at the New York Life Insurance Company, 51 Madison Avenue, at Twenty-sixth Street.
BOSTON, May 22 (AP) -Bill Monbouquette, a Boston Red Sox right-hander, pitched his way out of a bases-filled plight and into a 4-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight.
Conditions in the Bellevue psychiatric division are worse than those in Kings County Hospital, the head of a special committee studying psychiatric services in municipal hospitals said yesterday.
A golfing matter that seemingly could have been settled at the nineteenth hole has suddenly developed international overtones.

It has long been recognized that if the United Nations is to fulfill its dual function as both a parliament of nations and guardian of world peace, it must be reorganized to make it more effective than it is today. The latest effort in that direction, undertaken by a committee of experts that labored for a year on the single project of revising the Secretariat, has ended, like previous efforts, in frustration.
TRENTON, May 22 -- The State Supreme Court ruled today that the Waterfront Commission could investigate a dock strike if it suspected that it involved a violation of a bistate waterfront compact.
Continued tightness in the money market, a heavy corporate flotation calendar, and improved business expectations weighed heavily on the market for fixed-interest securities yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 21 -- Anti-monarchist political groups, including both pro-Nasser nationalists and Communists, have begun to exploit the struggle for power between King Saud of Saudi Arabia and his half-brother Crown Prince Faisal.

THIS week's American fall collections got off to a lazy Monday start. The jam is expected later in the week. The clothes new being unveiled and scrutinized by keen buyers and press will not be in the stores until the end of July, but the silhouette of fall, 1961, is shaping up.
The violence to the biracial group in Birmingham gives many of us the feeling that we have a great deal to do at home in the area of civil rights and "democracy."

LONDON, May 23 (Reuters) -- Britain's Daily Mirror Newspapers -- the world's biggest women's magazine system -- today announced a drop in profits of 1,200,000 (about $3,500,000) for the year ended last Feb. 28.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 23 (UPI) -- Charlie Ravenel and Perry Boyden today were named co-winners of Harvard University's highest athletic honor -- the William J. Bingham Award. Ravenel was quarterback of the football team and Boyden is the stroke in rowing.

ST. LOUIS, May 23 -- Mergers of Protestant denominations show a lack of Christian conviction, and the Southern Baptist Convention will have nothing to do with them, the president of the denomination said here today.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point up to 9 off yesterday.
MIAMI, May 23 -- The Cuban Government has ordered emergency measures that indicate it is having serious difficulty in harvesting the sugar-cane crop.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Kennedy is expected to tell Congress Thursday that there is an urgent need for the United States to land a man on the moon -- and to do it first, if possible.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Representative Charles S. Joelson said tonight the United Klans of America might be violating Federal law by telling prospective donors that contributions were tax deductible.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) -- The Republican National Committee today accused the Kennedy Administration of supplying Congressional Democrats with "do-it-yourself kits of pre-fabricated press releases" to help them praise the President's program.

Maria Tallchief, Erik Bruhn and the Andre Eglevsky Festival Ballet will appear at Lewisohn Stadium this summer in two successive programs of the Stadium Concerts series. The dance performances will be given on June 29 and July 1 in the second week of the Stadium season.

The United States District Court in Minneapolis yesterday entered a temporary restraining order enjoining the acceptance of any tender of General Outdoor Advertising Company stock made in response to an offer by Allen Co., New York investment banking concern. Allen Co. is attempting to buy the 470,000 shares on behalf of Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., wholesaler and retailer of general merchandise.
As citizens of this unmistakably great nation, the Negro populace in seeking equality is not asking what our country will do for us. Rather, we are seeking to do something for our country.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 23 -- The Israeli Knesset (Parliament) received today the case of Yosef Schuhmacher, a 9-year-old boy who is being hidden from his parents by religious zealots.
The only Negro vice president in the merged labor federation called on President Kennedy yesterday to implement his campaign pledge to press for a Federal Fair Employment Practices Act.

WASHINGTON, May 23 UPI) -- President Kennedy asked Senator Richard B. Russell today to place the Presidential wreath at the Tomb of the Unknowns in Arlington National Cemetery at the annual Memorial Day ceremony.
The United States Plywood Corporation has completed its acquisition of Western Plywood Company, Ltd., Canada, for about $6,500,000, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Peoples' Revolutionary Movement, which operated the main underground network in Cuba, has decided to quit the Cuban Revolutionary Council in what its spokesmen described today as "disgust" over the post-invasion situation.
VIENNA, May 23 -- Pierre Salinger, President Kennedy's press secretary, conferred today with Austrian and Soviet officials on plans for the Presidents meeting with Premier Khrushchev.
The State Banking Department approved yesterday the merger of the Hanover Bank into the Manufacturers Trust Company. The merger still must be approved by the Federal Reserve Board.
An Australian parliamentary delegation told business men and financiers here yesterday about "gaps" in their nation's economy suitable for profit-seeking foreign investors.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, said today that despite riots in Alabama the Kennedy Administration would not seek new civil rights legislation this year.
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- The grain futures market mustered a general rally at one time today but failed to hold it and prices closed mostly mixed on the Board of Trade.

A prediction that ample funds will be available soon to finance housing starts and realty developments was made here yesterday by Milton A. Vieser, executive vice president of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company of Newark.

LOS ANGELES, May 23 (AP) -- Ken McBride became the first man to pitch a shutout for the Los Angeles Angels as they broke Cleveland's winning, streak at six games by defeating the Indians, 9 -- 0, tonight. Ken Hunt and Earl Averill slammed three-run homers and Leon Wagner hit one with the bases empty.
Plans for a Hall of Education at the New York World's Fair 1964-65 were announced yesterday.

SUFFIELD, Conn., May 23 -- It is plain that the Connecticut River shad run hasn't yet reached its best for the year, but anglers whanging away with spin tackle at Enfield Dam are taking home a fair amount of fish.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 23 (UPI) -- E. Hadley Stuart Jr., 44, announced today his resignation as a vice president and a director of the Carnation Company because of a policy dispute with his 73-year-old father, E.H. Stuart, chairman.

PARIS, May 23 -- It is as harmful to diplomacy as to digestion when one bites off more than one can chew and it begins to look as if President Kennedy's European journey will suffer from precisely this defect.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Kennedy's "private golf course" really is a cow pasture.
IF all the world loves a lover, it may be partly because so many people stand to profit from his trip to the altar.

THE achievement of two well-known contemporary American artists, the sculptor Jose de Rivera and the painter Balcomb Greene, is surveyed in a pair of retrospective exhibitions opening today at the Whitney Museum of American Art.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said last night that he could conceive of "no set of circumstances" that would make him a candidate for Mayor this year.
THE matter of the Bikini has come up again, and no one is watching developments on this small, fashion front more carefully than Jack Vane. Lord Taylor's sportswear buyer.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 23 -- The first desperate appeal for ransom money by Jews in Central Europe when they learned of the gas chambers at Auschwitz was related today at the trial of Adolf Eichmann.
BONN, Germany, May 23 -- The West German Government is not hopeful about being able to increase its contribution to India's foreign exchange needs for her third Five-Year Plan.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Kennedy is expected to attend the opening session of the inter-American economic conference in Uruguay July 15.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Kennedy has cast himself in a difficult and rather unexpected role as the folk drama of the "Freedom Riders" moves toward its unpredictable denouement in the South.

On a wall in his office Newbold Morris has a framed copy of a New Yorker cartoon that shows two bums on a park bench. "I fail to see any difference," says one, "between the administration of Robert Moses and the administration of Newbold Morris."

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Following is the text of a telegram from Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy to the Alabama Congressional delegation, which asked him yesterday to withdraw Federal marshals from Montgomery:
WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) -- A House subcommittee voted today to kill President Kennedy's proposal to increase the powers of the Federal Communications Commission chairman.

Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation, said yesterday that a Harvard professor had made "appallingly baseless charges" in declaring that national voluntary health organizations were wasting money and misleading contributors on how the money was spent.
A Federal judge ruled here yesterday that 4,000 bags of coffee allegedly smuggled out of Brazil must be delivered to the importers in this country.
PHILADELPHIA, May 22 -- Ground-breaking ceremonies were held today for the largest apartment building ever planned here.
In a totally unexpected move, Ted Bates Co., Inc., withdrew yesterday afternoon from competition for the American Airlines account.
LONDON, May 23 -- With trading light, prices moved aimlessly on the stock market here today and small losses outnumbered gains in the main industrial sections.
NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa., May 23 -- A team led by Mrs. Bruce McGhie of New York, who carded a 31, 30-70, captured a best-ball sweepstakes competition at the Aronomink Golf Club today with a score of 65.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The five-month-old mystery of who should be serving the 391,000 constituents of Indiana's Fifth Congressional District in the House of Representatives appeared to have been solved tonight.
Oarsmen of the Norwegian America liner Stavangerfjord won the twenty-second annual International Lifeboat Race in the Narrows yesterday. It was their third consecutive victory.
The Transnation Realty Corporation, Henry Goelet, president, has contracted to sell the twenty-story office building at 40 Exchange Place, corner of William Street, to the 40 Exchange Realty Company.

BERN, Switzerland, May 23 -- Europe has hit on a really wonderful idea. It has devised some fast metal vehicles over here which carry human beings at high speed on steel rails from one city to another in accordance with a prearranged schedule.
More than 200 cars have been entered in the fifth national championship races of the Sports Car Club of America at Bridgehampton, L.I., Saturday and Sunday.
NEWARK, May 23 -- Newark teacher dismissed six years ago for having invoked the Fifth Amendment pressed today for reinstatement.

BALTIMORE, May 23 -- The Murchison family of Dallas. Tex., one of the wealthiest in the nation, formally took control here today of the Alleghany Corporation from the even wealthier Allan P. Kirby of Morristown, N.J.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 23 -- Carlos Mantero, of Portugal, president of the International Chamber of Commerce, said here today that the main testing ground of private business enterprise in its competition with the Communist economic system was the underdeveloped areas of the free world.
As a native Formosan who was heartened by your editorial of May 16 "Johnson at Taipei" may nevertheless point out a more fundamental aspect of the Nationalist regime which you have overlooked.
Commander Shepard's suborbital flight to the edge of space has served as a boost to national pride.

Jack Price, the trainer of the 3-year-old Carry Back, winner of the Kentucky Derby and Preakness, said yesterday that the horse would definitely start in the Belmont on June 3. If he wins it, he will be the first Triple Crown victor since Citation in 1948.
Jackie Leonard got a warm reception from many of the 24,132 fans at Aqueduct yesterday when he won the one-mile Wheatley Hills Handicap aboard the 10-1 betting outsider, Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Try Cash.

FRANKFURT, May 23 (UPI) -- West Germany's gold reserves increased by 129,000,000 marks ($32,495,100) to a total of 13,200,000,000 marks ($3,325,080,000) in the week ended on May 15, the German Federal Bank announced today.

LOS ANGELES, May 23 (UPI) -- Dr. Frank Baxter, who won fame as a television lecturer on Shakespeare, ended his more than forty years as a professor yesterday with a lecture on "Twelfth Night" and a blast at current TV.

Ninety-three banks yesterday extended loans totaling $65,000,000 to the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York and forty Jewish welfare groups throughout the country. Pledges to the nation-wide United Jewish Appeal will serve as guarantees for the loans.

The United Parents Associations said yesterday that the Board of Education was reducing essential services supposedly provided in the city's 1961-62 expense budget. A spokesman for the board confirmed the cut-backs.
A three-year city commitment of $24,000,000 for permanent improvements in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens, the site of the 1964-65 World's Fair, became virtually certain yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, May 24 -- South Korea's military junta rejected yesterday sections of a draft agreement aimed at ending the defiance by Korean military forces of the operational control of the United Nations commander here.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 23 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan said today that arms supplied by the Soviet Union to Afghanistan were being used against Pakistan.

The Armstrong Hotel, a squalid upper West Side tenement that recently evoked an exchange of accusations between City Hall and the State Rent Commission, was called "a rat ranch" in Housing Court yesterday.
Infra-red railroad detectives have been quite busy of late in Venezuela.

Governor Rockefeller asked Representative Herbert Zelenko yesterday to disclose his sources of information on the exploitation of migratory farm workers, but Mr. Zelenko promptly rejected the request.
The New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue at Forty-second Street marked its fiftieth anniversary yesterday, not too proud to recall that it fluffed its first request for a book.
PARIS, May 23 -- Twenty-four French Right-wingers were placed today in an internment camp in east-central France. All of them are opponents of President de Gaulle's liberal policy for Algeria.
Having received the go-ahead signal from the Federation of International Football Associations, the International Soccer League will continue its schedule tonight at the Polo Grounds.
The rugged northwest frontier between Pakistan and Afghanistan is one of the world's more unsettled borders. On both sides dwell the fierce and individualistic Pathans.

A study of the United States Office of Education, forseeing "an extension of the active Federal role in education," has recommended reorganization of the office to strengthen its traditional activities and to meet its new responsibilities.
CHICAGO, May 23 -- Willis Gale, chairman of the Common wealth Edison Company, said today that his company still had "a few puzzling price problems."

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 23 (AP) -- The Peurto Rican House voted, 49 to 0, today to unseat Representative Jose Feliu Pesquera of the Christian Action party. The House declared that he had won election last November through fraud and unconstitutional coercion of the voters by the island's three Roman Catholic bishops.
The second annual West Side Youth Day, dedicated to the promotion of friendship and neighborliness, turned up a new song yesterday in keeping with that purpose.
