WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, replying to a protest from Alabama members of Congress, said today that he would maintain a Federal peace force in their state only as long as necessary.

The directors of the Central Illinois Electric Gas Comney have proposed a 2-for-1 common stock split, it was announced yesterday by J.E. Murray, chairman. Approval for the split and authorization for the doubling of common stock to 4,000,000 shares will be asked at a special meeting on June 29.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 23 -- The Supreme Court of Errors ruled unanimously today that the Norwalk Jewish Center had the right to operate its property in an expensive residential area as a community center.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Kennedy has decided to press for a stronger program to shelter the populace against a nuclear attack.
DETROIT, May 23 -- Daniel C. Fisher, former president of the S.S. Kresge Company, was killed today in an automobile accident near his home here. He was 74 years old.

BALTIMORE, May 23 (AP) -- Dick Williams and Jerry Adair hit home runs in leading the Orioles to a 3-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight. The homers spoiled an outstanding pitching performance by Billy Pierce.
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that there were fewer traffic accidents and injuries in the city last week than a year ago. The death rate remained unchanged at eleven.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Two offices that specialize in developing weapons used in limted war were merged today under a single directorship.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Senate broadened the Administration's school-aid bill today to provide use of Federal funds to pay the costs of general operation and maintenance.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 23 (AP) -- Vice President Johnson said today that the struggle to preserve freedom in Southeast Asia would be "long, costly and in many instances dangerous."
Through the strategic investment of its own assets, which amount to some $150,000,000, the Alleghany Corporation as a holding company controls companies handling assets of more than $7,000,000,000.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 23 -- Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd rejected today an appeal for a debate on mass arrests and the mobilization of reserve troops in preparation for the establishment of a republic May 31.
The Federal Aviation Agency will soon test the workability of its mobile airport lounges.
More sellers than buyers were active in most sectors of the bond market yesterday and the result was a continuation of the heavy tone that was apparent on Monday.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 23 -- The long-awaited 1961 debut of Adios Butler, 1960's champion of champions, is set for Friday night at Roosevelt Raceway.

THE faded romance of the railroad steam engine chugging majestically across the countryside and the urgent anguish of the commuter yearning to get home on time were among the elements in the National Broadcasting Company's fascinating diagnosis of rail transportation last night.
Anthony Anastasia denied yesterday that there was any gambling in his union headquarters at 341 Court Street, Brooklyn, where the police conducted a raid last Thursday.

Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $38,799,500 of convertible subordinated debentures, due on July 1, 1986. The debentures are to be offered, on a rights basis, for subscription to holders of the common stock at the rate of $100 of debentures for each twelve shares held.

THE two unassuming, soft spoken multi-millionaires from Texas who took control of the multibillion-dollar Alleghany Corporation empire yesterday have become masters of the technique of the iron hand in the velvet glove.
GENEVA, May 23 -- Belkacem Krim, the Algerian nationalist Vice Premier and Foreign Minister, warned tonight that any move to partition Algeria would prevent the return of peace.
The City Planning Commission will hold public hearings this morning on four of the eighteen projects it has recommended for the city's 1961-62 urban renewal program.
A bitter contest for control of District 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers and the council's ten affiliated local unions went to Federal Court yesterday.

Stock prices drifted lower yesterday as the financial community continued to ponder the effects of the Supreme Court order telling E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. to divest itself of its holdings of General Motors Corporation stock.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 23 -- The Soviet Union called on the United Nations today to back a convocation of the Congolese Parliament along the lines laid clown by Antoine Gizenga, the dissident leader of Eastern Province.

Four hundred and twenty students from Aviation High School in Long Island City, Queens, marched seven miles to City Hall yesterday to protest the elimination of a technician's rating in their diplomas.
LONDON, May 23 -- The Labor party strongly criticized the Government today because of a remark attributed to Home Secretary R.A. Butler during a dinner in Madrid.
DETROIT, May 23 -- The Metropolitan Opera Association will no longer play to segregated audiences in the South, according to Rudolf Bing, general manager.
The Commissioner of Hospitals said yesterday he would close general care facilities at Fordham and Greenpoint Hospitals by July 1.
One-world television is becoming a live proposition although the programs at this stage of the game and for some time to come will be on film or tape.

The September world sugar contract climbed to a new high for the life of the position and October equaled the old high on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The July position was most active with short covering offsetting new selling.

To provide Freedomland Park with funds to discharge its indebtedness of $8,000,000 and to use for working capital to continue in operation, stockholders of the International Recreation Corporation will vote on a proposed refinancing at a special meeting on June 9.

A biography of David Lloyd George, Britain's Prime Minister during World War I, has been written by his eldest son Richard and an American edition of it will be published June 13 by Crown. In "My Father, Lloyd George," the author shows the strength, brilliance and weakness of the man who "saved" his country and whose career could have been changed if the facts about his private life had been made public.
Directors of R. Hoe Co., maker of printing machinery, tentatively have approved a recapitalization plan, J.L. Auer, president, announced yesterday.

BOSTON, May 23 (UPI) -- Bernard Goldfine's plea of guilty to indictments charging evasion of $790,000 in Federal income taxes was accepted "without reservation" today in court following receipt of a psychiatric report.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., in the first four months of this year carried twice as much military traffic as it did in all of last year. Juan T. Trippe, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday.
More than $50,000 in pledges has been received by the Greater New York Citizens Committee for Operation Rescue, set up to raise funds to help in the tractor exchange.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 23 -- The acting head of United Nations here flew to Coquilhatville today to confer vubu.
For two months following former President Dwight D. Eisenhower's heart attack in 1955, writes Sherman Adams, the Government was managed by an unofficial committee.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Protesting that taxpayers already had put up more than $1,000,000,000 to subsidize the merchant marine, Senator Frank J. Lausche asked today for a thorough Senate study of a proposal to raise jobless benefits for longshoremen.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Charles M. Meriwether, a controversial Kennedy Administration appointee to the Export-Import Bank, worked behind the scenes over the week-end to achieve Federal-state cooperation in protecting the "Freedom Riders" in Alabama.
CINCINNATI, May 23 (AP) -- Ken Hunt and Bill Henry, a relief pitcher, held the Los Angeles Dodgers to five hits tonight as the Reds triumphed, 2 -- 0.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 23 -- Communist guerrilla forces have opened a new offensive in the northern mountain regions of South Vietnam.

An era that has introduced-closed-circuit television, fastmoving escalators and air-conditioned grandstands for the racetrack fan now promises to give birth to a new easy-on-the-legs running surface for the horse.

In your otherwise superb editorial of May 16 you referred to a "serious flaw" in the formula for distribution of Federal funds to the states under the education bill now being considered in the Senate. This should not be considered a flaw, but rather a highly desirable change.

Trans World Airlines' plan for projecting first-run feature films aboard their jet planes on long-distance flights will be officially inaugurated on July 19, with a pre-release showing of "Tammy Tell Me True" as the probable opening bill.

The recent shocking events in Asuncion, Paraguay, deserve careful thought, as well as the condemnation of Americans. Students seeking to demonstrate peacefully on the occasion of Paraguay's 150th anniversary of independence met "harsh police measures, including beatings and wholesale arrests." The Times correspondent who witnessed the police brutality, said that women were not spared.

The cornerstone of an additional residence building for the Union Theological Seminary was laid yesterday as part of that institution's commencement program. The new structure, costing $4,000,000, will houses seventy-two student and faculty families beginning in the fall of 1962.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Treasury is considering issuing paper money in a variety of colors.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 23 -- Premier Fidel Castro's top foreign-policy adviser has promised Brazilian officials that Cuba will not try to export her revolution to other American countries.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) -- The method of electing the President came under fire today as the Senate Constitutional Amendments subcommittee opened hearings on seventeen proposals to change the system.
BUFFALO, May 23 -- American Protestantism was sharply criticized here today for what was described as a headlong flight to suburbia.
A French airline stewardess was convicted in the Federal Court, Brooklyn, yesterday on a charge of smuggling $500,000 worth of heroin into the country.
A man described by the District Attorney's office as the "biggest policy operator" in upper Harlem, with an annual business of $15,000,000 a year, was arraigned yesterday in Felony Court.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 (AP) -- E. Paul Gangewere, president of the Reading Railroad reported a deficit today of almost $5,500,000 for the first four months of 1961 but said he looked for improved business conditions later this year.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Space officials predicted today that by the middle of this decade the United States should be able to launch "rendezvous satellites" capable of resupplying or inspecting satellites already in orbit.
ST. LOUIS, May 23 (AP) -- Bill White drove in five runs with a home run, double and two singles and led the St. Louis Cardinals to a 12-4 victory over the first-place San Francisco Giants tonight.
KINGS PARK, L.I., May 23 -- Robert Emmet Clancy isn't yet the commuting type, but he seemed intent on catching the 7:51 here this morning -- the hard way.

Both President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev have now expressed hope that their meeting in Vienna next week will lead to better understanding and a peaceful solution of pending problems. Yet on one of the most important problems they will discuss, the two sides are not only deadlocked but are moving further apart.

The appointment of J. Robert Cooper of Detroit as executive director of the United Cerebral Palsy Associations, Inc., was announced here yesterday. Mr. Cooper is vice president of the Jones Motor Company, Inc., a trucking fleet concern, and was formerly president of the Red Star Transit, Inc., which was absorbed by Jones last year.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Navy announced today that a $58,659,000 contract had been awarded to the Bath Iron Works Corporation to build three guided-missile frigates.
GLASSBORO, N.J., May 23 (AP) -- The manager of the Glassboro farm labor camp protested today what he called a smear attack by a witness before the House subcommittee on migrant labor.
Robert C. Weaver believes a "significant breakthrough" in the construction of badly needed middle-income housing would result from passage of the Kennedy Administration program now before Congress.
Blood will be collected by the Red Cross today at Saks Fifth Avenue, Fifth Avenue and Forty-ninth Street.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 23 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers tied a major-league record by smashing three straight home runs in the ninth inning tonight to defeat the Minnesota Twins, 5 -- 2. It was the third time Detroit had equaled the mark. The Tigers did it previously in 1946 and 1956.

Your editorial of May 12 on "Federal Aid to the Schools II" rejoices that both the nondiscrimination amendment and the parochial school amendment are not attached to the bill as reported by the Senate Labor Committee. They are different.

The off-Broadway circuit soon will be expended by Lee Paton with the establishment of the New Playwrights Theatre at the corner of West Third and Thompson Streets, the site of La Jolie, former Greenwich Village night club.

ALGIERS, May 23 -- Ten French soldiers were killed and five were wounded yesterday evening when a French military convoy was attacked by Algerian rebels in a mountainous region sixty miles southwest of Algiers.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 23 -- This city lay sleepily last night under a quarter moon, its graceful old homes shuttered and silent beneath spreading oaks and magnolias.
A break-through in unionization of the hat industry in the South was reported yesterday by Alex Rose, president of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union.
GENEVA, May 23 -- The United States refused today to be committed indefinitely to an uoncontrolled moratorium on tests of nuclear weapons.
CHICAGO, May 23 (UPI) -- Bobby Malkmus tripled home a run in the tenth inning today, giving the Philadelphia Phillies a 2-1 triumph over the Chicago Cubs.
LONDON, Wednesday, May 24 -- Polish emigres in London, according to today's issue of The Daily Mail, assert that "the head of Polish intelligence" has fled to the West.
LONDON, May 23 (UPI) -- Israel's Premier David Ben-Gurion stopped briefly here today on his way to meetings with Prime Minister John Diefenbaker of Canada and President Kennedy.
Almost as quickly as one could say, "Reparez l'epee de Lafayette," the Park Department made note yesterday of the damaged condition of the marquis' statue in Union Square.
The election of Mrs. Jean E. Harris of 36 Gramercy Park East as president of the Washington Square Business and Professional Women's Club for two years was announced yesterday. Her term began May 1.
GENEVA, May 23 -- France proposed today that East and West accept an international charter for Laotian neutrality as an essential requirement for peace in Laos.

Halsey Stuart Co. Inc., and associates offered to the public yesterday $30,000,000 of Michigan Consolidated Gas Company first mortgage 5 1/8 per cent bonds due in 1986. The bonds were priced at 101.772 to yield 5 per cent.

In commemoration of the 125th anniversary, last Nov. 30, of the birth of Mark Twain, the Mark Twain Association of New York announced yesterday a poetry contest open to all resident American citizens.

NEWARK, May 23 -- The deadlock between New York and New Jersey over the construction of a World Trade Center in Manhattan and the purchase and improvement of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad appeared near resolution tonight.
THERE is something about spacious dining that forebodes a depleted pocketbook. The waiter who approaches down a wide aisle, however, does not necessarily bear an exorbitant check.
CLEVELAND, May 23 (UPI) -- Arnold Palmer and Gary Player, the two top golf money-winners of the year, will not play in the Memphis open tournament next month, their lawyer said today.

As the younger professionals dominated the local qualifying trials yesterday for the United States Golf Association's Open championship, 51-year-old Herman Barron of the Fenway Golf Club, White Plains, proved an exception.
PARIS, May 23 (UPI) -- Nicola Pietrangeli of Italy and Jan Erik Lundquist of Sweden advanced today to the semi-final round of the men's singles in the French tennis championship.
A LITTLE-KNOWN aspect of bidding was encountered in this deal last week in a set game played by John R. Crawford and Jack Dreyfus against Mr. and Mrs. Tobias Stone.

PARIS, May 23 -- French officials found grounds for optimism tonight in the willingness of the Algerian rebels to try their case in detail around the conference table instead of in the arena of world opinion.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, May 24 -- Premier Khrushchev invited Ambassador Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr. of the United States to the American ice show in Moscow last night and then talked with him until the early hours of this morning about the Soviet leader's scheduled meeting with President Kennedy.
Clark Foreman, director of the Emergency Civil Liberties Committee, replied yesterday to an attack on the committee made Monday by Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania.
ALBANY, May 23 -- The state plans to crack down on real estate brokers and salesmen who use the "blockbusting" technique.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Kennedy was reliably reported tonight to have personally asked three prominent private citizens last weeek to organize the "tractors-for-prisoners" exchange with Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.
TRENTON, May 23 (AP) -- A bill to give the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission new crime-fighting powers has cleared a major hurdle -- the State Senate Republican caucus.

Premier David Ben-Gurion arrived here last night en route to Canada for his first visit to that country as the chief executive of Israel. He will return to the United States Sunday to meet Secretary-General Dag Hammar skjold.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 23 -- Negroes reasserted today their determination to continue an anti-segregation "Freedom Ride" across Alabama and go into Mississippi and Louisiana.

LONDON, May 23 (UPI) -- Much of Western Europe's press expressed fear today that racial trouble in Alabama would weaken President Kennedy's position at the summit conference with Premier Khrushchev next month.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Kennedy will spend most of three days, including his birthday, at his Cape Cod home before leaving on his European trip next week. He will also address two $100-a-plate political dinners to help wipe out the democratic campaign deficit.

Although their American League standing hardly reflects it, the Yankees "are starting to find themselves at the plate and probably will show more offense from here on," Manager Ralph Houk said so yesterday.

Wall Street blended experience and high imagination yesterday and came up with any number of "solutions" for the du Pont-General Motors problem. Each embodied the conclusion that market effects of the Supreme Court order that E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., rid itself of its holdings of stock in the General Motors Corporation would be far less than many -- including the du Pont company -- have feared.
MILWAUKEE, May 23 (AP) -- Lew Burdette of the Braves fashioned a four-hitter today for a 1-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates and spoiled Bobby Shantz' first start in two years.
A taxpayer's suit against the validity of Mayor Wagner's Charter Revision Commission and to permit the creation of a competing commission will be carried to the Court of Appeals.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 23 -- A woman motorist crawled from a window of a slightly damaged car on a bridge of the New England Thruway here today and was killed when she fell from the bridge.
Two policemen rescued four persons yesterday from the top floor of a burning two-story frame dwelling at 226 Boerum Street in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

Glenn Davis, the former speedy Army halfback known as Mr. Outside, and the late Charles W. Caldwell Jr., who coached Williams and Princeton teams to many titles, were among ten men named to the Football Hall of Fame yesterday.

An issue of $36,500,000 of New York City Housing Authority temporary loan notes was sold yesterday to the First National City Bank of New York in four-parts. They were dated June 14, 1961, and come due on March 14, 1962.

KANSAS CITY, May 23 (AP) -- A thirteen-hit attack coupled with effective relief from Marty Kutyna tonight carried the Washington Senators to a 7-3 victory over the Kansas City Athletics, who suffered their fifth straight loss.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- A contract for designing a ship-based tracking system for a communications satellite was awarded by the Navy today to the Bendix Corporation.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., May 23 -- The twelfth annual convention of the Evangelical Lutheran Synod of New Jersey today ratified articles of consolidation to merge it with three other Lutheran bodies to form a new Lutheran Church in America.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The professional basketball star, Kenny Sears, today filed a $90,000 suit against the New York Knickerbockers of the National Basketball Association charging violation of antitrust acts and monopoly.

HONOLULU, May 23 (UPI) -- The pilot of a Pan-American jet carrying 121 passengers, including the Salt Lake City baseball team, dived 19,006 feet in ninety seconds yesterday as a [)recaution against an indicated failure of the cabin pressure system.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce told a Senate Labor subcommittee today that a proposed public-works program costing up to $1,000,000,000 a year would hurt the economy, not help it.
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Pentagon, after being prodded by a Tennessee Senator, has decided to evacuate six overseas hotels that it has been maintaining as leave centers or emergency quarters for traveling military personnel and their families.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- An Arkansas lawyer told House investigators today that Southern employers widely used anti-Negro appeals to thwart union organizing drives among white workers.
ROME, May 23 -- Foreign Minister Antonio Segni left by air today for Klagenfurt, Austria, to discuss the question of Alto Adige with the Austrian Foreign Minister, Dr. Bruno Kreisky.

Sam Minskoff Sons have taken title to property containing a parking lot at the southeast corner of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) and Fifty-fifth Street. The parcel, 100 by 95 feet, had been purchased from the Elliot Daitz estate.
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman announced last night that $1,500,000 was being raised to set up a foundation in the name of Ambassador Adlai E. Stevenson.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 23 -- Paul G. Hoffman, head of the United Nations Special Fund, called today for increased emphasis on education in under-developed nations so they could better utilize technical aid.
LONDON, May 23 -- Montgomery, Ala., is now as well known in Britain as Little Rock, Ark., as a place of racial hatred and violence.

The big outflow of gold from the United States last year and the attendant wild speculation in gold in the London market had a valuable lesson to teach -- the need for more international monetary cooperation. In its latest monthly business review, the Chase Manhattan Bank discusses some of the lessons learned.
WASHINGTON, May24 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission endorsed today a commercial communications satellite system owned jointly by international telephone and telegraph companies.

CLEVELAND, May 24 (UPI) -- The president of the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company said today that the Negro population of this country represented a $20,000,000,000 yearly market, bigger than American markets in Norway, Denmark, Sweden and Ireland combined.
ST. LOUIS, May 24 (AP) -- Larry Jackson pitched and batted the St. Louis Cardinals to a 7-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.

A filmed series of golf matches featuring Arnold Palmer, United States Open Golf champion, is expected to be televised next season by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The starting date has not been set, but the program probably will be presented on Sundays from 4 to 5 P.M.
The promotion of R.W. Baker Jr., D.E. Meads and W.M. Underwood to vice presidents of the New York Life Insurance Company was announced yesterday by Clarence J. Meyers, chairman and president.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, today urged Congress immediately to suspend the "equal time" requirement in the Federal communications law for elections at all levels through 1963.
NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa., May 24 -- The Philadelphia women's golf team won the Griscom Cup for the fourth year in a row today over the rolling, 5.920-yard, par-75 Aronimink Golf Club course.
A poem can have "baraka" and so can a house or a dented cooking pot, Robert Graves said yesterday. He found little "baraka," or inspiration, in modern poetry.
Several hundred thousand students seeking summer jobs are likely to find they will have to take a vacation after all.
A prominent Jewish religious leader charged last night that urban housing projects in the city had failed to make room for new synagogues, churches and schools.
Some of the best broken-field running in town can be seen every day at the intersection of Chambers and Centre Streets.

New Jersey's attempt to get its hands on the $38,000,000 to $50,000,000 its residents are now paying into the New York State treasury in income taxes raises interesting political, legal and moral questions.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., May 24 -- The Long Island Golf Association's decision to move its open championship eastward met with approval today. A field of eighty-five responded at the Westhampton Country Club.

A new feature was presented to the local racing scene yesterday, with the first running of the Brighton Beach Handicap. In keeping with an inaugural at the Aqueduct course, an American record performance was contributed by John M. Schiff's Our Jeep in winning the event, on the turf at a mile and five-eighths.

SEVENTH AVENUE was whirling like an electric mixer yesterday as store buyers were deluged with a steady stream of fall fashions. Collections were opening like clockwork, every hour on the hour. Although many of the designs had that look-alike stamp of flare, blackened shades or "no color" color, they were all developed into pretty, understated clothes, in outstanding fabrics.

Twenty-five migrant berry pickers returned yesterday from a job in Virginia on which they said they had been underpaid and lodged in unsanitary quarters inhabited by snakes and rats. Several said they had wound up in debt to the employer.
The head of the World Zionist Organization called on the American Zionist movement last night to become a "decisive and determining" force in every phase of American Jewish life.

Borough President James J. Lyons led a parade of Bronx witnesses yesterday in calling on the Mayor's Charter Revision Commission to retain Borough Presidents and the Controller's office with their present powers in the city government.

Your editorial of May 17 favors the Administration's proposal to subject unremitted profits of United States corporations operating abroad to United States tax rates. You state, "* * * no national purpose is served by continuing to subsidize through the tax system American investment * * *" in industrialized foreign nations.
The basketball scandal spread yesterday to five more universities and colleges, including three in New York City.
Financial difficulties may cause the cancellation of the 1961 Empire State Music Festival, according to Frank Forest, its general manager.
The situation in South Korea following the recent military take-over of the Government there gives cause for grave concern.
LOS ANGELES, May 24 (AP) -- Gary Bell pitched a four-hitter tonight as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Los Angeles Angels, 7 -- 1, before 5,586.
CHICAGO, May 23 (UPI) -- Despite high unemployment, thousands of jobs were going begging across the nation today.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The prospect of tax relief for the stockholders of E.I. du Pont de Nemous Co. is uncertain.

An investment banking group headed by the First National City Bank of New York apparently won yesterday the award of $17,225,000 Houston, Tex., various purpose bonds. The group bid 100.0668 with 2 per cent and 3 1/2 per cent coupons, setting a net interest cost to the Texas municipality of 3.3381 per cent.
A turnover rate of 100 per cent or more in three Manhattan elementary schools was disclosed in a survey yesterday. Eight schools had a transient rate of 90 to 99 per cent, it was found.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 24 -- Twenty-five houses in the Great Neck area have been made available for rental or purchase to Negroes, the community's Committee for Human Rights announced at its first public meeting tonight.

Two hydraulic ladders, each 146 feet high when extended, were included in $324,000 worth of new Fire Department equipment inspected yesterday by Mayor Wagner and Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- President Kennedy expects the forthcoming Inter-American economic conference to be a success and "one of the most important events of his Administration,'' the White House said today.

The city's new approach to the redevelopment of New York -- rehabilitation rather than bulldozing -- was generally applauded yesterday as the City Planning Commission opened hearings on its 1961-62 projects.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Robert F. Kennedy announced today the arrest in San Francisco of Artie Brown, 50 years old, whom he identified as a member of the executive board of Local 10, International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.
JACKSON, Miss., May 24 -- Twenty-seven "Freedom Riders" were arrested and jailed today after coming here from Montgomery, Ala., in buses under armed military escort.
Collegiate circles across the nation voiced shock and dismay yesterday over the scope of player involvement in the nation-wide basketball scandal.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- President Kennedy will deliver in person tomorrow a message on "urgent national needs" to a joint session of Congress.
The Institute of World Affairs will benefit from the Nov. 21 performance of the new Noel Coward musical, "Sail Away."
Strong Democratic organization pressure is developing for renominating Abe Stark and Lawrence E. Gerosa if Mayor Wagner decides to run for a third term.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Following are the texts of statements issued today by Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy on the "Freedom Riders" situation:

JERICHO, L.I., May 24 -- Mrs. Eben W. Pyne, Mrs. Gordon McGrath and Mrs. T.A. Bradley Jr., of the Piping Rock Club combined with Mrs. Joseph Dempsey Jr. of Southward Ho to win the Women's Long Island Golf Association four-ball best-ball tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today.
CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- A sporadic trade in July soybeans chased that contract over a 4-cent range today but activity elsewhere was generally dull with prices little changed.
LONDON, May 24 -- The twentieth season of opera at Glyndebourne, the jewel-box opera house in the Sussex countryside, began tonight with a new production of Donizetti's "l'Elisir d'Amore."

Sales of the American Stores Company, which operates a chain of 799 supermarkets and forty-one service-type stores, passed the billion-dollar mark for the first time in the year ended on April 1, Paul J. Cupp, president, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Vice President Johnson, just back from a two-week diplomatic mission to Southeast Asia, announced today that the Administration planned to ask for more than $100,000,000 for additional economic and military aid for the area.

JEAN DALRYMPLE, the redoubtable director of the New York City Center Drama and Light Opera Companies, has dabbled in the culinary arts since she was 6 years old. It was at that tender age that she won first prize in a baking contest, much to the chagrin of her family.

New orders for machine tools dropped sharply in April. The decline is considered especially significant not only because orders for tools, which take a long time to build, indicate planning for expansion by manufacturers, but also because it ran counter to the general upward trend of industry.
Metropolitan area motorists will face six major construction bottlenecks in the summer driving season now starting, but things could have been worse.

RABAT, Morocco, May 24 -- King Hassan II expressed satisfaction today with the development of United States-Moroccan relations and called for American assistance in the struggle for "decolonization and unification" elsewhere in Africa.
LONDON, May 24 -- The Western European Union announced today that West Germany would be permitted to build eight destroyers, weighing up to 6,000 tons each.

DR. FRANK STANTON, the president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, has made a wise move in reopening the question of television coverage of political campaigns. The issue of equal time is bound to arise again in the forthcoming New York mayoralty campaign and the New Jersey gubernatorial race, and now is the appropriate moment for Congress to weigh the problems peculiar to video journalism.

THE big move is about to begin. Last year more than 40,000,000 Americans changed homes, according to the Movers Conference of America. This year 41,000,000 are expected to do so, and the greatest number -- as usual -- have probably chosen June, July and August, when school is out, to make the step.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today a 10 per cent increase in urban crime during the first three months of the year.
LONDON, May 24 (AP) -- The press of Europe and Japan viewed the race violence in the Deep South today as a damaging blow to America's good name.

LOS ANGELES, May 24 (UPI) -- A check for $50,000 changed hands between the New York Yankees and the Los Angeles Angels in the baseball trade that sent Bob Cerv and Tex Clevenger to the Bronx Bombers for Rhyne Duren and three other players, it was learned today.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 24 (AP) -- Home runs by Al Kaline and Rocky Colavito carried the Detroit Tigers to a 5-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins tonight.
Textron, Inc. would further diversify its operations through the proposed union with Spencer Kellogg and Sons, Inc., producers of vegetable oils and meals, animal feeds and special chemical products.
The lucrative West Indies cruise field will be invaded this fall by six American-flag luxury liners.
SAN JUAN, P.R., May 24 (AP) -- The Catholic-supported Christian Action party's two members of the Puerto Rican legislature have been expelled.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges announced yesterday that officers, directors and large stockholders of listed companies last month reported the following changes in stockholdings under the Securities Exchange Act.

VIENNA, May 24 -- President Kennedy's press secretary, Pierre Salinger, departed this afternoon for Washington after having made arrangements for the meeting between President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev.

Families looking for apartments in New York are shopping the market to obtain the best values, according to Robert F. Bennet, vice president of Douglas L. Elliman Co. He said the tempo of renting activity so far this year seemed to indicate that the demand for new apartments would continue strong.

LISBON, Portugal, May 24 -- Portuguese assertions that seventy-one Ghanaians had been captured fighting with the Angola rebels have been proved erroneous, the Minister for Overseas Territories conceded today.
LONDON, Thursday, May 25 (Reuters) -- Herb Elliott, the world's fastest miler, has lashed out at America for its "soft, synthetic" way of life.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Senate rejected today an amendment to the school-aid bill that would have provided loans for the construction of non-public schools. It moved toward passage of the Administration's $2,550,000,000 measure, probably tomorrow.
Student leaders from Aviation High School in Long Island City, Queens, met with school officials yesterday and resolved differences that had resulted in a protest march on City Hall on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Racial violence in Alabama led Northern liberals and Southern Democrats to urge opposing courses of action today in the Senate.
St. John's University yesterday opened its $3,500,000 athletic field house for inspection.
Memorial Day announcements yesterday included not only plans for honoring the nation's war dead but also an estimate that 100 persons would be killed on the roads on the holiday, Tuesday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 24 Romain Gary probably had less trouble writing his best-selling novel, "Lady L." than Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has had making it into a movie.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (AP) -- Mayor Richardson Dilworth ousted today the City Treasurer and four other city officials touched by the Frankford elevated scandal He promised more shake-ups in three departments that deal with outside contractors.

Joey Adams, president of the American Guild of Variety Artists, will head a variety show this summer that will tour the Middle East and the Far East under State Department auspices as part of the President's Special International Cultural Exchange Program.
AMMAN, Jordan, May 24 -- King Hussein announced today that the English girl he will marry tomorrow will not be known as Queen of Jordan.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, liberator of the Philippines in World War II, will return to Manila to attend the fifteenth anniversary celebration of Philippine independence July 4.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Kennedy's statement today on the Tractors for Freedom Committee:
OTTAWA, May 24 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel arrived here today for a four-day visit. He will confer with Government officials and with leaders of the Jewish community of Canada.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- President Kennedy sent Arthur H. Dean back to Geneva today with instructions to make "every raesonable effort" to obtain a "workable and effective" nuclear test ban treaty.
The reported antitrust investigation of American Telephone and Telegraph Company by the Department of Justice was described yesterday by the company and Government officials as a routine check.

A film about the rehabilitation of a juvenile delinquent, made by students at City College's film institute and with narration by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, was shown last night at a meeting of the Women's Division of the Civic Center Clinic in the New York Bar Association Building.
EUGENE, Ore., May 24 (AP) -- Dyrol Burleson of the University of Oregon set a United States and American citizen record with a 3:57.6 mile tonight.
One of the biggest youth problems on the Lower East Side is narcotics addiction, and a Jewish settlement house has gone out into the streets to fight it.

PARIS, May 24 -- About 100,000 Algerians who have been uprooted from their homes because of the war and confined in camps will be released in the next few weeks as part of the French plan to ease tensions in Algeria and make a start toward normal conditions.

KANSAS CITY, May 24 (UPI) -- Pete Burnside walked Jerry Lumpe with the bases filled in the ninth inning tonight, forcing in the winning run and giving the Kansas City Athletics a 6 -- 5 victory over the Washington Senators.
ST. LOUIS, May 24, -- A liberal undercurrent broke the surface calm of the Southern Baptist Convention today, but the conservatives appeared strong enough to put it down again.
GREENWICH, Conn., May 24 -- A Beethoven recording that Greenwich High School's senior chorus made two years ago is, by a roundabout way, sending it to Vienna next month.
Fire swept through thirteen empty buildings in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn last night. Ten firemen, three of whom were trapped when one building collapsed, were treated at a hospital.
BUFFALO, May 24 (AP) -- The United Presbyterian Church today recognized the right of individual members to drink moderately. It was the Church's first formal acknowledgment of the privilege.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector). May 24 -- The trial of Adolf Eichmann finally reached late today the crucial chapter of the massacre of Hungarian Jews.
PARIS, May 24 (UPI) -- Three Australian doubles teams reached the semi-finals today in the French tennis championships.
MILWAUKEE, May 24 (AP) -- Art Mahaffey held Milwaukee to four hits tonight as Philadelphia staged a six-run rally in the fourth inning en route to a 7-1 victory.
The nation's inventories of gasoline declined seasonally by 2,874,000 barrels last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, May 17:
MINEOLA, L.I., May 24 -- Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs of the Port of New York, was named today for County Executive by Nassau County Republican leaders.
BALTIMORE, May 24 (AP) -- Home runs by Gus Triandos and Ron Hansen enabled the Baltimore Orioles to sweep a twilight-night double-header from the Chicago White Sox, 2 -- 1 and 5 -- 3, tonight.

The Fiduciary Trust Company of New York announced yesterday the election of Hamilton Hadden Jr. and Francis H. Burr as directors. The company also named John J. Clooney a vice president and treasurer.

BUFFALO, May 24 -- The United Presbyterian Church called on its 9,000 congregations today to avoid showing the controversial film "Operation Abolition" unless time was provided for an adequate presentation of what it described as "well-founded criticism of the film."

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 24 (AP) -- The Central New York Conference of the Methodist Church today offered its moral support to the efforts of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to break down racial segregation barriers in the South.
While international efforts are being made for the release of over 1,200 military prisoners in Cuba, the world must not forget the civilians incarcerated by Premier Fidel Castro's regime.
Twenty-eight companies have applied to the Maritime Administration to operate the country's first commercial hydrofoil passenger vessel, now under construction.

CINCINNATI, May 24 (UPI) -- Eight members of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the Congress on Racial Equality were arrested yesterday at Coney Island, an amusement park near here.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Justice Department acted today to place police officials in two cities in Alabama under a Federal court injunction prohibiting any inter ference with interstate travel.
A common misconception of the law is reflected in your May 17 editorial on "Taxes and Foreign Investment."

The bank and office building occupying the blockfront on the west side of Madison Avenue, between Forty-second and Forty-third Streets, will be demolished starting today to make way for a thirty-nine-story office building.

The Eastern railroads have been especially hard hit by the recession. As a result, some systems are reporting the largest deficits in their histories. The Western lines have not escaped the effects of the recession entirely, but most of them continue to operate profitably.

A USURY of contempt sometimes stains the extension of pity. Poor man, man, we say, he was his own worst enemy. That lets everyone else off the hook. Or does it? One may doubt that as one reads Malcolm Lowry's remarkable posthumous volume, "Hear Us O Lord From Heaven Thy Dwelling Place."*
LONDON, May 24 (UPI) -- The British Government said today it could find no trace of a Polish intelligence agent who was reported to have defected to the West.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The United States Government politely but firmly rejected today a suggested early meeting between President Kennedy and Lieut. Gen. Chang Do Young, head of the military regime that now runs South Korea.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 24 -- A mistake in the mutuel calculation department cost Roosevelt Raceway $10,057.25 tonight. The bonanza went to some 1,900 ticket-holders on Taffy Hanover, the winner of the third race.

THIS deal, in which good defense was overcome by declarer's correct play, is from a new edition of the bridge textbook, "The Elements of Play," by Ruth M. Cohen, which in earlier editions has been used by bridge teachers for several years.

Draft indebtedness of Latin American importers to United States exporters increased in April to the highest level since July, 1953, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. According to the bank's monthly survey of twelve large commercial banks, the debts of importers increased in sixteen of the twenty-three Latin American countries.
Ninety-seven park buffs toured Queens yesterday and learned that recreation areas had increased from 1,348 acres in 1928 to 16,000 today.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 24 -- Discrimination against United States-flag steamship lines was pictured today as a serious threat to the future of the American merchant marine.
ALBANY, May 24 -- Chiropractors will no longer be permitted to use X-ray equipment, the State Health Department announced today.
Members of the Dramatists Guild voted yesterday overwhelmingly in favor of royalty cuts to help producers weather what they consider "the worst economic crisis the theatre has ever had."
India's top-ranking member of the United Nations staff expects the Soviet Union to continue its attack on Dag Hammarskjold and on the United Nations itself.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 24 (AP) -- Janos Kadar, First Secretary of the Hungarian Workers (Communist) party, has indicated there is a possibility Soviet forces will be withdrawn from Hungary.
Two gunmen held up two employes of a construction company in an office building near Grand Central Terminal yesterday and escaped with a $20,000 payroll.
BRASILIA, May 24 -- Cuba's Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs declared today that Premier Fidel Castro's Government did not have any military pacts with Communist-bloc nations.
As the drums of political change boom across tropical Africa, other changes are in the making on the continent.

CINCINNATI, May 24 -- Dr. William F. Albright, archaeologist and professor emeritus of Semitic languages at The Johns Hopkins University, was honored tonight at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion on his seventieth birthday.
BEFORE she goes abroad, the wife of a diplomat is supplied with some very down-to-earth information about her husband's new post.

The proposals announced in The Times of May 17 to convert Welfare Island into a city of 70,000 middle-income families, is a logical outgrowth of a distorted and high-pressure campaign for such housing to the exclusion of all other considerations.
STRATFORD-ON-AVON, England, May 24 -- After an absence of eight years, "Richard III" was presented by the Royal Shakespeare Theatre here tonight as the third offering in its repertory season.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- A multi-billion-dollar housing bill, generally along the lines President Kennedy recommended, was approved today by the House Banking subcommittee on housing.
Two city commissioners called yesterday for the elimination of "incentive pay" to weighers in the home-laundry industry as a step to prevent overcharges to customers.
NEW ORLEANS, May 24 (UPI) -- Nine Nazi "storm troopers" and their leader, George Lincoln Rockwell, were arrested tonight as they tried to picket the movie "Exodus."
BONN, Germany, May 24 -- French pressure on West Germany to accept a common European farm policy has reached the stage where President de Gaulle himself has entered the negotiations.

GENEVA, May 24 -- The conference on Laos has produced divergent United States and Communist definitions of neutrality. Both definitions seem to stem from the power alignment in the Indochinese kingdom more than from what Webster has to say.

MIAMI, May 24 -- One of the most active anti-Castro Cuban groups, the Revolutionary Movement of the People, is not only pulling out of the Cuban Revolutionary Council, but is badly split within itself.

AGELESS Archie Moore swept jauntily into town yesterday and promptly injected needed blood plasma into the box office veins of his light-heavyweight championship fight with Giulio Rinaldi of Italy at Madison Square Garden two weeks from Saturday. Being a glib and amusing person, the Ancient Arch serves as his own best press agent and he soon was beguiling every newspaperman he met.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- President Kennedy will propose a three-point program tomorrow to combat unemployment and delinquency among youth.

CINCINNATI, May 24 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants scored three unearned runs in the seventh inning tonight and beat the Cincinnati Reds, 5 -- 4, despite an eighth-inning rally sparked by Vada Pinson's homer.
ALBANY, May 24 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today the names of 422 persons who had passed the bar examinations held March 22 and 23.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- President Kennedy has decided not to press for a Federal urban mass transit program until next fall.

Cleveland Buckner, a 6-foot-9-inch center, signed yesterday with the New York Knickerbockers of the National Basketball Association. He is a 230-pound resident of Yazoo City, Miss., and played at Jackson State (Miss.) College.
A thrilling second-half comeback by the Karlsruhe eleven of West Germany upset Bangu of Brazil, 3 to 2, in an International Soccer League game at the Polo Grounds last night.

After eight years of litigation the Supreme Court in 1957 decided that ownership of 23 per cent of the outstanding stock of General Motors Corporation by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. violated the Clayton Antitrust Act. This week the court has ruled that complete divestiture of the 63,000,000 shares is necessary to remove the danger of lessened competition.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- The Greyhound Corporation said today it had ordered disciplinary action against certain employes in its bus terminal restaurant in Montgomery, Ala., for refusing service to two Negroes.

BOSTON, May 24 -- The earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) for the year will show a satisfactory rise over those for 1960 when the company cleared $689,000,000. M.J. Rathbone, president, so informed stockholders at their seventy-ninth annual meeting held in the Metropolitan Theatre here.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Prince Rainier III and Princess Grace of Monaco spent two "thoroughly delightful" hours with President and Mrs. Kennedy at the White House today. The Princess, who was the actress Grace Kelly before her marriage, gave that description of the visit as they bade farewell to the Kennedys.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Edward R. Murrow said today that the people of the United States had irrevocably "lost the luxury of living in isolated America." He said they had to realize that "there are no more domestic issues."
BONN, Germany, May 24 -- The West German Government told the Soviet Union today that any new cultural exchange agreement between the two countries must be applicable to West Berlin.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- President Kennedy appealed to all Americans today to contribute to the purchase of tractors in a plan to win freedom for more than 1,200 imprisoned Cuban rebels.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 3 to 8 points (15 to 40 cents a bale) yesterday, except in the new October, on which a rise of 10 points (50 cents a bale) was bid.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The firm and effective way in which the Federal Government has forced the restoration of law and order in Alabama, that state and local peace officers had allowed the mob to supplant with brutal anarchy, was not less the sworn duty of the President and the Attorney General because the outbreak was deliberately incited.

Now that warm weather is here, New York males can anticipate the perennial game of model watching. Each year at about this time hordes of high-fashion models, each as thin as a signpost, peer vacantly into the reflecting pools at the Seagram Building, cavort with the lions at the Public Library, or smile icily from horse-drawn hacks in the vicinity of the Plaza.
LONDON, May 24 -- Stock market prices again showed no hard trend here today, although small gains among the blue chips outnumbered losses. The turnover remained small.

Electric power production in the nation continued to rise in the week ended last Saturday. Output was 14,352,000,000 kilowatt hours, compared with 14,678,000,000 the week before and 13,831,000,000 kilowatt hours a year earlier, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.
Cocoa and copper spotlighted trading on New York commodity exchanges yesterday as future prices generally showed a mixed to easier tone.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 24 -- Dr. Sture C. Linner, acting United Nations chief in the Congo, returned from Coquilhatville today after discussions with President Joseph Kasavubu and other Congolese leaders.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.,May 24 -- A $3,000,000 Cuban agricultural project was approved over United States objections today by the governing council of the United Nations Special Fund.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Governor Rockefeller and the New York Congressional delegations tonight decided to have the Joint Legislative Committee on Reapportionment take up the Congressional redistricting issue with four representatives of the House delegation.

The Crown Zellerbach Corporation, paper manufacturer, bought sixty-nine acres of land fronting on the Arthur Kill in Tottenville, S.I., at an auction of city-owned properties yesterday. The company's bid was $300,000, which was the upset, or starting, price.
The efforts now being expended to ransom 1,000 Cuban rebels by payment of 500 tractors and bulldozers are a startling example of humanism gone astray.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) -- Governor Rockefeller outlined to the New York Congressional delegation tonight an "action" program on Federal-state problems.

The Senate's so-called broadening of the public school aid bill has seriously weakened the measure. Instead of limiting funds to public school construction and teachers' salaries, the bill now permits the states to apply the money also to local costs of school operation.
Boys High won five races and set three meet records as it took the Brooklyn Public Schools Athletic League track and field team title at Red Hook Stadium yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, May 24 (AP) -- The new group of Freedom Riders that arrived in Montgomery today includes some Yale and Wesleyan University faculty members who are distinguished in their fields.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 24 (AP) -- A threatened racial clash near Johnson C. Smith University was prevented last night by the city police and the university president, Dr. R.P. Perry.
News developments affecting the nation's biggest companies continued to bother the stock market yesterday and prices fell for the third day in succession.
The new board of directors of the Alleghany Corporation met yesterday and elected John D. Murchison Jr. president on a "temporary" basis.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The House passed a record $12,368,000,000 defense authorization bill for airplanes, missiles and ships today. The roll-call vote was 401 to 0.

A summary and analysis of a recent study of the United States' position in international affairs, prepared for the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, will be published June 15 by Praeger under the title "Strategy for the Sixties."
A full-scale model of an earth-orbiting laboratory will be built at the American Museum of Natural History with a grant of $100,000 from the Martin Company of Baltimore.

TACOMA, Wash., May 24 (UPI) -- A C-124 Globemaster transport carrying twenty-two persons crashed and burst into flames minutes after having taken off from McChord Field today. Eighteen were killed and the four others critically injured.
Orders for steel have shown steady gains in recent months, but the industry's profit squeeze is intensifying, several top steel executives declared here yesterday.

KLAGENFURT, Austria, May 24 (AP) -- Austria and Italy resumed talks today on their long dispute over the rights of the 250,000 Italian citizens of Austrian origin in Alto Adige, on Italian section of the Tyroles region.
United States Government securities sustained sharp setbacks yesterday, despite continued attempts of the Federal Reserve to nudge prices in the opposite direction.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, May 25 -- The United States' swift rejection of a plan by South Korea's military strong man for immediate White House talks was interpreted here as a new public slap at the ruling junta.
A previously unpublished collection of notes of a granddaughter of John James Audubon has been discovered at the New York Historical Society headquarters.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The horses had barely passed the finish line in New York today when the name of the winner was flashed to the House Judiciary Committee room in Washington.
CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 24 -- Another group of white and Negro "Freedom Riders" arrived here tonight from Atlanta, Ga., aboard a Greyhound bus.

ROME, May 24 -- After stigmatizing the "racial shame of Alabama," the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano found comfort today in the reflection that outbreaks of racial violence here and there in the United States showed that antisegregationist ideas were rapidly gaining ground.
Elizabethan manuscripts and contemporary music played on vintage instruments were produced last night by the New York Public Library from its storehouse of treasures for its golden jubilee dinner.
Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges asserted yesterday that United States industry was lagging far behind other developed nations in export trade.
The Justice Department submitted "guidelines" yesterday for the desegregation of the predominantly Negro Lincoln School in New Rochelle.

LONDON, May 24 (UPI) -- Dr. Geoffrey Francis Fisher, who is about to leave an office that boasted its first holder more than 1,300 years ago, today preached his last public sermon as the Archbishop of Canterbury.
IN his sermon last Sunday the Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr. said a Christian must expect adversity and not seek the easy path. Yesterday he went more than half-way to meet adversity himself.
Painstaking detective work resulted in the arrest last night of two youths, accused of stabbing and killing an elderly retired musician in a mugging attempt last May 2.
Antonio Marine Carmenate, a 20-year-old Cuban pantry-man, went armed against all eventualities except bad luck.

Morgan Stanley Co. and The First Boston Corporation and associates were low bidders yesterday for $40,000,000 of twenty-five-year debentures of Consolidated Natural Gas Company. The bid was 99.912 for a 4 3/4 per cent coupon.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- Roberto Clemente hit two homers and Dick Stuart one as Vinegar Bend Mizell gained his fourteenth victory in the last fifteen decisions with the Cubs, pitching Pittsburgh to a 7-3 victory over Chicago today.
A Brooklyn lawyer was accused yesterday of fifteen violations of a state child-adoption law by bringing Italian orphans into the country for permanent placement with childless couples.

COPENHAGEN, May 24 -- A former director of the International Monetary Fund asserted today that, after having been belittled in the immediate postwar years, the achievements of the private enterprise system were now being recognized.
PARIS, May 24 -- King Baudouin and Queen Fabiola of the Belgians arrived here today for a three-day state visit, fifty-one years after the last such visit to France by reigning sovereigns of Belgium.

GENEVA, May 24 -- Communist China accused the United States today of planning wholesale interference in the political development of Laos through an "international condominium" aimed at making the kingdom a colony again.
Following are the details of the nine basketball games in which, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday, arrangements were made to shave points:

Sales of the Grand Union Company have continued the upward trend of the fourth quarter of last year into the present fiscal year, which began Feb. 26, Thomas C. Butler, president of the Eastern food chain, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

There is change in the air for dog shows, but no agreement that the changes are for the better. Last Sunday's Long Island Kennel Club event at Locust Valley was an example. It became the first in the country outdoors without variety group or best-in-show competition.

A financing plan of Trans World Airlines, Inc., was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday. Charles C. Tillinghast Jr., president of T.W.A., announced submission of the registration statement covering the proposed offering to stockholders of $111,235,900 in seventeen-year 6 1/2 per cent subordinated income debentures and attached warrants for the purchase of 3,003,369 common shares.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 24 (AP) -- Second-stage failure thwarted an attempt to orbit a satellite today to investigate the effect of the ionosphere on radio and television communication.

With missionary zeal, the American Bankers Association has begun a campaign to lower the number and dollar volume of defalcations by bank employes. The equipment for the campaign is a "bible" called "Direct Verification for Smaller Banks."
ALBANY, May 24 -- The New York Central Railroad will add fifty-three new air-conditioned commuter coaches to its rolling stock next year.
Westchester County high school students went to sea yesterday as guests of Navy in the first East Coast experiment with a program to acquaint teen-agers with life aboard combat ships.
NEW HAVEN, May 24 -- The failure of clergymen in the South to support the Freedom Ride movement was assailed by Mr. Coffin at a rally on the Central Green here yesterday.

EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, May 24 -- France and the Algerian nationalists are still sparring cautiously in the peace talks here, with not a solid blow struck by either side, and taking long rests between rounds.
A union representation election among racetrack employes of three trainers and one owner of thoroughbred race horses was ordered yesterday by the State Labor Relations Board.
Three of the Navy's latest rocket-firing jet fighters broke the transcontinental air-speed record yesterday in the twentieth running of the Bendix Trophy Race.
GENEVA, May 24 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a report, dated May 20, to the fourteen-nation conference on Laos from the International Control Commission in Laos:

WESTBURY, L.I., May 25 -- The harness racing season's top turnout of some 40,000 fans is expected at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night. The principal attraction will be Adios Butler, the superstandardbred, making his first outing of the year against False Step of New Zealand, Bye Bye Byrd and other ace pacers in the New Frontier, a $25,000 freefor-all race.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., May 25 -- Ed Merrins, who learned his golf in the South, won the Long Island Golf Association's open championship on his first bid today. The 28-year-old professional of the Rockaway Hunt Club in Cedarhurst, who came to the district a year ago, triumphed by four strokes with a score of 211.
I am impelled to write to you because of my horror and despair at the news from Alabama. It strikes home to me particularly because I recently returned from an extensive journey through Africa.
