A local law tightening and extending the ban on discrimination in private housing was unanimously approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

ONE-HUNDRED paintings from one of the remarkable collections of modern art made in recent years, formed by G. David Thompson of Pittsburgh, go on view today at the Guggenheim Museum. They will be shown there through Aug. 31.

The Shell Oil Company announced yesterday the appointment of Denis B. Kemball-Cook as executive vice president of marketing, manufacturing, purchasing, transportation and supplies. Mr. Kemball-Cook, a director, also was named deputy to Monroe E. Spaght, president.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended last Saturday were 6 per cent above the level of a year earlier.

Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges urged business men last night to increase investment in new plant and equipment to help move the economy forward. He declared that the Government's recent tax credit proposal to spur new capital spending was "the most immediate incentive for added investment, with the least loss of Federal revenue."

New York City's Center of Music and Drama has just completed one of the most successful seasons in its eighteen-year history. This statement was made Tuesday by Newbold Morris, chairman of the Board of Directors of the City Center at the annual corporation meeting.
The three television networks have scheduled a combined total of eighteen half-hour special news programs on President Kennedy's trip to Europe next week.

The recent racial violence in Alabama shows that there is a need for "forceful" Congressional action on civil rights, the American Civil Liberties Union declares in a letter to President Kennedy made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The President informed Congress in his special message today that he would increase his foreign aid request for the next fiscal year by $535,000,000 to meet "the growing threats to freedom around the world."

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said today that enough farmers had signed up under the emergency feed-grain program to assure the planned 20 per cent reduction in acreage of corn and sorghum grain this year.

I believe The Times was unfair both to its readers and to the organizations involved in its editorials of May 15 and May 18 on the mutual support agreement entered into on May 12 by the National Maritime Union, Teamsters and International Longshoremen Association.

Are pleasure boatmen getting too much V.I.P. (very important person) treatment? Is their sport spoiling them? Are they pampered, effete, too easygoing? Some of the rocking chair fleet say "yes" as they sit and gossip on clubhouse porches.

Loans to business at the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City dropped $154,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the like week a year ago, business loans were down $23,000,000.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 25 (AP) -- Jim Lemon's single to left field in the eleventh inning drove home Lennie Green with the winning run today as the Minnesota Twins beat the Detroit Tiger, 7 -- 6.

A five-story walk-up apartment house on plot 55 by 100 feet at 35-20 Ninety-fourth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, has been sold by 35-20 Associates. The buyer was an investing client of S. Mack, lawyer. The deal for cash over mortgages of $72,000 was negotiated by the William K. Langfan Company and Broadway Affiliates, brokers.

GENEVA, May 25 -- Qualified sources said tonight that the United States would submit a two-part plan for safeguarding peace and neutrality in Laos when the conference on that country's future reassembled next week.

Greenwich Villagers swayed the Board of Estimate yesterday with a plea to weigh housing needs carefully before putting through a new street, just 500 feet long, that would wipe out 160 low-rent apartments in their community.
ALBANY, May 25 -- The chairman of the legislative committee reshaping New York's Congressional Districts said today he did not see any need to hold public hearings.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The "urgent needs" outlined by President Kennedy in his message to Congress today would add at least three-quarters of a billion dollars to Federal spending in the coming year, mostly for space and defense.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 25 (AP) -- A group of white ministers met today and pledged themselves to "make efforts to re-establish better communications between the races" in Birmingham.
BONN, Germany, May 25 -- West German tank units will begin training in Britain in September or October, it was reported today as Defense Minister Franz Josef Strauss returned from talks in London.
EUGENE, Ore., May 25 (AP) -- Dyrol Burleson, the University of Oregon junior who recaptured the American mile record last night, believes he can take the world record as well.
The Waterbury Farrel Foundry and Machine Company will dedicate a modern, 315,000-square-foot plant today at Cheshire, Conn. The 110-year-old company is a division of Textron, Inc.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Freight loadings reports by the rail and truck industries today reflected a slight economic upturn.
A father and son who were recently expelled from the American Stock Exchange as broker-specialists were arrested yesterday on charges of conspiring to violate the Securities Act of 1934.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- The House Merchant Marine Committee today approved a bill to do away with a 6 per cent differential allowed West Coast shipyards in bids on construction contracts involving Federal subsidies.
Lumber production fell to 239,025,000 board feet last Week from 244,655,000 the week before and 248,430,000 board feet a year ago, according to reports from regional associations.

Pressure on American Telephone and Telegraph, du Pont and General Motors continued yesterday and the leading stock market averages moved down. Most' of their declines, however, came from losses in these three stocks and in Eastman Kodak.

IONE, Calif., May 25 (AP) -- Rioting between Mexican and Negro youth erupted last night during a track meet at California's biggest institution for juvenile offenders. Ten youths were injured, two seriously, officials said.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 25 -- The Congo will substitute a unicameral Congress for its two-chamber Parliament under a plan adopted last night by President Joseph Kasavubu and other Congolese leaders meeting in Coquilhatville.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 25 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold announced today the resignation of Rajeshwar Dayal of India as the United Nations special representative in the Congo.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 25 -- A program to improve education in Jewish high schools and increase their enrollments was outlined here today at the annual conference of the National Council for Jewish Education.
GENEVA, May 25 (AP) -- Ingemar Johansson boldly proclaimed "it would be fun to beat Sonny Liston" after he agreed today to fight the heavyweight contender from Philadelphia this year.
A strike of twenty-four salesmen has cut off the supply of Breyer ice cream to 3,000 storekeepers in the city, Long Island and Westchester County since May 6.
KANSAS CITY, Mar. 25 (AP) -- Joe Nuxhall pitched Kansas City to a 4-3 victory over Washington today despite home runs by Willie Tasby and Gene Green of the Senators.
AMMAN, Jordan, May 25 -- Antoinette Avril Gardiner, 20-year-old daughter of a British Army officer, became today the wife of a King, but not a Queen.
THE Eastern States championships will begin today at the Statler-Hilton Hotel with two contests -- men's pairs and women's pairs.

MOSCOW, May 25 (AP) -- Russian readers were given their first report on the ultra-conservative John Birch Society today. Pravda, the official organ of the Soviet Communist party, said the organization had "succeeded in making a Communist out of even former President Eisenhower."
MIAMI, May 25 -- The Cuban Government made it clear in a broadcast today that its invasion prisoners would be released if the 500 tractors were handed over.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These rates do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday the need for leadership in the field of human relations was never greater than now.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 25 -- The Westchester seniors champion, Joseph A. Lelash of Wykagyl, today won the Westchester Seniors Golf Association's annual spring tournament with a 40, 38 -- 78 over the Westchester Hills Golf Club course.
O. Roy Chalk has asked the Federal Government to approve his acquisition of control of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc.
Ludwig Teller, the first college professor to become a Tammany district leader, announced last night that he would not seek re-election to the New York County Democratic executive committee.

ENFIELD, Conn., May 25 -- The slow abatement of Connecticut River pollution may be a direct cause of the steady increase in a great spring shad run now giving sport to thousands of anglers. It may even justify a dim hope that salmon will be restored to the river years from now.

Paintings as abstract as a Kandinsky, as impressionist as a Monet, and as primitive as a Rousseau were exhibited here yesterday by juvenile artists from the State Training School for Boys at Warwick, N.Y.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 25 -- The State Mental Health Department bowed today to objections by property owners to a proposed day-care center at 128-130 Hubbard Avenue.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 25 -- Mrs. Bruce Starzenski of Apawamis shot a 42, 38-80 at the par-73 Wykagyl course today to win the weekly tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association by three strokes.

IN a shoe-box-shaped showroom, its walls dotted with abstract paintings, the buyers sit as noiselessly as girls and boys at an old-fashioned school. Like a museum curator expounding from his lectern, the lean, middle-aged man orates.
Six organizations issued a joint statement yesterday denouncing what they termed "the brutal rioting in Alabama and irresponsible police action in Mississippi."

A seafood importing company and three of its officers were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of importing $300,000 worth of frozen shrimp from Communist China since 1956, in violation of the Trading With the Enemy Act.
ST LOUIS, May 25 -- The Southern Baptists Convention, which warned last year against the election of a Roman Catholic to the Presidency, today praised the Roman Catholic who was elected.
Because of the complexity of state laws with regard to liquor advertising, the liquor advertiser who markets nationally must prepare twenty-seven different versions of the same advertisement.
DeWitt Clinton High won the Public Schools Athletic League Bronx track and field championships for the fifth straight year yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.
Dealers in bankers acceptances announced yesterday an increase of 1/8 percentage point in the rates on these short-term obligations used to finance goods in shipment or in storage.

The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company announced plans yesterday to acquire the Long Island Trust Company, Garden City, L.I. The merger would add fourteen offices in Nassau County and $120,881,000 in total resources to Chemical New York's 110 offices in the metropolitan area and $4,374,930,000 in total resources.
SEOUL, South Korea, May 25 -- South Korea's military rulers were standing firm today against United States pressure aimed at removing irritants in relations between the two countries.
Veiled threats of another teachers' strike were made yesterday after a Board of Education meeting at which action on collective bargaining was again postponed.
LIVINGSTON, N.J., May 25 -- Mrs. Fred Shehadi of Maplewood scored a 42, 38 -- 80 today and led the field in a Garden State Women's Golf Association tournament at Cedar Hill.
Government mediation men yesterday hailed as "historic" the signing of a maritime labor contract calling for the hiring of handicapped workers.
ALBANY, May 25 -- The New York Central Railroad's president, Alfred E. Perlman, in effect, today charged Walter J. Tuohy, president of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway, with bad faith.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Administration and one of the nation's major defense contractors agreed on an anti-discrimination plan today. President Kennedy called it a "milestone" in civil rights.
BALTIMORE, May 25 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles scored six runs in the first two innings on two singles and nine walks, and held on for a 6-4 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight.
THE first time Ted Williams saw Carl Yastrzemski swing a bat the Great Man walked over and put a fatherly arm around the boy's shoulders.
There is no reason why jet aircraft could not use Newark Airport if the Port of New York Authority lifted its jet ban there, the head of the Federal Aviation Agency has told the authority.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- A preliminary study that could lead to an investigation of the activities of United States intelligence agencies was authorized today by the House Rules Committee.

JACKSON Miss., May 25 -- Some liberal Southerners of both races joined moderates and others today in asserting that the Freedom Riders should be halted. But leaders of the movement pledged to continue and extend it into other states.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy cut the peace force of United States marshals in Alabama today by 85 per cent.

EASTCHESTER, May 25 -- If Westchester is to remain a leading county in the next twenty years it must plan "realistically" for land use and integrated transportation, 400 civic and business leaders were told here tonight.
The bond market was quiet yesterday.
A lawyer-physician's crusade to establish a new principle in law -- the right to treatment for the mentally ill in institutions -- took him into the Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday.
MEXICO CITY, May 25 -- This capital was alive with speculation today over a report by a Leftist writer that Mexico was to be the initial objective of a campaign to spread the Cuban revolution.
Federal Judge Sidney Sugarman yesterday transferred the Government's antitrust indictment against the General Motors Corporation to Chicago for trial.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., May 25 (AP) -- A space agency pilot flew the X-15 rocket plane to a record of 3,370 miles an hour today.

GREAT cities are like magnets. They draw people to them -- ambitious people intent on winning wealth and fame, humble people anxious to find work, romantically minded people dreaming of cultural opportunities, of attractive members of the opposite sex and of a grandstand seat at the spectacle of urban life.
LONDON. May 25 (Reuters) -- The British Overseas Airways Corporation argued today against allowing the independent Cunard Eagle Airline to carry passengers between Britain and Canada.

Broadway reaction to the Dramatists Guild's decision to accept a cut in royalties -- providing stars, directors, choreographers and producers do the same -- ranged from the highly welcomed to the reserved comment.

ARABIC food added a flavor bonus last night to the preview of an essay on Kuwait presented by the Near East Foundation. This philanthropic organization is sponsoring an exhibition of color photographs by Adolf Morath, British photographer.
LOS ANGELES, May 25 (UPI) -- Willie Kirkland and John Romano drove in four runs apiece today in leading the Cleveland Indians to a 13 -- 5 victory over the stumbling Los Angeles Angels.

The board of directors of the American Home Products Corporation voted a three-for-one split of the capital stock yesterday and announced its intention to raise the dividend on the increased shares. It also declared an extra dividend on the present stock.
OTTAWA, May 25 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel said today he was convinced that peace between his country and the Arab states would come eventually.

DEAL, N.J., May 25 -- Gus Siciliano, a Jumping Brook amateur, took the first-round lead in the 36-hole New Jersey pre-seniors golf championship today. He shot a four-over-par 36, 39 -- 75 at the Deal Golf and Country Club.
A "Books for Africa" campaign has temporarily replaced politicking for members of the Ninth Assembly District Republican Club on Manhattan's East Side.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Officials of the State Department, as well as of other branches of the Government, are becoming desperate over their inability to crack the radial barriers affecting African diplomats and their families in Washington.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- In the reply published yesterday of members of the faculty of the University of Havana-in-exile to the manifesto of a group of American educators who put the blame on the United States Government for current hostile American-Cuban relations, the headline reads, in type which dominates the rest: "To the Harvard Professors."

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Administration officials reported today that there had been bitter Latin-American criticism of the proposal by Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba to liberate captive rebels in exchange for 500 United States tractors.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Months of indecision and scientific debate within the Government were ended today with President Kennedy's challenge to the nation to spend up to $40,000,000,000 in an attempt to beat the Soviet Union to the moon.

BONN, Germany, May 25 -- The Ludendorff Movement, an anti-Semitic organization founded in 1925, was banned as unconstitutional throughout West Germany today in a joint action by the West German states.
A man who was on duty in the New York Public Library when it opened on May 23, 1911, came to its rescue yesterday.

Yankee persuasiveness, consisting of "more than $100,000 and less than $125,000," lured a college all-America football quarterback into professional baseball yesterday. Jake Gibbs of the University of Mississippi, a third baseman on the diamond, accepted the bait in the form of the largest bonus ever paid by New York's American League champions.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) -- The Federal Aviation Agency proposed a rule today that would require the airlines to install a new safety device on all commercial transports. The change would cost nearly $18,000,000.

EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, May 25 -- French and Algerian rebel delegations held their longest negotiating sessions thus far today with indications that, for the first time, there had been a real exchange of views.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A special White House panel urged the airline pilots and flight engineers today to merge their rival unions to end jurisdictional disputes over job security.

Cotton futures opened quiet on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, up 1 point, and closed with gains of 4 to 11 points. The new October position was an exception, falling 15 points. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)
The Capital Cities Broadcasting Corporation has arranged to buy a radio station and a television station in Buffalo, N.Y., for $14,000,000 in cash, it was announced yesterday.

THE torment of France in breaking with the past was analyzed last night in a superb documentary on "C.B.S. Reports" over Channel 2. Indeed, the season has not produced a more brilliant example of the exciting art of truly creative and altogether indigenous TV.
Everything was fine with the Yankees in most departments last night at the Stadium as they downed the Boston Red Sox, 6 -- 4.

LAGRANGE, Ga., May 25 (AP) -- All was reported quiet at this city near the Alabama-Georgia line today after police jailed five persons, saying they had tried to make trouble over the passing of a bus carrying Freedom Riders.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 25 (AP) -- United States District Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr. has called for testimony from the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. before deciding whether three remaining libel suits against The New York Times will be remanded to state courts for trial.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A resolution of support for the Kennedy Administration's intervention in the Alabama racial violence ran into the traditional Southern barricade in the Senate today.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 25 -- Princess Birgitta, the 24year-old granddaughter of King Gustav VI Adolf of Sweden, was married here today to Prince Johan George of Hohenzollern-Sigmaringen.
Following is the text of President Kennedy's address to Congress yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
AFTER completing a speaking tour on behalf of the American Friends (Quakers), Dr. Earle L. Reynolds is flying back to Hiroshima today.

Dally average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped $107,000,000 to $66,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements declined $26,000,000 to $575,000,000.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy is not completely neglecting French couture.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 25 (AP) -- The Florida Legislature has rushed to passage a bill authorizing city commissioners and highway patrolmen to break up unlawful and riotous crowds.
A plan for closer cooperation to help meet the crisis of short-staffed municipal hospitals was outlined yesterday to administrators of the city's voluntary hospitals.

The national headquarters of the Congress of Racial Equality, from which the anti-segregation drive in Southern states is being directed, sent out field orders last night to extend the drive to railroad and airline terminals.

BECAUSE "A Call on Kuprin" is so timely that it seems to jump from this year's headlines, it would have been easy to settle for a simple-minded cloak-and-dagger thriller based on the news. But Jerome Lawrence and Robert E. Lee have elected to aim higher, and their new play, which arrived last night at the Broadhurst, is not only contemporary and tautly suspenseful but also says something of vast importance.
DETROIT, May 25 -- The gradual rise in automobile sales, which has characterized recent weeks, persisted in the second ten-day period of May.
ALBANY, May 25 -- The Court of Appeals ruled in a 4-to-3 decision today that only publications containing what it called "hard-core pornography" should be suppressed as obscene.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 25 (UPI) -- Arnold Palmer, Jim Ferree and Johnny Pott shot four-under-par 67's today and shared the lead after eighteen holes of the $50,000 "500 Festival" open golf tournament. It is being played on the 6,605-yard course in the infield of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Senate passed a bill providing $2,550,000,000 in school aid tonight and sent it to the House of Representatives.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 25 -- Wild outcries from spectators twice interrupted testimony in the Eichmann trial today, forcing a fifteen-minute recess.

George H. Bostwick's Pocosaba made a strong finish to win the $12,400 Aqueduct National Hurdle yesterday by three lengths from F. Eugene Dixon Jr.'s Mantegna. Pocosaba cover the mile and seven-eighths in 3:24 2/5, only two-fifths of second slower than the track record.

While strolling through Central Park the other day, in the merry, merry month of May, I was taken by surprise. I had thought we had outgrown Robert Moses' tender notions of conservation through concrete. But apparently Newbold Morris was not kidding when he said recently that he had felt tempted to fill Central Park with green concrete.
For the last quarter of a century a pink-cheeked, goateed little man has been sitting close to a telephone every working day to answer questions about Judaism.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 25 -- Seven more Freedom Riders, including three from Yale University, were arrested today. They had planned to take a bus from here to Jackson, Miss.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- The oversupply of ships in world commerce, not Government policies, is at the bottom of the American merchant marine's difficulties, Harry X. Kelly, chairman of the Mississippi Shipping Company's executive committee, said here today.
The Board of Education barred two major construction concerns yesterday from doing further business with the city's school system.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Government said today that the Consumer Price Index remained unchanged at a record level in April, "marking a further extension of the over-all stability" shown since last October.
BERGEN, Norway, May 25 (AP) -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran and his Queen are cutting short a private visit to the scenic west coast of Norway and flying to Rome tomorrow.

The Paulist Choristers, one of the most venerable and respected groups in the country, sang in Town Hall last night under the direction of Rev. Joseph R. Foley. The concert was dedicated to the memory of Rev. William J. Finn, who founded the chorus in 1904 and who died last March.
CHICAGO, May 25 (API) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Two Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub teams that had been dropped to lower brackets because of defeats and disqualifications began the climb back to the top yesterday.
Net income of Deere Co. made a sharp recovery in the six months ended on April 30, rising to $16,902,534 from $8,292,944 in the fiscal 1960 period, the concern reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Members of Congress embraced with some warmth today the objectives outlined in President Kennedy's speech, but shied at the thought of providing all the funds to meet them.

SANDS POINT, L.I., May 25 -- Mrs. Allan A. Ryan of The Creek posted a 40, 39 -- 79 today to take low gross honors in the Women's Cross County Golf Association one-day tournament at the Sands Point Club. Mrs. Edward Gerry of Piping Rock was next with 39, 41 -- 80.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 25 -- The Theodore Roosevelt home at Sagamore Hill may be offered to the Federal Government as a national historic site.

Events today: Doris Mayes, mezzo-soprano, Carnegie Hall, 8:15 P.M.; Giulia Zangrilla, soprano, Giulio Polidori, tenor, and Robert Evert basso, Town Hall, 8:30; Phenix String Quartet, program of contemporary music, Room 1604, Hunter College, 8:30; "The Marriage of Figaro," presented by Opera Theatre, Scott O'Neal, director, Robert F. Wagner Junior High School, 8:00.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a $5,300,000,000 money bill carrying funds to hire more agents for the Internal Revenue Service agents to hunt down tax cheats.

MUNAA AL-HUSSEIN, the Arabic name that the King of Jordan's English bride took when she became a Moslem last month, means "The heart's desires of Hussein." The name was suggested by the 25-year-old monarch to denote the many qualities of Antoinette Avril Gardiner that made him choose her as his second wife in defiance of widespread opposition.
LONDON, May 25 -- Prices retreated in almost every section of the stock market here today.

ST. LOUIS, May 25 (AP) -- Sandy Koufax of the Los Angeles Dodgers pitched a three-hit 1-0 shutout over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight with Tom Davis' seventh-inning homer giving the left-hander all he needed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 25 -- In most cases, when two movie companies both claim to have purchased the film rights to a Broadway play it means that someone is lying, or at the very least, a publicity department has made a premature announcement.

GENEVA, May 25 -- President Kennedy's speech today is another illustration of a tragic fact in Soviet history -- namely, that the Communists have a genius for creating all the things they fear the most.
The 66,000-ton France will go to sea at the end of the year as the world's most heavily insured merchant ship.
LONDON, May 25 -- Princess Margaret is expecting a baby in the autunm.

The Indiana Dunes, which the Indiana Port Commission proposes to sacrifice for a deepwater harbor, can still be saved. Through exercise of its authority over navigation Congress has it within its power to rescue this last unspoiled area on Lake Michigan's south shore and keep it as a wonderland of nature and a needed playground in one of the nation's crowded metropolitan areas.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- The House Government Operations Committee officially rejected today President Kennedy's plan to reorganize the Federal Communications Commission and give its chairman more power.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- An emergency board recommended to the White House today a 10 per cent pay increase for flight engineers employed by Northwest Airlines. The top-rate pay scale would then range from $1,008 to $1,430 a month, depending on the type of plane.
A $1,500,000 donation from Percy and Harold Uris, investment builders, has made it possible for Columbia University to begin the construction of a new Graduate School of Business this summer.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Kennedy proposed to Congress today bold and expensive new measures to rocket a man to the moon, to expand non-nuclear military strength and to increase foreign aid spending.

OTTAWA, May 25 -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker said today that Canadian recognition of Communist China now would be interpreted in Southeast Asia and elsewhere as "approval" of the Communist regime.
The Ford Foundation plans to make another offering to the public, its fourth, of shares of the Ford Motor Company, it was confirmed last night.
The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad announced yesterday that it had a net loss of $2,944,142 last month. In the 1960 month the road cleared $853,800.
One of Pan American World Airways' chief pilots, Capt. Clarence N. Warren Jr., was near death in the Norwalk, Conn., hospital last night with a gunshot wound in the head.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 25 -- The Soviet Union has complained against continued financing by the United Nations of the activities of Sir Leslie Munro, the United Nations' special representative on Hungary.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 25 (AP) -- E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., and the Bell Howell Company announced plans today to go into the home movie and 35 millimeter film markets with color developed by du Pont.
ROANOKE, Va., May 25 (UPI) -- Attorneys for twenty- eight Negro students asked Federal Judge Oren R. Lewis today for permission to enter four Roanoke schools next fall.
CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- A late burst of selling wiped but or trimmed all the earlier advances today on the Board of Trade. Only the feed grains finished with gains.
TRENTON, May 25 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner called on the Legislature today to approve a series of pending bills before its summer recess, which is tentatively slated to begin June 2.

NEWARK, May 25 (AP) -- Seton Hall University officials said today that Art Hicks of Chicago and Henry Gunter of New York, two basketball players named in point-shaving scandals, had been dismissed from the university as of April 12.
LONDON, May 25 -- Britain reaffirmed today her policy of leading Kenya toward self-government and independence "in a responsible fashion."

Medical care is constantly increasing in cost largely because more people go to hospitals than need to and, at great expense, stay longer than is necessary. They do so partly because, with the growth of hospital insurance, the financial burden on patients is cushioned and also because hospitalization is the easiest way for the doctor to take care of them.

An American edition of Hesketh Pearson's new book, "The Marrying Americans," will be issued by Coward -- McCann on June 9. It is an account of American women who have gone to Europe in search of husbands, titled or otherwise.
Three new films will open in local theatres today.
Daniel D. Cantor, realty investor and mortgage consultant, has bought the five-story office building at 147 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, from the Consolidated Mutual Insurance Company, the occupant.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 25 (AP) -- General Mills, Inc., announced today that all electronics and allied operations within the company would be concentrated with two wholly owned subsidiaries to form a new General Mills Electronics Group.

Loft space is plentiful in Manhattan, according to a survey made last month by the Real Estate Board of New York. The study found a vacancy rate of 3.6 per cent compared with a rate of 2.5 per cent in April, 1960.

Villanova will win the team title in a landslide. There will be bristling individual competition in most of the eighteen events. With good weather half a dozen records may fall.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 25 -- Sheriff Howard W. Fitzpatrick of Middlesex County was indicted on charges of negligence today in connection with the escape of two accused murderers from the East Cambridge jail May 14. The jail master, David S. Robinson, was shot to death during the break.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., May 25 -- The first 301 computer system of the Radio Corporation of America to be made here was turned over two months ahead of schedule today to George Champion, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

LISBON, Portugal, May 25 -The Earl of Home, British Foreign Secretary, urged Portugal tonight to weigh new measures in solving the three-month-old rebellion in Angola.
The city's highest temperature of the year -- 85 degrees -- was recorded at 4:40 P.M. yesterday in Central Park.

NEW YORK CITY supermarkets are about as corny in May as Kansas is in August. Bright, tasseled ears are everywhere to be seen, and in many cases cost a fraction under 6 cents apiece. This is an attractive price for the season.
Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said last night that there had been a decline in the sale of hunting licenses in the last two years.

A majority of the Board of Estimate denied to Mayor Wagner yesterday the $14,570 needed to finance the work of his Charter Revision Commission through June 30.

PARIS, May 25 (AP) -- Manuel Santana of Spain and Nicola Pietrangeli of Italy advanced to the final of the French tennis championship today.

The J.C. Penney Company is expecting a 3 per cent sales gain for the first half of the present fiscal year, William M. Batten, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

Dave Garroway yesterday submitted his resignation from his early morning weekday television show, over which he has presided for nearly ten years.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 26 -- Obviously, False Step didn't mind the rain-soaked, sloppy going at Roosevelt Raceway tonight in the $25,000 New Frontier Pace.

Professional wrestling, listed as an exhibition program by the State Athletic Commission, returned to Madison Square Garden last night before a standing-room-only crowd of 20,702 fans.

BUYERS expect things from Jacques Tiffeau. The hearty bravos at the end of his superb collection yesterday assured this talented designer that the audience was not disappointed. Commodity futures moved in narrow price ranges yesterday in the New York markets and closed irregularly higher. PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 26 -- An evening that began as a gay dinner party ended early today in abduction, rape and death for two women who were socially prominent in this suburban area.

The United Service Organizations announced yesterday that drama groups of nine American colleges and universities had been selected from more than hundred applicants to present plays to United States armed forces overseas in the 1961-62 season.

ONE of the most disorderly areas of a woman's boudoir is often her make-up corner with its boxes of powder, jars of cream, eyebrow pencils and spray net. No matter how much paraphernalia has been collected, the bulk of it is considered a necessity to the fastidious woman and will accompany her even on short trips.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 24 -- Faced with a steadily accelerating campaign by Communist guerrillas, the army of South Vietnam is being thoroughly reorganized.
Herb Score, a left-handed pitcher who never fully regained the form he showed before suffering an eye injury, was optioned to San Diego of the Pacific Coast League yesterday by the Chicago White Sox.

In a recent dispatch Seymour Topping wrote that "at the age of 16, when Soviet citizens are issued their internal passports, Jewish youngsters have the option of entering their nationality as Jews or that of the republic in which they live." The facts are otherwise.

Francisco (The Hook) Molina, a pro-Castro Cuban found guilty of second-degree murder in the slaying of a 9-year-old girl last September, moved in General Sessions Court yesterday to set aside the jury's verdict and obtain a new trial.

If you have hankering for bear meat, or an uncontrollable compulsion for fresh goat's milk, New York City has recently come out with what to do about it. This information, and much more, is contained in the City of New York's Official Directory for 1961 -- a little green book that will fit in your pocket and may be obtained at Room 2213 in the Municipal Building for one dollar.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara expressed confidence in the Joint Chiefs of Staff today. He said he "certainly" intended that its five members fill out their terms.
GENEVA, May 26 -- The Soviet Union said today it would never sign an agreement on nuclear testing that did not ban all nuclear weapon explosions for all time.
GENEVA, May 26 -- The British Government is complaining to the Soviet Union over the Soviet refusal to agree on a reply to the International Control Commission in Laos.
SAFFORD, Ariz., May 26 (AP) -- A traffic crash here last night killed seven persons, including six teen-agers celebrating a high school graduation.

WAYNE, N.J., May 26 -- Stan Mosel of Essex Fells fired a 37, 31 -- 68, three under par, today to win the pro-individual competition on the North Jersey Country Club links. He also shared in the team victory of the pro-amateur tournament.
A highly competitive, $50,000,000-a-year industry that hardly anyone talks about is quietly filling one of the most important roles in the nation's space program.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Vice President Johnson denied today a report that he had bought forty-eight shirts in Hong Kong. It was eighty-two shirts, he said.

No amount of secrecy can obscure what the French and the Algerian rebel leaders are talking about at Evian-les-Bains. The major issues are clear. Success or failure will depend on reaching solutions or accommodations on all of them.
A Police Department horse, frightened by a noise, bolted and plunged off a pier into the East River yesterday morning.

A merger of ACF-Wrigley Stores, Inc., and Penn Fruit, Inc., was agreed upon yesterday by the boards of directors of the two grocery chains. The resulting company would be called Allied Supermarkets, Inc., and would have sales of about $550,000,000 a year, putting it around twelfth in volume among the nation's leading food chains.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Kennedy greeted 300 leading Democrats at an informal reception in the White House today.

THERE was a time when the social graces were as important a part of a child's education as any of the three R's. Today, however, little formal instruction is offered in America, according to Mrs. Luella Cuming, who has been teaching etiquette to interested adults for the last seven years.

The volume of financing in the new capital market next week will be below the high level of recent weeks. With a four-day week-end in prospect for some sectors of the Wall Street community, the value of major fixed-interest security deals is expected to be $125,670,000, compared with $287,000,000 a week earlier.

Many of the leading handicap stars of the West will meet today in the $112,700 Californian at Hollywood Park. Nine Eastern fillies and mares will contend in the $56,300 Top Flight Handicap at Aqueduct.
WHITE HOUSE, N.J., May 26 (AP) -- Six best-in-breed champions were selected today in the twenty-fourth annual Dog Specialty Show of the Cocker Spaniel Club of New Jersey. There were 114 entries.

Officers of the League for Industrial Democracy, an old-line liberal organization, have discovered to their surprise that a fellow member in good standing is Robert H.W. Welch Jr., founder and head of the ultraconservative John Birch Society.
LONDON, May 26 (UPI) -- World exports of manufactured goods were worth 15 per cent more last year than in 1959.
LOS ANGELES, May 26 (UPI) -- Four major container companies and an agent were sued yesterday for total of $500,000,000 for alleged patent infringement on a flexible dispensing closure cap.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals denied today motions aimed at delaying the merger of United Air Lines and Capital Airlines Inc.
A man found hacked to death with an axe on a roof at Third Avenue and Seventy-eighth Street Thursday was identified yesterday as Charles R. Oscar, an artist.
Professional demand halted a two-week decline in the United States Government securities market yesterday.

A multi-spindle drill said to be the world's largest has just been installed at the Harrison, N.J., plant of the Worthington Corporation, maker of heavy machinery and air-conditioning equipment. The giant device, which cost $250,000, is directed by an electronic control panel in drilling as many as 2,000 holes an hour in three-quarter-inch metal plates in any desired pattern.
Directors of Texaco, Inc., at a meeting held here yesterday adopted plans that are expected to lead to a two-for-one split in the company's shares.

TULSA, Okla., May 26 -- Scientists and space technologists showed today the muscles and the incentives behind President Kennedy's challenge to the nation to assert full leadership in the conquest of space.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- A spokesman for the Government of Afghanistan said today that reports from Karachi of Pakistani-Afghan strife in the Khyber Pass frontier region had not accurately described conditions there.

ONE of the leading figures of the current Freedom Riders' campaign for equality is a soft-spoken, tall and scholarly Negro who was born in Marshall, Tex., Jan. 12, 1920, the son of a scholar and the grandson of a slave.

After a nineteen-year career as one of Italy's leading directors, during which only one of his films was released in America, Luchino Visconti is about to be represented on local screens by two of his prize-winning works.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 26 -- Four Scarsdale homes, two in Purchase and one in Rye, will be open to the public from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. on June 6. The Westchester chapter of the National Cystic Fibrosis Research Foundation, which has headquarters in White Plains, is sponsoring the fete.
MILWAUKEE, May 26 (AP) -- Warren Spahn posted his fifth victory of the season and No. 293 of his career tonight in hurling the Milwaukee Braves to a 10-2 triumph over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
The Memorial Day weekend began with a squish yesterday. Thunderstorms in the afternoon and evening dropped more than an inch of rain on the city.
Traffic in lower Manhattan was reduced to a crawl yesterday after a twelve-inch water main burst shortly after 2 A.M. at Broadway and Canal Street.
The animal kingdom's younger set has taken over centers of attention at the Bronx Zoo and the Coney Island Aquarium.
PARIS, May 26 -- A United States B-58 jet bomber flew from New York to Paris today in the record-breaking time of 3 hours 19 minutes 41 seconds.

MIDDLETOWN, N.J., May 26 -- A large, well-proportioned 3 1/2-year-old dog advanced from the classes today and went best in show at the thirty-second annual specialty of the Irish Wolfhound Club of America.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, May 26 (Reuters) -- The liner Queen Mary, with 732 Atlantic crossings to her credit, marks her twenty-fifth birthday tomorrow.

Carmelo Soraci, the convict who designed and executed the stained glass windows for the Church of the Good Thief at Dannemora Prison and the windows in the Protestant and Catholic chapels at Sing Sing, has written the story of his life.
The less said both to and about the men in the armed forces the better, Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves declared yesterday.
CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -- Grain futures prices ranged from firm to weak at the close on the Board of Trade today after one of the most active days of the week.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 26 -- The Board of Education has agreed to reconsider a pupil redistricting plan after receiving a complaint on segregation by the Stamford branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

The managing agent of a rooming house at 202 West 103d Street that the city had described as a "rat ranch" was charged yesterday in Housing Court with 523 violations of the Multiple Dwelling Law and Administrative Code.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 26 -- Circumstantial evidence was given at the trial of Adolf Eichmann today that he had murdered a Jewish youth in Budapest. The youth had been accused of the theft of fruit from a cherry tree.

My interest in your excellent May 8 editorial "Operation Abolition" arises from interest in college students and in the impression deliberately fostered by the film that their protest against the House Committee on Un-American Activities was a direct or indirect result of Communist conspiracy and agitation.
The Commonwealth Edison Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the four and twelve months ended on April 30.
XENIA, Ohio, May 26 (UPI) -- American Legion officials called off a Memorial Day parade last night because of a controversy over alleged segregation.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Harry Bright's bases-filled single in the sixth inning drove home the tying and winning runs tonight as the Washington Senators gained a 4-3 victory over the Minneapolis Twins.
Envious glances raked young Jake Gibbs last night in the Yankee locker room at the Stadium while the noveau riche third baseman climbed into pinstriped Yankee flannels for the first time.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 25 -- If the Government of Premier Ali Amini accomplishes no other reform, it has brought corruption into the open -- and Teheran is laughing at the exposure, perhaps to relieve the conscience of a capital suddenly found out.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 26 (UPI) -- Five Freedom Riders, including three white professors and the chaplain of Yale University, posted $1,000 cash bond each today and were released from county jail.
SEWANEE, Tenn., May 26 (AP) -- A Negro teacher has enrolled in the University of the South, the first time a member of his race has entered any department there other than the School of Theology.

TRENTON, May 26 -- A resourceful Wisconsin lawyer is marketing a "do-it-yourself-kit" at the New Jersey State prison here. The kit contains copies of Criminal Court decisions and appeal briefs all neatly indexed, as well as tips on how best to get a case back into court.

MONTGOMERY, Ala, May 26 (AP) -- Five white men were convicted in City Court today on charges growing out of last Saturday's violence, which erupted when a group of integrationists arrived at a bus station here.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Government moved in Federal Court today to force the Teamsters Union to open its headquarters financial records to inspection by the Labor Department.

President Kennedy's Foreign Aid message to Congress yesterday calls for drastic but long-needed changes in the organization and operation of this nation's efforts in the vital field of foreign economic policy. These changes would make our substantial foreign aid expenditures more useful to recipient nations and more effective in carrying out our own national interests.
SHIELDING children from the harshness of the world may stifle their creativity, according to a professor of design at the University of Michigan.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 7 points off to 3 points up yesterday. Only one contract rose. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
A local law requiring the licensing and regulating of coin-operated public laundries will go into effect today.
CHICAGO, May 26 (UPI) -- Harvey Kuenn's hit today scored two runs in the thirteenth inning as the league-leading San Francisco Giants gained a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
Unfavorable weather and an early Easter were responsible for declines in the sales and earnings of Sears, Roebuck Co. for the first quarter of this year.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Labor Department today called the law covering disclosure of pension and welfare funds "a cruel deception on everyone involved."

ALBANY, May 26 -- The Board of Regents today announced the scholastic standards to be met by college students in qualifying for tuition-aid grants under Governor Rockefeller's "scholar incentive" program.

The United Lutheran Church in America is developing a new gambit in evangelism.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- From a long list of suggested sites for a new jet airport for the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area the Federal Aviation Agency has found only three that would fit in readily with the region's air traffic.
WHITE PLAINS, May 26 -- The state's new home-rule law giving Mayors a short cut to charter revision was challenged in State Supreme Court here today.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee said today that it possessed a memorandum to Post Office Department officials that it interpreted as putting them on notice that all decisions were to be made with political favors in mind.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, in a broadcast to the world, today acknowledged the United States' imperfections in the area of equal rights for Negroes. He pleaded, however, for recognition of the progress that had been made and for an awareness that everything pointed to continuing progress.

Through intense effort and private generosity, a luminous architectural jewel of this region has now been preserved for the public. It is the gracious mansion called Boscobel, built in 1795-1804 at Crugers and now, after many vicissitudes, adorning a height on the east bank of the Hudson between Garrison and Cold Spring, fifteen miles from its original site.
Jimmy Demaret was named last night to replace Arnold Palmer on the United States team for the Canada Cup golf matches.
Joseph Beruh, who was once a towel boy for the University of Pittsburgh's football team, probably has more roles than anyone, on or off Broadway.

PARIS, May 26 (UPI) -- Darlene Hard of Montebello, Calif., and Maria Ester Bueno of Brazil advanced to the doubles final in the French tennis championship today. They defeated the Australian team of Jan Lehane and Leslie Turner, 5 -- 7, 7 -- 5, 7 -- 5.
DETROIT, May 26 (AP) -- The auto industry will close all but three of its assembly plants on Tuesday for Memorial Day.

The Big Seven women's colleges, widely and justly admired for their academic achievements and standards, this year again invoked their agreement of silence concerning the details of their admissions picture. All they are willing to tell the public is that, in filling their total of about 2,600 freshman places, they have sent out an undisclosed number of acceptances, rejections and waiting-list notifications.

ST. LOUIS, May 26 (AP) -- Ken Boyer hit two homers and drove in six runs as the St. Louis Cardinals routed the Pittsburgh Pirates, 12 -- 2 tonight. The Pirate infield committed six errors.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Republican Congressional leaders said today that the country was headed for a fiscal disaster of major proportions unless President Kennedy's spending programs were curbed.
CHARLESTON, S.C., May 26 (AP) -- Whites and Negroes played at Charleston's municipal golf course today without incident, the first such integration in South Carolina.

ALTHOUGH "Primitive Paradise," a color documentary of New Guinea tribesmen, is interesting enough on the whole, it is most captivating in the last reel when a swarming mass of natives puts on a song and dance fest. The swaying performers, resplendent in their bizarre, colorful attire, literally choke the screen with their rhythmic gyrations.

The New York Central Railroad reported yesterday an operating loss of $22,335,085 in the first four months this year. But one of its subsidiaries -- the Pittsburgh and Lake Erie Railroad -- chalked up a $1,079,088 net profit in the same period.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Italian National Committee for Nuclear Energy announced plans today to construct a plant in Southern Italy to reprocess reactor fuel elements taken from an atomic power plant at Elk River, Minn.
JACKSON, Miss., May 26 -- Twenty-seven "Freedom Riders" were found guilty today of ignoring a police officer's order to leave the white waiting room of a bus terminal here.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 26 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer scored a one-under-par 70 on the Speedway course today to take a one-stroke lead at the halfway stage of the 500 Festival open golf tournament.

ATLANTA, May 26 -- Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said key integrationist leaders were meeting here today and tomorrow to plan a resumption of Freedom Rides on a "large scale." At the same time, he said, he expects a temporary lull in the demonstrations.
NEW ORLEANS, May 26 (UPI) -- George Lincoln Rockwell and his "storm troopers" went on a hunger strike today in the parish (county) jail here to protest their arrest.

DALLAS, May 26 -- The South's traditional one-party system will undergo its most acute strain in years tomorrow as a million Texans vote to fill their United States Senate vacancy, possibly with the first Republican to hold the office since 1877.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Seven thousand Americans in 340 centers across the nation will take a five-and-one-half-hour examination tomorrow. It will be their first hurdle on the way to the Peace Corps.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Kennedy submitted to Congress today a plan to consolidate the principal foreign economic aid programs in a single agency within the State Department.
SEOUL, Korea, May 26 -- The United Nations military commander and the South Korean military junta patched up their eleven-day dispute today with a compromise.
Five Sanitation Department employes have been fined or reprimanded as a result of the unauthorized use of a city snowplow to clear a private parking lot last winter.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Representative William E. Miller of upstate New York was apparently assured tonight of election next week as chairman of the Republican National Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- House leaders tried to persuade a new subcommittee today to go about its business without fanfare. The subcommittee officially is studying whether an investigation of the Central Intelligence Agency is needed.

NEW DELHI, India, May 26 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru has written to the heads of government of the United States, Britain, West Germany, Canada and Japan seeking some commitment on the amount of economic assistance likely to be available to India during the next five years, informed sources said here today.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Kennedy's foreign-aid proposal, submitted to Congress today, was his forty-second request for legislation during 127 days in office.
ATLANTA, May 26 (UPI) -- A Negro student group that claims membership in every Negro and interracial college in the Southeast called on its members today to volunteer to become Freedom Riders.

HENDERSON, N.C., May 26 (UPI) -- The Textile Workers Union of America called an end today to a two-and-one-half-year strike against the Harriet-Henderson cotton mills.

The Seamen's Church Institute of New York, for more than 125 years one of the main centers of welfare activities for sailors visiting the port, is confronted by two problems.

DORIS MAYES, young Philadelphia mezzo-soprano who won the International Singing Competition in Toulouse, France, in 1958, and has been singing much of the time since then in Europe, made her New York recital debut in Carnegie Hall last night.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Republican Congressional leaders sharply attacked today the proposed tractors-for-prisoners exchange with Cuba and President Kennedy's support for it.
A fourteen-foot bronze statue of the Prophet Isaiah will be unveiled and dedicated at 11 A.M. tomorrow at the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street.
A rainstorm yesterday forced the postponement until this morning of the trials of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America outdoor track and field championships.

SEOUL, Korea, May 26 -- South Korea's military leader said today that if he had been invited to the White House he would have asked President Kennedy for additional and more effective economic aid to shorten the duration of military rule here.

Under pressure for four days, the stock market shook itself yesterday and moved upward, closing the week on a strong note. Volume remained low but was encouragingly higher in the final hours, when prices were rising.

The lawyer for one of two construction concerns blacklisted by the Board of Education charged yesterday that his client had been subjected to "discrimination and intimidation" by certain school officials and employes.

WALKER PERCY, a nephew of the late great William Alexander Percy, brings new lanterns to light the levees of the South. His first novel, "The Moviegoer,"* is a searching study of tradition embattled with change. That is usually a somewhat ponderous and perspiring confrontation, isn't it? Yet Mr. Percy stages it buoyantly without losing requisite force.
OTTAWA, May 26 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel left for Quebec today after two days of talks with Prime Minister John Diefenbaker.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Treasury bill rates pushed upward again today on the sale of next week's issues. It was the third consecutive increase.

The Federal school aid bill passed by the Senate is, in its main provisions, a good measure. It would provide $2.5 billion over a three-year period, administered by the respective states for school construction or teachers' salaries in whatever proportion the local needs may indicate. The measure has succeeded in avoiding entanglement with such extraneous issues as civil rights and support of non-public schools.

VIRTUALLY every snatch of conversation overheard on a commuter train coming in from Long Island last Monday morning had to do with outdoor cooking. Two men were arguing about whether steak should be salted before it goes on the outdoor grill.

WITH THE ROYAL ARMY, Near Padong, Laos, May 26 -- Heavy fighting raged today in the mountains near Padong as Leftist rebels pounded Government positions with an artillery bombardment for the third consecutive day.
UNITED NATIONS, May 26 -- The United Nations is planning to hold a world-wide conference next year to help economically backward countries accelerate their development scientifically.

PARIS, May 26 -- Europe has now had time to take stock of President Kennedy's foreign economic policy and the initial reaction is favorable. This policy shows no radical departure from that of President Eisenhower which itself developed logically from the Marshall Plan.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The American Bankers Association opposed today income tax withholding on interest and dividends, but some bankers dissented and urged adoption of President Kennedy's plan.
The New York Americans, the leaders in the International Soccer League, meet Dynamo of Rumania in the first game of a league double-header at the Polo Grounds this afternoon at 2:30.
MAHWAH, N.J., May 26 -- Ten commuter buses equipped with rest rooms were put into service today by the Hudson Transit Lines, Inc.

F. Schumacher Co., manufacturer of decorative fabrics has leased 19,000 square feet of space for a showroom at 201 East Fifty-sixth Street. The space, which also will front on Third Avenue, is in the store and apartment building that was completed recently by the 5 Third Corporation, Francis J. Kleban, president. Bertram Liberman, vice president of Herbert Charles Co., was the broker.

PATCHOGUE, L.I. May 26 -- A woman drowned this afternoon when a twenty-eight-foot cruiser sank in Great South Bay near here. Two other persons suffered from exposure from an hour in the storm-swept water.

A new Italian Ambassador is always an interesting addition to Washington's diplomatic corps. The millions of Americans of Italian descent, the close ties between our two countries, the cultural impact of Italy, and our harmonious international relations all give meaning and emphasis to an Italo-American event of this nature. There is an added note this year, which is the first centenary of Italian unity and independence.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 26 -- An unusual opinion that defines for the first time the obligations and responsibilities of bankers and fiduciaries to open-end investment com panies was handed down here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The index of average Wholesale primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent to 118.9 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
The on-again-off-again merger of the Universal Match Corporation and Universal Controls, Inc., is off again -- for the third time in four months.

Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, is not the only Wall Streeter alarmed at the public's speculative fever. Most big brokerage concerns are becoming just as upset at the get-rich attitude of many uninformed customers.

Six timber-toppers representing five betting interests are entered in today's three-mile Connecticut Cup. This is the feature event on the seven-race program of the one-day Adjacent Hunts meeting in Purchase, N.Y.

LONDON, May 26 -- Most sections of the stock market, except South African gold-mining shares, had a tired look about them today. In the industrial section share prices continued to drift lower in the face of small but steady profit taking.

A robber who squeezed at least one victim into unconsciousness told Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz to "drop dead" yesterday after the judge had sentenced him to a prison term of up to twenty-five years.

At The Jewish Daily Forward building on the lower East Side a "lekach-bromfen" (cake-and- drink party) will be held Wednesday for Alexander Kahn, the paper's general manager.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Government applied new pressure today to reduce mortgage interest rates.

M. Also under way this week-end and throughout the coming week is the Pacific Coast's largest regional tournament, Bridge Week, in Los Angeles.

NUERBURGRING, Germany, May 27 -- The Cooper-Climax in which Jack Brabham will attempt to win the 500-mile automobile race at Indianapolis on Tuesday is basically the same machine he drove to two straight world championships in Grand Prix racing in Europe and the United States.

Kayden, professor emeritus at the University of the South, said today that he was "not a candidate" for an honorary degree in the same ceremony at which Thomas Waring, a stanch segregationist and editor of The Charleston (S.C.) News and Courier, is to be honored.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, May 22 -- On Zagreb's Republic Square, just below the old Austrian Empire buildings on Kaptol Hill, stands a new fourteen-story glass and steel "skyscraper."
