THE propaganda problems and capabilities of the United States were discussed last night in a stimulating and informative hour on Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's program, "Prospects of Mankind," over Channel 5.
BALTIMORE, May 28 (AP) -- Don Schwall, a rookie for the Boston Red Sox, pitched a seven-hitter in beating the Orioles, 5 -- 0, today. The loss snapped a five-game Baltimore winning streak.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 28 -- Brazil's success in obtaining $2,000,000,000 in United States and Western European credits and debt deferments is being matched in newspaper headlines here by spectacular reports of trade negotiations with the Communist bloc.
SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., May 28 -- Samuel Reshevsky took on forty-three chess players here today and sent them all fleeing for cover.

BRESCIA, Italy, May 28 (AP) --Gunnar Andersson and Charlie Lohmander, a Swedish driving team with a powerful Ferrari that they bought three days ago, today won the Mille Miglia -- the 1,000-mile Italian road race.

Now after desolate years, a once-sumptuous mansion here that is the only home that New York's statesman Alexander Hamilton ever built, may be removed to a spacious site, restored and preserved. The Federal departments most concerned, Interior and the Budget Bureau, have advised Congress of their support of such a step, according to New York's Senator Javits, long Hamilton Grange's champion.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Soviet Union is conducting extensive reconnaissance-mapping flights of the northern borders of Pakistan and Kashmir, diplomatic sources said today.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Weather Bureau plans to have its first hurricane hunter in space this summer -- a weather satellite capable of photographing the life of a tropical storm from birth to its destructive death.

WASHINGTON, D.C., May 28 (UPI) -- Representative Herbert Zelenko, Democrat of New York, announced today that he was introducing a bill to make it a Federal crime to fix or rig any amateur or professional athletic contest.

A monument to the memory of Frederick Douglass, a Negro slave who achieved fame as an orator, abolitionist and statesman, was unveiled yesterday in an integrated Staten Island cemetery bearing his name.
LOS ANGELES, May 28 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers rallied and ended a three-game losing streak by defeating the Los Angeles Angels, 9 -- 4, today.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 28 (Reuters) -- Two former directors of Iran's Fisheries Department have been arrested on charges of corruption and misuse of Government funds, it was announced here today.
A pacifist group that plans to agitate for disarmament in Moscow as well as in the United States arrived here yesterday after a cross-country walk from California.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 28 -- Jim Meehan sailed Kittiwake to a pair of victories today and won the Lightning Class honors in the annual Tri Club regatta. The three-race week-end event was conducted by the Huntington Yacht Club in Huntington Bay.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Representative Thor C. Tollefson, Republican of Washington, wrote President Kennedy and the Department of State yesterday that, unless the Gov ernment came to its aid, the copper smelting and refining industry might fold up.
PARIS, May 28 (Reuters) -- The Orient Express is no more.

CINCINNATI, May 28 (AP) -- Vada Pinson's two home runs and alert fielding helped Bob Purkey over some rough spots and led the Cincinnati Reds to a 4-2 victory over Philadelphia today. It was the eighth straight Red triumph over the Phils this season.

The no-strike pledge at missile bases is a much-needed assumption of responsibility by labor and management in an area vital to the national defense. It is too bad that it came only after revelations of unconscionable delays and waste had created the certainty of a Congressional crackdown if no corrective action were taken.

CLEVELAND, May 28 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Indians and Kansas City Athletics hit ten home runs as they split a double-header today. The Indians took the first game, 9 -- 1, and dropped the second, 8 -- A.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- To counter communism, the West must "whole-heartedly identify itself with the will for development" in emerging nations, the National Planning Association said in a study released today.
The American League set a major-league record for home runs in one day yesterday when twenty-seven were hit in seven games.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Following is the text of a statement by President Kennedy today on the special mission by Adlai E. Stevenson to Latin America:
A group of New York clergymen endorsed yesterday efforts of the Tractors for Freedom Committee to ransom the Cubans captured during the unsuccessful April 17 invasion of Cuba.
The Board of Higher Education will start work soon on a master plan for a vast expansion of the City University.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Radar measurements by a space tracking station in California's Mohave Desert indicate that the planet Venus is rotating slowly, probably only once in its trip around the sun.

LONDON, May 28 (AP) -- A Parliamentary storm burst around the head of Prime Minister Macmillan today over charges that United States Navy secret documents had vanished strangely while on loan to the British Admiralty.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 28 (AP) -- Doug Ford shot a 12-foot birdie putt on the second hole of a sudden-death play-off with Arnold Palmer today and captured the 500 Festival open golf tournament.
Trading in cotton futures last week was dull.
Laurian Cardinal Rugambwa yesterday became the first Negro Cardinal to preside at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Jewish Orthodox spiritual leader, appealed yesterday to Israel to adopt a code of laws based on the fundamental precepts of the Talmud.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Navy has planned a ten-year program costing more than $900,000,000 to multiply its efforts in oceanographic research.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Inter-American Development Bank announced today approval of a $250,000 loan to help finance the expansion of an agricultural colony in Paraguay.

A NEW movie theatre and an old film having its first presentation in New York were launched yesterday with the opening of the Carnegie Hall Cinema. A fair guess is that the theatre -- an attractive 300-seat affair in what used to be the Playhouse, in the basement of Carnegie Hall -- will last much longer than the picture, and deservedly.
LONDON, May 28 -- The London Daily Mail, which last week quoted Polish emigre sources as having said that "the head of Polish intelligence" had fled to the West, named the defector today.

CAPE CANAVERAL, May 28 (UPI) -- A photographers' union said today it had asked President Kennedy for Federal help in settling a labor dispute that threatened to touch off a strike at the missile firing center here.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI) -- The Flight Engineers Union has lost a round in its jurisdictional fight with the Airline Pilots Association.
DALLAS, May 28 -- John G. Tower, a Republican, has nosed out Senator William A. Blakley, the Democratic interim appointee, for a Texas seat in the United States Senate.
PARIS, May 28 (AP) -- A former commander of North Atlantic alliance forces in Central Europe and a former Chief of Staff of the French Army go on trial tomorrow accused of treason.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. announced yesterday that he planned to hold a public hearing here this week in his inquiry into alleged racial discrimination by both labor and management in New York and elsewhere.

CHICAGO, May 28 (AP) -Extra-base pinch hits by Eddie Bressoud and Joe Amalfitano with two out in the ninth inning enabled the league-leading San Francisco Giants to beat the slumping Cubs, 6 -- 5, today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Some of us who believe in the elimination of the entertainment deduction had anticipated a slight difficulty in proving how completely it was supporting the carriage trade, night club world. Mr. Sardi has now removed that difficulty, as reported by you on May 20.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, May 28 -- Relations between Pakistan and Afghanistan appear to have reached a new low, and no relief is in sight.
Suddenly there is a demand for quadrilingual hotel clerks, trilingual bellhops and a bilingual doorman who is at least six feet four inches tall.

A Protestant Episcopal priest expressed disagreement yesterday with the so-called Blake plan for unifying four Protestant denominations, saying that the supporters of the plan "would have us minimize our theology of the church."

MILWAUKEE, May 28 (AP) -- Dick Farrell pitched six innings of scoreless relief ball as the Los Angeles Dodgers registered a 4-3 victory over the Milwaukee Braves today. It was the Dodgers' only triumph in the three-game series.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., May 28 -- The Thomas School of Horsemanship's gray mare Peppermint of Huntington, L.I., ridden by Susan Jolly, won a jump-off for the jumper championship today in the Brookville Junior Horse Show at the Brookville Boarding Stable.

MEXICO CITY, May 28 -- Rightist organizations have requested the Mexican Government to investigate growing rumors pertaining to the activities of Gen. Lazaro Cardenas in the State of Yucatan. General Cardenas, a former President of Mexico, is a supporter of the Castro regime in Cuba.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Two Air Force stewards visited the White House the other day and conferred with Rene Verdon, President Kennedy's new French chef.

The newly-opened "Donnybrook!" marked the emergence of Jack Cole as a choreographer-director. He will continue in that double category with "Kean," in which Alfred Drake will impersonate the famous British star, Edmund Kean.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 28 -- The second of the two men accused of abducting, raping and killing two prominent women here last Friday has confessed his part in the crime, according to the police.

JACKSON, Miss., May 28 -- New waves of Freedom Riders descended on Southern bus terminals today in their campaign against segregated facilities. They met arrest as expected in Mississippi but no resistance in Alabama.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., May 28 -- In worship and rest, President Kennedy gathered strength today for a taxing week.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI) -- A Federal Trade Commission examiner has ruled that a television commercial showing the shaving of sandpaper is harmless exaggeration.
GENEVA, May 28 -- The United States has undertaken new measures designed to impede Communist infiltration from Laos into South Vietnam and Thailand.
The Yankees and White Sox regaled a gathering of 44,435 at the Stadium yesterday by belting each other from foul post to foul post.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 28 -- Adolf Eichmann's defense lawyer complained today that the former Nazi's trial was moving at excessive speed.

Fordyce Hamby Associates, architects, have leased about 4,000 square feet in the Corning Glass Building, 717 Fifth Avenue, at Fifty-sixth Street. They specialize in industrial, commercial, school and hospital designing and are expanding their quarters. Hans Dambach of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agent for the building, was the broker.
About 1,000 policemen will guard President Kennedy on his six-hour visit here toworrow.
New York racing will be stuffed with money today. The $25,000-added Juvenile Stakes will be run at Aqueduct, followed by the $25,000 Vanguard free-for-all trot at Roosevelt Raceway at night.
Usually there is no quieter spot in New York than Wall Street on a Sunday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas said today America at last was entering the ideological race after fifteen years during which two Presidents "taught us to find security in arms, not in ideas."
The Transportation Association of America has announced its opposition to any moratoriurn on transportation mergers.

JASHIMPUR, described as one of the smallest and most backward of India's princely states, is remote, isolated and surrounded by high mountains. Much smaller than Kashmir but just as beautiful, Jashimpur has been conquered so many times that its population -- 60 per cent Moslem, 40 per cent Hindu -- has been accustomed for thousands of years to the rule of tyrants, to abject poverty and to slavish humility.

The proposed merger of the Penn Fruit Company, Inc., and the ACF-Wrigley Stores, Inc., may be opposed by a substantial number of Penn Fruit stockholders unless some details of the transaction are satisfactorily explained, according to a statement made over the weekend by John Lamula, president of John Lamula Investors, Inc., Newton, Conn.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- President Kennedy announced today that Adlai E. Stevenson would leave soon on a three-week tour of South America. Mr. Stevenson's "special mis sion" is evidence of increased Administration efforts to promote hemispheric unity,weakened as a result of differences over developments in Cuba.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 28 -- There are three prime requisites for winning the 500-mile race on the Indianapolis Motor Speedway -- a skilled and courageous driver, a solid, well-set-up car and a bundle of luck.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

LINDEN, N.J., May 28 -- Ch. Gay Boy of Geddesburg, a peppy beagle, proved today to his new owners, Mr. and Mrs. Willard K. Denton of Mount Kisco, N.Y., that they made a wise purchase when they acquired him six weeks ago.
The city shook off the raindrops yesterday and enjoyed a sunny second day of a pre-holiday week-end.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 28 -- Commodore James B. Moore Jr. sailed Lure to a convincing Reslute Class victory in today's interclub event on Manhasset Bay. Saturday's scheduled opener was canceled because of high winds and rain.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Red Cross announced today that it would build a laboratory for blood research at Bellevue Hospital in New York.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $80,931,722,545. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:
A program to provide scholarships for African students at 150 of the nation's leading colleges and universities was announced yesterday.
Scenes from "All the Way Home," the Pulitzer Prize-winning play that has met with artistic acclaim and box-office indifference, will be televised Sunday evening on "The Ed Sullivan Show."

CHATHAM, Ont., May 28 (Canadian Press) -- Union Gas Company of Canada, Ltd., cleared $3,916,469, or 72 cents a common share after payment of preference dividends, in the year ended on March 31, compared with $3,032,049, or 58 cents, in the preceding year.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI) -- The Senators swept their three-game series with the Minnesota Twins today, gaining a 6-4 victory before a crowd of 18,882.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Republican leadership of the House and Senate expressed a wish today for success in President Kennedy's coming meeting with Premier Khrushchev, but at the same time was pessimistic about the prospects for the talks.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- With a vacancy on the seven-man board of governors of the Federal Reserve System imminent, the Administration plans to fill it with somebody from the Midwest who is young and sympathetic to President Kennedy's views.
The facades and interior walls of numerous new office buildings, hotels, churches and synagogues are today being decorated with mosaics, an art so ancient that its origins are lost in antiquity.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency said today that the joint use of long-range radar by the F.A.A. and the Air Force had saved the Government more than $15,000,000 in equipment costs since 1957.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has been asked to withdraw a registration statement covering 190,000 shares of common stock of the Burgmaster Corporation that were publicly offered at $12 a share on May 15 and that subsequently rose to above $20 a share.
Dr. John J. Theobald may cut short a European trip because of disclosures of alleged irregullarities in school construction here.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, May 28 -- Duncan Sandys, British Secretary of State for Commonwealth Relations, was mobbed by African nationalist demonstrators on his drive from the airport here today.
At Washington Square yesterday the fine arts, folk singing and sunshine teamed up to pack the park and its environs.
FRANKFURT, Germany, May 26 -- The United States Government, without telling anyone, has gone into the foreign exchange business.

"The Cow and I," a French comedy starring Fernandel, will have its American premiere at the Fine Arts Theatre next Monday. Henri Verneuil directed the import, which is being presented by Zenith International.
City Republican leaders were reported yesterday to have selected State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz as their candidate for Mayor.
Organized labor is undertaking a national program of consumer education to teach its members how to get more for their wage dollars.
LOS ANGELES, May 27 -- A prominent medical researcher said today that the Air Pollution Control District was doing all it could within a limited budget to combat smog in Los Angeles.

A man wounded by a police bullet was captured with two companions after a chase yesterday afternoon on the Lower East Side. The wounded man was chased in and out of a subway station and along a couple of blocks before he was finally caught.

ST. LOUIS, May 28 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Cardinals, scoring six runs off Harvey Haddix in the first inning, defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 8 -- 4, today. The loss was the first for Haddix after three victories.

La Vern Baker, a reformed rock 'n' roll singer, is helping Louis Armstrong jazz things up at Basin Street East. Miss Baker, who is making her first major night-club appearance, having served an apprenticeship in concert and dance halls and movie-vaudeville houses here and abroad, now concentrates on jazz and blues.

CHICAGO, May 28 (AP) -- The feed grains mustered a few flurries of firmness on the Board of Trade last week but the over-all sentiment was bearish all around and prices maintained a generally steady decline.

The Natus Corporation has acquired 98 per cent of the outstanding stock of the Kirkeby Corporation through an exchange of 1,088,463 of its shares for 32,105 shares of Kirkeby, according to an announcement made over the week-end.
RYE, N.Y., May 28 -- Hotel and Allegra scored today in the second phase of the American Yacht Club's three-part Memorial Day week-end regatta on Long Island Sound.

DURBAN, South Africa, May 28 (Reuters) -- Violence flared in South Africa tonight as the country stood mobilized for possible trouble tomorrow when nonwhites are scheduled to start a three-day strike. The strike will counter the proclamation Wednesday of the Republic of South Africa the country's leaving the British Commonwealth.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., May 28 -- In a picnic-like atmosphere of sand, sea and young women who watched the proceedings in toreador pants, Walt Hansgen won two of three national championship sports-car races today.

UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., May 28 -- After nine years in the building, northern Colombia's new Atlantic railroad will begin to carry freight this summer from Santa Marta on the Caribbean Sea to Salgar in the central part of the country. Its construction has involved the conquest of an almost impassable jungle, interspersed with treacherous swamps.
The nation's major stock exchanges will be closed today to give some brokerage houses time to catch up on work and also to provide for a four-day week-end with the memorial Day holiday tomorrow.
The city gained 19,053 dwelling units in 1960, the Department of City Planning reported yesterday.

The matter of television programing, a sensitive subject at the moment, is the concern of a memorandum now being circulated to the staff of Foote, Cone Belding, Inc., by Fairfax M. Cone, chairman of the executive committee.
SALT LAKE CITY, May 28 A series of mysterious explosions shattered three unattended telephone microwave and cable relay stations in western Utah today.
Which Oscar Brand do you like? In two concerts Saturday at Town Hall, the folk singer trotted out a whole catalogue of personalities.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your May 23 editorial "Alabama and the Cold War" you assert that the power, force and direction of the United States Government are aimed at carrying out the Constitution. In your editorial "Straightforward School Aid," on the same day, you call for a simple basic school-aid bill which is aimed at giving Federal aid to schools whether segregated or not.

As the scene of the vital battle for Federal aid to the public schools shifts to the House, there are disturbing indications that attempts will be made to entangle the measure in the controversy over aid to nonpublic schools. The Senate skillfully avoided this course, which would have endangered all school-aid legislation.
William Lombardy of New York took the lead in the international chess masters tournament at the Congress House in Zurich, last night, according to a report from Switzerland. His score is 2 -- 0.
KINGSPORT, Tenn., May 28 (AP) -- Dr. Charles Zucker, 35-year-old New York nuclear physicist, was killed near here early today in an automobile crash.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 28 -- Big and powerful Barlovento II emerged from a bitter brew of high winds, heavy rain and winter-in-springtime cold to win the Storm Trysail Club 200-mile yacht race around Block Island today.

PITTSBURGH, May 28 -- The momentum of the recent recovery in steel is expected to carry over into June -- and may go as far as early July before there is any significant leveling off, according to opinion in this steel center.

MADRID, May 28 (UPI) -- A high Spanish official has lost his job because he allowed a "highly immoral" movie to be sent to the Cannes Film Festival, where it shared first prize, informed sources said last night.

In chess, a cardinal rule is: never concentrate an attack on a movable piece. By the time the attack is completed, the piece may have been moved away and the attack will result only in a waste of moves and time. However, the New Jersey Legislature seems to have ignored the application of this rule in approving Gov. Robert B. Meyner's "commuter-benefit tax."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Wise as some of the President's proposals for changes in the tax laws are, one seems indefensible. This is his request for repeal of the recent provisions which give the income taxpayer a credit, against his tax, of a small portion of the dividends on which the tax would otherwise be computed.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 28 (AP) -- A leading educator challenged today the idea that the Soviet Union was ahead in space technology because it had better-educated scientists and engineers.

The election of Robert G. Tabors as president and chief executive officer and a director of Textron Electronics, Inc., was announced over the week-end. Royal Little has relinquished these offices but continues as a director of the company and chairman of the executive committee of Textron, Inc., the parent concern.
FOREST PARK, Pa., May 28 -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg today urged Americans to show the world with action that the nation intended freedom for all citizens.

Borough President Edward R. Dudley of Manhattan urged Civil Service workers in minority groups yesterday to realize that they would be judged on their merit and not by "the artificial barriers of race and religion."
The New York Americans and Bangu of Brazil scored easy triumphs yesterday in the International Soccer League double-header at the Polo Grounds.
JURUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 29 -- The Chief Rabbinate of Israel declared tonight that it would not stand in the way of a census that was begun in the country last Monday.

DALLAS, May 28 -- "My name is Tower -- but you can see that I don't." That is John Goodwin Tower's favorite ice-breaker with political crowds. It always gets a laugh because, by the greatest stretch of the facts, or of Mr. Tower, he stands a short 5-feet-6.
GREAT NECK, L.I., May 28 -- The bridge tables hummed and the coffee pot burbled merrily today in one of the more exclusive clubs in this community of expensive homes and high-style shops.
LONDON, May 28 -- Prices fluctuated within a relatively narrow range on the stock market last week with the trend, such as it was, in a downward direction.

President Kennedy intended, at the beginning of his term, to stay in Washington as much as possible. Tomorrow he embarks on a crucial journey to confer with the leaders of our two principal allies, President de Gaulle and Prime Minister Macmillan, and to confront our principal adversary, Premier Khrushchev.
SEOUL, Korea, May 28 -- The South Korean military junta outlawed 834 newspapers and news agencies today and arrested twenty-five business men, former military officers and Government officials.

Most taxpayers have received their 1960 income tax refunds. This is the word from both the Federal and the New York State governments. State Tax Commissioner Joseph H. Murphy has relatively more checks yet to mail than the Federal Government.
Leading maritime unions appear to be hampered by disunity in approaching their forthcoming negotiations with ship operators. But the tactical weakness is more apparent than real.
Trading in the over-the-counter market last week was the lightest in more than two weeks. Prices generally declined in the middle of the week but rebounded sharply in the last two days of trading.

NUERBURGRING, Germany, May 28 -- Flawless driving by Masten Gregory, competent help by Lucky Casner and bad luck for everybody else resulted in a Maserati triumph in the 1,000-kilometer (622-mile) sports car race today.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Senator Thruston B. Morton, retiring Republican National Chairman, said today that John G. Tower's "apparent smashing victory" in the Texas Senatorial race "not only signals a new era in Texas politics, but a rebirth of Republicanism in the Solid South."
THE Eastern States Championships, being played at the Statler-Hilton Hotel, entered their third day yesterday with 276 pairs entered in the two-session contest for mixed pairs.
JIM GENTILE can't wait for the day when the historians will stop repeating the canard that he was an utter failure during his eight years as a member of the Dodger organization.
The first step in the razing of an unusual tariff wall within the United States was taken last week by the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries.
More than 400,000 square feet of industrial space has been leased in less than six months in the Elizabeth Industrial Park on Trumbull Street in Elizabeth, N.J.

The Columbia University School of International Affairs and Regional Institutes will become a separate faculty of the university on July 1, Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia, announced yesterday.
Paul O'Dwyer, candidate for the Democratic nomination for City Controller, urged yesterday that city pension funds be used to combat racial discrimination in housing loans.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 28 -- The Kennedy Administration's policy of helping only those nations willing and able to help themselves is confronted with an uncomfortable dilemma in Haiti.
John Bowes led Fordham Prep to the team title yesterday in the Fordham University interscholastic tennis championships at the Rose Hill courts, the Bronx.

PARIS, May 28 -- The evident purpose of President Kennedy's talks with General de Gaulle is to bridge the existing lacuna in Franco-American policies. And, despite the traditional friendship of our countries, this is far from easy. In fact it is the most difficult negotiation Kennedy has so far faced.
MIAMI, May 28 -- Anti-Castro Cuban forces are going through a crisis that threatens to leave them completely disorganized.

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh announced yesterday the names of twenty men who will receive medals for heroism. The medals, which cite deeds in 1960, will be presented by Mayor Wagner at the Firemen's Monument, Riverside Drive at 100th Street, on June 6.

MODESTO, Calif., May 28 (UPI) -- Ralph Boston, the Tennessee State athlete who cracked the 27-foot barrier in the broad jump last night, said today that he could see no limit to the distance that jumpers could go.
Education is still a major part of the mutual funds' selling job.
Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel hailed the United States yesterday for "leadership in the family of freedom."

PROMINENTLY displayed, the seasonally abundant eggplant is lending an exotic but low-cost air to local fruit stands. Despite its boldly colored exterior, however, the inner eggplant is a shy-flavored vegetable. For this reason it makes an excellent ingredient in a wide variety of casseroles.

LOS ANGELES, May 28 -- The University of California at Los Angeles, which has been the scene of some of the most exciting professional dramatic productions in this area, will be host this week to what is probably the most important international music festival to be held in this part of the country.

The Rev. Dr. James H. Robinson, for twenty-three years pastor of the Presbyterian Church of the Master in Harlem, announced his resignation yesterday to devote full time to student work programs in Africa.

TO see one's name emblazoned in letters one-eighth of an inch high on a book jacket less than five years after graduation seems like the answer to a college maiden's prayer. To most young women emerging from their ivory towers next month, clutching their sheepskins and with hazy notions of "doing something creative," the freelance author and illustrator are objects worthy of emulation.
HOBOKEN, May 28 (AP) -- Local 1 of the International Longshoremen's Association urged the New Jersey Legislature today to take steps to terminate the bi-state Waterfront Commission.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am puzzled by that sentence in your editorial of May 17 on wiretapping which reads: "Experience with state tapping unhappily indicates that Federal rules are urgently needed."
TOKYO, May 28 (UPI) -- Premier Hayato Ikeda, who will leave for his first official visit to Washington in mid-June, is encountering several problems as he prepares for the trip.

NYACK, N.Y., May 28 -- Seven yachts were capsized and one dismasted as thirty-mile-an-hour southwesterly winds marred today's races in the Nyack Boat Club's spring regatta on the Hudson River. Yesterday's program was canceled because of high winds and rain.

"Hedda Gabler" and "The Blacks" each received three Obie awards for achievement in the off-Broadway theatre at the sixth annual presentation on Saturday at the Village Gate, 185 Thompson Street. Obie is the phonetic abbreviation of Off Broadway.

NEW HAVEN, May 28 -- The chaplain of Yale University said today that the Attorney General's office had tried to dissuade him and four fellow "Freedom Riders" from embarking on their trip to test bus segregation in the South.
Before John G. Tower's election, Texas had only two Republican Senators in its history. The last, Morgan C. Hamilton, gave up his seat in 1877.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 28 -- Turkey's new Constitution is designed to forestall any attempt to establish a dictatorship in the future.

SEOUL, Tuesday, May 30 (AP) -- South Korea's military Government is scheduled to make a final study today or tomorrow of a new provisional Constitution to replace the present supreme law, informed sources said today.

The steel picture continued to brighten last week as the industry's operating rate edged up from 70 per cent to 71 per cent of capacity. According to figures released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute, the nation's steel mills turned out 2,077,000 tons of raw steel, compared with 2,037,000 tons a week earlier.
A malpractice verdict totaling $130,866.52 against a Bronx physician was returned yesterday by a Supreme Court jury sitting before Justice William Lyman.

The public testimony given recently by migrant workers about conditions they suffered on farms in New York, New Jersey and Virginia repeat an oft-told tale: shockingly low wages (with deductions that leave little in cash) and deplorable living quarters. But the moral of that tale has seldom been so clear. Adequate protection from exploitation and the hazards in employment, which is the migrant workers' due, can come only through Federal legislation.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 29 -- Huntington High School will hold its 100th graduation ceremony next month and believes it will be the first public high school centennial in the state.
PURCHASE, N.Y., May 29 -- The fiftieth anniversary fund of Connecticut College in New London will benefit from a tour of three homes here and two in Rye that will be held June 6 from 1 to 5 P.M.
Representative Paul A. Fino announced yesterday his willingness to run for President of the City Council this far on the Republican ticket.
BOSTON, May 29 -- Donald B. Hurwitz, executive director of the Federation of Jewish Agencies of Philadelphia, was elected president today of the National Conference of Jewish Communal Service.
Ten public high school students in New York City yesterday were named winners of the Seventy-second annual Pulitzer Scholarships.

EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, May 29 -- Belkacem Krim, head of the Algerian nationalist delegation at the peace talks here was reported to have asked the French today for "neutral supervision" of a self-determination referendum in Algeria.
PARIS, May 29 -- The United States, Britain and the six-nation European Common Market agreed today to start bargaining tomorrow for what could be an important reduction in world tariffs.
A court ruling yesterday reversed the convictions of fifty owners of coin-operated laundries who had been found guilty of violating the Sunday closing law.

President Kennedy will have a busy week. He will be in New York today and in Paris tomorrow, Thursday and Friday, and then will go to Vienna for his meeting with Premier Khrushchev on Saturday and Sunday.
Jose Rigores, a Cuban boxer, was in critical condition at Roosevelt Hospital early this morning after suffering a brain injury in a preliminary bout last night at St. Nicholas Arena.

IN THE tourist boom of recent years, reams of fashion advice have been offered to prospective travelers by airlines, steamship companies, newspaper and magazine writers and book publishers. Despite the quantity of the information, many travelers have come to rely on their own experiences and thereby have become authorities in their own right.
LONDON, May 29 -- Prime Minister Macmillan stressed today the need for maximum unity in Europe "and beyond."
The Brown University Club here will move into its new quarters in the Columbia University Club at 4 West Forty-third Street on Thursday.

The Lanrich Realty Corporation has bought the six-story building containing forty apartments and six stores at 3804 Greystone Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. The building, on a plot 100 by 100 feet, was purchased for cash above mortgages totaling $234,978 from Irving Neiditch, who had made a contract to buy the property from 3804 Greystone, Inc. Frederick Pirk Jr. was the broker in the deal.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Tuesday, May 30 -- Martial law ended at midnight last night and National Guardsmen were withdrawn from here.

FUTURISM, Italy's major contribution to modern art, which soared and crashed like a rocket in Europe between 1910 and 1915, was the twentieth century's most violent assault so far on the conventions of life and art.
Treasury bills firmed yesterday. Otherwise, the markets for fixed-interest securities either were closed or operated under semi-holiday conditions.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The House Appropriations Committee agreed with President Kennedy today that the propaganda duel with the Soviet Union in Latin America and Africa should be stepped up, but with less money than the President had asked.
SEOUL, Korea, May 29 -- South Korea's military regime disclosed today that it was considering a "partial suspension" of the Constitution.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Neither the Council of Economic Advisers nor anyone else has estimated that the gross national product will rise to an annual rate of $550,000,000,000 in the final quarter of this year.

Joseph P. McMurray, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, has named a twelve-man "task force" -- including two savings bankers -- to advise the agency on problems facing it, the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation and the Federal Home Loan Bank System.

The Hughes Tool Company is dissatisfied with some of the actions of the trustees empowered to vote its controlling stock interest in Trans World Airlines. The complaint of Hughes Tool, which is owned by Howard Hughes, came to light in a T.W.A. prospectus dated May 25, covering the issuance of $111,000,000 of debt certificates.

PATERSON, N.J., May 29 -- Jose A. Plaza, 42-year-old ex-convict described by the police as one of the largest heroin suppliers in northern New Jersey, was held in $50.000 bail today when he was arraigned on charges of possessing heroin and selling narcotics to minors.

VIENNA, May 29 -- The faculties and students of Austria's fourteen universities, engineering colleges, and music and art academies began a week's strike today in protest against the Government's decision to reduce the educational budget.
ISFAHAN, Iran, May 26 -- Premier Ali Amini's land reform promises have won him considerable popular support in southern Iran.
Five adjourned games were completed yesterday in the international chess masters tournament in Zurich, according to a report from Switzerland.

Four of the nineteen films shown at Boston's first international film festival last week have received citations and commendations for general excellence, the festivals director, George Papaodopoulo, announced yesterday.
GENEVA, May 29 -- The West proposed today to reduce by as many as eight the number of annual inspections that would be carried out in the Soviet Union under the projected ban on nuclear testing.

IN an angry world, the mild bluebird has many admirers, excepting a recent column about the social status of the John Birch Society, nothing has brought so many letters to this desk as the gloomy comments about the decimation of the bluebird population, published in this column on May 5.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy moved today to wipe out racial segregation on interstate buses and in the terminals serving them.

" The Sound of Music" established a house record last week at London's Palace Theatre, where the Broadway hit opened May 18. The intake was 11,920 ($33,376}, according to word received yesterday by Richard Rodgers, who wrote the show with the late Oscar Hammerstein 2d and Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI) -- Vice President Johnson, through a sign-language interpreter, told a group of deaf students today they could help the cause of freedom by joining the Peace Corps.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Southern members of Congress today were reported seeking a Justice Department investigation of allegations that "someone" in the Government had threatened reprisals against cotton interests if they opposed the Administration's general farm bill.

LONDON, May 29 -- Europe is not very optimistic about President Kennedy's quick tour of the Continent. The general feeling in the Western capitals seems to be that he has taken on too much in too short a time.

Earnings of the International Harvester Company in its second fiscal quarter ended on April 30 were sharply higher than its first quarter, the company reported yesterday. It is a leading manufacture of trucks, farm and construction equipment.
LONDON, May 29 -- The Foreign Office announced today that the Earl of Home. British Foreign Secretary would visit the United States from June 13 to 16.

Sixty-five pacifists -- some of them "peace walkers" who plan to march to Moscow -- stood still for more than two hours at Madison Square Park yesterday afternoon in a silent demonstration for disarmament.

After their long, agonized, far-and-wide search for the best of all possible men to run for Mayor of New York, the Republican leaders are reported to have settled on State Attorney General Louis F. Lefkowitz. So they end up where they started, because he has been assumed from the beginning to be ready, willing and able if the lightning struck.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- President Kennedy has exercised his veto power for the first time.

New Jersey residents employed in New York were threatened yesterday with the loss of the income-tax concessions they had wrung from the New York Legislature earlier this year after a long and hard-fought battle.
LOS ANGELES, May 29 (AP) -- The University of California at Los Angeles said today a star guard on its basketball team had been approached by a contact man for gamblers.
PHILADELPHIA, May 29 -- Historic Old Christ Church contributed $1,000 today toward a building fund of the Mikveh Israel congregation.

The appointment of William H. Lawrence as political editor and staff member of the American Broadcasting Company's news bureau in Washington was announced yesterday. He resigned Friday as a member of the Washington bureau of The New York Times.

HARTFORD, May 29 (AP) -- Several public bequests are contained in the wills of Mrs. Eleanor L. Cunningham and Mrs. Helen T. Locke, both of Hartford. The wills were admitted to probate today by Judge James H. Kinsella.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
PARIS, May 29 -- The other night, outdoors in the centuries-old Roman arena at Nimes in southern France, a nearly full moon shone on a French opera company presenting "Carmen."

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. asked the Supreme Court today not to insist on a ten-year deadline for the company to dispose of its vast stockholdings in General Motors Corporation.
PARIS, May 29 -- Two unrepentant former generals of the French Army went on trial for their lives today for having led a military insurrection in Algiers last month.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 29 -- A threatened general strike of African workers failed to develop today on a nation-wide scale.

The New York Times is to be highly commended for the strong and uncompromising position that it has taken in opposing the erection of the Huntington Hartford restaurant in Central Park at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.
BOSTON, May 29 -- President Kennedy said tonight that he would meet Premier Khrushchev in the spirit of no equivocation and no retreat.
JERUSALEM (Israel Sector) May 29 -- Adolf Eichmann tried today to outstare a witness in court.

Private investors have overlooked the rehabilitation of the city's blighted areas as a possible source of major profit to themselves and to the community, according to a New York mortgage company executive.

Ken Boerg and John Moore of Fort Hamilton and Gene Campiglia of Newtown scored victories yesterday in the field-event portion of the Public Schools Athletic League city track and field championships at Randalls Island. The track events will be held tomorrow at the same site.
Raymond Burr, who had been threatening to quit his television role as Perry Mason, lawyer, won the biggest case of his career yesterday. He got a raise from the Columbia Broadcasting System.
White Protestantism has failed to face the challenge of racial violence in the South, according to the Rev. Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr, one of this country's leading theologians.

JACKSON, Miss., May 29 (AP) -- Municipal Judge James Spencer convicted seventeen more "Freedom Riders" today. He imposed on them $200 fines and sixty-day suspended jail sentences, the same penalties he imposed on twenty-seven others last week.
HONG KONG, May 29 -- Governor Sir Robert Black called on Hong Kong industrialists tonight to temper their stand on textile exports "with restraint and understanding of the problems of others."
ROCKVILLE, Md., May 29 (AP) -- Supreme Court justice William O. Douglas spoke in court today but from the other side of the bench.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Atomic Energy Commission moved today to stimulate the lagging nuclear power program. It cut the price of nuclear fuels as much as to 40 per cent.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 29 (AP) -- A former paratrooper testified today that he had asked three city policemen to stop a white mob from beating two Negroes and had been told to "get away from here."

TODAY is the kick-off for the summer season and, also, the graduation season. During the next four weeks, bright young things will be accepting diplomas and moving hopefully into higher education or the wide, wide world.

GENEVA, May 29 -- An attempt to reopen the international conference on Laos broke down today over the Soviet Union's refusal to implement what a United States source called "primary conditions of the conference."

South Korea's new military regime has taken a number of long-needed steps: rice has been distributed to the poor, farm debts have been canceled and full-time duty enforced among civil servants. There has been a stern crackdown on corruption and profiteering.

Red crepe poppies in lapel buttonholes, gleamingly scrubbed Boy Scouts, politicians speechifying in the spring sunshine, wreaths on graves, a languid holiday afternoon at home or at the beach -- the taste of Memorial Day.

Home building activity in the Midwest is lagging behind the rest of the economy, according to a quarterly survey by the Advance Mortgage Corporation of Detroit.
Alaska Airlines has proposed cutting air freight rates in and to Alaska.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 29 -- It was Su Mac Lad once again, this time in the season's fastest clocking and before the year's biggest turnout, tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. LAGRANGE, Ga., May 29 (AP) -- Three men were fined today for having tried to stir trouble over the passage of a freedom bus. Two others were transferred to a higher court or more serious charges.

Board of Education officials inspected two Brooklyn schools selected at random yesterday and were shocked and indignant at the conditions they discovered at both.
WELCH, W.Va., May 29 -- An unemployed coal miner, his wife and their thirteen children received $95 worth of food stamps from the Federal Government here today.

Memorial Day has grown from a local gesture of remembrance in the Deep South ninety-five years ago to a holiday observed in every section of the country. That first gesture took place not on May 30 but on April 26, 1866, and four states still observe Confederate Memorial Day in April.

THE interest of Bill Cox in sports has been deep and abiding. He made a brief foray into baseball as the owner of the Philadelphia Phillies and also had a fling in pro football. INDIANAPOLIS, May 29 -- The Indianapolis Motor Speedway ran its first 500-mile race fifty years ago tomorrow. With the exception of five years during World Wars I and II, there has been no interruption in the presentation of this world-famous sport spectacle.
ALBANY, May 29 -- A plan to buy a 220-acre Adirondack lake and 3,500 acres of land around it for a public campsite was announced today by the State Conservation Department.

IRVINGTON, N.J., May 29 -- When school closes for the summer, Marlin Brinser, music teacher at Irvington High School, will begin a trip to Europe with his wife, Jean. His hobby, importing violins, will pay for it.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Thousands of persons throughout Europe will pay homage tomorrow to men who lost their lives fighting for freedom. The scene will be European, but the men to be honored were Americans, and the occasion will be an American observance, Memorial Day.

STANTON, Del., May 29 -- A new track surface, developed after an extensive scientific study, was unveiled today as Delaware Park started its silver anniversary meeting before a turnout of 11,510.

MOSCOW, May 30 (UPI) -- The Soviet Academy of Medical Sciences elected Dr. Paul Dudley White of Boston, former President Dwight D. Eisenhower's heart specialist, today as its first American member.
The Slovak League of America called on President Kennedy and Congress yesterday to recognize "the right of the Slovak nation" to independence.
The women volunteer workers for the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center Development Fund will be guests for tea of Mrs. Sheldon Whitehouse tomorrow in her home at 1040 Fifth Avenue.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 30 (AP) -- Ruling that a merchant can serve the customers he sees fit, the Alabama Court of Appeals upheld today the conviction of twelve Negroes arrested in a series of sit-ins.
The Columbia Broadcasting System has demonstrated how to get a lot of mileage out of one show, once as a half hour and once as a full hour, yet without a rerun.

LISBON, Portugal, May 30 -- A jet airliner carrying sixty-two persons, ten of them children, crashed on a storm-buffeted Atlantic beach today minutes after take-off. Search patrols found charred wreckage and bodies but no signs of life.
ST. PAUL, May 27 -- The Minnesota Legislature has turned thumbs down on an iron ore mining industry proposal to write a tax equity guarantee for taconic processors into the state Constitution.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 30 (AP) -- Premier Ali Amini said today he wanted United States aid to help Iran through an economic crisis. The Premier said he expected the crisis to last six months.

A small house once occupied by a Civil War general in the hills of northwestern New Jersey burned down last week. This incident had little impact on most residents of the town, New Hampton, but it broke the hearts of forty Puerto Rican youths on the Lower East Side.
ATLANTA, May 30 -- The Southern Regional Council asserted today that whites must accept the changes demanded by the Freedom Riders to forestall the emergence of "real, genuine extremists."

RYE, N.Y., May 30 -- Pieces of Eight, built the year the Star Class was born fifty years ago, was accorded all the respect due a dowager today in the last of three regattas conducted by the American Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- Secretary of the Navy John D. Connally conferred with three top echelon admirals today in an apparent discussion of a successor to Admiral Arleigh A. Burke as Chief of Naval Operations.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds climbed into a tie with San Francisco for the National League lead today by beating the Giants twice, 7 -- 6 and 6 -- 4.
Doesn't anyone understand what is going on? The reason there is violence in parts of our benighted South is simply that there are many Americans who find the status quo intolerable.

The Riviera Congress Motor Inn, a motor hotel with 182 guest rooms that is nearing completion at Tenth Avenue and Forty-first Street, has been bought by a syndicate of investors for $3,200,000. It was sold by the Tenth Avenue Corporation, Irving Maidman, president.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (UPI) -- Young Art Mahaffey won his fourth in a row for Philadelphia with an 11-4 victory over Milwaukee today. The Braves took the opener with the double-header, 3 -- 1, behind Bob Buhl's four-hitter.
Three English secretaries who are to lend their Rolls-Royce accents to New York companies arrived here by air yesterday.
MINEOLA, L.I., May 30 -- The Nassau County Board of Supervisors has approved plans for three parks, including one on a ll7-acre site in Hicksville.
PARIS, May 30 -- President Kennedy will arrive tomorrow for a meeting with President de Gaulle that is expected to clarify their viewpoints but not resolve their differences.

Chilly temperatures and strong winds did not keep the faithful away from the annual Memorial Day concert by the Naumburg Symphony Orchestra on the Mall in Central Park last night. At least half the normal-sized audience turned up to sit huddled in sweaters, coats and an occasional blanket to hear a program led by Emerson Buckley, with Doris Yarick, soprano, as soloist.
MEXICO CITY, May 30 -- The position of Mexico toward the Cuban-United States dispute is coming under closer study here.

TUCSON, Ariz., May 30 (AP) -- Senator Barry Goldwater said today it was not Premier Fidel Castro but President Kennedy who had "blustered his way into a major blunder" in the tractor-prisoner trade deal.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- President Kennedy is expected to establish a special warfare unit at the Pentagon to handle a variety of unorthodox military operations, including guerrilla fighting.

KATONAH, N.Y., May 30 -- The Friends of the Katonah Public Library are sponsoring a benefit house tour featuring five contemporary homes on Saturday from 2 to 5 P.M. In case of rain the tour will be held on June 10. Tickets for the tour may be purchased at the library or from any of the committee members.

A $13,000,000 Air Force contract for installing and servicing equipment for re-entry vehicles (nose cones) at nine Atlas missile bases has been awarded to the General Electric Company. The contract covers work extending through 1962, according to a joint announcement by the company and the Air Force.

President Kennedy and Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel met yesterday for what was described officially as a "fruitful discussion of world problems." The meeting in the living room of President Kennedy's suite on the twenty-eighth floor of the Waldorf Towers lasted ninety minutes.
Attorney General Kennedy's proposal for rigorous rules against segregation in interstate bus facilities shows a refreshingly imaginative approach to the law.

In an effort to cope with the critical reading deficiencies in the city's schools, the Board of Education will turn for help to experts at twenty-one colleges and universities in the metropolitan area.

Sperry Rand Corporation reported net income of $27,815,655 or 95 cents a share for the year ended on March 31. There were 28,883,615 common shares outstanding at the end of the year. This compared with net income of $37,235,823 or $1.30 a share in the previous year, based on the 28,284,691 common shares outstanding on March 31, 1960.

Boston Fund has reported that it closed the first fiscal quarter of its thirtieth year on April 30 with record quarter-end highs in net assets and share value. The report placed total net assets at $280,909,327, or 27 per cent more than the $220,937,856 reported a year earlier.
" Somebody failed to do his job properly."

CAMDEN, N.J., May 30 -- Robert Lehman's 3-year-old colt Ambiopoise, the third betting choice among eight in the $124,000 Jersey Derby at Garden State, scored a ten-length victory today under Bobby Ussery.

LONDON, May 30 (AP) -- Unbeaten Johnny Caldwell of Britain opened a severe cut over Alphonse Halimi's left eye in the eighth round and won the European version of the world bantamweight title by scoring a decision in a fifteen-round bout tonight.

VANCOUVER, B.C., May 30 (Canadian Press) -- Harold S. Foley, former vice president of the Macmillan, Bloedel Powell River Company, has been dropped from the big forest industry concern's executive committee.

GENEVA, May 30 -- The United States urged the Soviet Union today to recognize the "complete fairness" of the West's latest offer on inspections of a ban on nuclear testing that is being negotiated here.
Two city electrical inspectors named as bribe-takers last December before the State Investigation Commission have been dismissed.
GENEVA, May 30 -- The Soviet Union refused today to agree to reconvoke the international conference on Laos except on its own terms.
Five men selected by the International Air Transport Association will meet in New York Friday to consider promotional fares on the Atlantic.

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles today swept a doubleheader from the last-place Chicago White Sox. The Orioles scored by 6 -- 0 and 2 -- 1 behind the pitching of Steve Barber and Hal Brown.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 30 -- Support to the fiftieth anniversary fund of Connecticut College, now nearing the $3,000,000 goal, will be given by the alumnae of Fairfield County from the proceeds of a theatre party on June 23, at the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre in Stratford.

JACKSON, Miss., May 30 (AP) -- Eight more Freedom Riders -- five white college students and three Negro collegians -- arrived in Jackson by train today. All were jailed, found guilty of a breach of the peace and fined $200 each.

Slavery in West Africa is the subject of a work of nonfiction by Robin Maugham that Harper will publish on June 21. In "The Slaves of Timbuktu" the author tells how he and two companions, a journalist and a young African of the Wolof Tribe, traveled 3,000 miles by Land Rover and river boat from Dakar to Timbuktu.

EARLY in the day, before she and President Kennedy honored Tunisian President and Madame Habib Bourguiba at the Administration's first State Dinner, Mrs. John F. Kennedy was busy at the White House, making certain there would be no large, formal and tightly massed flower arrangements.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) -- The Department of Commerce reported yesterday that construction activity rose about 2 per cent in May. The department took particular note of an increase in home building.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, May 30 (AP) -- Service was restored at one of three sabotaged telephone relay stations today as the Federal Bureau of Investigation sought to determine the cause of the explosions that wrecked them.

In the midst of the quiet luxury of the Waldorf Towers there is a dusty gray granite stairwell that leads to concealed power rooms that seem as remote from air and sunshine as the solitary confinement section in a penitentiary.
PARIS, May 30 -- Governments in Europe and North America had an answer today to the question: "What makes prices go up, and what should be done about it?"
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission today warned the convention of the Advertising Federation of America here to stay away from "brinkmanship" in false advertising.
Jose Rigores remained in critical condition at Roosevelt Hospital last night following surgery for a brain injury suffered in a boxing match at St. Nicholas Arena Monday night.

The members of the Karlsruhe team used their heads to excellent advantage yesterday. The West German eleven rallied twice to defeat the Kilmarnock team of Scotland, 3 -- 2, in the second game of the International Soccer League double-header at the Polo Grounds.
Second thoughts about liquor advertising seem to be following hard upon the heels of McCall's magazine's first thoughts on the subject.

LOS ANGELES, May 30 (AP) -- Willie Davis tied the score with a double in the seventh inning and then tallied the deciding run on an error as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 5 -- 3 tonight.

LONDON, May 30 -- The Constitutional Conference for the British West Indies Federation will open here tomorrow with the scattered Caribbean island territories still arguing whether they should have a strong or a limited federal government.
Horse and rider combined yesterday in the Metropolitan Handicap to give a crowd of 65,569 at Aqueduce as great a thrill as can be experienced at a race track.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 30 -- A British trawler was ringed by Danish and British warships in the North Atlantic tonight after having been chased and shelled by a Danish frigate.

Americans observed Memorial Day yesterday in the ninety-fourth annual acknowledgment of the nation's debt to its war dead. More than 1,000,000 Americans have fallen in eight wars from the Revolution to Korea.
OTTAWA, May 30 -- The possibility of a general election this fall was still an open question today following the governing party's victory in three out of the four by-elections held yesterday.

THE annual Eastern States Championships continued yesterday afternoon at the Statler Hilton Hotel with sixty-eight bridge teams entered in the two-session mixed-teams contest.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 30 -- A match race between Adios Butler, the world's fastest pacer, and the best one from New Zealand or Australia (False Step, Apmat or Arania) would be all right with the powers that be at Roosevelt Raceway -- if and if.

The twelve-story office building at 250 West Fifty-fourth Street, which serves as a center for the film industry, has been sold for all cash by the Fifty-fourth Street Realty Company, Thomas B. Gilchrist, president.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Congress is getting a brief respite from major legislative battles this week, but both houses will soon be embroiled again in the question of aid to education.

GENEVA, May 30 -- After exciting and often controversial careers as politician and pro-consul, Malcolm John MacDonald has taken his first dip in the stormy waters of a great international negotiation.
A 16-year-old youth was seized yesterday as the killer of a 76-year-old retired plumber in a mugging Monday night in the Baruch Houses. Three other youths also were arrested.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 30 -- President Joseph Kasavubu received a triumphant welcome here today on his return from a five-week conference in Coquilhatville, where he and other Congolese officials drafted plans for a Congo federal republic.
LONDON, May 30 -- The Assembly of the Western European Union urged that organization's Council of Ministers today to organize an African-European conference on economic cooperation.
While astronauts are conquering space, school officials in New Mexico have completed plans to move an entire school of 500 pupils underground.

Twenty-four alumni who are celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of their graduation from Fordham College, including Cardinal Spellman, will receive special honors at Fordham University commencement June 14.
PITTSBURGH, May 30 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5 -- 3 and 10 -- 0, today in a double header.

GENEVA, May 30 -- Belkacem Krim, chief of the Algerian delegation at the peace talks with the French, said today that he hoped the meeting between President Kennedy and President de Gaulle tomorrow would "facilitate" the negotiations on the Algerian question.

PARIS, May 30 -- The sedition trial of two former generals, Maurice Challe and Andre Zeller, was turned today into a trial of a French Army torn between its duty to obey and its desire to keep Algeria for France.
SIGMARINGEN, Germany, May 30 (Reuters) -- Princess Birgitta of Sweden was married in a glittering church ceremony today to Prince Johan George of Hohenzollern.

BERLIN, 30 -- Communist East Germany bestowed special honors yesterday on Martin Riesenburger, rabbi of the Jewish community in East Berlin. He received the gold medal of the Patriotic Order of Merit one of the East Germans' top decorations, to mark his sixty-fifth birthday earlier this month.

THE New York Yankees, an organization not hitherto noted for eleemosynary tendencies, have just paid an extravagant price for an autograph. It belonged to Jake Gibbs, an unproven collegian from Ole Miss., and it cost about $100,000.
PARIS, May 30 -- The nice thing about the Kennedy-de Gaulle meeting is that it takes everybody's mind off the facts.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 30 -- President Duvalier announced his new Cabinet today.
While the international chess masters tournament at Zurich, Switzerland, entered the third round yesterday, another international masters event began in Moscow.

BONN, Germany, May 30 -- The West German prosecutor announced today that pre-trial investigation of Dr. Hans Globke's possible involvement in wartime Nazi persecution of Jews in Greece had been dropped.

The National Committee for Maritime Bargaining -- an organization representing ten seafaring unions with 70,000 members -- asked ship owners yesterday to start contract negotiations here next Tuesday.
A grand old lady of the North Atlantic lay at her Hudson River berth yesterday, her crew in a reminiscing mood.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 30 -- Frantic appeals for Allied military attempts to halt the Nazi slaughter of Hungarian Jews were rejected by Britain, according to secret documents disclosed today at the trial of Adolf Eichmann.
BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., May 30 -- A near dead heat enlivened the final session of the Sports Car Club of America's New York Region national championship meet at the Bridgehampton Race Circuit today.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -- Down in Texas, where they do everything in a big way, some of the natives who trace their ancestry to the days of Sam Houston and the Lone Star Republic don't give their children names -- just initials.

IT is six years now since the publication of one of the finest historical novels yet written about the Middle Ages, "The Cornerstone," by Zoe Oldenbourg. Part of that notable book, which was a sequel to an equally distinguished predecessor, "The World Is Not Enough," was about the Albigensian Crusade.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) -- Three Republican Representatives called today for an end to the "free in county" newspaper postal rate, which has existed since 1851.
ASKED recently who was his "boss" on the North German Lloyd ship the Bremen, Otto Thoener pointed a finger at his own sturdy chest and answered "I am."
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 30 (AP) -- Federal lawyers today sketched the Ku Klux Klan into the picture of bus station race violence but were unable to pin the violence on any Klan member.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- A subsidiary of the General Electric Company took issue today with a ruling barring it from a joint effort to develop a commercial satellite communications system.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- Senator Clair Engle urged the Defense Department today to map procurement requirements four years ahead.

Arrangements are being made with Sam Levene, who is appearing in "The Devil's Advocate," to co-star with George Gobel in "Let It Ride," the musical version of "Three Men on a Horse." If negotiations are concluded, Mr. Levene will have the role he originated twenty-six years ago.
MONTREAL, May 30 (Canadian Press) -- Advances and declines were divided about evenly on the Montreal and Canadian Stock Exchanges in light trading today.

CLEVELAND, May 30 (AP) -- Barry Latman held the Minnesota Twins to two hits in the last three innings in relief and the Cleveland Indians scored a 7-5 victory in the second game of a double-header today. A pinch single by Don Dillard in the ninth drove in the winning run as the Indians won the opener, 4-3.

Five meet records were set and another tied in the third annual sectional track and field championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.

A dispute between two unions on what should be the prevailing wage rates for dredgemen is holding up a $100,000 dredging project at Salem Creek, Mass., according to Brig. Gen. Seymour A. Potter, of the New England Division, United States Corps of Engineers.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Canada's iron and steel industry has reported that 1960 was the second best year in its history.
A new medical and dental center for Manhattan dock workers and their dependents will be dedicated Friday.

OXFORD, England, May 30 (Reuters) -- Dag Hammarskjold today defended the right of the secretary-general of the United Nations to exercise political judgment. He declared that "politically controversial issues" could not be avoided in his position.
DEVON, Pa., May 30 -- Dear Junior, a bay gelding owned by Mrs. William R. Harris of Salisbury, Conn., was the only hunter to win two blues at the sixty-fifth annual Devon horse show today.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 30 -- A hurricane with 100-mile-an-hour winds, accompanied by a tidal wave, inflicted new destruction in East Pakistan's coastal area today.
MIAMI, May 30 -- A new union of underground fighters against Premier Fidel Castro was reported today to have been formed in Cuba.
TORONTO, May 30 (Canadian Press) -- The stock market made a late recovery in all segments to finish ahead in extremely light trading today.

PARIS, May 30 -- The Kennedy-Khrushchev meeting is regarded by Europeans as a negotiation even though Washington wishes to describe it as merely an exchange of views. Furthermore, the encounter occurs at a time when our prestige is low.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) -- About 150 Freedom Rider sympathizers from New York and Philadelphia picketed the White House today to express opposition to racial segregation.

The New York Athletic Club retained the Arthur Myers Point Trophy yesterday in the annual Memorial Day Regatta conducted by the New York Rowing Association on Pelham Lagoon. The N.Y.A.C. scored 77 points in the ten-event program.
CASABLANCA, Morocco, May 30 -- African labor leaders set aside their differences today to establish an independent, All-African Trade Union Federation.

BOSTON, May 30 (AP) -- Orleans Doge, a Preakness also-ran, found the opposition in the $10,000 added Tomasello Memorial Handicap more to his liking and raced to an easy victory as an 11-10 favorite today at Suffolk Downs.

Irving Maidman, realty investor and builder, has announced plans to construct a twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 361-63 West Forty-second Street through the block to 350-60 West Forty-third Street.
VIENNA, May 30 -- An explicit definition of "peaceful coexistence" as a new instrument for conducting class warfare inside capitalist and colonial countries was published recently in Bulgaria.
ANACORTES, Wash., May 30 (AP) -- Salvage operations were started today on the freighter Island Mail, which was beached yesterday in Puget Sound.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) -- A rookie, Ed Hobaugh, pitched six-hit ball to give the Washington Senators a 5-1 victory over the Los Angeles Angels today, before a crowd of 14,277.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The United States Ambassador to Haiti, Robert N. Newbegin, quietly returned to his post in Port-au-Prince last Saturday with instructions to be cool but correct toward the dictator-President, Francois Duvalier.

Rear Admiral Schuyler N. Pyne has been appointed deputy director general of the English-Speaking Union of the United States, effective June 12. He will retire today as commander of the New York Naval Shipyard at Brooklyn.

SECRETARY of Health, Education and Welfare Abraham Ribicoff set aside a few minutes from his pressing duties in Washington recently to send a warm message of congratulations to a young mother in Levittown about her family.
STANTON, Del., May 30 (AP) -- The Jaclyn Stable's Li'l Fella drove to a two-length victory in the $25,250 Brandywine Turf Handicap at Delaware Park today.
LONDON, May 30 -- Industrial shares weakened on the stock market here today as buyers became cautious and profit taking increased.
THE low state of physical fitness in the United States was the subject last night of a cursory documentary entitled "The Flabby American" on Channel 7.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- There is nothing like a business upturn to change predictions of what it will be like.
Bernard Kilgore, president of The Wall Street Journal, has been named by Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism to receive its fourth Columbia Journalism Award.
EPSOM, England, May 30 (AP) -- Four American-owned horses today were included among the twenty-eight starters for tomorrow's 182d English Derby -- the most wide open in years.
TRENTON, May 30 -- The commuter tax signed by Gov. Robert B. Meyner yesterday will be amended to make certain that no one's tax bill is increased "one penny."

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 30 -- Abba Eban, Israel's Minister of Education and former Ambassador to the United States, declared today that his country would continue to be significant to the world insofar as it could extend its influence beyond its own frontiers.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., May 30 -- Bob McKown of Malden, Mass., a 21-year-old pipe organ repairman, established a bicycling national record while winning the eighteenth Tour of Somerville today before 18,000 spectators.
Surveys of how employes feel about their jobs do not do much good unless the findings are followed up, according to a study of 155 companies just issued by the National Industrial Conference Board.

MOSCOW, May 30 (UPI) -- Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin began his orbit of the earth on a launching pad near Lake Aral and ended it in a farm field 400 miles southeast of Moscow, the official press agency Tass said tonight.
The independent liberal arts colleges stand in a more strategic position than ever before, Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College, said yesterday in her biennial report.
Amateur quartets will compete next week to represent their boroughs in the twenty-seventh annual Barber Shop Quartet Contest.
LOS ANGELES, May 30 (AP) -- Los Angeles voters choose tomorrow between the incumbent mayor, Norris Poulson, or his challenger, Sam Yorty. The term is four years.

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, May 30-- Premier Khrushchev will arrive here tomorrow for talks with the Communist leaders of Czechoslovakia and Hungary as a preface to his week-end meeting in Vienna with President Kennedy.

A ballerina floated onto the stage of Junior High School 141 in Riverdale the other day, dressed in a classic white tutu, with a misty look in her eyes. She was chewing gum to the music of Georges Bizet.
The number of unemployed in New York State continued to decline last month, while gains were made in over-all employment rolls.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, May 30 -- Duncan Sandys, Britain's Secretary of State for Commonwealth Relations, conferred here today with leaders of the African National Democratic party in an attempt to resolve a deadlock over a new constitution for Southern Rhodesia.
Mayor Wagner has summoned top school and other city officials to a meeting this morning at City Hall to discuss the school repair program and to take "immediate action."

Usually, however, as when meeting a person, the first glance is, especially in retrospect, awesomely revealing. But two current exhibitions, Satish Gujral's at the ACA Gallery, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street, and Manuel Ayaso's at the Cober Gallery, 14 East Sixty-ninth Street, demand time, and give generously in return.

A merger of the Thorp Finance Corporation. Thorp, Wis., into the C.I.T. Financial Corporation has been agreed to in principle by both concerns. Thorp Finance conducts a sales finance, personal loan and industrial equipment financing business through eighty offices in Wisconsin and Minnesota.

A Wall Street broker left a shoe box containing jewelry valued at $129,635 in a rented private limousine yesterday morning, and got it back last night.
Webb Knapp, Inc.'s transfer today of its title in the Denver, Colo., Courthouse Square Development to the Alleghany Corporation was postponed again yesterday. The closing now is set for June 12.

A syndicate headed by Jack Davis and Simon Goldstein, realty investors, has bought the shopping center at Teaneck Road and Tryon Avenue, Teaneck, N.J. Martin and Joseph Linkowsky, the builders, were the sellers. An A. P. supermarket is the major tenant in the center, which has parking for 150 cars.

TO rise to the top of his profession, a British diplomat must master difficult assignments in foreign posts and show that he can work smoothly with Britain's principal allies. When Sir Harold Caccia came to Washington as Ambassador in November, 1956, he faced both problems at once.

Plans to publish The Wall Street Journal in Southern California with the use of facsimile transmission were announced yesterday by Bernard Kilgore, president. He said that the system would be used at a new experimental Journal plant in Riverside, Calif., early next year.
