Frederick Brown, realty investor, has sold the three-story garage and service building formerly occupied by the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines at 4 to 20 East 102d Street, near Fifth Avenue. Jack Resnick, builder and investor, was the buyer.

Madison Square Garden again will serve as a bowling establishment for one day as the third annual Ruppert-Brunswick tournament of champions is staged today. Beginning at 9 A.M., bowlers will compete in both men's and women's divisions for $5,000 in prizes.

The Immigration and Naturalization Service at New York International Airport issued an order late last night preventing "generally" any United States citizens from traveling to the Dominican Republic.

BONN, Germany, May 31 -- The United States, Britain and France have begun consultations in Washington on American proposals to strengthen plans to meet a new Berlin crisis. A White House group headed by Dean Acheson, former Secretary of State, worked out the proposals on President Kennedy's orders, reliable sources here said.
CHICAGO, May 31 (AP) -- The strongest demand in more than a week held the grain futures market in a generally firm range today on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The cost to the American people of putting a man on the moon in this decade was recently estimated at $20 to $40 billion by Director Webb and Deputy Director Dryden of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Angels scored two runs in the twelfth inning to down the Washington Senators, 5 -- 3, tonight and give Bill Kunkel his second victory.
Stock prices moved higher on average last month in active trading. Volume was the heaviest for any May since 1933 and the second best for that month in the history of the New York Stock Exchange.
DENVER, May 31 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals today ordered a third trial for six former members of the Colorado Communist party.
You published on May 13 an interesting feature article by Harry Gilroy "The Talk of The Hague."

AFTER a day off, the American collections swung into action again. Buyers hustled once again through Seventh Avenue, checking out fall fashions. These designs will not be in the stores until the end of July.

Your strong and welcome endorsement of the creation of a Chesapeake and Ohio Canal national park along the Potomac River should help mightily to secure action by a lagging Congress on this measure to authorize development of this land already owned by the Federal Government.

The nation's fifth largest airline and the first in the country to operate jet-powered equipment, Capital Airlines, flies into oblivion today. It becomes a part of United Air Lines and the resulting system will rank as the nation's biggest, outstripping American Airlines, which has long held the title.

Production of electric power rose last week to 14,390,000,000 kilowatt hours, the highest level in a month and a half, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. A week before the figure was 14,352,000,000 and a year ago, it was 13,938,000,000 kilowatt hours.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 31 -- One of the world's natural wonders stood impressively among the Catskills today -- 5 feet 11 inches tall, wearing a patina of gray snow, a goatee and purple boxing trunks. It was, of course, Archie Moore.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, May 31 (AP) -- Loblaw, Inc., of Buffalo, N.Y., announced today the acquisition of thirty-nine supermarkets in eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania from the Century Food Markets Company in an exchange of stock.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) -- The satellite Explorer XI has switched its own radio channels and now is reporting its reatcion to cosmic radiation.
BECAUSE you cannot win a race every day, food is one of the most important diversions on a sailing vessel. This is the observation of William Snaith, the rugged and tanned skipper of Figaro III.
Of the six games scheduled for yesterday's second round of the international chess masters tournament at the Moscow Central Club, only four were decided, according to a report from the Soviet Union.

Igor Stravinsky will conduct two of his major dramatic compositions in Warsaw next fall. Appearing with the touring Santa Fe Opera Company, Mr. Stravinsky will direct productions of his "Oedipus Rex" and "Persephone" during the company's four-day visit to the Polish capital in early October.
TRENTON, May 31 -- A referendum in November on a $60,000,000 bond issue to permit the state to acquire lands for park and recreational areas was assured tonight.
LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, May 31 -- The Government of the Congo published today its plan for putting into effect the program voted at the Coquilhatville conference for setting up a federal republic.
ATLANTA, May 31 -- The telephone rang constantly in Room 103 of the modernistic building of old brick, new glass and wood paneling at 197 1/2 Auburn Avenue.

The Indiana and Michigan Electric Company, an operating concern in the American Electric Power System, borrowed $20,000,000 in the new capital market yesterday at a net interest cost of 5.0513 per cent.

Leading sales finance companies raised by one-eighth to one-half percentage point yesterday the rates on some maturities of commercial paper they sell directly to investors. The new rates are effective today.
PARIS, May 31 -- Former Gens. Maurice Challe and Andre Zeller were sentenced today to fifteen years in prison for their leadership of the military mutiny in Algeria last month.
The analogy in your editorial of May 22 between the exchange of Cuban prisoners for agricultural equipment and the attempt by Germany in World War II to trade Jewish captives for trucks is baseless.

PITTSBURGH, May 31 -- Construction unions in this city signed today a contract giving the builders of a middle-income housing development full freerom to use prefabricated equipment and other labor-saving devices.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 31 -- Joel Brand, the frustrated emissary of Adolph Eichmann's offer to trade Jews for trucks, testified today that not only British but even Jewish leaders had not believed his story.

Flotations of public utility and industrial bonds in May rose sharply from the levels of the 1960 month. However, the month's total of new bonds of all typee offered publicly here declined to $1,750,567,900 for 282 issues from $1,910,255,000 for 168 issues in April and $1,752,644,000 for 215 issues in May, 1960.

Prices for potato futures rose Sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Trading was influenced by the late planting of potatoes in Maine because of heavy rains. Normally, almost all of the fields are planted by the beginning of June.
ATLANTA, May 31 (AP) -- Three Negro Presbyterian churches have been invited into full membership in the all-white Atlanta Presbytery.
BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, May 31 -- Premier Khrushchev pledged the Soviet Union tonight always to be "the voice for peace."

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) -- Twelve girls and five boys avoided the pitfalls of such words as "recidivism" and "cochineal'' today to survive the first day of the thirty-fourth National Spelling Bee. The finals will be held tomorrow.
The following matter has the endorsement of forty-three Princeton University faculty members from the natural sciences, the social sciences and the humanities.

Large refundings of public utility bonds, as in the previous month, swelled the total of bonds called for redemption before maturity in May. The total of $107,780,000 was the largest for any month since June, 1958, when $155,984,000 was retired.
Premier David Ben-Gurion spoke to American Zionist leaders here yesterday in a congenial atmosphere and held fast to his view that Zionism means nothing less than "aliyah" -- immigration to Israel.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The advertising business got a mild scolding today from one of its leaders, who said that it did not have the right "to bore the blazes out of 170,000,000 Americans."

SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 (AP) -- Joe Amalfitano beat out a dribbler with the bases filled and two out in the ninth inning today, giving the San Francisco Giants a 3-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.
Prices of United States Government securities and other prime-risk fixed-income securities drifted downward yesterday as bearish sentiment regained a predominant position in the bond market.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Federal Housing Administration issued new regulations today simplifying the rules providing for a moratorium on monthly payments on mortgages it insures. The action was a move to help unemployed workers save their homes.
Republicans broadened their search for a candidate for Controller yesterday after John Roosevelt was eliminated as a possibility.
Hopes of averting a strike of 10,000 defense workers in Long Island plants increased early today as negotiations continued beyond a midnight strike deadline.
BOSTON, May 31 -- Life as manager of the Yankees continues to hold few dull moments for Ralph Houk. His Bombers outlasted the Boston Red Sox tonight, 7 -- .6
Columbia University will confer honorary degrees on seven leaders in education, medicine and government at its annual commencement exercises on Tuesday afternoon.

The paths of a frantic hotel manager and a singer who had been waiting five years to make his New York night-club debut happened to cross last week, and the result was far more exciting than either of them had bargained for.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 31 -- A Federal judge rejected today a request by the Justice Department for a no-violence injunction against the Birmingham, Ala., police, but warned sternly against further violence toward Freedom Riders.
The Tractors for Freedom Committee expects to place a firm proposal before Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba to exchange 1,214 prisoners for 500 tractors.

Claims of attorneys and expert witnesses in a recent suit won by International Railways of Central America against the United Fruit Company amount to more than the award received. Stockholders were told this yesterday at their annual meeting in Jersey City by Abraham K. Weber, attorney for International Railways.

The Long Island Rail Road operated at a net loss of nearly $1,000,000 in the first four months of this year. The deficit was attributed almost entirely to a 17 per cent drop in freight traffic from the 1960 level.

Graduates of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University were urged yesterday to remember always, in dealing with the human body as a machine, that man is a sensitive and ethical being.
The over-the-counter stock market continued quiet yesterday, with few major price changes.
The record of the Wagner Administration is "disappointing," especially in the second term, the City Club of New York said yesterday.

Jean Pierre Aumont and his wife, Marisa Pavan, will make their American musical comedy debut in a variation of Schnitzler's "Anatol." The couple will be seen in the show July 31 through Aug. 19 at the American Festival in Cambridge, Mass.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, May 31 (UPI) -- Following are the texts of a proclamation by President Joaquin Balaguer and of a decree issued by the President today:
Eight more customers for electric power applied yesterday for the services of the Niagara Falls power project. All forecast lower electric rates for consumers.

The story of Vitus Bering, the Dane commissioned by Peter the Great to explore the far reaches of Russia, has been written by Robert Murphy, an editor of The Saturday Evening Post. He became intersted in Bering while doing research for an article on sea otters for the magazine.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 31 -- The Screen Actors Guild, in a letter to Congress, detailed today the extent to which American companies are forsaking Hollywood to make films abroad.

LONDON, May 31 -- Sir Grantley Adams, Prime Minister of the Federation of the West Indies, pledged the loyalty and military forces of his island territories today to the defense of Western security in the Caribbean.

President Kennedy's foreign aid program will have to overcome considerable Congressional suspicion in the weeks immediately ahead. This became clear yesterday when influential members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee took the opening of hearings on the program as the occasion for critical public statements on the subject.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -The White House sent to Congress today a bill to make the Peace Corps permanent and give it $40,000,000 for the year starting July 1.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, May 31 -- Africans in Salisbury have started a sit-in campaign to break the color bar.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The White House announced today the resignation of M.S. Szymczak as a member of the Federal Reserve System's board of governors.

While it would be hypocrisy to express regrets at the passing of Rafael Leonidas Trujillo, assassination is an execrable method of political expression and can always be expected to create worse problems than it seeks to solve.

LOS ANGELES, May 31 (AP) -- Gene Freese hit a tie-breaking, two-run homer in the eighth inning and led Cincinnati to an 8-7 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight. The decision kept the Reds even with San Francisco for the lead in the National League.

GENEVA, May 31 -- The United States told the Communist bloc today that "constructive negotiations" here on the future of Laos would be impossible "under the threat of force" posed by Communist violations of the Laotian cease-fire.
VERA MAXWELL, the fashion industry's gentle, ladylike designer with silver gray hair, sat in her Seventh Avenue salon one day last week explaining her own clothes problems.

Subsidized American ship companies that serve South American, African and Asian ports will be given the opportunity to extend their services to Great Lakes ports, the Maritime Administration announced yesterday.
BERLIN, May 31 -- East Germany has obtained a pledge from the Soviet Union for long-term aid designed to offset her economic troubles, officials said today.
An angry Mayor Wagner told the Board of Education yesterday to speed school repairs -- "or else."
SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 (AP) -- Samuel Goldwyn, the motion picture producer, was awarded $300,000 damages today against distributors of seven of his films.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 31 -- Asian and African countries demanded today an urgent meeting of the Security Council on the Angola question and accused Portugal of having perpetrated massacres in the West African territory.
EPSOM, England, May 31 -- Psidium, a 66-1 shot, burst out of nowhere today and won the English Derby.
TRENTON, May 31 -- New Jersey rural areas must start planning now for a great spread of urbanization, a report made public by the State Department of Agriculture said today.

All parties involved in the Securities and Exchange Commission's action against the Townsend Corporation of America and its affiliates agreed yesterday to a consent decree. Judge William F. Smith of the Federal District Court at Newark approved the decree.
An assertion that business men increasingly will be the leaders in rebuilding this country into new urban patterns was made last night by Clarence Francis, chairman of Studebaker-Packard Corporation.
Area code dialing will be applied to all calls between New York City and southern Westchester and Nassau Counties within the next sixteen months, the New York Telephone Company announced yesterday.
PARIS, May 31 -- President Kennedy and President de Gaulle proclaimed today their "complete identity of view" on Western action to counter any threat to Berlin by the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The $500,000,000 Distant Early Warning (DEW) Line of radar and electronic defenses has been extended across the Atlantic, the Pentagon announced today.
JERSEY CITY, May 31 -- A 25-year-old mother was charged with manslaughter today in a tenement fire that caused the death of seven persons.

The city and the United States Lines signed twenty- year lease yesterday involving two projects that will comprise the largest terminal development for an individual steamship company in the port's history.
The Board of Education has decided to poll its teachers on collective bargaining.
PRETORIA, South Africa, May 31 -- South Africa became a republic today.

OTTAWA, May 31 (AP) -- The Government has defeated an opposition move in the Commons to delete a proposal exempting American lake vessels from compulsory pilotage dues on the Canadian section of the Seaway.

The first practical application of recent scientific advances in space appears likely to be the establishment within the next few years of communications satellites which will greatly expand existing facilities for international transmission of information and intelligence.
The City Planning Commission moved yesterday to revive the controversial plan for widening Fulton Street in lower Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Senator Russell B. Long of Louisiana is understood to have asked the Kennedy Administration not to promote the Federal district judge who ordered the integration of the New Orleans schools.
At the request of John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, 250 more special reading teachers, 300 in all, will be provided for New York City schools in the fall.
Cotton futures were mixed yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Three positions were unchanged at the close, three advanced and October declined 1 point. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)
Paul R. Hays, state chairman of the Liberal party, has been tentatively selected for nomination to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- A five-year plan to increase Federal funds gradually for an anti-pollution program was approved by the Senate Public Works Committee today.
The Appellate Division in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that the Democratic members had control of the Board of Supervisors in Suffolk County, a former Republican stronghold.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 31 -- Bergen County's population of persons more than 65 years old increased at a greater rate between 1950 and 1960 than the general population, the County Planning Board reported today.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 31 -- An interracial group seeking fuller integration in the public schools here has refused a request by the president of the Board of Education to identify its white members.

The House Un-American Activities Committee has reached a new low in know-nothingism by harassing the Fund for Social Analysis. After more than a generation of trying to impose its brand of political orthodoxy the H.U.A.C. now is trying to frighten scholars into intellectual orthodoxy.
Donald A. Newbery was named last night as New York University's baseball coach.
LOS ANGELES, May 31 (AP) -- Mayor Norris Poulson, seeking re-election, conceded defeat tonight to Samuel W. Yorty, a former Democratic Representative.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- John G. Tower, the first Republican Senator from Texas since the Reconstruction days, visited Washington today. He was met at the airport by more than 100 Republican leaders and party members.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk delayed his departure for Europe today at President Kennedy's request. The President asked Mr. Rusk to follow developments in the wake of the assassination of the Dominican dictator, Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina.

The number of industrial accidents reported to the Workmen's Compensation Board last year was the lowest since 1940, although the number of persons covered by the state compensation law increased "very substantially" in the two decades.

The Port of New York Authority released a study yesterday that forecast an increase of 134,580 jobs and of $717,900 000 in income by 1980 if a proposed jetport were built in the New York-New Jersey Metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) -- Spokesmen for the insurance and investment industries said today that a proposed 20 per cent withholding tax on dividends and interest would cause confusion for the public and the companies.
Sterling showed renewed weakness in foreign exchange dealings yesterday. Traders reported considerable activity in the "swap" market as attempts were made to establish short positions.
PARIS, May 31 -- It was 10:20 o'clock this morning at Orly Airport when a stream of small black cars flowed around the massed honor guard and halted at the edge of the scarlet carpet.
A number of changes in metals prices were announced yesterday.
SEOUL, Korea, May 31 -- South Korea's military government pledged tonight to promote "free economic activities."
GENEVA, May 31 -- The Soviet Union rejected today the Western compromise proposal on inspections under the projected treaty to ban nuclear testing.
Vic Tanny Enterprises, Inc., has named Kastor Hilton Chesley Clifford Atherton, Inc., as its advertising agency. Billings for next year will be about $2,000,000.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Administration today slashed the price of the land it sells to state and county governments for park development.

MIAMI, May 31 -- The Cuban Revolutionary Movement of the People protested today against the detention of thirteen Cuban foes of Premier Fidel Castro for more than three months without charges by the United States Immigration Service.
With metropolitan racing scheduled to shift today from the Big A (for Aqueduct) to Beautiful B (for Belmont), 26,556 fans took a lingering look at Aqueduct yesterday.
SHANNON, Ireland, May 31 (AP) -- A crippled American airliner with 104 persons aboard -- mostly women and children -- flew hundreds of miles over the Atlantic early today to a smooth landing here.

PRETORIA, May 31 (Reuters) -- President Charles R. Swart made it clear at his inauguration today that as a republic South Africa still would not tolerate any interference in its bitterly criticized domestic policies, which provide for strict segregation of the races.
MONTREAL, May 31 (Canadian Press) -- Canadair, Ltd., today delivered a giant CL-44 swing-tail aircraft to the Flying Tigers Airline of Burbank, Calif.
LONDON, May 31 -- William David Ormsby-Gore, Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, was named today to succeed Sir Harold Caccia as British Ambassador to Washington.

Enemies of the Trujillo regime rioted yesterday at the Dominican Consulate offices in Rockefeller Center. As a result of the disorders, thirty-one men were taken to the West Forty-seventh Street police station and charged with disorderly conduct.
BOSTON, May 31 -- Lawyers for Bernard Goldfine unexpectedly took steps today to withdraw a plea of guilty by him to charges of having evaded $791,745 in income taxes.
The Police Department urged yesterday that all persons possessing illegal weaponss and knives turn them in to their local police stations.
Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina, dictator of the Dominican Republic since 1930, was assassinated Tuesday night.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) -- A labor union that was a pioneer in the welfare and pension field supported legislation today that would require fuller disclosure and severe penalties for abuses of medical and retirement plan funds.

Business executives were advised yesterday to look to the Federal Government's regulatory agencies for advice and guidance on how to conform their operating policies to the requirements of trade practices laws.
The Publishers Association of New York City yesterday named George E. Donnelly, business manager of The New York Daily News, as its chairman for the coming year.

The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that officers, directors and large stockholders of listed companies last month reported the following changes in stockholdings under the Securities Exchange Act. The New York Stock Exchange did not issue an insiders' report.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 31 (AP) -- Ward Industries, Inc., showed a net profit of $72,971 for the first quarter of this year, stockholders were told at the annual meeting here today.

MOSCOW, May 31 -- A group of leading American and Soviet public figures, who have been holding unofficial discussions of major world problems, expressed hope today that the forthcoming meeting between President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev would contribute toward peace and security.
EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, May 31 -- The French and Algerian delegations to the peace talks here clashed today on the question of whether the Sahara is an "integral part" of Algeria.
OGDENSBURG, N.Y., May 31 -- This small city in northern New York is planning a major effort to capitalize on its position as the nearest to Europe of any American port on the St. Lawrence Seaway.

PARIS, May 31 (Reuters) -- Following are the texts of addresses by President Kennedy and President de Gaulle at a dinner in the Elysee Palace tonight:

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) -- About 24 cents of every dollar that drug makers get for prescription medicines is used to promote, advertise and otherwise sell their products, according to Paul Rand Dixon, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.

RYE, N.Y., May 31 -- Mrs. George J. Brady of Scarsdale and Mrs. Harold Kilpatrick of New Canaan held a two-stroke lead today at the halfway mark of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association's annual best-ball tournament.

CHICAGO, May 31 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox, who had scored only once in twenty-four innings, exploded tonight for a 9-4 victory over the Baltimore Orioles. The Sox belted five pitchers for ten hits in snapping a three-game losing streak.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 31 (AP) -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced today an offer of $10,000 for information leading to the conviction of the saboteurs who blew up three microwave relay stations in western Utah and eastern Nevada last Sunday.
A patrolman shot a knife out of the hand of a mentally ill man after a chase in the Bronx yesterday.
THE second knockout round of the Reisinger Teams- of-Four Championship was played last night at the Statler Hilton Hotel by the thirty-two teams that remained out the starting field of sixty-four.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Three boxing champions, including Rocky Marciano, endorsed today the idea of a Federal "czar" to drive underworld elements out of the sport.

The May Department Stores Company had slightly lower sales and earnings in its first fiscal quarter ended April 30 than in the "very strong first quarter of 1960," Morton D. May, president, reported at yesterday's annual meeting here.

Seattle, Wash., is planning the sale of $20,000,000 of sewer revenue bonds on June 15. The issue will come due serially from 1964 to 2000. The offering is part of a total authorized issue of $125,000,000. The obligations will be secured by revenues from the municipal sewer system.

Some of the leading dog show judges probably see more of the world with all expenses paid than any other group in sports except possibly the top tennis players. If a show is held in Zanzibar, it is probable that an American will be there to make the selections.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 -- Scheduled helicopter service, linking the San Francisco and Oakland airports with downtown heliports in both cities, will be inaugurated tomorrow.

The United States Court of Appeals yesterday reversed the convictions of two linen supply associations, eight member companies and six individuals for criminal anti-trust violations. A new trial was ordered.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 (UPI) -- A.J. Foyt and his crew tonight picked up a record $117,975 in prizes for winning the 500-mile Indianapolis Speedway event yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Government space scientists have simulated in a laboratory a free-flight speed of just under 30,000 miles an hour.
Raymond Cerabone, a 17-year-old Queens high school student, was honored last night for selling $150 worth of mosaic hotplates and ashtrays to friends and relatives around Flushing.
PHILADELPHIA, May 31 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs scored a 5-4 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies and Robin Roberts tonight. It was Roberts' seventh consecutive loss. He has yet to win this season.

Mrs. Auguste Redman saw her tenement operation come to an end yesterday in Housing Court. Magistrate Manuel Gomez told her: "You have been characterized queen of the slumlords with a slum empire. Today you've seen the liquidation."
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A high unemployment rate of nearly 7 per cent continued in May for the sixth straight month despite seasonal rises in jobs, the Labor Department reported today.

Robert Moses has applied to the Art Commission of the City of New York to demolish the "ornamental and architectural masonry" at the plaza areas of the Manhattan Bridge.

Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina was like a character out of an historical novel. He ruled the Dominican Republic as a baronical fief with an absolutism seldom rivaled in modern history.
The World Room at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism was dedicated yesterday in memory of Herbert Bayard Swope, editor of The New York World in the Nineteen Twenties.
The controversy over the proposed Morris County jetport was rekindled yesterday with the release of a new Port Authority report that, in effect, rejected any other site.
A total of 1,275 persons was injured in automobile accidents in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was an increase of 167 over the same week in 1960.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration said today that successful production synthetically of a chemical compound at its Dallas Hospital might lead to anti-cancer vaccines.

DETROIT, May 31 (UPI) -- Joe Pignatano, a cast-off catcher from the National League, got four hits tonight, including a home run and a double, and led the Kansas City Athletics to a 6 -- 4 victory over the Detroit Tigers.
Dore Schary will write and produce a special hour-long variety show to be televised in October by the National Broadcasting Company.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Factory inventories increased in April, breaking a seven-month decline and reflecting a pick-up in business. Factory sales and new orders rose for the third consecutive month.
The ninety-fifth anniversary observance of the founding of St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases will include a fashion show and card party Sept. 26 at the Plaza.
LONDON, May 31 -- Industrial shares continued their downward trend in the stock market here today.

A MAVERICK breeze danced through the crystal chandeliers and hid behind the expensive silk curtains. A vendeuse's pekingese raised its head, sniffed and went back to sleep in its place under a Louis XV fauteuil chair. And Mrs. Sophie Shonnard, wearing a Balenciaga dress and a Givenchy clutch coat, glided through a pair of champagne curtains to welcome her visitor.
The Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, L.I., will be the setting of an exhibition of paintings and sculpture arranged by the Creative Club. The event will open June 9 and continue through July 27.
KINGSTON, N.Y., May 31 -- Three residents of Woodstock were sent to the Ulster County jail today for five days for refusal to take cover during the Civil Defense drill April 28.

Stocks opened with a brisk advance yesterday, held on hopefully despite declining volume in the afternoon and slumped in the last half hour. There were small gains in the leading market averages. More stocks rose than fell.
IF fashion models have anything to say about the success of a hairdresser, a small fragile-boned man named Monti may he be on his way to the top.
PHILADELPHIA, May 31 -- Columbia ended its Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball schedule today with a 5-3 victory over Pennsylvania on Murphy Field.
A program to develop what may become the underwater equivalent of the North American radar-warning system was announced today.

Miehle-Goss-Dexter, Inc., Chicago producer of printing presses and graphic arts machinery, had a slight rise in earnings but a drop in sales in the quarter and six months ended on April 30, the report disclosed yesterday.
Two of his five commands will be relinquished today by Vice Admiral Charles Wellborn Jr.

PARIS, May 31 -- President Kennedy's meeting with President de Gaulle today was a ceremonial success Mr. Kennedy was elaborately complimentary and eloquent. General de Gaulle did not give his visitor the full Khrushchev television treatment in the streets of Paris, but he was more cordial and animated than usual.

Population changes reflected in the census of 1960 require a revision of Congressional districts. A joint legislative committee is now at work deciding how to accommodate New York State's reduction of House seats from forty-three to forty-one.

SHREVEPORT, La., May 31 (UPI) -- Union members representing all communications workers in Northwest Louisiana demanded today that Walter Reuther and James B. Carey pay $5,000 given to the Freedom Riders out of their own pockets.

The Bawl Street Journal, Wall Street's dollar-a-copy lampoon of high finance, will make its annual appearance today. It serves as an overture to the Bond Club of New York's annual field day to be held tomorrow at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough, N.Y.
The rapid growth of Israel's merchant fleet has overtaxed the nation's training facilities for seamen and officers, according to a report issued by Allalouf Co., Tel Aviv shipping agents.

The last hurdle in qualifying for the United States Open championship will bring 492 golfers into action next week. Sectional preliminaries at thirty-six holes will be held on June 5 and 6 in thirteen areas. At stake will be 129 places for the championship proper.

Fourteen guards were added last night to the five-man unit that has been patrolling Baruch Houses, the Lower East Side development where a 76-year old man was killed by a group of teen-agers Monday night.
IT hasn't been nostalgia or memory playing false tricks all these years. "Pal Joey" is as wonderful a musical as it seemed late in 1940, when it was new.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 31 -- Pity the poor little rich horse, Bye Bye Byrd, who has had little luck this season. As if the recent going had not been rough enough for Mr. and Mrs. Rex Larkin's 6-year-old, B.B.B. today drew the worst post position, No. 8, for Saturday night's $25,000 Miracle Mile Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.
LONDON, May 31 -- The British are convinced that the use of force by the West to maintain access to West Berlin would mean a world war.
BALBOA, C.Z., May 31 -- Oceangoing traffic through the Panama Canal reached a new monthly high during May, when more than 1,000 ships made the passage. All but about a score were commercial vessels.
Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman ordered New Rochelle yesterday to let any child transfer out of the predominantly Negro Lincoln Elementary School.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 31 -- Merryle Stanley Rukeyser, president of the New Rochelle Board of Education, said today that Judge Irving R. Kaufman's order, if carried out, would cause "chaos" in the New Rochelle public schools.

A thirty-two-year-old record was wiped off the books yesterday when Wilfred Parrish of Andrew Jackson High in Queens won the broad jump at the fifty-seventh annual Public Schools Athletic League outdoor track and field championships at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.
PARIS , May 31 -- Parisians did not have as much chance today to see Mrs. Kennedy as they would have liked to have. But what little they did see produced the most flattering comments.
ST. LOUIS, May 31 (AP) -- The proposed merger of the Pet Milk Company of St. Louis and the C.H. Musselman Company of Biglerville, Pa., was approved today by the directors of the two concerns.
The school construction scandals are causing Mayor Wagner deep concern these days as he continues to debate with himself whether to run for a third term on the Democratic ticket.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm product prices declined slightly more than 1 per cent during the month ended May 15. This decline came on top of a 2 per cent downturn during the preceding month.

PITTSBURGH, May 31 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates ended a five-game losing streak tonight by defeating the Milwaukee Braves, 9 -- 1. Eight of the fourteen Pirate hits were doubles.
DEVON, Pa., May 31 -- Qui Sait and Sandpiper won the two open jumper events of the sixty-fifth annual Devon horse show tonight.

A new state regulation will reduce the cost of credit life insurance for many persons who obtain loans to buy automobiles, home appliances and other consumer goods and for personal loan and mortgage borrowers.

The New York State Board of Regents' preliminary establishment of standards for recipients of the new "scholar incentive" grants represents a half attempt to make the handouts academically legitimate. The criteria for eligibility, to be formally approved by the Regents on June 23, aim at giving these grants the appearance of true scholarships.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The United States should make "self-help" an "insistent" condition of aid to less-developed nations, Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today.

Doug Harvey's appointment as player-coach of the New York Rangers became official yesterday, when the former star defense man of the Montreal Canadiens signed a three-year contract at unspecified terms.
MERIDIAN, Miss., May 31 (AP) -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People sued in Federal court today to desegregate the all-white University of Mississippi.
Marchal Jewelers, which occupies a store north of the entrance to the Squibb Building at 745 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Fifty-seventh Street, has taken additional space for expansion.

Richard Franko Goldman, conductor of the Goldman Band, will receive the 1961 Alice M. Ditson Conductor's Award at Columbia University, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Goldman, who succeeded his father, the late Edwin Franko Goldman, as conductor of the band in 1956, is also widely known as a composer, critic and teacher.

Loans to business at the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City declined by $10,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with an increase of $31,000,000 in the year-earlier week.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- Plans were announced today for ten experimental launchings of Saturn, the giant rocket being groomed for three-man Apollo satellites.
Mayor Wagner said last night he would soon set up "a task force" on integrating youth into the city's labor market.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 1 -- Dr. Israel Beer, prominent figure in Israeli military circles, went on trial today behind closed doors on a charge that he had spied for an unidentified Communist power.

THE flare is more than holding its own on Seventh Avenue, but otherwise designers are sticking to their own signatures, as the fall American collections continue to unfold as unceasingly as waves on a beach.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, June 1 -- Duncan Sandys, Secretary of State for Commonwealth Relations, and Sir Edgar Whitehead, Prime Minister of Southern Rhodesia, announced tonight that they had reached agreement on all points of the colony's new constitution.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) -- Legislation calling for a broad investigation of stock exchanges was introduced in the House today.
HAMMOND, Ind., June 1 (AP) -- A Federal judge upheld today the conviction of eleven major oil companies on gasoline price-fixing charges and fined them a total of $425,000.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 1 -- Adolf Eichmann's final operation in the liquidation of Europe's Jews, the "death march" from Budapest to the Austrian frontier at the onset of the winter of 1944, was described by survivors at his trial today.
The U.S. Rubber Company and the United Rubber Workers Union agreed last night on a new contract affecting some 25,000 employes in eighteen U.S. Rubber plants in eleven states.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $26,000,000 to $92,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $7,000,000 to $574,000,000.
The New York City Center spring season of musical revivals has produced one theatrical triumph after another. But, it has remained for "Pal Joey," the last in the series, to cap it all.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) -- A Senate subcommittee has prepared a report charging that Gordon M. Tiffany lacked both ability and competence as the first director of the Civil Rights Commission.

A young heiress' refusal to sign away a trust fund of $3,800,000 has thwarted her father's plan to give the money to his alma mater, Princeton University. He had started the fund for her with a $4,000 investment twenty-two years ago.

WASHINGTON, JUNE 1 (UPI) -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said today that he would not oppose inclusion of provisions of some present farm laws in the Administration's general farm bill.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The manager of the Federal Reserve System's open-market buying and selling of Government securities advised members of Congress today not to expect interest rates to fall when business was rising.
The General Development Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of Frank E. Mackle Jr. as chairman of the board and of H. A. Yoars as president.

CINCINNATI, June 1 -- Eighty-six years ago the late Rabbi Isaac Mayer Wise, with high hopes and noble purposes, founded a small educational institution in the dimly lit basement of Bene Israel Temple here.

George S. Young, chairman and chief executive officer of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., announced yesterday the election of John W. Partridge as president and a director. He succeeds Cecil E. Loomis, who was named vice chairman. Mr. Loomis will retain his post as chief administrative officer.
The Board of Education's decision to hold a referendum on collective bargaining for teachers has met with militant opposition from two major teacher organizations.

Armour Co., the nation's second largest meat processor, increased its sales in the six months ended on April 29 from those of a year earlier, but earnings declined, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.
The sugar futures market reacted nervously yesterday to the news of the assassination of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina, dictator of the Dominican Republic.

During the next few days a new de luxe motor cruiser will leave Minneford's yacht yard at City Island bound for its home mooring at Franklin, La. It will be the sixty-seven-foot Maimelee, regarded as the largest fiber glass boat ever built.
Woody Herman, one of the major bandleaders in the days when big swing bands could be heard regularly in New York hotels, is back in town playing his first hotel engagement here in five years.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Cheering Republicans heard General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower assail the Kennedy Administration tonight with charges of "Government by Big Brother" and "immoral" deficit spending.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP) -- Don Zimmer and George Altman hit homers and drove in three runs apiece tonight as the Chicago Cubs whipped the Philadelphia Phillies, 10-3. The victory was Chicago's fourth in a row.
Next week, Schenley Industries, Inc., will open a huge advertising campaign that will cost the company $21,000,000 over a two-year period.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 1 (AP) -- The tenth assembly of the International Press Institute ended tonight with the election of four new executive board members.

NEW, ORLEANS, June 1 (AP) -- About seventy-five white pickets -- the first in several months -- turned out at William Frantz Public School today, carrying placards protesting the integration of classes.
DETROIT, June 1 (AP) -- Rain and a hailstorm forced postponement of the Detroit-Kansas City baseball game today with the score 4 -- 4 and the Tigers batting in the eighth.

SEOUL, Korea, June 1 -- South Korea's military junta was reported tonight to be considering holding a nation-wide referendum on the question of approval of the May 16 coup. Informed sources said the matter had been under serious study both by the junta and its Cabinet. A decision was said to be expected shortly.
A seasonal decline of 3,199,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
Bank stocks were the best performers in the over-the-counter stock market yesterday. Most of the issues in this group moved ahead in price stimulated by strnog institutional demand.
An extra shopping day helped the eight major department Stores in the New York metropolitan area increase sales last month above the 1960 level.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, June 1 (UPI) -- The United States consul-General, Henry Dearborn, said today that none of the 5,200 United States citizens here had been harmed or involved in any violence in connection with the assassination of Generalissimo Trujillo.
CHICAGO, June 1 -- Seven Freedom Riders opened a drive here today to recruit "hundreds or thousands" of volunteers to converge on Jackson, Miss., in new "bus rides to freedom."
HARTFORD, June 1 -- A major legislative obstacle was cleared today with an agreement in the General Assembly on a four-year, $150,000,000 intrastate road program.
BOSTON, June 1 -- Just when Ralph Houk thought matters were finally running smoothly for his Yankees, everything today went into reverse once more.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk has given his department's "full support" to the Justice Department's proposal for stringent rules against interstate bus segregation.
MEMPHIS, June 1, (AP) -- A master's touch with woods and irons helped Gardner Dickinson Jr., card a seven-under-par 63 and take a one-stroke lead in the $30,000 Memphis open golf tournament today.
DEVON, Pa., June 1 -- McLain Street, a gray gelding owned by Duffy Stables of Rye, N.Y., won his second open jumper event tonight in the sixty-fifth annual Devon horse show.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 1 -- Greyhound Bus Lines has quietly desegregated its terminal here in the wake of the Freedom Riders' challenge.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Representative Peter Frelinghuysen Jr. today bitterly denounced the Port of New York Authority and its newest report suggesting a jetport in Morris County.
MONTREAL, June 1 (Canadian Press) -- Kilmarnock of Scotland tonight scored its first International Soccer League victory by defeating the New York Americans, 4 -- 0.
New York's biggest union yesterday completed union-label coverage for all of its 225,000 members in the metropolitan area.
Twenty-seven years ago a 5-year-old girl journeyed uptown with her parents from the bleak tenements of the lower East Side.

RYE, N.Y., June 1 -- Mrs. Bruce Starzenski of the home club and Mrs. James R. Hand of Sleepy Hollow won the annual best-ball tournament of the women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association by one stroke at The Apawamis Club today.

RYE, N.Y., June 1 -- Mrs. Mandel Doppelt scored 40, 40 -80 over her home course today and won the opening one-day Class A tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association season by two strokes at the Ryewood Country Club.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 1 -- The Motion Picture Academy of Arts and Sciences, the artist-is voice of the movie industry, is trying to cope with an embarrassing situation -- how to curb excessive expenditures by men and women seeking Oscars.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, June 1 -- Retired Brig. Gen. Juan Tomas Diaz, whom the Government named today as one of the conspirators in the assassination of General Trujillo, was believed to be still at large with most of his group.

I am in wholehearted agreement with your editorial statement of May 30 that this is a year of unusual, even unique, opportunity for Republicans and Liberals to offer to the voters an outstanding candidate as an alternative to the present feeble administration of city affairs.

Production of lumber in the week ended last Saturday was 226,266,000 board feet, compared with 239,025,000 in the prior week and 234,749,000 board feet a year ago, according to reports from regional associations.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- President Kennedy nominated Anthony B. Akers today to be Ambassador to New Zealand.
The chairman of the Bowater Paper Corporation said yesterday that increasing costs of production had raised the question of whether the company could continue to absorb the higher expenses.
What brave man -- either city official or school official -- will finally step forward and take the blame for disrepair of the New York educational plant ?
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points off to 8 points up yesterday. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)
Some Board of Education employes were charged with "improper behavior" on school construction and repairs in reports submitted to Mayor Wagner recently by the City Department of Investigation.
ALBANY, June 1 -- Governor Rockefeller was told today that no more New York migrant workers would be sent to out-of-state farms unless conditions there were checked first.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Kennedy Administration assured Congress today that it would take a stand on limited Federal aid to parochial and other private schools.

THERE is very little new in the state of the food market this week-end. Summer fruits, such as cherries, plums and blueberries continue to trickle in, but prices will probably remain on the high side for a few more weeks.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- United States commercial exports declined in April to $1,655,200,000, which was 2 per cent below the March level, the Bureau of the Census said today.
LONDON, June 1 -- Spokesmen for many of the island territories of the West Indies Federation called today for full independence from Britain, at the earliest possible moment.

The new commander of the Dominican armed forces, Lieut. Gen. Rafael Trujillo Jr., is no stranger to military authority. He has been taking the salute of the country's soldiers since he was 3 years old, when his father made him a major in the army, at a reported salary of $350 a month.
A sociological study of teenaged venereal-disease patients has prompted the city to set up a special clinic for adolescents.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 1 -- Greenwich learned today that it has at least 3,860 reverse commuters, one of them coming from as far as Princeton, N.J.
Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel said yesterday that he had found a "large measure of agreement" with President Kennedy on the problem of the Palestine Arab refugees.

Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn took the lead yesterday in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association track and field championships after six events at Randalis Island. The rest of the program will be held tomorrow at the same place.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 3 -- Rutgers University will hold its commencement Wednesday.

ALTHOUGH we live in an age of blinding speeds, it has taken more than twelve years for Paul Claudel's "Partage de Midi," a play of rare and subtle facture, to cross the Atlantic. Adapted by Howard Hart and titled "Noontide," it arrived last night at the Theatre Marquee in a performance of hushed intensity.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The United States Government expressed hope today that a democratic regime would come to power in the Dominican Republic following the assassination of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina.
CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

CAMDEN, N.J., June 1 -- The Greater Camden Movement today announced the award of a $25,000 contract to Candeub Fleissig and Associates of Newark, community planning and urban renewal consultants, for a study of the central business district.

PITTSBURGH, June 1 (AP) -- Two home runs by Smoky Burgess and one by Dick Groat helped the Pittsburgh Pirates score an 8-2 victory over the Milwaukee Braves tonight in a game shortened to seven innings by rain.
A 660-foot race track for neutrons has been put into operation by physicists at Columbia University's new Cyclotron Laboratory at Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y.

Mme. Isabel Docq Mercy, the French "candy girl," had these parting words as she left by plane yesterday after a ten-day visit to the United States: "I had so much joy I just don't know how to explain it."

From the windows of apartments on Riverside Drive, from the banks of the Hudson River and from the decks of boats, thousands of New Yorkers these last weeks have focused on a single yacht riding off the Seventy-ninth Street boat basin.
The Citizens Housing and Planning Council has urged family-sized cooperative apartments rather than smaller rental units for the entire site of the Cadman Plaza slum clearance project in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- A straight "A" student, who said he was uncertain of only one word, spelled down seventy-two other youngsters to win the national spelling championship today.
LOS ANGELES, June 1. -- Samuel W. Yorty, defying the odds-makers and bosses, edged Mayor Norris Poulson out of office by nearly 17,000 votes in yesterday's election.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These rates do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.

WASHINGTON. June 1 (UPI) -- Helen Hayes, the actress, was criticized on the House floor today by a Congressman who said she accepted $2,500 a week to appear in three plays sent overseas as part of this country's propaganda effort.
SYRACUSE, June 1 (AP) -- Bob Porterfield was released today as pitcher-coach of the Syracuse Chiefs after, the club said, he attempted to take over as manager.
ALBANY, June 1 -- Governor Rockefeller today established two new state agencies in an effort to coordinate state, local and Federal construction programs.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- India, which probably introduced sugar cane to the world thousands of years ago, was brought into the circle of United States sugar suppliers today for the first time since the present allocation system was set up in 1934.

Your recent articles concerning the border situation between Pakistan and Afghanistan have been full of reported complaints of the Pakistani Government against "Afghan agents" or "Afghan elements" in the Khyber Pass area. It is interesting to note that most of your dispatches are headed "Special to The New York Times," and all of them are datelined "Karachi," while there have been no reports whatsoever from Afghanistan.
ELIZABETH, N.J., June 1 -- Two men were indicted today by the Union County grand jury on murder charges in the rape-slaying of two women in Plainfield last Friday.
Frank D. Doyle, executive secretary to Mayor Wagner, helped to rescue a neighbor from a fire in her home late Wednesday night.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Cardinals, surviving a ninth-inning rally in which Lindy McDaniel was belted for two home runs, knocked the San Francisco Giants out of first place today by defeating them, 7 -- 6.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) -- Two sons of Franklin D. Roosevelt with differing political views faced each other across a Congressional committee table today and found they agreed on a Kennedy Administration legislative proposal.

The racing scene shifted yesterday to beautiful Belmont from utilitarian Aqueduct, where thoroughbred activity had been going on since the start of the local season on March 20. A crowd of 21,267 came out for the opening-day program at the old Elmont (L.I.) plant, and the turnout was just about what was expected.

AS one who did not see Cyril Ritchard exercise his elegant charm as the peregrinating papa in the Broadway stage hit, "The Pleasure of His Company," this reviewer finds it hard to imagine him or anyone better qualified to play the prodigal parent than our own movie-acting Fred Astaire.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Following is the prepared text of former President Dwight D. Eisenhower's speech to a Republican Congressional testimonial dinner in the National Guard Armory here tonight:

EPSOM, England, June 1 (AP) -- The Aga Khan's mare Petite Etoile the 2-5 favorite, moved in front of Sir Winston Churchill's colt Vienna over the last few yards today and won the Coronation Clip or the second straight year.
LONDON, June 1 -- Harold Watkinson, British Minister of Defense, declared today that "an aggressor" could not assume that the West would fight a limited war.
Governor Rockefeller accused Mayor Wagner's administration last night of "complacency, indifference, indecision and lack of foresight."
TRENTON, June 1 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner urged today the passage of a bill that would broaden the powers of the bi-state Waterfront Commission to deal with criminal elements.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) -- The United States Government is again acting to stop the sale of Swiss cheese with bogus holes.

Three five-story buildings occupying a plot 75 by 100 feet at 20, 22 and 24 East 118th Street have been sold by Frank Woodfein to the Patristic Corporation. The houses contain forty-five apartments. They were sold for cash over a mortgage of $14,000 through the Philip Fogel Company, broker.
CARLE PLACE, L.I., June 1 -- A do-it-yourself fall-out shelter that will serve eventually as a snack-bar at football games has been built by eight students at the Carle Place High School.

OXFORD, England, June 1 (Reuters) -- Bobby Simpson and Bill Lawry today followed their unbroken 186-run partnership against the Marylebone C.C. at Lords by putting on 202 for the Australian cricketers' first wicket against Oxford University.

DAR-ES-SALAAM, Tanganyika, June 1 -- A state of emergency and a dusk-to-dawn curfew were imopsed on the island of Zanzibar tonight following a day of rioting. At least four persons were reported dead and 140 injured, many seriously.

Those of us who were hoping that the Kennedy Administration was going to move toward a more constructive foreign policy have been somewhat disappointed by recent events. These tend to show that the cold war has by no means been abandoned.
ATLANTA, June 1 (UPI) -- An Atlanta couple who operated a stock brokerage firm were arrested today on charges of misapplying more than $1,500,000 of clients' funds.
The first full-time chairman of the State Board of Mediation, Joseph F. Finnegan, was sworn in yesterday by Secretary of State Caroline K. Simon.
RICHMOND, Ky, June 1 (AP) -- Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson said today that President Kennedy would warn Premier Phrushchev the United States "has no intention of yielding to diplomatic blackmail."

The Sacramento Municipal Utility District, Calif., borrowed $30,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to complete the financing of the Upper American River Project. The hydroelectric power project is intended to provide 238,000 kilowatts of installed generating capacity.

YONKERS, June 1 -- The opening of a new $15,000,000 sewage treatment plant here today was acclaimed by public officials of the metropolitan region as a major step toward reducing pollution of the lower Hudson River.
The activities of the new Premier of Iran, Dr. Ali Amini, offer the best prospect in years -- and perhaps the last -- of progress in one of the sickest of the world's sick nations.
Charges of disorderly conduct against thirty-one anti-Trujillo demonstrators who invaded the Dominican consulate Wednesday afternoon were dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Maurice Grey.

The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York said yesterday it would seek closer working arrangements with hospitals and would offer to cover drugs for immunization and for chronic illness if its application for increased premium rates were approved by the State Insurance Department.
UNIONTOWN, Pa., June 1 (AP) -- Pennsylvania's first food stamp program under the pilot plan of President Kennedy got under way today in economically depressed Fayette County.
Gene Doriot Heil, who had accumulated a record number of 196 unanswered traffic tickets before he was arrested, was sentenced to sixty days in jail yesterday.

In his recent address to Congress President Kennedy told the nation that his Administration "has been looking hard at exactly what civil defense can and cannot do." One can only hope that the "hard look" will lead to a constructive, realistic program that the American people could accept and support, rather than look upon it with apathy, indifference and skepticism, as has been the case so far.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 1 -- Congolese troops of Antoine Gizenga's forces killed 100 villagers near Nyangenzi in Kivu Province last week-end, a United Nations spokesman indicated here today.
CHICAGO, June 1 -- About 1,600 meat truck drivers struck today against packers in the Chicago area.
A tentative settlement was reached here last night in a strike by 10,000 workers at twelve Long Island plants that produce electronic defense equipment.

WASHINGTON, June I (AP) -- Gene Woodling belted a two-run pinch double after two outs in the ninth inning tonight -- the only hit of a three-run inning -- as the Washington Senators beat the Los Angeles Angels, 3 -- 2

WESTBURY, L.I., June 1 -- Ante Bellum, the C. and M. Stable's 7-year-old pacing mare, burst through in the last sixteenth of a mile tonight to win the Roosevelt Raceway feature before a crowd of 21,146.
Every day in every way, the chances are getting smaller and smaller that Flushing Meadow Stadium will be ready for the New York Mets on opening day of the 1962 baseball season.
DORADO BEACH, P.R., June 1 -- Sam Snead's five-under-par 67 paced the field today as the United States team took the opening-round lead in the Canada Cup golf matches.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- The Christian Century, a nondenominational Protestant weekly magazine published here, asserted today that the American Medical Association had directed a "highly organized pressure campaign" of false statements and bad manners against the General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board transferred the three routes of Capital Airlines to United Air Lines today.
Will the recovery take the shape of a "U" or a "V?"

In two exciting bowling matches that went dewn to the last frame of each, Billy Golembiewski and Mrs. Shirley Garms won the men's and women's laurels last night in the third annual Ruppel-Brunswick Tournament of Champions at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Not often in recent years has the last article in Jefferson's Bill of Rights been interpreted in favor of a state by a strongly pro-Federalist Supreme Court Justice. But this week Justice William O. Douglas, with whom Justice Whittaker joined; wrote a dissenting opinion against a step in the steady expansion of Federal power, during which state resistance based on the Tenth Amendment has been a losing battle.

The West India Fruit and Steamship Company is offering for sale its six freight car and automobile ferries that formerly plied between the United States and Cuba. It said the trade had dwindled to the vanishing point.

PARIS, June 1 -- President Kennedy and President de Gaulle approached the heart of the matter today -- their divergent views on the Atlantic alliance and defense generally -- and decreed total silence on the substance of their talks.
The United States Immigration and Naturalization Service ruled yesterday that Herman F. Marks, a native-born American who served as executioner in Cuba for Fidel Castro, is a deportable alien.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) The Senate went on record today in favor of the establishment of a "white fleet" of vessels to provide prompt worldwide emergency aid to victims of famine, disease, earthquakes, floods or other disasters.
LOS ANGELES, June 1 -- Richard M. Nixon cautioned the Soviet Union tonight against appraising the United States as soft.
PARIS, June 1 (Reuters) -- Following are the texts of speeches by President Kennedy today to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization Council and at a civic reception held in his honor:

More vigorous enforcement of the trade practices laws regulating operations where this would appear to maintain the vigor of business competition was pledged yesterday by several spokesmen for the Kennedy Administration.
Russian history and Irish literature are the college credit courses to be presented next fall when "Sunrise Semester" begins its fifth year over Station WCBS-TV (Channel 2).
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 1 per cent below the level of a year earlier.

A hearing on a suit involving the producer, authors and backer of "My Fair Lady" will be held before a board of arbitrators Monday at 10 A.M. The hearing will be in the offices of Rosenman, Colin, Kaye, Petschek Freund, lawyers, at 575 Madison Avenue.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 1 (AP) -- The former Commander in Chief of the Albanian Navy and three other Albanians were executed yesterday in Tirana. They were convicted of having plotted to overthrow their country's Communist regime.
The nation's output of passenger automobiles in May showed some improvement over that of April, but it was below the level of May, 1960, according to reports from the leading manufacturers.

Little excitement found its way into yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. Volume fell. Not a single major group showed anything resembling general strength. At the close the market averages showed a small loss. Many more stocks fell than rose.

CHICAGO, June 1 (UPI) -- R. Sargent Shriver, Peace Corps director, said tonight the organization would work with Africans, Asians and Latin Americans as persons rather than "as members of a particular race, or citizens of a particular nation."

PARIS, June 1 -- Every three-day conference between allied leaders tends to follow a common pattern. On the first day, the great men proclaim their perpetual love and unity. On the second, they try to prove it and fail. And on the third, they write a communique saying that love each other anyway.

The apse of a ruined Spanish Romanesque church, moved here block by block and reconstructed in about the time it would take to erect a skyscraper, was opened in a preview ceremony yesterday at The Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park.
A collection of paintings, conservatively valued at about $3,000,000 will be auctioned to provide bequests left by Mrs. Anna E. Erickson, who died last February.
CUMBERLAND, Md., June 1 (AP) -- Allegany County school children began a mass inoculation today with orally administered live vaccine for poliomyelitis.

Production of paperboard rose in the week ended last Saturday to the highest level in more than a year and a half. The figure stood at 331,806 tons, compared with 324,167 the week before and 310,595 tons a year ago, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.

Former President Harry S. Truman said yesterday that he did "not like government by assassination," but that Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina of the Dominican Republic had met "the end of all dictators from Julius Caesar on down."

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Dwight D. Eisenhower returned to the capital today for the first time since he became a private citizen Jan. 20. He walked almost unnoticed through crowded hotel lobbies on his mission of arousing a will to win among fellow Republicans.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Senate approved by voice vote today the addition of 4,575 aides to the Bureau of Internal Revenue to check income tax returns for cheating or carelessness.
BONN, Germany, May 31 -- A television series on the Hitler era has been concluded in West Germany and indications are that many viewers thought the series unfair.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Justice Hugo L. Black of the Supreme Court was honored tonight at a dinner put on by the Fund for the Republic.

SHIRAZ, Iran, May 26 -- One-third of the population in the south-central Iranian province of Fars lives in coarse, black tents, forages for food and sells a goat now and then to buy a piece of cloth in the bazaar.
THE quarter-final round of the Reisinger Championship, blue ribbon team event of the twelve-day Eastern States contract bridge championships, will be played tonight at the Statler Hilton Hotel.
MUNDA FORT, Pakistan, June 1 -- Pakistan unveiled today some of her defenses against what she considers a threat from neighboring Afghanistan.
JERSEY CITY, June 1 -- With a good deal of shouting and heckling, 400 persons today watched a drawing for ballot positions for this city's run-off election in twelve days.
PARIS, June 1 -- At least sixteen persons were killed and thirty-seven injured when several hundred square yards of ground caved in today in suburban Clamart.

CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) -- Influences in the grain trade today were feeble and prices showed no indication at any time of any significant move in either direction. Net changes at the close were limited mainly to small fractions.
Young Rubicam, Inc., the third largest agency in the world, and Dentsu Advertising of Japan, the fifth largest, are planning an affiliation.
PARIS, June 1 (AP) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy held a receiving line interview with women reporters today and declared that she was enjoying her state visit to France "terribly."

Samuel Goldwyn, the motion picture producer, who was awarded $300,000 damages against film distributors in Federal District Court in San Francisco on Wednesday, said here yesterday he planned to file an appeal with the state's Appellate Division.
The Securities and Exchange Commission's regional office here won permanent injunctions yesterday in Federal Court against two financial concerns and the top manage ment of both for alleged fraud.

NOT even the gray light of a dismal early morning could dull the lush green beauty of Belmont Park yesterday. The dowager queen of the turf was at her resplendent best for the opening of the spring season and ready for tomorrow's classic Belmont Stakes.

NOT even the gray light of a dismal early morning could dull the lush green beauty of Belmont Park yesterday. The dowager queen of the turf was at her resplendent best for the opening of the spring season and ready for tomorrow's classic Belmont Stakes.

A GASTRONOMIC controversy over the name of the late, great chef Auguste Escoffier is simmering quietly in Manhattan. It involves a recently formed group known as The Escoffiers, Inc., and a quarter-of-a-century old non-profit organization known as Les Amis d'Escoffier whose membership numbers about 250 in New York.

THERE is always room for another book about a great human experience or about a great human being. Because good books exist about the Battle of Gettysburg and the Western migration of the pioneers is no reason why there should not be more. And there will be more.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission and one of the commissioners disagreed today over President Kennedy's plan for reorganizing the agency.

DETROIT, June 1 -- A survey of transportation equipment and facilities of significant importance to the nation's defense has been undertaken by the National Defense Transportation Association and the Office of Civil and Defense Mobilization.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 1 -- Lieut. Gen. Rafael Trujillo Jr., 32-year-old son of the assassinated dictator, was named tonight to head all Dominican armed forces in a move to preserve the Trujillo dynasty.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 -- Eight men from this area, most of them churchmen, have organized "Freedom Writers" to seek a million signatures in support of the Freedom Riders in the South.
IN the current issue of The Shakespeare Newsletter, Louis Marder. its indomitable editor, emits a few groans over the excess of Shakespearean comment.

LOS ANGELES, June 1 -- A stubborn, little fellow who "always knew" he would be Mayor realized his ambition today to head the nation's third largest city. Samuel William Yorty, whose faith was shared by few politicians, owed much of his appeal at the polls to his Midwestern birth, his opportunism and his independence.
RAPID CITY, S.D., June 1 (AP) -- An African highway engineer who was refused restaurant service here wrote his embassy today that the incident was unfortunate but not serious.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Only a radical new Federal transportation policy will save the nation's railroads and other carriers from financial breakdown, the New York Central System's chief said today.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) -- Joe Louis, a former world heavyweight boxing champion, to a Senate committee today the fight game had become a disgrace that badly needed a czar to clean it up.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 1 (AP) -- Betsy Rawls set a course record of 69 for women today in taking the first-round lead in the women's Western open golf tournament.

LUANDA, Angola, June 1 -- Terrorists continued their attacks during the last twenty-four hours. Ten raids were staged along the northern border of Cabinda District, the Congo River and inside northern Angola.

Josef Kupper of Switzerland continued undefeated in the fourth round of the international chess masters tournament at the Congress House, Zurich, according to a report received from Switzerland yesterday.

With the eyes of thousands of persons fastened on him, an unemployed father of five children balanced precariously for an hour atop the flashing sign above the Manhattan Hotel last night before returning to safety.

PARIS, June 1 -- Following are the menus for the luncheon given today by President and Mrs. Kennedy for President and Mme. de Gaulle at the United States Embassy residence and for the dinner given tonight by the de Gaulles at the Versailles Palace:

PARIS, June 1 -- Eighteen helicopters held the center of the stage at the air show in Paris today. One after another, while thousands of spectators watched, they climbed straight up into the cold gray afternoon sky above Le Bourget airfield.
High grade bonds continued to slide downward in price yesterday, forcing up the market investment yields on United States Government obligations and other basic fixed-income investments.
The Air Reduction Company is planning to expand its activities into the carbon, graphite products and electronics fields through a proposed acquisition of the Speer Carbon Company.

GREAT NECK, L.I., June 1 -- Mrs. Pat Cici of Lido Country Club took the low-gross award with 41, 40 -- 81 in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association tournament at the Glen Oaks Club today. Mrs. Allan A. Ryan of The Creek Club was second in the fifty-six-player field with 41, 42 -- 83.

ALBANY, June 1 -- The Court of Appeals granted today an out-of-state life insurance company permission to acquire a controlling stock interest in a fire and casualty insurance company. The decision reversed two findings by lower courts, two opinions by the State Superintendent of Insurance and one opinion by the State Attorney General all of which had barred such an acquisition.
ALBANY, June 1 -- New equalization rates that will probably increase the real estate taxing power of New York City were announced today by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., and White, Weld Co. and associates submitted the winning bid for $30,000,000 of 5 1/8 per cent twenty-five year debentures of the Columbia Gas System yesterday.
GENEVA, June 1 -- Ambassador W. Averell Harriman will fly to Paris tomorrow to discuss with President Kennedy the deadlock in the conference here on the future of Laos.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A Navy spokesman said today that an announcement of plans for submarine detection tests with a high-powered sonar transmitter had not included material endangering national security.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 1 (AP) -- A four-day hearing on charges of police refusal to protect Freedom Riders from a mob ended today with an emphatic denial from Montgomery's Police Commissioner.

Handel's oratorio "Solomon" will open the sixteenth annual Caramoor Festival in Katonah, N.Y. Alfred Wallenstein, musical director of the festival, will conduct the Caramoor Chorus and Orchestra in the work on Saturday evening, June 17, to start the two-week concert series.
JACKSON, Miss., June 1 (AP) -- A group of jailed Freedom Riders began a fast today to protest segregation in Southern train and bus depots.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- President Kennedy's nomination of Joseph P. Kelly as Collector of Customs of the Port of New York was announced today. Mr. Kelly, a Democrat, was New York State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles from 1955 to 1959, when W. Averell Harriman was Governor.

VIENNA, June 1 -- The Austrian Foreign Ministry and the diplomatic corps were disturbed today by the Soviet Ambassador's invitation to all ambassadors and ministers in Vienna to a reception for Premier Khrushchev tomorrow.
