Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower will present the trophy to the winning owner of the Belmont Stakes tomorrow. General and Mrs. Eisenhower, who will be the guests of John W. Hanes, the chairman of the board of the New York Racing Association, will arrive at the clubhouse entrance of Belmont Park at 11:30 A.M.

Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower will present the trophy to the winning owner of the Belmont Stakes tomorrow. General and Mrs. Eisenhower, who will be the guests of John W. Hanes, the chairman of the board of the New York Racing Association, will arrive at the clubhouse entrance of Belmont Park at 11:30 A.M.
PARIS, June 1 -- President de Gaulle gave President Kennedy tonight a taste of the grandeur of French life of days gone by.
George S. Kaufman, the playwright, director and producer, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 1035 Park Avenue. His was 71 years old.
A prediction was made yesterday that the Kennedy Administration would wage "a wholesale assault" on the system of price leadership by which prices are set in many industries.
Lawyers for minority stockholders of a Guatemalan railroad controlled by the United Fruit Company yesterday asked legal fees of $8,500,000 out of a rate-case judgment against United Fruit.

Events today: Broadway Symphony Orchestra, Rosario Carcione, conductor, Aldona Kepalaite, pianist, Broadway Congregational Church, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street, 8:30 P.M.; Golden Hill Chorus, Charles Ennis, conductor, Town Hall, 8:30 P.M.; Kenneth Roberts, tenor, Masters Institute Auditorium, Riverside Drive and 103d Street, 8:30 P.M.
Fourteen teen-agers from an isolated county in Idaho left New York for Europe yesterday on their first journey to the outside world.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Six nations and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development committed themselves today to provide $2,225,000,000 in aid to India over the next two years.
RABAT, Morocco, June 2 -- King Hassan II reshuffled his team of Ministers today to form a Right-wing coalition Government under his personal control as Premier.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 2 -- The Government announced today that one of the alleged killers of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina had been shot to death early in the day after he killed one security agent and wounded another.

SAN JUAN, P.R., June 2 -- The emergence of Lieut. Gen. Rafael Trujillo Jr. in a position of power in the Dominican Republic following his father's assassination was seen by observers here tonight as a prelude to battling for control of the country.
MEMPHIS, June 2 (AP) -- Gardner Dickinson pulled away to a seven-stroke lead in the $30,000 Memphis open golf tournament today with a five-under-par 33, 32 -- 65.
VIENNA, June 2 -- The Austrian Government has assembled a security force of 7,000 to assure the safety of President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev in Vienna this week-end.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) -- The Senate opened debate on an Administration-supported $6,100,000 housing bill today, with opponents attacking key features of the measure.
"Pineapple Poll," performed by the National Ballet of Canada, will be the first presentation by the Columbia Broadcasting System under an international programming exchange agreement.
Methodists have relaxed the rigid code of behavior that once characterized members of the church, a survey conducted by the Boston University School of Theology indicates.

EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, June 2 -- The Algerian nationalist delegates told the French representatives here today that they would never compromise on the question of Algerian sovereignty over the Sahara.

An investment banking group headed by John Nuveen Co. yesterday won the award of $3,300,000 of bonds issued by the Maricopa County, Ariz., School District 210 (Phoenix). The group bid 100 with 3 3/8 and 1 per cent coupons, setting a net interest cost to the district of 3.4322 per cent.
LOS ANGELES, June 2 (AP) -- Emile Griffith of New York today remained a 2-1 favorite to retain his world welterweight title in a fifteen-round match with Gaspar Ortega of Mexico tomorrow night.

The six-story commercial building at 144 to 152 West Eighteenth Street, which was sold recently by Dr. Kurt E. Fontheim to a client of Walter Scott Co., has been resold to an investor. Assessed at $182,000, the building is on a lot 90 by 92 feet.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points up to 8 points down yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

PARIS, June 2 -- President Kennedy and President de Gaulle parted today in firm agreement on the defense of Berlin, better informed on their divergent viewpoints on other matters and with great mutual esteem.
Giulio Rinaldi opened a training camp in the parking lot alongside Leone's restaurant yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Rail car loadings last week showed a slight improvement from the preceding week's volumes.
LONDON, June 2 -- The retreat by the stock markets continued today, but it was not as sharp as it was yesterday.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 2 (AP) -- Far down in the black water, the nuclear submarine Tullibee moved quietly in a game of hide and seek.

PHILIPPI, W. Va., June 2 (AP) -- This little town in northern West Virginia, where the first land battle of the Civil War was fought, was reminded today of the necessity to guard against a recurrence of factors that set the nation aflame 100 years ago.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said today that he was willing to accept some Congressional guidelines or limits on his new farm proposals.
The nation's three living ex- Presidents were in town yesterday, occupying hotel suites within a mile and a half of each other.

A biographical study of Premier Khrushchev is planned for June 23 publication by Praeger and will be titled "The Grand Tactician: Khrushchev's Rise to Power." The author is Lazar Pistrak, a specialist in Soviet affairs and contributor to The New Leader, The Socialist Courier and Problems of Communism.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg said today that the United States Employment Service would make special efforts to find summer jobs for foreign students, including Africans.

COMPTON, Calif., June 2 (AP) -- Bruce Kidd, a 17-year-old Canadian high school runner, bettered the American record for three miles tonight in winning the 5,000-meter run in the Compton invitation track and field meet.

DE AAR, South Africa, June 2 (Reuters) -- Eric H. Louw, Minister of External Affairs, accused The New York Times today of hypocrisy for having criticized apartheid in South Africa while whites were attacking Negroes in the United States' South.

The directors of the Sunbeam Corporation voted yesterday to raise the quarterly dividend to 42 1/2 cents a share from 35 cents a share paid in previous quarters. The new distribution will be paid on June 26 to holders of record of June 16.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Treasury gave birth to a new technique for Government borrowing today -- a "strip" of short-term securities.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 2 -- David L. Yunich, president of Bamberger's New Jersey, was inducted today as a member of the board of governors of Rutgers University. He was one of five officials installed.
Sales and earnings of the Brown Shoe Company, Inc., for the six months ended on April 30 fell from the record levels of the year-earlier period, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.
Diana Cullom Davis demanded yesterday that her father turn over to her a $3,800,000 trust fund that he had planned to give to Princeton University.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Gene Tunney and Jack Dempsey called today for strong Federal medicine to cure boxing's ills -- ills that Tunney said included permitting a badly injured man to fight for the world heavyweight title.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- President Kennedy's plan for the reorganization of the Securities and Exchange Commission was described as a "blunderbuss" approach to day by Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange.

Congressional criticism leveled against Helen Hayes for allegedly having accepted $2,500 a week to tour with an overseas theatre repertory company under State Department sponsorship was characterized yesterday as unfortunate and inaccurate.

MILWAUKEE, June 2 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Milwaukee Braves tonight, 3 -- 1, on Ray Sadecki's four-hitter and Ken Boyer's two-run homer.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Dr. Malcolm S. Knowles, Professor of Adult Education at Boston University, said today the only solution to the problem of illiteracy in adults was a Federally-subsidized program to educate the illiterates.

Maritime labor and management struck a note of harmony yesterday when they jointly dedicated a $1,560,000 clinic in which 30,000 waterfront workers and their dependents may avail themselves of free medical and dental care.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., New Jersey Democrat, introduced legislation today to ease the tax effect of the Supreme Court's decision requiring E.I. DuPont de Nemours Co. to dispose of its General Motor stock.
THE Charles Pope Choristers gave their thirteenth annual Town Hall concert last night. Based in Brooklyn, the chorus has about sixty-five members, chosen without regard to musical training.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating said today that Communist propagandists were using altered tapes of telephone conversations with individuals in this country as part of their worldwide propaganda campaign.
HONG KONG, June 2 (AP) -- If one wants to buy a pair of socks in Communist China, he must turn in an old pair in exchange.
WASHINGTON, Saturday, June 3 -- United States Naval units on the Eastern seaboard have been placed on an "increased alert" status, it was learned early today.
PARIS, June 2 -- "I do not think it altogether inappropriate to introduce myself to this audience. I am the man who accompanied Jacqueline Kennedy to Paris, and I have enjoyed it."

The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway's traffic so far this year has slumped seriously along with that of most other Eastern carriers, but operations have been well in the black because of improved coal traffic.

The hostess, Mrs. Vera Paley, saw to that.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The United States Tariff Commission found today that Portland cement from Belgium was being dumped -- sold at less than fair value -- in the United States.

SYRACUSE, June 2 -- A looping single into right field in the eighth inning deprived Dave Giusti of a no-hitter today as Syracuse and St. John's moved into the final round of the Region 2 National Collegiate playoffs.

CHICAGO, June 2 (AP) -- Grain futures prices climbed slowly but steadily into a generally firm range today on the Board of Trade while soybeans, in a tightening range, finished mostly about steady.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 2 -- Fair and mild is the weather forecast for this vicinity tomorrow night. If it proves true, the 6-5 morning-line odds against Adios Butler's winning the $25,000 Miracle Mile Race at Roosevelt Raceway figure to drop sharply.

Perhaps it is this even more than ever because many of the city's young people practice an almost desperate imitation of Left-Bank Bohemianism as if to compensate for the tenuous basis on which their Westernized life rests.

The Bartow Pell Mansion Museum and Garden in Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx, will be the setting Thursday for a tea and fashion show through which funds will be raised for the maintenance of the mansion and its grounds.
WILMINGTON, Del., June 2 (AP) -- The Delaware Superior Court denied today Sol Dann's motion to dismiss a $30,000,000 Chrysler Corporation libel and slander suit against him.
DORADO BEACH, P.R., June 2 -- Sam Snead and Jimmy Demaret widened their lead to six strokes today in the Canada Cup golf matches.
Mayor Wagner charged yesterday that Governor Rockefeller was indulging in "cheap ward politics" and "wallowing in pre-election name-calling."

CLEVELAND, June 9 (AP) -- John Romano's two-run homer in the eighth inning tonight broke a 4-4 deadlock as the Cleveland Indians scored a 6-4 victory over the Los Angeles Angels. The game opened a four-game series.
VIENNA, June 2 -- Premier Khrushchev has staked much of his prestige in the Communist world on obtaining profitable results from his meetings with President Kennedy here this week-end.
THE third week of fall showings by American designers on Seventh Avenue was rounded out yesterday. The clothes will be in the stores beginning in late July.
BOSTON, June 2 (UPI) -- Vic Wertz' fourth home run of the season, in the ninth inning, enabled the Red Sox to beat the Baltimore Orioles, 4 -- 2, tonight at Fenway Park.
ALBANY, June 2 -- The country's first state-owned storage facility for atomic waste will be on a 3,500-acre site in Western New York.
The meeting of President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev at Vienna today is the seventh summit conference scheduled by chiefs of the United States and Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Texas Republicans, here for the party's National Committee meeting, were optimistic today about a coming special election. They said they expected to pick up a Congressional district to go with the Senatorial seat they won in last week's special election.
DETROIT, June 2 (AP) -- Jim Bunning pitched a strong four-hitter and home runs by Rocky Colavito and Al Kaline carried the Detroit right-hander to a 2-0 victory over the Minnesota Twins tonight.
United States Government securities were marked down sharply again yesterday. The trading, however, remained largely professional.
ALBANY, June 2 -- Legalized bingo grossed $21,703,569 during the six months ended last March 31, the State Lottery Control Commission reported today.
CINCINNATI, June 2 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs barely overcame a Cincinnati ninth-inning uprising tonight as they defeated the Reds, 7 -- 6.
CHICAGO, June 2 -- Whitey Ford once again was the sturdy little man who put the Yankees back on solid ground.
Consumers whittled $139,000,000 from instalment debts in April, on a seasonally-adjusted basis, the Federal Reserve Board reported in Washington yesterday. In March such debts showed a small rise.
Financial arrangements for the purchase of A.H. Bull Co., Inc., by Manuel Kulukundis and his associates were completed yesterday afternoon at the offices of the Irving Trust Company, 1 Wall Street.
ALBANY, June 2 (AP) -- An attorney for an Ulster County resort has charged the State Commission Against Discrimination with engaging in "unfair practices."

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board testified today that the outlook for interest rates "depends entirely on what happens in the business picture." The Reserve System can "moderate" the trend, he said, but not "control" it.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 2 -- Three officers of two phonograph-record companies were sentenced today in Bergen County Court for conspiring to sell records with counterfeit labels. They had pleaded no defense on May 2.
TRENTON, June 2 -- Efforts by the Port of New York Authority to put a new jetport in North Jersey received another serious setback today.
Who are the nation's top five earners? A telephone company, two makers of automobiles and two oil companies.
Britain's currency, the pound sterling, has been showing signs of weakness recently in world foreign exchange markets, declining slowly but steadily in value as against the dollar.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Seven members of the Senate Public Works Committee today called for an extension of the billboard control plan on the interstate highway system.
EPSOM, England, June 2 (AP) -- Sweet Solera won the Epsom Oaks today to complete the British 3-year-old fillies' double.
Television-Electronics Fund, Inc., has reported gains of 27 per cent in total net assets and 23 per cent in share value for the six months ended on April 30.

PARIS, June 2 -- When Mr. Kennedy took leave of General de Gaulle this afternoon, concluding the formal aspect of his state visit, his normally austere French host grasped the U.S. President's hand and said: "I have more confidence in your country now." Thus the Paris phase of this European journey can be qualified as a real success.

The Lansdale division of the Philco Corporation announced yesterday that it would gradually discontinue manufacture of electronic vacuum receiving tubes this year. Lansdale said that it would step up production of transistors while dropping the tube line.
A red-haired, blue-eyed, tiny, very quiet heroine was joyfully reunited in New York yesterday with a Jewish family she had saved from the Nazis in Poland during World War II.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, retired, is expected to submit his proposals on the nation's intelligence operations to President Kennedy shortly after the President returns from Europe next week.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) -- The Inter-American Peace Commission was ordered today to consider a Mexican request for an on-the-spot investigation of charges that troops were training in Mexico to attack Guatemala.

Most people call her simply The Mary, this gigantic superliner which has had such a unique role in the story of great shipping enterprise. She has sailed more miles in the shuttle service between Southampton and New York than any other ship, great or small.
Chief City Magistrate Abraham M. Bloch said yesterday that he was working on a plan to treat alcoholics as "social problems" rather than as "criminals" if they were arrested.

THIS is a monumental history of the first two centuries of the enterprise resoundingly chartered in 1670 as the "Governor and Company of Adventurers of England trading into Hudson's Bay." It is described in a brief foreword by Sir Winston Churchill, Grand Seigneur of the Company, as an "epic of British enterprise, interwoven with the growth of the great country that Canada has become."

A FEW years ago John Hersey wrote a moving novel about the magnificent forty-two-day uprising made in 1943 by the Jews of the Warsaw ghetto. Reviewers of "The Wall" were virtually unanimous in their praise; and I, for one, felt that Hersey had written the definitive story of that incredible, courageous battle.

ONCE asked to account for his success, John Moses Browning (1855-1926) responded, "one drop of genius in a barrel of sweat." Reading Gertrude Winders' fictionalized biography of this gun inventor and designer who received 128 patents in his lifetime, one is well aware of the talent and toil expended in the gunshop.
WHITE PLAINS, June 3 -Republican leaders of Westchester County were in virtual agreement today on a ticket for the November election.

CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) -Equifun, owned by a former Chicagoan, John E. Hughes, who now lives in La Jolla, Calif., ran the mile in 1:34 while winning the $28,200 Beverly Handicap at Washington Park today.
An exhibition of Japanese "vernacular graphics" has opened at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

WAYNE OVERHOLSER has provided much readable entertainment in cow-country settings. Twice winner of the coveted Spur Award for "Best Western," this writer tends to concentrate not so much on things done as on why people do them, and this generally makes for more fully realized characters.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Norman Bass hurled a six-hitter as the Kansas City Athletics defeated the Washington Senators, 8 -- 0, today. It was the first shutout victory of the year for the Athletics.

BOSTON -- Beginning with the Boston Arts Festival next Friday and continuing through the yacht club regattas over Labor Day week-end, Massachusetts will observe the 1961 summer vacation season with a series of events aimed at exploiting the historic, educational and cultural traditions of the Commonwealth.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Details of a Senate subcommittee report criticizing Gordon Tiffany, staff director of the Commission on Civil Rights under the Eisenhower Administration, were made available today.

AMHERST, Mass. -- Most of the articles I have read of bicycling depict groups of happy teen-agers pedaling along the road, headed for some distant youth hostel. Few have recorded the joys of bicycling for those of middle age.

CORNING, N.Y. -- One of New York State's biggest and most spectacular man-made tourist attractions, the Corning Glass Center here, is celebrating its tenth anniversary this season. The Center has welcomed more than 4,500,000 visitors since opening its doors in May, 1951, and it hopes to surpass this mark in the decade ahead.
BOSTON, June 3 -- The tenth annual Boston Arts Festival will open next Thursday in the Public Garden.

HE has come forth and has spoken out more than anyone really had a right to expect. He has been an unusually generous adversary, loquacious, frank, well exhibited. But he has played, it seems, to a most unappreciative audience -- a world that still thinks quaintly of him as Nikita Khrushchev, the mystery man.

MOSCOW, June 2 (AP) -Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin complained today that Soviet journalists had raided his apartment, stolen his personal photograph album and family correspondence and had published both without permission.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 3 -- Sixteen debutantes of Greenwich and its neighboring communities of Old Greenwich and Riverside will be presented at the fourteenth annum Debutante Ball next Saturday at the Greenwich Country Club. Because the club building was destroyed by fire last fall, the fete will be held in two tents on the club grounds.
SYRACUSE, June 3 -- Syracuse University's baseball team started fast and finished faster to defeat St. John's, 12 -- 5, in the National Collegiate District 2 final today.

Federal District Judge Johnson has issued an injunction in Montgomery, Alabama, which is directed equally at the sponsors and opponents of the Freedom Riders Movement. Though Judge Johnson's desire to avoid violence is certainly laudable, the court's action has the effect of equating persons seeking to exercise their legal rights and others who are violating the law by trying to prevent such exercise.

The thirty-second annual Eastern States Championships went into its ninth day at the Statler Hilton Hotel yesterday with 290 pairs entered in the Open Pairs Championship.

NEWBURGH, N.Y. -- It has been a long time coming, but it now seems likely that a historic campground used by George Washington's troops finally will get its due recognition. The site is Temple Hill in New Windsor, five miles southwest of Newburgh.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -Nearly two months behind schedule, President Kennedy's foreign aid bill started through the Congressional mill this week. The delay was perhaps inevitable. It is easy to send a message to Congress proclaiming one's intentions to redirect and reorganize a program.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 2 -- Every day at 4 P.M. loudspeakers click on in Wenceslaus Square, the heart of Prague, and in the major streets. LONDON, June 3 -- Dinners at Buckingham Palace for visiting heads of state have become commonplace events in recent years but not for Presidents of the United States.

Deprived of its scoring ace, Roy Vernon, the 24-year-old Welsh international who was suspended last Friday, the Everton soccer team of England's First Division makes its New York debut today. The club will oppose Karlsruhe of Germany in the second game of an International League double-header at the Polo Grounds.

PARIS -- For what amounted to $100 in francs, my wife, my three children and I recently completed a round-trip journey from Paris to London by car. The money we spent for hotel accommodations and food during our week's stay in London was separate on our budget, but the cost of transportation proved surprisingly small. We went by way of the car ferry.
HAROLD SCHONBERG'S article, "Poles Apart," was an interesting one. His thesis that performers and musicologists would benefit by closer cooperation is valid.

THERE'S one thing to be said for theories that go to extremes -- they certainly cut down the wear-and-tear of making decisions. Take the matter of discipline: When an authoritarian approach was in vogue the "best" parent was the one whose children jumped when he said, "Jump."

HOW do you halt a party of Indians in mid-gallop when you, a lone traveler in Comanche country, are about to be run down? How do you tell an Arapahoe from a Sioux? Exactly what provisions does one need while traveling from Fort Smith, Ark., to the California gold fields?
A $30,000,000 all-year exhibit of merchandise has taken shape on the edge of Dallas on land that not long ago was subject to flooding.
Mrs. Wilfred J. Funk and Mrs. Cyrus McCormick, co-chairmen of the Southampton (L.I.) Horse Show Ball, met recently with some of their committee at the Sheraton-East to plan for the fete on Aug. 19.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 3 (AP) -- Mary Lena Faulk, a lanky professional from Sea Island (Ga.) Country Club, shot an 8-trader-par 67 today to take the lead from Betsy Rawls in the $7,500 women's Western open golf tournament.

LISBON -- The Hotel Aviz, which many sybarites considered the finest small hotel in Europe, quietly closed its doors and went out of business here the other day. After twenty-nine years, this symbol of fin-de-siecle luxury finally expired, crushed between mounting costs and Portuguese bureaucracy.

OCEAN BEACH, L.I., June 3 -- A meeting to protest plans for a fifteen-foot right-of-way for emergency vehicles between this Fire Island village and Kismet, five and a half miles west, drew 400 persons here today.

THIS latest poem by one of the Western world's greatest living poets (who will shortly be 74) is in large part a confident hymn to the future. Such ability to look beyond death ("We live on what is beyond death, and on death itself shall we live"), rather than bemoan the past or the supposedly carefree days of youth, is not the least engaging of "Chronique."
When he was 16 years old Mark Press achieved the highest score in the State Regents' examination for college scholarships. Now, four years later, he is still at the top of his class.

A price reduction for most grades of high density polyethylene has been announced by W.R. Grace Co., polymer chemicals division. The cuts, ranging from 3 to 5 cents a pound, affect a number of special resins and compounds priced up to 52 cents a pound.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 3 -- Fifteen years ago, New York won the vote as the site of the permanent headquarters of the United Nations.

Two school districts in the North Bronx are trying to erase the picture of the city schools as "a blackboard jungle" by inviting future teachers from nearby colleges to come and find out what they are really like.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -The new military Government in South Korea has picked a military man to be its next Ambassador to the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Because lichens thrive on fall-out and caribou eat lichens and Eskimos eat caribou, the Atomic Energy Commission may encounter unexpected difficulties on its plans to use atomic explosives to carve out a harbor in northern Alaska.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Kennedy's decision to meet Premier Khrushchev in Vienna this week-end was in line with Napoleon Bonaparte's remark to Czar Alexander I of Russia: "If they want peace, nations should avoid the pin-pricks that precede cannon shots."

Gains in personal income and cash farm income furnish the bright colors for the district and unemployment problems the dark ones, according to the monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Personal incomes are expanding at rates 5 to 6 per cent above year-ago levels, a substantially better rate than for the nation as a whole.

VIENNA, June 3 -- President Kennedy's trip to Europe has been important in a special way. It has helped put a few things back in perspective, including Cuba. It has helped restore the President's confidence, his sense of history, and his sense of humor, all of them vital to the success of his Administration.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J. -- The major state-operated parks in New Jersey's northwestern lake district have been the scene of brisk preparations for the coming summer season. In general, most of the area's lakeside resorts either have expanded their facilities or have spruced up their traditional attractions in anticipation of the usual crowds of bathers, picnickers and water-sports enthusiasts.
SALEM, Ore., June 3 -- Democratic leaders from thirteen Western states will meet on the slopes of Mount Hood next weekend. They will register some complaints about the Kennedy Administration.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 3 -- Judge Johnson said today he had not forbidden Freedom Riders as such to travel in Alabama on interstate transportation.

LOS ANGELES, June 3 (AP) -- Daryl Spencer broke up the game with a lead-off homer in the ninth inning tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers took a one-game lead in the National League by defeating San Francisco, 4 -- 3.

Activity in Wall Street was restricted last week with securities and commodity markets closed for an extended Memorial Day holiday. But the transition into a new month was made in a confident vein, as a number of pivotal issues under pressure a week earlier displayed a firmer tone.

An influential panel of mathematicians proposed last week that the Federal Government establish a retraining program which by increasing the knowledge of college teachers "could double the number of institutions capable of offering modern mathematics programs" in five years.

SEOUL, Korea, June 3 -- Reports circulated in diplomatic quarters tonight that a reshuffle of South Korea's military rulers to reduce the power of Lieut. Gen. Chang Do Young was possible. General Chang is now chairman of the junta and chief of the cabinet.

IN recent decades, dance has been one of the motivating forces in the Broadway musical theatre. Indeed, in many instances, dance has said most eloquently what neither the spoken word nor songs could project.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, June 3 -- Two men and two women members of Southern Rhodesia's main African nationalist group, the National Democratic party, were arrested today after they had taken part in a "freedom sitters" campaign to smash the color bar.

HILLSIDE, N.J., June 3 -- The proposed Route 78 annoys residents of this Union County township and the neighboring Weequahic section of Newark. It has given rise to a controversy in which both sides are crying foul.

BUENOS AIRES, May 31 -- For years Argentines from top governmental officials to chagrined shippers, harassed riders and track walkers have been talking about the sorry state of the nation's railroads. But, just as with the weather, nobody ever did anything.

NEWARK, June 3 -- Richard J. Hughes, the Democratic candidate for Governor, declared tonight the American people no longer needed to be "merely educated" in civil rights; instead, he said, the need is for enforcement of these rights.

GENEVA, N.Y. -- As vacation areas go, it is hard, to match the Finger Lakes region for scenic beauty and recreational possibilities. The lake country stretches across eight counties of central and western New York State.

Two developments last week dramatized the manner in which General Charles de Gaulle has reoriented French policy toward Algeria since his return to power. At the Hotel du Parc in Evianles-Bains yesterday, delegates of France and the Algerian nationalist rebels began their third week of negotiations for a peace settlement.

MEXICO CITY -- It is a fairly ironic fact that the turbulent events in Cuba have been of considerable benefit this year to other parts of the Caribbean as regards tourism. Tourists are not going to Cuba these days, and the thousands of Americans, mostly from the Eastern states, who formerly went there annually and proceeded no farther, apparently decided in 1960 to explore more of the Caribbean.

MOTORISTS with a spirit of adventure will have a new road to conquer in Canada this summer -- the toll-free Trans-Canada Highway. With the exception of ninety rugged miles through Glacier National Park in British Columbia west of Banff, it will be possible to drive 4,800 miles from St. John's in Newfoundland on the Atlantic to Victoria on Vancouver Island facing the Pacific.
A 310-bed tuberculosis hospital in the Bronx will be closed next year over the protest of its medical director.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board appears ready to eliminate private clubs of airlines unless they open their membership to all passengers and stop giving members such special privileges as free drinks and check-cashing services.

LOVE and flowers may bloom in June for much of the world, but investigations are going to be the thing of the month for television. The broadcasters, just recovering from the ministrations of Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, are booked for some more baths in the headlines.
Ramfis and Rhadames, the names by which the two sons of the late Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina are known, reflect the slain dictator's penchant for culture.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Inter-American Development Bank is seeking to interest some of Europe's more stable economies in Latin American development.

The world's eyes this week-end are centered on the meeting in Vienna of President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev, the two most powerful individuals on this planet. It is a dramatic confrontation, for behind each of the two men is a different world, a different philosophy, and a different set of values. President Kennedy speaks for the cause of freedom.
While reading with the keenest interest Mr. Schonberg's enlightening article, "Poles Apart," I kept thinking how much it would have pleased one of the greatest musicians of our time, Wanda Landowska.

The International Association of Great Lakes Ports, meeting in Chicago last week, elected Ernest B. Griffith, Toronto port director, as association chairman for 1962. Mr. Griffith and Clifford W. Morgan of Hamilton, Ont., were selected directors of the association's Canadian division, consisting of fifteen port managers.

COULD the reference by Ved Mehta in his review of "A Tagore Reader" to "What * * * Schiller did for Shakespeare" possibly be explained by a confusion of names? The foremost German Shakespeare translator was A.W. von Schlegel (1767-1845), outside Germany mainly known for his relationship with Mme. de Stael.

Thomas Alva Edison went to school for only three months. That was in the one-room Engle Academy in Port Huron, Mich., in 1855, when he was eight years old. Today, more than a century later, a portrait bust of the man who became the symbol of the American inventive genius will be installed in the Hall of Fame for Great Americans on New York University's campus in the Bronx.

IN her new and excellent historical novel, Zoe Oldenbourg brings back to us the cruelty and terror of one of the unhappiest episodes in the long story of man's inhumanity to man -- an episode so shocking and so brutal that it would be difficult to accept today as reality had we not before us the dispatches from the Tel Aviv courtroom where Adolf Eichmann is on trial.
ABADAN, Iran, May 25 -Oil-exporting Abadan views the peaceful revolution of Premier All Amini through a reversed telescope.
Jose Rigores, knocked out at St. Nicholas Arena Monday night, died at 3 A.M. yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 25 years old.

GRAND JUNCTION, Colo. -- Almost exactly fifty years ago, President William Howard Taft signed a proclamation setting aside the Colorado National Monument as a public preserve. The 18,000-acre site is the greatest sideshow of geological freaks in the high Rockies, and its drawing power today is stronger than ever.

WASHINGTON -- A boundary line, run by two British surveyors between Maryland and Pennsylvania in the years 1763-67, although important enough in its time in settling a gigantic real estate dispute, was later to attain a much more spectacular significance.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 3 (AP) -- E.B. Johnston's Darling June lived up to her reputation as a stretch-runner today and captured the $29,050 Hollywood Express Handicap at Hollywood Park.
THE day they broke the record at WNYC brought no joy to the city station but it produced happy results.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) -- Glenn T. Seaborg, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, announced today that Dr. Hans A. Bethe, Cornell University physics professor, had been named winner of the commission's Enrico Fermi Award for 1961.

A NEW vitality has become evident in Italian film-making in the last year or so for the first time since neo-realism went the way of all trends. Italian motion-picture exports are up, box office returns for Italian films of all kinds are up but most notably both critics and the public are, for the first time, strongly supporting quality fare turned out by Italian producers.

I am a mother of four (teen-ager to toddler), live in the country, have no help and a very small budget. However, I am proud to say that my home is stunning compared to that which you have pictured in the article "When Pattern Predominates" (May 7).
Sales of industrial chemicals are moving upward, after a decline that lasted nine months.

"MASQUERADE" starts out, like many a junior novel, to be the story of a group of girls weaving in and out of each other's lives during their first year at a new school. Liz Gordon, the central character, is a vital, outgoing girl who has come to Philadelphia ostensibly to study dress design, but actually to forget an unhappy love affair.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 3 (AP) -- Denmark took a 4-0 lead over the United States as the interzone semifinals of the Thomas Cup badminton tournament began today.

"Nobody was prepared! They didn't have the stock!" This is one Manhattan distributor's excited assessment of the strain on the toy industry imposed by the Yo-yo (capital letter because it's trade-marked) boom that has struck New York. Said an officer of the David F. Duncan Co., largest manufacturers of Yo-yos: "It's approaching hula-hoop proportions."

IN last Sunday's column, which discussed the varying reactions to the New English Bible's translation of the New Testament, space did not permit closer examination of the reasons why there have been successive revisions of the traditional King James text.

IN 1957, after insisting on carrying his own bags up a steep flight of steps, Peter Freuchen died suddenly while en route to the North Pole. Except for Richard E. Byrd, and despite his foreign beginnings, Freuchen was perhaps better known to more people in the United States than any other explorer of our time.
MADRID, June 3 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco launched a scathing attack here today on Western policy, on capitalism, on liberalism and on democracy in general.
CARMEL, N.Y., June 3 -- Sybil Ludington, a little-known Revolutionary War heroine who aroused the militia against the Redcoats in 1777, achieved a lasting memorial here today.

SAN QUENTIN prison and surrounding Marin County, California, were for nearly twenty years the news beat of Bernice Freeman Davis of The San Francisco Chronicle. But the focal point of this disturbing book is the dilemma of the occupants of Death Row.

Recent studies prepared by local statistical organizations agree that the 1960-1961 recession was milder in New England than in the United States as a whole. Figures for overall employment, personal incomes, and retail sales here have been showing up better than the national averages.

NORTH of the Canadian mainland lies a vast archipelago of islands, surrounded by a drifting, ever-changing mass of pack ice. Wind and tide so change the extent and location of this shifting ice, that any ship venturing into these regions can be trapped, held and sometimes crushed and sunk in a matter of hours.

Les Moglen, a 20-year-old junior at Columbia, has extended the family reign of varsity tennis captaincy to three years. Moglen, whose older brother Lloyd was the net captain in 1960, was reelected for a second year yesterday.

THIS present volume is one in a series by the retired English school teacher who writes under the pseudonym of "Miss Read." American readers have had good cause to be grateful for her "Village School," "Village Diary," "Storm in the Village" and "Thrush Green," all of them obvious exercises in autobiography.

FOR THIS WEEK: Visit rose gardens to select new varieties or old favorites for future planting. . . . Sow strawflowers for drying in the fall. . . . Finish planting chrysanthemums. . . . Set out caladiums, ferns, tuberous begonias or impatiens for color in a shady area. . . . Plant another row of corn. . . .
TEANECK, N.J., June 3 -- Plans for an institute on African affairs, to be opened in September, have been announced by Fairleigh Dickinson University.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -More visitors come to Florida during July and August than in any other two months of the year, the Florida Development Commission announced recently.

TEN years ago a vice president of the National Broadcasting Company summoned an interviewer from the network's personnel department and informed her that she was going to have a new job -- to produce religious programs for television.

A DESERT minstrel and a desert prince, the one as mighty in song as the other is in statecraft, are the heroes of this exotic but wonderful tale of the Central Sahara. Though only one of the youths wins the beautiful Tiu'elen, wise and brave daughter of a holy Marabut, there is a sweetly sad-happy ending for both the rivals.
VIENNA, June 3 -- Here in the home of the waltz, schmaltz, hot dogs and Habsburgs, the two most powerful men in the world met today in a music room.

DORADO BEACH, P.R., June 3 -- Two Americans of the game's old guard find golf in the tropics to their liking. Sam Snead and Jimmy Demaret increased their lead again in the Canada Cup matches today at the Dorado Beach Golf Club course.

HUNTINGDON VALLEY, Pa., June 3 -- A 3-year-old Kerry blue terrier of Canadian birth, Ch. Kerrycroft's Mister O'Rourke, owned and handled by Mrs. J.R. Christ of Boyertown, Pa., was adjudged best in show today at the thirty-fifth annual Huntingdon Valley Kennel Club show.
The New York-Washington land New York-Boston routes appear to have been chosen as a testing ground for two widely different concepts of air travel.

TO hail this book as the definitive Irish-American, middle-class, Catholic novel would do it an injustice. It is all of that, much more than "the Last Hurrah" was, but to approach it so would be to veer aside before one ever got to the real subject. The subject is Grace.
ALBANY -- Tourists considering a summer vacation in New York State will find a rich and varied hill of fare available at budget prices in the state's extensive and expanding park system.

LONDON, June 3 (AP) -Britain, South Africa, West Germany and Poland gained the quarter-finals of the Davis Cup European Zone tennis competition today. Italy, France, Spain and Sweden needed only one more victory apiece to advance.

ALL postal administrations at times have a surplus stock of stamps. Periodically this surplus stock is destroyed, although some Iron Curtain countries, and Ghana, recently, have followed a practice of canceling remainders "to order," ostensibly to make stamps available to collectors at a lower price, but a much-frowned-upon practice.
Design details of the "porous wing" plane, one of the most promising craft in the Air Force research program, have been disclosed by the Northrop Corporation.
Milton Bracker's bouquet of verses was as welcome and as fresh as flowers in the spring ("A Bouquet of Verses for Paris in the Spring," May 14). His delightful poetry inspired the following:

THE word drifting down the Housatonic River to Manhattan was that when the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre opened its seventh season at Stratford, Conn., next week, one or more of the plays in the repertory would have striking parallels to contemporary events.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- The mountain laurel, Pennsylvania's state flower, is in full bloom now. This shrub, which forms an undercover in the forest, puts forth deep pink buds that open to form densely packed clusters of white flowers.

VIENNA, June 3 -- Soviet and East European observers in Vienna have privately expressed surprise and misgivings with what they consider to be massive and aggressive public preparations for the Kennedy-Khrushchev conversations.

GENEVA, June 2 -- If, as experts contend, patience, precision and alertness are the hallmarks of sound diplomacy, then the diplomats of the new Administration in Washington have made an impressive debut at the international conference here on the future of Laos.
If Congress goes along with the wishes of the Kennedy Administration, the Government's military-civilian program to develop communications satellites will soon be expanded appreciably.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 3 -- Dr. Juscelino Kubitschek, who was succeeded as President of Brazil by Janio Quadros four months ago, is a candidate for a Senate seat in an election tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The population of Puerto Rico increased only 6.3 per cent between 1950 and 1960, the Census Bureau reported today. The increase in the previous five decades had averaged more than 18 per cent.

The sixty-passenger hydrofoil Flying Fish will return to Puerto Rico in September to open a regular service, the owners said yesterday. The craft has been operated in experiments on the West Coast for the last five months.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 3 -- Lieut. Gen. Rafael Trujillo Jr. declared today that the Dominican authorities were holding fewer than sixty suspects in connection with the assassination of his father, Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- The Yankees today suffered what will have to go down as their most painful defeat to date this season. After blowing a three-run lead to the White Sox in the eighth inning, the Bombers came down with a final crash in the thirteenth when Roy Sievers smacked a homer that gave Al Lopez' Chicagoans a 6-to-5 victory.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 3 -- President Joseph Kasavubu is writing to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold about "the tragic situation in Kivu Province," the Foreign Ministry announced today.
John J. Horgan, sometimes called "Mister Cork," said this area in southern Ireland has made greater progress in the last few years than ever before in his lifetime.

THE recent military coup in Korea was undoubtedly upsetting for most Americans, who tend to think of our allies as democratic states, not military dictatorships. Indeed, much of the justification for the aid. technical training and arms which the United States gives to the newly independent states of Africa and Asia stems from the belief that democracy will eventually triumph around the world.

Signs that the expected internal struggle in the Dominican Republic is developing have caused alarm and put American naval units on the alert. Harsh repressive measures, which the United States would like the Organization of American States to investigate, are leading to questions and fears about the immediate future.

PARIS, June 1 -- For Pierre and Jacques, Jean and Roget big things are happening now that the sun is shining, the streams are running and the days are long and bright. The outdoors paraphernalia, closeted since the dreary days of last October, have been brought into the open again.

Retail trade in this area continued last week close to the level of the 1960 period. A spot survey of key department store executives showed that sales were unchanged or were at best slightly ahead of 1960. Among the weakest sales areas frequently mentioned were women's shoes and men's wear.

SEASON and weather conspired this year to produce one of the greater glories of gastronomy at its plump and tender best. This is the sweet corn of the South. Although a brief cold spell in the spring delayed the harvest, there is currently an abundance of top-quality corn in the husk flowing from the Florida fields.
DEVON, Pa., June 3 -- Natchez, a chestnut gelding owned by R.B. Snyder Stables of Denver, Pa., won the John Wanamaker Stake as the week-long sixty-fifth annual Devon Horse Show ended tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 3 -- Adlai E. Stevenson will fly to Caracas, Venezuela, tomorrow to begin an eighteen-day tour of all ten South American capitals.

The Consolidated Edison Company and the union representing its 20,000 employes were accused yesterday of discrimination against Negroes. The charges were made by three Negro witnesses during a hearing of the House Committee on Education and Labor, headed by Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Democrat of Manhattan, at the Federal Building in Foley Square.

Twenty highly selected high-school juniors will spend six weeks this summer at Union College, Schenectady, N.Y., to apply their carefully tested unusual scientific talent to pure research in chemistry and physics. Sponsored jointly by the college and the General Electric Foundation, the program will give the students access to 400 staff scientists at the G.E. Research Laboratory for professional consultation.

This corner recently learned of an executive officer in a large corporation who instructed the mail clerk to bring him a minimum of printed matter as he was finding it difficult to keep his desk clean.
BETWEEN the Indian silversmith and the Herald Square shopper lies an ocean of problems that Macy's hopes to help solve within seven or eight years.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 4 -- Eight midget ocean-racing yachts slipped between the breakwaters of Stamford Harbor early this morning after a fifty-mile overnight race from Mamaroneck N.Y., that had taken them around Stratford Shoal.
The Rev. Walter Donald Kring outlined yesterday the role of Unitarians in times of personal crisis.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI) -- The House Antitrust subcommittee announced today it would conduct hearings this week on legislation to prohibit auto manufacturers from financing and insuring installment sales of cars.
The Jewish Theological Seminary of America bestowed its Universal Brotherhood Medal last night upon Governor Rockefeller.
Republican city leaders, still unsettled on their candidate for City Controller in the election this fall, were attacked yesterday by Herbert H. Lehman.

Two city Councilmen made a special tour of Greenwich Village coffeehouses last night to determine whether Bach, poetry and bongo, served without alcoholic beverages, were entertaining enough to be taxed.
VIENNA, June 4 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Kennedy's farewell statement to President Adolf Schaerf at Schwechat Airport today:

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Bill Stafford, a cool cookie from the Catskills, indicated to Manager Ralph Houk today that the Yankees had at least one pitcher besides the redoubtable Whitey Ford capable of finishing what he started.
A kind of friendly turning of the commercial tables will be executed in London this month with the opening of the United States' first permanent overseas trade center.

NEW YORK television had its first municipal spectacular last night when two dozen city officials, headed by Mayor Wagner, presented an account of their stewardship for two and a half hours over Channel 13.
VIENNA, June 4 -- Premier Khrushchev said tonight that his talks with President Kennedy represented "a very good beginning" toward improving relations with the new United States Administration.
PARIS, June 4 -- The problem of Russian oil in Western Europe is like the weather -- everybody talks about it and nobody does anything about it.
Foreign exchange market was quiet during the past week. British pound sterling continued weak while the Canadian dollar showed a steady undertone as it fluctuated within a limited area.
CLEVELAND, June 4 (AP) -- Cleveland swept a doubleheader from Los Angeles today, 5-3 and 8-4, and ran its winning streak to six games.

The theory that the major right of education belongs to the state was assailed yesterday by a spokesman for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York as "secularism at its best and totalitarianism at its worst."
THERE were 156 qualifying contract bridge pairs yesterday afternoon in the first of two final sessions of the Open Pairs event of the Eastern States Championships at the Statler Hilton Hotel.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 4 -- Today's second phase of the Beach Point Yacht Club's annual three-day regatta was highlighted by the get-up-and-go of two Stars and a 210. These three boats overtook the entire International Class on the 9.4-mile course.
Of the six fifth-round games of the international chess masters tournament at the Moscow Central Club, five were decided yesterday. All were drawn, according to a report from the Soviet Union.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 4 (AP) -- Mary Lena Faulk of Thomasville, Ga., won the $7,500 women's Western open golf tournament today with a 72-hole total of 290. She had a 75 for the final round.
MOSCOW, June 4 (UPI) -- Russia's first space man, Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin, said today that "in case of necessity" he would have been able to pilot his space ship.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 4 -- The Radcliffe Institute for Independent Study has announced the selection of its first group of twenty-four scholars.

The telephone switchboard at the Municipal Building, which handles some 12,000,000 calls a year, will be relieved of part of this load beginning today when a new fourteen-position board goes into service for seven city agencies.
PARIS, June 4 -- United States authorities continued today their investigation of yesterday's crash of a record-breaking B-38 Hustler jet seven miles northeast of here. The three-man crew was killed.
The resignation of retired Rear Admiral Waiter C. Ford as deputy administrator of the Maritime Administration was announced yesterday.

An indication of the seaman's interest in contract bargaining issues is reflected in a survey completed recently by the 7,000-ember Marine Cooks and Stewards Union, West Coast affiliate of the Seafarers International Union.
Parents' associations must keep informed and prepared for social changes if they are to deal successfully with school integration problems here, a study showed yesterday.
Jesus Christ is an "incomparable storyteller" for the present generation as he was in generations past, the Rev. Dr. Terence J. Finlay said yesterday.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 4 (AP) -- A leading Protestant churchman said today that the segregationist White Citizen Councils in the South "do more damage to the security of the nation than most professional spies in the pay of Soviet Russia."
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 4 -- The Israeli Cabinet agreed today to ban the sale of weapons to any countries fighting to preserve colonial rule.
MILWAUKEE, June 4 (UPI) -- Home runs by Lee Maye and Frank Boiling powered the Milwaukee Braves to a 7-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today as Warren Spahn gained his sixth victory.

Chrislaw Productions, Peter Lawford's newly formed independent company, has completed a deal with United Artists for the production of films for theatrical and television distribution by United Artists over the next three years.

MEDIA, Pa., June 4 -- A 3-year-old white miniature poodle, Tedwins Top Billing, owned by Col. E.E. Ferguson of Hollywood, Calif., and handled by Anne Hone Rogers, took group honors and went on to best-in-show laurels today at the thirty-first annual Delaware County Kennel Club fixture.

WHEN the telephone rang at 6 o'clock in the morning Father Hugh Kennedy, pastor of Old St. Paul's, was awake but still in bed. Why old Charlie Carmody should telephone him at such an hour he couldn't guess, nor why Charlie should invite him to a party on his parishioner's eighty-second birthday.

In creating new playgrounds through a system of drainage canals and flood impoundments, south Florida faces the possibility that the complicated process of water manipulation designed by the engineers may ruin its greatest wildlife area and its best recreational attraction. Everglades National Park, world-famous wonderland of nature, could be irreparably damaged.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Both sides are stepping up pressures on Congress in preparation for the crucial phase of the battle over Federal aid to education.
LONDON, June 4 -- This old and stately city gave a young President a regal welcome tonight.
The Federal Maritime Board has been asked to determine how independent an independent foreign-flag shipping company can be in maintaining cut-rate services in and out of United States ports.

THE tonic effect of the two adapted Soviet short stories at the Cameo is so reassuring and satisfying that a customer can only wonder why on earth movies from Hollywood to Moscow don't dip wholesale into the world library of classic miniatures.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., June 4 -- Joseph Hunt's Inamorata and Ronald Smith's Caprice won today in races staged by the Riverside Yacht Club. The events were among the first of seventeen won in the East-of-Rye schedule for the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- On his way to speak in Boston last Monday night, President Kennedy passed a familiar statue of William Lloyd Garrison, the nineteenth century reformer. An idea for his speech came to him. He said he would like to have the Garrison quotation from the statue.
A contract for the construction of a $2,500,000 national headquarters building for Volkswagen of America, Inc., in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., has been awarded to Jos. L. Muscarelle, Inc., of Maywood.

On May 25 The Times published a report according to which "Janos Kadar, First Secretary of the Hungarian Workers (Communist) party, has indicated there is a possibility Soviet forces will be withdrawn from Hungary."

PITTSBURGH, June 4 -- Steel order volume, output and shipments continued to rise last week. It is now believed that results for June will not show much change from those for May. Earlier, some observers had predicted a decline.

THE term "playboy-diplomat" has been affixed to Porfirio Rubirosa for so many years that it may come as a surprise to some to realize that he is 52 years old. As a diplomat, Senor Rubirosa, known to millions of tabloid readers and a succession of five wives as Rubi, has evi dently served the Dominican Republic well enough to hold onto his diplomatic passport for twenty-five years.
Now that the circus has left town, it might be pertinent to note that the sawdust, which was once as much a part of the circus as the clowns, is no more.
VIENNA, June 4 -- The question of a possible visit by President Kennedy to Moscow was left unanswered by the President's meeting with Premier Khrushchev this week-end.

JERSEY CITY, June 4 -- Diplomas were awarded to 377 graduates of St. Peter's College this afternoon during exercises at Roosevelt Stadium here. Thomas Joseph Fallon of 836 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, was the class valedictorian.
The new format introduced by Life Magazine in its June 2 issue has drawn some mixed comment in the advertising trade.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 4 -- President Joaquin Balaguer said today that a formula for "certifying" electoral practices throughout the Western Hemisphere might be "a basis for discussion" to bring the Dominican Republic back into the inter-American family.

ZANZIBAR, June 4 (UPI) -- A new wave of knifings, beatings, burnings and stonings swept Zanzibar today. A Government official estimated that more than fifty persons had been killed in the political violence of this island off East Africa.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Supporters of a $150,000,000 urban transit program face a hurdle this week in Congress.

In 1949 the late Thomas Mann published "Die Entstehung Des Doktor Faustus" in Amsterdam. It was an account of the writing of "Doctor Faustus," in which he told of "the incubation" of the novel, its "sudden ripening" under the impact of world events and of the many hours of self-doubt and the trials that his self-criticism imposed upon him.

JACQUES TIFFEAU, the designer who is about as Seventh Avenue as the Eiffel Tower, took the long view of fashion shortly before leaving for Europe Saturday and came up with some predictions for the future.
Two Republican Senate leaders challenged Vice President Johnson yesterday to visit the South in support of integration. They said this would test his personal allegiance to civil rights.

ATLANTA, June 4 (AP) -- The Freedom Ride Coordinating Committee said today riders would continue to test segregation of interstate bus terminals and facilities in the South despite a court order curbing such sponsored activity in Alabama.

Mayor Wagner defended the efficiency and honesty of his administration last night in an extraordinary two-and-a-half-hour telecast. The heads of twenty-three city departments and agencies participated in the presentation.

Lehman in 1934, Robert Moses once said: "I knew when I accepted the Republican nomination it would be like trying to swim up Niagara Falls." The Lionel Corporation is planning to more than double its electronics operations by acquiring Hathaway Instruments. Inc., at a cost of $30,000,000.

The New York Chamber of Commerce went on record yesterday for abolition of the offices of Borough President and concentration of legislative power in the City Council.

DORADO BEACH, P.R., June 4 -- Two old golfing partners, Sam Snead and Jimmy Demaret, retained the Canada Cup for the United States today. They did it with a combined score of 560 for seventy-two holes, out-distancing Australia, the second-place team, by twelve strokes.
Your editorial in The Times of May 25 headed "Fool's Gold in New Jersey" poses a question long debated among citizens concerned about "evolution" in our country: Why no state mergers?

The enforcement phase of the Sanitation Department's clean-city campaign starts today, with 200 blue-uniformed Sanitation patrolmen and 1,000 field supervisors -- armed with summonses -- on the prowl for litterbugs.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 4 -- The first twenty-five graduates of the State University of New York-Long Island Center received B.S. degrees here this afternoon in a garden ceremony on the Planting Fields campus.

LOS ANGELES, June 4 (UPI) -- Felipe Alou's seventh-inning, two-run homer and the relief pitching of Stu Miller led the San Francisco Giants to a 4-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers before 47,463 fans today.

From now on, there should be smooth sailing for Irene Mayer Selznick's long-awaited importation of "The Complaisant Lover," a London success. Yesterday Mrs. Selznick made it known that she had signed Googie Withers, a leading British star, to act opposite Michael Redgrave in Graham Greene's comedy about adultery.

A random telephone survey of 100 homes in New York City last night did not disclose a single person who had seen Mayor Wagner's television program.
The city will start widening Thirty-seventh Street from Madison to Eleventh Avenues today to ease garment center congestion.
New York City warned eight automobile manufacturers yesterday to remove air-pollution sources from their new cars voluntarily or run the risk of being compelled to do so.
An anti-smoke order directed at a newly automated furnace of the Republic Steel Corporation in Buffalo has started a political backfire that may have statewide implications.
BOSTON, June 4 (Canadian Press) -- Americans should know more about the Canadian problem of living next door to the most powerful country in the world, Lester B. Pearson said today.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Kennedy Administration is negotiating with several more major defense contractors on plans to end discrimination against Negroes in hiring and promotion.

The New York Americans and Everton of England's First Division fashioned well-earned triumphs yesterday in the International Soccer League double-header at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- President Kennedy is expected to receive a recommendation this week that the Central Intelligence Agency continue both its present intelligence functions and its undercover operations abroad.
SEOUL, Korea, June 4 -- The concubine, for centuries a tolerated figure in Korean socity, became a casualty today of the coup of May 16.

LANCASTER, Ohio, June 4 -- Mr. and Mrs. Cyrus L. Fulton have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Lanman Fulton of New York, to Perry Lorimer Burns. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. David P. Burns of Larchmont. Plans have been made for an autumn wedding.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 4 -- A four-day Congress for Liberty and Democracy ended here today with the adoption of resolutions for united action against what was termed "Castro-Communist Imperialism."

Trading in the over-the-counter market slowed measurably last week and prices generally marked time.

EAST MORICHES, L.I., June 4 -- Two men were killed and one was injured here last night when their sports car skidded off the Montauk Highway in light rain and hit a tree.

But there was no blow-up either, as at the Paris summit, and the Vienna meeting as well as the President's whole European trip have been useful on several counts.

LONDON, June 4 -- It is fifteen miles from London Airport to Prince Stanislaus Radziwill's house, near Buckingham Palace, and applauding crowds lined the entire route to welcome President Kennedy to London.

First and Second Avenues between Thirty-fourth and Fifty-seventh Streets will emerge in the next ten years as the fastest-growing area for commercial building construction in the city, according to a realty investment specialist.

A great new find of beryllium in Utah in January of 1960 has led to an important breakthrough in production of the metal. Beryllium is lighter than aluminum and almost as strong as steel and has the greatest weight-to-strength ratio of any metal.

NEWARK, June 4 -- Backstage at Mayor Wagner's television show today, it was as informal as a political picnic until the camera lights winked red for "on."

The people of New York City last night saw or had a chance to see Mayor Wagner's marathon television program explaining the complex operation of the city government. The Spanish dictator lashed out at Western policy, capitalism, liberalism and democracy, the favorite targets also of Communist totalitarian leaders. And to complete the parallel, the Generalissimo announced that his form of dictatorship is the wave of the future, thus echoing a theme of which Premier Khrushchev never tires.

The Central and South West Corporation and its subsidiaries have reported gains in operating revenues for the three and twelve months ended on March 31. Net income for the twelve months was greater than in 1960, but, for the three months, was lower.

Commercial paper dealers yesterday raised by 1/8 percentage point the interest rate on the short-term notes of business borrowers sold by them in the open market. The change was made effective immediately.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 5 -- President Charles Robberts Swart, in his inaugural speech to both houses of Parliament of the new republic, accused the United Nations today of violating the sovereignty of member states and interfering in their internal affairs.
The local spiked-shoe set will scramble for twenty district titles on Saturday in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships at War Memorial Stadium in Yonkers.
LONDON, June 5 (UPI) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy ordered a box of clothes, on approval, from a London fashion house today for her children, Caroline and John, Jr.

The steel industry's operating rate declined in the week ended June 3 from 71 to 70 per cent of capacity. The downturn was the first in more than two and a half months. The week included the Memorial Day holiday.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Government gave informal encouragement today to the establishment of a committee to work out a plan for private ownership and operation of a communications satellite system.

Prices of United States Government securities broke sharply yesterday. The decline represented a collapse of the artificial levels to which the intermediate and long-term areas of the market had been "nudged" since late last winter by Federal Reserve purchases.

BALTIMORE, June 5 (AP) -- Backed by Ted Kluszewski's continued assault on Baltimore pitching, Run Moeller of the Los Angeles Angels stopped the Orioles, 3 -- 0, tonight for his first major league victory.
The appointment of Dr. Joseph J. Shomon as director of the Nature Centers Division of the National Audubon Society was announced yesterday.
Edward Albee has been named winner of this year's Lola D'Annunzio award for his "sustained accomplishments in original playwriting."

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The index of primary market prices remained unchanged at 118.9 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended May 30, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. An increase for farm products was offset by a decline for processed foods.
THE teen-age son who is promoted to "man of the family" when his father is absent though death or divorce often finds that the new responsibility rests heavily upon his shoulders.
LOS ANGELES, June 5 (UPI) -- Vernon Law gained his first victory in five weeks tonight and drove in the tie-breaking run as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Dodgers, 5 -- 2.

The Appellate Division ruled yesterday that three small children could remain with their Protestant mother even though she had made a pre-wedding agreement with her husband to rear them as Roman Catholics. The couple is now separated.

DETROIT, June 5 (AP) -- Gordon Watson, accused of first-degree murder and conspiracy to murder in the 1959 slaying of Parvin Lassiter, a wealthy auto dealer, was found not guilty by a jury today.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 5 (UPI) -- A top Government official said today Iran must have $40,000,000 in United States aid "within one week" if economic disaster and the collapse of the Government of Premier Ali Amini were to be averted.

ROBERT FROST, as far as I remember, said that a poem begins in delight and ends in wisdom. Applying this to three current exhibitions the consequence is reversed, for the first is wise, the second witty, and the third, which is not art at all, is rather delightfully insane.
The Department of Sanitation issued 690 summonses here yesterday as it launched the enforcement part of its annual campaign against litterbugs.
CHIGAGO, June 5 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer and Jay Hebert will set a target for the nation's golfers tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Organization of American States decided tonight to send a special fact-finding mission to the Dominican Republic. It will investigate charges of police terror and brutality following the assassination last week of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 5 -- The Government displayed today the bodies of two Dominicans accused of being the leaders of the plot that led to the assassination last Tuesday of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (UPI) -- The House overrode Administration objections today and overwhelmingly passed a tax-relief bill designed to help the self-employed save for retirement.

With the current baseball season getting hotter each day, it is pleasant to recall some of the unrivaled teamwork of the first decade of this century, hen our national pastime was then, as now, near and dear to many.

The twenty-ninth annual Edison Electric Convention opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to the usual warnings of creeping socialism and threatened Government power encroachment. Some 3,500 leaders of the investor-owned electric utilities are in attendance at the three-day session.

While one may differ over the degree of their success, the Republican county leaders, in consultation with Governor Rockefeller and the party's state chairman, have been desperately trying to assemble a slate of able men, attractive to the voters, for high city office. They have made an earnest search; they have had some disappointing refusals from likely prospects.

WASINGTONG, June 5 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today that a company had engaged in an unfair labor practice by recognizing a union as exclusive bargaining agent at a time the union had represented only a minority of the company's employes.

Carry Back's left front ankle is the current anatomical cause celebre of the thoroughbred world. Mrs. Katherine Price's colt, the 9-to-20 choice who ran seventh in the Belmont Stakes last Saturday, was thoroughly examined again yesterday at his barn at Monmouth Park and was found to be suffering from an infection of the left front ankle.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 5 -- A birdie 3 on the second hole enabled Dick DeMane and Nat Greenman of Engineers to win the Long Island Professional Golf Association pro-amateur tournament today with a 32, 32 -- 64 at Wheatley Hills.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 5 -- President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana has written to twenty countries suggesting a conference of representatives of all governments that have forces in the Congo under United Nations command.

HOUSTON, June 5 (UPI) -- Warren Giles, the president of the National League, put his "one-year approval" today on Houston's plans for a temporary stadium to open the 1962 baseball season. The stadium will seat 33,000 fans.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 5 -- President Romulo Betancourt has presented to Adlai E. Stevenson a Venezuelan plan for collective inter-American action to guide the Dominican Republic toward a democratic government.

MANCHESTER, England, June 5 (UPI) -- Chris Crawford of Piedmont, Calif., scored two victories today in the opening of the Northern lawn tennis championship, a tune-up for the all-England championships at Wimbledon later this month.
ST. LOUIS, June 5 (AP) -- Bill White hit a grand-slam homer and Carl Sawatski a two run homer in the seventh inning as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Chicago Cubs, 10 -- 8, tonight.

The Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company is taking its Schlitz Beer billings, estimated at $16,500,000 a year, away from the J. Walter Thompson Company and awarding them to the Leo Burnett Company, Inc., it was learned yesterday.

It has long been a popular American pastime to castigate railroad officials on their passenger services. Chemicals, electronics and most of the steels and motors advanced in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. Aggregate market value rose more than one-half of 1 per cent.
Thousands of commuters from Grand Central Terminal were delayed up to thirty-five minutes during the evening rush hour yesterday by damage to a third rail in the Bronx.
DETROIT, June 5 (AP) -- The production levels of nine automobile lines, including two compact cars, are each running at least 50,000 units below those of 1960.

THE crowds of curious Britons who stood patiently for the last two days in front of 4 Buckingham Place in London have been a strange sight to Princess Stanislas Radziwel, nee Caroline Lee Bouvier, 28-year-old sister of Mrs. John F. Kennedy.

Eight of the nine games adjourned from the sixth and seventh rounds of the masters chess tournament at the Congress House in Zurich were played off yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 5 -- Asian and African countries have agreed to ask the Security Council to call on Portugal to cease repressive measures in Portuguese Angola. The eleven-member Council will meet at 3 P.M. tomorrow on the Angola question.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- General imports dipped about 2 per cent in April from the March level after allowing for seasonal fluctuations, the Department of Commerce reported today. The total was estimated at $1,106,000,000.

DETROIT, June 5 -- Retail automobile sales soared in May to a new high for the year, according to manufacturer reports issued today. Preliminary sales figures indicated that auto dealers sold nearly 538,000 units in May, surpassing the 500,000 mark for the first time in any month this year.
VIENNA, June 5 -- President Kennedy is ending his European trip more convinced than ever of the importance of strengthening the nation's defenses and its relations with the Allies.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- At the request of Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, the House passed a bill today designed to make sure that persons perpetrating bomb hoaxes in airliners are punished.

PARIS, June 5 -- In France last week, guys and girls -- and hundreds of tired businessmen, too -- flocked to the 132 Go-Kart tracks that now litter this country. They sought a little fun and relaxation at speed.
The Bar Association of Puerto Rico has invited a group of New York judges to visit the Commonwealth from Aug. 13 to 21.

An unemployed air-conditioning mechanic went berserk yesterday in a densely populated section of the West Bronx and fired about 100 wild rifle shots before the police subdued him.

Sales of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., for the thirteen and fifty-two weeks ended on April 29 set new records for the periods. Earnings, however, dipped from the year-earlier levels as a result of very bad weather and the generally sluggish economy this year, the big department store chain reported. It noted that there were definite indications of an upturn in May.

In its first major diversification move, the Diners' Club, Inc., announced yesterday it had acquired Simpson Factors Corporation, New York, and its two subsidiaries, by means of an exchange of stock. Factors are concerns that buy accounts receivable and assume the job of collecting the money due.

LONDON, June 5 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy's triumphant tour of Western Europe with the President ended in Buckingham Palace tonight with "a small private dinner" for fifty persons. Queen Elizabeth II presided.

Jasimo Associates, a syndicate of realty investors, have purchased the taxpayer building occupying a triangular plot at 1274-96 Gun Hill Road, 1275-97 Burke Avenue and 3220-22 Bouck Avenue, the Bronx The plot is 160 by 150 by 150 feet.
