KEY WEST, Fla., Wednesday, June 7 -- Premier Fidel Castro has accepted in principle an exchange of tractors for prisoners who were captured in the April 17 invasion of Cuba, the Havana radio reported early today.

Demolition of the ornamental architectural plazas, with their sculpture, at both ends of the Manhattan Bridge seems inevitable as part of the reconstruction of the fifty-two-year-old span to provide connections for new expressways on either side of the East River.

STANLEYVILLE, the Congo, June 6 (AP) -- Antoine Gizenga, who asserts that he is the rightful Premier of the Congo, said today he was prepared to negotiate with his political enemies on where to reopen the Congolese Parliament.
Traffic injuries in the city last week totaled 1,052 persons, the police reported yesterday. This was a decline from 1,358 in the like 1960 period.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 6 (AP) -- The Naval Academy retired football jersey No. 27 today. It was the number made famous by a squat halfback named Joe Bellino.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- John J. Hooker Jr., executive secretary of the Tractors for Freedom Committee, announced today that its sponsorship had been broadened by the addition of twenty nationally prominent figures.
Sears, Roebuck Co., Inc., giant retail-mail order concern, reported yesterday that sales last month rose to the highest level for any May in history.

The nation's railways, using the full-cost accounting methods required of them by the Interstate Commerce Commission, operated their passenger trains last year at a deficit of $485,000,000. This was the smallest deficit since 1947 and compared with an operating loss of $544,000,000 in 1959.
Leading sales finance companies increased by one-eighth of 1 point yesterday the rates on their commercial paper sold directly to investors. The change is effective today.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 6 -- Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester Country Club and Mrs. Irving Kaufmann of the home club tied for the first-round lead in the women's Eastern fifty-four-hole golf championship today.
BOSTON, June 6 (AP) -- Phil Watson today was named coach of the Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 7 -- The Japanese Government, under strong Leftist pressure, shelved its controversial antiviolence bill early today. It thus suffered a political defeat on the heels of wild anti-Government demonstrations last night resulting in injuries to 600 persons.
The New School for Social Research held commencement exercises last night, during which it conferred graduate and undergraduate degrees upon seventy-six students.

Bank and fire insurance and casualty stocks were the best performers in the over-the-counter market yesterday. Most of the issues in these two groups made modest advances in price stimulated by good institutional demand.
A major expansion of the pulp and paper industry is under way in Finland. It is expected to lead to an improvement in the country's international trading position.

Fridrik Olafsson of Iceland yesterday moved into first place in the international chess masters tournament at the Moscow Central Club, according to a report from the Soviet Union. He defeated Edward Gufeld, Russia, in the sixth round and raised his score to 4 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces would blast back with nuclear weapons if they faced destruction under non-nuclear attack from Communist armies, a top pentagon official said today.
ROME, June 6 (UPI) -- A Pennsylvania Supreme Court justice gave Pope John XXIII today a report on the trial of Adolf Eichmann.
CAIRO, June 6 -- The United Arab Republic is talking back to the Soviet Union.

LONDON, June 6 (Reuters) -- London's fashion industry today worked at top pressure to meet a "just like Jackie" Kennedy sales boom that has swept Britain since America's First Lady arrived here Sunday.
An offering of 900,000 common shares of Public Service Electric and Gas Company stock at $52.25 a share is being made today to the public by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith Inc. and associates.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 6 (AP) -- Don Demeter and Clayton Dalrymple drove in five runs each tonight, helping the Philadelphia Phils crush the San Francisco Giants, 13 -- 9.
BALTIMORE, June 6 (AP) -- Chuck Estrada pitched a two-hit 2-0 victory over the Los Angeles Angels tonight as the Baltimore Orioles split in a twilight-night double-header.
A gang of youths -- nearly all from substantial and respectable middle-class homes -- was rounded up by the Queens police yesterday as suspects in thefts totaling more than $100,000.
Dr. Thomas Hale Hamilton, president of the State University of New York, deplored yesterday the lack of kindness in American society.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Business inventories increased in April for the first time since mid-1960, but sales results were mixed.

John W. Abbes Garcia was among the closest and most trusted associates of Generalissimo Trujillo. He ranked high in that group of powerful men considered certain to try to carry on the Trujillo method of government.
Ten years ago somebody -- name now unknown -- gave the Bronx Zoo an eighteen-inch alligator he had bought at a souvenir stand in the South.

During a two-fisted foray against a thick steak, eggs, olives, cherries and grapes yesterday, Giulio Rinaldi discussed his recent life and times as a challenger preparing to face Archie Moore for the world light heavyweight championship.

LOS ANGELES, June 6 (AP) -- John Roseboro pinch-hit a ground-rule double in a wild seventh inning and led the Los Angeles Dodgers to an 8 -- 7 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight before 15,784 in the Coliseum.
Armory Houghton, former Ambassador to France, will speak today at New York University's 129th annual commencement exercises, where 5,745 students will receive degrees.

SYRACUSE, June 6 -- Governor Rockefeller declared today that he was "very surprised and disturbed" by the Board of Regents' decision to pay public assistance for college students directly to private institutions.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Cleveland's rampaging Indians won their eighth straight game tonight, shattering the Washington Senators, 14 -- 3, with a sixteen-hit attack that included two home runs by John Romano.
HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., June 6 -- Al Feminelli, 37-year-old Dellwood Country Club professional, led twenty Eastern qualifiers for the United States Golf Association's Open championship today.
HARTFORD, June 6 -- Connecticut's legislators agreed today on a program of tax increases aggregating $122,000,000 for the biennium starting July 1.
CHICAGO, June 6 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

PARIS, June 6 -- The French Government announced today that further tariff-cutting in the European Common Market would stop after this year unless France's partners went along with a common agricultural policy.
Trading in commodity futures on New York exchanges was relatively quiet yesterday. Prices showed a mixed-to-easier tone.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 6 (AP) -- Jack Price, the trainer of Carry Back, said today he was encouraged by the improved condition of the ailing Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner. He said he hoped to have the 3-year-old colt ready for exercise by Monday.
Maritime labor set a new standard yesterday for contract bargaining.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Dr. Wilbur H. Goss, a physicist at the Applied Physics Laboratory, received today the Navy's Distinguished Public Service Award for his work in developing guided missiles for the Navy.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- President Kennedy reported to the nation tonight that his talks with Premier Khrushchev should at least have lessened chances of a "dangerous misjudgment" on either side.

The future of the United States will be determined more by the wisdom and discipline of its citizens than by the vast physical power at their disposal, Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday afternoon.

Dennis McDonald will make his independent managerial debut with "Out by the Country Club." The former vice president and treasurer of Theatrical Interests Plan a producing-investing, group, confirmed a report yesterday that he would present the play by Speed Lamkin and Eva Wolas in the fall.

RANGELEY, Me., June 6 -- Frank Porter, the most experienced guide in this area, repeated a cliche late this afternoon. He said a fellow is never too old to learn. And, he should know. He's a robust 88.

Carter Products, Inc., showed a slight increase in sales and earnings in the fourth quarter. It failed, however, to lift results for the year to March 31 to the levels of fiscal 1960, according to a report issued yesterday by H.H. Hoyt, president.
The possibility that rent increases will be required to provide more police protection in Housing Authority projects was suggested yesterday by Borough President Edward R. Dudley of Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- House subcommittee decided today to take secret testimony and recommend whether the Central Intelligence Agency should be investigated by Congress.
RIDGEWOOD, N.J., June 6 -- Fifty-nine children, 3 to 5 years old, were introduced to a new means of transportation today.

The directors of an insurgent Manhattan Democratic Club voted 19 to 1 last night to urge Mayor Wagner to run again. They also voted unanimously in favor of asking Borough President Edward R. Dudley and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan to run for re-election.

Senator Lister Hill of Alabama said last night, that unless there were a major increase in medical education in this country a crisis in the health and wellbeing of the American people would develop in a few years.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, June 6 (AP) -- The Katanga Government announced today a plan of cooperation with United Nations Indian troops.
An Air Force rocket soared 101 miles above the White Sands, N.M., Proving Ground yesterday in what was believed to be the first attempt to capture dust in space and return it to earth.

A one-day inspection of junkyards, dumps, vacant lots and cellars to locate abandoned refrigerators from which the doors or locks have not been removed was ordered yesterday by Health Commissioner Leona Baumgartner.
Please refer to your report (from The Associated Press) captioned "Pakistanis Strafe Afghans on Border" in your issue of' May 22.
ON a typical Monday morning recently a matron in mink and a millworker in overalls stood side by side studying a floor-to-ceiling, wall-to-wall display of hundreds of hasps, hinges and handles.
RYE, N.Y. June 6 -- Joseph Morrill Jr. of Great Barrington, Mass., a former Harvard football sta, took a two-stroke lead in the United States Senators' Golf Association championship today.
Parking meter manufacturers will be required to install, service and repair their products if they expect to get city business after the first of the year.
Antibodies that "home in" selectively on a specific type of animal cancer have been produced by scientists at Roswell Park Memorial Institute in Buffalo.
A dismal picture of city schools was painted yesterday at a public hearing of the Board of Education's Committee on Buildings and Sites.

GENEVA, June 6 -- The United States and Britain asked today that their draft treaty to ban nuclear weapons tests be circulated to members of the United Nations, thus demonstrating their readiness to stand on their record at the stalemated negotiations here with the Soviet Union.

Returning home from what he characterized as a "somber" but useful encounter with Premier Khrushchev, President Kennedy promptly submitted a public report to the nation last night in which he painted a grim picture of a world that must look forward to a continuing crisis in this decade.

Mort Sahl is back in town for the first time since the country changed presidents. He is bravely trying to bear as much malice toward President Kennedy as he did toward President Eisenhower -- but, plainly, his heart isn't altogether in it.

ST. LOUIS, Wednesday, June 7 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals beat the Chicago Cubs, 16 -- 2, in the first game of a twilight-night program last night. The teams played to a 3 -- 3 tie in the second game, which was called early today after ten innings because of a National League rule that no inning may start after 12:50 A.M.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz was designated formally yesterday as this year's Republican candidate for Mayor. His selection was announced by the five Republican county chairmen in the city.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Sharp Congressional opposition was expressed today to an Administration plan guaranteeing selected industries against the risks of investing in underdeveloped countries.
A Charter review commission should be set up every ten years to keep the city government's structure up to date, City Council President Abe Stark declared yesterday.
An organization has been formed to help television stations exchange locally produced programs.
LONDON, June 6 -- Industrial shares were buoyant on the stock market here today.

One of the features of the omnibus housing bill on which voting in the Senate starts today is the proposal by Senator Harrison A. Williams of New Jersey to authorize $150,000,000 in loans and grants to assist communities in grappling with emergency rapid-transit needs.

CAIRO, June 6 -- Dr. Raul Roa, Foreign Minister of Cuba, proposed today that the neutralists' conference being arranged at a preparatory meeting here be held in Havana, "the center of resistance to United States imperialism."
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- President Kennedy received a bipartisan welcome home today from his first experiment in personal diplomacy abroad.

Plans are being completed by Mrs. Harding Bancroft and her committee for a champagne preview of an art collection belonging to Vassar College alumnae or their families in the New York metropolitan area. It will take place at the Wildenstein Gallery, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, next Wednesday from 4 to 7 P.M.
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 6 -- Harold M. (Ron) Hannon received top honors at the athletic awards review at the United States Military Academy today. The ceremony was a part of June Week activities.

EIN KAREM, Israel, June 6 -- Convoys of Israeli Army ambulances moved most of the hospital patients of Jerusalem's Israeli sector today to a new Hadassah Medical Center here in the Judean Hills. The move marked the formal opening of the center.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 6 -- A ten-year fund-raising drive with a goal of $18,500,000 was announced by the Princeton Theological Seminary at its 149th commencement in the Princeton University chapel this morning.

The State of Ohio borrowed $32,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the construction of major highways. The money was raised by the sale of serial bonds secured by motor vehicle revenues, gasoline taxes and other excise revenues.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 6 -- Venezuelan officials and newspapers expressed praise for the Kennedy Administration's approach to Latin-American policy today, but President Kennedy's special envoy, Adlai E. Stevenson, was presented here with complex political and commercial problems.
The pace-setting New York Americans and Everton of England's First Division will share the spotlight in tonight's International Soccer League double-header at the Polo Grounds.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 6 -- Robert W. Dill of Garden City South, 59-year-old collector of Customs of the Port of New York, was designated today to head the Nassau County Republican slate in the November elections.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Six manufacturers of electrical transmission line hardware were indicted by a Federal grand jury at Milwaukee today on charges of conspiring to fix prices and rig bids.
Among the three city-wide Republican candidates, John J. Gilhooley, the choice for City Controller, was the last to be selected and is the least known politically.

The president of the University of Notre Dame told Columbia University alumni yesterday that "those who worry so much about communistic subversion at home might well give equal energy to the task of making democracy dome true here for all Americans."

The president and secretary-treasurer of two financial concerns were arrested here yesterday and charged with the larceny of securities valued at $1,259,349 from the Sutro Brothers Co. brokerage house of 80 Pine Street.
VIENNA, June 6 -- Chancellor Alfons Gorbach confirmed today that the Soviet Government was pressing the question of transferring the United Nations headquarters from New York to Vienna.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 6 -- Arnold Forster, general counsel of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, said tonight that the exposure of the John Birch Society by the nation's press had sharply impaired its chances for success.

The Princeton professors in their letter published June 1 base their endorsement of United States attempts to overthrow the Government of Cuba on the "hope" that the United States "will always oppose tyranny, he it of the Right or of the Left."
Sales of three properties on First Avenue and the leasing of one on Second Avenue were among Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 6 -- Lieut. Col. John V. Abbes Garcia, whose name has inspired terror in this country, was formally dismissed from the Dominican Army today by decree of President Joaquin Balaguer.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 6 -- The United States' determination to champion nations striving for independence has again involved it in a diplomatic tangle. This development came to light today at a session of the Security Council.
CHICAGO, June 6 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox defeated the Detroit Tigers, 7 -- 1, tonight with the help of splendid relief pitching by Turk Lown and Al Smith's bat.
MANILA, June 6 (Reuters) -- Gil Puyat, a 54-year-old Senator and wealthy business man, today was named Vice Presidential candidate of the ruling Nationalist party in the November general election.
VILLA GONZALES, Dominican Republic, June 6 -- A former Chief of Staff in the Dominican Army confirmed today that one of his sons had been seized as an alleged assassin of Generalissimo Trujillo.

President Kennedy's idea of sending a man to the moon in a shorter time than was expected attracts us by its courage, vigor and vision. Of course the request for the staggering sum of money for this purpose will induce many anxious taxpayers to argue that these dollars may be diverted from other necessary projects.

PARIS, June 6 -- All the Khrushchev-Kennedy confrontation proved is that, although it has turned polite, the cold war continues. The Russians in no sense seem anxious for a showdown; but this Will be an uneasy summer.

The State Investigation Commission announced yesterday it would hold public hearings on the city school construction program starting June 20. Six daily sessions are expected to be held: three the first week and three the second week.

IN addition to taking issue with the First Lady of the United States on the shortness of her skirts, Italian designer Emilio Schuberth, in an article in a recent issue of the magazine Oggi also chides Mrs. Kennedy for dressing so casually to go to church in Palm Beach, Fla.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company borrowed $250,000,000 in the market for new capital yesterday through the sale of thirty-seven-year debentures at a net interest cost of 4.727 per cent.
A youth with a long record of delinquency was convicted last night of the "Christmas tree murder" of a 14-year-old boy.

The Republican leadership in the five counties of New York has completed its ticket for city-wide offices, subject to ratification in the primary election: Louis J. Lefkowitz for Mayor; Paul A. Fino for President of the City Council; John J. Gilhooley for Controller.

On May 24 some of the costliest and most creative writing talent in the American theatre, meeting at a hotel, agreed, without significant dissent, to cuts in writers' royalties "in an effort to alleviate the plight" of the Broadway theatre.
ALBANY, June 6 -- Leon Braun of New York City, a member of the Liberal party, has been appointed to a $21,185-a-year position as a Deputy State Controller.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 15 to 25 points yesterday (a point equals 5 cents a bale). Commission house buying and trade covering increased toward the close.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The elimination of tax deferments for American-owned shipping under foreign flags could result in the loss to the United States Navy of its major auxiliary fleet, Erling D. Naess, president of Naess Shipping Company, Inc., declared today.

VIENNA, June 5 -- The tragedy of the Western nations today is that they underestimate their possibilities. Potentially, they have everything necessary, knot only to save themselves, but to create another Golden Age: the manpower, the energy; the skill, the experience -- everything but unity and faith.
From the time that a boy is able to walk, the sight of a knight's armor is something to set his heart beating faster.

Shares of the Sony Corporation, Tokyo, a producer of radio and television sets and tape recorders, are being offered to the United States public today. The offering group is headed by Smith, Barney Co. and the Nomura Securities Company, Ltd.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 6 -- A fight to the finish against court rulings on racial integration in elementary schools here was pledged tonight by Merryle Stanley Rukeyser, president of the Board of Education.
AN ice show may not be the sort of thing to rouse savage critical passion but it can be an agreeable way to spend a TV hour at season's end when tuning about often results in instant torpor.
Leaders of the nation's electric power industry were urged here yesterday to abandon the concept of the combination company -- one selling both gas and electricity.

A new book by Harrison E. Salisbury, to be called "Moscow Journal," is planned for fall publication by the University of Chicago Press. It will cover the years 1949-53 when the author was The New York Times correspondent in the Soviet Union.

The police stepped up the ticketing of illegally parked cars near Brooklyn Borough Hall yesterday. Mayor Wagner directed the Board of Education to halt the use of a schoolyard as a parking lot for teachers. The Queens Borough President ordered two damaged park benches picked up for repairs.

As the nation moves out of the recession some of the adverse effects are beginning to come to light. For example, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., credit-reporting agency, said yesterday that business failures in 1960 set a record at 15,445 compared with 14,053 the preceding year.

THE man selected yesterday to carry the Republican banner for Mayor in this overwhelmingly Democratic city knows what it means to swim against the tide. Louis Jacob Lefkowitz has been doing it all his life -- with remarkable success.

Your editorial of May 17 in support of "controlled wiretapping" has evoked an opposing view by the Executive Director and by the Chairman of the Due Process Committee of the American Civil Liberties Union in their letter printed in your issue of May 23.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) did not participate in the negotiation of a consent judgment through which the Department of Justice approved on Monday a merger of the Standard Oil Company (Kentucky) with the Standard Oil Company of California.
BARNES, England, June 6 (AP) -- Three members of the Lamar Tech tennis team won second-round matches today in the Lowther lawn tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI) -- The Army spent $61,212 in remodeling commanders' quarters at a Maryland base rather than limit itself to $22,000 in building a new structure, Congressional auditors reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- A roman Catholic spokesman urged Congress today to use its ingenuity" to devise some form of Federal aid to parochial and other private schools.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- The House Agriculture Committee passed its first hurdle today on the Administration's omnibus farm bill.
FAR uptown, at the Riverside Museum, 310 Riverside Drive at 103d Street, a painter and a sculptor are posthumously exposed to the broad and cruel prespectives of retrospective exhibitions.

WHEN Mary Stewart was beheaded in the great hall of Fotheringay Castle on Feb. 8, 1587, she was only 44 years old. For the last nineteen years she had been the prisoner of her father's first cousin, Elizabeth Tudor. It was the sad end of one of the most romantic, dramatic and unfortunate lives in royal history.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 6 -- Post position, an item of prime consideration to most harness horses, means next to nothing to the streaking Su Mac Lad.

JACKSON, Miss., June 6 (AP) -- Seven more Freedom Riders made an unsuccessful attack on segregated bus terminal facilities here today. They were put in jail and were quickly convicted on charges of breach of the peace.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 6 -- Professor Carl Gustav Jung, one of the founders of analytic psychology, died today at his villa in Kuessnacht on Lake Lucerne. He was 85 years old. The famed psychologist was beset by heart and circulatory troubles and began to fail several weeks ago.
PARIS, June 6 -- President de Gaulle made public today an exchange of farewell messages with his last guest, President Kennedy, and consulted with a new one, Premier, David BenGurion of Israel.
Bachelor of Arts degrees were conferred yesterday on 182 graduates of the College of Mount St. Vincent in Riverdale.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 6 -- Practical-minded diplomats were cool today to Premier Khrushchev's renewed campaign to move the United Nations away from New York.
With Manager Cookie Lavagetto looking on in furloughed mufti from the press box, the slump-shackled Minnesota Twins took another pasting from the resurgent Yankees last night.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.L, June 6 -- The Southampton Hospital will benefit from the fifth annual Midsummer Night's Ball, to be held at the Meadow Club here on July 15.

Belmont Park's spotlight focused on 2-year-old fillies yesterday as Ogden Phipps' Broadway gained a nose decision over C.V. Whitney's Jazz Queen in a $4,500 allowance race called the Montauk Women. The event was at five and one-half furlongs.
A retired General Sessions Court judge and a lawyer were charged yesterday with having signed a will as witnesses after it had been admitted to the Surrogates' Court.

Paul A. Fino, the choice of Republican leaders for President of the City Council, has tasted political defeat only once in his career. That was in 1940 in his maiden trip to the polls as a candidate for the State Assembly.

In the next few days, $1,500 to $7,500 weekly checks will be sent to such Broadway stars as Mary Martin, Lee Tracy, Richard Burton, Julie Andrews, Anna Maria Alberghetti, Sam Levene, Phil Silvers, Kim Stanley, Cyril Ritchard, Barbara Bel Geddes, Michael Rennie and Eli Wallach.

LONDON, June 6 -- President Kennedy's visit to London was short but effective. In a little less than twenty-eight hours he and Prime Minister Macmillan appear to have opened a new phase in relations between the two Governments.

STOCKHOLM, June 6 (UPI) -- Chuck McKinley of St. Ann, Mo., and Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., won singles matches today while playing for the United States against the Netherlands in a team lawn tennis tournament.
SEOUL, Korea, June 6 -- The South Korean military junta decreed today an absolute military dictatorship with power wielded by a handful of officers.
Fourteen meet records were broken as Bishop Loughlin High gained the team honors in the New Utrecht Spiked Shoe Club's track and field meet yesterday at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.
Following are excerpts from the statement issued yesterday by the city's Republican county leaders in announcing candidates for Mayor, Council President and Controller:
GENEVA, June 6 -- The United States called on Premier Khrushchev today to translate promptly into action his agreement with President Kennedy for an effective cease-fire in Laos.

TO keep up with one of the warmest days this year, American designers had harried buyers jumping in and out of taxis, racing uptown and down to get a look at more fall clothes, although these designs will not be in the stores until the end of July. The excitement came at high noon at the showing by Talmack.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI) -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy scoffed today at Republican charges that he and his brother, President Kennedy, were attempting to "cover up" a Massachusetts highway scandal.
CHICAGO, June 6 (AP) -- Profit takers easily snuffed out all indications of a firmer range in grain futures prices today, and the market finished lower on all contracts.
Food Fair Stores, Inc., which operates a supermarket chain of 438 stores, is planning to enter the discount chain store field.
CHICAGO, June 7 -- The Post Office Department announced today the beginning of a program designed to speed delivery of first-class mail, perhaps by twenty-four hours.
The National Committee for Maritime Bargaining yesterday opened contract talks with coastwise and offshore tanker operators.

KABUL, Afghanistan, June 6 -- Premier Mohammed Daoud accused Pakistan tonight of having used jet aircraft supplied by the United States in cruel and savage bombing of "peoples who are fighting for their freedom."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 7 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has reached major decisions to correct what members of its board of directors consider gross inefficiency.
ALBANY, June 7 -- The Court of Appeals was asked today to declare unconstitutional three new provisions of the Residential Rent Control law that are scheduled to take effect June 30.
TIME takes priority over money among the problems faced by today's homemaker, according to a United Press International report on a new study by home management experts.
PURCHASE, N.Y., June 7 -- Degrees were conferred on 152 women here today at the 120th commencement of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart.
ATHENS, June 7 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy, after a triumphant tour of three European capitals, came to Greece today to rest.

EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, June 7 -- Quarters close to the French delegation here were markedly gloomy here tonight after a short afternoon meeting with the Algerian nationalist representatives on the question of the status of Europeans in a future Algeria.
CHICAGO. June (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

THE current off-Broadway attraction, "Young Mr. Lincoln," was brought to television last night over Channel 5; its ambition, to give youngsters a glimpse of history within the framework of entertainment, is especially commendable in terms of TV.

The New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects awarded its Medal of Honor yesterday to Gordon Bunshaft, the designer of Lever House on Park Avenue. It gave its Award of Merit to Othmar H. Ammann, the engineer responsible for the Triborough, George Washington, Whitestone, Throgs Neck and Narrows Bridges.
AN audience of influential women saw a play recently that was written to help correct some stereotypes about unwed mothers.

Joy Adamson, author of "Born Free," which was on the best-seller list for almost a year, has written a sequel that Harcourt, Brace will issue Oct. 16. Called "Living Free," it tells of Elsa as a lioness mother and of the author and her husband, George, spending Christmas, 1960, with Elsa and her three cubs.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Republican National Committee announced today a major new campaign to enlist "the specialized knowledge and experience of the nation's intellectuals."

Archie Moore, preparing to defend his share of the world 175-pound title in Madison Square Garden Saturday night against Giulio Rinaldi of Italy, sparred two rounds yesterday in Monticello, N.Y., with Greatest Crawford.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) -- An Air Force general discounted today reports that foreign saboteurs had been responsible for blowing up three important communications facilities in Utah and Idaho on May 28.
The Board of Education has set June 16 as the date on which the city's teachers are to be asked whether they want collective bargaining.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz and his two running mates on this year's Republican city ticket began campaigning yesterday, less than twenty-four hours after they had been designated.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 7 -- Holy Cross ended Yale's four-game winning streak today by beating the Elis, 11 -- 9. The teams totaled twenty-six hits, with the losers getting fourteen of them.

IN attempting "a new development'', in opera activity on its campus and in greater New York, the Brooklyn College Opera Workshop tackled nothing less than a brand new opera, Jan Meyerowitz's "Godfather Death."

It would be "outrageous hypocrisy" for American Broadcasting Company commentators to criticize segregationists when their own organization has been a "far more powerful obstruction" to racial equality, Norman Thomas declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Indians ran their longest winning streak since 1956 to nine games and took a half-game lead in the American League tonight, when they beat the Washington Senators, 11 -- 0, behind Jim Grant's six-hitter.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 7 -- A petition requesting that a Charter revision commission be set up was submitted to the Nassau County Board of Supervisors here today. It was said to have the signatures of 53,053 county residents.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Martin Company announced today the development of a new radiotelephone system it described as "probably the most significant development in the field of voice communications electronics since the end of World War II."

TORONTO, June 7 (AP) -- Dr. John E. Martin, director of the School of Veterinary Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania, said today there was "inherent danger" in administering Butazolidin to race horses in repeated doses.
City police reported no luck yesterday in finding the thief who took 109 golf clubs last Friday as they were en route to the Disabled Veterans' Hospital in Ossining, N.Y.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 7 -- The former acting chairman of the Liberal party in Nassau County and four former members of the party's executive committee pleaded guilty in County Court here today to having made false statements in election petitions.
A Manhattan lawyer announced about 3 A.M. today that the family feud between Shelby Cullom Davis and his daughter Diana over a $3,800,000 trust fund had been settled.
Fifty-four producers of live industrial shows, sponsored by corporations, have agreed to bar segregation at their performances in the United States and Canada starting next Jan. 1.

Production of electric power fell in the Memorial-holiday week ended last Saturday to 13,887,000,000 kilowatt hours from 14,390,000,000 the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. A year ago the figure was 13,503,000,000 kilowatt-hours.
A memorial service will be held today for Francis Hall Bedell, a prominent Wall Street broker who has been missing since May 29.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 7 -- Antoine Gizenga, head of the Stanleyville regime, may lead supporters of the late Premier, Patrice Lumumba to Leopoldville for a parliamentary struggle with the forces of President Joseph Kasavubu and Premier Joseph Ileo, it was reported here today.

" The Spy Next Door," the quasi-documentary about Soviet espionage activities in this country, will be repeated by the Columbia Broadcasting System television network on Wednesday, July 5, from 10 to 11 P.M.

CAIRO, June 7 -- Officials of the United Arab Republic said today the fact that they were standing up to the campaign of criticism by the Soviet press did not necessarily mean the Arab nation was entering a pro-United States phase.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 7 -- A Southampton woman contended in State Supreme Court here this week that she had been illegally barred from access to her converted lighthouse home on Cedar Island in Gardiners Bay.

The electric power industry's exhibition at the 1964 New York World's Fair will include "the greatest concentration of light ever generated." A 24,000,000,000 candlepower "tower of light" will be visible from Boston to Washington.
The over-the-counter market continued quiet yesterday, with very few major price changes.
PARIS, June 7 -- Western Europe's most comprehensive international stock market index hit a new peak this week.

Operations of J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., in the six months ended on April 29, resulted in a decline of 11 per cent in sales and a 58 per cent drop in earnings, according to the semi-annual report of the big textile producer.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 7 -- The sinister world of Auschwitz, greatest of the Nazi death camps, was revived today in all its insane terror by survivors at the trial of Adolf Eichmann.
" ALL THE SUMMER DAYS,"* by Ned Calmer, is a historical novel of Paris in the Nineteen Twenties. The expatriates run the gamut of their emotions again from American Express to Zelli's.

Teen-age neighbors of the seventeen "respectable" youths arrested in Queens Tuesday as burglars indicated yesterday that their prosperous community might have been partly to blame.
WEST MILFORD, N.J., June 7 (AP) -- Three members of a state trooper's family were shot, one fatally, in their home on High Drive tonight.

Governor Rockefeller will name Oren L. Root as State Superintendent of Banks, it was learned yesterday. He will succeed G. Russell Clark who resigned to become chairman and chief executive officer of the Commercial Bank of North America.
A call for compassion and integrity in the medical profession was made yesterday by Dr. Jeremiah S. Finch of Princeton University.
Stock prices moved irregularly lower yesterday until about 3 P.M. Then, in the final thirty minutes of dealings, bids were lowered measurably and the list closed near the lows of the day.

Everton remained undefeated and moved into a first-place tie with the New York Americans by halting Dynamo of Rumania, 4 -- 0, in the feature of the International Soccer League double-header at the Polo Grounds last night.

A decline of only 18,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. This unusually small change came in the face of a decline in gasoline production to 29,060,000 barrels from 29,089,000 in the preceding week.
CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -- The July soybean contract attracted major attention again today on the Board of Trade, with heavy selling pressure driving the price to lowest level in more than two months.
Truck and other commercial vehicle owners have until June 20 to pay the city tax due for the 1961-62 tax year, City Treasurer Hilda G. Schwartz reminded them yesterday.

MONTREAL, June 7 (Canadian Press) -- Biochemical research into mental illnesses has uncovered a powerful basis for believing that the seeds of schizophrenia are inherited, Dr. Abram Holler of the University of Saskatoon said today.
The rebel military junta in South Korea has further reinforced its position by adopting a new basic law investing itself with all executive, legislative and judicial powers.

The country's merchants are through with the "doom and gloom" psychology that marked the year's start and they expect sharp rises for retail sales and profits in the second half of the year. This is the picture that emerged yesterday as the National Retail Merchants Association (N.R.M.A.) summarized the findings of a national survey of its member stores, which represent about $6,500,000,000 in sales potential.
RABAT, Morocco, June 7 -- King Hassan II promised today that this absolute monarchy would receive a constitution and democratic institutions; but he did not say when.

Along with his teacher, Sigmund Freud, Carl Jung will be remembered as one of the pioneer explorers of the hidden recesses of the human psyche. Obsolete and insanitary school conditions, dating back in some cases for twenty years, were described yesterday at a public hearing on the proposed 1962 capital budget for the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Senate investigators have reduced their demand for records of the General Electric Company in the face of a company contention that its constitutional rights would be violated.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk told Congress today that the Administration's $4,800,000,000 foreign-aid request had taken on new urgency in view of what President Kennedy had learned from Premier Khrushchev in Vienna.

BALTIMORE, June 7 (AP) -- Ted Bowsfield, making his first start of the season, pitched five-hitter and defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 4 -- 0, tonight to lift the Los Angeles Angels out of the American League cellar.

It's enough to make every male duffer abandon golf and take up tiddlywinks or some game better suited to their talents because Mickey Wright is not a guy but a doll.

State Supreme Court Justice Henry Epstein ordered yesterday that a special stockholders' meeting of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company be held to decide which of two rival factions should obtain control. Justice Epstein stipulated that the special meeting be held no later than July 28.

HARTFORD, June 7 -- The General Assembly, in session for five months, adjourned tonight after having adopted a record general fund biennial budget of $560,000,000 and increasing various taxes by $122,000,000.

With a strike deadline a week away, the nation's largest seamen's union and the operators of the 375 passenger ships and freighters that employ them met for seven hours yesterday to hammer out seven issues involved in the negotiation of a new three-year contract.

LONDON, June 7 -- With volume small, most sections moved narrowly and irregularly on the stock market here today.

HAVANA, June 7 -- The Cuban Cabinet approved a law tonight nationalizing education. The measure is one of the most radical adopted by the Castro regime.

For the second successive year, the New York Philharmonic will open its season with a nonsubscription concert.

Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman has accused the City Club of New York of distorting his position on how far "reform" within the Democratic party should be carried.

The stockholders of the Industrial Bank of Commerce have approved plans to convert the bank from an industrial to a commercial bank and to change the name to the Bank of Commerce. The proposal is subject to approval by the State Banking Department.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 7 -- Effective June 16, Friday will be the biggest and the busiest night of each week at Roosevelt Raceway. WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Members of a Senate subcommittee linked television violence to the rise of juvenile delinquency today. The producer of "Whispering Smith," "Wagon Train" and "Checkmate" denied the charges.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8 -Igor Stravinsky today tentatively accepted an invitation from the Soviet Union to conduct his own work in Russia next year.

Six hundred and thirty-nine properties in Manhattan were sold for prices amounting to $93,634,000 in the first quarter of this year compared with 733 parcels for $77,185,316 in the comparable period of 1960. The figures show a decline of 13 per cent in the number of deals but a gain of 17 per cent in the dollar volume.

President Kennedy is right to keep on trying to get a cease-fire in Laos and a nuclear test ban agreement by negotiation with the Russians. The Republican brinkmanship of Senator Dirksen, Representative Halleck and other party leaders is dangerous.
LONDON, June 8 -- The Soviet Union protested today to the West against the proposed meeting of the upper house of the Bonn Parliament in West Berlin June 16.

DE WITT, Iowa, June 8 -- A visiting professor of geography at the University of Chicago was killed today, and another professor was critically injured when the car in which they were riding collided with a semi-trailer truck on U.S. 30, two miles west of here.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- Licensed imports of crude oil and oil products were 1,456,036 barrels a day during April, the Department of the Interior reported last night.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 8 (UPI) -- Ohio State University's Board of Trustees dropped-the compulsory Reserve Officers Training program today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 8 -- Complaints of uninspired colonial management were brought against the United States today just as it was making new efforts to convey an enlightened position on "colonialism" issues.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 8 (AP) -- Philadelphia ripped into Sam Jones for three runs in the first inning today en route to a 5-2 victory, over the San Francisco Giants.
While streaking in opposite directions, the Yankees and Athletics collided at the Stadium last night and took off again on new headings.
YORK, England, June 8 -Katharine Worsley, the golden-haired daughter of a Yorkshire squire, was married today to Prince Edward, Duke of Kent, eighth in the line of succession to the British throne.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $30,000,000 to $62,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements declined $58,000,000 to $554,000,000.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals upheld today the dismissal of a suit in which two stockholders of Alleghany Corporation had challenged the company's acquisition of control over the New York Central Railroad.

The word "retirement" finally has crept into the vocabulary of Archie Moore, according to a report yesterday as he completed training for his fifteen-round defense against Giulio Rinaldi in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

BIRMINGHAM, England, June 8 -- (Reuters) -- Caught on a difficult pitch after several interruptions by rain, England today struggled to reach 180 for eight wickets by the close on the first day of the first test against Australia.

The movement westward over the Appalachian mountain barrier by the Colonial pioneers is described in a new book of Americana by Dale Van Every. Morrow will issue it June 21 under the title "Forth to the Wilderness."

The recent murder of Harry Heisler by an adolescent in one of our public housing projects on the lower East Side of Manhattan should serve as a horrible and necessary reminder of those preventive measures yet to be implemented by somewhat detached city and state administrators.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 8 -- Reinforcements were sent for troops in the northeastern city of Recife today as the Government refused to deal with striking students there until they returned to their classes.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 8 (Reuters) -- Communist guerrillas have been repelled with heavy losses in two of three recent raids near Saigon, officials reported today.
The city's commercial laundries have eliminated the weight-rate system of incentive pay, the Department of Markets announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- To land a manned expedition on the moon, the United States will need a rocket standing more than 300 feet tall, weighing some 5,000 tons and generating 12,000,000 pounds of thrust on take-off.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 8 -- One of the tiniest golfers in the women's professional ranks, Mrs. Marlene Bauer Hagge, gained a sizable lead as the Triangle round-robin started at the Wykagyl Country Club today.

Probably the first "gall bladder operation" in the history of Carnegie Recital Hall occurred there last night. The fact that the performers employed viola da gamba and harpsichord rather than scalpel and clamp detracted not one whit from the effectiveness of the operation.
LONDON, June 8 -- The continuing weakness of British Government securities had a depressing effect on the industrial sections of the stock market here today.
DETROIT, June 8 -- The Tractors for Freedom Committee announced late today that it was prepared to ship the first consignment of 100 tractors to Cuba not later than June 22, two weeks from today.
THE Trigere collection, one of the last in the current showings of fall fashions by Seventh Avenue designers, made its entrance with a great swirling cape.

CINCINNATI, June 8 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves set a major league record today as four players hit home runs in succession in the seventh inning. It was wasted effort because the Cincinnati Reds won, 10 -- 8.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 8 -- The United States has decided to side with Asian and African states and the Soviet Union in a move to reprove Portugal for repressive acts in the African territory of Angola.

FIFTH AVENUE shoppers who may be in midtown at lunch time will find a delicious bargain at Bond's third-floor "The Country House." For 95 cents, they will be served a choice of entrees, dessert and a beverage.
PALM BEACH, Fla., June 8 -- President Kennedy stepped off his jet and was taken to the oceanside home of friends here today. He planned three days of rest and swimming.

Three men, including one described by Assistant District Attorney Richard H. Kuh as the largest distributor of pornographic films in the New York area, were indicted here yesterday. They were charged with conspiracy, photographing and manufacturing pornographic films, sodomy and rape.
Check transactions last month came to $131,405,389,000, the highest level for any month on record, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 8 -The Government is taking severe measures against Leftist union leaders following its announcement that it had thwarted a Communist plot.

THE sweet aroma of fresh-picked strawberries predominates at most produce shops now as New Jersey berries and the first of the Long Island crop arrive to swell supplies that have been coming in from California and Florida.

CURACAO, Netherlands Antilles, June 8 (AP) -- Seven political prisoners hijacked a Venezuelan military plane in flight tonight and forced it to land here after a bloody battle with guns and knives. The fight continued at the Curacao airport after the landing.
A sharp protest was registered yesterday on behalf of Belgian producers against recent Tariff Commission recommendations for an increase of import duties on sheet glass.

The general secretary of the Communist party in the United States said yesterday that his organization would not comply with the United States Supreme Court's decision last Monday that it must register as a "communist-action organization" under the Internal Security Act of 1950.

The Federal Communications Commission has ordered two television-set owners to appear at a hearing and "show cause why they should not cease and desist" from causing interference to a neighbor's radio reception.

Vassily Smyslov of the Soviet Union, the former world champion, moved into first place yesterday in the international chess masters tournament at the Moscow Central Club, according to a report from the Soviet Union.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 8 (AP) -- A Discoverer rocket was launched today -- after a last-minute adjustment by a man with a wrench. But it failed to go into orbit.

About 150,000 Protestant Sunday School children marched and rode yesterday in the 132d Anniversary Day parade in Brooklyn and Queens. The public schools in the two boroughs were closed by act of the Legislature to permit the pupils to take part.

PARAMUS, N.J., June 8 -Two youngsters -- Hanse Halligan, 25 years old, of Montclair and Roger Ginsburg, 22, of Alpine -- shot one-over-par 72's today in qualifying for the state amateur golf championship.

The election of Vice Admiral Roy A. Gano, commander of the Military Sea Transportation Service, as president and chairman of the board of directors of the United Seamen's Service was announced yesterday.
BALTIMORE, June 8 (UPI) -- Billy Martin's two-run homer helped the Minnesota Twins snap a thirteen-game losing streak tonight with a 3-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.
A convicted gambler charged yesterday that Magistrates' Court judges had "surrendered and abandoned their inherent power" when sentencing persons convicted of gambling violations.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 8 -- The names of 390 persons were stricken from the rolls of the Monroe County Liberal party today. This was authorized when Supreme Court Justice Clarence H. Briscoe granted a motion to eliminate from membership in the party all persons who failed to respond to subpoenas to appear in his court.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company has leased its ore dock facilities and other property on the Calumet River in South Chicago to Luria Brothers, Inc., which will establish two big shipping terminals there, it was learned today.
LONDON, June 8 -- The British have an insatiable appetite for news of the royal family.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Treasury sold its unusual issue of "strip" bills today at discounts averaging 2.283 per cent.
Four former college basketball players, previously named as co-conspirators in indictments returned against gamblers, were indicted here yesterday on charges of conspiracy and bribery.

Ardalt, Inc., and Ardalt Imports, Inc., importers of giftware, lamps and decorative accessories, have leased a floor for offices and showrooms at 11 East Twenty-sixth Street. The concerns moved on Tuesday from 95 Madison Avenue.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 8 -- Adolf Eichmann sat through eighty minutes of filmed horror today without flinching or batting an eye.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- The Administration called today for Federal scholarships to overcome a growing shortage of physicians and dentists.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 8 -- Woody Ash and Joseph E. Vallace of the North Jersey Country Club won the second annual Saul Lantzis Memorial seniors invitation tournament by two strokes at Fenway Golf Club today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 8 (UPI) -- Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., and Chuck McKinley of St. Ann, Mo., defeated Eduardo Soriano and Enrique Morea today in the United States-Argentina match of the Swedish seven-nation tennis tournament.

BOSTON, June 8 -- Boston opened its tenth annual Arts Festival today in the Public Garden. The festival will continue through June 25 with art displays, opera, drama, dance, orchestral music and poetry.
WASHINGTON, Jne 8 -- President Fulbert Youlou of the Republic of the Congo joined today the growing list of foreign leaders who have been welcomed to Washington by President Kennedy.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The United States is taking a cautious and rather skeptical view of the latest overtures toward democracy by the new regime in the Dominican Republic.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) -- The Court of Claims set a precedent today by awarding $27,000 to an American of Japanese ancestry for damages suffered during a wartime internment program on the West Coast.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) -- Senators gave their views today on improving election procedures. They ranged from letting 18-year-olds vote to overhauling the Electoral College and abolishing the poll tax.

New York City borrowed $60,400,000 in the public bond market yesterday to buy equipment for the rapid transit system, to finance school construction and for other public improvements. The borrowing was done on four issues of bonds maturing over twenty-five years. The cost of the borrowing was 3.54985 per cent.
CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Loans to business at the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City fell $172,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the like 1960 week, the decline was $129,000,000.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Defense leaders asked Congress today for new authority to send military equipment to neutral countries to combat increased Communist infiltration.

BEFORE its final distribution among her legatees the collection of French Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings made by the late Mrs. Adele Rosenwald Levy will be on view at the Museum of Modern Art until July 9.

A splendid opportunity to demonstrate that the United States really is against dictatorships and in favor of democracy in Latin America is being missed. On Monday Ambassador Adlai E. Stevenson will go to Asuncion to pay his respects to the one remaining military dictator of South America -- Gen. Alfredo Stroessner.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- Funds to establish a Federal register of names of automobile drivers whose licenses have been revoked were approval today by the House Appropriations Committee.
DETROIT, June 8 (AP) -Automotive News said today passenger car production this week will come within 8.7 per cent of that in the comparable week of 1960 -- one of the narrowest margins of the year.

Anti-segregation demonstrators continued yesterday to picket the offices of American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc., 7 West Sixty-sixth Street, to protest the racial policy of Paramount theatres in Austin, Tex.

PETER USTINOV'S broadside deriding of the diplomacy of the "cold war," exploded four years ago on Broadway in his play, "Romanoff and Juliet," has been reloaded into a movie that carries the same belabored tag and rattles a tinkling reminder of "The Mouse That Roared."

The aviation industry is devoting an increasing amount of attention to development of a supersonic airliner able to fly passengers from New York to London in less than three hours. It is confidently forecast that such a plane will be put into service by about 1970. There are numerous air travelers, however, who are less interested in halving their trans-Atlantic flying time than in halving downtown-to-airport ground-travel time.

The proposed plans for the new gymnasium for Columbia University at Morningside Park are a botch. The architects -- Eggers Higgins, who often do a fine piece of work -have been either so circumscribed by the university or so befoozled by their desire to put up a big modern building that they have completely lost sight of what the site calls for, if it is to be sacrificed to the university's needs at all.
Trading in over-the-counter issues was at a slightly faster pace yesterday after several days of comparative quiet. Prices of most issues were down somewhat from Wednesday's Closing levels.
The state acted yesterday against a tenement at 5 West 117th Street that it described as "a better living place for rodents than for human beings."

Negotiations broke down yesterday on major maritime labor contracts involving more than 80,000 officers and crew members on about 900 passenger-cargo ships, freighters and tankers that fly the United States flag.
An exhibition of children's best-sellers in the Soviet Union opens at the New York Public Library tomorrow -- the first Soviet book exhibition to be held in this country.
NEW CITY, N.Y., June 8 -- No heirs have been found to an estate of more than $150,000 left by a Sparkill, N.Y., woman who died on April 22 at the age of 100.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The United States has urged the Soviet Union in a new note to cooperate in achieving an effective cease-fire in Laos.

SLAGEN, Norway, June 8 (AP) -- M.J. Rathbone, president of Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, today struck out at Russian use of economic competition as a weapon. Mr. Rathbone spoke at the dedication ceremony of the new Esso refinery in Norway.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) -- Justice Department trust investigators finally won permission today to examine minutes from closed meetings of the Commerce Department's Business Advisory Council.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 8 -- About fifty arrests have been made by the military authorits in Istanbul, Eskisehir and Bursa. The arrests were announced in the last two days, but it is not clear whether they were made then or some time ago.
A $40,000,000 issue of 5 per cent, twenty-five year debentures of the Union Tank Car Company, Chicago, Ill., was offered to the public yesterday priced at 100.
Proposals for sharply reduced promotional fares across the Atlantic are under study by major international airlines.
About fifty construction inspectors and supervisors of the Board of Education have been ordered to appear today for questioning at the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

An officer of the Green Giant Company, a leading vegetable canning concern, said yesterday that Puerto Rican migrant workers on its asparagus farm at Galena, Md., had been well-fed, adequately sheltered and paid full contractual wages.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The White House is preparing to intervene, if necessary, in a dispute over strategy for handling legislation on Federal aid to education.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -Business expenditures for plant and equipment fell slightly more than expected last winter, but have now leveled off and are headed for the predicted upturn this summer, according to a Government survey made public today.
" Fright campaigns" to promote safer driving may do more harm than good, a leading traffic research authority said here yesterday.
The State Department has commissioned Arnold Moss to serve in Latin America this summer as a sort of roving American specialist on the classics.

PARIS, June 8 -- The French Government decreed today its right to retire and ultimately dismiss men in the military forces who have been deemed deficient in health, professional skills and -- probably -- loyalty.
After one of the grimmest seasons in its history, the Broadway theatre can only hope that it has been through its darkest hour.
WILMINGTON, Del., June 8 (AP) -- The largest and oldest utility company in the Philippine Islands came under complete control of Filipinos today.

Five hundred acres of land in Matawan Township, N.J., about thirty-five miles from Manhattan, have been purchased by Levitt Sons, Inc., for a development containing 1,300 homes. The project marks the return of the country's largest builder of homes to the New York area after an absence of ten years.
Beaunit Mills, Inc., producer of textiles and chemicals, experienced a sharp setback in earnings in the fiscal year ended on March 31, the report of Irwin S. Meltzer, president, disclosed yesterday.

ROME was a matchless study in antiquity last October. From the exquisite Campidoglio atop Capitoline Hill the sweeping eyes of a tourist could identify such imposing monuments to the past as the Colosseum, the Forum and Archie Moore. The only one that moved was Archie and he didn't move very spryly. He was hog fat.
A queen for New York Is a Summer Festival was crowned yesterday at the official opening of the season's program.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:

The Citizens Housing and Planning Council charged yesterday that the city's housing program was being "seriously Impaired" by Mayor Wagner's delay in naming a third mereer of the Housing and Redevelopment: Board.

SEOUL, Korea, June 8 -- The ruling military junta accused South Korean students today of having made "numerous vigorous pro-Communist declarations" and forbade them and their professors to engage in political activities on the nation's campuses.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The official line in Washington today is that President Kennedy hurt his back digging holes for trees in Canada, but there is another theory that he did it straining in disbelief at what he heard from Nikita Khrushchev in Vienna.
ROME, June 8 -- King Baudouin of the Belgians and Queen Fabiola were received in audience today by Pope John XXIII. It was reported that they had informed him that the Queen was expecting a child.

JERUSALEM, June 8 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion returned to Israel in an exuberant mood today and declared that he had achieved more than he had hoped for in his visit with leaders of the United States, Canada, Britain and France.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that the city would try something new -- vandal-proof parking meters. It will test 5,000 of them between July 1 and next Jan. 1.

TAKE a husky voice, a deep French accent, an amber-blond head of hair and good-looking features offset by ever-present dark glasses and it sounds more like a glamor ous actress than one of Seventh Avenue's top designers.
Only 215 persons have applied for the medical assistance that became available here on June 1 to 40,000 men and women 65 years old or older.
Dr. Ray E. Trussell, Commissioner of Hospitals, told the City Council yesterday that on an early morning visit to Fordham Hospital he had found one registered nurse on duty for 350 ward patients.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 8 (AP) -- A former reserve policeman was convicted today on the charge of beating two newsmen during racial rioting May 20.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The House of Representatives voted, 295 -- 88, today to continue for another year the so-called Korean War increases in corporate income and excise taxes.
UNION CITY, N.J., June 8 -- The secretary-treasurer of a teamster local that was the subject of a Senate rackets investigation two years ago was reported today to have been missing since Sunday.
BUTLER, Pa., June 8 (AP) -- A 53-year-old grandmother was rearrested today in a shortage of more than $431,000 at the Working, men's Building and Loan Association.

A 100 per cent stock dividend has been declared by the directors of Life Insurance Investors, Inc., a mutual fund holding shares in life insurance companies. The announcement of the dividend was made to shareholders at their annual meeting in Baltimore yesterday.
The New-York March of Dimes has arranged a dinner in honor of Robert W. Dowling I June 27 in the Grand Ballroom l of the Plaza.
Stocks took a pounding in the early hours of trading yesterday but recovered in the last sixty minutes and ended with a net gain for the day.
BARNES, England, June 8 (AP) -- Bill Bond gained the semi-finals in the Lowther tennis tournament today with a victory over a fellow-Californian.

BONN, Germany, June 8 -Paul-Henri Spaak, Belgium's Foreign Minister, was reliably reported today to have undertaken the role of peacemaker in the quarrel between France and the Netherlands on how to proceed with European political unity.

The North Shore Council of Homeowners' Associations, Inc., representing home owners in North Queens, has asked television station WNTA-TV for equal time to respond to Mayor Wagner's broadcast of last Sunday.
PARIS, June 8 -- A potato rebellion flared in Brittany today and led to the Virtual seizure of the town of Morlaix by several hundred farmers.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- The Justice Department, citing slow legal action, gave its support today to a bill to prevent auto manufacturers from financing and insuring their cars.
ALBANY, June 8 -- The Court of Appeals heard a final plea today to upset the state law under which Mayor Wagner appointed his commission to draft a new Charter for New York City.

THE Marchese Emilio Pucci, the Florentine couturier who created the international set's sports uniform, flew to New York this week to accept Sports Illustrated magazine's Sporting Look Award and to promote what he calls the need for modern romanticism.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Pakistan's Finance Minister, Mohammed Shoaib, said today he was disappointed at the results of this week's six-nation Conference to plan aid for his country's Five-Year Plan.

The Caterpillar Tractor Company announced plans yesterday to offer $50,000,000 of sinking fund debentures to the public through an investment group headed by Blyth Co., Inc. The proceeds are to be added to working capital.
SIR WILLIAM GILBERT was once asked if he expected that some of the lines from "H.M.S. Pinafore" would become catchwords.

Oren Root, a top political adviser to Governor Rockefeller, became State Superintendent of Banks yesterday. Secretary of State Caroline K. Simon administered the oath of office at a ceremony in the Governor's office here.
BALTIMORE, June 8 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles today traded an outfielder, Gene Stephens, to the Kansas City Athletics for a first baseman-outfielder, Mary Throneberry.
NEW ELLENTON, S.C., June 8 (UPI) -- A Negro accused of the shotgun killing of Police Chief Thomas L. Meeks was placed in the county jail at Aiken today.

AMERICAN society may be something of a matriarchy, as European writers so often proclaim with smug masculine superiority; but American women are still meekly subservient to their husbands in at least one respect: They accompany them anywhere.
NEWARK, N.J., June 8 -Newark College of Engineering awarded 414 Bachelor of Science degrees and 136 Master of Science degrees tonight at its forty-fifth commencement exercise.
GENEVA, June 8 -- Andrei A. Gromyko rejected tonight the idea of Soviet concessions to restart the Laos conference.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 8 -- A high army officer was said today to have been involved in the plot that ended in assassination of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina on May 30. The officer's name has not been disclosed.
PHILADELPHIA, June 8 -- The Court of Common Pleas was asked today to convene a special grand jury to investigate alleged contract frauds and payola scandals in Philadelphia's City Hall.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., June 8 -- A rocket man floated through the air today in a brief but significant demonstration of how soldiers might move around a battlefield of the future. His short but spectacular journey at near-by Fort Eustis lasted about fourteen seconds, carried him over a big truck to an altitude of fifteen feet, and then eased him to a landing 150 feet away.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Administration's foreign aid program has come before Congress for approval in the most defensive position these proposals have ever occupied. The position is that of a large borrower who, despite very unsatisfactory tangible earnings, wants not only to renew his loan at the bank, but make it annually self-renewing for five years.
Miss Peggy Guggenheim, who formerly operated a gallery of modern art here, charged yesterday that the late Jackson Pollock had defrauded her when he was her protege.

The Government yesterday threw another roadblock to the plans of the management of Hazel Bishop, Inc., and more than one hundred stockholders to sell 1,274,823 shares of the company's common stock. The shares would be sold through a secondary offering on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) -- The Federal Aviation Agency set up a new reporting system today under which pilots generally would be granted immunity from prosecution in near-collision cases.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Port of New York Authority asked Congress today to appropriate $1,653,200 for eight channel improvement projects for the New York Harbor.

A growing demand in Europe for small pleasure craft manufactured in the United States has given rise to a form of piggy-back boating, that is, one boat riding atop another to reach its final destination. This year an estimated $50,000,000 in boats, motors and accessories will be shipped abroad by Uni ted States manufacturers to meet the needs of the European boating market.

CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) -- Another broad setback in July soybean futures today ran the loss in that contract to more than 15 cents a bushel in three successive declines on the Board of Trade. September soybeans also were weak.

The United States' monetary gold stock rose $25,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $17,428,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The increase was the largest in three and a half years.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) -- Following is the transcript of President Kennedy's speech and answers to questions today at the 1961 conference of editors and publishers who are clients of United Press International:

The failure of motorists to observe "No Standing" traffic signs on West Forty-third Street -- despite ticketing by the police -- is causing traffic to back up at the site of the Princeton Club Building project near Fifth Avenue.

Mayor Wagner is in the politically uncomfortable situation of being required by the calendar to make his decision on whether to run for a third term at a time when his popularity with the public, with political leaders and with other people of influence is at a low point. While he is in part to blame, almost a conspiracy of adverse circumstances has also occurred.
DETROIT, June 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of the reply sent tonight by the Tractors for Freedom Committee to Premier Fidel Castro of Cube:
The bond market extended Wednesday's gains yesterday.

Prices for commodity futures moved irregularly yesterday in generally dull and featureless trading on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, potatoes, copper and wool rose; domestic sugar, zinc, rubber and cottonseed oil declined, and coffee, world sugar, hides and lead were mixed.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) -- The Senate Republican leader Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois, said today his party would go to court if President Kennedy appointed Joseph C. Swidler as chairman of the Federal Power Commission.
A teachers' union asked Mayor Wagner last night to demand the resignation of the nine members of the Board of Education.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 8 -- Marge Burns of the Starmount Forest C.C., Greensboro, N.C., won the Women's Eastern Golf Association's fifty-second 54-hole medal-play championship at the Century Country Club today.
NEVER do anything dishonorable, unless you have to.
On a bright May day in 1922 a Royal Air Force pilot, Maj. John C. Savage, streaked across the skies over Epsom Downs and, trailing smoke behind, scrawled "The Daily Mail."
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended last Saturday were 1 per cent above the level in the 1960 week.

MANCHESTER, England, June 8 (UPI) -- Jack Frost of Monterey, Calif., the American remaining in the northern tennis championships, defeated Bob Howe of Australia, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5, to reach the singles semi-finals today.

Today's new film is "Wild in the Country," a musical drama from Twentieth Century-Fox, at the Paramount Theatre, Broadway and Forty-third Street. Elvis Presley, Hope Lange, Tuesday Weld and Millie Perkins play leading roles in the Jerry Wald production, under the direction of Philip Dunne.

I should like to comment on your June 2 editorial "Last Call in Iran" since I have visited Iran many times in my present capacity and before that as foreign editor of Newsweek, and since I am personally acquainted with the Shah, Prime Minister Amini and other Iranian leaders.
Mayor Wagner tried his hand at peacemaking among the Democrats on Staten Island yesterday and thereby touched off a rash of speculation on his third-term intentions.

Mrs. Cordelia S. May's Be Moderate remained in front all the way in winning the Bushwick Hurdle Handicap at Belmont yesterday. The second choice with the crowd of 23,052, Be Moderate, scored by six lengths over Mrs. Lawrence W. Knapp Jr.'s Nautilus in the two-mile race.

The wholesale commodity price index slipped to 84.7 on Wednesday from 84.8 Tuesday. This was the lowest level since 84.4 was registered on Feb. 21, 1960. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 86 on June 1, 1960.

Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, called last night for a long-range sugar act with provisions that would give domestic producers a greater share of the former Cuban quota in the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The White House disclosed today that President Kennedy strained his back on May 16 and had since been in "constant discomfort." The injury occurred at a tree-planting ceremony in Canada.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 8 -- A North Hills estate will be acquired by Nassau County for about $700,000 for development as a county park, County Executive A. Holly Patterson announced today.
PARENTS who call the wrong signals when teaching children good eating habits are playing a dangerous game of emotional football, according to a nutritionist and a psychologist at Cornell University.

Vincent J. Velella, a 46-year-old East Harlem lawyer, went on trial for perjury yesterday in connection with the promotion of the frist heavyweight title fight between Ingemar Johansson and Floyd Patterson in 1959.
