PARENTS who call the wrong signals when teaching children good eating habits are playing a dangerous game of emotional football, according to a nutritionist and a psychologist at Cornell University.

Vincent J. Velella, a 46-year-old East Harlem lawyer, went on trial for perjury yesterday in connection with the promotion of the frist heavyweight title fight between Ingemar Johansson and Floyd Patterson in 1959.
CHICAGO, June 8 -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg said today that steps to end discrimination should begin at home.

DETROIT, June 8 -- Scientists of the Ford Motor Company's Aeronutronic division at Newport Beach, Calif., are developing test decoys in support of the nation's intercontinental ballistic missile program.

YONKERS, June 8 -- Mrs. Philip Conway of Siwanoy carded a 37, 41 -- 78 at the par-73 Hudson River course today. She won the weekly tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association by eleven strokes.
NORTH HILLS, L.I., June 8 -- Piping Rock golfers took the top places in the low-gross competition of the Women's Long Island Golf Association's tournament at the Links Club today.
WASHINGTON, Friday, June 9 -- Rallying from a surprise setback, the Administration pushed through the major provisions of its $6,100,000,000 omnibus housing bill in the Senate early this morning.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -Freight loadings during the Memorial Day week dropped sharply, the rail and truck industries reported today.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, June 8 (AP) -- The United States' final survivors, Ben Northrup, a lightweight, and Dick Wilson, a flyweight, were eliminated as the Soviet Union swept to five gold medals today in the world Greco-Roman wrestling championships.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8 -- At a time when there is considerable trepidation here about using writers of suspect politics, Kirk Douglas has been hiring Dalton Trumbo, best-known of the blacklisted writers, for a series of movies.

BUENOS AIRES, June 8 -- The Argentine Government is telling Adlai E. Stevenson that the United States should stop putting a theatrical spotlight on Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba by arguing with or about him.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 8 -Right Time paced the mile in 2:00 3/5 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight to take top money in the $4,500 Class AA-1 feature.

Millicent C. McIntosh, President of Barnard College, addressed 700 alumnae yesterday at the annual meeting of the Associate Alumnae. Mrs. McIntosh posed the question: "What Are the Undergraduates Thinking About?"

MEXICO CITY, June 8 -- President Adolfo Lopez Mateos has stepped into the increasingly bitter struggle in Mexico over communism. He warned yesterday that the Government would not tolerate further attacks on the "national tranquility."

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Atomic Energy Commission entered the debate today over the use of atomic explosives to carve out a harbor in Northwestern Alaska. Its argument was that there would be no danger from radioactive fall-out.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 8 -- Monmouth Park opens fifty days of thoroughbred racing at the seaside tomorrow with Pied d'Or, a likely 3-1 choice, among the dozen sprinters entered in the featured $20,000 Oceanport Handicap.

Three artists and five horses, all of whom have shared snug quarters for years in a former carriage house-livery stable at 240 East Twentieth Street, must vacate by July 15 to make way for building wreckers.
Half of the $40,000,000 in promissory notes to be sold by the World's Fair have been subscribed, Robert Moses, president of the fair, announced yesterday.

In 1933 a journeyman pitcher named Lewis Bernard Krausse was released by the Philadelphia Athletics after having acquired, in two and a half seasons in the major leagues, a 5-1 won-lost record, a sore right arm and a total salary of $6,500.

DETROIT, June 8 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians and the Detroit Tigers, locked in a battle for first place in the American League, divided pitchers' battles tonight. The first-place Indians won the opener, 1 -- 0, and the Tigers took the disputed second game of a twilight-night double-header, 2 -- 1.

The Cunard Line passenger ship fleet, the largest in the North Atlantic, will provide 311 trans-Atlantic sailings next year, G.L. Bowen, general passenger manager in this country, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) -- The Navy announced today the development of a device that may make it possible to use the sea as a laboratory for radiation experiments that, on land, would require concrete shielding "a mile or more thick."

JACKSON, Miss., June 8 (UPI) -- Two new groups of Freedom Riders were arrested today. They included four young white girls, a New York State legislator and the president of the Manhattan branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

LOS ANGELES, June 8 (AP) -- Bob Skinner and Bill Mazeroski each slammed a two-run homer in the fourth inning tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates knocked the Los Angeles Dodgers out of first place by defeating them, 4 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Justice Department lawyers are still studying the Supreme Court opinions in the Communist party registration case and making their plans for the next step in the campaign to make the party register.
THE death last week of George S. Kaufman will be considered almost as great a loss by New York's bridge experts as by the theatre world in which he made his fame.

For forgetful stockholders, Walter R. Fletcher has a story with a memorable ending. It began on Feb. 7, 1930, when he received a certificate from his broker, Fenner Beane, for one share of Texas Pacific Coal and Oil Company stock.
All-State Properties, Inc., real estate developer and home builder, which entered the bowling centers business last September, is now diversifying into the barber shop and beauty salon field.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture forecast today that this year's wheat crop would amount to 1,343,022,000 bushels, or 16,000,000 bushels more than predicted a month ago.

Galvanized by a sudden downpour, groundskeepers covered are Stadium infield with a bright green tarpaulin in 1 minute 19 seconds last night. That halted a seventh-inning rally that had propelled the Yankees ahead of the Athletics by a margin of 7 -- 5.

Four Scots, whose average age is 77 years, play golf together twice a week over the rolling hills of the public links in Van Cortlandt Park, but their memories play over the curlier grass and the greener courses of Scotland.

LONDON, June 9 (Reuters) -- Among those on Queen Elizabeth's honors list today were two members of Britain's delegation to the United Nations, Alan Alves Dudley, economics-social minister, named a knight commander of the Order of the British Empire, and Arthur Hillis, fiscal adviser, named companion of the Order of St. Michael and St. George.
The Board of Estimate voted $833,750 more for the new sports stadium in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens, yesterday. But the additional fund was approved only after a sharp debate.
LONDON, June 9 -- An offering of shares for sale by tender next week is the latest attempt by the financial houses here to beat the "stags."
Tax-greedy public officials are precipitating a highway transportation crisis, the president of the Automobile Club of New York asserted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Legislation to relax Federal controls over natural gas producers has been introduced in the House by Chairman Oren Harris, Democrat of Arkansas, of the Commerce Committee.
BANGKOK, Thailand, June 7 -- This sensitive capital is pessimistic about the future of Laos.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- A Federal employe listened today to a contractor accuse him of demanding pay-offs and then denounced the charges as false.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 9 -- Louis Lee Haggin 2d's 4-year-old colt Careless John raced six furlongs in 1:09 at Monmouth Park today to win the $17,350 Oceanport Handicap by three-quarters of a length.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 9 -- A broad new collective approach to the problem posed by Cuba for the inter-American system is emerging from Adlai E. Stevenson's conversations with Latin-American chiefs of state.
A member of the Board of Education denied yesterday that the board had rejected the findings of its Commission of Inquiry on collective bargaining.

Northeast Airlines, Inc., is conducting merger talks with companies other than Trans World Airlines, Inc., David A. Stretch, president of the Atlas Corporation, said yesterday. Atlas, a closed-end investment company dealing in special situations, owns a controlling interest in Northeast.

PARIS, June 9 -- Two men who led a group of Breton farmers yesterday in an assault on the town of Morlaix were charged today with attacks on a public official, damaging public buildings, blocking roads and violating a domicile.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Kennedy Administration planned to put more political muscle behind its omnibus housing bill after a narrowly won victory in the Senate early today.

WINDHOEK, South-West Africa, June 8 -- United Nations intervention in South-West Africa would be welcomed by part of the white population as well as by the Africans, who outnumber the whites ten to one here.

OSTRAVA, Czechoslovakia, June 5 -- A round little woman in coveralls, her gray hair tucked under a greasy kerchief, stepped off the production line at the Klement Gottwald Steel Works to tell how she became a Socialist worker at 51 years of age.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 -- D. Emmert Brumbaugh, former Secretary of Banking for Pennsylvania, told the United States District Court here today that the tendency toward bank mergers in this country was "getting out of hand."
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Army said today it would need more men on active and reserve duty to carry out President Kennedy's plan for increasing the readiness of the Reserve forces.

An increase from 3 to 5 cents in the price of bus transfers was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate for Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., and its subsidiary, Surface Transit, Inc. About 200,000 daily bus riders in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens will be affected.

The bill to provide Federal aid to public elementary and secondary schools was approved by the House Education and Labor Committee more than two weeks ago. The measure should have been brought to the floor this week. Whatever the disguises or the excuses, it has been held up because of the fight, increasing in intensity, over Federal aid to parochial schools.

CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- Moe Thacker singled across the winning run from second in the ninth inning today as the Chicago Cubs outlasted Milwaukee, 11--10, in a game marked by four Braves' homers. The home runs accounted for all the Braves' runs.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- A court-martial was ordered today for Col. William M. Banks on charges arising from the collapse of a Texas tower radar structure off the New Jersey coast last Jan. 15.
Visitors to the City Building at the 1964-65 World's Fair will get a simulated helicopter ride around the five boroughs.

TRENTON, June 9 -- The Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court today upheld the will of a retired 89-year-old Jersey City school teacher who had disinherited her nephew and left an estate of more than $700,000 to a country church in New York.
TOKYO, June 9 -- The Japanese Government approved today an agreement reached between the United States and Japan on the repayment of loans by the United States during the occupation.

The New York Baptist City Society and the Park Avenue Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) at Eighty-fifth Street will join forces on July 1 to make a comprehensive survey of how Protestantism can best serve the Yorkville area in Manhattan.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 6 to 16 points off yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

At 12:19 P.M. yesterday, Jack Jenner, his parents and a friend, Janet Lincoln, pulled up to Pier 84, at Forty-fourth Street, after a leisurely drive from upstate New York. They read with dismay a sign reading "Aurelia Sails June 9 Noon."
MONTAUK, L.I., June 9 -- The Off Soundings Club fleet of 122 yachts took from eight to ten hours today to sail from New London to this port in the opening event of the two-day spring regatta.
LONDON, June 9 -- Prices of industrial shares receded on a wide front in the stock market here today. Falls were heaviest among the leaders.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Senator Thruston B. Morton, Republican of Kentucky, opposed today dipping into the Federal Treasury to help political parties pay their Presidential campaigns.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 9 -- Su Mac Lad, the top-winning trotter this year as well as last, goes to the post for the eighth time this season tomorrow night in the Walter Cox Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

BOSTON, June 9 (AP) -- Ryne Duren of the Los Angeles Angels couldn't finish the game, but he established an American League record tonight by striking out seven consecutive Boston batters in the second game of a twilight-night double-header.
The United States equestrian team disclosed yesterday that it had been notified that its exempt status under the internal revenue laws had been revoked.
The last of 200 new air-conditioned, two-level coaches has been delivered to the Chicago and North Western Railway, the company announced yesterday.

PARIS, June 9 -- Today's most serious diplomatic negotiation is that taking place at Evian-les-Bains, where French aria Algerian nationalist envoys are seeking North African peace. On the outcome of their talks depend critical issues transcending Algeria in importance.

BOATING, once considered a man's sport, is becoming one of the most popular family recreations in America today. In fact, the number of boats afloat reportedly has grown to about eight million, double what it was five years ago.

The winners of the annual college short story contest have been announced by Story Magazine. First prize of $500 was awarded to C.E. Botner, a student of the University of Arizona, for "I Saw the Moon Go." Second prize of $150 went to Helen Essary Ansell of Sarah Lawrence College for "The Threesome."

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The Canada-United States interparliamentary group declared today its support for the use of all necessary force -- including nuclear weapons -- to maintain access by the Western Allies to West Berlin.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 9 (AP) -- Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., said it had instructed Allen and Co., Chicago brokerage house, to buy all available stock of General Outdoor Advertising Company tendered today.

Hotel managers here have been warned that unless they make greater efforts to remove fire hazards, the Fire Department would investigate all hotels "from cellar to roof, and close some floors if necessary."

EVANSTON, Ill., June 9 -- The Council on Undergraduate Life, representing the administration and faculty at Northwestern University, gave unanimous support today to the Interfraternity Council's decision to enforce a deadline of Nov. 1, 1963, for the removal of discriminatory clauses from national fraternity constitutions.
A New York insurance executive has become the fourth board chairman, in as many months, of National Telefilm Associates, Inc., owner of Channel 13.

NEW ORLEANS, June 9 (UPI) -- Segregationist pickets carrying signs saying that their children were "dispossessed" Paraded in front of an integrated school here today as a Negro girl inside got her promotion to the second grade.

Eight dry-cargo and tanker companies, operators of fifty ships, began separate talks with the National Maritime Union yesterday in the first break in the deadlocked labor negotiations that began four weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Post Office moved today to ban Henry Miller's "Tropic of Cancer" from the mails.
ALONG series of tournament hands, played in the Eastern States Championships from May 26 through June 6, delayed the reporting of the deal shown today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 9 -- The Norwegian tanker Sanifjord crashed into the Passyunk Avenue drawbridge over the Schuylkill in South Philadelphia today, but apparently suffered no serious damage.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- James V. Bennett, the director of the United States Bureau of Prisons, told a Senate subcommittee today that television "crime, mayhem and conflict" was one of the factors leading to juvenile delinquency.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit granted the Switchmen's Union of North America authority yesterday to strike against the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 9 -- Attorney General Gideon Hausner submitted today at the trial of Adolf Eichmann what he implied were the complete and unexpurgated memoirs of the former Nazi leader.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 9 (AP) -- Ed Bailey capped a six-run rally in the seventh inning tonight with a three-run homer that led the San Francisco Giants to a 9-6 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
The Air Force's Military Air Transport Service received its first pure jet cargo and troop plane yesterday.

CAIRO, June 9 (AP) -- The newspaper Al Ahram reported today that Premier Khrushchev had bitterly attacked President Gamal Abdel Nasser's suppression of communism in the United Arab Republic and had predicted Nasser's downfall unless he embraced communism.
An active week is ahead in the market for new capital, with $354,882,000 of fixed-interest obligations scheduled for sale.
FROM the fortieth floor at 512 Seventh Avenue, the showroom, workroom and office of Ben Zuckerman command a four-sided view of Manhattan.
The Honolulu Oil Company announced yesterday that its stockholders would receive $379,707,767, or $101.28 a share, from the sale of the company's assets.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 9 -- A key witness to the past conduct of the Dominican Government left the country suddenly today while a subcommittee of the Organization of American States was preparing to collect evidence on conditions here.

HYDRAS ISLAND, Greece, June 9 (Reuters) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy sailed away from this Greek island tonight after a day in which she joined local inhabitants in native dances, dined on Greek food and won the hearts of the 2,000 islanders.

DETROIT, Saturday, June 10 -- A spokesman for the Tractors for Freedom Committee indicated early today that he saw nothing in the message from Premier Castro that would alter the committee's plans to send a group of technicians to Havana Monday.
FARMVILLE, Va., June 9 (AP) -- Prince Edward County, which abandoned its public schools in 1959 to escape court-ordered desegregation, moved today to keep them shut for a third year.
A policeman waiting to testify in Uptown Manhattan Arrest Court yesterday suddenly bolted from the courtroom to thwart a crime taking place across the courtyard.

LE MANS, France, June 9 -- The Le Mans twenty-four-hour race, which begins at 4 o'clock tomorrow afternoon, may mark the end of international sportscar racing as the world has known it for a decade or more.

Chester Hall, a six-story building containing fifty-two apartments and six stores at 1050-58 Southern Boulevard, corner of Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Bonera Realty Corporation. It was bought by an investing client of Allen Brothers, lawyers, for cash over a new first mortgage of $200,000.
Two New Jersey school districts have sold bonds totaling $2,392,000 to an investment banking group headed by John Nuveen Co.
CHICAGO, June 9 -- Swift Co.'s sales for the first six months of the 1961 fiscal year showed an increase while net earnings for the period declined, Foster M. Jarvis, president, reported today.
PARIS, June 9 -- A score of Left-Wing journalists were arrested and an extreme Right-Wing paper was suppressed today under President de Gaulle's special emergency powers.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 9 -- Ambassador William M. Rountree assured Pakistanis today that there had been no change in the attitude of the United States toward Pakistan and that Washington still regarded her as "one of its closest friends."

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, accused the General Motors Corporation today of hiding from its car-buying customers the fact it gets a 15 per cent refund on life insurance it sells them.

In his letter about the "Problems Iran Faces," published by The Times on June 9, Harry S. Kern states that he "was told in Teheran" that the private American company of which David E. Lilienthal and the undersigned are principal officers "has an arrangement by which it is not obliged even to show its books to the Iranian authorities."
LONDON, June 9 (UPI) -- The pound sterling recovered slightly today, after falling yesterday to the lowest level since 1957 under the pressure of growing confidence in the United States dollar.
Mayor Wagner won a decisive victory yesterday in his battle for full control of Charter revision.
RAVENNA. Ky., June 9 (AP) .... A tornado swept through Ravenna this afternoon, injuring about fifty persons.
VADUZ, Liechtenstein, June 9 (UPI) -- Liechtenstein, a stamp-sized country with a stamp-based economy, as an international postage-stamp war on her hands.
MONTREAL, June 9 -- A new theory of how anesthetics operate in the human brain was described here today by Dr. Linus C. Pauling, the Nobel laureate chemist.

Giulio Rinaldi doesn't know it, but he'll be fighting two legendary opponents at Madison Square Garden tonight, Achilles and Nestor. Both of those Homeric figures are represented by Archie Moore, who will be risking his light-heavyweight championship of the world against the 26-year-old challenger from Anzio, Italy.
The Mother Goose Stakes, the second leg of the newly created triple crown for 3-year-old fillies, will be run at Belmont Park today.

Prices generally moved but slightly in a lackadaisical session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, but the eight most active stocks were all up. Aircrafts and cosmetics were the strongest groups.
LOS ANGELES, June 9 (AP) -- Don Drysdale scored his first victory in a month with a four-hitter tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers regained first place by defeating the Philadelphia Phillies, 3 -- 1.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 9 (AP) -- Gov. Matthew E. Welsh halted all new state construction today and announced other economies to meet a "critical financial situation," which he said could bankrupt the state.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 9 (AP) -- About 150 Negroes staged a "Freedom March" through downtown Memphis today, singing hymns as policemen stood by in force.
ALBANY, June 9 -- The Court of Appeals today upheld the right of George Lincoln Rockwell, the self-styled American Nazi leader, to speak in a New York City park.
THE great whirl of fall collections ended yesterday with only one showing. And now the store buyers are turning their attention to the next task at hand, that of writing orders.

Senator Barry M. Goldwater urged graduates of Long Island University yesterday to work for the kind of change "that will better our lives, that will make more secure the blessings of freedom in this country."

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 9 -- The Westchester Mandolin Orchestra, which has been performing at free concerts throughout Westchester County since 1948, will forgo its regular weekly rehearsal on Wednesday.

Fred H. Hill has resold the three-story store and loft building at 206 East Fiftieth Street to an investing client of Paul Schorr, lawyer. He bought the property recently from George Victor Robert John Innes-Ker, the Duke of Roxburghe. It was resold for cash over a purchase money first mortgage of $100,000 for one year at 6 per cent interest.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 9 -- Sarah Lawrence College awarded degrees to eighty-three women today at its thirty-third commencement.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Spokesmen for common carrier barge lines asked Congress today for relief from a problem thrust on them by a ruling of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 9 (AP) -- The Justice Department has objected to a Federal court order prohibiting groups and individuals from sponsoring Freedom Rides into Alabama. In a brief filed in United States district court here department attorneys contend that the Freedom Riders are merely exercising constitutional rights.

LARRY McMURTRY'S "Horseman, Pass By,"* owes its title to a line from a great poem by William Butler Yeats and its spirit, perhaps, to something of what Yeats called "still the indomitable Irishry." But the scene of Mr. McMurtry's excellent first novel is Texas -- far from Yeats' Dublin or Ben Bulben or Innisfree.

PLUMMER LIMITED, which recently moved to 3 East Fifty-seventh Street, diagonally across from its old haunt at 734 Fifth Avenue, not only has a new spacious interior, but also two new departments on its second floor.

Magistrate Manuel Gomez attempted in Housing Court yesterday to pierce what he called the "veil" of ownership of a slum tenement at 17 West 118th Street before sentencing the owner on Health Department charges.

The nation's retailers increased their sales in May more than 3 per cent above the April level and 1 per cent above the volume for May, 1960, according to a preliminary report issued yesterday by the Department of Commerce.

The new cooperative college scholarship program for African students is a soundly based, carefully thought-out plan, in contrast to some of the "crash" programs that contain more "crash" than "program." It will this year give some 300 carefully selected Africans a free four-year course in carefully selected colleges. About 150 institutions are involved.

Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union, in a fighting finish for first place in the ninth round of the international chess masters tournament at the Moscow Central Club, yesterday defeated his countryman, V. Bakulin, according to a report from the Soviet Union.

MONTREAL, June 8 -- Apparently senseless acts of juvenile delinquency in an era of social and economic security were reviewed here today by a British psychiatrist. His findings help to explain why "good boys in good families" go wrong.

The board of directors of Swank, Inc., maker of men's jewelry and accessories, has voted a two-for-one split of the common stock, it was announced yesterday. The split would be made by issuing one additional share for each share held on July 15 to stockholders of record of June 16.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- Representative Gordon H. Scherer, Ohio Republican, said today that "instructions from the White House" had stalled an investigation of how a man convicted of contempt of Congress had got a Federal scholarship soon after his trial.

Brooklyn lost out to Miami Beach yesterday in a 2-to-1 decision in the United States Court of Appeals. The judges ruled that two Miami restaurants called "Wolfies" were solely entitled to use that trade name and that a Brooklyn resstaurant must give up the same name.
A new master, and one of the youngest, was on the bridge of the Zim Lines' Zion when the 9,855-ton Israeli liner sailed for the Mediterranean yesterday.

IF a poll were taken it would probably show that cornstarch is most frequently used in American homes as an ingredient in lemon pies. It has a multitude of other uses, however, and it is totally indispensable in French cuisine.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Carl B. Spaeth, lawyer and diplomat, has been selected as Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American affairs.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The United States' only official "press agent" on home soil received an award here today for "superior service" to the 500 foreign correspondents in New York and thereby to "better understanding of what stirs us as a people."
LONDON, June 9 -- A cross-section of British life and livelihood was chosen today for the birthday honors of Queen Elizabeth II.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 9 -- Following is the text of a resolution adopted tonight by the Security Council on the situation in Portuguese Angola:
I want to correct one statement in Joseph A. Loftus' article published on May 22 discussing my criticism of the Administration's action on Cuba.

As a present private citizen but also as a former member of Mayor Wagner's administration (Commissioner of Welfare -- 1951 to 1959) I wish to protest the tone of your June 5 editorial review of the Mayor's TV presentation.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 2 -- Ankara these days is betwixt and between. The old Menderes regime is finished and in jail; the new regime has not yet begun. The revolutionary junta, having "thrown out the rascals," has declined to use its power to make a revolution.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The index of primary market prices rose to 119.0 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 9 (AP) -- Four major oil refining concerns are abandoning "fair trade" prices for their gasoline in Pennsylvania.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 9 -- The Women's Tri-County Golf Association opened its season today with a one-day tournament over the Westchester Hills Country Club course.
Communist China's desperate food shortage seems largely responsible for a curious slowdown in the communization of Tibet that has been ordered from Peiping.
Monday marks the twentieth anniversary of the start of the national tree farm program.
ST. LOUIS, June 9 (AP) -- Ken Boyer drove in three runs with two singles tonight to lead a St. Louis Cardinal twelve-hit attack in on 8-4 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges announced today the appointment of LeRoy Collins, former Governor of Florida, as chairman of the twenty-five member advisory committee on Federal aid to the depressed areas.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 9 (AP) -- The Rev. Odon Lenard, a Roman Catholic priest, stirred a courtroom today by pleading innocent of attempting to overthrow the Communist regime here.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Ten countries bought gold from the United States in the first quarter of this year, compared with twenty-six at the peak of the "gold rush" in the closing months of last year.

RANGOON, Burma, June 9 (AP) -- The Government motorship Aung Teza sank in the Andaman Sea Wednesday and shipping officials said tonight that of the 125 persons aboard only forty survivors had been found.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 9 -- Nationalist China expressed its concern and resentment today over the United States move to establish diplomatic relations with Communist-governed Outer Mongolia.

The trial of French armed forces officers for mutiny in Algiers serves to recall that sometimes the French like to turn a courtroom into a political backdrop and sounding board. French trial procedures and customs make this fairly easy.

William P. Rosensohn, promoter of the first heavyweight championship fight between Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson, was called "a swindler, artist of fraud and perjurer" yesterday in General Sessions Court.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- President Kennedy has made it clear that United States ambassadors are in full charge of American Government activities in the countries in which they are stationed.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- A new enzyme called keratinase, discovered at the Institute of Microbiology of Rutgers University, may revolutionize the traditional methods of making leather. It digests wool much as the clothes moth does.

PALM BEACH, Fla., June 9 -- President Kennedy took to crutches today to lift the pressure from aching muscles in his lower back. His condition, caused by back strain on May 16, was described late in the day as "improved."
Mayor Wagner called yesterday for a detailed summary of the Hospitals Commissioner's proposals to close general care facilities at Fordham and Greenpoint Hospitals by July 1.
PESHAWAR, Pakistan, June 1 -- In one afternoon in Peshawar, it is possible to span nearly 2,000 years.

BOSTON, June 9 -- Allen W. Dulles said tonight that the Soviet Union appeared to be on the right track toward achieving an overhaul of managerial incentives in its drive to overtake the United States industrially.
LONDON, June 9 (Reuters) -- Alleged recruiting activities of a Texas college's athletic director will be the subject of a protest to the British Lawn Tennis Association, it was disclosed tonight.
Final plans for the Battery Park slum clearance project have been submitted to the City Planning Commission for public hearings, the Housing and Redevelopment Board announced yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 9 -- An unusually large coalition in the Security Council adopted tonight a resolution calling on Portugal to "desist forthwith from repressive measures" in the West African territory of Angola.

BIRMINGHAM, England, June 9 (Reuters) -- The Australians pounded the English bowling on the second day of the first cricket test today. At the close the visitors had 359 runs for five wickets -- a lead of 164.
PHILADELPHIA, June 9 (AP) -- American Viscose Corporation announced today it will build a plant to make Avicel, an edible cellulose, on a commercial scale.

GENEVA, June 9 -- A break in the deadlock that has stalled the international conference on Laos suddenly appeared tonight after a forty-five-minute talk between W. Averell Harriman and Andrei A. Gromyko.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 9 -- A meeting of heads of state of uncommitted nations will be held in Yugoslavia beginning Sept. 1, Tanyug, the Yugoslav press agency, declared tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has sent all members of the American Stock Exchange a detailed eight-page questionnaire, inquiring about their activities since July 1, 1956.
A letter from Johannes Filiusgeraldi Kennediensis has been proudly framed by the eximiae puellae of the Dalton School here.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- A 28-year-old clerk from the National Security Agency, William Hyter Covington of Laurel, Md., was being sought tonight as a missing person.
TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 9 -- The population explosion has come to Tuxedo Park, and today the Federal Government granted this four-square-mile area of gracious living $5,000 to help solve the problem.
The estimated cost of the Hartford Pavilion and Cafe to be built in Central Park has risen from $862,500 to $1,712,000.
JACKSON, Miss., June 9 (UPI) -- Negro attorneys filed suit in the United States District Court here today to stop the arrest of Freedom Riders under Mississippi segregation laws.

Crawford Clothes, Inc., filed yesterday a petition in voluntary bankruptcy under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act. Terms of settlement are to be submitted to creditors, but the company said that claims would be paid in full.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered a westward extension of the Eastern Time Zone today.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that thirty-two school construction inspectors and supervisors would be suspended for allegedly accepting gifts from concerns working for the Board of Education. The thirty-two represent about a fourth of the staff.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The Washington Senators took tko hairline decisions from the Chicago White Sox tonight -- 1 -- 0 in ten innings on the six-hit pitching of Dick Donovan and 10 -- 9 on a ninth-inning rally that produced four runs.

GENEVA, June 9 -- The United States accused the Soviet Union today of trying to set the clock back more than 100 years with its proposal for a three-member administration to supervise the ban on nuclear tests.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission and the Civil Aeronautics Board endorsed a bill today to relieve members of Federal regulatory agencies from ruling on routine cases.
CHICAGO, June 9 (UPI) -- The General Board of the National Council of Churches endorsed today "non-violent movement" to break down the bars of segregation in interstate travel in the South.

IN a hazardous arena humanely reserved for hardy youths, Archibald Lee Moore has become a living legend by remaining irrepressibly young at heart. His attitude should rank high on the list of neatest tricks of the past quarter century -- the span of his career as a professional boxer.
Six Bronx youths accused of committing seventy-five burglaries "for kicks" were indicted yesterday.

DETROIT, June 9 (AP) -- Bubba Phillips cracked a 3-and-2 pitch into the lower left-field seats with one out in the ninth inning tonight and lifted the first-place Cleveland Indians to a 5-4 triumph over the second-place Detroit Tigers. A crowd of 43,427 looked on.

HOUSTON, June 9 (AP) -- Most of the Negro track stars entered in the Meet of Champions withdrew from the competition tonight. They pulled out in protest of what they called segregated seating of spectators.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- United States officials rejected today as unfounded the Soviet charge that West German parliamentary meetings in West Berlin would con stitute "provocations endangering peace."
CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- Liquidation became general in late grain futures dealings today and all prices on the Board of Trade weakened.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The Government named today the first 114 areas that are eligible for special Federal aid under the new program designed to help root out pockets of heavy and persistent unemployment.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Half of all American families had money incomes of at least $5,600 in 1960 -- an increase of about $200 over 1959.

HAVANA, Saturday, June 10 -- Premier Fidel Castro agreed early today to receive experts from the Tractors for Freedom Committee of United States citizens to discuss details of an exchange of prisoners for tractors.
Futures prices for commodities were irregular with most moving in narrow ranges yesterday on New York exchanges. Trading was relatively quiet.

The appointment of John I. Henry as director of communications of The New York Times was announced yesterday. He succeeds Fred E. Meinholtz, who had been in the communications department since 1920 and had held the title of director since 1931.

FRESNO, Calif., June 9 (UPI) -- A husky high school pitcher who never has been defeated today signed a contract with the Milwaukee Braves for a bonus "in excess of $100,000."

EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, June 10 -- The Algerian Nationalists and the French got down to the hard grind of negotiating a solution to one of the world's most difficult colonial problems this week, some ten days ahead of a quasi-deadline established by the French side for June 20.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., June 10 -- Francis Drake Wells of 323 Forest Avenue here and of Manchester, Vt., and Southold, L.I., a senior partner in the New York law firm of Coudert Brothers, died today in Mountainside Hospital in Montclair. He was 54 years old.

ANY big-league scout will freely admit that the scarcest commodities on the baseball market are catchers. The two ball clubs most successful at snaring these rare critters are the Yankees and the Chicago White Sox. The Yanks collect them as philatelists collect stamps. They have four crackerjacks in Yogi Berra, Elston Howard, John Blanchard and Jesse Gonder, even though jolly Jesse is temporarily on loan to the Richmond farm.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -The Government is offering a two-and-a-half-acre island for sale, secure in the knowledge that it will bring a good price. The security is the product of a seller's market -- fewer and fewer islands and more and more island buyers.

SINCE the death of the British author and playwright, Israel Zangwill, in 1926, a good novel about Anglo-Jewry has been as rare as a pro-Semitic demonstration in Trafalgar Square. Now, with an accolade of applause from the English critics, comes "The Crossing Point," a panorama of Jewish life on the outskirts of London.
MONTREAL, Que., June 10 -Psychiatrists from sixty-two countries at the Third World Congress of Psychiatry, which concluded here today, heard more than 500 scientific reports.

A close and delicate look at the life of Anna Vorontosov, teacher of a kindergarten in the New Zealand hinterland: her unfulfilled but long remembered romance; her sometimes exasperating but always rewarding relation with her small charges that supports her through the daily round.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 10 -- Off at 9-1, the Jaclyn Stable's 3-year-old Hasty Honey charged through the stretch today to win the six-furlong Select Handicap by four lengths from the 12-5 favorite, H.O.H. Frelinghuysen's Merry Ruler. The winning colt was the fourth choice of the 24,302 Monmouth Park fans.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -The Communist party, U.S.A., suffered two more blows this week in the Supreme Court. WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) -- The Navy has reduced the price of defense to a standard the average housewife can understand and sympathize with.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The mental and physical urge which drives President Kennedy to inspect, talk about and perform for himself so many more things than any predecessor is becoming a matter of concern in Washington. But there is at least a connection.

Last week the Security Council joined the General Assembly in bringing pressure on Portugal to carry out reforms in Angola and to admit United Nations investigators. In fact, the Security Council went further than the General Assembly did last March. Without waiting for a report from the investigators named by the Assembly, it adopted a resolution deploring the "large-scale killings" in Angola and admonished Portugal to cease "repressive measures" forthwith.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 9 -- Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina lies in a crypt in the $250,000 church he erected in his native town of San Cristobal. The regime he put together in thirty-one years as the strong man here runs on -perhaps even more smoothly.
The election of Rabbi Eugene J. Lipman as spiritual leader of Temple Sinai in Washington was announced yesterday.

What is the Standard Oil Company (Kentucky) worth? This is a question that many in the oil industry have been trying to determine since the announcement last week that the Department of Justice had approved its proposed merger into the Standard Oil Company of California.

ON Harbour Island, at the tip of Eleuthera in the Bahamas, you can stand on the bluff over the beach and hear it: the distant, rumbling roar -like a freight train that never ends. It is the sound of the sea thundering onto the jagged reef a mile off the island.
An appeal for funds to send 1,280 city children to upstate camps this summer will be started this week by the Catholic Youth Organization.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) -- Gen. Thomas D. White, retiring Air Force Chief of Staff, doubts that President Kennedy would spend extra money for powerful intercontinental bombers even if Congress provided it. He gave his opinion in testimony delivered nearly a month ago but disclosed for the first time today.
BALTIMORE, June 10 (AP) -- Hoyt Wilhelm, a relief pitcher checked a ninth-inning rally by Minnesota today as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Twins, 4 -- 3, on a two-run homer by Ron Hansen.
A new round of defaults in the dollar-payable bonds of foreign governments is bringing into focus serious financial, political and legal questions related to international debt contracts.
AYER, Mass., June 8 -- Ever since Tuesday morning men like Frank Hasey have spent much of their time watching clean-up work at the site of Ayer's worst fire in eighty-nine years.
BRIDGETON, N.J., June 10 (AP) -- Vice Admiral Wallace M. Beakley, Deputy Chief of Naval Operations for Fleet Readiness, said Thursday night that the super aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk was badly built.
About 400 theatre associates and friends paid tribute yesterday to Robert E. Griffith, the Broadway producer, who died Wednesday of a heart attack. He was 54 years old.

THERE is little mystery left these in the functioning of the Executive or Legislative branches of the Government. The idly curious can find in their newspapers or on their television screens intimate accounts of how even the President does his job.

IT seems unfortunate that in our present pan-psychiatric mood any criticism of a new form of psychiatric treatment is regarded as an expression of hostility and narrow-mindedness on the part of the reviewer.

A showdown is in the making over who is to distribute the country's merchandise at retail and how it is to be done. The conventional retailers and the discounters are fighting it out, with the favor of the consumers as the prize.

HANOVER, N.H., June 10 -- Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Dartmouth staged an exciting warm-up for next week's Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta today when M.I.T. won a two-mile race by less than half a length. Columbia was third, another five lengths back over the Connecticut River course.
ST. LOUIS, June 10 (AP) -Joey Jay posted his seventh consecutive victory today, pitching the Cincinnati Reds to a 4-2 decision over the St. Louis Cardinals with some ninthinning help from Bill Henry.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Representative William E. Miller, Republican of upstate New York, has told colleagues that he wants to bring some new and youthful faces to the party leadership's "Ev and Charlie" television show.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 10 -Su Mac Lad's dominance of the world's free-for-all trotters ended abruptly tonight. The 7-year-old gelding, undefeated in all seven previous outings this season, finished third behind Air Record and Silver Song in the Walter Cox Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

ST. PAUL, June 10 -- Minnesota's Legislature adjourned its biennial session Thursday after twenty-three weeks of regular and special sessions without redistricting to accommodate for loss of a Representative.

THINGS have been literally jumping in the realm of air transport the past few days, some of them having value and serious import for the industry and its customers, and others so inane as to make the reader blush for the officials involved.
" MY FAIR LADY" will set a new record on July 11 when it gives its 2,213th performance, outdistancing the previous, long-run musical champion, "Oklahoma!"
A 9-year-old boy was fatally shot last night in the Bronx when his older brothers were attacked by five men in a grudge fight.
THREE one-man and two group exhibits currently on display here reflect contemporary photographers' absorbing interest in the human scene.
BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., June 10 -- Two hundred and eighty-six years ago, 300 refugees from the Popham Beach colony, escaping from Indians, landed on near-by Damariscove Island because of an emergency.

MORRISBURG, Ont. -- The formal opening here on June 24 of Upper Canada Village, the reincarnation of a typical nineteenth-century community, comes at a time in history when Canadians are really beginning to appreciate the story of their beginning and the significance of their heritage.
A letter by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and one by Gen. Robert E. Lee were purchased last week by Philip D. Sang, a Chicago business man and autograph collector.
HARLECH, Wales, June 10 (AP) -- Bob Sandler of Iowa yesterday became the first American to win the British Society of One-Armed Golfers championship. He defeated A.S. Eggo of Scotland, 7 and 5.

JUNE, the month of weddings, graduation parties and flower shows, is also the month of roses in the northeastern part of the United States. Although many rose fanciers prefer to admire the blooms in the garden, there are others who delight in arranging them.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 10 -- From ten foreign countries and areas throughout the United States Vassar alumnae flocked back today for the centennial of "a magnificent enterprise,'' as Matthew Vassar called the college for women he founded.
GLEN COVE, L. I., June 10 -- The city took over the main pumping plant of a private water supply company here today to repair the main pumps among four that supply this city with drinking water.
The Atco Marine Corporation has moved into 46 South Street, one of the waterfront's historic buildings, which was owned in the early nineteenth century by William Whitlock Jr.

An industry's split personality came in for some strong words last week from Philip Sporn, spirited and outspoken president of the American Electric Power Company, one of the nation's largest and most profitable utilities.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N.H. -- History will be repeated next Sunday afternoon when a horse and buggy will leave the Glen House at the base of Mount Washington and travel up the Old Carriage Road to the summit.

ONCE upon a time I spent last two days of a trans-Atlantic ship-crossing puzzling out a Dutch translation of a P.G. Wodehouse story left on board, I suppose by a Dutch passenger. I knew nothing of the language. But I was fresh out of reading matter, and the rest of the scanty ship's library made Jeeves in Dutch seem preferable.

IN his review of my book, "The Couch and the Circle," Dr. Thomas S. Szasz illustrates that differences of opinion exist among psychiatrists on methods of psychological treatment. He also distorts the content of the book and misrepresents the motives of a fellow psychoanalyst in writing about the application of psychoanalytic understanding and principles in group psychotherapy.

HOLLYWOOD. THE most heated argument in Hollywood today -apart from the perennial row about whether stars get too much money -- revolves around the principle that might be described as representation without taxation.
BALTIMORE, June 10 -- The Chicago White Sox tonight made a fourfor-four player swap with the Kansas City Athletics.

DURING the Twenties, these Sunday drama pages were put to bed every week by George S. Kaufman, the sardonic playwright who died at the age of 71 on June 2. From 1917 to 1930 he was drama editor of The Times.

Archibald Lee Moore, philosopher, poet, humorist, actor and boxing champion, was more brilliant in the dressing room last night than he was in polishing off Giulio Rinaldi in their light-heavyweight title fight at Madison Square Garden.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, June 10 (AP) -- Stockholders of Century Food Markets, Inc., approved today the sale of its thirty-nine food stores to Loblaw, Inc., of Buffalo. The merger will be effective Monday.
A city-wide round-up of known sex offenders was ordered last night by police officials investigating the slaying of a 7-year-old boy whose body was found Friday night on a tenement roof.

NICE, France -- It is true that there are two main concentration points for tourists in France -- Paris and the Riviera. Yet, for motorized tourists, the 650 miles that lie between them can be fascinating, for scenery, history, architecture and gastronomy.

WHEN the author of "Kicks Co." sat down at the piano before the cameras of the National Broadcasting Company's "Dave Garroway Today Show" recently, he was in need of $40,000 if his musical was to open on Broadway in the fall.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Herman Kahn, director of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Library at Hyde Park, N.Y., was appointed today a special assistant to the archivist of the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) -- Senators who like their scenery free of advertisements of beer and baby foods mounted a determined drive today to ban billboards along the nation's growing network of interstate highways.

The nation's women are the principal victims of rising education costs. A major reason: parents are more inclined to scrape up money to finance the education of sons than daughters. This is a conclusion of a survey by the American Association of State Universities and Land Grant Colleges, which covered its ninety-four members. The survey was published last week.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 7 -Anxiety is apparent in the Pacific Northwest over Canada's delay in ratifying a treaty for cooperative development of water resources in the Columbia River basin.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 10 -- The United States plans to welcome some criticisms of its management of the Pacific islands under its jurisdiction but to insist also that its fifteen-year record there can stand scrutiny.
Flushing gained more in population between 1950 and 1960 than any other community in Queens, according to the Queens Chamber of Commerce.
BOSTON, June 10 -- Medals and citations were awarded tonight to nine winners of Brandeis University's Creative Arts Awards for 1961.
PROPER care of rosebushes will encourage vigorous plants to blossom through the summer. Good deeds for rosarians include mulching, feeding, watering and pest control.
THE temper of America Indians has reached the boiling point. One symptom is the American Indian Chicago Conference this Tuesday, where Indians will expound their complaints and desires.

Department store sales in this area last week were estimated by leading merchants to be 3 to 5 per cent greater than in 1960. Sportswear, dresses and children's wear were said to be selling well, while volume in white goods and shoes was off.

ON the evening of May 20 a heavy silence descended on Algiers. The streets were deserted, save for patrols of helmeted soldiers, armed to the teeth. They edged almost furtively past the shuttered windows of the houses as though in an enemy town.

DARIEN, Conn., June 10 -Youth activities sponsored by Darien civic organizations and aid to the United States Equestrian Team will gain from proceeds of the thirty-second annual horse show and horse show ball held by the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

A committee of the International Air Transport Association, assigned to study promotional air fares on the trans-Atlantic routes, will meet in London July 18. The five-man group, which convened in New York early this month, arranged the London meeting to assure wide representation.

In the Times of May 14, Bosley Crowther writes about the German film "The Bridge." Mr. Crowther refers to "The Bridge" as wallowing in defeat, and further indicates this is conceivably a masochistic trend of nationalistic proportion for the purpose of "a purge."
HOUSTON, June 10 (UPI) -- Dave Styron of Southern Illinois set a Meet of Champions record last night in the 220yard dash despite a soggy track.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., June 9 -- This historic old city on the Hudson, where George Washington once made his headquarters and where he rebuked a colonel who would have made him a king, is wrestling these days with a problem as old as sin and perhaps as insoluble -what to do about its poor.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -"Byrd's Nest Shelter" was dedicated today near the top of Old Rag Mountain in Shenandoah National Park, Virginia.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, June 10 -- Six hundred pounds of ducks and geese are resting in a cold storage locker here while Federal and state officials try to resolve a conflict between Alaskan Eskimos' ancient hunting rights and United States treaty obligations.

These are the questions troubling manufacturers of automobiles, appliances and other durable goods, department and mail order store operators and installment lenders.

In an article titled "For Want of $3.94 --," published in this magazine April 30, we told the story of an Iranian peasant stricken with a brain tumor and going blind. The head of the Zionist Organization of America said yesterday that assimilation was "the greatest peril to Jewish Survival," and called on American Jews to strengthen the Jewish day school system.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 10 -An-out-of-the-blue victory by Bob Harper of Pennsylvania in the 440-yard run paced the combined Cornell and Pennsylvania track and field squad to victory over a favored Oxford and Cambridge side, 8 first places to 7, in a dual meet today.

TRIESTE, Italy -- The ideal way to arrive at this port high in the Adriatic is by ship from Venice. The approach by sea is fitting, for the story of Trieste is written in terms of shipping. It is first and last a seaport, and the visitor who comes here from Venice is given a point of view, a frame of reference.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) -- Marty Keough's two-out homer off Russ Kemmerer in the fifteenth inning gave the Washington Senators a 4-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox today. The Senators swept the three-game series.

Announcements of plans for industrial expansion and new plants increased sharply during April and May as improvement in the general economic life of the Chicago area was noted. The Association of Commerce and Industry reported that projects valued at $37,754,000 were announced in May.
In his article "Secret Mission in an Open Society" (May 21) Harry Howe Ransom cites two examples where the C.I.A. aided in the overthrow of two established governments: in Iran and Guatemala.
EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, June 10 -- The French-Algerian peace talks recessed here today until Tuesday in a near deadlock.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 10 -The leaders of Kenya's largest African party said today that they would attempt to arrange a secret meeting of all Legislative Council members and police officers to discuss reports of Communist infiltration of the territory.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 2 -- Air Congo, an airline being set up here by Sabena, the Belgian airline, and the Congolese Government will eventually fly to other parts of Africa and Europe under present plans, in addition to providing service within the country.

Early roses -- and even some hybrid teas -- are now in bloom in the New York area. Many local gardeners report that climbing and rambler types are colorful. Also brightening the June flower display are rhododendrons, iris, daylilies and mountain laurel.

FOR many cautious northern area gardeners the middle part of June -when balmy nights have come to stay -- is the traditional "safe" time to put all the tender house plants outdoors for summer vacations.

GENEVA, June 10 -- India asked Britain and the Soviet Union today to reconvene the conference on Laos Monday. No meetings of the fourteen-nation conference have been held since the Western powers announced Wednesday that they would not attend any more sessions until steps had been taken to insure the cease-fire in Laos.
Borough offices and swimming pools under the Parks Department are now accepting entries for a series of swimming meets, for boys 18 years and under and girls 16 years and under.

AS a very pleasing shift of pace from the abundance of tormented, introspective novels, Yashar Kemal (described in a newspaper story as an "angry young Turk" ), has written a book that is in tone a folk legend, in content an evocation of a society, a way of life, an era, an exotic world.
Political developments in various parts of the world this month are having a direct effect on the price the consumer pays for sugar.

LONDON, June 10 (Reuters) -- The first London edition of The Sunday Dispatch came out fifteen minutes late tonight after some newsmen stopped work amid rumors of the paper's sale to the Sunday Express. The Express is owned by Lord Beaverbrook.

SEOUL, Korea, June 10 -- The military junta that ruthlessly replaced South Korea's hothouse democracy with a military dictatorship the morning of May 16 is staring rather empty-handedly these days at what it has wrought.

MANDEVILLE, Jamaica -- Remote from the ken of most Jamaicans and virtually all island visitors, a mysterious no-man's land called the Cockpit Country exists as a tropical wilderness only twenty miles in from Montego Bay.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 9 -- The Government's refusal to aid religious education was described today by Bishop Lawrence J. Shehan of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Bridgeport, Conn., as "against all religion and therefore against morality itself."
MILTON, N.J., June 10 -- A man who believes North Jersey abounds in creativity has decided to bring the mountain to the talent.

IN the Thirties, summer stock meant a group of dedicated young actors settling down in the country to practice their art in a temple that had been, only yesterday, a barn. Salaries were slim, audiences small, dramas dominant, and musicals scorned. In the Sixties, summer stock means stars, big money, plays "packaged" in Manhattan to tour the hinterlands -- and musicals everywhere.

FARMVILLE, Va., June 10 (AP) -- The subdued war of attrition between whites and Negroes on the field of education has reached its second anniversary in the Virginia County of Prince Edward. Neither side has yet signaled a truce.
PALM BEACH, Fla., June 10 -- President Kennedy's back strain discomfort continues to diminish, his physician said today.
Bill Cox of Noroton, Conn., the national Tigercat sailing champion, took the lead yesterday on the first day of the Eastern Multihull Sailing Association's regatta at the Bayside (Queens) Yacht Club.

HOLLYWOOD. THOSE who considered the Walt Disney Studio a fantasy factory back in the old days, when the producer was devoting his time exclusively to the filming of animated cartoons, should see it today.
TYRONE, Pa., June 10 -- Dr. John Carnett Howell, former Professor of Surgery at the Graduate School of Medicine of the University of Pennsylvania, died today at his home here. He was 60 years old.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 10 -- The acquisition of a ten-acre site here for a county workhouse for seventy-five men as recommended to the Bergen County Board of Freeholders this week by a committee headed by County Judge Arthur J. O'Dea.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 10 -An Arabic paraphrase of what President Kennedy wrote in a letter to Arab chiefs of state in the Middle East last month has been published by the newspaper Al Bina.

Aided by a last-minute pre-holiday impetus, sales of new automobiles advanced to 7,225 in May, highest monthly total of the year to date, but still below the 1960 level. A post-holiday letdown occured, however, and sales of 1,484 units in the week ended June 3, represented a six-week low.

WHEN a family of four living in the New York metropolitan area decides to take a brief vacation -- one amounting to what is known as a long weekend -- the problem of finding a place that will please both adults and children can sometimes be difficult, especially if something out of the ordinary is desired.

THIS is a factual, albeit somewhat biased, account of the long-drawn struggle of Caryl Chessman to escape the gas-chamber at San Quentin, a case that has done untold damage to American prestige. It is also a full-dress biography, covering his unhappy childhood, his boy-gangster years, his stints in reform school -- and the years of crime and imprisonment that brought him to his final plight. As a book, it is interesting, exciting, and important.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- In the midst of weighty decisions on communism this week the Supreme Court threw new light on another old issue -- the relationship between fair trial and free press.

ANN ARBOR, June 10 (AP) -- Chheng Guan Lim, whose fear of scholastic failure drove him into hiding in a church loft for four years, will be among the 3,700 persons to be graduated by the University of Michigan next week.

BOSTON -- Hikers who follow well-marked trails through the White Mountains of New Hampshire this summer owe a debt to the Appalachian Mountain Club. Members of the club were leaders in the movement that has led to the establishment of national forests.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) -- The Civil Rights Commission has received complaints about racial discrimination from every state except Vermont and North Dakota, a survey shows. Most have been from Louisiana and Alabama.
