FOR the gardener who wants continual bloom, late June is a bare period. The last of the spring perennials, delphinium, monkshood and late iris have faded, and the annuals have not yet begun to blossom well enough to make any show. I have found perennial musk mallow (Malva moschata) an excellent filler for this period.

GLOUCESTER, Mass -- A four-tiered church spire welcomes visitors to this old New England settlement around the clock. It flashes its daytime greeting in the Cape Ann sun, and after dark it radiates the warm glow of discreet floodlighting.

ROME. AT the central post office, a former convent, in Rome's Piazza San Silvestro, the clerk at the telephoto window glances appreciatively at a picture of a curvaceous blonde locked in combat with a slim, pretty brunette. The blonde is a movie starlet who has been much in the news lately. "Whose hair is she pulling?" the clerk asks serenely. "Isn't that her director's wife?"

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 9 -- Ambassador Adlai Stevenson's scouting mission to South America is taking policy bearings that promise to influence heavily the Kennedy Administration's relations toward this area for some time.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 10 -- The Danish Parliament decided today to hand over to Iceland several thousand historical documents that have been in the possession of Copenhagen University for 300 years.
Twenty-five years ago next Saturday twelve men met in the district headquarters of the United Mine Workers in Pittsburgh and set up a committee to organize the steel industry.

HOBOKEN, N.J., June 10 -The graduating class of Stevens Institute of Technology was told today that world-wide cooperation in scientific fields and the exchange of technical information might help to break down the barriers between Communist and non-Communist countries.
The former head of the Board of Education's Bureau of Construction has been accused of accepting money and gifts from contractors working for the city school system.

Comeback, Inc., will benefit from the first Comeback Gala, to be held in the Embassy Ballroom of the Summit Hotel on Oct. 9. Mrs. Edmund F. Johnstone is chairman of the "Seven to Eleven" dinner dance, which will feature a showing of "Furs Around the World."

BIRMINGHAM, England, June 10 (Reuters) -- Australia scored 516 runs for nine wickets declared today for a first-innings lead of 321 on the third day of the first cricket test against England. Rain held up play several times.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 10 (AP) -- A gasoline tank truck overturned and exploded on the edge of the downtown district today, injuring at least seventy-one persons, including thirty-eight children and teen-agers, and setting nearby houses afire.

AMSTERDAM -- A walk in the center of this big Dutch city becomes a study in contrasts, old and new. One's course is plotted through a maze of little streets and beside canals lined with gems of ancient architecture, the mansions of the city's merchant-princes of the seventeenth century. One discovers vistas down the tree-bordered canals to quaint bridges and old churches. The great Dutch painters painted scenes like this three hundred years ago.

MURIEL BEADLE'S views of Oxford, "These Ruins Are Inhabited," may not belong with the knitting -- yet it is difficult to determine just what place should be reserved for this kind of book. So many travelers who settle down in one spot long enough to rent a house feel impelled to write a book these days.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Advocates of a liberal foreign trade policy are quietly turning their backs on the Reciprocal Trade Law, for which they have fought for the last quarter century.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, June 1 -- The possible entry of Britain into the European Economic Community, or Common Market, is worrying New Zealand. Some persons say New Zealand faces her greatest crisis since World War II.

BONN, Germany, June 10 -The "cold war" rages around the globe, erupting with occasionel virulence at distant spots -- now a Laotian jungle, a steaming Congolese port, a swampy Cuban beach. But the focal point of conflict is the dot on the map or North Central Europe that represents Berlin.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The prolonged East-West negotiations on a nuclear test ban began to take on the appearance this week of a psychological chess game in which each side was trying to checkmate the other in the eyes of the world before getting up from the negotiating table.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- The apartment-construction boom in Florida continues to grow. Four projects totaling about $20,000,000 are to be started soon in this area. Two of these, the $9,000,000 Coral Ridge Towers, a sixteen-story building with 330 apartments in the Galt Ocean Mile district, and the $4,000,000 Atlantic Towers, are being financed under an F.H.A. program that permits forty-year mortgages and low initial down payments.
LONDON, June 7 -- The changing face of Britain was drawn in statistics today.
LONDON, June 10 -- Sir Anthony Eden called today for "a political general staff" of Western leaders to enable free countries to stand up to "the monolithic mass which is the Communist world."
THERE is an adage of the theatre that save an actor can never go wrong doing a show about a baby, a dog, a doctor or Abraham Lincoln.

DANNY KAYE, who made his official television debut (a debut can be sliced many ways for promotional purposes) last October, is expected to star on another special hour-long program next fall over the Columbia Broadcasting System.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -The State Department is reducing its training program in the languages of Southeast Asia. Lack of volunteers among Foreign Service officers is blamed for the cutback.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -There are growing signs that President Kennedy's proposal to continue the foreign economic aid program this year at a cost of nearly $3,000,000,000 will encounter greater difficulties with Congress than aid programs have met in many years.

THE news from the Congo, Angola, Kenya, the Union of South Africa naturally leads many Westerners to think of Africa as a place of bloodshed, chaos, racial bitterness, warring tribal factions -- indeed, as a threat to the continued existence of the United Nations.

LONDON. IT is nine long years since the New York City Ballet danced in London, and Martha Graham has not returned since her season here in 1954. Those of us who love the dance, therefore, are in the curious position of seeing more performances of ballet than is possible in any other capital city and yet remaining ignorant of the recent work of two of the world's great companies.
DETROIT, June 10 -- A four-man team of tractor and agricultural experts prepared today to go to Havana Monday on an unusual foreign mission to discuss exchanging tractors for prisoners.

THE unhealthiest thing that can happen to one's nostalgia is confrontation with the objects one is nostalgic for. I thought this was a fairly obvious truth; too bad that Eugene de Thassy chase to ignore it and thus spoil an otherwise interesting first novel.

MADISON, N.J., June 10 -A total of 1,032 graduates won degrees at Fairleigh Dickinson University's eight annual commencement this morning. The degrees were conferred in outdoor ceremonies by the university's president, Dr. Peter Sammartino.

FOR the first time in history a large-scale festival of modern music was held in a Balkan country. The Muzicki Biennale Zagreb, which took place in the capital city of Croatia between May 17 and 24, presented an ambitious program in which avant-garde music had a prominent place.

FOR THIS WEEK: Cut roses in the morning and condition them before making an arrangement. . . . Stake tomatoes if there is not enough room for them to sprawl. . . . Pinch chrysanthemums to encourage branching. . . . Pick strawberries. . . . Put a cheesecloth cover over blueberries to keep the birds away from the harvest. . . .
MONTREAL, June 10 (Canadian Press) -- The Besiktas Soccer Club of Turkey and Kilmarnock of Scotland fought to a 1-1 tie today in an International Soccer League game.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 10 -- Dr. Al Fields' Song Bird finished five seconds in front of Arthur and Carl Buhr's Fury and won Lighting Class honors today in an interclub regatta on Manhasset Bay.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 1 -- Half the 850,000 Congolese men who used to work for wages are unemployed.
PORT WASHINGTON NORTH, L.I. June 10 -- This North Shore village of 1,000 persons, without a government since May 15, elected a Mayor and two trustees last night. All are members of the Liberal party.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Things change fast for President Kennedy. Not so long ago he was supposed to be too young to sit down with Nikita Khrushchev, and now it turns out that he has been getting old-age medical assistance for his aching back.
OSLO, Norway, June 10 (AP) -- Arnstein Arneberg, Norwegian architect who decorated the chamber of the United Nations Security Council in New York, died here last night. He was 79 years old.

JOHN WILCOCK, who composes a weekly column of items for The Village Voice, a thriving journal in Greenwich Village, is a mild man in print, and maybe that's why he calls himself the Village Square. It is only when he regards such uptown phenomena as gossip columnists that he seems to grit his teeth.

WESTWOOD, N.J., June 10 -- Walter E. Seibert Sr., the founder of a group of mining companies here and in Canada, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Thursday night in St. Mary's Hospital, Hoboken. He was 59 years old.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Bill Veeck bowed out of baseball today and the ownership of the Chicago White Sox was narrowed to two men as Arthur C. Allyn bought out his majority-control partners, Veeck and Hank Greenberg, for an estimated $2,500,000.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 10 -- With two members of the class of 1886 at their head, 5,000 Princeton Alumni marched this afternoon in the annual "P-Rade," highlight of Princeton University's annual reunion week-end.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 10 -- Navy's undefeated heavyweight crew warmed up for next Saturday's Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta at Syracuse with a three-length victory over Wisconsin today.
MOSCOW, June 10 -- The Soviet Union has begun an intensive propaganda campaign to promote an international youth forum to be held here July 25 to Aug. 3.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- President Kennedy has named his brother-in-law, R. Sargent Shriver Jr., to substitute for him on a personal visit to the African country of Guinea.

Republican hopes of victory in this year's New York City municipal elections rest on two imponderables: the extent of public dissatisfaction with Mayor Wagner's Democratic administration and the consequences of the internal upheaval taking place in the Democratic party.

IDLEWILD International Airport will be the site on June 28 of first-day ceremonies for a new 13-cent red and black United States airmail stamp. The new stamp will be a revision of the current 10c green and black air-mail stamp featuring, in a panel at the left, the Liberty Bell with the words "Let Freedom Ring" below it.

LONDON, June 10 -- Amid traditional British royal pomp, Queen Elizabeth II took the salute today in the Trooping the Color ceremony, which was televised to the Soviet Union as well as through the British Isles.
DUBLIN, June 10 -- A significant development in the fight against cancer has been reported by a group of research workers at Dublin University.
A total of $419,600,000 in unemployment benefits was paid in April the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Employment Security reported yesterday.

Synthesis in a test tube of the basic chemical that directs the synthesis of proteins in all living things was described last week by Dr. Jerard Hurwitz of New York University Medical Center at the annual symposium on quantitative biology.

KATMANDU, Nepal, June 10 -- The number of projects in Nepal in which the Soviet Union or Chinese Communists were scheduled to participate may be reduced. The money saved would be used to meet the local costs of the remaining projects.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 10 -The Government sent additional reinforcements by sea and air to Recife today after striking students resisted troops in the streets.

WHEN the nation's key network, the 41,000-mile interestate system, marks its fifth anniversary on July 1, the gigantic job of providing adequate roads for a motorized America will be more than one quarter finished.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, May 31 -- A caravan of choralists, dancers, speakers and members of women's and youth leagues is winding its way through Nyasaland to spearhead a campaign for the first democratic elections in the British territory.

THE ideal vacation house should be a simple shelter requiring a minimum of upkeep -- a place where city-weary people can drop everyday worries and just relax. Too often it ends up long on practicality but short on looks.

THE American Bridge Teachers' Association, which is holding its fourth annual national convention in Chicago this week-end, now seems likely to accomplish something that has been attempted several times in the past and always unsuccessfully -- to survive as a wholly independent organization of professional teachers of contract bridge.

THIS is a long, wide-ranging, ambitious and, on the whole, successful attempt to encompass the realm of physical science for the lay reader. The author ebulliently and dramatically devotes the first half of the book to the macrocosm.

* * * The reviewer writes that the book is "marred by serious flaws," explaining that the "patients somehow never become persons; they remain 'cases.' Identified by fictitious first names they move * * * from page to page, carrying an assortment of human theories with them."
WATERTOWN, N.Y., June 10 -- More than 12,700 National Guardsmen and Reservists arrived at near-by Camp Drum from home stations in New Jersey and New York today to begin two weeks of field training.
In her "Never Underestimate 18-Year-Old Girls" (May 28), Shelagh Delaney makes some sweeping statements without benefit of sociological support or statistical references.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy said today that he would move promptly to make the Communist party register with the Government and list its officers and members.

At dawn a rivulet of Nigerians began moving through Lagos to the near-by ocean shore. By noon, the stream had become a great river of people in gay dress, fames together. By 4 o'clock, 100,000 had gathered.
DO Americans read or don't they?
LOS ANGELES, June 10 -Dr. Francis Marion Pottenger, Sr., a leading authority on tuberculosis, died today in the Cedars of Lebanon Hospital. He was 91 years old.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- David D. Henry, president of the University of Illinois, said this week steps would be taken to save the original building of Hull House as a memorial to Jane Addams on the campus of the Chicago branch of the University.

Every thoughtful citizen who is concerned with the question of constitutionality, and also convinced that Federal aid is the only way to provide adequate public education in this country, will commend your June 6 editorial on the "highly questionable tactics" of Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 10 -- Columbia, the successful defender of the America's cup in 1958, defeated Weatherly, which had sought the defender's berth, in a splendid match race on Long Island Sound today.
LOS ANGELES, June 10 -- Richard M. Nixon's "first hundred days" as a combination private and public citizen have projected an enigmatic picture of his political future.
LONDON, June 10 -- Mr. and Mrs. Wrightsman, whose Palm Beach home Mr. Kennedy is using, are old friends of the Kennedy family.

LONDON, June 4 -- A proposal to bring modern sanitation facilities into one of the most famous rustic villages of southern England has provoked protests from country-lovers, antiquarians and naturalists who say it will spoil the appearance of the place.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 10 -- The role of the Roman Catholic Church in Africa can best be fulfilled through the maintainance of the traditional family structure and the indoctrination of the people in basic human rights, Laurian Cardinal Rugambwa said here yesterday.
ACCRA, Ghana, June 11 -- Nigeria's Opposition leader called today for the formation of a "Pan-African organization" that would enable nationalists throughout Africa to take concerted action.

Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways each will be limited to two international championship harness races a year under special rules announced yesterday by the State Harness Racing Commission chairman, Robert A. Glasser. Each track will be permitted one pacing and one trotting championship event designated as international.
JACKSON, Miss., June 11 (AP) -- Six more Freedom Ridlets were arrested today, increasing the total here to 110.
BERLIN, June 11 -- The East German Communists acknowledged today that they had welcomed the convening of the West German Parliament in West Berlin as late as 1955.

NEW HAVEN, June 12 -- Howard A. (Hardy) Will Jr. of Kenilworth, Ill., a three-sport athlete, received Yale's highest athletic honer, the William Neely Mallory Award today. The presentation was made at the university's Class Day exercises.

SOME services offered by hotels are not always just for visitors. One of these is the hairdresser, who often finds more than half of his clients are not from within the hotel. Two salons that have made their mark in this manner are in the Waldorf-Astoria and Manger-Vanderbilt hotels.

At 8 A.M. yesterday morning Archie Moore, dressed in a yellow polka-dot bathrobe, put his bare feet on a coffee table in his hotel suite and discussed Aristotle's Golden Mean, courage, compassion, the benefits of walking on one's hands and the hard road that a boxer of more than two score years must travel.
Mounting indications that President Kennedy's foreign-aid program is running into trouble in Congress suggest that a new look is needed at the debate on this matter.
HURFFVILLE, N.J., June 11 -- There was a noisy atmosphere of serious horsemanship and county fair gaiety.

Investors Planning Corporation of America celebrated its eighth year of operations with record May sales of $16,687,000. This was 28.1 per cent higher than the year ago level and raised total sales for the first five months to $77,517,000, a gain of 12.8 per cent over the record high in the 1960 period.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Four United States agricultural experts are to fly to Havana Tuesday to discuss what type of tractors are to be offered in exchange for the prisoners captured by Cuba in the April 17 landings.
Four contracts totaling more than $1,450,000 were awarded last week by the Port of New York Authority in the bi-state agency's harbor development program.

Everton of England's First Division suffered its first International Soccer League defeat yesterday. Everton bowed to a greatly improved Bangu team of Brazil, 2 -- 0, in the feature match of a double-header at the Polo Grounds.

Traditionally, the freedom-loving Cuban people have scorned a "chivato," or informer. But today in Fidel Castro's cuba, to spy on one's neighbors and denounce them to the authorities is a "patriotic duty."

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Kapingamarangi is a coral atoll in the Caroline Islands. It and its 500 Polynesian inhabitants were made part of the United States Trust Territories system after World War II.
Six men were arrested yesterday in the fatal shooting of a 9-year-old boy Saturday night in a grudge fight in the Morrisania section of the Bronx.

A growing partnership of the American National Red Cross and the United Community Funds and Councils of America was pointed up yesterday in a joint statement of policy announced by leaders of the two organizations.

Peaceful use of atomic energy holds great promise for improving man's lot, but that promise could be ended and even reversed unless maximum safety is assured.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The troika is not exclusively Russian.
LE MANS, France, June 11 -- Phil Hill of Santa Monica, Calif., and Olivier Gendebien of Belgium, the 1958 victors, won the twenty-four-hour Le Mans sports-car race again today.
OMAHA, June 11 (AP) -- Western Michigan made ten hits count for twenty-two total bases and eliminated Texas, 8 -- 2, from the National Collegiate baseball play-offs.
Trading in the over-the-counter market last week continued at a snail's pace for the third week in a row. Prices moved in a narrow range and there was little buying interest in most issues.
HARTFORD, June 11 (UPI) -- The president of the World Bank said today that Asian, African and Latin-American reaction to the impact of Western civilization was certain to dominate foreign affairs.

STORRS, Conn., June 11 (AP) -- Dr. Luther Evans, former general director of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, said today that the Soviet Union had replaced the United States as the champion of newly emerging countries.
The first in a series of commencement-week celebrations at Fordham University began yesterday when the Very Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president of the university, celebrated the baccalaureate mass.

PITTSBURGH, June 11 -- Some leveling off has occurred in steel production but the trend to date does not indicate a serious drop in steel output this summer. Rather, it indicates more a hesitation than a step backward.

LONDON, June 11 -- The stock market appeared headed toward recovery early last week, but new concern over the pound sterling and more caution from buyers brought another slide backward by the close of trading on Friday.

Experimental techniques that are expected to lead to the isolation and analysis of a single gene -- the basic unit of inheritance -- were described at a weeklong scientific meeitng that will end at Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., today.

Temporary construction financing amounting to $65,000,000 has been obtained for the fifty-nine-story Pan Am Building at 200 Park Avenue, adjoining Grand Central Terminal. The financing was said to be the largest construction loan ever placed on a single commercial property here.
The nature of sin has not changed since the dawn of recorded history, a Lutheran minister said yesterday.

BONN, Germany, June 11 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk has told the North Atlantic Council that the United States cannot accept the Soviet Union's memorandum on Germany and Berlin as a basis for new negotiations on these issues.

Richardson-Merrell, Inc., has appointed a new executive vice president and a senior vice president for advertising, it was announced over the week-end by the drug and pharmaceutical producer formerly known as the Vick Chemical Company.
Action at the final four holes of the National Open Golf championship will be televised Saturday by the National Broadcasting Company. Coverage will begin here over Channel 4 at 5:30 P.M.
GENEVA, June 11 -- East and West agreed late tonight to resume fourteen-power conference on Laos and to issue a new appeal to the warting parties there to observe a ceasefire.

RANGOON, Burma, June 11 Comunist China's increasingly firm status in neutralist Burma is being viewed warily by the historically minded people of Rangoon. Nevertheless, there can be little doubt that Communist China is the chief foreign power in this capital.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 11 -- Global trade in wheat and wheat flour appears likely to soar in the 1961 season by about 4,500,000 tons above the 36,700,000 tons traded in the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) -- Senator Albert Gore, Tennessee Democrat, complained today, in a speech for delivery in the Senate that Federal tax laws encouraged artificial operations, "if not outright fraud," by United States enterprises abroad.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 11 -- The largest fleet of the season at a regatta of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound turned out today.
The Port of New York Authority is investigating the possible use of the Levacar, an experimental wheelless vehicle, to link a distant jetport with the heart of Manhattan.

BALTIMORE, June 11 (AP) -- Billy Pierce ended a Chicago White Sox four-game losing streak today, defeating the Baltimore Orioles, 7 -- 1, in the second game of a double-header. Baltimore won the opener, 8 -- 2, behind the three-hit pitching of Chuck Estrada.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 11 -- Ray Kautman's Furious II captured Snipe Class honors today as sixty-five boats, the largest fleet of the season, sailed in the interclub races sponsored by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

POZNAN, Poland, June 11 -- The thirtieth Poznan trade fair opened its doors today with fifty-six nations, including the United States, represented. Politics, not business, was the center of attention, however.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A special subcommittee of the House Judiciary subcommittee has begun a study of one of the oldest and most perplexing problems of American federalism-state taxation of interstate commerce.

Continued weakness in the British pound sterling was the main point of interest in the foreign exchange market last week. Canadian dollar showed a steady undertone in the fore part of the week then eased slightly in the closing sessions.

How members of the United Nations share skills and resources through technical assistance is the subject of "The World's War on Want," by Kathleen McLaughlin. The book will be issued June 26 by Oceana Publications in cloth-bound and paper-bound editions.

ST. JOHNS, Newfoundland, June 11 -- The Wabush Iron Company, with its sights set on full production by 1965, has received new blood. Newfoundland's Premier J.R. Smallwood last week announced additional participants in the ownership of the company, which is engaged in a large-scale iron ore mining development in Labrador.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 11 -- It was officially stated today that Maj. Gen. Jose Rene Roman Fernandez had confessed to complicity in the May 30 assassination of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina, the Dominican Republic's strong man.

EAST LANSING, Mich., June 11 (AP) -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur declared today that if global war were outlawed, "it would mark the greatest advance in civilization since the Sermon on the Mount."
HANOVER, N.H., June 11 -- Jean Monnet, a French architect of Western unity, called today for an extension of the partnership of Europe and United States.

ST. LOUIS, June 11 (AP) -- Jerry Lynch and Gene Freese delivered key hits in a three-run, eighth-inning rally today. They led the Cincinnati Reds to a 9-3 victory and a sweep of a double-header with the St. Louis Cardinals.

The Right Rev. Stephen F. Bayne Jr., executive officer of the world-wide Anglican Communion, reminded worshipers yesterday that the church belongs not to them but to God. He preached at Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Representative William E. Miller of upstate New York, new Republican National Chairman, said today President Kennedy had "rescinded and revoked" an Eisenhower Administration plan to protect with United States air power the anti-Castro exiles who invaded Cuba April 17.

The Philadelphia Yearly Meeting of Friends (Quakers) has challenged the conscience of the nation -- and President Kennedy's -- in its report on the Kinzua Dam. That project would put under water valuable lands of the Seneca Indians despite opposition by the Seneca Nation.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Prospects for Congressional approval of the Administration's school-aid bill have risen sharply with the emergence of Speaker Sam Rayburn as strong advocate and undisputed director of the strategy for winning favorable House action.

Wilson Co., Inc., reported yesterday that it had a net profit of $3,068,892, or $1.17 a common share, in the six months ended on April 29. PALM BEACH, Fla., June 11 -- Even though his back strain is officially described as improving. President Kennedy will appear in public tomorrow using crutches.
The Yankees, determined to keep the pressure on the American League's front-runners, said it with homers at the Stadium yesterday. They whacked two in the first game, three in the second.

THE impact of Mrs. John F. Kennedy on the global scene was the subject of television studies by the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System over the week-end. The half-hour documentaries -- N.B.C.'s last night and C.B.S.'s on Friday evening -- left scant doubt that the First Lady is on the way to becoming something of a controversial figure in her own right.

The Rev. Leonard Helie of the Universalist Church of New York, Central Park West and Seventy-sixth Street, told fifty congregants yesterday that the soul as well as the people had gone out of that church.
The chairman of the American Zionist Council said yesterday that the success of Jewish culture over the world could be achieved only through Zionist identification with the cultural life of Israel.

CEVELAND, June 11 (AP) -- Chuck Essegian was the star in both games for the league-leading Cleveland Indians, who swept a double-header today from Kansas City, 7 -- 3 and 4 -- 3. LONDON, June 11 -- The United States will soon be engaged in two secret negotiations with two different interlocutors and two wholly opposite objectives.
