Brooks-Palant, a new corporate financial counseling concern, has leased tower-floor space in the Corning Glass Building, 717 Fifth Avenue at Fifty-sixth Street. It arranges public offerings, mergers and other financing for industrial corporations in this country, Europe and South America.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 11 -- The Central Government of President Joseph Kasavubu is making strong efforts to get the Congolese Parliament to meet here before June 30, the first anniversary of the Congo's independence.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates hit three home runs in the third inning today en route to an 8-4 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

LOS ANGELES, June 11 (UPI) -- Sandy Koufax pitched his sixth straight complete game and posted his ninth triumph of the season today as the Los Angeles Dodgers scored a 6-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.
PARIS, June 11 -- The Gaullist Union for the New Republic showed the biggest gains today as voting ended for seats in the departmental General Councils in metropolitan France and overseas holdings.
ROME, June 11 -- A man who has directed the recovery of many millions of dollars of Italian art works taken by the Germans during World War II honored in Rome today.

Your Topics column of June 3 about the neglected child could not be more timely if written for the District of Columbia. Here we have what is called "Junior Village," an obligation of the Congress, which has actually accommodation for 240 children while we have a population of over 500.
The Commercial Solvents Corporation has announced an offer to purchase 200,000 shares of the common stock of the Chemical Process Company, San Francisco, at $15 a share.
Paul Keres of Estonia won the international chess masters tournament yesterday in Zurich, according to a report from Switzerland.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Administration is considering giving research subsidies to private industry to hasten the start of an operational system of communications satellites.

A jurisdictional dispute has disrupted the harmony between Actors Equity Association and the American Guild of Variety Artists. The guild charged that its members were being displaced in the Las Vegas, Nev., night clubs by such long-run Broadway musicals as "Tenderloin," "La Plume de ma Tante" and "Gypsy."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 11 -- The theatrical equivalent of defying the law of gravity has been undertaken by a California producer named John T. Pool Jr. He is taking a Hollywood show to Broadway.

ARCHIE MOORE was fighting from memory against Giulio Rinaldi at Madison Square Garden Saturday night. But as most elderly persons discover to their embarrassment and alarm, the older they get the more their memory will trick and betray them. Ancient Arch had many a grievous lapse during a dull, uninspired defense of his light-heavyweight championship.
The speaker referred to the problem as "the tiger on my back."
Young Rubicam, Inc., which has been fighting a vigorous, but losing, battle against the increase in television station break time, has not given up yet.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Even an old sea dog can get the shakes when missiles start flying the wrong way.
Domestic cotton futures prices moved higher last week. At the close of trading on Friday, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 14 to 29 points for the week.

NEW DELHI, India, June 11 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party has scored a resounding electoral victory in the Eastern State of Orissa to give the party majorities in all state legislatures for the first time in independent India's electoral history.
The chairman of the Liberal party warned yesterday that Democratic candidates should not take his party's endorsement for granted in this year's city elections.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 11 -- Ralph Petersen's Gangster, from Brookville, L.I., took the working hunter championship and retired the Meadow Brook Challenge Trophy today at the Sands Point horse show.

WHEN women switch from old-fashioned ranges and ovens to new equipment they often experience frustration, fear or overconfidence. The dials, timers and automatic sensing devices are misunderstood, or disregarded, according to one home economist.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 11 (AP) -- If the world would rid itself of secrecy, it would rid itself of the danger of catastrophe at the same time, John J. McCloy, United States disarmament director, said. today.

Further evidence that Premier Khrushchev is not only nibbling at the periphery of the free world but also driving toward a showdown at its center, with Berlin as a focal point, is provided by a memorandum he handed to President Kennedy in Vienna and now propagandizes to the world.

Following, in translation, are the texts of memoranda on Germany and disarmament handed to President Kennedy by Premier Khrushchev during their meeting in Vienna June 3 and 4, as made available here Tass, the official Soviet press agency:

SALT LAKE CITY, June 11 (AP) -- Two teen-age soldiers cracked under interrogation and said they had killed seven persons on a cross-country robbery spree, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.

Twenty-five Sanitation Department trucks and twenty-five city police cars will soon be equipped with "blowby" devices to reduce noxious gases from the automobile exhaust ,Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Justice Department has threatened the General Electric Company with divestment proceedings unless it signs a consent decree that the corporation's management considers foolhardy and impossible of fulfillment.
BOSTON, June 11 (UPI) -- Harmon Killebrew led the Minnesota Twins to a 10-5 victory over the Boston Red Sox in the second game of a double-header today. Boston won the opener, 8 -- 2.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 11 -- Princeton University has raised $40,367,079 toward its goal of $53,000,000 in capital funds, James F. Oates, chairman of the campaign, told the National Alumni Association here today.
CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- The July soybean future alone accounted for about 75 per cent of the activity last week on the Board of Trade as it went into its steepest slide of a long downward trend.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 11 -- Adlai E. Stevenson said today after all interview with President ganio Quadros that he was "comforted by the extent of agreement between our views."

Unemployment remains a bleeding wound in our economy, despite the encouraging pace of general industrial recovery. The latest Labor Department report shows that, even though seasonal pick-ups in farming and construction cut the number of idle workers by 200,000 in May, the jobless rate stayed close to 7 per cent for the sixth consecutive month. This is almost double the level President Kennedy has set as a reasonable yardstick of full employment.

Premier Amintore Fanfani of Italy is expected to recommend to President Kennedy at their two-day meeting in Washington starting today a reappraisal of President Gamal Abdel Nasser's regime in the United Arab Republic.
A plan to deepen a channel in Flushing Bay and rebuild a marina to accommodate excursion boats and 800 yachts at the edge of the World's Fair was disclosed yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 -- Sixteen thousand West Coast longshoremen will receive a wage increase tomorrow.
Controller Lawrence F. Gerosa represents the heart and core of a complex and delicate political dilemma facing Mayor Wagner and the Democratic party organization in New York City.

THE shop with a thousand delights was the phrase Efstathios Pappas used some time ago in a brochure to describe his store at 37 Seventh Avenue, between Twelfth and Thirteenth Streets. That description is more accurate than the real name, the Everfresh Nut Shop.

PARIS, June 11 -- Helen Hayes arrived here Friday at the end of a gruelling three-and-a-half-month tour of fifteen European and Middle Eastern countries with the Theatre Guild American Repertory Company, which is under State Department sponsorship.

Intensive efforts are due to be made this week by Federal and other mediators to ward off a general maritime strike threatened for Thursday night. Negotiations so far have brought virtually no progress.

Twenty years ago today a voluntary program of growing trees as a crop on private lands across America was started. In the two decades since, this American tree farm program has done much to change the face of the nation.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 11 -- As the threat of a nationwide miners' strike developed, the Bolivian Government announced today that it had lost telephone and telegraph contact with the mining town of Potosi.

BOLZANO, Italy, Monday, June 12 (AP) -- An hour-long series of violent dynamite explosions early today cut off electric power in half a dozen communities of the disputed Alto Adige, the former Austrian South Tyrol.

WHY have so many novelists written about painters? There are two reasons. The first is a bond of fellow feeling. Painters are fellow creative artists. Like novelists, more often than not they are poor, unappreciated by critics and the public, rebellious nonconformists in a society that considers them an unnecessary luxury.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 11 -- Mary Lena Faulk won the Triangle round-robin golf tournament today on the final hole.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 11 -- Robert Marshall Jr.'s Electra led the Luders-16 Class today in the second Yacht Racing Association championship regatta for Eastern Division fleets.
A priest of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday said confession "goes far beyond any mere wish to wipe away a past of sin."
WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) -- The United States realizes that its aid money is being wasted in Korea, but cannot afford to withhold it, the Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, said today.
FOUL RIFT, N.J., June 11 -- ''When you can ride 5,000. horsepower in a stretch of water like this, who wants to putt-putt around with a noisy, smelly fifty-horse outboard?"
NIAGARA FALLS, Ont., June 11 -- Three persons were killed tonight when their motorboat capsized in the tumultous water up the Niagara River from the Horseshoe Falls. A fourth was feared dead.
LONDON, June 9 -- The "buy now, pay later" habit is spreading in every country of Europe, but the men in the consumer finance business still feel somewhat on the defensive.

St. John's University yesterday awarded 1,717 degrees, the highest total in the university's ninety-one-year history. Eight thousand persons attended the exercises in a new university, building, Alumni Hall.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., June 11 -- The annual all-breed show and obedience trial of the Longshore-Southport Kennel Club drew 776 dogs and a traffic jam to the Cedar Ridge hunting preserve today.
A box-top offer of a thumb-size radio may not suggest taxes to the average person. But the Federal Government is usually more responsive in these matters.

Singers and dancers demonstrated the folk rhythms of seven cultures yesterday in Prospect Park, Brooklyn. The occasion was the third annual Nationality Day U.S.A., proclaimed by John F. Hayes, Acting Borough President.

In his letter published May 27 Dr. Luis F. Capriles makes some rather far-reaching statements regarding support for Fidel Castro among the people of Latin America and particularly in his native Venezuela.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 11 -- Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard University, told members of the graduating class today that "the times now cry loudly for unusual men."
A production-model phantom designed to help take guess-work out of radiation treatment has been developed by a New York concern with the help of specialists at three medica centers.
Governor Rockefeller was accused yesterday of having permitted the city's schools to deteriorate political gain.

In your issue of May 25 you published a letter written by Frances Goldin, chairman of the legislative committee of the Metropolitan Council on Housing. This letter is based on misinformation about the proposed East Island project. As planner and architect for this project, I would appreciate it if my corrections could be printed.

LOUIS MALLE, one of the youthful coterie of French directors loosely grouped as the "new wave" and known for the to torrid but often lagging "The Lovers," released here in 1959, now is represented by an expert, if occasionally obvious melodrama, "Frantic," which landed at the Little Carnegie Saturday.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 11 -- The twelve-meter yacht Columbia, captained by Cornelius (Glit) Shields Jr., today made it two straight over Weatherly, sailed by Arthur Knapp Jr., in their match-race series on Long Island Sound.
Washington, June 12 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

LONDON, June 12 (Reuters) -- A wave of buying in newspaper shares hit the London Stock Exchange today after the announcement last night that Lord Beaverbrook's Sunday Express had bought The Sunday Dispatch.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Supreme Court, in an important test case for the atomic energy program, upheld today the procedures of the Atomic Energy Commission for authorizing the construction and operation of nuclear power plants.

A picture of schools with leaking roofs, falling plaster, peeling paint, defective sanitary facilities, faulty wiring, broken doors and fire exits, broken windows, and vermin infestation was painted yesterday by city school principals.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Vice President Johnson called on responsible Americans today to raise their voices against "ill-considered assaults on the fundamental institutions of our free society."
WILMARTH SHELDON LEWIS' "Horace Walpole"* (1717-97) is a superb portrait of a man and his time in England and in the eyes of posterity.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 12 -- One of the most critical periods of picture making is the month immediately before the camera goes into action. In that month, the success or failure of a movie can be decided -- though this may not become apparent until after the shooting is well under way.
The New York Philharmonic will play in four Eastern cities just before its season opens in Carnegie Hall on Sept. 26.

Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker did something worse than merely make absurd statements attributing Communist activity to prominent Americans while he was commanding the Twenty-fourth Infantry Division in Germany. He violated the long and sound tradition that active military personnel should keep away from anything remotely looking like political commentary.
PARIS, June 12 -- The managing Director of the International Monetary Fund said today that all rumors about further currency valuation changes were "entirely baseless."

Sonny Fox will be the master of ceremonies for the American Broadcasting Company television network's first Saturday morning children's program, which will begin Sept. 23. It is entitled "On Your Mark."
GENEVA, June 12 -- The Soviet Union served notice today that the negotiating stage was finished at the conference on the projected treaty to ban nuclear tests.

JACKSON, Miss., June 12 (UPI) -- The Mississippi Supreme Court overturned today the contempt conviction of Medgar Evers, state field representative for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- For the second time in a few months, the Kennedy Administration has evaluated the policy which engages it in a popularity contest with the Soviet Union in Asia and Africa as paramount, and therefore required this Government to vote for two fundamentally defective motions in the United Nations.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 12 -- A Federal judge's refusal to prolong a temporary restraining order left the door open today for new Freedom Rides in Alabama.
Bal Musette didn't have it too easy in the mile-and-a-sixteenth race that highlighted yesterday's card at Belmont Park, but the King Ranch colt won it, all the same.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Government struck today at what it called a growing danger to health in the repackaging and sale of prescription drugs distributed to physicians as free samples.

BOOTHBAY Harbor, Me., June 11. -- Considering that there are lots more trout and landlocked salmon than people in Maine, the finny fellows have been doing a masterly job of making the state's fish and game statisticians appear like lying scoundrels.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- President Kennedy's Council of Economic Advisers joined battle publicly today with the one-time chairman of former President Dwight D. Eisenhower's council.
Net sales of the National Dairy Products Corporation for the quarter ended on April 1 rose to $440,968,586 from $418,511,759 for the 1960 period, the company reported yesterday.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 12 -- Adios Butler, who will start from the rail, is the 3-to-5 morning-line favorite to win the Summer Festival Pace at Roosevelt Raceway Friday night.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- The United States and Canada signed a $200,000,000 aircraft production agreement today.
TRENTON, June 12 -- The state began mailing commuter-tax forms today to 125,000 New Jersey employers.
CONTRARY to a thoughtless though widespread impression, the history of Russia did not begin with the Communist revolution of 1917.

GLADSTONE, N.J., June 12 -- Thirty-two young people 16 years or older engaged in a new kind of sports enterprise today. Some were accomplished horsemen. Some were less accomplished. And some would have accomplishments in the future, if at all.
The Bank of Huntington, Huntington, L.I., has been denied permission to open a branch at 1640 New York Avenue, Huntington Station, L.I.

CAIRO, Tuesday, June 13 (AP) -- A K.L.M. Royal Dutch Airlines prop-jet Electra crashed and burned on its approach to Cairo yesterday, killing nineteen of the thirty-six persons aboard and scattering more than $300,000 worth of dunes.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- Representative Edgar W. Hiestand, Republican of California and an avowed member of the John Birch Society, said today he was "very greatly disturbed over General Walker's treatment."

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 13 (AP) -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China and Premier Pham Van Dong of Communist North Vietnam have accused the United States of aggression and intervention in South Vietnam, Hsinhua, the official Chinese Communist press agency, reported today.
NEW DELHI, India, June 12 -- The leaders of India's 42,000,000 Moslems have appealed for a concerted effort to curb religious bias and promote national unity.

A new selection of former President Herbert Hoover's letters, addresses, reports and minutes of committee appearances is planned for July 21 publication by Caxton Printers of Caldwell, Idaho. In "Addresses Upon the American Road, 1955-1960" there are talks on American ideals, malnutrition and starvation abroad, an interview on "Meet the Press" and comments on the reorganization of the Federal Government.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 12 -- Mr. and Mrs. Allyn Phelps Evans of Englewood, and Christmas Cove, Me., gave a supper dance at their home here tonight to introduce their daughter, Miss Eleanor Frazier Evans.
BALTIMORE, June 12 (AP) -- Roy Sievers and Al Smith powered the Chicago White Sox to a 9-8 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight. The teams totaled twenty-five hits.

WASHINGTON June 12 (AP) -- The Prudential Insurance Company of America began laying out for he Securities and Exchange Commission today its plan to sell variable annuity contracts designed to protect purchases against inflation.
In a soggy market, stocks showed their widest loss yesterday since April 24. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was the smallest since Jan. 3.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 12 -- The Israeli tribunal trying Adolf Eichmann decided today against admission of a ghost-written "confession" that the prosecution had saved as a bombshell for the closing hour of its case.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Twelve Hollywood actors, actresses and writers lost a legal maneuver today to avoid being questioned about their political associations or beliefs, past or present.

IN "Red Eye of Love," which was presented last night at the Living Theatre, Arnold Weinstein is looking back, a few thousand years from now, at the United States today. Mr. Weinstein, who is aware of the comedy of life, has chosen to tell his history of the country in terms of an all-meat department store that grows from thirteen to fifty floors.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court reversed today a lower court decision that the Government said had placed the veterans' home-loan program in jeopardy.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 12 (AP) -- A legislative committee said today that a resurgent Communist party was seeking with some success to gain a foothold on California college campuses.
The ornamental and architectural masonry in the plazas of the Manhattan Bridge won a reprieve yesterday. There will be no decision on demolishing it before July 6.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Gen. Curtis E. Lemay as Air Force Chief of Staff, to succeed Gen. Thomas D. White, General White's retirement, effective June 30, was approved at the same time. General LeMay will take over July 1.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Congress gave swift approval today to a $12,571,000,000 authorization for the production of missiles, warships and planes.

OMAHA, Neb., June12 (UPI) -- Dave Giusti of Syracuse struck out fourteen batters and allowed only four hits tonight as he shut out Western Michigan, 6 -- 0, and eliminated the Brones from the National Collegiate baseball tournament.

NEWTON, Mass., June 12 (AP) -- The United States must meet threats of world conquest with more power, "especially American determination to use power intelligently and, if necessary, ruthlessly," a former Under Secretary or State said today.
CLEVELAND, June 12 (AP) -- Leo Posanda hit a pinch two-run homer in the tenth inning off Frank Funk as the Kansas City Athletics beat the league-leading Cleveland Indians, 7 -- 5, tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- A young nuclear physicist's conviction for contempt of the House Committee on Un-American Activities was reversed today by the Supreme Court.
Governor Rockefeller mixed politics with a question-and-answer "fact-finding" session yesterday before more than 200 Negro civic leaders in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

Steel production in the nation took a slight drop in the week ended last Saturday. Figures issued yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute showed output of 2,040,000 tons of raw steel, compared with 2,052,000 tons in the preceding week, in which Memorial Day occurred.

IF there was some mistiness in the eyes of Richard Charles Lee when he stepped up at the Yale Commencement yesterday to have the white hood of a Master of Arts draped around his shoulders, his friends would not have been surprised.

CALGARY, Alta., June 12 (Canadian Press) -- Pipeline hookups with fields in the British Columbia interior will bring substantial increases in oil and gas production for Pacific Petroleums, Ltd., before the end of the year John Getgood, president, said today.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 12 (AP) -- Billy O'Dell struck out ten Los Angeles Dodgers in relief today as the San Francisco Giants mustered twelve hits for a 7-4 victory.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 10 points up yesterday. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.) Commission house brokers bought 5,000 old October and 1,500 May.
A huge scale model of the city being built for the 1964-65 World's Fair may ultimately wind up in a new building in City Hall Park.

Your recent editorials refer to the present provisions on taxation of income earned abroad through foreign subsidiaries as "a deferral privilege," and indeed this is a term used in the President's message. You further interpret these provisions as in effect giving a "subsidy" to firms investing and operating in countries without the United States.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Premier Amintore Fanfani of Italy began two days of discussions today with President Kennedy and other United States officials.

PARIS, June 12 -- Any Italian will tell you that the 1961 Tour of Italy, which ended yesterday, was the most majestic ever -- unless the man happens to be a bike racer. Except for Arnaldo Pambianco, the surprised and delighted young man who won, the racers all hated the thing and will be muttering about it for weeks.
The Police Department took to the sidewalk yesterday in a drive to recruit 940 members and so end a shortage on the force that has existed for several years.
The silly season in politics arrived full-blown with the comment on the New York City school scandal by Edward N. Costikyan, Democratic leader of Manhattan's Eighth Assembly District South:
Price fluctuations in prime-risk bonds were mixed yesterday.

The New York State Association of Real Estate Boards, Inc., elected Richard E. Dunn, North Tonawanda real estate broker, president yesterday at its fifty-seventh annual convention at Kiamesha Lake, N.Y.
NEW HAVEN, June 12 -- A New Haven factory worker's son who became this city's youngest Mayor was among thirteen recipients of honorary degrees at Yale University's 160th commencement today.

SUMMER is the season to be athletic. There is no excuse for avoiding physical exercise except, of course, downright laziness. Nearly every sport requires some apparel investment. One of the joys of horseback riding is that the style changes in this sport occur so slowly.
BOSTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox defeated the Minnesota Twins, 10 -- 8, today. The game lasted 3 hours 33 minutes, 19 minutes under the major-league record.

First Mortgage Fund, Boston, a new closed-end investment trust, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 1,000,000 shares of beneficial interest for public offering at $15 a share through a group headed by Shearson, Hammill Co.

The real estate investment concern of Fechter, Schneider Spector has resold its contract to purchase the four- story store and loft building at 1175 Sixth Avenue, between Forty-fifth and Forty-sixth Streets.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- President Kennedy appeared on crutches today and used mechanical lifts to board and leave the plane that returned him from a week-end vacation at Palm Beach, Fla. The White House said he was continuing to show improvement from the back strain he suffered May 16.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- President Kennedy asked the nation's mayors today to get behind a "Boost the Economy Program" aimed at wiping out unemployment and speeding the industrial recovery already under way.
Division within the Protestant Episcopal Church constitutes a major threat to the advancing unity of American Protestantism, according to a leading New York theologian.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 12 -- Scott Marozan and Stanley Reader of Rockrimmon won the Westchester Country Golf Association pro-amateur tournament today after a matching of cards was used to break a six-way tie.
Folk singers seeking to reverse a court ruling banning their gatherings in Washington Square asked the courts yesterday to remove the issue from politics.

Premier Fidel Castro rules Cuba today by the magic of his voice and the power of the rifle. "If Fidel should lose his voice he would be overthrown in two months," one Cuban remarked bitterly after having listened to the Premier whip an audience of thousands to a fever pitch of loyalty to him and hatred of the United States.

Two of the key unions involved in a ten-union joint bargaining effort with the nation's major ship operators appeared split last night on the issues they wanted to put before the shipowning companies.

A determined effort to strengthen the southern half of Vietnam in its struggle against Communist aggression from the north is now being made by the Kennedy Administration. This is a crucial test of policy and action; if it fails the results can and probably will be disastrous to all that remains free in Southeast Asia.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 12 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Forest Hill Field Club and Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Apawamis tied for medalist honors today in the fifty-eighth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship.

There has been a noteworthy change in inventory policy in the nation, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. In its latest monthly review it points out that a "recent surge in production and manufacturers' new orders is not based primarily upon an increase in sales of products to final users."

PRINCETON, N.J., June 12 -- Darwin R. Labarthe, president of the class of '61 at Princeton University, was awarded the two highest honors his classmates can confer in Class Day ceremonies here this afternoon.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, June 12 -- Adlai E. Stevenson arrived today for a one-day visit to Paraguay and delivered a carefully worded message of greeting that dad not mention President Alfredo Stroessner by name.

As a final tune-up for their forthcoming transcontinental tour, the Yankees last night finished the business of mopping up the Los Angeles Angels. They won, 3 -- 1, for a sweep oil the three-game series at the Stadium.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that three employe-officers of a Texas company had acted in time to appeal an income-tax conviction.

MONTREAL, June 12 (Canadian Press) -- The National Hockey League rules committee redefined the penalty-shot, rule today. The change is expected to lead to a substantial increase in the number of penalty shots called.
ALBANY, June 12 -- Governor Rockefeller made a half-hour inspection tour of the burned-out Executive Mansion today and found it full of old timbers, fresh plaster and scurrying artisans.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- Robert C. Hill, who served as a United States Ambassador in Latin America, charged today that the State Department and The New York Times had contributed to the rise of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.
ATHENS, June 12 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy, visiting the Parthenon today, said she would like to see the Elgin Marbles returned to Greece.

BOSTON, June 12 -- A $2,250,000 renovation program inside the Boston Safe Deposit and Trust Company building tells what is happening to fiduciary banking here perhaps better than a dozen balance sheets.
JACKSON, Miss., June 12 (AP) -- Police here prepared today for fresh onslaughts by Freedom Riders.
Pan American World Airways accused K.L.M. Royal Dutch Airlines yesterday of having violated its foreign carrier permit and the United States-Netherlands air agreement.
LONDON, June 12 -- Prices of industrial shares proved sensitive to small selling in the stock market today and prices declined.

QUAINT stores with old-fashioned, pot-bellied stoves are not for all comers. The section of the public that fancies such places, however will be fascinated with The Country Emporium at West Redding, Conn.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 12 -- Members of the Turkish armed forces, particularly the Air Force, apparently have taken over control of the National Unity Committee that has been ruling Turkey' since the overthrow of the Menderes Government.

Premier Khrushchev's drive for a showdown with the West is giving new impetus to the movement toward a real Atlantic community whose military, economic and moral strength could be mobilized to meet the challenge.

A very strange extension of the "new frontier" is the effort of the Kennedy Administration to perpetuate, and even to increase, military aid to Latin America. The long course of history, and especially the events of recent years, have shown that such a policy strengthens the military, favors dictators, and forces the individual countries to spend far more on defense than they can afford.
Now that much of the clamor and publicity has died down, perhaps the community's objection to the folk singing in Washington Square Park can be told.
AN unwise false card cost declarer his contract in this deal, but it was a false card that perhaps most players would have made.
DETROIT, June 12 (AP) -- Auto production this month apparently will be almost a carbon copy of that in May, when 542,303 cars were built.

HAVANA, June 12 (AP) -- Armando Hart Davalo, Cuban Education Minister, said last night that specialists from the Soviet Union, East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Communist China would come to Cuba soon to raise the island's educational system to the standard of the communist countries.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg said today that the Administration's youth program was part of a concerted attack on the national problem of unskilled labor.

Max Stern, president of the Hartz Mountain Products Corporation, manufacturer of pet foods, yesterday gave $1,000,000 to Yeshiva University. The money will be used for the university's $25,000,000 Midtown Center development program.

Whatever event Herb Elliot runs, the combined Harvard and Yale track and field squad shapes up as too strong for Oxford and Cambridge in their meet at Harvard Stadium in Cambridge, Mass., this evening.

MIAMI, Tuesday, June 13 -- A committee of agricultural equipment experts en route to Havana to negotiate the release of rebel prisoners announced here early today that it would refrain from all public statements during its stay in Cuba.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Senate and House conferees agreed today on a program to encourage foreigners to visit the United States in the interest of international trade and better understanding.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 12 (AP) -- A salesman wrote his own obituary and then, apparently, killed himself today by running a garden hose from his automobile exhaust pipe through a ear window, John Stargel, a city detective said.
A forty-seat airliner flew from here to Washington yesterday with one passenger aboard.

All cottonseed oil futures tumbled to new lows for the move yesterday on the New York Produce Exchange. Trading was active and more than half of the volume was in the near July position. Final cottonseed oil prices were Off 17 to 43 points (hundredths of a cent a pound), on volume of 663 tank cars of 60,000 pounds each.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 12 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that the political crisis in the Congo appeared to be over. At the same time, he announced a $10,000,000 United Nations loan to that country.

Directors of Waltham Precision Instrument Company. Inc., yesterday declared a stock dividend of 300,000 shares of the 600,000 capital shares of Dextra Corporation stock it acquired last month. The dividend will be distributed Aug. 11 on the basis of one share of Dextra stock for each ten shares of Waltham Precision stock held on July 12.
THE one American dress designer who looks and acts like an Italian movie star is Sarmi. Anyone could be forgiven, on a chance meeting, for casting him in the role of the "mature" romantic lead.
Thirteen residents of the city are among forty-nine persons who have been awarded Opportunity Fellowships this year by the John Hay Whitney Foundation.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 12 (UPI) -- Deane W. Malott, the president of Cornell University, told members of the graduating class today that they had a choice of making their lives "as futile as sand or as strong as granite."
Litterbugs, in the vernacular of the Department of Sanitation, are subdivided into throw-outs, dump-outs or shake-outs.

EAST MEADOW, L.I., June 12 -- Two youths who spent almost nineteen hours clinging to their capsized boat off Long Island today recounted a night of horror in which their 17-year-old companion drowned.

TERRENCE O'FLAHERTY is headed for a formidable distinction: the first television critic to make a success of appearing in front of the cameras. The reviewer for The San Francisco Chronicle made his national debut last night as host and narrator on "PM West" and both he and his program seem destined for the winning column.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today decided that a second trial had not subjected a defendant to double jeopardy after an earlier trial had ended in a mistrial ordered by the judge on his own motion.
KATMANDU, Nepal, June 12 (Reuters) -- Physicians have advised Sir Edmund Hillary, conquerer of 29,028-foot Mount Everest, never again to climb above 16,000 feet.
The president of the Western Pacific Railroad said yesterday that he would rather see his road controlled by the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad than remain independent.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- Two business groups strongly criticized today President Kennedy's plan to speed decisions of the National Labor Relations Board.

Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday that he would not take any disciplinary action at this time against thirty-nine school construction employes accused of having taken gifts from contractors.

FORT DIX, N.J., June 12 -- A House subcommittee came to this Army post today to investigate housing conditions. The group left convinced that some of the housing could be improved but that Washington, rather than the military post, was responsible for the deficiency.
Trading in over the-counter issues yesterday was one of the smallest this year. Clerical staffs of most houses were able to catch up with some of their backlog of work.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- President Kennedy won another legislative victory today when the Senate passed his $6,140,000,000 housing bill with few changes.

CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) -- There still was no sign of slowing in the fast retreat of old-crop soybean futures today as the July delivery slumped the limit of 10 cents a bushel allowed for a single day on the Board of Trade.

Mrs. Douglas Williams, chairman for the Grosvenor Ball, will give a luncheon at the Plaza next Monday for the twelve young women who will be presented at the nineteenth annual debutante fete. The event will be held in the hotel on Nov. 25.

TOKYO, June 12 -- The members of the United Nations Commission for the Unification and Rehabilitation of Korea were reported today to have agreed that they should express to South Korea their hope that representative government and civil liberties will be restored.

THANKS to the enterprise of an American business man, Russian women will soon be saving their kopecks to use in washing machines. Romaine Fielding has just sold the Soviet Union $1.5 million dollars worth of laundry and dry-cleaning equipment including what he says are the first self-service, coin-operated machines to be available in Russia.
CHICAGO, June 12 -- About 1,000 American Indians representing more than 100 tribes will open a week-long meeting here tomorrow to formulate a Declaration of Indian Purposes.
COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., June 12 -- The cell machinery through which genes maintain normal growth in bacteria is believed to be fairly well understood, it was reported here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. June 12 -- Following, in translation from the French, are excerpts from an exchange of letters by President Joseph Kasavubu of the Congo and Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold, and from an agreement between the Congo and the United Nations:

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Two more busloads of Freedom Riders, one composed of rabbis and Protestant ministers, the other of professional people and union men, will leave here tomorrow to test bus segregation on the route to Florida.
San Francisco borrowed $11,275,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance airport school and other public improvements. The average borrowing cost was 2.9948 per cent.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 12 -- Danny Kaye tried out his own particular double-talk on the United Nations' corps of simultaneous interpreters. He left them speechless, but only for seconds.
A proposal for strengthening both the Mayor and the city's five Borough Presidents through forthcoming Charter revisions was made last night by Borough President Edward R. Dudley of Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Births in this country are estimated to have exceeded deaths in 1960 by 2,593,000, the Public Health Service reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- President Kennedy sent a message to Congress today asking a major overhaul of Government maritime functions.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz warned yesterday that some promoter-salesmen of prefabricated homes had developed an "unconscionable easy- credit" scheme that had driven some purchasers into an "unexpected nightmare of debt."
CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
C. Vasiukov and Vasily Smyslov, both of the Soviet Union, tied for first place yesterday with scores of 7 1/2 -- 3 1/2 in a chess masters tournament in Moscow.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 12 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that the United States could not wait much longer for an agreement on a ban on nuclear testing.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Judge Luther W. Youngdahl will hand down a decision Wednesday in the trial of Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority. Federal District Court aides said today.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 12 (UPI) -- The president of the State University of New York said here today that higher education should provide a proper atmosphere for the development of creative and imaginative students.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 -- Public Property Commissioner William T. Gennetti, whose department has figured prominently in the City Hall payola scandal, resigned suddenly yesterday from his $20,000-a-year job, it was announced today.

TURNBERRY, Scotland, June 12 (UPI) -- One of the weakest American delegations in recent years fared better than expected today with eleven winners and nine losers in the first round of the British Amateur golf championship.

Abraham Cohen, controller of the First National Realty and Construction Corporation, has been appointed assistant-treasurer controller of the real estate concern. Romolo G. Oliva, lawyer, has been named assistant secretary.

A split apparently has developed between Feature Sports, Inc. and Championship Sports, Inc., which, despite seemingly combative titles, have been sparring without animosity in the commerce of the squared circle.
GENEVA, June 12 -- Communist China rejected today the Western powers' proposals for safeguarding the political integrity and neutrality of Laos.
Mayor Wagner has agreed to meet Thursday with a Liberal party committee trying to find out if he intends to run for re-election.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 12 -- Connecticut today filed a formal declaration that it had approved a law authorizing the state Tax Department to furnish New York State with employment and salary information on New York residents who work in this state.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Sam Rayburn doubled the previous record for service as Speaker of the House today. His fellow Representatives kept praise, applause and sentiment flowing for nearly two hours.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Army announced today the "admonishment" of Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker for publicly accusing prominent citizens, the American press and television and certain commentators of links with communism.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall urged the Senate today to authorize a special national fuels and energy study so the country may never face an "energy gap."

ALTHOUGH parents and teachers often must make split-second decisions on how to preserve order in their respective domains, they impart basic feelings about discipline during every moment spent with the children.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., June 12 -- Mary Pickford, the film star was among five persons honored here today at commencement exercises of Middlebury College.
ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J., June 12 -- Two boys were injured, one seriously, when they slid down a 100-foot slope of the Palisades here this afternoon.
Therman Gibson of Detroit, who won $78,250 for a couple of nights of strikes and spares on the television show "Jackpot Bowling," is going to part with some of the cash real soon.
Smoke abatement laws date from thirteenth century England and were very effective in those earlier periods, an air pollution control officer declared yesterday.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 12 -- Colonial decorations with pale pink the predominating color was the setting of the Morristown Debutante Assembly held here this evening at Macculloch Hall.

As all Americans lose every day that racial discrimination is allowed to live on in our country, it strikes this early member of the Southern Regional Council that all Americans indeed do have the right to demonstrate against such discrimination wherever it is asserted.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Treasury bill rates broke sharply on today's sales of the regular weekly issues, wiping out two-thirds of the substantial increases made in the pre ceding four sales. Today's sale of ninety-one-day bills was made at discounts averaging 2.295 per cent, compared, with 2.516 per cent last Monday.

CINCINNATI, June 12 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower acknowledged today that during his Presidency he had ordered measures to help organize, train and equip Cuban refugees so they could act at the proper time.
New York City Republicans got another jump on the entrenched Democratic opposition last night as they picked Borough President candidates in Queens, the Bronx and Richmond.
Students, faculty members and alumni of City College said good-by with respect and gratitude last night to the man they affectionately referred to as "Cool Buell."

SEOUL, Korea, June 12 -South Korea's military junta appointed Song Yo Chan, a retired lieutenant general, as Defense Minister today. Mr. Song, a former army Chief of Staff, has been studying at George Washington University in Washington during the last year at the invitation of the United States Defense Department.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Supreme Court looked back twenty-five years today to censure the conviction of a youth who was sentenced to 199 years in a Chicago killing. However the tribunal said that the state should still have a chance to retry him.
A Puerto Rican grocer asked a special three-man Federal Court yesterday to outlaw a state requirement that voting applicants pass an English literacy test.

LONDON, June 12 -- A group of prominent Laborites introduced a motion in the House of Commons tonight opposing Britain's entry into the Common Market and urging the Government to support the call of Prime Minister John Diefenbaker of Canada for a meeting of Commonwealth leaders to discuss the question.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Administration was coming under increasing pressure from Congressional Democrats today either to break off the nuclear talks in Geneva or to resume atomic tests.
ROCHESTER, June 12 -- William N. Posner resigned tonight as Monroe County Democratic chairman with a subtle hint that the party might benefit if some other Democratic leaders followed suit.

Flag Day, which occurs tomorrow, was first observed when the American flag was one hundred years old in 1877, but the events of the Civil War gave the flag an urgent importance in American life and emotions years earlier.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 12 (AP) -- Big Bird, who returned $47.60 for $2, and Science Major ($66.20) won the first and second races, respectively, at Monmouth Park today and formed a $1,264.20 daily double.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 12 -- Maj. Gen. Jose Rene Roman Fernandez will be tried by court-martial for treason for his part in the May 30 assassination of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina, the Dominican Republic's strong man, the General Staff announced tonight.

Production of men's suits, pants, overcoats anti sport coats during the first four months of this year declined from the levels of the 1960 period, according to the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A.
LONDON, June 12 -- An American curate at Llandilo, Wales, said today he had been advised to return with his family to the United States because of "differences of ideas" with his vicar.
BONN, Germany, June 12 -- The Federal Government reiterated today its rejection of the Soviet memorandum on Germany and Berlin.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 12 -- The effect of the attempts of the Bolivian Government to assert authority over the powerful Communist and Leftist-dominated labor unions remained uncertain today.
EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, June 12 -- The French-Algerian peace talks will go into their fourth and probably most crucial week here tomorrow with both sides in a markedly gloomy frame of mind.
MOSCOW, June 12 (AP) -- The new president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, Mstislav Keldysh, said today full electrification was the main goal of Soviet science.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The United States, seeking new concepts of economic aid to Latin-American nations, is negotiating with Western European countries to increase their purchases of products from the Western Hemisphere.
Nineteen union officials, who said they would have appeared voluntarily anyway, answered subpoenas yesterday from the House Committee on Education and Labor only to find no hearing and no questions.

' The Naked Edge," the last film completed by the late Gary Cooper, will be the next attraction at the Victoria Theatre following the current "The Last Time I Saw Archie." Deborah Kerr, Eric Portman, Diane Cilento and Hermione Gingold also appear in the United Artists suspense drama, which was directed by Michael Anderson and produced by George Glass and Walter Seltzer.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 12 -- Association of Greece with the Common Market received final approval here today. Cabinet ministers representing the six nations of the European Economic Community voted unanimously for the accord with Greece.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Navy today backed an admiral's claim that the super-carrier Kitty Hawk was poorly built. A union had earlier denied the charge and demanded proof or an apology.

PARIS, June 12 -- The British are going through an acute debate over whether Britain, after centuries of proud independence, should cast her lot with the continent of Europe. The immediate question is whether to join the six-nation European Economic Community of France, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 12 -- Lenny Peters and Jack Wallace of the Huntington Crescent Club clipped ten strokes from par and posted a 30, 32 -- 62 today in winning the Long Island Professional Golf Association pro-amateur tournament at the Hempstead Golf Club.
BIRMINGHAM, England, June 12 (Reuters) -- Rain limited play to 2 hours and 20 minutes from tightening its grip on the first test cricket match with England.

Precision Radio Instruments, Inc., has expanded its phonograph record business through the acquisition of the Allied Manufacturing Company and its affiliates for an undisclosed amount of stock and cash.
The Government plans to save $1,695,000 by omitting fallout shelters from the $78,000,000 Federal center it will start building here early next year.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 12 -- President Mario Echandi Jimenez formally opened today the first Conference of the Americas on World Peace Through Law, attended by forty-five delegates from twenty-three hemisphere countries.

Six cousins of the late Albert H. Liebenau, former Bronx Democratic leader who left $4,000,000 when he died March 1, withdrew their objections to his will yesterday and agreed on a settlement granting them a total of $340,000.
The city said yesterday it planned to direct Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., to establish five new transfer points in Manhattan.
An important realignment of top management was announced yesterday by Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc.

A public offering of $18,000,000 of United States Government-insured merchant marine bonds of American Export Lines, Inc., is being made through an investment banking group headed jointly by the First Boston Corporation and Childs Securities Corporation.

When the dramatists voted recently to help the Broadway theatre out of its chronic financial plight by offering to take a cut in royalties, they did so on the contingency that directors, stars, producers and other groups make similar sacrifices.

The directors of S.H. Kress Co., variety store chain, have elected Louis P. Johnson as president and James P. Mercer as vice president in charge of store operations, it was announced yesterday by Paul L. Troast, chairman.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Supreme Court unanimously set aside today a New York State decision that had ended the Communist party's participation in the state's unemployment compensation system.

The Monday before Memorial Day was unusual in Wall Street. It was a holiday for stock trading but the back offices of brokerage houses stayed open to whittle at the backlog of clerical work arising from recent heavy stock trading.
A practice known as lease-timing is gaining in popularity with companies seeking office accommodations in Manhattan, according to Hal K Negbaur, a leasing specialist.
ROME, June 12 -- Pope John XXIII opened the first meeting today of the Pontifical central committee that is to prepare for an ecumenical council of the Roman Catholic Church.
Commodities on the New York exchanges moved in narrow price ranges yesterday and closed irregular.

ONE of America's most famous custom milliners has turned to the mail-order catalogue. A group of hats and dresses designed by John Frederics will appear in the fall edition of the Montgomery Ward catalogue, 45,000,000 copies of which will reach its subscribers shortly after the Fourth of July.

I must take exception to your editorial of June 7 concerning the recent Supreme Court decisions on the Smith and Internal Security Acts, in which you stated "It is important to remember, as Justice Douglas pointed out * * * that only speech is involved in Smith Act prosecutions."
MONTCLAIR, N.J., ,June 13 -- Two upsets marked the first round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fifty-eighth annual championship today.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- A Foreign Service officer was arrested on espionage charges today a few blocks from the State Department.

We speak for fifteen members of the Yale Law School faculty. We share your concern, expressed in an editorial on June 3, at the news report that Louisiana's Senator Long is seeking to block the proposed promotion of Federal District Judge J. Skelly Wright of New Orleans to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
FRANKLIN LAKES, N.J., June 13 -- An incomplete census of bald eagles in New Jersey has indicated that the huge birds continue to have an uphill fight for survival.

PERHAPS a player in the rough-and-tumble bridge games that prevail in most circles, where bids and doubles are alike speculative, would be aghast at West's apparent attitude toward his hand in this deal.
