Major hospitals in the area affected by the power failure continued to function last night, using auxiliary generators or Police Department emergency services.

The Western Union Telegraph Company announced plans yesterday for issuing to its stockholders rights for an offering of about 1,070,000 shares. The offering would be on the basis of one new share for each six held.

If Mr. Justice Frankfurter and his colleagues read the Congressional Record (June 7, 1961, pp. 8899-8901), they will discover that their decisions involving the Communist party have unleashed the strident heresy-hunters of the Right to renew their assault on civil liberties.
The demise of the old Stillman's Gymnasium on Eighth Avenue is finally at hand after two years of indefinite plans by realty developers.

ALABASA, "one of the most pestilential tracks of country on the whole African coast," was the most isolated and the most primitive region in the colony. The British officials in the capital know little about it. Most of the Africans were still afraid of the Alabasians as their ancestors had been before them.

MOST parents are driven to distraction after a few hours in a car with their offspring, but Mr. Chris Abajian was driven to his drawing board after a two-month, eight-thousand-mile trip across the country with his family.

THIS week a tall, mild-mannered Swedish economist and classical scholar moved his family from a modest apartment in downtown Leopoldville to a luxurious villa called the "Royal Residence." He was Dr. Sture Linner, recently named to head United Nations operations in the Congo.

Noses played a prominent part in the proceedings at Belmont Park yesterday. John M. Schiff's Muguet II got his in front of Tuscarora and won the forty-fifth running of the Meadow Brook steeplechase handicap.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 13 -- Adlai E. Stevenson said today in Paraguay that "the prevailing climate of political tension" there impedes United States economic cooperation with the Government of President Alfredo Stroessner.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Post Office abandoned its move today to bar Henry Miller's "Tropic of Cancer" from the mails as obscene.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The United States and the Soviet Union will open talks Monday on arrangements for a general disarmament conference this summer.
A major power failure on the hottest day in two years threw five square miles of mid-Manhattan into confusion for four and a half hours yesterday.
TURNBERRY, Scotland, June 13 (AP) -- An American airman, Ralph Morrow, and big Jimmy McHale today led nine Americans into the third round of the British Amateur golf championship.

The State Investigation Commission announced yesterday that it had obtained further evidence of alleged pay-offs to the police by Greenwich Village coffeehouse operators. The facts have been turned over to Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- President Kennedy is taking an extremely cautious line about renewing underground nuclear tests. The Russians have been making a mockery of the test-ban talks in Geneva, and the powerful Joint Atomic Energy Committee in Congress has been pressing the President to renew the testing.
BOSTON, June 13 -- A former president of the American Dental Association expressed disapproval today of advertising for Crest toothpaste. He termed it "unethical, misleading and unfair."
A photograph of the shoplifter who shot two Bloomingdale department store detectives Saturday was taken by a man who was visiting the city at the time.
CLEVELAND, June 13 -- The Yankees, eager to find out whether Jimmie Dykes' Indians were serious about this business of leading the American League, cracked head-on into the answer tonight.

NO self-respecting author of whodunit make mysteries would ever dare make use of a plot with the butler as the guilty party. But a lot of suspense has been drained from harness racing the past two seasons by a character known as The Butler. His full name is Adios Butler and he kills off other pacers with such monotonous regularity that he's the prime suspect from first chapter to last.
LONDON, June 13 -- The immediate superior of a Briton later convicted as a spy was told seven years ago that he was taking secret official papers, it was reported today.

LONDON, June 13 -- Prime Minister Macmillan announced today he was sending some of his senior ministers to other Commonwealth countries for discussions on whether, and on what conditions, Britain should join the European Economic Community, known as the Common Market.

MAKE all the allowances that hard luck and charity require. Grant that "The Billy Barnes People" stormed New York under the most difficult conditions. The fact remains that the revue, which arrived last night at the Royale Theatre, is a cheap, raucous affair.
JERSEY CITY, June 13 -- Hudson County Supervisor Thomas F. Gangemi won a run-off election for Mayor of Jersey City today.

EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, June 13 -- France broke off the three-week-old Algerian peace talks here today for an indefinite "period of reflection" despite Algerian nationalist protests against the adjournment.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 13 -- "Well, the crisis is over; now we can table the crisis."

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company recorded declines of 6.2 per cent in sales and 7.4 per cent in earnings for the six months ended on April 30, but predicted a marked upturn in business in the months ahead.
HONG KONG, June 13 -- President Sukarno of Indonesia was accorded the type of reception Communist China reserves for special guests when he arrived in Peiping today from Moscow.

BONN, Germany, June 13 -- The United States answer to the latest Soviet memorandum on Germany and Berlin will open the way for new East-West negotiations without actually proposing a conference, informed sources here predicted today.
In some parts of the Lower East Side yesterday it was possible to pay more for a glass of milk at a lunch counter than for a whole quart at a delicatessen.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- President Kennedy named deLesseps S. Morrison today Ambassador to the Organization of American States.
OTTAWA, June 13 -- Donald Fleming, the Minister of Finance, has demanded the immediate resignation of James E. Coyne, governor of the Bank of Canada.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
Prices of United States Government obligations and other prime debt securities backed away yesterday from price levels attained in recent rallies. Market activity slackened.
I should like to make a small point concerning Edmund Delaney's comparison of European and American railroads, published June 4.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- President Kennedy and Premier Amintore Fanfanti of Italy agreed today on the need for strengthening the Atlantic Community both as an instrument of defense and in its political and economic aspects.

A new book by James Baldwin, called "Nobody Knows My Name: More Notes of a Native Son," will be issued June 26 by Dial. The author says it is a part of a private logbook." It records the last months of his self-exile in Europe, his return to America and to Harlem and his first trip South when the school integration battle was beginning.

In recent months Russia has seemed to be calling the shots on Laos for the Communist bloc, but the Geneva conference is providing evidence that on this issue Communist China may now be the dominant operator among the bloc nations.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Administration stepped up its bid for public support of the $4,800,000,000 foreign aid program today and set the stage for a major appeal Friday by President Kennedy.
A band of mothers, indignant because a Washington Square Park area reserved for small children is being invaded by adults, told their troubles volubly yesterday to their Assemblyman.
Pool-players scratched in the dark; men left barbershops in a half-shaved state and otherwise fashionable women swept through Park Avenue with their hair in curlers and pink nets over their ears.

GENEVA, June 13 -- The Soviet Union challenged the States today to translate into "specific agreements" the statement calling for a neutral and independent Laos that President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev agreed on at their meeting in Vienna.

HAVANA, June 13 -- A group of United States experts on farm machinery conferred for more than two hours today with President Osvaldo Dorticos Torrado on exchanging captive rebels for 500 American tractors.

THE fifth annual sailboat regatta and design competition will be held on Saturday lat 2 P.M. at the Conservatory Lake in Central Park. Regatta events range from class A boats which are twelve to eighteen inches long, to those for boats up to fifty inches long.
MONTREAL, June 13 -- The New York Rangers acquired two players in deals with the Montreal Canadiens and the Detroit Red Wings today. The trades took place at the National Hockey League meeting.

RALEIGH, N.C., June 13 (AP) -- New groups of thirty-two white and Negro Freedom Riders traveling south from Washington by regularly scheduled bus to test racial segregation arrived today in Raleigh and Wilmington, N.C. without incident.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The House Science and Astronautics Committee said today that it would ask officials of the National Science Foundation why a $3.800 fellowship was granted to a student convicted of contempt of Congress.

Stocks dragged yesterday in tired fashion through another uninspiring day. For the first time since Dec. 6, there were more new lows for the year than new highs. Volume sank again to the lowest since Jan. 3. Aggregate market value declined somewhat more than one-half of 1 per cent.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- President Kennedy asked Congress today to modernize the nation's unemployment compensation system by increasing coverage, benefits and payroll taxes.
A new sign of price weakness in the steel industry appeared yesterday.
The midtown Manhattan portion of the IND subway system was knocked completely out of operation late yesterday afternoon by the power failure.

It took the United States Government seven years to decide to join one of the most important international programs to protect oceanic natural resources: the International Convention for Prevention of Pollution of the Sea by Oil.

LONDON, June 13 -- Africa's direct influence on European politics is an odd contemporary fact. An army coming from African Morocco overthrew the Spanish Republic in the Thirties. An army stationed in African Algeria overthrew the Fourth French Republic three years ago and tried again to upset it this spring.

Flashlights and candles replaced electric light in the news department of The New York Times yesterday as the first edition of today's paper was prepared for publication during the midtown power blackout.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- In The New York Times of Sunday, June 11, an article about lobbying activities for and against the foreign-aid program listed the American Farm Bureau Federation as a frequent user of anti-foreign-aid material supplied by the Citizens Foreign Aid Committee.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13 -- With Jim Stack winning the 880-yard run from Herb Elliott, the world record-holder in the mile, the combined Yale-Harvard track team handily defeated Oxford-Cambridge in their nineteenth international match today.

STOCKTON, Calif., June 13 (UPI) -- A truck-trailer caught fire and its load of twenty tons of Army small ammunition, artillery shells and rockets exploded early today. The explosion was heard four miles away.
The Transit Authority awarded a contract for the purchase of cable to a Canadian concern yesterday in an effort to smash a persistent pattern of identical bids by United States manufacturers.

While sharply rebuking the prosecutor, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn ordered a new trial yesterday for J. Milford Kirkup Jr., former Suffolk County Welfare Commissioner, who had been convicted of heading an illegal drug-buying combine.
It has been a long time since anyone could see hope in the Congo; but what Secretary General Hammarskjold called "the grievous stage" may now -- thanks largely to the U.N. -- be nearing its end.
The City Council's opposition to Mayor Wagner's Charter revision plans evaporated yesterday as the Council killed its own revision measure.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 13 -- "Cum Harvardiani diplomaticians suis linguam Anglicam nuperrime adhibuerint (hic deplorate), attamen vos, custodes traditionis Princetoniensis, in his documentis lingua Latina etiam nunc uti gaudemuz (hic vehementissime plaudite)."
RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 13 -- A pigeon's eye view of Riverhead High School's year of activity, filmed in color, is receiving its finishing touches this week.
A completely automatic cafeteria with no kitchen was opened yesterday by the General Electric Company in its world headquarters at 570 Lexington Avenue.
President Kennedy's back condition, which has been widely publicized as a result of his use of crutches publicly, has been described by his physician, Dr. Janet G. Travell, as a lumbo-sacral strain.

Two young mothers-to-be kept up the spirits of thirteen fellow passengers in a stalled elevator for two hours and forty minutes last evening. But the ordeal was too much for two of the men in the group -- they fainted.

A number of distinguished religious and civic leaders have asked the New York City Board of Education to remember "mercy as well as justice." The reference is to the case of the five teachers who, after more than five years, continue to be suspended without pay, ostensibly for false statements made in their applications many years ago but actually because they refused to turn informers against other teachers.
WHITE PLAINS, June 13 -- The Westchester Planning Board today advocated immediate acquisition by the county of the old North Yonkers Arboretum of the Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research.

The failure of a circuit breaker -- and not an overload caused by the record heat -- was blamed by Consolidated Edison for yesterday's blackout of parts of the midtown area. The circuit breaker was in the utility's substation at West Sixty-fifth Street and West End Avenue.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- President Kennedy is receiving a treatment called "ultra sound," or supersonic radiation, to relax the muscles and ease the discomfort in his lower back.
The last great power failure here occurred on Aug. 17, 1959.
The Virginia Electric Power Company borrowed $30,000,000 in the public capital market yesterday at an interest cost of 4.855 per cent.
Only three of the twenty-three theatres now operating in the Broadway area canceled their performances last night after the power failure.

Legal complications arising from the Board of Education's blacklisting of twenty-six contractors have forced the school administration to suspend all awards of new contracts for school construction and modernization.

Massey-Ferguson, Ltd., manufacturer of tractors and combines, increased its world-wide net sales in the six months ended on April 30 by 3 per cent. The volume rose to $228,558,000 from $220,967,000 in the year-earlier period, according to a report issued yesterday.
CHARLESTON, S.C., June 14 (AP) -- Freedom riders received a cool but orderly reception in South Carolina today.

Trading in the over-the-counter market began very quietly yesterday with prices of most issues off slightly. Later, following the stronger tone on the Big Board, interest in the off-board securities rose and many stocks closed with moderate increases.

Imp, a Yorkshire terrier who weighed only two ounces at birth, was as chipper as a chipmunk at the home of Mrs. Adele Eisnitz in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., yesterday. The puppy had grown to 1 pound 10 ounces in the six months since she was whelped during a December snowstorm.

BALTIMORE, June 14 (AP) -- Dick Donovan pitched a six-hit, 5-1 victory tonight as the Washington Senators beat the Baltimore Orioles for the first time in seven games. Gene Green and Gene Woodling drove in two runs apiece.
CLEVELAND, June 14 -- Even when Whitey Ford doesn't have one of his better days, or nights he still exerts an inspiring influence on the Yankees.

LONDON, June 14 -- The British Government has presented to Parliament a proposed Constitution for Southern Rhodesia giving Africans more political rights, but it was denounced today by an African nationalist.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 14 -- The subcommittee of the Organization of American States investigating political conditions in the Dominican Republic completed its interviews here today. The committee members are due to leave for Washington tomorrow to report.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Stockholders of California Eastern Aviation, Inc. today voted to change their company's name to Dynalectron Corporation.
LONDON, June 14 -- A small portrait by Goya of the first Duke of Wellington was sold at auction today for 140,000 ($392,000.)
Mayor Wagner called yesterday for a state investigation of the Consolidated Edison power network here as a result of Tuesday's massive blackout in mid-Manhattan.
A possible new complication in the proposed purchase and rehabilitation of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad by the Port of New York Authority became known yesterday.

Sun Glint of the Calumet Farm sped through a shower and won the $24,650 Vagrancy Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The race, at seven furlongs, was for older fillies and mares and attracted a field of fourteen.

CHICAGO, June 15 (UPI) -- Ray Herbert pitched a three-hitter tonight and led the Chicago White Sox to a 4-1 victory over the Los Angeles Angels in the first game of a twilight-night double-header. In the second game, Don Larsen halted a ninth-inning threat and saved a 9-8 triumph for the White Sox.
LIKE the eye of a hurricane Joseph Charles Swidler remained calm during the six months he was the center of a political storm over his nomination as a member of the Federal Power Commission.

The Hickory House, which has been serving jazz with its steaks since 1933, is enjoying a pleasant paradox. The Don Shirley Trio, which is now stationed inside the oval bar where a long succession of jazz pianists have played, is attracting more business than the fifty-second Street restaurant has seen in its twenty-eight year history.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 14 -- Not one of the 108 mutuel machines clicked and nary a tout was in sight, but Monticello Raceway was the proverbial beehive of activity today.

The debutante committee for the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball will be honored at a luncheon, to be given today by Mrs. Eugene W. Ong and Mrs. Sherman Pratt, cochairmen for the ball, in the Pillement Suite at the Waldorf-Astoria.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 14 -- Henry Cabot Lodge said here today that the United States could not begin to meet Communist competition on equal terms unless it developed a long-range goal.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The 391,000 residents of Indiana's Fifth Congressional District were officially represented in the House today for the first time since Jan. 3.

A giant step toward full automatic operation of machine tools was announced yesterday by the International Business Machines Corporation. The company said that it had developed the first computer system that automatically generated tool paths required to mill complex three-dimensional surfaces.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 14 (UPI) -- Louisville's Board of Aldermen stood firmly today on its position of more than a year ago that businesses were entitled to choose their own customers.

The Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn awarded 616 graduate and undergraduate degrees last night at its 106th commencement. The exercises were held in the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Ashland Place and Lafayette Avenue.

RYE, N.Y., June 14 -- -Thomas Edlefson of Mercersburg upset Ham Magill of Choate, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3 today and gained the semi-finals in the Manursing Island Club Eastern interscholastic tennis tournament.
Baseball bird dogs converged on Baker Field yesterday and confirmed what many had suspected: Dan McDermott of Staten Island is a potential bonus baby.

BIRMINGHAM, Mich., June 14 -- It now comes full cycle for Samuel Jackson Snead, the millionaire hillbilly. Here is where his frustration began twenty-four years ago. Over the same menacing Oakland Hills terrain where another United States Open will begin on the morrow, the sweet-swinging backwoodsman made his first bid for golf's most cherished prize.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 14 (AP) -- Capital Cities Broadcasting Company will finance its purchase of three radio and television stations with little dilution of equity, its president Frank M. Smith, has declared.
Domestic producers of acetate yarn and rayon shipped 87,100,000 pounds of fiber last month, a gain of 13 per cent over the 77,300,000 shipped in April and 4 per cent above May, 1960, deliveries.

GUSTAVE TASSELL, who was born in Philadelphia, discovered himself in Paris and currently lives and works in Los Angeles, is in New York this week enabling store buyers to climb on his bandwagon. Suddenly his is the name on fashion industry lips, and one of the fruits of success, according to this 35-year-old designer, is that now he can tell people how to pronounce it.
Traffic fatalities declined 60 per cent and personal injuries 26 per cent in the first nine months of one-way operation on Lexington and Third Avenues, Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- A special White House commission reached a milestone today in refereeing the railroad industry's work-rules dispute.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 14 -- Bolivia's labor-governmental crisis continued today but with some encouraging signs for President Victor Paz Estenssoro, at least for the short run.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg stirred Republican opposition today with a proposal for a $275,000,000 youth training and employment program.
MOSCOW, June 14 -- Deputy Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin conceded today that science in the capitalist world was developing at "a quite rapid rate."

Following are statements issued yesterday by J. Eliot McCormack, vice president in charge of operations for the Consolidated Edison Company, and by Mayor Wagner on Tuesday's power failure in mid-Manhattan:

Civic Concert Services, Inc., one of the oldest and largest companies providing musicians for organized audiences across the country, has been purchased by the Summy-Birchard Publishing Company of Evanston, Ill.
The Michigan Wisconsin Pipe Line Company borrowed $30,000,000 in the public capital market yesterday at a net interest cost of about 5.46 per cent.
GENEVA, June 14 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma committed Laos today to neutrality and abstention from military pacts.

Something is seriously wrong with damage control in our vital utility system when faults of insulation in a couple of circuit-breaker switches in a substation can cause a massive breakdown of electric power distribution for hours -- not minutes -- in five square miles of the heart of New York City.

BRISTOL, England, June 14 (UPI) -- Ron Holmberg of Brooklyn and two other Americans scored third-round victories in the West of England lawn tennis championship today. Three other United States players were eliminated.

IF the Senate Subcommittee on Juvenile Delinquency and the television broadcasters should chance to yearn for an accord on the issue of crime shows, they could find no happier meeting ground than last night's premiere of the "Kraft Mystery Theatre" on Channel 4.
BIRMINGHAM, Mich., June 14 -- After Ben Hogan won the United States Open championship over the Oakland Hills Country Club course in 1951, he said he was happy he had brought the monster to its knees.
One-hundred and seventy-four graduates of Cooper Union received their degrees and certificates last night at commencement exercises in the Great Hall at Cooper Square.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Senate approved today by voice vote the nomination of Joseph Charles Swidler of Nashville, Tenn., to the Federal Power Commission.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 14 -- Plans for the increased integration of the 5,498 white and 1,234 Negro children in the twelve neighborhood elementary schools here encountered new trouble today.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Greater Philadelphia sought support in Congress yesterday for its efforts to replace New York as the international air gateway to the United States.
CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 9 to 12 points yesterday, except the new October contract, on which a closing bid reflected a rise of 15 points. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

NEW ORLEANS, June 14 -- The United States Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals held today that The New York Times and one of its staff members could not be sued for libel in Alabama over an article on segregation that appeared in the newspaper.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 14 (AP) -- Louis Lee Haggin 2d's Careless John, who had not won a stakes race until five days ago, scored his second straight added-money victory today in the Salvator mile at Monmouth Park.
A large American real estate investment partnership was named yesterday to manage the interests of a British property investment concern that has $25,000,000 in assets entirely in North America.

The New York and American Stock exchanges announced yesterday that officers, directors, and large stockholders of listed companies reported last month, pursuant to the Securities Exchange Act, the following changes in stockholdings:
The blockfront occupied by three apartment and store buildings on the south side of East 147th Street, between Third and Willis Avenues, the Bronx, has been sold by the estate of Victor Hammerschlag.
NEW ORLEANS, June 14 (UPI) -- The leader of the American Nazi party, George Lincoln Rockwell, left his nine "storm troopers" in the county jail here today and headed for home under a $1,000 bond.
The year's first heat wave was broken here in mid-afternoon yesterday by a thunderstorm and a dramatic and welcome drop from the day's high of 88 degrees at 2 P.M. to 56 degrees at 8 o'clock.
CARACAS, Venezuela, June 14 -- The automobile of the United States Ambassador, Teodoro Moscoso, was attacked and burned tonight by university students as it was parked on the campus.

LONDON, June 14 -- A more cheerful tone was evident in most sections of the stock market here today. However, business volume remained small and, while gains outnumbered losses in many of the important sections, net changes generally were less than 1 shilling (14 cents).
LOS ANGELES, June 14 (AP) -- The staff captain of the cruise liner Matsonia was found shot to death today, shortly after the ship had cleared the outer harbor for Honolulu.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 14 -- Turkey's senior arm officers on active service have asserted the independence of the armed forces from control by the Committee of National Unity. The committee is the military junta headed by Gen. Cemal Gursel, that overthrew former Premier Admen Menderes regime in May of last year.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 -- The world premieres of two symphonies will be played by the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra during its golden anniversary season beginning in November.

The H.J. Heinz Company plans to purchase Hachmeister, Inc., 58-year-old Pittsburgh manufacturer of baking ingredients for commercial bakers. Directors of both com panies have approved the acquisition, Henry J. Heinz 2d, chairman, announced yesterday.
Herb Elliott of Australia, the world's fastest miler, clarified some of his thought yesterday on whether soft American living produced soft American athletes.
OTTAWA, June 14 -- The Government has decided to use a parliamentary decree in its effort to remove the Governor of the Bank of Canada.
Everton of England defeated Besiktas of Turkey, 4 -- 0, in a rather lackluster International Soccer League game at the Polo Grounds last night.
GENEVA, June 14 -- The United States said today that the Soviet Union was abandoning even the pretense of negotiating at the three-power conference on a treaty to ban nuclear testing.
When the Philharmonic Hall of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts opens in September, 1962, concertgoers will sit beneath a ceiling of acoustical panels called "clouds."
Bargaining sessions in a major dispute in the maritime industry proceeded haltingly yesterday and the threat of a strike grew as tonight's deadline neared.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 14 -- A trend in movie-making that may touch off a stormy controversy is now under way. There is a boom in Hollywood in feminine nudity.
CHICAGO, June 14 -- One word that inflames tribesmen now attending the American Indian Chicago Conference is "termination."

WASHINGTON, June 14 -The White House reported continued improvement today in President Kennedy's ailing back. In a busy schedule the President saw Nguyen Dinh Thuan, who brought a message from President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam.
CLEVELAND, June 14 -- In a startling turnabout, the Yankees today completed two deals that involved five players.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 14 -- Dr. Barnaby S. Keeney, president of Brown University, announced today the appointment of Dr. Rosemary Pierrel as dean of Pembroke College at Brown, effective Sept. 1.

The International Mining Corporation operated at a loss of 5102,688 in the quarter ended on April 30, stockholders were told yesterday at their annual meeting. This compared with a loss of $49,103 in 1960. However, the latest figure included a special charge of $167,000.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) and the International Development Association announced jointly yesterday that they were making available to the Republic of Sudan the equivalent of $32,500,000 to help finance construction of the Roseires Dam on the Blue Nile.
The Peace Corps selected its first twenty-seven volunteers yesterday to start training for a world-wide assault on poverty, illiteracy and disease.

PITTSBURGH, June 14 (AP) -- Dick Stuart drove in four runs tonight on a single, triple and home run to lead the Pittsburgh Priates to a 5-4 victory over the Cincinnati Reds. Stuart's ninth-inning triple scored the tying and winning runs.

Reports that continued rains in Maine would delay planting sent potato futures prices sharply higher yesterday in unusually heavy trading for this time of the year on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
GENEVA, June 14 -- Hope for resumption of the French-Algerian peace talks within two weeks increased tonight.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 14 -- Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Apawamis and Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Forest Hill Field Club, the co-medalists on Monday with 74's, reached the semi-final round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fifty-eighth annual championship today.
Audience appreciation was higher than usual early yesterday morning during a night-club revue skit satirizing the Consolidated Edison Company.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 (UPI) -- Directors of Bishop Oil Company today approved an offer by Shell Oil Company to buy Bishop's oil and gas properties and the stock of its wholly-owned Canadian subsidiary, Canadian Bishop Oil, Ltd.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 13 -- An unexpected but apparently basic "right-handedness" has been found in growing plants.

Electric power production in the week ended last Saturday was 15,004,000,000 kilowatt hours. It is compared with 13,887,000,000 the week before and 14,147,000,000 kilowatt hours a year ago, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.
A significant and disturbing documentary about political, social and economic unrest among Brazilian peasants made a powerful telecast on Tuesday night over Channel 7.

MONTREAL, June 14 (AP) -- Twelve hockey players switched teams today, four by trades and eight in the annual National League draft. The acquisition of Bronco Horvath by the Chicago Black Hawks and Guy Gendron by the New York Rangers highlighted the draft session.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 14 (AP) -- Charles E. Bohlen said today that fundamental changes in the world over the last thirty years "are nothing compared to what will occur in the next generation."
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy received a Master's degree in public administration from City College last night at the school's 115th commencement exercises.

A proposal to erect a thirty-five-story office and showroom building for the toy and novelty industry at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Forty-first Street was made yesterday to representatives of the industry.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 (UPI) -- Ed Bailey, who had a perfect day at the plate, smashed two home runs and two singles as the San Francisco Giants overpowered the Milwaukee Braves, 11 -- 2, today.
OSLO, Norway, June 14 (AP) -- Sgt. Lloyd G. Crow of Carolltown, Miss., and Fort Benning, Ga., today won the running deer single shot event of the world shooting championships.

After only three weeks of discussion, France has suspended the Evian peace conference on Algeria in what appears to be an intricate but potentially dangerous bargaining maneuver to break a deadlock. According to the French the suspension does not mean a rupture but merely provides a "period of reflection" for each side to explore new ways out of the present impasse.
The Diamond Alkali Company announced yesterday that it would match an offer by the Commercial Solvents Corporation to buy 200,000 shares of stock of the Chemical Process Company at $15 a share.

Stockholders of the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation and the Bridgeport Brass Company voted at separate meetings yesterday to merge their companies. Bridgeport Brass, maker of mill and fabricated products of nonferrous metals, will become an operating division of National Distillers, when the merger becomes effective on June 30.
Surrogate Joseph A. Cox is expected to rule today on the eviction of Mrs. Alice Snow Barbee Lurcy from the five-story mansion at 813 Fifth Avenue.

The first ground-breaking on the site of the 1964 World's Fair in Flushing Meadow Park will take place this morning with the start of construction of a $6,000,000, wall-less paviliion for the gas industry's exhibit.
Three Brooklyn areas, all at least partly deteriorated, were designated by the City Planning Commission yesterday as appropriate for urban renewal.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) -- Senator Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania said today that Adlai E. Stevenson, United States representative at the United Nations, flew here in the middle of the night to obtain a last-minute reversal of plans that would have supplied air cover for the rebel landing on Cuba April 17.
The sudden brief thunderstorm yesterday afternoon disrupted but failed to halt the 116th commencement exercises of Fordham University.

WHEN Sir Edward Grey sadly said in 1914 that "the lights are going off all over Europe; we shall not see them lit again in our lifetime," an irreverent wag in London's Portland Club remarked, "Not here; they can turn off the gas, but not our lamps."
COCOA, Fla., June 14 (UPI) -- A 12-year-old Little League baseball player collapsed and died on the field today after being struck in the throat by a pitched ball.

A translation of Mao Tse-tung's treatise, "Yu Chi Chan," the ideological and organizational guide for the Chinese Communist guerrilla forces in the war against Japan, will be published in October by Praeger. It will be called "Mao Tse- tung on Guerrilla Warfare."

Paperboard production rose in the week ended last Saturday to 332,425 tons from 300,899 the week before, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. A year ago the figure was 327,206 tons.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 14 -- With some new faces and a drastic change in tactics, the Republican party in Nassau County set out today to regain some of the ground it has lost to the Democrats in the last fifteen years.

BONN, Germany, June 14 -- The Government announced today that new negotiations would be sought with Washington "as soon as possible" to discuss the return of German assets seized as a result of World War II.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 14 (AP) -- A Southern newspaper publisher, speaking on desegregation, said today the leadership of the Southern bar had not lived up to its responsibility.
PARIS, June 14 -- The aroused farmers of Brittany continued their rampage against the Government today.
ATLANTA, June 14 -- The stage apparently has been set for a full test of the Atlanta school system's pupil placement plan.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (AP) -- Sonny Liston, a leading contender for the heavyweight crown, stood silent in Magistrate's Court today as he won a' delay until July 1 to answer charges of disorderly conduct, conspiracy and impersonating a policeman.

HAVANA, June 14 -- Premier Fidel Castro agreed today to accept agricultural tractors in exchange for prisoners captured in the April invasion, provided the number of vehicles would correspond to the value of 500 heavy bulldozers he originally requested.
The Board of Education's Commission on Inquiry, which was appointed to advise on collective bargaining, has resigned after a dispute on procedure.

There seems to be no shortage of prime time for television appearances by high ranking government officials both here and abroad. Scheduled soon are interviews with Japanese Premier Hayato Ikeda, Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy and Secretary of State Dean Rusk.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The United States Government hopes its new Ambassador to South Korea, Samuel D. Berger, will be able to encourage an early return to civilian rule in that country.

Mayor Wagner's "six-point program to aid hospitals," as reported in The Times of June 4, brings up a major question. Why cannot the City of New York provide access from Manhattan to Welfare Island and its two municipal hospitals? Why must personnel who live in Manhattan and who work in Bird S. Coler and Goldwater Memorial Hospitals travel all the way to Queens Plaza, then transfer to a Welfare Island bus?

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 14 -- Andrew Zemba, the advertising manager at Arnold Constable, gained the Rothschild Cup as first low-net golf winner at the annual outing today of the New York City Newspaper-Retail Dry Goods Association at the Century Country Club.
Prices of United States Government obligations and other prime debt securities continued to drift downward yesterday.

The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation announced yesterday that Dr. Everett Case, president of Colgate University, would succeed Alfred P. Sloan Jr. as foundation president and chief executive officer on July 1, 1962.
BECKENHAM, England, June 14 (UPI) -- A former Stanford quarterback, Jon Douglas, and Bill Bond of La Jolla, Calif., today scored third-round victories in the Kent lawn tennis championship.
The music of Mozart, Bach and Berlioz blotted out the cacophony of crosstown traffic yesterday as the New York Public Library began its fourteenth summer series of recorded outdoor concerts.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I., June 14 -- Dr. and Mrs. Harold E.B. Pardee of New York and Lawrence gave a dinner dance tonight at the Lawrence Beach Club, the first of the "Little Season" debutante parties on Long Island, in honor of their granddaughter, Miss Dwight Pardee.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- All nonalcoholic carbonated beverages -- soft drinks -- will be required to bear a label listing ingredients after June 15, 1962, the Food and Drug Administration announced today.

TURNBERRY, Scotland, June 14 (AP) -- Ralph Morrow, an airman from Oklahoma City, and Henry Timbrook, a 40-year-old Los Angeles mortgage banker, moved into the fourth round of the British Amateur golf championship today.

MANY parents soon will be watching their children depart for their first summer away from home at camp. Mixed emotions on both sides often accompany these leave-takings. The New York State Camp Directors Association offers the following suggestions to assist parents facing this problem.

Fifty years ago, measles, mumps and chicken pox kept Stuyvesant Polyclinic busy. Physicians coped also with ailments ranging from tuberculosis to the common cold among immigrants on Manhattan's lower East Side.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) -- Irvin C. Scarbeck, the diplomat arrested on charges having given United States secrets to Poland, was caught in a classical blackmail trap by the Communists, informed sources said today.

The Urban League of Greater New York charged last night that it had received a "run-around" from the New York World's Fair Corporation in its efforts to get a pledge of fair employment opportunities for Negroes.

Caught in the middle of an economic fracas, the Canadian dollar has weakened in the last two days. It closed yesterday at 100 13/32 cents in terms of the United States dollar, lowest point since early in January. In the two days it has fallen about 3/4 of a cent, quite a sharp drop in such a short period.
ASCOT, England, June 14 -Gray and black toppers were waved and a loud cheer went up today when Queen Elizabeth II's Aiming High won the Coronation Stakes at the Royal Ascot meeting.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 14 -- The United States drew high praise today for allowing outsiders a candid look at the way in which it has administered its Pacific island trusteeship.
Dr. Jacob E. Goldman said here last night that "freedom for the pursuit of thought" gave the United States the edge over the Soviet Union in science competition.
RICHMOND, Va., June 14 -A Federal judge denied today the Justice Department's request that it be allowed to intervene in a suit to open the public schools of Prince Edward County in Virginia.

An appeal to leaders of the major faiths to exercise their influence on spiritual and moral issues was made last night by the Rev. Dr. Julius Mark, newly elected president of the Synagogue Council of America.

WITH the beginning of summer, ground meat is rarely a grind. And it is as certain as sunlight and rain that a staggering percentage of ground meat will find its way over millions of charcoal fires during the next few months.
"SOCIALISM means we should not only love our fellow-man, but also our fellow-woman."

The recent brief of the Justice Department to the Federal District, Court in Louisiana on matters of education raises some interesting constitutional questions. The basic issue whether some form of education should be provided as a right or a privilege transcends the problem of segregation, although a decision will of necessity have a wide impact.
Oil production and processing last week fell below the levels of the week before, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 7, 1961:
Hunter College awarded bachelor's and master's degrees yesterday to 1,788 students in exercises held at the college's Bronx campus.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -Representative Chet Holifield, chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, urged the Administration today to renounce the voluntary moratorium on atomic tests.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Reports that Senator Estes Kefauver is in line to replace Associate Justice Hugo L. Black on the Supreme Court were denied strongly today.

Jacob Brownstein, one of two Brooklyn lawyers convicted in a slum-operations case involving Banton L. Wyckoff, protested yesterday that the city was using the "same dilatory tactics" he had been accused of using.

Flag Day, the anniversary of the founding of the United States Army on June 14, 1775, by the Continental Congress and of the adoption of the thirteen-star flag two years later, was observed yesterday on historic ground in Battery Park.
LOS ANGELES, June 14 -- A new system of mock warfare using electronic computers was described here today.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Robert C. Weaver today termed the Housing and Home Finance Agency, which he heads, a bureaucratic monstrosity.
Thomas B. Gilchrist Jr., special state investigator of bingo, announced yesterday that he would examine how profits from the game were being spent.

A SUMMER-long delight of an exhibition opens today at Wildenstein Co., 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, to close Sept. 9. It is the Vassar College Centennial Loan Exhibition, moved down from Poughkeepsie and composed of 155 drawings and watercolors lent by fifty-six Vassar alumnae and their families.

I have often criticized the Rhee regime for its tyranny and the Chang Myun Government for its inaction. The recent military coup d'etat in South Korea gravely concerns the security of both our countries.

Among the principal securities offerings on Tuesday were $30,000,000 of bonds of Virginia Electric Power Company, $15,000,000 of debentures of the City Products Corporation and 1,000,000 common shares of DeSoto Chemical Coatings, Inc.
ALBANY, June 14 -- The merger of three rural school districts in central Westchester County was postponed today for a month by court order.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 14 -- Cocoa growers around the world have been making increasing use of the latest production and disease-prevention techniques with some striking results. The most immediate result has been a sharp rise in output, so large that it poses the problem of a glut of supplies on the world market.

An early morning fire yesterday in the eight-story Amsterdam Hotel at the southeast corner of Lexington Avenue and East Twenty-fifth Street killed a woman resident and injured five other persons, one critically.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 14 (UPI) -- The Kansas City Athletics, held to two hits in seven innings, scored eight runs in the eighth inning tonight and trounced the Minnesota Twins, 9 -- 2. Camilio Pascual, who had struck out thirteen Athletics, was the victim of the attack.

WARSAW, June 14 -- In the carefully compartmented embassy in Warsaw, Scarbeck had no access to the files or activities of the political and military sections, situated upstairs in the three-story chancery building.
A Hong Kong nightclub operator interrupted his two-day-old trial in Federal Court yesterday to plead guilty to conspiring to conceal $85,000 in gold bullion aboard a vessel that docked here.
Some of the acrimony that has been building up between Young Rubicam, Inc., and the television affiliates overflowed into a meeting the agency called yesterday morning.

Some day father will be asked if he is going to the graduation exercises. Father's response is likely to be a puzzled query as to who is graduating -- the boy next door who has been attending a West Coast college?
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Senator Philip A. Hart said today United States consumers were being swindled and deceived by "subtle and refined" packaging and labeling techniques of some manufacturers.

The Senate has the opportunity today to show that it is bigger than the billboard lobby that has cowed so many erstwhile "liberal" and other members of both houses of Congress, not to mention vast numbers of legislators throughout all of the fifty states.
Resentment and concern have been aroused in Taipei over American moves to establish relations with Communist Outer Mongolia.
The owner of a tiny roadside stand selling coffee at 3 cents a cup and a few groceries in Camaguey Province recently leaned against the counter and spoke sadly to his lone customer.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The nation's defense chiefs told Congress today that the Soviet Union and Communist China were shipping large amounts of arms to Cuba and using the island as a base from which "to export revolution to South America."

CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -The first general advance in soybean futures prices in more than a week added almost 7 cents a bushel to the July contract today and a cent or more generally to all other deliveries.
LOS ANGELES, June 14 (AP) -- Don Drysdale pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers back into the National League lead tonight with a five-hit, 7-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

The International Typographical Union expressed regret yesterday over "a serious deterioration of harmonious relations" between the Publishers Association of New York City and New York Typographical Union No. 6.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 14 -- Discussions of Soviet higher education by three prominent Soviet officials have been compiled in a pamphlet issued today by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- One of the leading Congressional authorities on scientific research complained tonight that the Government's scientific advisory machinery was in danger of becoming "monopolized" by a clique of cautious scientists.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 14 -- Canon Albert J. duBois, executive director of the American Church Union, said tonight that "within days a "call will go out to American Christians and to leaders of the Anglican Communion throughout the world which may very likely mark a turning point in the catholic revival.
PARIS, June 14 -- Many observers here have concluded from the suspension of the Algerian peace talks that the rebel leadership is more revolutionary than nationalist.
William Rosenwald, a leader for thirty years in Jewish resettlement work, was honored last night at a dinner given in his honor at the Pierre Hotel.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Navy has decided to move the super-carrier Kitty Hawk to a West Coast naval shipyard for further work before she is pronounced ready for sea duty.

Morgan New York State Corporation, the state-wide bank holding company planned by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, has announced the election of directors. The new company will have six upstate banks.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Differences of opinion and full freedom to express and promote them, supply the life-blood of an open, creative and free society. This is no less the fact because, as is being widely noted, the depth and duration of some of these differences among Americans are producing consequences which suit Premier Khrushchev as well as if he had planned them.
DETROIT, June 14 (AP) -- Frank Lary beat the Boston Red Sox for his tenth victory today as he pitched the Detroit Tigers to a 4 -- 2 triumph.
A sixteen-story apartment building will be erected by the Frouge Corporation, builders, on a plot the company owns at the northeast corner of Sixty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- President Kennedy and most of his leading policy advisers considered major foreign problems, including differences with the Soviet Union, in a series of meetings today.
Mayor Wagner appeared yesterday to have decided to run for a third term. He also seemed to be insisting on reshuffling the top places on the city-wide Democratic ticket.
The first major discount house on Fifth Avenue will open next spring in premises occupied for years by a store that once catered to the carriage trade.

The gas industry expects to require $10,000,000,000 to $15,000,000,000 in the next ten years from Wall Street and other sources, according to Lester T. Potter, president of the American Gas Association and of the Lone Star Gas Company of Dallas, Tex.

PITIFUL is the word for the little crime melodrama called "20,000 Eyes," which opened yesterday at local neighborhood theatres. It is all about a slick investment counselor who tries to hoodwink a shrewd retired racketteer, gets in deeper (a jewel robbery) and involves his secretary and best pal, two nice and extremely dumb people.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -Carl B. Spaeth, dean of the Stanford University Law School, has decided not to take the post of Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, White House sources said today.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -The Administration asked Congress today to raise the ceiling on the national debt by $5,000,000,000 for the coming year.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, urged today that Berlin be made a free city under international guarantees and protection. In a Senate speech designed to stimulate debate on the Berlin issue, Mr. Mansfield, a Montana Democrat, said that continuation of the status quo could lead only to nuclear war.
The Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday that it would establish a $100,000,000 aluminum complex in Australia in partnership with a group of leading Australian mining companies.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that considering how many Puerto Rican children came here from rural areas, it was "extraordinary how well they have adapted themselves to the most confusing of all places to live."
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- President Kennedy authorized the Secretary of Agriculture today to send surplus food to Negroes in Haywood and Fayette Counties in Tennessee.
The twenty-seven men named yesterday to go to Colombia and Tanganyika in the Peace Corps represent every section of the United States.
Former Representative Francis E. Dorn was designated yesterday as the Republican candidate for Borough President in Brooklyn.
IF Elisa Daggs had her way, Americans would have to take some kind of refresher course in courtesy in preparation for what the United States hopes will be an influx of foreign tourists.
The Soviet Union's chief delegate suggested yesterday that the United Nations begin at once to dismiss large numbers of its employes to make room for citizens of Communist and neutral nations.

WASHINGTON' June 14 -- High officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters have sent out letters to the union's 3,000 local officials and staff, members suggesting $25 contributions "for the re-election of James R. Hoffa" as president of the international union.
Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy urged the public yesterday to take more interest in the fight against organized crime, juvenile delinquency and antitrust and civil-rights violations.

ONCE David Ben-Gurion, Premier of Israel, was told that a desert problem was insoluble. Contrary to what you might suppose, even quantities of water would not provide the solution. The experts said so, and that seemed to be that.
BECKENHAM, England, June 14 (AP) -- Neale Fraser said today that he would retire from big-time tennis at the end of this year.

Determined at last to bring the Police Department up to authorized strength, the Wagner administration is going out on the streets and to other cities looking for men, instead of just waiting for them to drift in. This is hardly a novel idea; business and industry have been recruiting young people for years by visiting college campuses, and otherwise.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, June 14 -- The United Nations' effort to reduce foreign influence in Katanga Province is beginning to take effect.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Pierre Salinger, White House press secretary, who has been an involuntary medical student for the last week, received a birthday salute today from his staff, the President and the press.
Twenty more persons -school representatives and contracting company employers -- were questioned yesterday about alleged irregularities in the city's school building program.

"Little Me" will bring Sid Caesar back to Broadway after a fourteen-year absence. The popular television comic will be starred in the musical version of Patrick Dennis' forthcoming novel. Seven characters -- four husbands and three lovers -- will be impersonated by Mr. Caesar.

NINE teen-agers who recently were appointed "junior curators" by the Brooklyn Children's Museum have wide interests, love animals, play musical instruments, read everything in sight -- including comic books -- are partial to science fiction stories, which they also write, and are about as difficult to live with as most children in their early teens.

Springfield, Mass., borrowed $6,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements. The money was raised by the sale of general obligations to a syndicate headed by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

A Long Island group warned yesterday that Nassau County might have to carve a new airport out of built-up areas if it allowed its only airfield -- Mitchel Air Force Base near Hempstead -- to disappear.

Borough President Edward R. Dudley of Manhattan gave an insurgent Democratic group a strong indication yesterday that in a race for re-election he would have to accept the support of Carmine G. De Sapio, leader of Tammany Hall.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) -- President Kennedy got a new car today. It is a button-pusher's dream, with an elevator seat, a choice of three tops and global communications.
The Humble Oil and Refining Company, principal domestic affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), is getting set to invade the marketing territory of the Standard Oil Company (Kentucky).

The two leading officers of Previews, Inc., international real estate clearing house, have been promoted. John C. Tysen, president since 1950, was named chairman of the board, and Robert T. Furman Jr., formerly executive vice president, succeeds Mr. Tysen in the presidency.

Springfield, Mass., borrowed $6,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements. The money was raised by the sale of general obligations to a syndicate headed by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

Barnabys Bluff was so much better than his opponents in the Annapolis Hurdle at Belmont Park yesterday that it wasn't even close. George H. Bostwick's home-bred 3-year-old gelding finished five lengths ahead of Theodora Randolph's And Now in the mile-and-a-half race, and he could have made the margin bigger if his jockey, Ronald Cartwright, had wanted him to.

DETROIT, June 15 (UPI) -- Vic Wertz hit the tenth grand- slam home run of his major league career and Bill Monbouquette pitched a four-hitter today to lead the Boston Red Sox to a 10-1 rout of the Detroit Tigers.

It was a chilling speech that Premier Khrushchev delivered in Moscow yesterday. As it contained essentially what Premier Khrushchev told President Kennedy in Vienna, it is easy to understand why the President used the word "somber" to describe his meeting with the Premier.
PARIS, June 15 -- The Deputies of Brittany appealed today to President de Gaulle to intervene in the two-week-old farm crisis.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 15 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Forest Hill Field Club and Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Apawamis, the co-medalists, will meet in the 36-hole final of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fifty-eighth annual championship tomorrow.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 15 -- In a movie era in which failures greatly outnumber hits, career-conscious stars are increasingly wary about choosing roles. The factors that decide which movie Audrey Hepburn will select are numerous and sometimes she is very uncertain.
GROTON, Conn., June 15 (AP) -- Models of two of the first light bulbs flashed a signal today and the Navy's eighth Polaris missile submarine, the Thomas A. Edison, was launched.

IN 1846 the spring rains were unusually heavy on the high plains that were soon to be called Kansas and Nebraska. Emigrant trains setting out from Independence were held up by mud, swamps and flooded rivers. The delays were worrying, particularly to those bound for California. If autumn snowstorms in the Sierra Nevadas came early there would be trouble.
NEW BRITAIN, Conn., June 15 (AP) -- The president of the Stanley Golf Club said today that two Negroes were denied membership in the club because their applications had not been properly prepared.

The World War II experiences of a "dedicated Frenchman," Michel Hollard, is told by George Martelli in "The Man Who Saved London." After the fall of France, Hollard organized a network of amateur informants that grew so efficient that Allied intelligence accepted, "almost without checking," any report it submitted.
CHICAGO, June 15 (AP) -- A rapid retreat in July soybeans took the price down the limit of 10 cents allowed for a single day on the Board of Trade in the early afternoon today.
Supreme Court Justice Henry Epstein yesterday dismissed an action in which a convicted gambler sought to stop a city magistrate from sentencing him on a gambling conviction.

For refusing to turn over to a House Judiciary subcommittee all documents demanded by Representative Celler as chairman, the Port of New York Authority executive director has been found guilty in Federal District Court of contempt of Congress. The judgment lodges against Austin J. Tobin, but it bears equally against Governors Rockefeller of New York and Meyner of New Jersey, who supported his withholding of subpoenaed data.

GROCERY shopping should be a pleasure this week-end, for virtually every market counter is loaded with good things to eat. The abundant variety in fruits is particularly welcome after the spring months when only citrus fruits and bananas were reasonably priced.
For about six months people who ride buses that normally cross the Broadway Bridge over the Harlem River will have to walk the 312 feet across to bus service at either end.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 15 -- The Westchester County Democratic committee designated William D. Carlebach of Chappaqua tonight as its choice for County Executive.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 15 -- Turkey's military rulers have settled down after an angry quarrel among themselves to an uneasy wait for elections next September.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 15 (UPI) -- Jose Valdivielso's single in the ninth inning scored Earl Battey with the winning run tonight as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 4 -- 3. Jack Kralick held the Athletics to six hits.

A 5 per cent sinking fund debenture issue of Gimbel Brothers, Inc. was offered to the public yesterday priced at 99 to yield 5.09 per cent. The issue consisted of $25,000,000 of the debentures due in 1981 and not subject to call for a lower cost financing for five years. Lehman Brothers and Goldman, Sachs Co., managing underwriters, said that the distribution was by all indications a success.
A rash of price cuts in various basic industrial materials came yesterday in the wake of similar recent reductions.

American Electric Power Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday slight gains in net income for twelve months ended May 31 and for the month of May. Earnings for the first five months, however, fell below the 1960 level.
PITTSBURGH, June 15 (AP) -- Joey Jay posted his eighth straight victory tonight as the Cincinnati Reds routed the Pittsburgh Pirates, 8 -- 1.
The head of the Religious Zionists of America called on the American Zionist Council last night to establish a network of day schools and facilities for religious education in every Jewish community.
ALBANY, June 15 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller said today that the state had completed steps necessary to qualify for a $2,000,000 Federal bonus for restricting billboards along interstate highways.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- A new application for licensing of Krebiozen as a hormone has been rejected, it was learned tonight. A long controversy has raged over contentions that Krebozien is effective in treating cancer.

Abraham D. Beame, the Director of the Budget, has written you a letter, published June 8, on which you make editorial comment. The Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., would like to add the following:
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan seemed assured last night that he would have no opposition when he seeks a sixth term in office.

Ingmar Bergman's "Secrets of Women," a Swedish-made drama, has been scheduled at the downtown Fifth Avenue Cinema, following the current "Ashes and Diamonds." Eva Dahlbeck, Gunnar Bjornstrand, May-Britt Nilsson, Birger Malmsten and Anita Bjork have the leading roles in the Janus Films release, which has English subtitles.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 15 -- Franz Slavic, who is said to have been a member of Adolf Eichmann's wartime bodyguard, is to give evidence before an Austrian judge on behalf of the defense in the Eichmann trial.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to hold a consolidated hearing on various merger proposals submitted by Eastern railroads.

LONDON, June 15 -- The announcement of a sharp increase in Britain's trading deficit for May caused precipitous declines in the industrial shares and British Government securities in the stock market today. Some sections managed to recover slightly before the session ended.
Check transactions in the twenty-six leading cities of the nation aggregated $27,203,195,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved today President Kennedy's bill to increase Social Security benefits by $780,000,000 a year and allow men to retire at 62 years of age.
The approach of two patroling detectives saved the 13-year-old son of the Argentine Consul General from being robbed and beaten in Central Park last evening.

Burton N. Pugach, the disbarred lawyer who is on trial for conspiracy in a lye attack that partly blinded his former fiancee, slashed his wrists yesterday in a court detention room and shouted that he would be dead before the trial ended.

Shareholders of the defunct German Reichsbank are assured of a full pay-off under a liquidation law adopted on Wednesday by the Bundestag after a five-year parliamentary struggle. The legislative body went along with the point made by Ludwig Erhard, Economics Minister, that further postponement of action on the issue would hurt West Germany abroad.
Philadelphia, Pa., borrowed $24,957,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance expansion of water and sewerage facilities and other public improvements.
NEWARK, June 15 -- One man was hospitalized and three were arrested today as violence broke out on a picket line at the Kolker Chemical Corporation plant at 600 Doremus Avenue.

The moving reports on the Eichmann trial tell of a nightmare era in history whose reality was comprehended by those who had been imprisoned by Nazis. The trial will have served its purpose, and all the untold sufferings of millions of innocent victims will not have been in vain if we listen to their cry, which expresses a challenge to us rather than mere fate.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Government has developed a lopsided program of cancer research that is neglecting the prevention of cancer, a medical scientist told Congress today.

" THE home and the church should be every man's first interest," Federal Judge Luther Wallace Youngdahl said once. To this list Judge Youngdahl might well have added the law, for he has spent most of his career studying it, enforcing it and interpreting it.

BIRMINGHAM, Mich., June 15 -- During the early part of the week the Monster had been in a prankish mood, letting itself get buffeted around by the little men with sticks in their hands. The Monster, naturally enough, is the Oakland Hills Country Club, which is supposed to be as terrifying a course as golf has to offer.

MRS. LYNDON B. JOHNSON was between engagements one afternoon this week, and she sat a few minutes among the French furnishings of her temporary home at the Park Sheraton Hotel, sipping iced orange juice and explaining that the pretty little cookies on the coffee table were left over from a party.
A powerful hoisting crane will set in motion this morning the final construction phase of the $7,460,000 Alexander Hamilton Bridge over the Harlem River.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The pattern for the American-owned fleet of foreign-flag vessels, whose crews the shipping unions are seeking the power to organize by contractual agreement, was established by the United States Government in 1939 as a national security measure.

The Ampex Corporation reported yesterday that it experienced a $4,000,000 loss in its fiscal year ended on April 30. Coincidentally, it announced the election of a new president and chief executive officer.

BERLIN, June 15 -- Walter Ulbricht, the East German Communist leader, today threatened Communist interference with Western air traffic to and from Berlin after the conclusion of a peace treaty between East Germany and the Soviet Union.
The Deputy Superintendent of Schools in charge of buildings admitted yesterday that he had received a case of liquor from a construction concern doing business with the school board.

TOPEKA, Kan. -- Seventeen distillers who say they supply 75 per cent of the liquor sold in Kansas have filed a suit in Shawnee County District Court here to test the constitutionality of the state's new liquor price-fixing law.
BRISTOL, England, June 15 (AP) -- Rod Laver, Australia's left-handed tennis star, said tonight he stood ready to turn professional if he won the all-English title at Wimbledon.

Almost all potato positions hit new highs for the lives of the contracts in early trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. However, hedge selling and liquidation reversed the price movement. Although some investment buying was noted, final quotations were off 1 to 5 points (hundredths of a cent a pound), on volume of 507 carrots.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) -- The National Conference on Weights and Measures warned today that American consumers were being cheated on a gigantic scale by packages that purport to contain more than they actually do.

The Misses Alice Dodge and Gale Rainsford were presented to society last night at a dance given by their grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Cleveland Earl Dodge at their home in Riverdale, the Bronx.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $9,000,000 to $71,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $84,000,000 to $655,000,000.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- A student who was awarded a $3,800 Government fellowship after having been convicted of contempt of Congress will lose the grant only if he swore falsely in his application. The conviction itself apparently does not invalidate the award.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Two leaders of the International Union of Electrical Workers fought recently in a feud over control of the 275,000-member organization.
LONDON, June 15 -- Dr. Fricis Menders, labor leader and legislator during the period of Latvian independence, has been arrested, according to a report from Riga.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 15 -- The Earl of Home, British Foreign Secretary, called today for greater sacrifice by the West to maintain the balance of power in the "cold war."
Premier Amintore Fanfani of Italy and Vice President Johnson reaffirmed here last night the friendship and understanding between their countries.

GENEVA, June 15 -- The Soviet Union welcomed today assurances that the United States wished to continue negotiating for a treaty to ban nuclear weapons testing but expressed concern at the possibility that testing would be resumed.

Loans to businesses at the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City rose $174,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Robert Goldstein, who has been serving as temporary head of production at Twentieth Century-Fox' Hollywood studios since the death of Buddy Adler last July, will return immediately to his former position as head of the company's European film production in London.

LONDON, June 15 -- British and Soviet space experts abandoned today their search for the missing Russian Venus rocket with the Jodrell Bank radio-telescope. For the last three days of the week-long hunt they have worked in conjunction with ground commands in Russia but received no signal from the rocket.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 5 per cent above sales in the 1960 week.

PARIS, June 15 -- Helen Hayes and her touring Theatre Guild American Repertory Company tonight began a two-day holdover stand at the Paris International Drama Festival popular and critical successes in the last week.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Secretary of the Navy John B. Connally Jr. held a news conference today, the first in several years by any of the service secretaries in Washington.
CHICAGO, June 15 -- Broad changes under the Kennedy Administration will lead to a Federal policy "more sympathetic" to the needs and desires of Indians, it was forecast today.

Production of lumber totaled 229,336,000 board feet in the week ended last Saturday, compared with 220,943,000 board feet the week before and 239,418,000 a year ago, according to reports from regional associations.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Navy will scrutinize with special care other ships in the New York Shipbuilding Corporation's yards at Camden, N.J., in view of its dissatisfaction with the work on the supercarrier Kitty Hawk, the Secretary of the Navy said today.
The burning ambition of Fidel Castro has confronted the United States with an embarrassing and dangerous situation in Latin America.
LOS ANGELES, June 15 (AP) -- Johnny Podres went for his seventh victory tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers opened a two-game series with the Chicago Cubs.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 15 -- So many opening-night records were shattered at Monticello Raceway tonight, its officials immediately made plans to petition the New York State Harness Racing Commission for a 110-night meeting here in 1962.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Paul H. Hammaker has resigned as president and a director of Montgomery Ward Co. and his duties have been assumed by John A. Barr, chairman. Ward's vice president in charge of personnel, Anthony D. Eastman, also has resigned as an officer and a director.
ASCOT, England, June 15 -- Pandofell, a 4-year-old English colt, upset the forecasters today and won the Ascot Gold Cup as the heavily favored French invaders ran out of the money.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Walter P. Reuther clashed today with a South Carolina business man over President Kennedy's order banning job discrimination on Federal projects because of race, color, creed or national origin.
BOLZANO, Italy, June 15 -- For the fourth consecutive night bomb explosions shattered the quiet of the green valleys of the Alto Adige.

Potts-Woodbury, Inc., an advertising agency with headquarters in Kansas City, Mo., and branches here and in Chicago and Denver, has leased larger local offices at 1270 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) in Rockefeller Center.
A single cigar lying in an ashtray filled with cigarette stubs was the only indication yesterday that a different president held office at City College.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 15 -- The biennial Annapolis-to-Newport yacht race began coming alive tonight when the rating list showing the time allowances in five classes was distributed to those concerned.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Premier Khrushchev's statement today on Soviet foreign policy reinforced the view in Washington that Moscow is intent on pressing for a German settlement on its own terms.
