The modern six-story apartment building at 825 South Tenth Street, Newark, has been sold by the Hilltop Holding Corporation to the Sincou Realty Company. The broker was J.I. Kislak, Inc.
District 50, a catch-all union of the United Mine Workers, lost one of its units yesterday.
A landlord with seven convictions for policy operations was sentenced to thirty days in jail yesterday for Health Code violations.

GENEVA, June 15 -- Ambassador W. Averell Harriman appealed to Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union today to show in the conference on Laos the spirit of the communique on the Vienna meeting between President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev.
Mayor Wagner told a press conference at City Hall yesterday that, in effect, he would pick his own running mates if he decided to run again.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These rates do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) -- President Kennedy today named Mercer Cook, a Negro, as Ambassador to the new African republic of Niger.

OTTAWA, June 15 -- The Royal Commission on Publications, which has been investigating charges of "unfair competition" by United States publications against Canadian periodicals, asked the Government today to change tax and tariff laws to give Canadian magazines a bigger share of advertising.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 -- Southern California was a strong favorite tonight to run off with the team honors in the fortieth annual National Collegiate track and field championships, which start tomorrow at Franklin Field.

ALBANY, June 15 -- The Public Service Commission refused today to force the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad to put a third brakeman on its freight runs between the Connecticut border and New York City.

Net assets of the nation's mutual funds crossed $20,000,000,000 in May, the first time this level has been reached, according to figures issued yesterday by the National Association of Investment Companies.
Four newspaper executives were named yesterday to the advisory board of the American Press Institute at Columbia University.
OTTAWA, June 15 -- James E. Coyne, Governor of the Bank of Canada, who the Government has decided must leave his $62,000-a-year position, fired another shot at his critics today.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation and three other electrical equipment manufacturers yielded to Federal pressure today and agreed to sign an order against sales at "unreasonably low prices" that might lessen competition.
NAIROBI, Kenya, June 15 -- Representatives of Kenya's two leading African political parties conferred with Jomo Kenyatta today and agreed to press for full independence for Kenya this year.
Trading volume and prices of most stocks on the over-the-counter market increased slightly yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission is considering a new reduction in long-distance telephone rates, it was disclosed today.

The role of Carnegie Hall in promoting international cultural relations is being advanced through the formation of a World Inter-Cultural Advisory Committee. Edward L. Bernays, trustee of the world-famous concert hall, has become chairman of this new committee, whose membership is representative of leading international business and cultural groups.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, June 15 -- Finance Minister Mohammad Shoaib said at a news conference today that Pakistan would consider offers of assistance to finance her second Five-Year-Plan from all friendly countries.

FOUR and one-half million American children are expected to forsake home and parents the first week of July for seaside, mountain and country camps. To delight the child far from home, parents and relatives can surprise him with an occasional basket or a birthday package to share with bunkmates.
Lehnnan Brothers, Wall Street investment banking concern, said yesterday it would join in the development of the Golden Triangle Industrial Park in Southern California.
IT is difficult for many players to learn to make high bids on weak suits, so South's bid of four spades in this deal is worthy of attention.
PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals' youthful battery of 20-year-old Ray Sadecki and 19-year-old Tim McCarver paced a 6-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.

NARROWSBURG, N.Y., June 15 -- Spokesmen for the New York State Conservation Department insist that there are plenty of trout, bass and walleyes in the Delaware. They maintain that the river made famous by Washington just isn't fished enough.
Steel production in May aggregated 8,978,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the highest level since April, 1960, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 15 -- Second guesses reverberated through the Jim Ten Eyck Boathouse today as rival coaches revived their estimates of Cornell's entry in Saturday's Intercollegiate Rowing Association championship.
The hardest-hitting publisher in town beat his way into the magazine business yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Factory production advanced another 3 per cent in May, lifting it to a level two-thirds of the way up from the recession low to the pre-recession peak.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Six Detroit witnesses invoked the Fifth Amendment 100 times today in a Senate investigation of the Detroit chapter of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 12 -- The significance of President Kennedy's letters of nearly a month ago to five Arab chiefs of government is beginning to make an impression on leaders here.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today a broad new attack upon deceptive practices in the sale, advertising, and shipment, of food, drugs and cosmetics.
CLIFFSIDE PARK, N.J., June 15 -- The library board, irked by the failure of book borrowers to return overdue books, has decided to hire a professional collector.

ROME, June 15 -- The European debut of off-Broadway's Living Theatre was enthusiastically acclaimed here today. Audiences and the press joined in applauding performances of two plays, both new to Italy -- "The Connection," by Jack Gelber and "Many Loves," by William Carlos Williams.
The lemon slices are wrapped in gauze so the seeds won't drop in the caviar.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- President Kennedy's physican reported definite signs today of further improvement of his wrenched back.

LOS ANGELES, June 15 -- "If one-season climate isn't all you thought it was going to be . . . If those glamorous projects you were promised you'd work on haven't materialized . . . If the kids miss their grandparents."
BALTIMORE, June 15 (AP) -- Ed Hobaugh of the Washington Senators pitched a four-hit, 5-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.
CLEVELAND, June 15 -- The Yankees swept tonight into the American League lead for the first time this year.

A LITTLE late but as welcome as the luscious Long Island strawberries that also have been tardy in making their annual appearance is lettuce from nearby New Jersey and upstate counties. The cold spring delayed these and other crops.
The number of scheduled airlines flying the North Atlantic will increase from nineteen to twenty tonight with the scheduled inauguration of service into New York by Pakistan International Airlines.

CHICAGO, June 15 (UPI) -- The Chicago White Sox ran their winning streak to seven games today. They spoiled Eli Grba's budding shutout with three unearned runs in the eighth inning for a 3-2 victory over the Los Angeles Angels.

With the teen-ager market now estimated at something close to $10,000,000,000 a year and its present population of 17,000,000 expected to increase sharply by 1970, it becomes important for advertisers to know something about adolescents.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower cautioned an international gathering of Mayors today against yielding local authority to centralized national government.
The first ground-breaking ceremony for an exhibit of the 1964-65 World's Fair was held yesterday, with the gas industry sponsoring the start of a $6,000,000 project.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 15 (AP) -- Segregation-testing Freedom Riders met scant resistance today as they pushed into southern Georgia and northern Florida.

The United States monetary gold stock rose $48,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $17,476,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The increase, like the $25,000,000 increase a week earlier, was the largest in four years.
A city commissioner said yesterday that he thought the city should have some control over electric service operations of the Consolidated Edison Company. The state now has supervision.
BOSTON, June 15 (UPI) -- Attorneys for Bernard Goldfine announced today that the year and a day Federal prison sentence meted out to the wealthy industrialist would not be appealed.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Administration's school-aid bill encountered a new obstacle today when Democratic leaders discovered they could not muster a majority of the House Rules Committee for action at this time.

Surrogate Joseph A. Cox did not give an expected ruling yesterday on a petition to evict Mrs. Alice Snow Barbee Lurcy from the five-story mansion at 813 Fifth Avenue. There was no explanation for the delay, nor was there any indication when the ruling would be forthcoming.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 15 -- Adlai E. Stevenson declared here today that Senator Hugh Scott was mistaken when he said Mr. Stevenson had influenced a United States decision to withhold air support for the rebel landing in Cuba on April 17.

Red Ruffing, former pitcher with the New York Yankees, Boston Red Sox, and Chicago White Sox and a pitching coach with the Cleveland Indians, signed a contract yesterday to serve as a coaching scout and trouble-shooter with the New York Mets of the National League.

WALTER LIPPMANN, columnist for The New York Herald Tribune, returned to "C.B.S. Reports" last night for the second of his lucid conversations with Howard K. Smith. As in the case of his television premiere a year ago, his appearance afforded one of the home medium's more provocative and informative hours in the realm of political commentary.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- -- Significant modifications by Congress in the scope and form of the foreign aid program requested by President Kennedy were forecast today by one of its stanchest Senate supporters.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 (AP) -- Willie McCovey smashed a two-run homer that highlighted a nine-hit San Francisco attack today as Mike McCormick of the Giants gained a 6-3 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.
WASIHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) -- A television producer testified today he had been told by two networks to get more sex and violence into his shows.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 7 points up to 4 points off yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

Further price cuts, this time in wire rope, copper futures and kraft linerboard, upset the stock market yesterday afternoon. There was a general but rather gentle decline and an estimate of a 3 per cent increase in May for industrial production -- confirmed after the close -- had no retarding effect.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Senate approved today an $11,560,000,000 program for completion of the Interstate Highway System. It included a two-year extension of the controversial bonus to states that ban advertising billboards near the new roads.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 15 -- The members of the investigating subcommittee of the 0rganization of American States are believed to be sharply divided in their views on how to deal with the Dominican situation.
Bond dealers advanced their bids yesterday on high-grade corporate bonds and marked down prices on United States Government obligations. The trading session was the most active of the week.

A spectacular waterfront fire poured towering black clouds across midtown Manhattan yesterday afternoon when a New York Central freight-car storage pier burned at the foot of Seven tieth Street and the Hudson River.
The naming of Charles O. Finley as the 1961 National Christmas Seal Campaign chairman was announced yesterday by the National Tuberculosis Association.
BIRMINGHAM, Mich., June 15 -- Just as the course seemed to have the upper hand, par was broken in the United States Open golf championship as first-round play neared completion today.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) -- Republican Congressional leaders urged the Administration today to tighten its belt as an example of sacrifices demanded by President Kennedy.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., June 15 -- Joseph A. McBride and Chester Sanok, both three-time champions, were among the survivors of the first two rounds of the sixtieth annual New Jersey State amateur golf tournament today.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) -- Richard M. Nixon and his family made a poignant departure from Washington today.
TURNBERRY, Scotland, June 15 (AP) -- Ralph Morrow, an Air Force private from Oklahome City, won two matches in the British Amateur golf championship today and moved into the quarter-final round.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The Rural Electrification Administration announced today a loan of $60,225,000 to provide power for sixteen cooperatives distributing electricity in southern Indiana.
OSSINING, N.Y., June 15 -- About twenty feet of snow is still left from last winter in a gulch near here and the townsfolk do not know what to do about it.

Twenty Brooklyn mothers were arrested on disorderly conduct charges yesterday after they had refused to end a demonstration for a traffic light at a street crossing where a child was killed last November.
Several weeks ago you ran an article on the various entrances to Central Park and the possibility of individuals endowing some entrances and giving names to them.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The United States indicated today that it was not satisfied with the length or the thoroughness of an investigation of conditions in the Dominican Republic made by a subcommittee of the Organization of American States.
NEW DELHI, India, June 15 -- The power of the fast as a political weapon is being demonstrated in India again.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals restricted today the Army and Navy's issuance of less-than-honorable discharges to inactive reservists unless they were given at least the right to confront accusers.
ARMONK VILLAGE, N.Y., June 15 -- The proposed merger of the Armonk, Bear Ridge and Middle Patent school districts was approved tonight in a referendum. The vote was 1,404 to 257.

Yeshiva University awarded 441 degrees and diplomas yesterday at its thirtieth annual commencement. About 2,000 graduates and guests attended the outdoor ceremony on the Danciger Campus, 184th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 15 -- When Adios Butler steps out at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night in the $25,000 Summer Festival Pace, the crowd will not be looking so much for a victory -- he is the 3 -- 5 choice for that -- but for a new record.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, was found guilty today of criminal contempt ofCongress for having refused to give confidential records of the authority to a House subcommittee.
OMAHA, June 15 (AP) -- Jim Withers pitched Southern California to its third National Collegiate baseball title tonight, beating Oklahoma State, 1 -- 0, on a four-hitter.
Thirty of this city's public housing developments will be used as depots for the distribution of free food to 100,000 needy families.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy rejoined the President tonight after a week's vacation in Greece.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 15 -- Consumer are increasing their demands for mortgage and installment credit, but business is throughout New York State still trimming its bank debt, a state-wide panel of bankers attending the annual convention of the New York State Bankers Association said today.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- There is an odd distortion in Premier Khrushchev's report today on his Vienna talks with President Kennedy.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange is transferring the stock of the international Rectifier Corporation on Monday from its present specialists to others who are still unnamed, for violating the exchange's rules regarding stock options.
The National Association of Broadcasters has amended its television code whereby commercial time will be reduced on some programs and expanded on others.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Following are excerpts from Federal Judge Luther W. Youngdahl's opinion today convicting Austin J. Tobin of criminal contempt of Congress:
BARCELONA, Spain, June 15 -- Anthony J. Drexel Biddle, the United States Ambassador to Spain, said tonight that the United States would continue to help Spain play a "major role" internationally.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The representatives of the Tractors for Freedom Committee returned tonight to report Premier Fidel Castro's stiff demands for exchanging prisoners captured in the April 17 landings.

BECKENHAM, England, June 15 (AP) -- Two Australian girls defeated United States stars in the Kent tennis championships today and reopened Australia's claims to be included in Wightman Cup competition.
DETROIT, June 15 -- The average selling rate for new passenger cars slowed down the first ten days of June, after a booming final period in May.
NEWARK, June 14 (AP) -- The Robert Treat Hotel here has announced plans for a fourteen-story addition costing $6,000,000.

MOSCOW, June 15 -- Premier Khrushchev emphasized today that the Soviet Union intended to push for the conclusion of a German peace treaty this year, -- if not by East-West agreement with both German states, then unilaterally with Communist East Germany.
PARIS, June 15 -- France extended today her unilateral cease-fire in Algeria for an indefinite period despite her suspension of peace talks with the Moslem rebels.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The House of Representatives, with more Democrats than Republicans helping, killed today President Kennedy's plan to reorganize the Federal Communications Commission.
TOPEKA, Kan., June 15 (AP) -- Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., has been suspended indefinitely from doing business in Kansas for sending magazines to liquor wholesalers in the state.
Trans World Airlines yesterday became the second United States international carrier to accuse K.L.M. Royal Dutch Airlines of violating the Netherlands' air transport agreement with this country.
RICHMOND, Va., June 15 (AP) -- Public school buildings in Prince Edward County may be opened for the first time in two years if a school board offer is accepted by a Negro teacher group.
BONN, Germany, June 15 -- The West German Government sharply rejected today Senator Mike Mansfield's proposals for a compromise solution of the Berlin problem.

The A.F.L.-C.I.O. construction unions in Pittsburgh have made a significant contribution to cutting home building costs for middle-income families. They have agreed to allow contractors full freedom to use prefabricated equipment and other labor-saving devices in erecting a small-homes project for families in the $5,000 to $8,000 bracket.
A seamen's strike that threatened to paralyze the country's merchant marine on three coasts began at midnight last night.

LONDON, June 15 -- Members of the House of Commons pleaded in vain today for a posthumous pardon for Timothy John Evans, a truck driver who was hanged in March, 1950, for the murder of his infant daughter Caroline.
Eleanor Powell has Broadway at her feet once again.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) -- The State Department said today that the United States "opposes" the Soviet proposal to incorporate the stalemated nuclear test-ban talks in the general East-West disarmament negotiation that are tentatively scheduled to begin July 31.
A will that retired General Sessions judge and a lawyer allegedly signed as witnesses after it had been admitted to court was voided yesterday.
Tammany Hall laid plans yesterday for an attempt to purge the three Manhattan Councilmen who sided with Mayor Wagner against Carmine G. De Sapio in the election of a Borough President last winter.

The League of New York Theatres has requested that four theatrical craft unions extend for a year their existing contracts, scheduled to expire soon, to help the current financial plight of the theatre.

PARCHMAN, Miss., June 15 (UPI) -- Forty-five Freedom Riders were transferred from Jackson to the Mississippi State Prison today. But Gov. Ross Barnett, in an appearance at the prison, directed that they not be put to work in the fields as other prisoners are.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The pattern of freight loadings last week was substantially higher than the preceding holiday week but virtually unchanged from year-ago levels, the railroad and truck industries reported today.
MONTREAL, June 15 (UPI) -- A second-half goal by Ademir da Guia gave Bangu of Brazil a 1-0 victory over Montreal Concordia tonight at Molson Stadium in an International Soccer League game.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Administration sources said today that President Kennedy had decided to designate Joseph C. Swidler as chairman of the Federal Power Commission.

LONDON, June 16 -- The American musical "Bye Bye Birdie" opened in London last night at Her Majesty's Theatre to a tumultuous reception from the audience. The newspaper critics were more restrained, but by and large, they liked it.
Evenings-by-the-River, the series of free summer concerts sponsored by the Lower Eastside Neighborhoods Associations (LENA), will begin on July 11, for the seventh consecutive season.

Mr. Khrushchev is still interested in stopping hostilities in Laos and establishing the kingdom as an independent, neutral state, "not a tool in the hands of military blocs," and free of outside interference in its domestic affairs. This, at least, is what he told the Russian public on television in reporting on his talks in Vienna with President Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- George P. Larrick, Commissioner of Food and Drugs, warned the nation's druggists today that physicians' samples of potentially dangerous prescription drugs were being mixed and mislabeled by repackers.
A former French airline stewardess was sentenced here yesterday to ten years in prison for trying to smuggle $500,000 in heroin into the country.
Prices and trading volume in the over-the-counter market decreased yesterday.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 16 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Forest Hill Field Club won the fifty-eighth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship over the 5,861-yard Montclair Golf Club course today.
PARIS, June 16 -- A principal male dancer of the Kirov Opera ballet group of Leningrad sought asylum in France today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 16 -- President Janio Quadros' firm policies won a victory today over Leftist-led student strikers in Recife.

I am surprised that the editorial writers of The New York Times could have erred so strikingly in concluding that responsibility (issue June 13) for the condition of the schools in this city rests upon the Mayor. That conclusion is squarely contrary to statutory and case law.

Two men clung for their lives yesterday to a scaffold that slipped to a 45-degree angle after swinging wildly at the twenty-first floor of a West Fifty-seventh Street building. They were rescued after ten minutes.

CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- A late rally left the grain futures market with a few gains on the Board of Trade today after it had been under steady selling pressure for all but a few minutes of the session.

Bankers acceptances -- credit instruments used by foreign traders and domestic corporations -- have been rising in volume for a year. Yesterday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported a decline, with the May 31 volume down $50,624,000, to $2,203,000,000.
GENEVA, June 16 -- "Is it the Bardot?" asked a Swiss of middle years gesturing toward the crowd. Told by a passing American that it was, he said: "Please excuse me, I am going to telephone Papa."
Newsprint production in Canada and the United States rose to record levels last month, while consumption in this country declined, it was reported yesterday.
THE revived interest in early twentieth-century American painters has brought a good many of their lesser efforts into the market.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The proposal to exchange tractors for Cuban prisoners appeared today to be endangered by a substantial difference between the demands of Premier Fidel Castro and the offer of the tractors for freedom committee.
The Bohemia Stable's Kelso, the horse of the year for 1960 and the winner of his two starts this season, will tackle seven rivals today in the Whitney Stakes at Belmont Park.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 16 -- Adlai E. Stevenson left Bolivia by air for Peru today with the impression that President Victor Paz Estenssoro's Government was showing some strength in a time of trial.

THIS deal, played at the Mayfair Bridge Club by Samuel Mitchell, who held the South hand, was reported chiefly because of the bidding. But a problem that developed in the play is more interesting and is entitled to some attention from students of the game.
DARIEN, Conn., June 16 -- Flying Curlew, owned by Mrs. Henry D. Paxson of Holicong, Pa., won four ribbons today at the thirty-second annual Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse Show.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 16 -- Four of his seven rivals challenged Adios Butler strongly at different stages of the $25,000 Summer Festival Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

Legislation to provide Federal aid to the public schools has run into two related, critical obstacles. The first is the attempt within the House Rules Committee to hold up the measure until after a second bill, providing aid for parochial schools, is also ready for floor action. The second obstacle is that second bill itself, the revised National Defense Education Act.
Dr. Robert A. Soblen was ordered yesterday to go on trial Monday on wartime espionage charges, a crime for which the maximum punishment is death.
The city's Fair Housing Practices Law was broadened yesterday so that it now bans discrimination in 95 per cent of all private housing in the city.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 4 -- The Yugoslavs are having trouble with their unorthodox economic machinery. People are spending too much and not producing enough.
Frank Kern's June 9 comments on your timely editorial of June 2 "Last Call in Iran" was, to say the least, an ill-conceived apology for Iran's corrupt-ridden military regime.

The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will hold its ninth annual San Juan Festival tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. in Downing Stadium on Randalls Island. St. John the Baptist is the patron saint of Puerto Rico.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 16 -- Freedom, the eighty-eight-foot Naval Academy schooner that had been alone in a special class for the 468-mile race to Newport that begins tomorrow, gained an opponent today. The rival is the fifty-six-foot Felucca, also schooner-rigged, also old and owned by Henry Whitney of Washington.

SOME pleasant surprises are in store for shoppers who think that hostess gifts, like bathing suits, mysteriously disappear off the shelves of stores before summer sets in. At Henrietta Tischler, 837 Madison Avenue, an Italian pitcher is available that is both refreshing to look upon and inexpensive.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 16 -- Massachusetts Institute of Technology achieved its eleventh Morss Trophy victory in twenty-five years today. The prize represents the North American intercollegiate dinghy sailing championship.
The Industrial Real Estate Brokers Association of New York has elected Burnett W. Straus as president. He succeeds Henry Gilligan of Brooklyn.

SPOLETO, Italy, June 16 (AP) -- The Italian press today hailed the Italian premiere of the Samuel Barber opera "Vanessa," presented here last night as the opening work at Spoleto's fourth Festival of Two Worlds.

BECKENHAM, England, June 16 (UPI) -- Jon Douglas, a former Stanford University quarterback from Santa Monica, Calif., powered his way into the final round of the Kent lawn tennis championships today with a 6-4, 7-5 triumph over Warren Jacques of Australia.

LONDON, June 16 -- British Government securities and industrial shares fell sharply in the stock market today. A combination of selling and marking down lopped shillings off the prices of most leaders.

THE fashion ladies were like ants trapped in their hill as they rushed about on stacked leather heels, talking about who was going to wear what. "Everything would be a lot easier if we could have quiet," said their leader, attempting to get everyone's attention. "Could we have; quiet?"
A subsidiary of the same company that will supply 5,000 "vandal-proof" parking meters for testing here beginning next month submitted the low bid yesterday for repairing present meters.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 16 -- The joy in the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre's "As You Like It," which was unveiled last night, is in its laughter, its "humorous sadness" and its evocation of an idyllic forest inhabited by warm-blooded men and women.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 16 -- George A. Newbury, the new president of the New York State Bankers Association, entered banking through a law office. Mr. Newbury had practiced law almost thirty years before he was hired by the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company, Buffalo, the second largest bank in that city.
The twenty-story office building at 40 Exchange Place, on the southwest corner of William Street, has been sold for $4,272,000, subject to a new mortgage of $2,000,000, to the Tenney Corporation.

The first sale of tax-exempt-interest bonds by the New York State Housing Finance Agency will take place on July 12, according to an announcement yesterday by James William Gaynor, the agency's chairman.

The directors of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) have authorized a loan equivalent to $25,000,000 to Mifalei Yam Hamelah B.M. (Dead Sea Works Ltd.) of Beersheba, Israel.
ST. LOUIS, June 16 -- A walkout by employes forced the St. Louis Zoo to close all its buildings today.
DETROIT, June 16 -- The Yankees' brief tenure at the top of the American League closed with a loud bang tonight before a roaring crowd of 51,774 Detroit fans.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., June 16 -- Joseph A. McBride of Arcola and Lloyd Monroe of Upper Montclair, two former winners, reached the semi-final round today in the sixtieth annual New Jersey amateur golf championship at the Forest Hill Field Club.
BOSTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox scored eight runs in the fourth inning tonight and defeated the Washington Senators, 14 -- 9, in a 3-hour-44-minute game.
Should a dinner guest do anything to reflect on her hostess -- for example, warn her that her hand is greasy and she is in danger of dropping a carving knife?

Oil wells in Texas must continue to operate on an eight-day producing schedule in July, the Texas Railroad Commission ordered yesterday. Allowable production was set at 2,629,959 barrels a day, 47,901 below the June level.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- A Democratic Senator charged today that the rules of the Senate were "stacked against the people." A Republican Senator said the rules invited wasteful "backdoor" spending.
GENEVA, June 16 -- The Soviet Union refused today to approve a Western proposal to supply six aircraft to the International Control Commission in Laos.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Federal Reserve Board has granted the request of the Marine Midland Trust Company of southern New York, Elmira, to reconsider its application to acquire the First National Bank of Ithaca, N.Y.

LONDON, June 16 (AP) -- Italy's Davis Cup team ran into heavy going and had to settle for a 1-1 tie today in the opening singles matches of the European zone quarter-final tennis match with West Germany.

CHILDREN under 6 give us human behavior on a silver platter, sometimes an overwhelming dose of it. This is the belief of Dr. James L. Hymes, Jr., Chairman of the Department of Childhood Education at the University of Maryland and a past president of the National Association of Nursery Education.

CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- Excellent relief pitching by Pedro Ramos and the timely hitting of Jim Lemon and Bob Allison helped the Minnesota Twins snap the Chicago White Sox seven-game winning streak, 6 -- 1, tonight.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 16 -- The Misses Carole Denham Ferris and Lissa Truebner made their debuts here tonight at a dinner dance given jointly by their parents, Mr. and Mrs. George F. Ferris of New York and Stamford, and Mr. and Mrs. Louis H. Truebner of this city.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) -- The airline business, both domestic and foreign, is in deep trouble so far this year because of rising costs and declining traffic, two re ports said today. The twelve domestic trunk lines had a combined net operating loss of $15,957,727 in the first four months of 1961, the largest deficit for any such period since 1947, the Air Transport Association reported.

Jomo Kenyatta, the African leader, and his connection with the Mau Mau crisis in Kenya are discussed in a book scheduled for August publication by Doubleday. The volume, called "Jomo Kenyatta: Toward Truth About the 'Light of Kenya'," has been written by George Delf, a London newspaper man who has been a resident in Kenya and knew friends and the family of Kenyatta.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Senator Clair Engle, Democrat of California, Chairman of the Senate Merchant Marine subcommittee, recommended today temporary extension of a law permitting steamship conferences and dual rates.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Dr. Dirk U. Stikker, the new Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, charged today that Premier Khrushchev was deliberately increasing world tension.
PARIS, June 16 -- Farmers in Brittany clashed with security troops today for the first time in their current protests against the lack of Government help to maintain agricultural prices.

RYE, N.Y., June 16 -- Thomas Edlefsen of Mercersburg Academy captured the singles title sad Lawrenceville retired the team trophy at the thirtieth Manursing Island Club Eastern interscholastic tennis tournament today.
A collective bargaining referendum for teachers that was scheduled to start yesterday will not begin until Tuesday because of a delay in preparing the ballots.
Sales of the nation's major retail chains last month rose by 4.9 per cent from those of May, 1960. Volume for the first five months of 1961 was 2 per cent higher than in the 1960 period.
" I DID not feel any disposition to upbraid them for their sins," a rare missionary wrote in his journal, "but merely endeavored affectionately to show them that they are unfit for Heaven."
LONDON, June 16 (AP) -- Robert Gerle, violinist, of New York made his debut here last night and was hailed as "unquestionably one of the great players of our time."
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- John Wicklein of The New York Times is the winner of the sixth annual Faith and Freedom Award of the Religious Heritage of America.

When throngs of women are spotted scurrying through the Waldorf Astoria Hotel at 9 o'clock in the morning, dressed in their fashionable best, it is a sure sign that the Fashion Group is about to present one of its massive productions summing up current trends in the American designer collections.

BRISTOL, England, June 16 (UPI) -- Charles (Chuck) McKinley of St. Louis and Bob Mark of Australia advanced to the final round of the men's singles in the West of England lawn tennis championships today with victories over fellow countrymen.
CHICAGO, June 16 -- The Earl of Home, British Foreign Secretary, said today that Britain and the United States should encourage all efforts to achieve freedom through international cooperation.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Members of the House Science and Astronautics Committee agreed today that the National Science Foundation Act had to be changed to prevent cases like that of Edward Yellin.
KANSAS CITY, June 16 (AP) -- Lew Krausse, the Kansas City Athletics' $125,000 bonus pitcher, made a sensational debut tonight; shutting out the Los Angeles Angels on three hits, 4 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The State Department said today the representatives of twelve state governors met today to find means to assure "friendly and dignified treatment" for representatives of foreign countries traveling in the United States.
Yankee Stadium will be in good hands next week while the ball club is on the road.
MONTREAL, June 16 -- The Canadian dollar, fighting a losing battle, found itself at par today with its United States counterpart for the first time in five years.
Missile and space flights will burn up 35,000,000 pounds of fine aluminum powder a year by 1965, Edward F. Reilly, market manager of Reynolds Metals Company, said yesterday.

Thursday's upturn in prices of prime-risk corporate bonds was carried further yesterday. The over-the-counter market in the corporate debt investments was kept humming all day with the most active business in weeks.
The Rockefeller Institute, the nation's only exclusively graduate university, conferred ten Doctor of Philosophy degrees at exercises here yesterday.

THE language of diplomacy is not reserved for politics. It meets one of its greater tests in the fragile relationship between a hairdresser and his client. Communication of ideas is the problem. Through pictures, words or gesturing hands, the two minds must somehow come to a satisfactory understanding.
PITTSBURGH, June 16 (UPI) -- The Pirates, who blazed a bonus trail eleven years ago when they paid $100,000 to a California prospect, turned again to that state today for an even costlier young star.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 16 -- Liberia, the oldest of the African republics, has been moving quietly but steadily into a modern "iron age" that has already acquired a golden tinge.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Kennedy announced today that he had selected Robert F. Woodward, Ambassador to Chile, to be Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs.
Three local revival programs that should be of particular interest to the motion picture connoisseur have been announced.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Air Force awarded $200,000,000 in contracts today, chiefly for missiles and radar work.
A Hempstead, L.I., businessman was sentenced yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to an eighteen-month term for conspiring to smuggle Chinese aliens into the country.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 16 (AP) -- Ten hunger-striking Freedom Riders refused to obey a police order to disperse at the Tallahassee airport today and submitted quietly to arrest. Three others scuffled with two white men at the Ocala, Fla., bus station and were also taken to jail.
Two governmental agencies continued their investigations yesterday into the causes of last Tuesday's four-and-a-haft-hour power failure in mid-Manhattan.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 16 (AP) -- North Carolina clinched the team title today in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis tournament and Virginia won the doubles crown. Virginia ended its tourney play, trailing North Carolina, 23 -- 22, in points.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 5 to 37 points yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

Major steel makers have reduced the West Coast price of hard-drawn wire by $10 a ton. The price cut, put into effect about a month ago, was confirmed yesterday by the United States Steel Corporation and Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

Directors of the Ansul Chemical Company voted a 50 per cent stock split to become effective July 3 for stockholders of record at the close of business on that date. The board met in Marinette, Wis., on Thursday after a special meeting of stockholders.

GENEVA, June 16 -- David Ormsby-Gore, Britain's disarmament negotiator and Ambassador-designate to Washington, flew here today from London to deliver a stinging attack on the Soviet Union at he nuclear test-ban talks.

The United States, the North Atlantic allies and the whole world are now confronted with the grim fact that Premier Khrushchev has reinstated the six-month time limit in his 1958 ultimatum on Germany and Berlin, and threatens an atomic war unless the Western powers bow to it.
CLEVELAND, June 16 (AP) -- Dick Stigman and Barry Latman pitched the Cleveland Indians to a 3-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight in the opener of a four-game series.
EAST MORICHES, L.I., June 16 -- An 18-year-old high school student has found a way to combine sport and business. He traps muskrats and sells the skins with an assist from the family freezer.

A bomb, apparently thrown from a passing car, exploded last night in a narrow Greenwich Village street. A pedestrian was injured slightly and an eight-inch hole was blown in the trunk of a parked car.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The index of primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent to 118.8 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
POZNAN, June 15 -- The Poznan trade fair, Poland's commercial window on the world, has completed this year a gradual transition from a propaganda show window to a business man's market.
A delegation representing the Taxi Council of Independent Owners told Mayor Wagner at City Hall yesterday that it would "like his help" in getting a general taxicab fare increase.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) -- The United States confirmed today agreements to send additional and more direct aid to the pro-Western Government of South Vietnam, which is battling Communist guerrillas.

OSLO, Norway, June 16 (AP) -- Kenneth L. Pendergras of1 Jacksonville, Fla., and Carlos Plaza of Caracas, Venezuela, are leading in the world skeet-shooting championship with perfect scores at the halfway mark.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Earlier this year, Eduardo V. Haedo, President of Uruguay, wrote to the State Department praising the outgoing United States Ambassador. He said that he had seen many able American diplomats in his country, but that none "has succeeded so well in defending the position of the United States while at the same time evidencing a deep comprehension of the people and problems of the Republic of Uruguay."

The office of Chief City Magistrate Abraham M. Bloch mailed 150 letters to scofflaw motorists yesterday warning them that if they did not answer their summonses within ten days their drivers' licenses would be suspended.

Aggregate market values on the New York Stock Exchange fell about three-quarters of 1 per cent yesterday but volume failed to rise significantly and the mood of the market was more bored than disturbed.
ALBANY, June 16 -- Governor Rockefeller was host tonight to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and accompanied the Negro leader to two local fund-raising meetings.

CAMBRIDGE, England, June 16 (Reuters) -- The world's fastest miler, Herb Elliott of Australia, today turned down a challenge from a San Franciscan for a four-day test of physical prowess to determine whether Americans are "soft."

Because of the "blind attitude" of New Jersey officials on "blocking" a reorganization plan for the bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad, Federal Judge Archie O. Dawson suggested a fare increase yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 16 -- Rowing buffs studied a variety of unreliable omens today in efforts to divine the probable design of finishes in the title regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President and Mrs. Kennedy flew to their near-by Virginia retreat late today hopeful that another quiet week-end would get the President off his crutches and back in full stride.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, June 16 Reuters) -- South Africa imposed new controls today to restrict the outflow of capital and block drains on its foreign exchange.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Kennedy urged the nation today to fight expanding communism by supporting his $8,800,000,000 foreign-aid program and by helping to stamp out the conditions on which communism thrives.

TURNBERRY, Scotland, June 16 (AP) -- Ralph Morrow, an unheralded Oklahoma City airman, was beaten today in the semi-finals of the British amateur golf tournament by Jimmy Walker, a 40-year-old Scot, who also whipped Joe Carr, the defending champion from Ireland.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- A representative of the writers declared today that they did not like crime and violence on television, but had to provide them on order.
HAVANA, June 16 -- Fidel Castro put his foot on the rusting wreckage of a rebel B-26 bomber on Playa Giron and motioned his guests to come closer.

DETROIT, June 16 (AP) -- A stockholder's suit charging officers and directors of the Briggs Manufacturing Company with irregularities in the purchase of 148,000 shares of Briggs stock was dismissed today in United States District Court.
DETROIT, June 16 -- Bishop Marshall R. Reed, head of the Methodist Church in Michigan, has announced the first appointment of a Negro minister as an associate pastor in a white Methodist church here.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- A former Congressional employe was sentenced to one to three years in prison today for defrauding the Government of $14,000 by padding payrolls of the office he supervised.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 -- The Northern California Pharmaceutical Association was found guilty in Federal Court here today of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act by conspiring to fix the retail price of drugs.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 16 -- On the eve of The Race, Harvey Love, the graying saltwater philosopher who coaches Harvard's crew, discoursed tonight on the part that emotions, past performances, strokesmanship, coxwainship and capricious winds and tides could play in tomorrow's four-mile rowing match between Yale and Harvard.
PHILADELPHIA, June 16 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds scored all their runs in an eighth-inning rally tonight and beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 4 -- 1.

PARIS, June 16 -- The "basic" deficit in the United States balance of international payments last year was only $860,000,000, a new official analysis concluded today. The balance of payments is the difference between a nation's total payments to foreigners and total receipts from foreigners.
VIENNA, June 16 (AP) -- Lauren Bacall and Jason Robards Jr., American stage and screen stars, left here today after they were unable to obtain a marriage license.
The last time that the Canadian dollar was exactly equal in value to the United States dollar was in 1956.
LIMA, Peru, June 16 -- The police used tear gas tonight to disperse students who gathered outside the University of San Marcos as Adlai E. Stevenson conferred with Peruvian officials here.
Copper futures on the New York Commodity Exchanges fell to new lows for the move in active trading yesterday.

Fat people have been objects of ridicule far too long as have "drunkards." But as the medical profession has discovered, and the public is beginning to understand, obesity and alcoholism are illnesses deserving treatment, not derision.

AT this hot and humid time of year, most shoppers search grocery shelves for food products that are quick and easy to prepare. Among the new offerings that fit well into that category is Village Inn herb rice, seven ounces of skillfully seasoned grains in a cellophane packet.

LONDON, June 16 -- The pound sterling slumped in the foreign exchange market today, losing three-eighths of a cent against the United States dollar, at $2.78 4/16. It also fell in terms of Continental currencies.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 16 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits proposed today that the technical and managerial resources of private industry be tapped to step up economic aid to developing countries.
Final equalization rates announced in Albany yesterday gave the city a substantial increase in its capacity to tax real estate and borrow for capital improvements.
Fortune and Anthony Pope were snubbed during the visit here by Premier Amintore Fanfani of Italy.
Sydenham Hospital, 123d Street and Manhattan Avenue, will continue as a general hospital for at least a year, Dr. Ray E. Trussell, Commissioner of Hospitals, announced yesterday.

LONDON, June 16 -- During four centuries British world influence has in the end derived from successful application of a foreign policy which balanced off great powers against each other. That technique, supported by differing coalitions, allowed an island kingdom with a small army and a relatively small population to speak with a large voice.
Premier Amintore Fanfani of Italy expressed "prudently constructive optimism" regarding the world situation before ending a five-day official visit to the United States yesterday.

LONDON, June 16 -- Mme. Olga Ivinskaya, friend and collaborator of the late author Boris Pasternak, and her daughter Mlle. Irina Ivinskaya, are seriously ill in a prison hospital at Potma in European Russia, about 300 miles from Moscow, an informant said tonight.

FLORAL PARK, L.I., June 16 -- A two-year experimental program to shorten the conventional seven-week summer high school program by two weeks has proved a success, officials of Sewanhaka Central High School District 2 said today.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 16 -- Maj. Gen. Joseph D. Mobutu had forty of his soldiers arrested today on charges that they were involved in a plot to have him and other Congolese leaders "either poisoned or kidnapped."

Alexander Hamilton Institute, Inc., executive training concern, has leased a major part of the fourth floor in the Pfizer Building at 235 East Forty-second Street. The institute has been at 71 West Twenty-third Street for the last twenty years.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 16 -- A brother of Maj. Gen. Jose Rene Roman Fernandez shot himself dead in his home here last night when military security agents arrived to question him about the May 30 assassination of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 16 -- The Congolese parliament is expected to be called into session in Leopoldville in the last week of this month, United Nations sources said today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 16 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold announced today the appointment of ten experts to consider "the national economic and social consequences of disarmament."

ATHENS, June 16 -- Atlantic Alliance commands throughout Europe have been warned by the Turkish Government that a squadron of three Soviet destroyers is scheduled to enter the Mediterranean from the Black Sea tonight or tomorrow, the Athens newspaper Ethnos reported today. The report was laid to "responsible Allied sources."

The Queens District Attorney indicated yesterday that two or three school construction inspectors faced possible arrest next week in his investigation of irregularities in the school building program.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- An engine that was said to represent a major advance in solid-fuel rocketry was patented this week for the Thiokol Chemical Corporation. It reportedly has been incorporated in most solid-propellant American missiles.

LOS ANGELES, June 16 (AP) -- Lew Burdette scored his ninth straight victory at the Coliseum tonight as the Milwaukee Braves defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 2 -- 1. The right-hander hurled a five-hitter and contributed a second-inning homer.
The paralyzing effect of the seamen's strike spread slowly along the nation's coasts yesterday.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 16 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan said in effect today that Nationalist China would veto the admission of Outer Mongolia to the United Nations if necessary to keep her out.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Three House subcommittees, sitting jointly, approved today a program of long-term Federal loans for construction of parochial and other private school buildings.

The Temporary State Rent Commission moved yesterday to contest a recent Supreme Court decision making a $42,000 commission rent increase retroactive. Affected by the increase were the tenants in the Armstrong Hotel at 202 West 103d Street.
PHILADELPHIA, June 16 -- Two meet records were broken today as the fortieth annual National Collegiate track and field championships got under way in bright, warm weather at Franklin Field.

President Kennedy's persuasive address yesterday did much to supply needed perspective in the current national debate over his foreign aid program. He struck at the heart of the problem when he pointed out that today freedom "is endangered all around the globe less by massive armies than by massive poverty and discontent."
WESTMINSTER, Md., June 16 (AP) -- Some 125,000 Negro Methodists along the nation's Eastern seaboard were invited today to become part of a church conference now composed only of white persons.
A 100-foot-long steel girder was slipped into place yesterday and the construction of the superstructure of the Alexander Hamilton Bridge was under way.

Another active week is ahead in the market for new capital. Major fixed-interest securities issues amounting to $245,350,000 are slated for public offering, of which $117,850,000 are to be offered competitively, the rest through investment managers chosen by the companies.
An eleven-story motor hotel will be constructed at Thomas Circle in Washington, D.C., four blocks north of the White House. It will be called the International Inn and will have 352 rooms.
The seamen's strike begins -- result of too little bargaining in good faith, too much inter-union rivalry and too heavy internal stresses within the ranks of organized management.

PITTSBURGH, June 16 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals broke up a pitching duel with a three-run seventh inning tonight and beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5 -- 2. The runs were scored when Tim McCarver and Bob Gibson hit consecutive bases-filled singles and Bob Lillis reached first on a fielder's choice.

MIAMI, June 16 -- A United States District Court judge ruled here today that Maj. Gen. Marcos Perez Jimenez, former dictator of Venezuela, is to be returned to his homeland to face trial for embezzlement.

TRENTON, June 16 -- Clams harvested in New Jersey and now on the market in the state are of approved quality and may be consumed in a raw or cooked state with confidence, Dr. Roscoe P. Kandle said today.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Justice Department has recommended an indefinite continuation of the controversial Civil Rights Commission.

BIRMINGHAM, Mich., June 16 -- Par took a beating today as Doug Sanders and Bob Rosburg tied for the lead in the second round of the United States Open golf championship. Each scored a 67 over the Oakland Hills Country Club course for a thirty-six-hole aggregate of 139.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 16 -- A Czechoslovak diplomat charged today that United States intelligence agents tried to hire him as a spy over a smorgasbord lunch eon Tuesday and arranged for his expulsion when he refused.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Gov. John Patterson of Alabama has warned the Alabama State Highway Patrol that any state trooper who cooperates with an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation will be dismissed.

" A concerted drive to reduce expenses" enabled the Caterpillar Tractor Company to report an increase of 32 per cent in earnings in the first five months this year. This was accomplished in the face of a 6.4 per cent drop in sales from the 1960 level, according to the report issued yesterday.
The Federal Court House in Foley Square will house a backstage, off-camera television spectacular starting next Tuesday.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 16 (AP) -- The twenty-fifth rocket in the Discoverer satellite series went into polar orbit tonight, one hour and 45 minutes after blasting into space.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs collected twelve hits, including Billy Williams' grand-slam homer, to rout the San Francisco Giants, 12 -- 6, tonight.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 16 -- The Sittin' Starin' 'n' Rockin' Club, a world organization of 2,648 rocking chair fans, hopes soon to be able to enroll a most distinguished member. His name is John Fitzgerald Kennedy.

BERLIN, June 16 (UPI) -- Mayor Willy Brandt called on West Berliners today to attend a rally at the City Hall tomorrow to show Premier Khrushchev and the world that they are not afraid of his threats.

CEDARHURST, L.I., June 17 -- All four seeded teams reached the semi-finals of the Eastern Father-Son grass-courts tennis championship at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., June 17 (AP) -- The Netherlands All-Stars ended their United States baseball tour today with their eighth straight loss.

The cost of haircuts in union barbershops in the Times Square area has been increased to as much as $2, a survey showed yesterday.

The yield of industrial stocks has been below that of AAA corporation bonds for fourteen consecutive quarters and for sixteen of the last eighteen quarters. Yet the bottom has not dropped out of the stock market.

Today, twenty years later, we still feel its effects; and we shall long continue to feel them -- though they were not the effects intended. For on that day Hitler hurled his hitherto invincible armies against the only other land power which he respected: Russia.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 16 -- The Consensus of San Jose, embodying the resolutions of the continental conference of prominent lawyers from twenty-two American countries who met here this week, was made public today. ONE of our loyal readers wrote in the other day with a simple observation that brought us up relatively short. "Almost six months have gone by in 1961," she wrote, "and not one good original dramatic film from Hollywood has appeared."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 17 -- If the United Nations had an award for swimming or gallantry, it would have gone this week to Carlos Salamanca, an athletic, 6-foot-4 Bolivian delegate.
YONKERS, June 17 -- Three tear-gas bombs exploded in a motion picture theatre here tonight, slightly injuring thirteen persons and forcing the audience to flee into the street.

Retail business was brisk in this area last week. Department store merchants estimated that sales were 5 to 10 per cent above those in 1960. Trade was spurred by purchases for Father's Day and favorable shopping weather.

IN an office on the fourth floor of 145 West Fifty-seventh Street there is a large map of New York State. It is peppered with colored pins. The nineteen red-headed pins are stuck in the communities that will be visited next season by the Buffalo Philharmonic.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 17 -- Erratic shifts in the volume and direction of the trade of mainland China and the Soviet bloc countries in recent years have highlighted the growing general significance of this commerce in the international commodity market.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 17 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has promised the Czechoslovak Government that he will personally investigate its charge that United States agents tried to hire a Czech diplomat for espionage.

MOSCOW, June 17 (AP) -- Pravda denounced newspapers of the United Arab Republic today for conducting an anti-Soviet campaign. It suggested the aim of the campaign was to curry favor with the United States.
The board of directors of the Jewish Agency for Israel, Inc., announced allocations of $39,000,000 last night for immigration and rehabilitation programs in Israel.
Buyers were shopping the fall market last week. Reports from resident buying offices indicated that there was good demand for fur-trimmed costumes and transitional jacket dresses.

PAPEETE, Tahiti -- Success, in the form of jet airplanes and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, has not spoiled Tahiti, it is a pleasure to report from this capital of South Seas romanticism. The jets began landing on the new airstrip here just a few days before this tourist's cruise ship, the Monterey, docked near the full-size replica of Captain Bligh's Bounty.

The top-ranking Federal shipping official here was elected head of the Federal Business Association of New York last week. He is Capt. Hewlett R. Bishop, Atlantic Coast Director of the Maritime Administration.

IT was reported recently that the Tioga Pass road into Yosemite National Park would be improved because the present road was considered to be too hazardous. This is written in defense of untamed, or "bad" roads.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 -- The Ellen Phillips Samuel Memorial, a three-terrace statued story of America, was dedicated and presented to the Fairmount Park Commission today. The presentation was by Philip Price, president of the Fairmount Park Art Association, formed eighty-nine years ago to "promote and foster the beautiful" in Philadelphia.

BECKENHAM, England, Jun 117 (UPI) -- Jon Douglas of Santa Monica, Calif., overcame a sluggish start to win the men's singles crown in the Ken tennis championships today Eighteen-year-old Margaret Smith of Australia upset Christine Truman of Britain for the women's title.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 17 -- The largest Saturday fleet of the Yacht Racing Association season -- 126 boats -- encountered exasperating breezes on Long Island Sound today.
The New York Public Library's outdoor concerts from noon until 2 o'clock this week in Bryant Park will include recorded performances by Renata Tebaldi, Isaac Stern and Dennis Brain.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Stalin proposed at the 1943 Big Three conference in Teheran, Iran, the "physical liquidation" of at least 50,000 and perhaps 100,000 of the German commanding staff, the State Department disclosed today.
CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) -- Juan Pizzaro gained his second consecutive victory today, beating the Minnesota Twins, 5-1.
DARIEN, Conn., June 17 -- The Wizard of Oz and the Hot Shot Kid captured the pony championships of the thirty-second annual Ox Ridge Horse Show today.
CHICAGO, June 17 -- Four Indianapolis business men sought in court today to force Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy to bar private citizens from trading tractors for captive rebels in Cuba.

PORT WASHINGTON, June 17 -- In contrast to last years turmoil, Long Island Sound was a good host to the Huckins predicted log contest today. The race was held in a flat calm on the first half, with gentle winds of 15 knots on the return leg.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., June 17 -- Ch. Sam of Blaircourt, a black Labrador retriever owned by Grace Lambert of Princeton, N.J., won best-in-show honors tonight at the firty-first annual Bryn Mawr Kennel Club event. There were 595 entries.

Seamen and their employers in the two-day maritime strike went back to the bargaining table yesterday on the firm insistence of Federal authorities. The U.S. merchant marine consists of 950 freighters, tankers and passenger vessels owned by about 300 shipping companies which operate out of ports on the East, West and Gulf coasts. They are manned by 50,000 seamen and officers, members of a dozen unions.

Evening hats this summer are true lightweights -- open and airy and not much heavier than an airmail letter. In black, they are darkly mysterious, often dramatic, even a bit romantic. The Rev. Dr. Israel Margolies, rabbi of Beth Am, the Peoples Temple, 71 Thayer Street, yesterday commended the first twenty-seven designates for the Peace Corps as reflecting the high idealism that President Kennedy's plan has generated in American youth.

To concentrate its capabilities in the broad field of propulsion, the Curtis-Wright Corporation has brought several diverse facilities under the administration of its Wright Aeronautical division in Woodridge, N.J.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- John Hope 2d, Negro economist at the Fisk Race Relations Institute, will become director of Federal employment for the President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunities.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- This 300-year-old South Shore town, whose historical celebrations generally are devoted to its first two centuries, has joined countless other areas in commemorating the centennial of the Civil War this summer. At the Historical Museum here, a special Civil War exhibition will be open to the public now through Sept. 15.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 15 -- The old spirit of the kibbutz movement is fading away in Israel.

COLUMBIA, S.C. -- Here in the capital of the first state to secede from the Union are many Civil War landmarks and a wealth of early Americana. Almost all of the sites can be taken in during a leisurely walking tour of the city, starting from the Capitol, or Statehouse, as it is called in South Carolina.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 17 -- Charity balls, horse shows, tennis week and the Fiesta still form the basis of the summer season here.
Borislav Milic of Yugoslavia captured first place in a recent international chess tournament in Madrid. The field of twelve players represented six countries, including the United States.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Judge Learned Hand has written to President Kennedy urging the promotion of Federal District Judge Irving R. Kaufman of New York to the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
CHICAGO, June 17 -- The first of forty new bi-level suburban coaches will be placed in commuter service Monday by the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad (Milwaukee Road).

WESTBURY, L.I., June 17 -- After being held off the lead for seven-eighths of a mile, Merrie Adios, driven by Johnny Patterson, scored by three lengths tonight in the feature pace before 36,603 fans at Roosevelt Raceway.

A PRETTY blonde, Peggy Jacobsen, was crowned Queen of New York City's Summer Festival the other day in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel before 1,200 courtiers, and she is now reigning over the eighth annual summer mardi gras here that will continue over Labor Day.

Why put $2 on the nose when $4 buys a share in more than a dozen noses forever? That's a racy question for horse fans and investors, too. HARTFORD, June 17 -- Each of the 169 cities and towns in Connecticut received this week authority to set up "historic districts" within its borders. Gov. John N. Dempsey signed a bill passed by the General Assembly without argument several weeks ago.

TURNBERRY, Scotland, June 17 (UPI) -- Michael Bonallack, a 26-year-old Englishman, won the British Amateur golf championship today with a 6-and-4 victory over 40-year-old Jimmy Walker of Scotland in the final over the rain-swept Alisa course.

HURLEYVILLE, N.Y., June 17 -- The rumor has spread that Sullivan County's fish population was decimated by last winter's unusually cold weather. This rumor, like the reported death of Mark Twain, however, has been grossly exaggerated.

KEARNY, N.J., June 17 -- George Ball of Woodhaven, Queens, moved into the third round of the New Jersey men's singles tennis championship with a 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5 victory over Herb Charlop of Brooklyn as tournament action opened today at the Arlington Players Club.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Republicans said today that President Kennedy was dealing with the Soviet Union in the same way that President Franklin D. Roosevelt did in World War II. They charged that President Roosevelt had sold out free peoples to the Communists.

The day set aside for father has lent some assistance to retail sales. Gift buying for father generally lags until just before the day itself, and such was the case this year. Men's wear sales perked up toward the end of the week but the rise was attributed more to higher temperatures than to Father's Day.

CALAIS, Me. -- Elsewhere in the world these days, tensions may mount along international boundaries, but life along the United States-Canadian border goes on serenely. There are no military installations on either side of this great transcontinental frontier; the only uniforms visible are those of Customs and Immigration officials, and crossing the border in either direction involves formalities stripped to the bare essentials.

After difficult negotiations at a conference in London, the West Indies Federation that came into being on Jan. 3, 1958, has now agreed on a Constitution and is scheduled to take its place among the free and independent nations of the world as a member of the British Commonwealth on May 31, 1962.

The development of a method of saving time and expense in joining lengths of polyethylene pipe for oil, gas, chemical and electrical conduit lines was announced recently by the Phillips Petroleum Company.

BUFFALO, June 17 -- A joint legislative committee created in 1960 to study the state's liquor laws will hold its first public hearing here Monday afternoon. It will meet in the wake of two rulings by the State Liquor Authority that have drawn widespread criticism.

BIRMINGHAM, Mich., June 17 -- Bobby Jones had a putter that was known as Calamity Jane. It's time that Gene Littler held christening services for his own putter. It's a weapon of the same deadly serviceability and it won the United States Open golf championship for him in the drenching sunlight at formidable Oakland Hills today. Littler is so good that Ben Hogan has been known to follow him just to study his technique.
BERLIN, June 17 -- More than 100,000 Berliners went out into the streets tonight to demonstrate for the city's freedom in the face of new Communist threats.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 17 -- Twelve villages in Nassau County will hold elections on Tuesday, but only one will have a contest.

A bus load of thirty-seven Protestant Episcopal clergymen will leave New Orleans Sept. 12 on a "Prayer Pilgrimage" in support of the Freedom Riders. The trip is designed also to point up racially segregated educational institutions operated by the ministers' church.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn is a man of few words at any time; in a House debate, he is positively sphinx-like, letting his more eloquent lieutenants do the name-calling and finger-pointing. Thus, when the Speaker put aside the gavel and advanced to the well of the House last week, it was an event approximately as unusual as a unanimous Democratic vote.

The latest available figures covering developments in business reveal that not only is New England in a strong and continuing business recovery but that this section is outperforming the country as a whole. Statistics of real trade, unemployment, incoming orders, factory production, and the like, all indicate better current performance in New England than in the whole United States.

LOS ANGELES, June 17 -- Summer vacationers caught up in the annual flurry of packing, stopping the milk delivery, getting the car tuned and parking the pets are in a position to understand just what it is that electronic computers are doing for and to our civilization.

NOT every delightful theatrical experience takes place in a formal theatre. Two evenings that shine cheerfully in this professional theatregoer's recollections of the season had nothing to do with formality or the conventional forums of the drama.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 10 -- No. 2 Vukovarska Street is a big old stuccoed house in a quiet residential section of Belgrade. Its yard has grown wild in paths and patches. The unattractive concrete fence is falling to pieces. A range of garages in the rear houses an automobile repair shop.

GENEVA, June 17 -- Three new violations by Communists of the cease-fire in Laos were reported today by the United States delegation to the fourteen-nation conference on the future of the Asian kingdom.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark, June 17 (AP) -- The Little Rock school board, which made limited high-school integration work here after mob violence and a year of closed schools, faces another test this fall.

After a close-quarters dash through the stretch Joseph Colando's Our Hope crossed the finish line a head in front of the Bohemia Stable's Kelso in the one-and-one-eighth-mile Whitney Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. HAVANA, June 16 -- Behind the velvet rope of the plushly but quietly decorated hotel restaurant where armed soldiers mixed with a crowd of pretty young girls in khaki fatigues and with intense, shirt-sleeved Eastern European intellectuals, Cuba's Premier Fidel Castro sat far into the night conducting a political bull session with a group of highly skeptical visiting United States newspaper men.

TORONTO, June 17 (AP) -- Col. K.R. Marshall's Blue Light won the 102d running of the $71,475 Queen's Plate today in a photo finish with Just Don't Shove. The Queen's Plate, for Canadian-bred 3-year-olds, is the Dominion's most important horse race.

ST. ANTHONY, Idaho -- The primary goal of many visitors here in northern Idaho is Yellowstone National Park, which lies to the northeast and across the border in Wyoming. THE Metropolitan Opera is even more in the red this year than it expected and it is turning to the rank and file of its subscribers for help.
BOLZANO, Italy, June 17 -- For the second night in succession the people of the Alto Adige slept undisturbed by exploding bombs.

SOME seventy-five years ago, two Germans, Gottlieb Daimler and Carl Benz, applied for motorized vehicle patents at the German patent office. The patents were granted on July 3, 1886. Both men were pioneers in the development of the internal combustion motor, whose theoretical principles had been announced with remarkable accuracy in 1862 by a French scientist, Alphonse Beau de Rochas.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., June 17 -- An Israeli Army officer who has spent most of his life in defense of his country toured nearby-Camp Drum this week to inspect the field maneuvers of the Fiftieth Armored Division, National Guard unit from New Jersey.

A plastic shoe last, said to be the first to become available on a commercial scale, has been introduced by the Sterling Last Corporation of Long Island City, Queens.

PARIS, June 17 -- The dispute between France and the Algerian rebels over the future of the Sahara -- a dispute complicated by both economic and propaganda factors -- appears to be the main stumbling block to a resumption of the Algerian peace talks.
ITHACA, N.Y., June 17 (AP) -- The individual American is neither all good nor all bad, in the opinion of foreign students in the United States.

What is called "disruptive squabbling" among rabbis of the three branches of Judaism is frustrating religious growth in the American Jewish Community, according to a prominent layman.
Laurian Cardinal Rugambwa, the first Negro prince of the Roman Catholic Church, was honored in Brooklyn yesterday by Protestants and Catholics.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., June 17 -- Ralph Boston of Tennessee A. and I. surpassed the listed world record in the broad jump tonight with a leap of 27 feet 1/4 inch in the Albuquerque invitation track and field meet.

THE appearance of Shirley Ann Grau's first book, "The black Prince and Other Stories," was a notable event of 1955. LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, June 17 -- Events in Angola, Portugal's West African territory, have caused a bad case of jitters in this East African Portuguese territory.

DENVER, Colo. -- At a cost considerably above that covered by the figure in the name it bears, Colorado's famous Million-Dollar Highway has been repaired along its entire route. Once a challenge to the most daring motorist, the road now can be traveled safely and without apprehension by any careful driver.

BONN, Germany, June 17 -- Today is National Unity Day in West Germany and West Berlin and hundreds of thousands of free Germans are gathering to commemorate the uprising eight years ago of the population of East Germany against Communist rule.

CLEVELAND, June 17 -- Wynn Hawkins blanked Baltimore on one hit in the first five innings today, but the Orioles collected eight hits and four runs in the next three innings to beat the Cleveland Indians, 4-1.

To start a wood screw in a tight spot, try pushing the screw through a piece of adhesive tape first. Push it through with the sticky side up, then insert the screwdriver blade in the screw slot. BIRMINGHAM, Mich., June 18 -- Samuel Jackson Snead had swallowed his disappointment and had become communicative again. For him the United States Open was over, another milestone of failure for the man who is generally considered golfdom's supreme stylist. He sat in front of a television set in the clubhouse at Oakland Hills yesterday afternoon and watched Gene Littler make his finishing bid for the title that Snead never has won.

This group of twenty men, all prominent in the economic community, has given our financial system its most thorough examination in fifty years. STRATFORD, Conn., June 18 -- The accent is on action in the rousing production of "Macbeth" that entered the reportory of the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre Friday night.

McCarthy, formerly associated with the Yale University Center of Alcohol Studies.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 (AP) -- At 1 P.M. today this old joke died: "I went to Philadelphia on Sunday but it was closed." The city had its first legally wet Sunday in 167 years.
