The Black Diamond Lines freighter Black Swan will receive the port's traditional welcome for new vessels this morning on her maiden arrival from Hamburg, Germany. She will dock in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A Senate subcommittee proposed today the creation of an office of science and technology within the White House to strengthen the direction of the nation's scientific efforts.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 (AP) -- Gene Freese, who once played for the Phillies, made seven hits in eight trips to the plate today as the Cincinnati Reds swept a double-header from Philadelphia. The scores were 7 -- 2 and 10 -- 0.

The Rev. John Papandrew preached his farewell sermon yesterday as associate minister of the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-Fifth Street. He will become minister of the Unitarian-Universalist Church of Portsmouth, N.H., Sept. 1.
PARIS, June 18 -- The Government measures announced to aid farmers appeared today to have had little effect in calming tempers in Brittany and elsewhere over falling prices.

According to your editorial of June 9 I delivered a "slashing indictment" about misplaced ideas of democracy. I did not slash and did not indict. I think that picking a few sentences out of their context distorts their meaning, especially if those sentences were part of a discussion of a scientific society.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 18 -- Dr. Arthur Frederick's chestnut mare Betty Sunset, ridden by his son Douglas, won the hunter championship of the Southampton junior horse show today with 13 points.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Following are the votes of the members from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major, roll-calls in Congress during the week ended June 17:
VANDERBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 18 (UPI) -- A 300-pound capsule from the Discoverer XXV satellite was recovered from orbit today in the Pacific near Hawaii.
TOKYO, Monday, June 19 -- Premier Hayato Ikeda left by air today on what is for him a delicate mission to the United States. He was accompanied by his wife and Foreign Minister Zentaro Kosaka.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover said that the Navy was run in a way that would ruin any business unless it had unlimited capital or employed "a damn good forger" to raise the money.
Collective bargaining by itself cannot fully solve the employment problems caused by technological change, a progress report by the Armour Automation Committee concluded yesterday.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa estimated at a record $878,559,000 yesterday the city's general fund revenues for the new fiscal year starting July 1.

The First Federal Savings and Loan Association of New York has purchased 141 home mortgages totaling $574,000 on dwellings built and financed by the Federal Government in Oak Ridge, Tenn., the atomic energy center.

MOSCOW, June 18 (Reuters) -- Valeri Brumel, a 19-year-old Moscow University student, broke the world outdoor high-jump record of his American rival, John Thomas, today by one-twentieth of an inch. Brumel cleared 7 feet 3.8 inches.

TUNIS, June 18 -- North African hopes for an early resumption of French-Algerian peace talks, broken off last Tuesday, were at a low ebb here following the return yesterday of the Algerian negotiating team.

Members of New York Typographical Union 6 backed yesterday the recommendation of their parent union that they stay at work pending efforts to break a deadlock in contract negotiations on ten metropolitan daily newspapers.

CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) -- Ninth-inning homers by Billy Goodman and Nelson Fox in the opener and an extra-base-hit attack in the second game enabled the Chicago White Sox to beat the Minnesota Twins today, 4 -- 3 and 10 -- 7.

PALMYRA, N.J., June 18 -- Ch. Marquam Hill's Comanche, a boxer owned and bred by Dr. and Mrs. Robert W. Burke of San Rafael, Calif., topped a field of 586 contenders today to win best-in-show honors at the fourteenth annual Burlington County Kennel Club feature.
CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) -- Except for small gains in wheat, the grain futures market trended lower last week and finished with additional steep losses in soybeans.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Republican criticism of President Kennedy's foreign policy grew louder today. It included some voices heard occasionally in support of his domestic proposals.

Brumel's performance on Sunday gives the Russian claim to the highest jumps ever made indoors or outdoors. However, his indoor mark of 7 feet 4 1/2 inches, achieved on Jan. 28 in Leningrad on a dirt infield, probably never will be recognized as a world record.

Corporate business in this country reached a new plateau this spring, if only by virtue of the crowded and spirited annual meetings that made the headlines. Prices have been fluctuating in their usual way, now suggesting rapid progress, again hinting at decline, but the news about "big business" has included new and unusual slants on the stockholders.

Commercial Solvents Corporation announced yesterday that it would pay $15 a share for every share of Chemical Process Company stock tendered it by the close of business on Friday, thus removing a 200,000-share limit on its original tender plan announced a week earlier.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 18 -- La Nacion, a newspaper regarded as semi-official, published today letters indicating a link between the Cuban Embassy here and local Communist plotters.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 (AP) -- Three-run homers by Willie McCovey and Orlando Cepeda enabled the Giants to beat the Chicago Cubs, 7 -- 2, today.
Today is "W-Day" in the mutual funds industry.

One of the principal negotiators in the maritime strike charged yesterday that a ship-owners' committee had attempted to "bribe" maritime labor. His stand indicated that the three-day strike could become a prolonged tie-up.

A City Hall spokesman disclosed yesterday that the Wagner Administration has been studying the possibility of suing to recover millions of dollars from concerns that had failed to meet specifications on school contracts.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 18 -- Mrs. William H. Foulk Jr., with Firefly in the Luders-16 Class race, and the Thomas Mell-Ashton Collins Jr. Quincy Adams-17, Dancer, were among the winners as seventy-five boats sailed in the third East-of-Rye Yacht Racing Association regatta of the season off Riverside Yacht Club today.
LOS ANGELES, June 18 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves slammed five homers today in a 10-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
The calling of the priesthood was extolled yesterday at the 10 A.M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
The city's Housing and Redevelopment Board, at the end of its first year of operation, can look back on a prodigious volume of paper work. But not one brick has been laid in a new project.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- From the end of World War II through June 30, 1960, The United States provided $56,985,000,000 in economic aid of all kinds abroad.

Six leading Christian clergymen in Israel have unanimously approved of the manner in which the Israeli Government is conducting the trial of Adolf Eichmann, but have varying ideas on how Eichmann should be punished if he is found guilty.

AN expectant father recently upended the stereotype of the floor-pacing, nail-chewing, chain-smoking fathers-to-be. After taking his wife to the hospital during the wee hours, the groggy gentleman seated himself in a hospital chair and slept during the birth of his child.
Leader's of the Transport Workers Union have set a four-day, thirty-two-hour week as their main goal in bargaining this fall with the Transit Authority and seven private bus lines.

CLEVELAND, June 18 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians beat Baltimore, 2 -- 1, today on Bob Nieman's two-on, two-out pinch single in the ninth inning. Then the Indians wasted a 5-0 lead and lost the second game, 8 -- 5, as the Orioles scored all their runs in the second inning.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- In open hearings before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee last week, Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara expatiated on what his department was doing to save the taxpayers' money.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Not all Indian tribes accept the chronically depressed economic situation in which they find their reservations. Instead of continuing to scrape along on Federal aid and other meager sources of income some have made successful corporate efforts to improve conditions.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey has informed the Kennedy Administration that he will not vote for the new foreign-aid program until he "gets some answers" on improvements in the program for Latin America.
Seven records were set yesterday as the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union junior track and field championships opened at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium, the Bronx.

GALVESTON, Tex., June 18 (AP) -- A tornado struck Galveston tonight after flood waters had driven hundreds of persons from their homes in south central Texas and heavy rains were blamed for accidents that took twenty lives in Texas during the week-end.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) June 18 (AP) -- An Italian archaeologist said today that the carved name of Pontius Pilate had been found on a stone on the Mediterranean coast of Israel.

While lower mathematicians from the two nations that have put rockets into orbit groped yesterday with the problem of whether John Thomas or Valeri Brumel had jumped higher, track and field's elite swarmed here for the East's biggest meet in years.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Admission of Communist China into the United Nations would irreparably damage United States national security, a committee of six retired Army and Navy officers and a past president of the American Bar Association said today.
Manufacturers of so-called "top-quality" products must learn to recognize where value ends and waste begins, a leading cost analyst warned yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 19 -- Djinn, Nina, Royono and Dyna were ahead today in the 468-mile ocean race from Annapolis to Newport, according to a noon report received from the escorting Coast Guard tug Tamaroa.
New York University has undertaken a three-year study to see if there is a way to do what some consider impossible -- divert or weaken hurricanes.

BOSTON, June 16 -- The secluded figure regarded by some as the most powerful force in Massachusetts government creates a disarming impression. A round face, prominent jowls and a fringe of gray hair give William Francis Callahan an almost pixie-ish look.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) -- The indictment against Scarbeck, twice-married father of four, made no mention of a report that Communist agents had blackmailed him after catching him in an affair with a 22-year-old Polish blonde.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted Irvin C. Scarbeck, 41-year-old former United States embassy official in Warsaw, on charges of giving classified information to representatives of the Communist government of Poland.

The unions on strike are the National Maritime Union, 37,000 members; the Seafarers International Union, Atlantic, Gulf and Lakes section, 22,000; the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, 11,000; The Masters, Mates and Pilots, 11,000, the American Radio Association, 1,000, and the tanker section of the Radio Officers Union, which has 1,500 in all.
The Board of Higher Education asked the Board of Estimate last night for $75,000 to prepare a master plan for the City University.

DETROIT, June 19 -- The Tractors for Freedom Committee told Premier Fidel Castro tonight that it would not increase its offer of 500 agricultural tractors in exchange for the 1,200 prisoners captured in the April invasion of Cuba.
LONDON, June 19 -- The slide in share prices that began last week with the announcement of poor national trade figures for May gathered pace in the stock market today.

New commission-house buying of cocoa contracts touched off stop-loss buying early yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Profit taking and hedge selling lowered prices from the highs of the day, but the market recovered toward the close on continued new buying.
KANSAS CITY, June 19 -- The Athletics changed managers today and almost immediately the switch changed their luck.
CHICAGO, June .19 (AP) -- An inquest has been ordered into the death of Edward Gaedel, the only midget ever to play baseball in the major leagues. He was 36 years old.

Steel production last week declined for the third consecutive week, it was disclosed yesterday. The industry's estimated operating rate fell to 68 per cent of capacity from 70 per cent a week before and a 1961 peak of 71 per cent three weeks earlier.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- With a bit of grumbling, the House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to appropriate $32,200,000 for the United Nations' military assistance program in the Congo. The roll-call vote was 291 -- 63.
CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) -- Sears Roebuck Co. issued its 1961 fall-winter catalogue today and price tags on 2,300 representative consumer items listed show average prices 1 per cent below last year's.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Commissions Commission, continued his criticism of television programs today. He called the material aimed at children "indefensibly wasteful."
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court set aside today the conviction of Arthur Culombe, who was sentenced to death in Connecticut in the holdup' slaying of two personal in a gasoline station at New Britain.
George Oka, a Japanese designer, showed a collection of his play street and evening clothes yesterday at the Sheraton-East Hotel, and each of the designs had an oriental air.

If Mayor Wagner, running again, replaces Abe Stark with Paul R. Screvane for City Council President and Lawrence E. Gerosa with Abraham D. Beame for Controller, he will certainly have a more competent third-term ticket.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 19 -- The establishment of positions for three to five under secretaries general has been recommended to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold as a means of strengthening the United Nations.

The Setman Realty Corporation, a subsidiary of the Arnold Constable Corporation, has entered into a contract to sell its eight-acre portion of the Miracle Mile Shopping Center. The property, on Northern Boulevard in Manhasset, L.I., was bought by Nadon Realty Company, Inc., for almost $3,000,000, subject to a mortgage of about $1,600,000.

" We are very proud we are American actors -- and grateful, too." This statement was made by Helen Hayes, when she returned yesterday afternoon with fifty-two other members of the Theatre Guild American Repertory Company by plane from Paris at the New York International Airport.

WHEN the Yankees emerged from the dugout runway for the opening game of their series with the Detroit Tigers a couple of nights ago, eyes widened at the sight of Norm Cash moving spryly around first base with the agility of an acrobat. The newspapers that day had carried the mournful news that an ankle injury might keep the newest Bengal star hospitalized.
Soviet-American negotiations for the establishment of direct Moscow-New York air service are about to get under way after a lengthy delay.
Preparations for the Lewisohn Stadium summer concert series, scheduled to begin tonight, are nearly complete.

PITTSBURGH, June 19 (AP) -- Gene Baker, an infielder who received an unconditional release from the Pittsburgh Pirates last week, was named today as non-playing manager of the Pirates' Batavia (N.Y.) club in the Class D Pennsylvania-New York League.

Tommy Tibbs, the durable Boston lightweight, fought the 111th bout of his career last night. It was a winning one, resulting in a unanimous decision over J.D. Ellis of Trenton in the feature ten-rounder at St. Nicholas Arena.
The Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the twelve months ended May 31.
Members of an independent organization of special officers struck the city Welfare Department yesterday morning to enforce demands for higher wages.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy met privately with a group of Freedom Ride leaders here last week and urged them to concentrate on Negro voting registration in the South.

The former superintendent of construction and the present director of architecture for the Board of Education have admitted to the State Investigation Commission that they solicited political campaign contributions from private architects working for the city.

CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) -- The grain futures market reversed itself suddenly today after a weak early trade and finished in a mostly firm range with rye leading the advance on gains running to more than 3 cents bushel.

The haphazard suburban developments -- "urban sprawl" -- spreading with alarming speed around the perimeters of our cities present an issue of truly national proportions. The open land areas are rapidly giving way to the indiscriminate advance of the bulldozer and the real estate promoter. Yet open space is essential not only to the suburban areas themselves but also to the welfare of the cities they surround.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines today issued a revised forecast that production of domestic crude oil this year would be 7,144,000 barrels a day, or 1.5 per cent more than during 1960.
Bond dealers were more interested in appraising major new issues of corporate and local government bonds yesterday than in putting through trades in the secondary market.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 19 -- The Misses Marianne Bell and Sandra Lee Sunderland were introduced to society at a supper dance given this evening by Miss Bell's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Bell Jr., and Miss Sunderland's mother, Mrs. J. Southworth Sunderland.

ISLAND PARK, L.I., June 19 -- William Landgraf wears three hats. Sometimes, he's the Honorable William, Mayor of Island Park. Sometimes, he's the Right Worshipful William, a highly regarded Mason. The rest of the time, he's "just plain Bill," a 73-year-old bowling-historian.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) -- Republicans in Congress were urged today to help President Kennedy gain reorganization of the National Labor Relations Board.

THE details of a culinary project that will be monumental if fulfilled were announced last night at a press reception at the French consulate, 934 Fifth Avenue. The enterprise will be carried out in Villeneuve-Loubet, France -- the home of Auguste Escoffier, considered to be the greatest chef who ever lived.

An investing client of George E. Maran, real estate broker, has bought the one-story building occupied by a supermarket at 66-54 Fresh Pond Road on the corner of Woodbine Street, Queens, for cash above a first mortgage of $315,00.
The case of the tenant at 303 West Ninety-third Street who has refused to move while the building is reconstructed reached the name-calling stage yesterday.

LONDON, June 19 (AP)-- Ron Holmberg of Brooklyn, the seventh-ranked American, and Whitney Reed of Alameda, Calif., No. 8, were among the casualties as twenty-five United States men and women competed in the Queen's Club Lawn tennis tournament today.
Net sales of the Collins Radio Company for the nine months ended on April 30 increased to $164,145,046 from $138,991,830 in the 1960 period.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Administration's two principal economic officials testified today that the Government's official gold reserve requirement was unrealistic.
A new cultural exchange program that will bring prominent performing artists of Asian countries to the United States for extended tours has been organized by the Asia Society.

LOS ANGELES, June 19 (UPI) -- Premier Hayato Ikeda of Japan stopped off here today on his way to a visit with President Kennedy. He expressed a "sincere hope" his talks with the President would strengthen "mutual understanding."

NORWALK, Conn., June 19 -- Silvermine, a residential area divided among the towns of Norwalk, New Canaan and Wilton, will have its third annual Strawberry Festival on Saturday. Proceeds from the event will go to the development fund of Norwalk Hospital.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 19 (Reuters) -- Foreign Minister Kashim Jawad of Irac accused President Kennedy tonight of having meddled in Middle Eastern affairs.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The most important feature of the new procedure the Department of Justice has adopted in antitrust law enforcement is not its "toughness," even though that is of the stand-and-deliver variety. The most important feature is the reversal by the department of perhaps the most basic of the Anglo-American legal concepts: that innocence is the presumption of those charged with guilt, and guilt must be proved "beyond reasonable doubt" by the accuser.
ALBANY, June 19 -- Governor Rockefeller today appointed Ogden R. Reid, former United States Ambassador to Israel, to a five-year term on the State Commission Against Discrimination.

Three children, waiting to be adopted, played happily yesterday in a reception room at Louise Wise Services, 12 East Ninety-fourth Street. The agency hopes to find "parents who can accept them totally," said Mrs. Florence G. Brown, executive director.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company borrowed $20,000,000 in the public capital market yesterday at an interest cost of about 4.99 per cent. The money was raised through the sale at competitive sealed bidding of twenty-five-year first mortgage bonds.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Chicago's "People-to-People"' book drive ended officially at noon today when the last of more than 300,000 donated books were crated for a naval airlift to Brooklyn and overseas readers.
La Guardia Airport has a new landing-light system that is counted on to increase the safety and smoothness of landings on the good-weather runway.
An attempt to explain what true interest rates are is the object of a very vocal campaign by the Savings Banks Association of New York State.

Certified Industries, Inc., East Coast transit mix concrete producer, has purchased Preferred Transmix Concrete, Inc. of Hicksville, L.I. for about $3,000,000 in cash and notes. No stock was involved, Emanuel L. Litwin, president of Certified, said yesterday in the announcement of the transaction.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 19 -- Carole Wright of Brooklyn, the defending champion, led the way into the third round of the New York women's tennis championship at the Beach Point Club today.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 19 -- Wes Ellis of Mountain Ridge carded an eight-under-par 136 today in leading the New Jersey qualifiers for the National Professional Golfers Association tournament to be held July 27 -- 30.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 19 -- Some excellent examples of the curious results of the cross-pollination of movies and television have begun to bloom here and they are being watched with great interest by movie companies.

It often happens amid the claims and counter-claims of the calendar that we are called upon to do two things at once, when everyone knows that it is much better to concentrate on doing one thing well.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 19 (Reuters) -- Hungary jailed twelve prominent Roman Catholics today for terms ranging from two and a half to twelve years on charges of crimes against the state. Five of the defendants were priests and three were monks.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Supreme Court declined today to rule on Connecticut laws that make it a crime to use birth control devices or for physicians to advise their use.
CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets are by the Department of Agriculture follows:

SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 19 (AP) -- The size and wealth of the "American Republican Army" where among questions authorities sought to answer today as they continued investigation of the blowing up of three communications towers May 28 in Nevada and Utah.

The Harry Weinberg forces said yesterday that a total of 107,275 common shares had been pledged to them in their drive for control of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc. Mr. Weinberg, an out-of-town transit executive, and his associates are seeking to unseat present management by a proxy fight.

BALTIMORE, June 19 (UPI) -- Capt. Ernest Brace, a Marine Corps flier was found not guilty today of charges that he had deliberately crashed his $142,000 Government aircraft in a scheme to escape gambling debts and to enable his family to collect on a $50,000 life insurance policy.
George Meany accused the Government yesterday of "too much hesitancy" in fighting unemployment.

OTTAWA, June 19 -- James E. Coyne, Governor of the Bank of Canada, made public today the measures he recommended to Finance Minister Donald Fleming to reduce unemployment and increase Canadian prosperity.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee said today the "fatuity and danger of one-man, secret diplomacy" had never been better revealed than at the 1943 Cairo and Teheran conferences unless it was at Vienna recently.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- Before a capacity audience, Robin Hood Dell's thirty-second season of summer concerts got under way tonight in its sylvan amphitheatre above the banks of the Schuylkill River in Fairmont Park.

PARIS, June 19 -- A high French military tribunal sentenced to twelve years' imprisonment tonight the former air force general who had authorized the flight to Algeria of two generals who led an army mutiny there in April.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Congressmen and textile industry officials were told today by George W. Ball, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, that the imposition of quotas on textile imports would hurt the country's foreign relations.

A Bronx cab driver returned $10,000 in cash yesterday to a housewife who had lost it after she had saved thirty-three years for a trip to her native France. The cabbie followed this up with a courtly gesture that would have done credit to a d'Artagnan.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Supreme Court overruled today a landmark decision of 1949 and held that the Constitution forbids the use of illegally seized evidence in state criminal trials.

Current Congressional attempts to revise the National Defense Education Act have been dominated by efforts to write into this legislation provisions for aid to private and parochial schools. The furor over this issue has obscured the real purpose of the N.D.E.A., and also obscured some important proposals for its improvement.
Jehovah's Witnesses are conducting literacy classes in twenty-two countries, with the major emphasis on Asia and Africa, according to an official of the organization.
The automobile insurance industry was urged yesterday to help curb the multimillion-dollar tow car racket.

The Federal Communications Commission will begin a hearing here today on the creative aspects of programing practices by the television networks. The hearing, which is expected to run at least ten days, will be broadcast in full by radio station WNYC beginning at 10 A.M.
Argument on an appeal against the fuller integration of New Rochelle's predominantly Negro Lincoln School was set yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the week of July 17.
Columbus, Ga., borrowed $3,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance hospital construction and street improvements.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Treasury bill rates rose slightly on today's sale of the regular weekly issues. They plunged on last week's sale.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 19 (AP) -- A shift of top operational responsibilities of executives of The Louisville Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times was announced today after a directors' meeting.

Representatives of 78,000 dairy farmers and hundreds of milk dealers from ten marketing areas in the Northeastern United States met at the Belmont Plaza Hotel yesterday at the opening of hearings on "manufacturing milk" prices.
A plague of cankerworms, sometimes called inch worms or measuring worms, has given some sections of the metropolitan area their worst epidemic of the pests in at least ten years.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Kennedy is seriously considering the appointment of Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor as White House military adviser.
LONDON, June 19 (AP) -- Seventeen nations met in London today to discuss how to share the world's whale harvest.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) -- The White House released today the first official photographs of Mrs. Jacqueline Kennedy as First Lady.

WHAT is the national purpose? Since the normal complacence of the nation has been disturbed by the "cold war," it is useful to think about national objectives. The National Recreation Association, 8 West Eighth Street, is now engaged in a survey of opinion on this theme.

GENEVA, June 19 -- Semyon K. Tsarapkin, the Soviet dele gate at the nuclear test ban talks, declined today to comment on the United States note rejecting Premier Khrushchev's position on the future of the negotiations.

WHITE PLAINS, June 19 -- A psychiatrist, a hospital administrator and a business man agreed today that group therapy, government action and the opening of hospitals to problem drinkers were vital to relieving the plight of Westchester's 20,000 alcoholics.
PARIS, April 19 -- The Government suffered its most humiliating blow today in its three-week dispute with French farmers.
GENEVA, June 19 -- The leaders of the three factions seeking to form a coalition government for Laos have run into "profound" disagreement, according to word from Zurich today.
The sophisticated confines of the Blue Angel were invaded last week-end by one of the least sophisticated forms of entertainment, old-time country music.

NEW HAVEN, June 19 (AP) -- Seven of eight pacifists convicted of seeking to interfere with the launching of Polaris-missile submarines at Groton were sentenced to prison terms today. The terms ranged from a minimum of twenty days to a maximum of four years.
CHICAGO, June 19 -- A national conference of Indians urged the Federal Government today to "abandon the so-called termination policy of the last Administration."
Dr. Robert A. Soblen went on trial yesterday in Federal Court, charged with the transmitting military information to the Soviet Union over the last twenty years.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., June 19 -- Mayor Wagner proposed today that the State Constitution be rewritten to give New York City more power over its own affairs.

QUIT, Ecuador, June 19 -- Ecuadoran Government leaders told Adlai E. Stevenson, United States representative at the United Nations, that the first problem for inter-American economic cooperation is to devise systems to prevent the fall of prices of basic export commodities.

Stocks rallied briskly in the final hour yesterday and wiped out about 29 per cent of their earlier loss as the ticker tape ran late. The decline, however, remained one of the widest of the year, trimming almost 1 per cent from aggregate market values.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court declared today that warrants calling for the seizure of obscene publications must contain adequate safeguards to protect nonob-scene material from being confiscated.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The White House announced today further improvement in President Kennedy's ailing back, but said he had canceled more engagements.
Prices of most issues traded on the over-the-counter market tumbled from 1 to 2 points in moderate trading yesterday.
Thirteen players from five Ive League colleges were named to the sectional all-star team today by the United States Intercollegate Lacrosse Association.

THE twenty-first Antique Dealers' Fair and Exhibition, now on view at Grosvenor House, is considered to be the brightest and most handsome in its history. The Fair was opened by Antony Armstrong-Jones and visited by Jacqueline Kennedy during her brief private stay here.
THE coming of hot weather usually means the cessation of duplicate games at many of New York's bridge clubs.

The board of directors of Shulton, Inc., proposed yesterday a 2-for-1 stock split on the class A and class B common stock. The proposal is subject to approval by shareholders of an increase in each class of stock from 1,000,000 shares to 2,000,000.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., June 19 -- Ferdie Catropa of Peninsula and Mrs. Samuel Herstone of Island Hills combined for a net 31, 34 -- 65 and took first prize by draw in the Long Island Professional Golf Association pro-lady tournament at the Middle Bay Club today.

SOME women strive for elegance by playing it safe, particularly when it comes to accessories. A black alligator handbag for daytime and a black faille for evening will be a passport to fashion distinction -- they hope.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 19 (UPI) -- The president of the Communications Workers of America charged today that poor leadership and internal discord were leading to the collaose of the merged labor movement.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 19 -- Czechoslovakia rejected today a United States demand for the removal of one of her diplomats here. She threatened to take the case to an international arbitration panel.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that states could not compel officeholders to declare belief in God.
LOT-Polish Airlines has established an office in New York, the first carrier based in the Soviet sphere of influence to do so.

DETROIT, June 19 -- Miss Anne Ford, daughter of Henry Ford 2d, board chairman of the Ford Motor Company, and Mrs. Ford, made her debut tonight at a party attended by 1,200 guests at the Ford mansion in suburban Grosse Pointe.

The issue framed by your editorial (June 3) "Politics and the Federal Bench" and Prof. Herbert Wechsler's sharp retort (June 8) sounds in sterile dialectic devoid of a sense of reality. It is based on the false premise that to secure excellence in judges their selection must be wholly divorced from politics. This thesis is opposed to American tradition and practice.
Mayor Wagner promised last night that he would formally announce his decision on running for a third term today or tomorrow.

The Opinion Research Corporation of Princeton, N.J., has just completed a national probability sampling of 537 households to determine their attitudes toward foreign economic competition and their thoughts on how the United States can best meet the threat that is posed.
A mural by Thomas Hart Benton depicting Hennepin's first view of Niagara Fails will be unveiled here today by the State Power Authority.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Officials of the United States and the Soviet Union met today to work out arrangements for another round of disarmament negotiations.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The White House announced today that the visit of President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan had been advanced from November to July 11.

Mrs. Winston F.C. Guest will give a luncheon at the St. Regis today for the committee chairmen and members for the tenth anniversary April in Paris Ball, to be held at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Oct. 20. Mrs. Guest is general chairman of the ball and president of the American French Foundation, sponsor for the event.
LAKEVIEW, L.I., June 19 -- Negro residents of an integrated section of this community are urging other Negroes not to buy homes here to prevent the area from eventually becoming predominantly Negro.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Air Line Pilots Association was denied today a Supreme Court review of a Federal Aviation Agency order grounding pilots more than 60 years old.

Although the Phoenix Theatre will be closed for the summer, a company of eleven of its actors will be working in East Hampton, L.I. The troupe will present four plays in "A Phoenix Summer Festival" at the John Drew Theatre.

LONDON, June 19 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Communist party's Central Committee unanimously adopted today a new draft party program that was reported to contain a chart for the future course of the Soviet economy.
The General Assembly of North Carolina passed a resolution last week designating the Vagabond Players of the Flat Rock Playhouse as the State Theatre of North Carolina.
PARIS, June 19 -- The central banks of Continental Europe are rallying to the rescue of Britain as the pound sterling once again comes under heavy pressure.
NEW ORLEANS, June 19 (AP) -- The four first-grade Negro girls who desegregated two New Orleans schools last November have all been promoted, the superintendent's office said today.
Mrs. Alice Snow Barbee Lurcy was ordered yesterday to leave by July 5 the five-story mansion she lives in at 813 Fifth Avenue.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- Joint negotiations conducted by Teamsters and Longshoremen's unions won wage increases up to 27 cents an hour today for their warehouse divisions in northern California.
BOLZANO, Italy, June 19 -- Two young men were killed by Italian Army sentries in a widespread outburst of shooting throughout Alto Adige last night.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- If Cuba becomes a Communist state -- all indications are that she is marching in that direction -- the result may be a new sort of communism with its own peculiar features.
NEW DELHI, India, June 19 -- Steadily mounting doubts about the value of Pakistan's ties with the United States are evident in recent reports from Karachi and Rawalpindi.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 19 -- The reasons why seemingly usable office buildings in many of the nation's cities are being abandoned for new or remodeled structures were examined today by some 1,000 building owners and managers.

CHICAGO, June 19 (UPI) -- A 73 per cent jump in earnings in the first nine months of its current fiscal year was announced today by the Hallicrafters Company.
LONDON, June 19 -- The Leningrad State Kirov Ballet, which is to play a season in New York in the fall, made its London debut tonight at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, before a gala audience.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, accused an officers' union yesterday of giving labor a "black eye" in the national maritime strike by refusing to clear ships for the transportation of military cargoes.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 to 24 points downward yesterday. ( A point equals 5 cents a bale.)

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to order that a special three-judge Federal tribunal be set up to hears protest by parents of fourteen Negro children of Duval County, Fla., against Florida's new pupil, assignment law.

CONCORD, N.H., June 19 (UPI) -- Sherman Adams said today that former President Dwight D. Eisenhower should be named a "world peace mediator." He indicated that he believed General Eisenhower would accept such a post if it were offered to him.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) -- The drive to pass President Kennedy's school aid bill is so bogged down it may have to be abandoned until next year, Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., chairman of the House Education Committee, said today.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- A House Agriculture subcommittee approved, 7 to 5, today the Kennedy Administration's wheat proposal for 1962. It provides for mandatory cut of 10 per cent in acreage.
The First Deputy Fire Commissioner in Mayor William O'Dwyer's administration, James J. Moran, was released from state prison yesterday and turned over to Federal authorities.

PARIS, June 19 (UPI) -- Rudolf Nureyev, the 23-year-old Russian ballet star who defected to the West last week, has a job. He starts work Friday for the Marquis de Cuevas Ballet troupe as the male lead in "Sleeping Beauty."

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the American Automobile Association's income-tax return must show all membership dues paid in a calendar year, with no offset for estimated expenses later.

CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) -- There is bad news for the consumer at the international home furnishings market -- prices are going up. Wholesale buyers looking over the new fall lines at the week-long market are being told to expect a 3 to 5 per cent price jump within the next month or six weeks.

KANSAS CITY, June 19 - The Kansas City Athletics, in a surprise move, dismissed Joe Gordon as manager today. He will be succeeded by Hank Bauer, the one-time right fielder of the Yankees and still an active player for the Athletics.
Twenty-eight youths were taken into custody when the police broke up a crowd of teen-agers armed with sticks and car antennas that had assembled in a Bronx housing project last night.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Supreme Court held today that a man compelled to join a railway union may prevent the union from spending his dues for political purposes he opposes.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) -- President Kennedy asked Congress today to authorize $80,000,000 to aid in planning development and improvement of mass transportation systems in metropolitan and urban areas.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) June 18 -- Adolf Eichmann will begin ten days of testimony tomorrow at his trial before an Israeli tribunal on charges of having played a major role in the murder of millions of Jews.

Rolf Italiaander, a Dutch scholar-explorer, has been intimately connected with Africa ever since he joined the French Foreign Legion in 1933. He has made eleven major expeditions across Africa, engaging in private discussions with the emerging personalities of that area.

CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) -- The prosecution of 235 precinct election judges accused of misconduct in the election of Nov. 8 was set back today when Acting County Judge John M. Karns dismissed charges against several defendants.
Complaints from a group of mothers that a Washington Square Park area reserved for toddlers was being invaded by adults brought action yesterday from the Park Department.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The American Civil Liberties Union opposed appeals today from Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy for new powers to force testimony from witnesses who invoke the protection of the Fifth Amendment.

A Housing Court magistrate directed the city yesterday to serve a summons on the holder of a mortgage to an Upper West Side tenement after finding the owner of record to be nothing more than a "glorified superintendent."
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The New York Central Railroad made a new effort here today to derail a Chesapeake and Ohio Railway plan to acquire control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to change a ten-year deadline it set for E.L. du Pont de Nemours Co. to dispose of its 63,000,000 shares in General Motors Corporation.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 19 -- Among the contenders in next Friday night's $50,000 Harness Tracks of America pacing series final at Roosevelt Raceway, Sampson Direct fared best in the draw for post positions today.

An application by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to conduct an inquiry into housing discrimination was rejected yesterday.
The city's second annual cargo exposition will be held at Pier 9, North River, at Carlisle Street, on Sept. 6, 7 and 8. Its theme will be coordinated transportation.

ALDERSON, W. Va., June 19 (UPI) -- Mildred Gillars, once known as Axis Sally, will be released from prison July 10. She will go free for the first time since she was arrested in Berlin in 1946.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 19 -- Proctor Academy, skippered by David Waiters of Riverside, Conn., led the way into the finals of the twenty-sixth regatta of the Interscholastic Yacht Racing Association today.

Christopher T. Chenery's Cicada won the Filly Division of the National Stallion Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday in an exciting duel with Batter Up of the Wheatley Stable.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -The United States recalled today its chief negotiator at the stalemated conference for a ban on nuclear testing. Officials said it was "an open question" whether he would return to the Geneva parleys.

Commodity trading was dull and featureless yesterday on the New York exchanges. Most prices fluctuated in narrow ranges. Futures moved irregularly higher.

Merger of the H.L. Green Company, Inc., into the McCrory Corporation was approved by stockholders at separate meetings yesterday. The new combined organization will become fourth in volume among the nation's variety store chains and third in number of outlets.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -The grain futures market was generally firm on the Board of Trade today.

Of the several significant decisions handed down by the Supreme Court yesterday, the most puzzling was the court's dismissal of a suit challenging a Connecticut law against the use or prescription of contraceptive devices. It said Connecticut had brought only one prosecution under the statute and there was no indication any violator would now be prosecuted.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 20 -DeCoursey Fales' Nina, 33 years old and still as nimble as a youngster, slipped across the line tonight as the first yacht to finish the biennial race from Annapolis to Newport.
LAFAYETTE Ind., June 20 (AP) -- The former United States amateur champion, Jack Nicklaus of Ohio State, today won the qualifying medal in the National Collegiate golf tournament.
PARIS, June 20 -- The peasant women of Brittany joined their menfolk today to protest against the crop price collapse that has jeopardized their standard of living.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -The White House announced late today that President Kennedy's physician and two consultants had agreed that the President should be able to discard his crutches in two days.
BOSTON, June 20 -- A member of the Massachusetts Legislature was sentenced to a year in jail and was fined $300 today on a charge of larceny involving a sidewalk paving contract.

MEXICO CITY, June 20 (UPI) -- The appointment of former New Orleans Mayor de Lesseps Morrison as United States Ambassador to the Organization of American States was severely criticized today by a Dominican exile organization here.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 20 -- Al Feminelli, the Dellwood Country Club stylist, today led the seven Metropolitan qualifiers for the Professional Golfers Association national championship.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Howard E. Simpson, chairman of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, said today that his company was in a precarious financial condition and urgently needed an early affiliation with the prosperous Chesapeake and Ohio Railway.

OTTAWA, June 20 -- The Canadian Government embarked tonight on a deliberate policy reduce the value of the Canadian dollar in comparison with its United States counterpart. The effect would be to stimulate exports and reduce imports from the United States.

CHICAGO, June 20 (UPI) -The Chicago White Sox scored five runs in the first inning tonight and sent Jim (Mudcat) Grant to his first loss of the season in beating the Cleveland Indians, 5 -- 3. The victory was Chicago's fourth straight.

The City Planning Commission's eighteen-project urban renewal program was decried yesterday as displacing lowincome tenants and forcing present Negro and Puerto Rican residents to move into "ghetto areas."

LOBATSI, Bechuanaland, June 20 -- Another of Britain's African protectorates came nearer self-government here today when Bechuanaland's new multi-racial Legislative Council was inaugurated by High Commissioner Sir John Maud.
WILTON, Conn., June 20 -Quick intervention by the Wilton Garden Club has saved one of the town's finest maple trees.

LONDON, June 20 (AP) -Chuck McKinley of St. Louis and Karen Hantze, of Chula Vista, Calif, the best United States hopes for next week's Wimbledon championships, won their matches today in the Queen's Club lawn tennis tournament.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 20 -President Victor Paz Estenssoro announced last night that he was considering resigning within five days if his Government could not solve the nation's economic crisis.
BOSTON, June 17 -- "The people are fed up."

SOMERTON was only a small town in Sligo County sixty miles east of the Mississippi in west Tennessee. But every year during the strawberry festival Somerton swelled with importance. Thousands of people lined the streets as the parade went by, to applaud the high school bands. They went to the carnival and watched old Starkey Pole dressed in red underwear make his annual parachute jump from a balloon.
A major Protestant denomination and the American Jewish Congress protested to the Peace Corps yesterday against the signing of overseas contracts with religious groups.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 20 -It may seem odd, but when Adios Butler bobbed up with No. 4 in this morning's draw for post positions for Saturday night's $25,000 Dr. Stanton Pace at Roosevelt Raceway, Paige West was the most relieved man on the grounds.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The House of Representatives today voted approval of President Kennedy's plan to reorganize the Civil Aeronautics Board and the Federal Trade Commission.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Peace Corps named forty-two more young Americans today to train for work in Tanganyika and Columbia.
Abe Stark put Mayor Wagner on notice yesterday that he would fight any attempt to drop him from this year's Democratic city ticket as a candidate for re-election as President of the City Council.
ALBANY, June 20 -- The State Bar Association today named Anthony Lewis of The New York Times as the winner of its 1961 Press Award for news writing and reporting.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of goods that are reasonable in cost. A menu is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

NEWPORT, Ky., June 20 (UPI) -- Two men accused of framing a former football star, George Ratterman, by putting him in a hotel room with a strip dancer to embarrass his campaign for sheriff were act quitted today.

Landlord and tenant have agreed on the basic conditions of a thirty-year lease, and optimism was expressed yesterday that work would begin on Flushing Meadow Stadium in Queens by the end of the month.
The Association of Ship Brokers and Agents is compiling a list of shipowners who are delinquent in their brokerage payments, John M. Reynolds, secretary of the trade group reported yesterday.
The city's Housing and Redevelopment Board announced yesterday that 4,266 new apartments had been occupied and that 14,607 more were under construction so far under its year-old program.
Welfare Commissioner James R. Dumpson received an anonymous telephone threat yesterday as the strike of the department's special officers continued.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York, today took exception to criticism by Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, of the method he and Senator Jacob K. Javits used to select possible candidates for Federal judgeship posts.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz declared last night that the Wagner administration's "retreat from responsibility," coupled with "bankruptcy of initiative," represented the major issue of the 1961 city campaign.

Paul O'Dwyer, younger brother of former Mayor William O'Dwyer, declared yesterday that he would enter the Democratic primary for Controller unless Mayor Wagner chose as his running mate for that spot a candidate with the social philosophy "of a true liberal."
Tom Scott, a defensive player, yesterday signed his 1961 contract with the New York Giants of the National Football League. The Giants obtained Scott in a trade with the Philadelphia Eagles in 1959.

The City Labor Department's reply to a union study showing that New York ranks last among the country's metropolitan centers in average factory earnings will be more reassuring to statisticians than to those of us who are alarmed by the return of economic exploitation to this city.
WILMINGTON, Del., June 20 (AP) -- Chief Judge Caleb M. Wright today signed a Federal District Court order barring Wellington Equity Fund, Inc., from use of the name "Wellington."

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee poked fun today at the Administration over a press packet made available to Canadian news media when President Kennedy visited Ottawa May 16.
TRENTON, June 20 -- The State Youth Study Commission warned today that a permanent state agency to deal with juvenile delinquency was essential if the problem were to be solved.

Henri-Georges Clouzot, director of the prize-winning French suspense drama, "Diabolique," has signed an agreement with Columbia Pictures to make his first English-language film, with Sir Alec Guinness.
" When No One Is Looking . . ." will open Oct. 26 at the Belasco. Frederick Knott is the author of the psychological thriller, his first since the absorbing "Dial M for Murder."

Paperboard production fell to 325,848 tons in the week ended last Saturday from 332,425 tons the week before, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. A year ago the figure was 31,358 tons.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Senate approved today a farm fund bill carrying more than $7,000,000,000 to operate agricultural programs for the next twelve months.
The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange stood at 3,434,038 shares on June 15. This figure reflected a drop of 91,288 shares below the mid-May figure of 3,525,326.
The Belmont Park feature today is the $39,650 Bowling Green Handicap at a mile and a half on turf. Louis Wolfson's Wolfram is the high weight under 130 pounds and a likely even-money favorite.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., June 20 -- City Manager Joseph McD. Mitchell acted today to reorganize this city's welfare program. In a memorandum to John O'Donnell, Commissioner of Public Welfare, he ordered that thirteen changes be put into effect July 15.
One of advertising's least publicized but most important problems in the months ahead will be to find a successor for Frederic Gamble, president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.
ST. LOUIS, June 20 (AP) -The United States won the Carling Cup golf matches today defeating Canada, 7 1/2 to 4 1/2. The matches were played at the Old Warson Country Club.
Leading sales finance companies generally reduced by one-eighth percentage point yesterday the rates paid on their short-term obligations sold directly to investors.

CINCINNATI, June 20 (UP) -- Delegates to the convention of the Boot and Shoe Workers Union voted today to negotiate a merger with the United Shoe Workers Union and to seek a merger of all unions in the shoe industry.
Three plans for solving problems affecting pricing of Class 3 milk in the New York-New Jersey area were offered yesterday by Dr. David A. Clarke Jr., a Government economist.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- House Speaker Sam Rayburn said today there was a nation-wide campaign under way against President Kennedy's foreign aid bill.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -The United States has scheduled intensive discussions with France and Britain to review possible political and military steps as the Berlin crisis grows.

Although the concert music of the western world is highly organized and elaborate, something is still lacking. No symphony orchestra has, for example, a xylophone in the shape of a dragon's back, a bell suspended from a cobra's mouth, or a lyre fashioned from a human skull with antelope horns.
Uncertainty troubled the market for fixed-interest securities yesterday as traders pondered the possible reception two major negotiated, tax-exempt issues due to reach the market this week.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- With a declining coal industry, the United States has reached the point where it is a "matter of decision whether there will be a domestic fuels industry at all," Congress was told today.
Committee chairmen have been chosen to work for the success of the second annual Hope Ball, which will take place at the Waldorf-Astoia Oct. 17.

Continental Copper and Steel Industries, Inc., said yesterday it had concluded an agreement to acquire the largest single stock interest in Consolidated Halliwell, Ltd., of Canada together with major representation on the board of directors.
PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP) -- Extra base hits including home runs by Dick Stuart and Don Hoak helped the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 6-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 20 -- Following is the text of a note transmitted to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today by the United States delegation in the case of a Czech official accused of espionage.

The Glen Classic sports car races will be run Friday and Saturday on the 3.2-mile course at Watkins Glen, N.Y. All of Friday will be taken up by practice by more than 150 entries. The racing will start at 10 A.M. Saturday.

STRASBOURG, France, June 20 -- The house of Europe, in this ancient city on the Rhine that mingles the language and history of France and Germany, was dominated today by the faces and voices not of Europe but of Africa.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -Douglas Dillon, Secretary of the Treasury, said today that the nation's business probably would be "rolling in high gear" at this time next year and "may well be in the midst of an economic boom."

The country's electrical manufacturers, shaken by the conviction of the giants of the industry on price-rigging charges, have adopted a code of principles designed to guarantee full compliance with the anti-trust laws.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The league-leading Detroit Tigers quelled an eighth-inning rally by the Washington Senators tonight and went on to a 5 -- 4 victory.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Navy began using today what it says is the largest simulated ocean in the world.

GENEVA, June 20 -- The United States offered today to take its military advisers out of Laos if the withdrawal was "phased and coordinated" with that of the other foreign forces whose presence was inconsistent with the 1954 accord of Indochina.

An official report to Mayor Wagner castigated the Consolidated Edison Company, the Westinghouse Electric Company and the Public Service Commission yesterday for the four-and-a-half-hour power failure in mid-Manhattan on June 13.
THE National Broadcasting Company updated its report on President Kennedy's Administration with another commendable hour last night.
LEOPOLDVILLE, June 20 -The Congolese National Parliament will meet here Sunday or shortly thereafter under the protection of the United Nations.
PARIS, June 20 -- German flags flew over Paris today for the first time since this city was liberated in World War II.

Savings in New York State's 233 savings and loan associations rose by $43,290,684 to $4,486,550,834 in May, according to the Savings Association League of New York State. The increase was 15.7 per cent greater than that achieved in the 1960 month.

The unions on strike are the National Maritime Union, 37,000 members; the Seafarers International Union, Atlantic, Gulf and Lakes section, 22,000; the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, 11,000; The Masters, Mates and Pilots, 11,000, the American Radio Association, 1,000, and the tanker section of the Radio Officers Union, which has 1,500 in all.

BOLZANO, Italy, June 20 -Bursts of submachine-gun fire by army sentries foiled what the Italian police described as seven attempts by "terrorists" to blow up rail and road bridges in Alto Adige last night.
Prices staged a general rally yesterday and added seven-eighths of 1 per cent to aggregate market values on the New York Stock Exchange.
Esquire, Inc., is negotiating with four or five potential purchasers of its Coronet magazine, Lewis W. Gillenson, editor of Coronet, said yesterday.

Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, now conducting a study of the nation's intelligence activities while on leave as president of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, has many talents, including an eager, questing mind. As Army Chief of Staff from 1955 to 1959 he fought for a strengthened limited-war capability, an objective now accepted in the Kennedy Administration.
WEST NEW YORK, N.J., June 20 -- A 2 1/2-year-old girl with a prodigious memory and an interest in unusual bits of information has received a membership card for the Free Public Library.

CINCINNATI, June 20 (AP) The St. Louis Cardinals avenged a 4-3, eleven-inning defeat in the first game of a twilight-night program tonight by defeating the Cincinnati Reds, 6 -- 3, in the second game.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 20 -- The Loomis School won Interscholastic Yacht racing Association honors today in Manhasset Bay.

KEARNY, N.J., June 20 -George Ball of Woodhaven, Queens, and Henry Bassford of Staten Island gained the quarter-finals of the New Jersey State tennis championships at the Arlington Players Club today.

ATHENS, June 20 (UPI) -The International Olympic Committee today set the dates for the 1964 Olympics in Tokyo and the Winter Olympics in Austria. The committee also appointed a commission to study sports aid to African and Asian nations.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver proposed today immunity from prosecution for underlings in big antitrust cases to compel them to testify against ringleaders.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -Former Secretary of State Christian A. Herter and former Under Secretary Will Clayton will direct a survey of world economic and trade problems for a subcommittee of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
JERUSALEM, June 20 (AP) -- In his first appearance on the stand, Adolf Eichmann repeatedly attributed responsibility for his actions as a Nazi official to "my superiors."
The League for Planned Parenthood of Connecticut will offer "all contraceptive techniques" under medical supervision, it was announced yesterday.

HOUSTON, June 20 (AP) -The Gulf Coast Amateur Athletic Union today handed a year of probation to eight Texas Southern University track athletes who withdrew from the June 9 Meet of Champions because of alleged segregation policies on ticket sales.

The election of William B. Rand as president of United States Lines to succeed C. David Gibbons was announced yesterday by John M. Franklin, chairman of the board. Mr. Rand formerly was executive vice president of the company.
TUNIS, June 20 -- The Algerian nationalist Provisional Government expressed hope today that the peace talks with the French Government would resume by June 28.

TOKYO, June 20 -- Premier Hayato Ikeda's visit to the United States is already a success for two groups of Japanese who do not usually have much good to say of each other -- the feminists and the kimono makers.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Senator Everett M. Dirksen, Republican of Illinois, protested in the Senate today against a Department of the Interior information circular that he said described possible benefits from the Soviet Union's increasing oil exports.

DENVER, Colo., June 21 (AP) -- Two filers from the Air Force Academy near Colorado Springs were killed last night when their plane crashed and exploded in a plowed field about fifteen miles east of here.
LONDON, June 21 (UPI) -- Easy-going Karen Hantze clashed with the umpire during the London grass-court tennis championship at the Queen's Club today.
ALBANY, June 21 -- New York income taxes on the earnings of residents employed in Connecticut will be withheld beginning Oct. 1, Governor Rockefeller's office announced today.
PARIS, June 21 -- President Heinrich Luebke of West Germany paid his respects today to France's Unknown Soldier in a discreet and abridged ceremony at the Arc de Triomphe.
Despite a number of strong gains and despite the fact that more stocks rose than fell yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, the session ended with small losses in the leading market indicators.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- A merger within thirty days to one year is the goal of the Baltimore and Ohio and Chesapeake and Ohio railways, if the Interstate Commerce Commission approves the C. O.'s pending application to acquire control of the B. O.

The Chicago Board of Trade, the big grain exchange, is not taking its cue from the New York Stock Exchange, when it comes to opening and closing. The directors of the Chicago exchange voted yesterday to close on Monday, July 3, preceding the Independence Day holiday.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Since a five-judge majority of the Supreme Court decided the compulsory railway union membership case Monday on a free-wheeling interpretation of the Railway Labor Act, and avoided the constitutional issue presented by the highest court of Georgia, few durable conclusions can be drawn from the decision.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 21 -- At least 100 more key posts for Soviet-bloc citizens and more jobs for Africans and some Asians have been recommended by an eight-member review board to correct a "geographic inequality" in the United Nations' staff.
Dozens of party workers in the city will embark today on a drudger's task -- gathering thousands of signatures to designate candidates for public and party office.

LONDON, Thursday, June 22 (Reuters) -- Charles B. Wrightsman of New York and Palm Beach., Fla., whose purchase of a Goya portrait brought protests here, offered today to sell the painting to Britain's National Art Gallery at the price he paid for it -- $392,000.
An American oil man suggested yesterday that the nations of Western Europe establish an economic alliance to check Soviet dumping of oil and other industrial products.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange declined by 5 to 19 points yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

A thirty-year chapter of financial history was brought to a close yesterday with the announcement of the termination of the German Standstill Agreement by Andrew L. Gomory, chairman of the American Committee for Standstill Creditors of Germany.

THE not altogether waggish theory that children rule the roost in American homes is not altogether subtly proved in the new Walt Disney film, "The Parent Trap," which was set for everybody at the Capitol yesterday.
BOSTON, June 21 (AP) -- Floyd Patterson will defend his heavyweight boxing championship here against unbeaten Tom McNeeley on Sept. 23 or Sept 25, it appeared today.
The maritime strike which paralyzed many of the country's ports yesterday emphasizes the importance of the United States merchant marine to the nation's defense.
ZURICH, Switzerland, June 21 (Reuters) -- Deputies of the leaders of the three Laotian factions have agreed here on a plan to integrate their opposing military forces, it was announced today.
The elevation of Robert M. Hill and John P. Morgan 2nd to vice presidents of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York was announced yesterday by Henry C. Alexander, chairman.

The market for fixed-interest securities continued to wilt yesterday under the weight of a growing backlog of new offerings.

Probably no major money in recent history has been "talked down" in value more vigorously by its own countrymen than the Canadian dollar. Government officials, economists and business men north of the border have been delivering speeches for years about how fine it would be if the good old days returned -- the days when the Canadian dollar sold at par with or below the value of the United States dollar.
The Lee Higginson Corporation and associates are offering to the public today 350,000 capital shares of the Wrather Corporation at $10 a share.
Mayor Wagner postponed his scheduled announcement yesterday on whether he will run again. He promised it for this afternoon.
The State Department has estimated that "30,000 political prisoners jam Cuban jails," and "several hundred more have been executed in secrecy."
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- President Kennedy today named Salvatore A. Bontempo of Newark, a New Jersey official, to be administrator of the State Department's Bureau of Security and Consular Affairs.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 21 -- Commodore W. Mahlon Dickerson of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club on Centre Island here and Mrs. Dickerson gave a dinner dance tonight at the club, with Mr. and Mrs. Dale E. Sharp of Oyster Bay, to introduce their daughters to society.
Roman Catholics who are unwilling to discuss the Bible with Jehovah's Witnesses show the weakness of their teaching, the head of the Witnesses' organization said here yesterday.
LE HAVRE, France, June 21 -- A long-simmering dispute over an assistant table captain in the dining room of the Liberte halted her scheduled sailing for New York today with 1,235 passengers.
A high-ranking Federal narcotics agent yesterday recommended the impeachment of judges who forestalled mandatory sentences on narcotics offenders.
MONTREAL, June 21 -- The Canadian dollar fell today to the lowest level in ten years. Trading here was described as "wild, erratic and confused."

The Revolutionary Movement of the People has formally repudiated the National Revolutionary Council, which was formed late in May by underground groups operating in Cuba.

The nation's gasoline inventories showed a small seasonal decline last week, according to figures issued by the American Petroleum Institute yesterday. Production of crude oil and refined products increased from the week-earlier level.
MILWAUKEE, June 21 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves rallied twice tonight to defeat the San Francisco Giants, 5 -- 3, as Lew Burdette posted his sixth victory.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Following is a transcript of President Kennedy's remarks today on the dedication of a demonstration plant for saline-water conversion at Freeport, Tex.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Senate-House conferences agreed today on tax provisions of the highway financing bill. The aim is to complete work on the interstate system by 1972.

" Lack of training for dog judges is one of the serious ailments affecting dog shows," Dr. E.S. Montgomery said at the Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club's final meeting of the season at Luchow's restaurant yesterday.
Mayor deLesseps S. Morrison of New Orleans denied here yesterday that he had had any ties to the Trujillo regime in the Dominican Republic.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 21 (AP) -- A -- Mace-B guided missile successfully flew ran evasive 1,100-mile course today, ending its research and development program.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Sharp cuts in foreign aid personnel and replacement of some "misfits" now in overseas missions were promised today by Administration officials under the pending $8,800,000,000 development loan program.

The sun was at its highest point in the heavens at 11:30 A.M. yesterday, making it the first day of summer. But it was invisible behind rain clouds that washed out a noon ceremony planned by the city to salute the newly arrived season.
LONDON, June 21 -- Equity prices continued to respond to renewed demand on the stock market here today.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Senate approved today a one-year extension of the $150,000,000 Federal milk program for children. The bill, approved by voice vote, now goes to the House.

TENAFLY, N.J., June 21 -- Only two strokes separated the first four players after the first round of the thirty-eighth annual Women's New Jersey Golf Association 54-hole, medal-play championship today.

Electric power production in the week ended last Saturday was 15,345,000,000 kilowatt hours, the highest since the week ended Jan.28,1961, when 15,861,000,000 kilowatt hours were produced. The total compared with 15,004,000,000 kilowatt hours a week before and 14,441,000,000 kilowatt hours a year earlier, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

BOSTON, June 21 -- The Massachusetts Turnpike Authority said today that its second attempt to finance an extension of the toll road into Boston through a bond issue had been unsuccessful.
