WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) -- The latest art touch of Mrs. John F. Kennedy prevailed today in a historic room of the White House. Portraits of former Presidents took a back seat to borrowed paintings.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 22 (AP) -- Baltimore rallied with seven runs in the ninth inning tonight for an 11 -- 5 victory over the Minnesota Twins. The game was halted four times by rain and took five hours.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Individual Americans increased their financial savings some $5,000,000,000 in the first three months of 1961 -- the largest quarterly increase since the 1958 recession.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- In a surprise move, House Republicans decided today to offer a modified substitute for the Administration's housing bill instead of trying to cut it piece by piece.
May I comment on your editorial of June 19 "To Test or Not to Test." The issue is extremely critical and there is need for the greatest accuracy in presenting it.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 21 (AP) -- Hugh A. Grant's Airmans Guide survived a claim of foul and won the $24,300 Regret Handicap today by a length and a quarter at Monmouth Park.
LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, June 20 -- Strong groups of Mozambique's white population opposed to Portugal's Government are demanding autonomy for this East African territory.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 20 -- The United Arab Republic, after pressing in Cairo last week for the creation of a joint Arab military command, is working this week for an Arab common market.

Vincent J. Belella, who was a central figure in the promotion of the first heavyweight championship fight between Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johannson, was acquitted yesterday on two charges of perjury.
LONDON, June 21 -- A one-day token strike by Southhampton dockers caused minor delays in the sailings today of the United States Line's liner America, the Cunard Line's Queen Mary and other vessels.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- President Kennedy and Premier Hayato Ikeda agreed today to the formation of a United States-Japan economic committee. The group will be on a ministerial level with top representatives from both Governments taking part.

Four schoolboys who tackle football opponents and text books with equal fervor received scholar-athlete awards from the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame yesterday during a luncheon at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
BOLZANO, Italy, June 21 -- There was firing by Italian sentries in the valleys again last night in Alto Adige and the police reported two suspected attempts at arson.
Television's three major networks have rejected a proposed series of documentary programs featuring former President Harry S. Truman, a producer told Federal investigators here yesterday.

ATHENS, June 21 (AP) -- The International Olympic Committee (I.O.C.) today approved a new, potentially stiffer, amateur code and accepted a twenty-sport program for the Tokyo Olympics in 1964. Volleyball and judo were included for the first time.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday he had set up a Rackets Bureau to handle a "shameful increase in the number of complaints from victims of shell-housing schemes, business franchise schemes, mail-order frauds and financing gyps."
" OFFICIAL SECRET,"* by Clayton Hutton, is a lively now-it-can-be-tolder about how British fighters were helped to elude captors during World War II.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Two Senators complained today upon learning that the United States is paying $30,000 a year for the Waldorf Tower apartment for Adlai E. Stevenson, chief Delegate to the United Nations.
A $6,000,000 capital venture with American participation was announced yesterday for the establishment of a brewery and glass works in Western Nigeria.
A twenty-ton box girder, the final section of big steel stop the Port Authority Bus Terminal, was eased into place yesterday with the aid of a "come along."

PARIS, June 21 -- A statement by the Algerian rebels that they are willing to resume the suspended peace negotiations has been found by France to be encouraging but still short of the positive action needed to get the talks started again.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox, scoring fifteen runs on homers, routed the Cleveland Indians twice tonight, 15-3 and 11-1, before a capacity crowd of 45,125.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 21 -- The following table shows the division of top-echelon jobs in the United Nations Secretariat as of April 1, 1961. The figures under the columns marked "goal" show the apportionment considered desirable under present formulas, geared to the financial contributions of member nations, and under a proposal to give some weight to regional status and population.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 21 -- Despite a downpour that formed rivulets on several greens, Bob Gardner, the metropolitan amateur champion, won the William Rice Hochster golf tournament today. His score of 74, 73 -- 147 was compiled under conditions so bad that only thirty-six of the seventy-four starters finished.

PARIS, June 21 -- Angry French farmers battered clown the door of the government administration building in Poitiers, south of the Loire Valley, today to present their demands for increased government aid to agriculture.
Prices and trading volume in the over-the-counter market increased slightly yesterday.
A contest over the $5,000,000 will of a British Honduras lumber operator by his thirteen illegitimate children was decided yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

The St. Joseph Lead Company has agreed to sell its 40 per cent interest in the Brunswick Mining and Smelting Corporation for $10,500,000 in cash to two Canadian mining concerns and a Canadian industrialist.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 21 -- The head of the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division said tonight his agency was powerless to prevent the arrest of Freedom Riders in the South.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 21 (AP) -- Former Maj. Gen. Jose Rene Roman Fernandez, who was defense minister under Generalissimo Rafael Leonides Trujillo Molina, has been, found guilty of treason in connection with the May 30 assassination of the Generalissimo, officials announced tonight.

HONG KONG, June 21. -- The chairman of the Hong Kong Federation of Industries asserted in his annual report issued today that "clamors against our textile imports [in the United States] are exaggerated."
CINCINNATI, June 21 (UPI) -- The league-leading Cincinnati Reds beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 9 -- 2, tonight, as Ken Hunt, a rookie right-hander registered his eighth victory against three losses.
DISCARDING to show distribution is an old practice, going back perhaps forty years, but only in recent years has the practice spread to players below the highest expert rank.

A biography of Jane Addams (1860-1935), founder of Hull House of Chicago, first president of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom and co-sharer of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1931 with Nicholas Murray Butler, has been written by Margaret Tims, editorial assistant at the Fabian Society in England and editor of Peace and Freedom, the bulletin of the Women's International League.

BACK in the days when ballplayers signed contracts for love of the sport and not as the climax to a financial coup, Casey Stengel had a problem. The Ol' Perfessor then was managing the Boston Braves, a poverty-stricken organization that remained one step in front of the sheriff. Somehow or other, however, the Braves had contrived to scrounge up a thousand dollars to lure a collegian.

Pan American World Airways asked the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday to prevent Scandinavian Airlines System from offering service "in gross excess" of the traffic requirements between this country and Norway, Sweden and Denmark.

Howard K. Smith has resumed his Washington news analysis on the "Douglas Edwards With the News" program over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network. He had been off the program for more than five months for reasons that never were officially clarified.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 21 -- The Czech diplomat accused of espionage by the United States will fly home tomorrow morning. He decided to return to Prague after the State Department threatened him with arrest and deportation.
The Air Force disclosed yesterday that its Venus Flytrap rocket had succeeded in collecting what are believed to be the first samples of space dust.
CURRAGH, Ireland, June 21 (AP) -- Your Highness won the Irish Derby today at odds of 33-1.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 21 -- Adlai E. Stevenson is convinced after having visited ten South American countries that the unsuccessful rebel invasion of Cuba has caused serious but reparable damage to inter-American relations.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- The first national conference of American Indians has called upon the United States to give Indians a greater voice in determining Government policy toward them.

CHICAGO, June 21 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers took a twin bill from Chicago today winning the opener, 4 -- 1, on Andre Rodgers' costly error and taking the second, 4 -- 2, on the wildness of three Cub pitchers.

The chance to send good money after good will come today when the Board of Estimate will either agree or refuse to appropriate $60,000 for this season's productions of free Shakespeare in Central Park. That is the balance needed to carry out the program in full -- namely, "Much Ado About Nothing," "A Midsummer Night's Dream" and "Richard H."
A code of ethics to guide new and used car dealers in the metropolitan area in "cleaning their own house" is expected to be adopted today.
Substantial support for the City Planning Commission's proposal to declare four areas of the city suitable for urban renewal was expressed yesterday at a public hearing in City Hall.

As a resident of Greenwich Village who has been in Washington Square Park every Sunday afternoon since folk singers were again allowed to sing there, I feel obliged to comment on Owen J. Grundy's letter in The Times of June 13.

The investment bankers managing a $118,000,000 issue of Turnpike Authority of Kentucky toll road revenue bonds have offered the bonds to the public. The proceeds are intended to finance a limited access toll road in western Kentucky.
LOS ANGELES, June 21 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Angels snapped Boston's winning streak at six games tonight by defeating the Red Sox, 5 -- 1.
The liner United States docked here yesterday with 1,597 passengers in the midst of the one-day walkout by longshoremen.
A member of the Board of Education said yesterday he had inadvertently voted to build a school partly on property owned by a corporation that he heads.

GENEVA, June 21 -- Canada and Poland, both members of the International Control Commission in Laos, clashed today over how much transportation equipment the commission needs to police the cease-fire in Laos.
The Association for the Preservation of Freedom of Choice, Inc., filed suit yesterday in Federal Court to void the selection of Edward R. Dudley as Borough President of Manhattan.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 21 -- Congolese leaders were understood today to be aiming at the formation of a broad national coalition government prior to the opening of Parliament next Sunday or shortly thereafter.

MONTREAL, June 21 (Canadian Press) -- The International Civil Aviation Organization voted unanimously today to increase its Council membership to twenty-seven nations. Its present membership is twenty-one.
After forty-five years of service, Miss Hazel Gay will retire today as head librarian at the American Museum of Natural History.

BILOXI, Miss., June 21 (UPI) -- Lawyers for a jailed Freedom Rider charged today that Mississippi state courts were supporting segregation in defiance of the United States Constitution and the Supreme Court.

STRATFORD, Ont., June 21 -- Although it is not much of a play, "Henry VIII" combines pageantry and several moving characters, into an immensely shrewd theatrical fusion. The Stratford Shakespearean Festival has taken advantage of all the assets of the discursive piece to fashion a grand, sumptuous-looking show.
The Committee for Nonviolent Action, a United States pacifist group, announced here yesterday it had received permission from the Soviet Union to demonstrate on Soviet soil against nuclear weapons.

Edgar R. Baker, managing director of Time-Life International, said yesterday that the recommendations of the Canadian Royal Commission on Publications, if adopted, would deprive Time, Inc., "virtually without notice and certainly without compensation, of a property interest valued at more than $10,000,000."

ST. LOUIS, June 21 (AP) -- Sue Behlmar, a 19-year-old student from Long Beach (Calif.) State College, gained the quarter-finals of the women's collegiate tennis tournament today by defeating Alice Luthy of the University of Florida, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The second of President Kennedy's plans to reorganize Federal regulatory agencies by giving more powers to their chairmen was vetoed today. The Senate, by a vote of 52 to 38, rejected the proposal for the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Alphonse J. Pupino's Dead Center showed that 107 pounds was easier to carry than 130 pounds in the $39,650 Bowling Green Handicap on the turf at Belmont Park yesterday.

TRENTON, June 21 -- A bi-state accord that would authorize the Port of New York Authority to build a World Trade Center in Manhattan and acquire, rehabilitate and operate the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad appeared imminent tonight.
The Central Conference of American Rabbis yesterday voiced strong opposition to the use of Federal or state grants to private and parochial schools or subventions to students of such schools.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Pentagon named today four air bases in south and central England that will be closed or reduced in operations. The move will force a shift in major reconnaissance operations to bases near Metz, France.

Ambassador Adlai Stevenson returns to Washington today from his trip to all ten South American countries. The project was a gamble which paid off handsomely. Except for minor hostile demonstrations here and there, Mr. Stevenson was warmly received. He performed his task of preparing the groundwork for the economic conference to be held in Uruguay next month.
NEWARK, June 21 -- The chief fiscal officer of the bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad testified today that the line could operate "indefinitely" under a proposed reorganization plan.

IN coming months, more and more foreign women visitors to the United States may find themselves in an average American home, eating bacon and scrambled eggs and discovering to their surprise that the home is not the pushbutton wonder it is reported to be.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- President Kennedy has taken up where President Dwight D. Eisenhower left off with the difficult business of trying to collect more money from the users of Government services. The Administration is studying at least a half-dozen lines of Government activity on which user charges might be established or increased.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- William C. Foster, former high defense and foreign aid official in the Truman Administration, is expected to become head of an enlarged disarmament agency to be proposed shortly by President Kennedy.
AN eloquent and remarkable documentary, "The Dedicated American -- The Story of Dr. Gordon Seagrave," was televised last night on the "Armstrong Circle Theatre" on Channel 2.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The White House said today that the Government was near an agreement with the Publicker Chemical Corporation to stop importing molasses from Premier Fidel Castro's Cuba.
Representative Jack Westland, Republican of Everett, Wash., was named captain of the Walker Cup team by the United States Golf Association yesterday.
BONN, Germany, June 21 -- Chancellor Adenauer has decided to pay a two-day visit to West Berlin starting July 12, the West German Government today.

The Federal Maritime Board's power to grant antitrust immunity in the proposed merger of the American Export Lines and the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company has been challenged by the Prudential Steamship Corporation.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 21 -- More and better residential facilities in downtown areas were held essential today if business districts were to be improved.
On a side street just off Broadway, and one flight up, is a window bearing what must be New York's most contemptible sign. "Time Clocks Repaired," it says, and "Satisfaction Guaranteed."

OTTAWA, June 21 -- The Government's decision to depress the value of the Canadian dollar in foreign exchange was welcomed by exporters and viewed with some concern by consumers. As it will increase the cost of imports it is expected to increase the cost of living correspondingly.

With word yesterday that judo would be an Olympic sport in the XVII Olympiad at Tokyo in October, 1964, sixteen divisional chairmen of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States made plans to grapple with the International Judo Federation over the conduct of the sport.

The nation-wide membership in Blue Cross increased in 1960 by more than 1,000,000 persons to a new peak of 56,063,215, the Blue Cross Association said in its annual report. The Association is the national coordinating organization for the seventy-nine regional Blue Cross non-profit hospitalization insurance plans in the United States.

The public school aid bill is being held for ransom by the House Rules Committee. The payment required, before this measure is to be considered for clearance, is an amendment to the National Defense Education Act that specifies low-interest long-term Federal loans to nonpublic and parochial schools.
SALVATORE ANTHONY BONTEMPO, New Jersey's Commissioner of Conservation and Economic Development, is described by associates as 'immensely energetic and tremendously popular.

The Glidden Company, paint, food and chemical producer, increased sales in the nine months ended May 31 to $148,393,233 from $145,874,617 in the 1960 period. Earnings fell, however, according to Dwight P. Joyce, chairman and president.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Senate gave final approval today to the Administration's program for attracting more foreign visitors to the United States. President Kennedy is expected to sign the measure promptly.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) -- Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, charged today that Gordon M. Tiffany had resigned as staff director of the Civil Rights Commission under pressure of a Congressional investigation.
A 27-year-old superintendent of an upper West Side building shot and critically wounded yesterday one of a gang of boys who had been annoying him.
Jesse Freidin, special labor counsel to the Board of Education, has submitted his resignation.
The establishment of corporate objectives based on planning in depth is essential to effective use of capital, John V. James, controller of Dresser Industries, Dallas, said yesterday.

SEVERAL months ago a label company in California conducted a survey to determine the influence of men on the nation's shopping. The company distributed 28,000 questionnaires to wives in forty-eight states with the query "Does your husband cook?"
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., June 21 -- This was a big day or the cause of conversion in Texas.

Dealers in commercial paper have reduced by one-eighth percentage point the rates on short-term unsecured obligations of leading industrial concerns sold in the open market. The reduction erases an increase of the same size that went into effect on June 5.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., June 21 (AP) -- Jack Nicklaus of Ohio State rallied and won twice today in the first match play session of the National Collegiate golf tournament.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 21 -- Following are brief biographical sketches of the members of the review board on reorganization of the United Nations, which issued its report today:
The State Investigation Commission was told yesterday that because of defective locks and warped doors some children and teachers had been trapped in classrooms of new schools.
A FEW steps away from a bustling East Side street, one New York family dines by lamplight in an Old World atmosphere.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., June 21 (AP) -- City Manager Joseph McD. Mitchell said today that the city would go to court if necessary to uphold its stringent new welfare regulations.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 21 -- Reindeer, the only sloop-rigged member of the Block Island-40 persuasion of fiber-glass yachts, became the main winner in the Annapolis-to-Newport race today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 21 -- The executive shake-up at Twentieth Century-Fox from Hollywood to Europe has focused attention on weaknesses that exist not only at Fox, but throughout the movie industry.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) -- The National Science Foundation today revoked a $3,800 fellowship awarded to a graduate student at the University of Illinois who was convicted of contempt of Congress for refusing to say whether he was a Communist.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- The grain futures market reversed an early upward trend today and finished generally weak with numerous contracts near their lows of the day.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The special dividend on veterans' life insurance policies is now scheduled for complete payment next month, in half the time that was originally estimated.

LONDON, June 21 -- A regrouping of Western forces in West Germany has been discussed by the Allies as a means of impressing the Soviet Union with the seriousness of their determination to defend West Berlin, qualified sources said today.

Real estate assessments here will be increased by $1,149,690,450 the City Tax Commission said yesterday. But the indications were that the basic tax rate would drop from $4.12 to $4.10 on each $100 of assessed valuation.
FREEPORT, Tex., June 21 (UPI) -- President Kennedy flipped a switch in the White House today and a two-and-a-half inch stream of fresh water spouted from the sea at Freeport.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 21 -- The oak tree that is said to have inspired Joyce Kilmer's famous poem "Trees" is losing the battle with age and has gone into decline.
Two faint, cloud-like objects have been seen circling the earth a moon's distance away, according to a Polish astronomer who reports having photographed them four times on two different occasions.
GOING from California to Italy to start designing for sale in America may seem a roundabout way to start a career, but it looks as if it may pay off for a man who designs under the name of Pavone.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 22 -- Moise Tshombe, President of secessionist Katanga Province, was released from political detention today. He promised to cooperate with the Central Government, which had held him captive for nearly two months.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- Senator A. Willis Robertson, Democrat of Virginia, said today there was no legal basis for granting a $12,500,000 loan to the New Haven Railroad from Defense Production Act funds.
Sharp declines in sales and earnings were reported yesterday by the Dana Corporation and its subsidiaries for the nine months ended on May 31.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 22 (UPI) -- Arnold Palmer, Doug Sanders and Frank Stranahan head a field of sixteenAmericans in the British Open golf championship starting July 10, the official draw disclosed today.
CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Fewer than 10 per cent of the automobile dealers in the metropolitan area attended a meeting yesterday called to adopt a code of ethics for their industry.
CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- The police are ready to take action against 220,000 motorists who have ignored nearly 1,000,000 traffic tickets since Jan 1, 1959.

The board of directors of the General Dynamics Corporation decided yesterday to omit the dividend on the common stock for the three months ending on Aug. 10. The company has paid 25 cents a share in each quarter since November, 1960.

TENAFLY, N.J., June 22 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Forest Hill Field Club increased her lead to three strokes today in the second round of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's 54-hole medal-play championship.

A contemporary history of Laos by Sisouk Na Champassak, Laotian Ambassador to the United Nations, will be published July 27 by Praeger. It will be called "Storm Over Laos." The author gives an account of events since 1945, traces the development of the country's political parties and presents such personalities as Prince Boun Oum, Prince Souvanna Phouma, Prince Souphanouvong and Capt. Kong Le.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 23 -- Naute Mia, owned by Mrs. Robert Schmid of New York, gained his first leg on the Greenwich, Ox Ridge and Fairfield Trophy for working hunters at the Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show today.
BERLIN, June 22 -- Today's exercise was the third Operational Readiness training the U.S. Army has undertaken in West Berlin in the last six months. The other tests were held in December and March.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- A House Agriculture subcommittee studying the farm cost-price squeeze concluded today that all the farmer needed was more money. But it said that there was not much hope he would get it.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- Federal Aviation Administrator Najeeb E. Halaby notified airline pilots today that he had decided to continue his predecessor's rule requiring them to retire at age 60.

The merger of the California Oregon Power Company into the Pacific Power and Light !Company went into effect on Wednesday, the surviving com:pany announced yesterday. It had been under review for six months.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 22 -- The Annapolis - to - Newport yacht race was wrapped up today with all the contestants across the finish line and in possession of such silverware as they had managed to acquire.
City Republican leaders professed yesterday to welcome Mayor Wagner's decision to seek re-election, declaring it would simplify the decision the voters must make on Nov. 7.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- President Kennedy and Premier Hayato Ikeda of Japan announced today their intention to "strengthen the partnership" between their countries.

IT will be quite a springboard. It will catapult some forty young men from New York to Moscow with all expenses paid. This athletic launching gadget is the national track and field championships of the Amateur Athletic Union and it will be put into formal operation at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island tomorrow and the next day.
LONDON, June 22 -- The British Government is fully prepared to rouse public opinion to meet any tense, difficult and possibly desperate situation that may arise out of new Soviet pressures on Berlin.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday he would run for re-election provided he had Democratic running mates in whom he had the fullest confidence.

The Wembley Farm's Outgiving had little difficulty in taking the feature race, the Montauk Club Purse, at Belmont Park yesterday. Manuel Ycaza moved the 5-year-old son of Better Self into the lead the start of the seven-furlong race and kept him there all the way.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 22 -- The United States expects an "overwhelming majority" of countries to insist that the United Nations continue to the administered by an impartial, international civil servant.
The shipowners and the feuding unions in the maritime industry should lose no time in accepting Secretary of Labor Goldberg's proposal for a fact-finding commission to end the crippling ship strike.
LONDON, June 22 -- The British Overseas Airways Corporation, a nationalized airline, lost today its right to the Britain's only carrier on the rich North Atlantic route to the United States.
After a series of meetings in Zurich the heads of the three principal political groups in Laos have expressed agreement on a program and a policy for a government of national union.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 22 -- A leading United States foreign aid official in Taiwan said today that the Chinese Nationalist Government was spending too much money on itself, particularly on its armed forces.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Officials of the Labor, Justice and State Departments conferred today over an expected lifting of border passes of some 13,000 Mexicans who commute daily to jobs in Laredo and El Paso, Tex.
The Staten Island Savings Bank, a $100,000,000 institution doing business ninety-seven years, will open a new temporary branch office tomorrow -- in a diner.
AMES, Iowa, June 22 (AP) -- Southern California took the lead from the defender, the University of California at Los Angeles, in the National Collegiate tennis championships today.
Frontier problems where racial minorities spill over from one country to another are among the most stubborn and least soluble of all international quarrels.
MONTREAL, June 22 (UPI) -- Bob Cleroux of Montreal scored a seventh-round technical knockout over Alex Miteff of Argentina tonight in their scheduled ten-round heavyweight bout at the Forum.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Senate and House conferees agreed today to extend for two years a bonus to states that regulate billboards along the Interstate Highway System.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 22 -- Today Irving Wallace was very much the man who had returned to the small town after making good in the big city. For Mr. Wallace, who quit movie writing some time ago, was at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to sign a contract that would pay him a minimum of $250,000 for the movie rights to his latest novel, "The Prize."

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that a United States marine guard was wounded in an incident June 10 by an Argentine civilian. Mr. Rusk said there was no evidence linking the incident to the Argentine visit of Adlai E. Stevenson on June 7.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- President Kennedy's program for a $741,000,000 annual increase in postal rates appeared to have been killed by the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee today.

RYE, N.Y., June 22 -- The former United States and British amateur champion, Dick Chapman, shot the low gross of 38, 37 -- 75 over the Apawamis Club course today and helped Williams regain team honors in the twenty-sixth College Clubs Golf League tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- R. Sargent Shriver, director of the Peace Corps, proclaimed today an across-the-board policy against extending any aid by his organization to countries that practice racial and religious discrimination.

Forty thousand street lights equipped with photoelectric cells went on here automatically yesterday afternoon as thick, grayish-yellow clouds darkened the city. Earlier in the day the low ceiling closed New York International Air port and rain flooded several streets and impeded service for twenty-five minutes on the BMT's Fourteenth Street Canarsie line in Brooklyn.
Regulatory steps have been taken to alleviate the jet noise problem around New York International Airport at Idlewild, especially in communities just northeast of the Queens airfield.
What with television scouring the globe for new faces for viewers to look at next season, Ed Sullivan is going about as far as he can go -- Teheran in midsummer.
A vacancy rate of 5.4 per cent, the highest since 1951, has been reported by the Government in rental apartments financed with mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration.
Two one-act plays by William Saroyan that lasted eight performances on Broadway in 1942 are planned for a revival Off Broadway in October.

BERLIN, June 22 (AP) -- United States troops staged a suprise combat exercise in West Berlin today and Russian soldiers marched to the Soviet War Memorial in the British sector. These activities underscored the mounting "cold war" tensions in this divided city.
CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- An improved demand in the last hour or so of dealings injected a firm balance today in the grain futures market on the Board of Trade.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange fell yesterday to the smallest figure since Jan. 3 and prices declined moderately.
CINCINNATI, June 22 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds stretched their National League lead to two games tonight as Frank Robinson led them to a 7-5 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

A Manhattan artist has rented the window of a Chinese hand laundry on Lexington Avenue as a showcase for his work. If the venture is profitable, he may soon be displaying paintings in the windows of Chinese laundries in all the better parts of town.
ST. LOUIS, June 22 (AP) -- Carl J. Pursey, a St. Louis attorney who helped Buffalo residents get divorces here, pleaded guilty of criminal contempt today in an unexpected move.
The Oscar B. Hunter Memorial Award of the American Therapeutic Society will be presented this afternoon to Dr. Hattie E. Alexander for her contributions to therapy.
I should like to offer a few comments regarding your report of June 11, "Wages Here Rank Lowest in Study of Eighteen Cities in United States."

TOKYO, June 22 -- From the look and sound of things tonight, fifty-six young Americans in white jackets will be having a most pleasant time in Japan the next three weeks -- and so will tens of thousands of Japanese who will come to hear them sing.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board gave qualified permission today to Trans Caribbean Airways and its controlling stockholder, O. Roy Chalk, to attempt to buy control of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines in New York City.

The United States Government filed suit in Federal Court yesterday to recover $352,000 from the Royal Bank of Canada. It contended that the bank negligently failed to cancel a transfer of the funds to a bank in Cuba afer Cuba had nationalibed a United States owned business.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Dean Rusk's statement on the Berlin crisis read at the start of his news conference today:

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- Rocky Colavito hit his eighteenth homer and then doubled during a seventh-inning rally that carried the first-place Detroit Tigers to a 6-4 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.
CAIRO, June 22 (Reuters) -- The United Arab Republic's National Assembly approved early today a Government bill suspending the cotton futures market of Alexandria until further notice.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 22 -- Mrs. Allan A. Ryan of The Creek won the Women's Long Island Golf Association's 54-hole medal-play championship at the Meadow Brook Country Club today.

LOS ANGELES, June 22 (AP) -- Chuck Schilling's fourth-inning single -- one of only five hits in the entire game -- brought in the deciding run tonight as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Los Angeles Angels, 3 -- 2.
Mayor Wagner has asked Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, to investigate complaints that anti-Catholic bias existed at Queens College.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., June 22 (AP) -- Jack Nicklaus of Ohio State gained the semi-final round of the sixty-fourth National Collegiate golf tournament today at the Purdue University course.
Fourteen-year-old Michael Balon Jr. held open house in his hospital room here yesterday for the neighbors who had helped to pay for his operation.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- President Kennedy set up today a task force of Cabinet level to review and advise him on relations between the Government and groups representing Federal employes.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Plans for a nation-wide program to help states solve their court problems were set forth today by the American Bar Association.
A plan to maintain health insurance policies in full force during periods of unemployment was put forward here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Government will permit sales of subsidized farm products, including cotton textiles, to the Soviet Union and its European bloc, providing they pay in dollars or in currencies convertible into dollars.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 22 -- United States leaders were urged today to demand that Portugal cease repressive measures in Portuguese Angola or be expelled from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Two groups are seeking the requisite legal identity to enable them to condluct public appeals to save all or part of the present Metropolitan Opera House from demolition.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A $375,000,000 program of Federal construction loans for parochial and other private schools was approved today by a Senate Labor and Public Welfare subcommittee.
ALBANY, June 22 (UPI) -- The State Department of Social Welfare declared today that half of Newburgh's drastic new welfare code violated state and Federal law.
A transmission line carrying the highest voltage of any in the world was energized yesterday at Apple Grove, Va.
Dr. Robert Soblen was pictured in Federal Court yesterday as a troublesome spy who "despised" his employers -- the Russians -- for their low rate of pay.

An investment team has signed a contract to purchase the St. Moritz Hotel, it was learned yesterday. The team consists of Lawrence A. Wien, senior partner of the law firm of Wien, Lane Klein, and Harry B. Helmsley, president of Helmsley Spear, Inc., real estate concern.
EAST MEADOW, L. I., June 22 -- With the help of thirty-three men and one woman an eight-pound girl was born in a home here today.

PALERMO, Italy, June 22 -- The regional Parliament of the semi-autonomous island of Sicily elected a Socialist President tonight, but he asked for twenty-four hours before deciding whether to take the job.

Texas offered $25,000,000 of veterans' land bonds for sale yesterday. A syndicate managed by major commercial banks and bond houses of New York and Chicago submitted the only bid, a price of 100 for 3 1/2 per cent obligations due serially from 1966 to 1991.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 7 per cent above sales in the 1960 week.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 22 -New Jersey will resume its annual spraying of DDT from aircraft this weekend to combat mosquitos in its shore counties.
Television's rating systems for measuring program popularity were described as "phony" and "appalling" in testimony before a Federal Communications Commission inquiry here yesterday.

The unions on strike are the National Maritime Union, 37,000 members; the Seafarers International Union, Atlantic, Gulf and Lakes section, 22,600; the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, 11,000; the Masters, Mates and Pilots, 11,000, and the American Radio Association.
GENEVA, June 22 -- The three Princes who head the rival factions in Laos announced today in Zurich their intention to form a national union government.

SEOUL, Korea, June 22 -- The South Korean junta announced today a revised supplementary budget for the National Government. It is aimed at raising the salaries of Government employes and easing unemployment.
CHICAGO, June 22 (UPI) -- The Chicago Cubs opened an extra-base-hit barrage today and defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 7 -- 5, salvaging the finale of a four-game series.

An Appellate Division ruling yesterday upheld the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad in its long-standing contention that it had an equal voice with the New York Central Railroad in the control, maintenance and leasing of the Biltmore Hotel.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Senate passed a water pollution control bill today authorizing $440,000,000 in grants to the states to help build sewage plants.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested a 29-year-old actor and model yesterday and recovered stolen art works valued at $200,000, including a Degas pastel. The actor, who has appeared in off-Broadway productions and summer stock, is Jimmie C. White of 269 Greene Street. He has been appearing in "Fanny" with the Lambertville Music Circus in Lambertville, N.J.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- To search for an alternative by which war could be averted, without sacrificing the honor or the treaty obligations of the United States, is the highest duty of statesmanship. When the threat from a status quo to which such an alternative might be found is nuclear war, the obligation of government is even more demanding.

" The time for talking has ended. The time for doing has arrived." Those were the words of Albert Deutsch in a ringing call to action at the recent annual meeting of the President's Committee on Employment of the Physically Handicapped in Washington.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- William S. Ginn, former vice president and general manager of the General Electric Company's turbine division, today was named president of the Baldwin-Lima-Hamilton Corporation.

The Central Conference of American Rabbis denounced the John Birch Society yesterday for repeating "some of the worst evils of McCarthyism." At the same time the group called for the abolition of the House Un-American Activities Committee and condemned the committee's film, "Operation Abolition."
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A mixed loadings pattern was reported today by both the rail and truck industries.
CHICAGO, June 22 -- The once-glittering Auditorium Theatre was filled today with the sound of concert music for the first time in twenty years.

Two $4,000 prizes for drama criticism will go to Harold Clurman, drama critic and stage director, and C.L. Barber, Professor of English at Amherst College. The first two winners in the series of George Jean Nathan Awards were announced yesterday by Prof. William R. Keast, chairman of the English Department at Cornell University.

The pleasant-looking young man knocked gently on the door of a second-floor apartment on East Eighty-fourth Street. He was wearing a dark brown suit and a conservative tie and he was carrying a Bible.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 22 (UPI) -- Gus Triandos drove in five runs on three hits today to lead the Baltimore Orioles to an 8-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins before a crowd of 14,479.

The idea of a Peace Corps when first announced was a truly extraordinary and imaginative one. Here would be a brilliant way of utilizing the humanitarian ideals that have been characteristic of our country for the total good of mankind. But already the human element enters the picture.
Following is the text of a statement issued by Mayor Wagner at a press conference at City Hall yesterday afternoon and excerpts from the question-and-answer period afterward:
The Greek Ministry of Mercantile Marine announced yesterday the Greek Government had "categorically turned down" all requests to register foreign-controlled ships under its flag.

PARIS, June 22 -- Two Breton farmers were acquitted today of having been the leaders in an outbreak of violence at Morlaix June 8. They became heromartyrs of farm discontent in France after the Morlaix incident, the first in a series of demonstrations.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 22 -- A conservative was elected tonight to head the College Service Committee of the Young Republican National Federation.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Following are the texts of a joint communique issued by President Kennedy and Premier Hayato Ikeda of Japan and an exchange of notes between Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Zentaro Kosaka, the Japanese Foreign Minister:
Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg last night proposed a three-man citizens' panel to work out a solution to the week-old seamen's strike.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 22 -- A Czechoslovak diplomat accused of espionage by the United States flew home tonight.

Businesses borrowed $256,000,000 from the fifteen weekly reporting Federal Reserve member banks in New York in the two weeks surrounding the June 15 quarterly corporate tax payment date, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with $285,000,000 in the comparable period a year before.

The March, April and May potato options climbed to new highs for the lives of the contracts, and the November and January futures equaled their old highs yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Continued heavy rains along the East Coast, which may damage seeds, firmed the market.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 22 -- The 4-year-olds, an age group more or less neglected in harness racing, take the front and center stage tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway. Too old for the big-money stakes and too young for the traditional events, they get a shot at a $50,000 purse in the Harness Tracks of America Pace Final.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk expressed the concern of the United States today over the "militant tone" of Soviet leaders on Berlin.

A Kings County Rackets grand jury was convened hurriedly yesterday to investigate reports of a crime link between members of the Police Department and a gang of thieves operating in Brooklyn and Queens.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -- The Northern California Pharmaceutical Association was fined $40,000 by Federal Judge Louis E. Goodman today for conspiring to fix prescription-drug prices in violation of antitrust laws. Judge Goodman also imposed a $1,000 fine on Donald K. Hedgpeth, a San Francisco druggist.

THE strawberries some New Yorkers will have for dessert today may have been picked yesterday morning on the Herbert Smith farm in Riverhead. If so, the berries had to pass the critical inspection of Mrs. Shirley Smith, the attractive young farmer's wife.
EN ROUTE from a meeting in New York to a meeting in Washington, Dr. Arthur H. Compton of St. Louis had time for a little conversation.

Mayor Wagner will seek a third term at City Hall. His announcement sets at rest long uncertainty compounded of health, family and political considerations. It means that the contest is now Wagner Ticket vs. Lefkowitz Ticket -- a contest on which we reserve judgment at this time, pending campaign developments.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A Professor of Law and Government denounced the John Birch Society today as "the least useful organization to appear on the American political scene in the last hundred years."
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Vice Admiral George W. Anderson Jr., 54-year-old commander of the Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean, was named by President Kennedy today to be Chief of Naval Operations.
An extensive revision of speed regulations on the city's parkways and expressways is expected as a result of a radar study that will be undertaken soon by three agencies.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Spokesmen for large and small cities urged Congress today to centralize the Government's urban programs in one Cabinet-level department.

LONDON, June 22 (UPI) -- Chuck McKinley of St. Louis and Nancy Richey of Houston rallied in their final sets today to reach the semi-finals of the London grass-court tennis championships at the Queen's Club.
PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP) -- Smoky Burgess hit two home runs in succession tonight to account for four of the Pittsburgh Pirates' runs in a 5-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A respiratory infection disabled President Kennedy today. His physicians diagnosed the ailment as a one or two-day virus attack. The President, aided by heavy doses of antibiotics, appeared to have overcome the infection in less than twenty-four hours. Awakened by a sore throat and fever, Mr. Kennedy called his physician, Dr. Janet Travell, at 1:30 A.M.
MILWAUKEE, June 22 (UPI) -- Frank Thomas hit his eleventh and twelfth home runs of the season tonight as the Milwaukee Braves defeated the San Francisco Giants, 8 -- 6.
LONDON, June 22 -- Prices drifted downward on the stock market today in a quiet session.
MOSCOW, June 22 -- A United States corporation reported today that it had made encouraging progress in negotiations with the Soviet Union for the sale and exchange of patent rights.

Mayor Wagner failed to sell the Big Three among New York City Democratic leaders yesterday on his proposed city ticket. The slate would have Abe Stark running with him for Controller and Paul R. Screvane for City Council President.
LONDON, June 22, -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Selwyn Lloyd, in a somber review of Britain's economy, said today that the Government must reduce its expenditure at home and abroad.
The Monmouth Turf Charity Ball and Carnival will be held at the clubhouse of the Monmouth Park Race Track in Oceanport, N.J., on July 29.

Proposals by the state's Moore commission for revising the city's Charter would drastically reduce the powers of the Controller -- the job to which Mayor Wagner proposes to shift Council President Abe Stark.
The most notable marketing development in the world of Scotch whisky is the matter of lightness.

Fully recovered from the leg soreness that followed his double victory in the National Collegiate championships, Frank Budd is all set to go full blast in pursuit of a sweep that, over the years, only two sprinters have been able to accomplish.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The United States plans to continue the talks in Geneva on a prohibition of nuclear weapons tests despite the "uncooperative attitude" of the Soviet Union, Secretary of State Dean Rusk said at a new conference today.
Rushing to patch some of the rents and tears in the city's school plant, the Board of Estimate voted $245,500 for fire-prevention improvements to seventeen schools yesterday.

DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, June 22 (AP) -- The Organization of Oil Exporting Countries (O.P.E.C.) is planning a drive to obtain more royalties from Western oil companies operating in the Middle East.

The United States monetary gold stock rose $50,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. It was the third weekly increase in a row and the largest since the week ended on Feb. 20, 1957, when there was a rise of $51,000,000.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Following is the vote by which the House of Representatives defeated today a Republican-backed substitute for the Administration multi-billion-dollar housing bill:

Textron, Inc., announced yesterday that it had invited the tender of shares of Textron common stock at $28 a share. Of the stock purchased, up to 744,060 shares, at a cost of $20,832,000, will be used by Textron for the proposed acquisition of Spencer Kellogg Sons, Inc., Buffalo, N.Y.
BOSTON, June 22 -- The Boston Globe, in an editorial today, endorsed as "instructive and valuable" a series of New York Times articles on corruption in the Massachusetts government.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- Senate antitrust investigators turned to the electrical motor industry today. They heard testimony that private talks by competitors in the field had sometimes been followed by price increases.
The State Investigation Commission charged yesterday that city school employes had accepted gratuities from contractors on cue from higher-ups in their department.

Production of lumber totaled 240,668,000 board feet in the week ended last Saturday, compared with 229,336,000 board feet the week before and 249,942,000 board feet a year earlier, according to reports from the regional associations.
ROME, June 22 -- Mario Scelba, Minister of the Interior, told the Chamber of Deputies today that prompt intervention by the police and army had re-established order in Alto Adige.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 22 (UPI) -- Ten white and Negro clergymen were convicted of unlawful assembly tonight for demanding service in a restaurant at the city's airport that is used only by whites.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- Government auditors disclosed today deficiencies in the multimillion-dollar program of Federal aid to airports in the Northeast. The deficiencies included $6,000 to pay for an unauthorized lawn sprinkler system at one airport.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The United States' propaganda organ is angry with the Republican party's propaganda organ.
The Freedom Riders have revealed "that the real agitators are the states involved," Ralph McGill, publisher of The Atlanta Constitution, declared here last night.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 22 -- Hope that the physical upgrading of downtown business districts will reverse the rising trend of vacancies in office buildings was expressed today as the National Association of Building Owners and Managers ended its annual convention.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 22 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer and Al Geiberger led a mass assault on par today as both carded 65's six under par in the opening round of the Western open golf tournament.

CLEVELAND, June 22 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People started picketing the Cleveland Trust Company yesterday. It plans to continue the action indefinitely.
STRATFORD, Ont., June 22 -- A jewel of a "Love's Labour's Lost" was introduced last night at the Festival Theatre to cast a cheerful sparkle on this season's Shakespearean trinity.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- A Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad attorney charged today that the New York Central Railroad was engaging in "a plain case of delaying tactics" on the rival bids of the C. and New York Central for control of the Baltimore and Ohio system.
U.S. Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that ot had developed what was termed the first general-purpose automation machine available to manufacturers as standard "off-the-shelf" hardware.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- President Kennedy today signed a $12,500,000,000 authorization for procurement of planes, missiles and ships. It includes authority for buying new bombers that the President is not expected to use.
WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Following are excerpts from a news conference today with Dr. Janet Travell, President Kennedy's physician:
PURCHASE, N.Y., June 22 -- Two teams tied for the lead today in the second annual Grace Herbert Memorial golf tournament at Old Oaks.

In a neutral corner of his birch-paneled office in Harlem yesterday, the 40-year-old president of Sugar Ray Robinson Enterprises talked hopefully of another chance to win the world middleweight boxing title. He weighed 161, a pound over the class limit.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 22 -- The story of Otto Klemperer is well known, but one has to see him at work to appreciate the triumph of indomitable will over the frailties of the body.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) -- Given a chance, Pennsylvania Republican leaders with sound out former President Dwight D. Eisenhower the Monday night on whether he would be interested in running the United States Senate in 1962.

In the light of experience as a non-Communist expert witness in several of the Smith Act trials may I comment on the letter of Congressman Francis A. Walter in your issue of June 14. He challenges the statement in your informed and excellent editorial of June 7 that "only speech is involved in Smith Act prosecutions."

MOBILE, Ala., June 22 (AP) -- Maurice Olen, former head of a New York chain of more than 400 variety stores, was fined $2,500 in United States District Court yesterday on his plea of no contest to a charge of violating securtieis regulations.
A rush-hour patrol of portions of four expressways by private tow trucks has been undertaken by the Department of Traffic.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 22 -- The eighteen-day mission of Adlai E. Stevenson to South America has left in motion, with United States blessings, the most important diplomatic initiative to emerge in Latin America for collective action on the dangers posed by Communist control of Cuba.
The extension of a $60,000,000 credit to India for highway development was announced in Washington Wednesday by the International Development Association.
Business and political leaders concerned with the new effort to spur Latin-American economic progress were urged yesterday to see their goal "with the same fanaticism as the Communists do."
CANTALOUPE for Sunday brunch or, filled with ice cream, for dessert at some meal during the week-end is one of the fresh foods that deserve a place on today's shopping list.
Record check clearings of $33,258,944,000 in the twenty-six leading cities of the nation were reported yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., for the week ended on Wednesday.

A smoky fire that broke out early yesterday morning aboard the new British freighter Sidonia caused injury to one member of the crew and damage to the crew quarters. The 472-foot vessel was berthed at Pier 51, at Jane Street and the Hudson River.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Adlai E. Stevenson returned here from South America tonight to report to President Kennedy and help the Administration reshape its LatinAmerican policies. The President sent Mr. Stevenson to ten South American countries to gather facts and impressions and to counter uneasiness over United States intentions following the unsuccessful attempt to invade Cuba in mid-April.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Daily index numbers and spot primary market commodity prices June 13 to 20, 1961:
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Administration officials are divided on proposals for stiffer taxation of savings and loan associations and mutual savings banks.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- The Federal Aviation Agency will make public reports it receives about equipment failures on commercial airlines if the information will prevent accidents.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- An international center for the more than 1,200 symphony orchestras in this country and Canada will be established by the American Symphony Orchestra League on forty acres of woodlands in Fairfax County Va., twenty miles from Washington.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 22 -- Adolf Eichmann said at his trial today that he had been the chief architect of wartime plan to deport European Jews to Madagascar. But he said his dream of a "nonEuthopian" Jewish state had been shattered by his Nazi superiors.
The bond market turned in a defensive trading session yesterday, with most of the action taking place in over-the-counter dealings in investment-grade corporate obligations.
ALBANY, June 22 -- New limits on the amounts that college students may borrow under the state-guaranteed loan program were announced today by the New York Higher Education Assistance Corporation.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Edward R. Murrow urged Congress today to provide the United States Information Agency with adequate appropriations to meet the new requirements of the "cold war."

HARD work and ambition have taken him from truck driver in Sanitation Department to Deputy Mayor and Mayor Wagner's choice for President of City Council. . . . Sanitation Commissioner from 1957 until last March.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the "full amount" of President Kennedy's $26,000,000,000 foreign aid program for the next five years was essential to the survival of this nation and the free world.

DETROIT, June 22 -- The Tractors for Freedom Committee is prepared to abandon is efforts to exchange tractors for prisoners seized in the April invasion of Cuba unless Premier Fidel Castro accepts the group's terms by noon tomorrow.

ACCRA, Ghana, June 22 -- South-West African nationalist leaders in exile warned a United Nations committee here today that, if the United Nations did not find a solution for their territory's problem of self-rule quickly, there might be bloodshed.
Five men were honored yesterday by the Greater New York Councils of the Boys Scouts of America for outstanding service to scouting.
THERE were many variations to the theme, but the burden of much of the advice Robert Ferdinand Wagner received from his father was this: "Think things through and never make a snap judgment."
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The House passed tonight the Administration-backed $4,900,000,000 housing bill without a major change, frustrating repeated Republican efforts to cut it.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 22 -- An 18-year-old boy has built a cyclotron though many physicists believed such a project was beyond the intellectual capacity of a high school student.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Senate passage today sent to President Kennedy the bill extending present tax rates on corporation income and major excise tax rates to preserve $3,700,000,000 of annual revenue.

The Bell Howell Company has acquired a 49 per cent ownership in Japan Cine Equipment Manufacturing Company, Ltd., wholly owned subsidiary of J. Osawa Co., Ltd., Tokyo, it was announced yesterday by Everett F. Wagner, president of Bell Howell's international division.
DEAUVILLE, France, June 22 (UPI) -- Henry Timbrook of Beverly Hills, Calif., was one of six Americans to advance today to the second round of the French amateur golf championship.
The wholesale commodity price index stood at 83.1 on Wednesday unchanged from Tuesday's level. The index figure, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, was 85.5 on June 15, 1960.

Some predicted-log cruiser contests are held within the confines of nice, smooth, protected waters. On the other hand, there are skippers who aver they like to navigate offshore where the wind, waves and weather can be rough and rugged.

A suit has been filed in Federal court to void the election of Edward R. Dudley as Borough President of Manhattan. It accuses Mayor Wagner and four City Councilmen of discrimination, on the ground that at no time was any candidate other than a Negro considered to replace Hulan Jack, also a Negro.
The leader of the Zionist Organization of America said last night that the movement faced problems that must be solved immediately if it was to function successfully in this country.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 22 (UPI) -- Two New York State residents and a Texan are the winners of the eighteenth annual Bausch and Lomb science scholarships, the company said today.

Northern Illinois Gas Company is offering to holders of its common shares subscription rights to 450,037 additional shares at the rate of one new share for each sixteen shares held of record of June 22. The stock is priced at $49.50 a share. The offering, which will expire on July 11, 1961, is being underwritten by a group managed by The First Boston Corporation and Glore, Forgan Co.
AFTER seeing last night's "Close-Up!" on Channel 7, one can only conclude that the United States ought to allot a little foreign aid to our Foreign Service officers abroad.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $29,000,000 to $42,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements declined $36,000,000 to $592,000,000.

Sir Eugene Goossens, the English conductor, will make his first American appearances in five years during this summer's Empire State Music Festival. He will conduct two concerts at the festival, the first on Saturday, July 22.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 7 points up to 6 points down yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

MARSHALL MILES of San Bernardino, Calif., who was not yet 30 years old when he made an international reputation by writing the standard book on tactics in duplicate and tournament bridge, cited the deal shown as an example of the highest-level defense.
LONDON, June 22 -- Lord Carrington, First Lord of the Admiralty, offered in vain to resign after the Admiralty had been criticized for security lapses by a committee reporting on a recent spy case.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Soviet diplomacy, like Soviet ballet and opera, is technically perfect, but unoriginal and predictable. It moves from one extreme to the other, from Swan Lake to Boris Godunov, very quickly. Thus, just a few days ago, we saw Sweet Nikita in Vienna, cooing peace, and now we have Naughty Nik in full-dress uniform, spouting fire.
The West German Government yesterday pledged $2,500,000 to the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. The gift was designated for the new Metropolitan Opera House.

BEVERLY VALDES, a 23-year-old Negro mannequin, has gone to work for Pauline Trigere. Miss Valdes is believed to be the first Negro to be hired as a house model for a high-fashion Seventh Avenue designer.

Two thousand persons cruised up the Hudson River yesterday for the annual excursion of the Institute of the Crippled and Disabled called a Day in the Sun. Most of the time they sailed through heavy fog, but they enjoyed a full program of dancing, guessing contests and talent shows.
KANSAS CITY, June 22 -- The Yankees tonight finished the business of polishing off Hank Bauer's hapless Athletics. Save for a slight disturbance near the end, it was virtually no contest.
Edward P. Larkin of Floral Park, L.I. Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, was appointed to the Public Service Commission yesterday by Governor Rockefeller.
Individual body cells do not appear to age as much as do organs and organ systems in the body, it was reported here yesterday to the American Geriatrics Society.
Pakistan International lines, the newest trans-Atlantic carrier, rejected yesterday any suggestion that small airlines could not compete successfully against large ones.

"THE SILVER PILGRIMAGE,"* an engaging novel of India by M. Anantanarayanan, is supposed to be set in a faraway medieval time. Its quaintnesses and curiosities, however, suggest that man lives in a perpetual age of fable.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 23 -- The United Nations Committee on Contributions recommended today new assessment scales that would slightly raise the dues of twenty-two countries and slightly reduce those of thirty-seven countries.
The fattest baby at the Bronx Zoo yesterday was a two-week-old pigmy hippopotamus.

EXCITING trips to Ecuador, Rome, Paris, Lebanon and England have filled much of Elizabeth Squire's life. It was while strolling the myriad streets of Gotham, however, that this sophisticated, globetrotting New Yorker received inspiration to write her first book.

CARSON CITY, Nev., June 23 (AP) -- Gov. Grant Sawyer, Attorney General Roger Foley and State Controller Keith Lee pleaded not guilty today to a criminal complaint charging them with violation of Nevada's open-meeting law.
Panama's politics will be viewed and analyzed on "Editor's Choice" over the American Broadcasting Company television network on July 2 at 10:30 P.M.

PARIS, June 23 -- President de Gaulle is making plans to settle the Algerian problem this summer by agreement with the rebels, if possible, and unilaterally if necessary, to be free to face an autumn Berlin crisis.

Additional power began to flow last week to consumers in the Pacific Northwest as the first generator on the $262,000,000 Rocky Reach hydroelectric project swung into action. When the huge facility near Wenatchee, Wash., is completed later this year, seven huge generators will feed 775,000 kilowatts into the system. All seven generators are expected to be operating by Nov. 1.
The Central Conference of American Rabbis yesterday unanimously approved the establishment of a Religious Action Center in Washington despite the protests of some Reform Jewish congregations.

Two long lines of men and women -- most of them in bathing suits, but some in street clothes -- padded barefooted across Orchard Beach and into Long Island Sound yesterday. In less than an hour 1,732 new Witnesses of Jehovah were within the fold.

Some time next week, the presidents of the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange will undergo stiff questioning by a Congressional subcommittee. Representative Peter Mack, Democrat of Illinois, heads the group, which starts hearings on Tuesday on legislation to authorize the Securities and Exchange Commission to undertake a $750,000 investigation of stock exchanges and the over-the-counter trading in securities.
The police put a guard yesterday over the home and family of Juan Torres at 140 West Ninety-fourth Street.

One hundred and sixty-eight employes of Kings County Court, including the judges, were startled to find yesterday that their bi-weekly city pay checks did not have the signature of Miss Hilda Schwartz, the City Treasurer.

Rarely have I seen two such brilliant analyses of the news as in the two parallel columns on the editorial page by Arthur Krock and James Reston in your issue of June 9. Mr. Krock's analysis of the misgivings one must feel about relaxing the control of Congress over the appropriations for foreign aid was masterly.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 23 -- The chairman of a special committee that has been trying to inspect Portugal's handling of Angola has been invited to visit Lisbon, alone and unofficially.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 23 -- Fireone, owned by Laughlin Place Farm of Niles, Mich., won his third blue ribbon at the thirty-eighth annual Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show today.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 23 -- Liquor dealers here expressed fear today that new state taxes, effective next Saturday, would cut heavily into their business.

PARIS, June 23 -- We do not yet know precisely why Khrushchev wants a crisis at the precise time he has chosen, next autumn. All we know is that he does. He took pains to stress this by appearing in general's uniform at a veterans' meeting to make his militant speech on Berlin.

LIVINGSTON, N.J., June 23 -- Township officials here have approved plans for a multimillion-dollar home office for the Foster Wheeler Corporation, engineering and construction concern with headquarters at 666 Fifth Avenue, New York.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., June 23 (UPI) -- Mr. Mitchell said today that the relief question was one of the economic and social future of the city and what powers the city had in shaping that future.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) -- Senator Estes Kefauver called on the Justice Department today to look into the possibility of antitrust prosecutions against makers of electric motors.
BERLIN, June 23 -- At a time of mounting Communist pressure on West Berlin, surrounding East Germany is heading toward a critical supply shortage.
The City Council yesterday set a basic real estate tax of $4.10 on each $100 of assessed valuation for the fiscal year starting next Saturday.
The National Labor Relations Board charged the International Ladies Garment Workers Union yesterday with unfair labor practices against a union of its own staff employes.
Father Knickerbocker will have a close-up view today and tomorrow of the most spectacular show track and field has to offer short of the Olympic Games.

SYRACUSE, June 23 (AP) -- The State Veterans of Foreign Wars contended today that the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission was failing to keep known Communists and other subversives from the New York docks.

Antonino Rocca and Vittorio Apollo of South America, the "favorites," lost to Buddy Rogers and Bob Orton in the feature wrestling exhibition last night before a crowd of 15,675 at Madison Square Garden.

The refusal of leaders of the striking ship unions to accept Secretary of Labor Goldberg's proposal for an impartial panel to recommend terms for settling all issues in the paralyzing maritime walkout is as foolish as it is irresponsible.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 23 -- The Del Miller Stable entry of Countess Adios and Dancer Hanover finished one, two in the $50,000 Harness Tracks of America Pace Final at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

A difference of opinion about the quality of television developed yesterday between Ed Sullivan, the TV showman and columnist, and Vincent Donehue, the director, in testimony before Federal investigators here.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee accused Pierre Salinger today of "hiding the truth" from reporters.
